The three main types of pain share some common characteristics that have been found in recent years in various chronic pain conditions. The concept of nociplastic pain refers to neuropathic pain due to persistent abnormalities in the pain processing system in the central nervous system. Chronic migraine and fibromyalgia are two of the conditions mainly classified as nociplastic, while vulvodynia has not been fully categorized yet. The study will evaluate the role of personality factors, defense mechanisms and history of traumatic events, the presence of central sensitization in the genesis of these pain conditions and the possible therapeutic implications in the treatment of these conditions.

<|assistant|>
This study aims to test the hypothesis that the pressure ulcer is a factor affected by cube/block system massage feature of beds that prevent pressure ulcers. A total of 36 patients will be included in the study. Group I will use a support surface with the massage feature and a viscoelastic pressure sore prevention mattress, while Group II will use a standard of care viscoelastic pressure sore prevention mattress with an orthopedic support surface. Patients will have their pressure ulcers risks assessed using the Braden scale, and the formation of pressure ulcers in patients will be prevented by using the massage feature of the mattresses. Patients will be followed up for four weeks. The study aims to reveal that pressure ulcer development is affected by the mattress massage feature and the cube/block system.

This study will examine the effects of the "Epic Quest" application, which creates digital interaction with the child, on the metabolic parameters of children with type 1 diabetes, as well as change their perceived quality of life and anthropometric measurement values. It is thought that with the use of digital interaction with the child, the exercise will be more continuous and enjoyable. The researchers plan to examine the effects of exercise with augmented reality glasses in order to reach the metabolic targets of children with type 1 diabetes and to increase their quality of life. It is predicted that a significant increase in perceived quality of life will be revealed as a result of the intervention.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of acupressure application on preoperative anxiety during abdominal surgery.
The hypothesis of the study: - There is a significant difference between the preoperative anxiety level in the groups in which acupressure will not be applied (no intervention group) and the preoperative anxiety level of the groups in which pre-opertive acupressure will be applied.(primary hypothesis).
- The level of preoperative anxiety in the group where the video will be watched with virtual reality will differ significantly from the level of anxiety in the group where the video will be watched without virtual reality, after the intervention(secondary hypothesis, sub-hypothesis)

Background: Abdominal wall wound closure remains a critical step in open abdominal procedures and its outcomes can significantly impact overall patient recovery. Currently, there is no standardized measurement or guidance for surgeons on how to best close these incisions. Methods: This is a single center, single arm prospective interventional study on suture device Suture-TOOL® for the closure of midline abdominal incisions. The aim of this study is to evaluate stitch length adequacy and ease of use. 92 patients are planned to be consecutively enrolled. The primary endpoints are i) proportion of laparotomy incisions with a stitch length/wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4, and ii) wound length/stitch length ratio. Secondary endpoints are i) evaluation of comfort for surgeons as well as satisfaction with the final closure using the Visual Analog Scale.

The aim of the study is to identify immune markers through the analyses of peripheral blood and stool samples, as well as from imaging the tumor. Further, metabolic characteristics with their potential immunological relevance in tumor patients should be analyzed. The study will include cancer patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma, patients with benign salivary gland tumor (chronic inflammatory tumor) and healthy volunteers.
All patients will be recruited before surgery or radiotherapy, if applicable. In salivary gland carcinoma and benign tumors, a tumor sample will be collected before tumor surgery. Peripheral blood and a stool sample will be collected from each patient in salivary gland carcinoma and chronic inflammatory tumors as standard procedure for the treatment. Furthermore, saliva and tumor samples will be stored by using specific protocols for the tissue collection. The patients with a benign tumor will be assessed once and stool and saliva samples will be collected once only. Healthy volunteers will be recruited only once and they will donate stool and saliva samples only once.

Clinical studies examining the effects of various dietary patterns on MS are ongoing, and evidence is still lacking regarding the use of any specific dietary therapy for individuals with MS. In general, individuals living in high-income western countries where the disease is more common; They lead a sedentary life, are less exposed to sunlight, and are fed a high-energy diet rich in animal-derived saturated fats and refined sugar. The Mediterranean diet is a nutritional model that is universally thought to improve health, and it is known that the Mediterranean diet has beneficial effects in the prevention and treatment of chronic diseases.
The major difference between the Mediterranean diet and the Western-style diet is the source and amount of dietary fat and carbohydrates. The Mediterranean diet is rich in foods containing monounsaturated fat (especially omega-3), antioxidant vitamins and minerals (vitamins A, C, E, folic acid, selenium, zinc, calcium), which are thought to have positive effects on the prevention and course of MS. Preferring vegetable oils instead of animal fats in Mediterranean type diet, preferring fish instead of red meat consumption, preferring low-fat / fat-free milk and dairy products, limiting the intake of simple sugar and refined carbohydrates, increasing the consumption of fruits and vegetables rich in pulp and antioxidants. It is thought that this type of nutrition may positively affect the course and treatment of immune diseases by reducing inflammation. Although there is no effective clinical evidence for the application of nutritional support as complementary therapy in MS patients, it is known that patients often use various nutritional supplements to reduce symptoms that negatively affect their quality of life. It is also important to determine the frequency of current nutritional support use in order to prevent unconscious use of nutritional support in the group. Because the most common symptoms of MS are muscle weakness, individuals with MS are often less physically active than age-matched adults All these negativities result in decreased functional activities, loss of mobility and balance problems. Walking and, in a broader sense, mobility are functions that are frequently affected in MS and have a high negative impact on quality of life. Gait problems are not uncommon in MS, and it is reported that a significant portion of individuals in this group are adversely affected by their daily living activities. The aim of this study is to determine compliance with the Mediterranean diet, the tendency to use various nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related problems and quality of life in MS patients and to evaluate whether there is a significant relationship between these parameters.

<|assistant|>
Crohn's disease (CD) is a chronic, recurrent, and incompletely understood disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which in turn leads to significant physical and mental health problems. The clinical manifestations of CD are diverse, mainly manifested in abdominal pain, abnormal gastrointestinal motility, bowel obstruction, abdominal mass, weight loss, anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, and other symptoms, seriously affecting patients' life. CD prevalence rates have been increasing year by year worldwide. In terms of socio-economic burden, CD is known to involve a high degree of disease recurrence and relapse. In clinical practice, current medical strategies for the treatment of CD focus on reducing disease recurrence and maintaining disease remission. However, the current situation of the disease activity and disease progression of CD are often not accurately evaluated by standard indicators (such as CRP). It can lead to suboptimal treatment and increase the risk of the ineffectiveness of CD treatment, resulting in lower patient compliance, and even the failure of treatment.
Ustekinumab (UST) is a fully human anti-interleukin (IL) 12/23 receptor that selectively targets multiple pro-inflammatory cytokines, with significant efficacy and safety in the treatment of CD in Chinese and foreign data. In the past two years, our team has made more in-depth practice and experience with UST in the treatment of CD. In order to guide UST treatment and improve patient response to UST, our team initiated the development of a selective induction therapy (SIIT) based on UST clinical decision-making tools for CD in a research. The concept of SIIT mainly aims to select patients with high likelihood of response to UST regimens according to different indicators (C-reactive protein (CRP) level, Mayo score, and history of treatment failure), and then give a more personalized therapy to reduce the number of doses of UST, shorten the duration of intravenous dripping, and thus improve treatment compliance and adverse events caused by UST.
This study is an original design based on the above considerations. It will use a prospective and randomized manner to compare the efficacy and safety of 2 treatment methods (SIIT and standard induction therapy group) in patients with moderate and low response CD. Our team believes that SIIT can effectively improve the short-term and long-term treatment effects of UST for CD, and also reduce the adverse events of UST and improve patient compliance, providing a new medical approach for the individualized treatment of CD.

The investigators intend to design the characteristics of two fictitious overactive bladder (OAB) therapies to conduct a discrete choice experiment (DCE). To complete this study, patient will be approached in the urology department. They will be given a questionnaire to provide their treatment preferences given the trade-offs in therapy characteristics. This study will include a total of 88 adult patients with overactive bladder. Their treatment preference will be measured as their choice between two fictitious OAB treatments - one involving Onabotulinum Toxin A (Botox) and the other involving Sacral Neuromodulation (SNM). They will choose between the therapies by filling in the DCE questionnaire. The DCE will also include sociodemographic questions such as age, gender, ethnicity, education level, language spoken, and OAB-related quality of life questionnaires to improve understanding of the CALD population with OAB.

<|assistant|>
Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is a chronic endocrinologic disorder that is characterized by the absence or insufficient production and release of insulin due to specific autoimmune destruction of the pancreatic islets. This autoimmune destruction is the result of the body's abnormal immune response, leading to significant impairment of the production and secretion of insulin. This impairment leads to hyperglycemia, which over time, can cause damage to multiple body systems such as the eyes, kidneys, nerves, and the cardiovascular system resulting in chronic complications and significantly reduced quality of life for those living with T1DM. In 2013, it was estimated that there were 145 047 people living with T1DM in South Africa, with some estimates even higher. The prevalence of T1DM in South Africa is increasing, making T1DM one of the fastest growing chronic conditions in the country. Type 1 diabetes mellitus, unlike Type 2 diabetes mellitus, has no clearly defined prevention strategies, hence, there are limited strategies for preventing long-term complications for this disease. Therefore, ongoing management of T1DM, including blood glucose levels, is crucial in preventing the occurrence of these complications, improving life expectancy and quality of life. The use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) in the management of T1DM is becoming increasingly popular due to its ability to continuously measure glucose levels, provide real-time insights into glucose trends, and provide alerts when blood glucose levels exceed certain thresholds of either too high, or too low. The use of CGM devices has been shown to be associated with clinically significant improvements in HbA1c and other glycemic measures in people living with T1DM. However, despite the benefits of using CGM, there is limited or no access to CGM in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) such as South Africa, due to factors such as high cost, difficulty of use, and lack of local regulatory approval. With the emergence of FreeStyle Libre CGM as a technology that does not require calibration, and the subsequent local regulatory approval in South Africa, there is an opportunity to test the effectiveness and safety of this technology locally. Despite the benefits of using CGM in diabetes management, there has been limited information related to the use of CGM and its impact on glycemic control, quality of life, and cost in South Africa. While there has been research on the use of CGM in both developed and LMICs, little is known about the effectiveness and safety of CGM in LMICs such as South Africa. The primary objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness of using CGM compared to standard of care in improving HbA1c levels, while assessing its impact on unplanned admission visits related to diabetes, quality of life and cost effectiveness of using CGM among people living with T1DM. The secondary objectives will include: 1. Impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on blood glucose levels in comparison to standard of care in people living with type 1 diabetes; 2. Impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on the variability of blood glucose concentrations related to diabetes; 3. Impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on unplanned visits to outpatient clinics and/or hospital related to diabetes complications; 4. Impact of continuous and intermittent CGM use on quality of life of recipients of diabetes care and their caregivers (where applicable); 5. Cost of continuous and intermittent CGM use from a user and provider perspective. The study aims to enroll 330 participants, divided into 3 study arms. The first arm will consist of participants who will use a CGM in a continuous manner for 9 months starting at enrolment. The second arm will consist of participants who will use the CGM on 4 occasions over the course of 9 months, each CGM use lasting for 2 weeks, with a 9-week break between each use. The third arm will consist of participants who will receive standard of care which will include their own choice of blood glucose monitoring device.  The study is a randomized controlled trial with a pragmatic design aimed at assessing the effectiveness and safety of using CGM compared to standard of care in improving HbA1c levels, while assessing its impact on unplanned admission visits related to diabetes, quality of life and cost effectiveness of using CGM among people living with T1DM, taking into consideration real-world conditions.  A mixed method design will be used to collect data from recipients of diabetes

AIM OF THE STUDY: The main aim of the study is the treatment of PCa with fractionated Stereo Tactic Body Radiotherapy (SBRT), an effective and safe treatment, with an intensification of the dose of the radiation target inside the tumor (Dose Intensified Localisation), with the possible increase of cancer control. A few institutions have reported on the intensification of the dose to the DIL (Dose intensified Localisation), without negative consequences on the urinary and gastrointestinal complications. A SBRT study could be defined as a local therapy, not requiring androgen deprivation treatment.
CONDITIONS: Prostate cancer is the main reason underlying the increase in number of diagnostic and therapeutic techniques. Recent developments in imaging and therapy have brought about an improvement in accuracy and dose distribution. SBRT is a stereotactic radiotherapy technique that uses a higher doses than conventional radiation for the same duration of time, thus reducing the overall treatment time.
OBJECTIVE: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a treatment protocol based on SBRT with focal dose intensification on the DIL (Dose intensified Localisation) on PCa patients.
TARGET SIZE: The proposed study has a one-arm, open-label, phase II design, to assess the efficacy, safety and tolerability of a dose escalated SBRT treatment.
POPULATION: Patients will be selected according to the standard risk assessment for prostate cancer. Patients will be histologically confirmed with adenocarcinoma of the prostate, clinical stage intermediate or high and radiological evidence of Prostate cancer.
TREATMENT: A total dose of 36.25 Gy in 5 fractions of 7.25 Gy will be delivered to the whole prostate (including seminal vesicles) using VMAT. Focal dose intensification on DIL as a simultaneous integrated boost - SIBOMP - will be delivered with a dose of 50 Gy in 5 sessions, with a partial protection of the prostatic urethra and bladder trigone. This treatment could be defined as a local therapy, therefore allowing to avoid systemic therapy or androgen deprivation treatment.

<|assistant|>
The objective of the proposal "smIlEr" is to conduct a clinical study in which young people with controlled asthma, age 12-17, can experience a serious game called "smIlEr" specifically designed to evaluate whether it has an impact on the effectiveness of the intervention. The main focus is on the physical and psychosocial effects on the children. The study was inspired by the observation that exercise can lead to a significant reduction in asthma related symptoms and that, at the same time, it can improve the overall quality of life. The study is a randomized, controlled trial with pre-post design. 42 children (M = 14; f = 6), 12-17 years old and with controlled asthma according to GINA will receive either the "smIlEr" experience or the standard treatment plan (i.e. asthma educational material and physical exercise at home). The children of both intervention groups will be asked to complete 3 in-lab sessions for physiological monitoring and assessment of quality of life. After the sessions, each child will take home a smart wristband suitable for monitoring the amount of exercise performed. Data analysis will focus on group-mean differences in the number of steps recorded during the first and the last week of treatment using the wristbands, in the level of quality of life measured by questionnaires and in the level of the psychobiological response measured by blood biomarkers.

The research hypotheses of the study are: 
1. Acute stress enhances the behavioral and neural effects of PIT on drug-associated cues in subjects with AUD and increases with the severity of AUD. 
2. SUD subjects who show strong PIT effects also show higher impulsivity, worse cognitive control, stronger urge to drink and higher levels of alcohol consumption over the following year. 
3. Cue-induced PIT effects differ between outcome-specific and general PIT effects. 
4. Sources of chronic stress (e.g., social readjustment rating scale, perceived stress scale) moderate the effects of acute stress on PIT effects on drug-associated cues in individuals with AUD. 
5. Sources of chronic stress (e.g., social readjustment rating scale, perceived stress scale) moderate the effects of acute stress on SUD subjects' impulsivity, cognitive control and urge to drink.

Frexalimab is a first-in-class therapeutic human monoclonal antibody (mAb) that selectively inactivates complement component 5 (C5), a component of the complement system that drives inflammation and destruction of tissues. Preclinical studies demonstrated that frexalimab reduces neuronal death and reduces clinical disease and neuropathology in multiple sclerosis (MS) animal models.
This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase III multicenter study to assess the efficacy and safety of intravenous infusions of frexalimab vs placebo in subjects with nonrelapsing secondary progressive MS. Approximately 840 subjects with nonrelapsing secondary progressive MS who have experienced stable disability progression and are on no concomitant disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) will be enrolled. Subjects will be randomized 1:1 to receive intravenous infusions of frexalimab (two infusions of 900 mg, followed by monthly infusions of 600 mg for up to 160 weeks) or placebo. The co-primary efficacy endpoints include time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP), confirmed over 6 months. The primary analysis will be based on a mixed model for recurrent (MMRM) analysis. Additional secondary efficacy endpoints include time to onset of cCDP, confirmed over 3 months, time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3 months or 6 months, number of new and/or enlarging T2hyperintense lesions per scan as detected by MRI, and number of new and/or enlarging T2hyperintense lesions per month. Safety endpoints will assess adverse events, SAEs, AEs leading to permanent study intervention discontinuation and AE of special interests (AESIs), number of participants with potentially clinically significant abnormalities (PCSAs) in laboratory tests, ECG, and vital signs, number of participants with abnormal laboratory results, abnormal ECG with the occurrence of AEs during the double-blind treatment period or the End of Study (EOS) visit. Exploratory biomarker endpoints will include change from baseline in serum Ig levels, serum free light chain (FLC) levels, plasma NfL levels, and plasma c5 levels over time. Subjects who experience disability progression after 80 weeks of treatment will be offered an additional blinded treatment phase with open label frexalimab. All subjects after 160 weeks or early withdrawal will enter the open label treatment period with frexalimab. Subjects may also receive rescue therapy at any point if judged needed by the investigator.

Cleft lip and palate are the most common congenital craniofacial anomaly. For unilateral cleft lip repair, Mishra and modified Millard techniques, have been recently improved. No research has been done to compare these two techniques. Aim of the study is to compare surgical repositioning outcomes between both these techniques and evaluate surgical correction of unilateral cleft lip with Mishra and modified Millard techniques.
Inclusion Criteria: 21 infants of unilateral isolated cleft lip in a group of 21 age of 3-6 month group A -21 patient of unilateral cleft lip had mishra technique repair group B -21 patient of unilateral cleft lip had modified Millard technique repair.
Methods: Anthropometric measurements of both cleft and non cl-teft sides with digital caliper (mm) in centimeter in millimeter, unilateral cleft lip measurements: Vertical lip height Horizontal lip length (horizontal lip length)Philtral length on surgical repaired cleft lip compared to surgical repaired non cleft lip. Qualitative assessment were evaluated before and after repair.
Statistical Analysis: Statistical software was used for data analysis. Analysis was performed by SPSS ver. 24. Student t test, Mann Whitney U test, One way Anova test was used for analysis. p<0.05 was considered statistically significant.
At 3 months post operative, the surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurement of the non cleft side (N = 21) the vertical lip height, horizontal lip length and philtral length was measured as 25.6 ±1.99 mm, 37.88±0.66 mm and 11.33±1.33 mm respectively.
The postoperative measurements of horizontal lip length were statistically significant between group A and group B (p<0.001). The mean post operative horizontal lip length of group A was significantly increased than the group B at a post operative of 25 mo.

This study tested if endoscopic clipping can reduce recurrence of controlled pericutaneous fistulas; which is the result of an inflammatory process in the wall of the intestine (diverticulitis) and the fistula is present after the acute episode has subsided.

The Canadian Cardiovascular Society (CCVS) predicts that in 2031 heart failure will be the leading cause of hospitalization among those 65 years and older, outstripping all other cardiovascular diseases combined. Unfortunately, many people with HF do not know they have the condition until they end up in the hospital. Early screening for HF can help detect and treat the disease before it is too late. The goal of this study is to provide a screening strategy to help identify patients who are at risk of developing HF within the next 6 months. It is a 6-month pilot study of usual care versus invitation to screening, focusing on patients with three and above risk factors for HF. The investigators want to determine if early screening of patients at risk of developing HF can help identify the right patients, so they can receive treatment, as well as potentially identify those at the most danger so that they can receive closer follow up.

Patients who will be induction of anesthesia with propofol will have a body analysis with Tanita before the operation. Patients' height, weight, age, gender and other general information will be recorded. Total body weight (TBW), ideal body weight (IBW) and lean body weight (LBW) of the patients will be calculated. Patients over the age of 18 who will be operated under general anesthesia for 2-6 hours will be included. Patients with propofol allergy or contraindicated to propofol are included in the study. In order to decide and try the most appropriate weight-based scalar for propofol dosing for anesthesia induction to be evaluated by specifying patients who need additional propofol during intubation in the study, Ingrande et al. 80 patients with a mean body mass index [BMI] between 18-35 and Bispectoral index (BIS). ) monitorization, propofol infusion (100 mg/kg/hour) will be started according to total body weight, and the infusion will be stopped with a BIS value between 50 and 40, and the elapsed time will be recorded. Routine anesthesia applications will be performed with neuromuscular blocker applied. The total dose of Propofol given; the dose applied to kilograms will be calculated according to TBW, IBW and LBW. And the relationship between the doses given and the body mass index will be evaluated. In our study, we aimed to evaluate the effects of Propofol dose according to lean body weight by evaluating patients with bodymass index below 35.

Both the primary and secondary outcomes are significant as they help physiotherapists understand the impact of hospitalization on patients with cardiac diseases and assess the most important factors involved in the complexity level and physical therapist care required. This information is essential in guiding interventions aimed at preventable morbidity in patients hospitalized for cardiac diseases such as respiratory and systemic complications that lead to longer hospital stay, complications, and ultimately mortality. The time frame for the study is an average of 3 months for phase 2 and 3 years for phase 3. This is a reasonable timeframe to collect data and assess the outcomes of the intervention.

<|assistant|> Research has found that patients with multiple myeloma (MM) have relatively high symptom burden and poor health-related quality of life (HRQoL) prior and subsequent to chemotherapy and targeted therapies for relapsed/refractory (R/R) disease. Although symptom burden in this population has received increasing attention from clinicians it remains unclear how best to assess and address symptoms and distress in MM patients. The advent of effective therapies for R/R MM, including combination treatments that include immune therapies has led to improved long-term outcomes for patients. However, it is unclear how recent advances in treatment have influenced the symptom burden, daily lives, and HRQoL of MM patients undergoing therapy. A prospective study of patients with R/R MM to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary outcomes of DLC and its potential to augment existing standards of care for patient support is underway. An opportunity exists to explore how a digital health coaching platform might be used for symptom assessment, behavioral interventions, and to foster greater patient activation. This study is feasibility-based and will seek to understand the role of digital therapeutics in improving the care of patients with R/R MM. The preliminary outcomes of this study are: (1) to provide a first-look at the feasibility and acceptability of a DLC intervention in patients with R/R MM undergoing chemotherapy treatment; (2) to examine the relationships between PROs, clinical assessment, and wearable data; and (3) to characterize how patients with R/R MM engage with a digital health coaching platform and the effect of engagement on HRQoL and other supportive care outcomes. By characterizing barriers and enablers to enrollment, feasibility, and patient engagement, and through the inclusion of bi-directional assessments between the patient and participating health advisors, this study will inform future interventional studies designed to engage and support patients with R/R MM as they undergo chemotherapy treatment. Official Title ----------------- Evaluating Patient-Reported Outcomes and Wearable Data Among Individuals With Relapsed/Refractory Multiple Myeloma Conditions ----------------- Multiple Myeloma, Relapsed Hematologic Malignancy Intervention / Treatment ----------------- * Behavioral: Digital Health Coaching Program * Device: Fitbit Participation Criteria ================= Eligibility Criteria ----------------- Inclusion Criteria: Age 18 or older Confirmed diagnosis of MM as determined by participants' primary physicians at the study site. Patients with concurrent AL amyloidosis will be eligible. Initiation of at least the second line of MM-directed therapy for multiple myeloma at time of study enrollment. Participants must have been exposed to at least one proteasome inhibitor (PI) and/or one immunomodulatory drug (IMiD). Exclusion Criteria: Individuals who are terminally ill, defined as individuals identified by their physician as likely having 6 months or less to live, or those individuals transitioned to comfort measures only (meaning only supportive care measures without curative focused treatment) Individuals who have previously participated in Pack Health digital health coaching Physician-assessed lack of sufficient English proficiency Lack of ownership of a personal smartphone or device allowing for access to text, email or mobile application Any serious and/or unstable pre-existing medical, psychiatric, or other condition that could interfere with participant's safety, provision of informed consent, or compliance with study procedures Concurrent enrollment on a therapeutic study in R/R MM that precludes simultaneous enrollment onto our non-therapeutic study Ages Eligible for Study ----------------- Minimum Age: 18 Years Sexes Eligible for Study ----------------- All Accepts Healthy Volunteers ----------------- No Study Plan ================= How is the study designed? ----------------- Design Details Primary Purpose: Supportive Care Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment Interventional Model Description: A single cohort of 100 individuals with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma will be enrolled in the study, all of which will be enrolled in a digital health coaching program and receive a Fitbit device for activity tracking. The effect of a 4-week 10-20 g/day WholeFiberTM intervention (a dried vegetable rich in 4 types of prebiotic fiber, including inulin, pectin, cellulose and hemi-cellulose) on fecal calprotectin, IBD-complaints and QoL, serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota and SCFA-levels, was investigated in patients with Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis. Secondary endpoints were the response on the intervention with WholeFiberTM, depending on whether the patient had Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis. Fecal samples were analysed using 16S ribosomal RNA gene sequencing and SCFA-levels determined in stool samples. In addition, an evaluation questionnaire was administered to assess feasibility and acceptance of the WholeFiberTM intervention in this population. All samples were collected by the UMCG study team before and after a 4-week intervention. It was determined that the intervention resulted in improvements of fecal calprotectin and several aspects of fatigue in patients with Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis. The effect of WholeFiberTM on health-related quality of life was not consistently observed in the two groups of patients. Improvements of stool consistency and stool frequency were not consistently observed either. Changes were observed in the fecal microbiota composition for patients with ulcerative colitis, but not for patients with Crohn's disease. Overall, this pilot study suggests that the daily use of 10-20 g WholeFiberTM for 4 weeks may provide beneficial effects on clinical outcomes, quality of life and the gut microbiota in patients with Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis, although more in-depth studies are warranted.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the recession reduction effect of the use of a porcine acellular dermal matrix associated with coroneal advanced flap (CAF) in the treatment of localized gingival recessions (LGR) when compared to the coronal advanced flap alone.
The study is a multicenter, randomized controlled, double-blind clinical trial, with 6 months and 12 months of follow-up, approved by a Research Ethics Committee.

The main objective is to compare the changes in heart rate variability that occur during exercise with Virtual Reality in chronic renal patients during in-center hemodialysis to those that occur during conventional exercise. The study will include the main questions: What are the differences in the changes in heart rate variability modulation between chronic renal patients who undergo conventional physical exercise before and during hemodialysis sessions, and those who engage in virtual environment exercises? How does the virtual environment influence the changes in heart rate variability modulation compared to conventional physical exercise in chronic renal patients before and during hemodialysis sessions? What is the relative effectiveness of conventional physical exercise compared to virtual environment exercise in improving heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients before and during hemodialysis sessions? For this purpose, heart rate and respiratory rate data, as well as blood pressure, oxygen saturation, laboratory tests, quality of life, anxiety, depression, and physical activity will be collected.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the surgical efficacy of carpal tunnel release performed with a longitudinal mini incision compared to conventional longitudinal incision. To compare the surgical outcomes regarding; the improvement of symptoms, pain, sensibility, scar effect and recurrence of symptoms postoperatively between both surgical incisions.

Study Population
All selected cases with primary CTS (> 2 years) in Mansoura University hospitals between December 2020 and December 2023; will be submitted to the pre-operational evaluation.
Inclusion criteria:
The main inclusion criteria is patients with primary CTS (> 2 years) attending Mansoura University hospitals, whose diagnosis is EMG-and NCS-proved median neuropathy at the wrist, failed conservative treatment, and absence of any other hand pathology. Additionally, patients with a positive Tinel sign, presence of median nerve entrapment are also included.
Exclusion criteria include presence of proximal radiculopathy, previous history of cervical spondylosis, preoperative presence of inflammatory joint disease and gout, as well as combined nerve compression. Patients with incomplete follow-up data and patients with psychiatric disease are also excluded.

Study Design
This study is designed as an institutional-based, randomized-controlled trial with 2 arms and a cohort size of 104 patients.
Preoperative evaluation will be done for all patients, including; history-taking, visual analogue scale for pain assessment, neurological and neuro-physiological examination, and NCS.
Randomization will be done using a computer-generated table of random numbers, and patients will be assigned to one of the two groups (2-arm trial);
- Active Comparator 1: Mini Incision group
- Active Comparator 2: Conventional group

Intervention/Treatment
The intervention includes two procedures, carpal tunnel release (CTR) mini incision and CTR conventional incision.
In the Mini Incision group, a special metal guide will be used to make a longitudinal mini-incision started just above the proximal flexor wrist crease, then advanced proximally for 1.5 to 2 cm. After blunt dissection, the median nerve will be exposed, with the use of the metal guide, and the transverse carpal ligament will be cut longitudinally using a scissor inserted along the groove in the guide.
In the Conventional group, a longitudinal incision is created between the thenar and hypothenar eminences until reaching the proximal flexor wrist crease.

Postoperative data
All patients will be followed up a a minimum time of 6 months, including out-of-out patient follow-ups. At each follow-up visit, the investigator measures and records; improvement in symptoms, pain, sensibility, scar effect and recurrence of symptoms.

The intervention (AOT+g) is based on the mirror neuron system, which is the same mechanism used to learn new motor skills, through imitation of movements performed by the therapist, and later by patients with CI.
AOT is a training technique based on the concept of neural plasticity of the motor system. AOT is the observation of a specific motor gesture performed by another individual, which promotes neural plasticity by facilitating the imitation of the observed gesture. Neural studies have shown that the observation of an action activates the same regions of the brain that are activated during actual execution of the behavior. Specifically, this technique has been successfully used in children with cerebral palsy and in individuals who have experienced a stroke, with positive results in terms of motor recovery. Furthermore, the technique has proven effective in improving motor skills in healthy adults, in clinical and preclinical populations.
The main objective of this study is to test the effectiveness of AOT as a neurorehabilitation tool in patients with MCI, by comparing the effects in patients who observe an action performed by the therapist, compared with patients who observe an action performed by other patients with the same characteristics, and compared to a control group who do not receive any intervention.
The study is a randomized controlled clinical trial with three groups: an experimental group that will observe an action performed by the therapist, an experimental group that will observe a movement performed by other patients with MCI, and a control group (usual maintenance care).
To determine functional status of the upper limbs, we will use the FMA scale (with items: voluntary movement within synergies, voluntary movement mixing synergies, voluntary movement with little or no synergy, grip, coordination/speed, and passive movement of the joints).
At the beginning of the program, all patients will receive a standardized assessment of the upper limbs carried out by a physical therapist, and the same physical therapist will perform the last assessment at the end of the program. In addition, we will include other assessments specific to the intervention group. Patients in the observation groups will have additional interventions and assessments.
After completing the program, a second assessment in patients with MCI will be made to determine the effectiveness of the AOT.

In the context of ultrasound guidance, the use of a real-time, easily accessible, portable and non-expensive device has recently become possible through the development of ultraportable ultrasound equipment. The study has 2 aims:

Although episiotomy has been accepted as a routine part of obstetric care worldwide, it can cause several maternal morbidities such as wound dehiscence, postpartum hemorrhage, infection, sexual dysfunction, scarring/chronic pain. The aim of the study is to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Er:YAG laser on the genital pelvic pain and scar tissue healing of the episiotomy scars in postpartum patients.

Patients with gallstone disease have differences in their gut microbiome and these changes are important in the development of complications, including cholecystitis and acute pancreatitis. The investigators will collect stool from patients with gallstone disease and analyse it for changes in microbiome composition. They will then assess which changes are associated with patient outcomes, such as complications and recovery after cholecystectomy. They hope their research will provide clues to developing new treatments for gallstone disease. The investigators anticipate that the data collection and stool sampling could be completed within 3 years. If you need any further information, please contact the Research and Development office at East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust.

Inclusion criteria: All adult patients diagnosed with gallstone disease following confirmation by imaging at an East Kent University Foundation Trust hospital will be eligible to take part in this study. This includes patients awaiting cholecystectomy or those who have not yet been referred for surgery. There are no exclusion criteria.

Samples and data collection: Participants will be given a stool collection kit containing three plastic pots (one inner container within a larger outer container which is then sealed in a second outer container with a clear label showing the patient's name, date and time of sampling). They will be provided with a three-day food diary. Participants who are unable to provide a stool sample at home will be asked to attend the hospital for a stool sample. Stool samples will be collected at the same time points as data is collected from electronic patient records (at least three, see data collection below).
The investigators will explain how the samples will be stored, with the first sample being stored for two years before being removed from the deep freezer, and a sample taken and stored in the laboratory.
Data collection: The patient's routine electronic medical records and imaging results will be reviewed, and information collected from these records. Data collected will include:
- Demographic information such as age and gender
- Risk factors such as Body mass index (BMI), smoking status, alcohol intake, current medication and comorbid conditions
- Pregnant women will also be asked about pregnancy and smoking status during pregnancy
- Cholecystectomy details - type, date and surgical approach; post-operative outcomes - complications, hospital stay, etc. Each time a stool sample is collected, the participant will be asked to fill in the food diary and to complete a small bowel movement questionnaire. They will be reminded of further stool sample collections. The investigators will store each sample in the freezer, before removing the first one after two years. Further samples can then be collected at scheduled time points.
Retrospective data: Data from 2019 will be collected retrospectively according to the same schedule. All data will be maintained as a pseudonymised data set. The information will only be accessible to the research team.

Sepsis-associated liver dysfunction (SALD) is a common complication in patients with sepsis, with a significant impact on patient mortality and prognosis. Elevated aspartate aminotransferase(AST) to platelet (PLT) ratio index (APRI) has been shown to suggest the presence of sepsis-associated organ injury, and the increased APRI levels are associated with poor prognosis of sepsis-associated organ dysfunction. However, it remains unclear whether elevated initial APRI could predict the development or outcome of SALD. Therefore, we sought to evaluate the predictive role of the initial value of APRI for the occurrence of SALD in patients with sepsis.
Elevated initial APRI was a strong predictor, and the level of APRI was continuously increasing in SALD group with time. Elevated initial APRI was also associated with shorter ICU stay, longer hospital stay, and higher 30-day mortality rate in adult patients with sepsis.
In conclusion, elevated initial APRI was associated with the occurrence and outcome of SALD in sepsis patients, which was found to be a clinically useful parameter for early prediction and monitoring of SALD in adult patients.

This study will demonstrate the superiority of the omicron variant vaccine and provide reasonable data to support its emergency use in a population at risk of serious outcomes from this virus.

The main goal of this study is to compare Visual Analogue Scale(VAS) scores and total opioid consumption between patients who underwent sacral erector spinae plane block and control patients in lumbar disc discectomy surgery. Lumbar disc hernias are most commonly encountered among spinal conditions, and lumbar disc surgery (LDD) is one of the common spinal procedures. While discectomy surgery relieves symptoms and improves the quality of life of patients, it often causes severe post-operative pain, and opioid consumption may cause side effects. There is a consensus in the literature that regional anesthesia techniques may have an important place in the management of postoperative pain. The erector spinae plane block of the sacral erector spine muscle, whose existence was first demonstrated by Forero et al in 2011 as LESB, provides postoperative analgesia in a limited number of studies on abdominal and lumbar surgeries and has become an interesting application in recent years. We aimed to study the effect of an erector spinae plane block performed in patients undergoing lumbar disc discectomy surgery in terms of reducing postoperative pain. Fifty-four ASA 1-3 patients randomized into ESPB (n=27) and control group (n=27) were included. There was no statistically significant difference between the groups in terms of visual analog scale scores and opioid consumption at all times (p>0.05). The results of our study showed that Erector Spinae plane block with bilateral 0.25% bupivacaine did not reduce post-operative pain and opioid consumption in lumbar disc discectomy patients. 13 patients in the group who received the block used it for emergency, we think that these results may be because the patients could not rest in the prone position due to early respiratory efforts after surgery, and the erector spinae muscles were partially stretched at higher levels. In addition, the short-term effect of ESPB on other sensory nerve levels other than the sacral spine may not have provided maximum anesthesia. In a study with similar indications, Ripamontano et al showed that patients with 0.25% ropivacaine had reduced postoperative pain, but not in those with 0.125% bupivacaine. 13 We think that the amount of local anesthetic in this study and the local anesthetic used may have affected the results. It has been shown that ESPB can be performed as a single-shot and continuous block technique. It seems that more studies are needed on the amount of local anesthetic and the use of local anesthetic. Further studies are needed to determine the level of erector spinae muscle that will be most effective in the lumbar region. It seems that the level to be operated on, such as the level of disc herniation, may be the most effective in terms of ESPB success.

To confirm this, the investigator has chosen three other performance criteria, namely (1) psychological status: state-Trait Anxiety Scale on a scale of 1 to 10, (2) acquisition of medical knowledge: OSCE skills assessment, finally, (3) medical knowledge: OSCEs score. This study, with a randomized control group study, and of an interventional type, will be conducted in a cohort of medical students in a French public hospital.
The inclusion criteria: Students who have completed their last hospital-based internship (ERASMUS) in one of the two emergency departments of CHG, are 18 years of age or older, are medical students, and who have chosen to continue their medical internship in non-ERASMUS emergency departments. Students have the opportunity to participate in this study after signing an information sheet. The exclusion criteria: Refusal to participate, students who return to the emergency department and who have already participated in the study, and non-ERASMUS students. Study methods: Students are divided into two groups, the control group and the intervention group, using sealed and labelled blocks of envelopes. Enrolment by envelope concealment until the end of data collection. In the intervention group, students practice, several times a week, on ECOX training sheets during their hospital-based internship. The control group will practice in the usual way in the department, with an internship tutor and/or specific education, depending on the availability of the latter. Improvement in patient care during the end-of-internship service examinations. Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) as well as other chronic diseases were becoming more and more common in modern society. Pulmonary arterial hypertension is usually accompanied by various other co-morbidities, such as cardio-vascular disease, connective tissues disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. Chronic disease patients, especially PAH patients with many health problems experience lower quality of life and life expectancy than the normal population. Many studies showed lower activity tolerance, poorer social support, and more symptoms distress, anxiety and depression in PAH patients.
The goal of this project is to develop a web-based health care program, and we want to evaluate the effects of this program on the improvement of PAH patients' social support, active tolerance, symptoms distress, anxiety, depression and quality of life. The investigators have already developed an internet-based home management system that could improve heart failure patients' quality of life. The investigators will modify this program to customize for PAH.
A total of 140 PAH patients will be recruited. There are 4 subgroups, and each group would have different interventions. All groups will have a face-to-face survey at the baseline, 12 weeks, 24 weeks, 36 weeks, 48 weeks and 60 weeks, and receive the first survey once the patient confirmed as the diagnosis of PAH. This survey will include demographic data, medical history, and quality of life scale. The investigators will use multivariate analyses of variance (MANOVA) to examine the changes of the PAH symptoms, social support, activity tolerance, and quality of life before and after the intervention.

Background: ALS is a rare neurodegenerative disease with a great variability in clinical progression, disease patterns, and quality of life (QoL) needs. Long term mechanical ventilation support (LTMV) is offered to patients whose ALS-related breathing difficulties is not relieved without mechanical ventilation. There are no consistent data on which factors influences the decision to choose life prolonging treatment with LTMV. However, the quality of life (QoL) and QoL need has become increasingly important. The aim of our study is to describe factors likely to be associated with the QoL of ALS patients and their partners and children.
Furthermore, there are some evidence suggesting that LTMV may be associated with lower QoL in some studies. However, we lack consistent data of the effect of ventilator support on QoL. As a result of high variability in the disease and treatment, we aim to investigate if the decision to accept or reject ventilator supported treatment for ALS influences the QoL of ALS patients and partners and children.
Objectives: To describe factors likely to be associated with the QoL of ALS patients and their partners and children.
To investigate if the decision to accept or reject long term invasive or non-invasive ventilation support in ALS influences QoL of ALS patients and partners and children.
Study design, participants and study arms: In this study, we will investigate factors likely to be associated with the QoL of ALS patients and their partners and children. We will carry out health economics and process evaluation to identify resource use, clinical and health economic outcome measures, cost, and quality of life for both ALS patients and their partners and children. We will perform a longitudinal follow-up study.
We will include both patients who has accepted (Acceptors) and declined life extending treatment (Non-Acceptors) with LTMV. The interventions we consider will be long term mechanical ventilation support.
Primary outcome: To compare general and disease specific quality of life of ALS patients and their partners and children who has accepted or declined long term mechanical ventilation support.

<|assistant|> Chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH), also known as subdural hygroma, is an accumulation of blood in a subdural space below the dura mater. Symptoms occur due to the mass effect from the accumulated blood which may lead to neurological deficits related to focal edema and/or mass effect. Indications for treatment include large chronic subdural hematoma (> 3-5 cm thickness with significant midline shift), symptomatic patients, patients with midline shift 4mm, increased ICP in 24 hours, hydrocephalus, seizure disorder and significant clinical neurologic deficit (National Institute of Health Stroke Scale ≥ 5). Treatment is done under general anesthesia via craniotomy and bur hole evacuation of the hematoma. As part of routine patient monitoring, patients are monitored by electroencephalogram (EEG) intraoperatively for the presence and location of epileptiform activity and then followed for 24 hours in an intensive care unit setting. There have been several reports in the literature regarding subdural hematomas and the development of epilepsy, particularly focal epilepsy. Electroencephalogram has been the primary modality used to detect and monitor epileptogenic activity in this patient population. This study seeks to examine the relationship of subdural EEG abnormalities to clinical presentation and post surgical neurologic outcomes in patients with large and symptomatic chronic subdural hematoma. After surgery, patients will have a subdural electrode placed under the craniotomy, crossed from one temporal lobe to the other temporal lobe and overlying the frontal lobes. This electrode will be sampled by continuous video EEG monitoring lasting between 1-5 days. EEG recordings will be obtained at least at 1 hour post-operative and at hourly intervals. All patients and their families will be consented for research. Inclusion Criteria: Inclusion Criteria: - chronic/ subacute subdural hematoma deemed necessary for surgical evacuation - Ability to consent or have LAR consent Exclusion Criteria: - emergent need for evacuation - acute traumatic subdural hematoma - severe baseline disability (mRS>2) (modified Rankin Scale) This proposal has specific goals related to monitoring subdural hematoma patients with intraoperative electrocorticography for the presence of epileptiform activity which correlates with anatomic location of post operative complication, a decrease of consciousness/ post operative clinical deterioration, and a decline in patients quality of life. Subdural ECoG monitoring may be used as a tool to monitor this at-risk population, and to improve early detection of post operative complications. By identifying early signs of clinical deterioration and by intervening early, we hope to achieve an outcome reduction and an improved quality of life for these patients. The investigators will include 80 patients with early colo-rectal cancer, at 6 national and 2 international departments of surgery and cancer centers. The primary purpose of this study is to provide preliminary data for the potential benefits of CELS. The results of this study will help us make informed conclusions about the benefits of CELS surgery in elderly frail patients with colorectal cancer.

Inclusion criteria:

- Tumours involving the ileocolic or ileocecal valves
- Tumors taking up more than 50% of the lumen in an air-distended bowel wall.
- Any histological high-risk features in biopsy material from the tumor.
- Preoperative chemo or radiotherapy.
- Any non-Danish speakers.

5 or more of the following :

- Presence of metastases.
- Impaired vision, hearing or speaking due to deafness or blindness.
- Patient that is unable to understand any of the spoken languages in Denmark (Danish, German, English and Turkish).

- Any known malabsorption disorder.

- Patient with severe comorbidity e.g. unstable angina, respiratory failure, myocardial infarction within the last 3 months, congestive heart failure, end-stage renal or liver disease.
- Patient with known psychiatric illness (or a history of such an illness) making compliance to study protocol unlikely.

Background and Rationale:

People with neuromuscular and neurodevelopmental conditions are typically at risk of developing respiratory complications in later life. Treatment with nebulised hypertonic saline (HS) is effective in improving respiratory disease in children and adults with cystic fibrosis (CF). However, its long term safety and benefits in individuals with neuromuscular disease (NMD) or in those with neurodevelopmental conditions such as cerebral palsy (CP) are not known. Therefore, we aim to test the effectiveness and tolerability of a low-dose of HS (6%) as a preventative therapy.

Objective:
The aim is to assess the effect of low dose once daily nebulised hypertonic saline (HS) on the frequency of antibiotic use for respiratory infections over a 52 week period in patients with NMD or CP.

Methods:
The primary outcome will be the number of full courses of antibiotics for respiratory infections (both oral and intravenous). Patients and carers will keep an e-diary recording symptoms and use of antibiotics. A patient is any person with NMD or CP with an indication for HS. The study arms are as follows:
1) HS treatment arm: Nebulised 6% HS once daily.
2) Control arm: Nebulised 0.9% normal saline (NS) once daily

Interventions:
1) HS treatment arm: Nebulised 6% HS once daily.
2) Control arm: Nebulised 0.9% NS once daily

Design:
Open-label, prospective randomised study with 52 week follow-up.

Participants:
Adults and children >5 years old who have NMD or CP.

Inclusion criteria:
Age ≥ 5 years
Diagnosis of NMD or CP
A history of at least one respiratory exacerbation requiring antibiotic treatment with or without the need for hospitalisation in the 12 months prior to recruitment.
If prescribed HS, this will need to be a different dose/ frequency from that being investigated and should be part of an escalation plan.

Exclusion criteria:
Additional diagnosis (e.g. cystic fibrosis), but those with aspiration and/or bronchiectasis secondary to respiratory complications of NMD will be included.
Patients who are already prescribed daily HS in any concentration (i.e., 3%, 5%, 6%, 7%)

Outcome measures:
Primary:
1) Course of antibiotics for respiratory infections measured by the full course of antibiotics as prescribed by the doctor: One full course is the full treatment for one event of respiratory infection, irrespective of the number of days that the course was prescribed for.

Secondary:
1) Lung clearance index measured by multiple breath washout (MBW)- the gold standard lung function test in CF, but not commonly used in NMD or CP.
2) Forced oscillation technique (FOT) - Respiratory resistance (Rrs) (measured in c/L) and respiratory reactance (Xrs). These will be measured by Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT) at 12.5 MHz.
3) Lung ultrasound - Global Lung ultrasound score. The global lung ultrasound score (LUS) quantifies lung aeration by translating lung ultrasound patterns into a numerical score across 12 lung regions (six areas on each side of the chest: two ventral regions, two lateral regions, and two posterolateral regions) and summing the results. The aeration pattern observed in each region is scored as: 0: A pattern with ≤2 B lines; 1: >2 separated B lines that cover ≤50% of the pleural line; 2: B lines that cover >50% of the pleural line; or 3: lung consolidation. In theory, the global LUS score can range from 0 (normal aeration in all regions) to 36 (severe abnormal aeration in all regions).

Paraphilic disorders are a group of disorders consisting of sexual deviations, such as sexual preferences to children, sexual acts with non-consenting adults or non-human objects, and so on. They typically manifest as arousal disorder and can create a high risk of sexual assault.

Compulsive sexual behavior disorder (CSBD) is another condition with the potential to create sexual assault, particularly by its association between alcohol and other substance abuse.

Sexsomnia is a rare, yet severe condition characterized by automatic sexual behaviors during sleep, and may cause harm to self or others.

The aim of the present project is to improve our knowledge of the psychosocial determinants of offending behavior and of psychopathology in adults with paraphilic disorders, CSBD and sexsomnia.

The first part of the study is in the form of a diagnostic study.
The second part of the study is a patient registry.
The third part of the study consists of three prospective studies of patients with CSBD or sexsomnia receiving treatment.
The fourth part of the study consists of one prospective, observational study of a sample of randomly selected citizens and controls with regard to paraphilic disorders and CSBD.

The current study is the first to evaluate the effectiveness of multi-pronged, patient-level CDS and embedded clinical pharmacist co-management for improving GDMT in HFrEF patients. Investigators will test the effectiveness of a targeted intervention package on clinicians and clinician perception of GDMT treatment. A focus on the role of clinical pharmacists, education, best practice advisory (BPA) interruptive clinical alerts and patient portals on GDMT, will be evaluated. The study will test whether an alert for patients without GDMT can help physicians identify the appropriate drug therapy for patients with HFrEF. An embedded, patient-level, clinical pharmacist co-management in selected clinics will determine the best approach for optimizing GDMT care.

Upper urinary tract stones pose an enormous treatment challenge. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is now firmly established as a minimally invasive technique for treatment of urinary stone. Previous study on combination Tamsulosin therapy (alpha-1 blockers) with ESWL for ureteric stone, revealed encouraging improvement in stone clearance. This is a prospective randomized trial to compare success of ureteroscopic stone clearance after single ESWL alone and ESWL combined with Tamsulosin therapy for ureteric stones less than or equal to 15 mm in upper ureter in a university hospital. In patients who failed ESWL alone in a study on stone clearance after single extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy in upper ureteric stones, the outcome after single ESWL is poor and has been reported to be around 30%. Urologists now have 3 choices for management of ureteric stone; extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL), ureteroscopy and ureterorenoscopy with Holmium laser lithotripsy. Ureteric stone clearance rates after ESWL for upper urinary tract stones of 0.5-1.8 cm are 33%, 67%, and 80% after one, two and three sessions, respectively. Patients are left with morbidity such as ileus, hematuria and pain. Most patients are treated by 2nd or even 3rd sessions. However, ureteroscopy in upper ureter is considered as gold standard for stone clearance. It is an invasive procedure which gives excellent results, however its morbidity is more. Urologists all over the world tend to combine Urenoscopy with Holmium laser, with ESWL for upper UT stones. Recent trends of management of ureteric stone is to combine alpha 1 blockers with ESWL with reported stone free rates of 80%. ESWL combined with alpha blocker therapy is considered as the future in clearance of ureteric stones. Patients who have stones less than 15 mm, are candidate for Eswl with Tamsulosin therapy, for which there will be a prospective RCT in this Department to compare stone clearance. Null hypothesis: There will be no difference in stone clearance in upper ureteric stone treated with single ESWL (A) and ESWL combined with Tamsulosin therapy (B). Alternative hypothesis: ESWL combined with Tamsulosin therapy will give better stone clearance than ESWL alone in ureteric stones less than or equal to 15 mm..

Tracheostomy-associated tracheal stenosis (TOTS) is a feared complication after percutaneous tracheostomy. Standard interventions (cyroablation or APC) are no guaranty for success as recannulation and tracheotomy tube exchange are not uncommon. Thus, several interventions have been developed: endoscopic and surgical resection of tracheal tissue, laser, photodynamic therapy and Nd:YAG laser have been tried without long-term, randomized and controlled study results. In this retrospective study, the results of a large group of patients from a single center who underwent one of the above interventions after TOTS will be compared. 
The study aims to compare clinical and technical success (reintervention-free) of several interventions and long-term effects. These include the required number of interventions, the recannulation rate and the rate of longterm tracheotomy-dependence. These data are essential for the decision for the appropriate interventional strategy. 
Patients diagnosed with stenosis after percutaneous tracheostomy during inpatient care at the German Cystic Fibrosis Centre at the Thoracic Clinic Bremen will be evaluated. All patients will be treated with an initial biopsy and cold knife dissection after topical application of lidocaine with Xylocaine®. Depending on the degree of stenosis, resection of tracheal tissue will then be stopped at the stoma, in the middle or the lower part of the trachea. All patients who are cannulated postintervention without stridor and dyspnoea and without the need for tracheal intubation will be regarded as clinically successfully treated. Patients undergoing unplanned interventions and those requiring tracheal intubation or intensive care support will be considered as having failed treatment. The interventions will be judged as successful if the patients have been successfully decannulated after treatment. Those patients who have survived the intervention and required another intervention and recannulation or tracheotomy tube exchange will have failed treatment. If no stenosis is visible and no stridor or dyspnea occurs, no further interventions will be carried out unless the patient is under re-intervention. 
Long-term results related to stenosis after tracheal stenting, tracheostomy tube exchange and decannulation will be collected from the outpatient clinic including results from outpatient laryngo-tracheoscopy. 
The results will be compared by Kaplan-Meier analysis and Chi square statistical analysis to identify the optimal therapeutic strategy. 
The first part would include the comparison of the results of cryotherapy and APC or loop extractions, the second part would focus on patients undergoing laser treatment. 
The first part of the study should help clarify which treatment should be used preferentially in cases with long lesions of the trachea. The second part of the study would investigate whether a single laser treatment is superior to cryotherapy and the type of ablative laser.

The object of the present study is to evaluate if the adjuvant use of photodynamic therapy (PDT) with diode laser associated with an endodontic treatment (ET) in patients with apical lesion produces greater disinfection of the canal and improvement of the lesion and success rate. For this, a clinical randomized study will be carried out, controlled, blinded and masked, with 3 parallel groups, in which the patient sample will be randomized in 3 treatment groups. The first is the placebo group, which will receive conventional ET and a simulated treatment with the equipment in which no radiation will be emitted; the second group will receive conventional ET associated with PDT with diode laser, wavelength: 660 nm, fluence 10 s/canal and the third group will receive conventional ET associated with PDT with diode laser at 660 nm, wavelength: 20 s/canal. The photosensitizer used will be methylene blue. Clinical and radiographic examination will be used to obtain baseline values (T0) and values 6 months post-treatment (T1). The presence and size of the apical lesion will be assessed at T0 and T1, the percentage reduction of the lesion will be calculated and the PAI index will be used as a scoring system to evaluate the lesion. The success rate will be assessed for each group 6 months after completion of the treatment. Disinfection of the root canals will be analyzed through the analysis of colony formation (ufc/ml). This study will allow us to know the efficacy of PDT and the effectiveness of the adjuvant use of PDT in apical chronic periodontitis, the type of treatment to be selected between ET and ET+PDT and help to minimize the risk of infectious disease transmission during endodontic procedures.

Objectives
-----------------
The study is to test the hypothesis that the psychodynamic effects of SNRI duloxetine (Cymbalta©®) and SSRI sertraline (Zoloft©®) can improve the psychoneurotic mood stabilization in non-psychotic persons with ASD.
Design Overview
-----------------
The study follows a single group assignment, and the participant is the sole subject for observation. No control group is involved. The participants must meet the inclusion criteria and they receive the diagnostic test.
Outcome Measures
-----------------
Primary Outcome Measures are designed to observe different psychoneurotic conditions. The time frame for the follow-up is 90 days.
For example, one of the primary outcome measures is the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A). It is a 14-item, clinician-administered instrument used for evaluating anxiety. The maximum total score is 56, with scores less than 7 indicating no clinically significant anxiety.
Secondary Outcome Measures focuses on measures including: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD-7), Dissociative Experiences Scale - II (DES-II), The Defeat Scale (D Scale), Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS), Severity Measure for Agoraphobia-Adult, BPD Check List, Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ), Personality Belief Questionnaire (PBQ), Behavioral Satisfaction Questionnaire (X and Y axis), heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and diastolic blood pressure.

Official Title
-----------------
Psychiatric Orders in Psychoanalytic Treatment of ASD

Conditions
-----------------
Autism Spectrum Disorder High-Functioning, OCD, Agoraphobia With Panic Attacks, Depression, Anxiety Disorder, ADHD - Combined Type, Borderline Personality Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder, Avoidant Personality Disorder, Stockholm Syndrome, Severe Agoraphobic Avoidance and Mild Panic Attacks, Anxiety Disorders, Depression Anxiety Disorder, Panic Disorder With Agoraphobia, Grief, Separation Insecurity

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Diagnostic Test: Psychoanalysis
* Drug: sertraline 50mg
* Drug: Duloxetine 20 MG
* Behavioral: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy

The investigational use of the Trastuzumab-deruxtecan (T-DXd, ADC-rh7-mcc-HER2) is an intravenous infusion, administered as 5.4 mg per kilogram on every three weeks. Patients, eligible to T-DM1 and who agree to participate in the study, will undergo serial blood samples for liquid biopsy (LB) until progression disease. LB will be performed at baseline and repeated at different time points and/or at progression disease. Based on the results of this study, a diagnostic test for the evaluation of HER2 and (over)expression through liquid biopsy will be developed, with the aim to identify patients with HER2-2D status potentially eligible to receive Trastuzumab Deruxtecan (T-DXd). Patient must have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status of 0 or 1. It should be noted that HER2-2D is a liquid biopsy method that is being developed to measure HER2 addition (overexpression + amplification) in blood. It is not approved or available for diagnostic use, and must be considered investigational. This study aims to improve outcome of patients with advanced, metastatic HER2-positive breast cancers who can be exposed to T-DXd by assessing the concordance between radiological RECIST-based evaluation and liquid biopsy results according to HER2-2D status, leading to the choice of appropriate treatment options.

A high number of mental health disorders including posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are expected to emerge after natural disasters. After such catastrophic events such as the Earthquakes in Türkiye, the mental health needs of earthquake survivors often exceed available care resources. This study will be designed as a pilot randomized controlled trial, and the potential effectiveness of individual Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) will be tested compared to the Enhanced-Care as Usual (E-CAU) control group. Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) is a cognitive behavioral treatment for PTSD consisting of 12 one-hour sessions. Randomized clinical trials have revealed that CPT is an effective treatment for PTSD and other comorbid conditions in a variety of civilian trauma populations. The study will be conducted in container cities where earthquake survivors from earthquake-affected areas have been relocated. After the baseline assessment, 30 eligible participants will be randomized to two arms: in either the CPT (n =15) or only the control group (E-CAU; n=15). The first session will take place no longer than one week after the pre-intervention assessment. The post-intervention assessment through the same measures will be scheduled six weeks after the pre-intervention assessment (i.e., one week after the 12th CPT session). The follow-up assessment will be conducted one month after the post-assessment. All study participants, including dropouts, will be invited to all outcome assessments. The primary outcome is post-traumatic stress disorder, and the following are the secondary clinical outcomes: symptoms of depression, anxiety, and well-being.

In 2017, Holt, Dehlendorf, and Langer created a framework for contraceptive counseling quality grounded in quality of care and human rights principles and research in healthcare communication. Based on this framework, Holt et al. developed and validated the Quality of Contraceptive Counseling (QCC) Scale, which covers three interrelated aspects of counseling quality: information exchange, interpersonal relationship, and disrespect and abuse . The scale comprehensively measures aspects of the counseling process related not only to information receipt but also individuals' experiences having the opportunity to participate in the method selection process and the degree to which they had positive and trusting experiences with the provider . Associations between quality of contraceptive counseling and characteristics of clients, such as age, education, and reproductive status, could represent significant health disparities and indicate the need for research.

The study will investigate the level of perceived quality of family planning counseling in primary healthcare settings and its determinants among 423 women at reproductive age in El-Dakhla District, New Valley governorate.

Data will be collected through a semi-structured interview administered questionnaire including: Socio-demographic characteristics of women Family planning practice 3-Facility factors such as gender of providers, qualification of providers, type of the health facility. 4-Quality of contraceptive counseling (QCC) scale: it is a 22-item scale which measures the quality of care received by women during family planning visits. It includes : 1) information exchange, 2) interpersonal relations, and 3) disrespect and abuse in contraceptive counseling. The information exchange subscale consists of ten items, the interpersonal relationship subscale consists of seven items, and the disrespect and abuse subscale consists of five items.
The study will use different statistical tests to detect the factors that affect quality of family planning counseling in different domains, and then the findings will be shared with the stakeholders to facilitate policy and practice change. The study results will be beneficial for the policy-maker in the Family Planning department of New Valley Governorate, public health institutes, NGOs, and healthcare providers themselves.
