The St. Joseph Children's Program (SJC) is a comprehensive early intervention home visitation program designed for first-time mothers and their infant children during the pregnancy/first year years. A core component of the program is parent-child dyadic interaction. The Home Visitors deliver the content of the program curriculum using a parent-child dyadic interaction approach. The SJC intervention targets the following domains including a healthy pregnancy and life-course health-related behaviors and physical activity, social-emotional health, academic success, and family stability and financial stability. These programs have the potential to improve school readiness, academic attainment, family economic self-sufficiency, social-emotional and behavioral health in the first five years of life and may reduce the risk for adverse short and long-term outcomes (e.g., juvenile delinquency, poor academic achievement, poor health status, etc.). The purpose of this randomized controlled trial is to determine the effectiveness of the SJC intervention. A convenience sample will be provided by Catholic Health Initiatives (CHI). A randomized controlled design was used to assign 325 eligible SJC participants (who meet at least five of the seven characteristics) into two groups; intervention and wait-list control. Participants were followed during their children's first, second, third, fourth, fifth, and sixth years of life. Intervention sessions were held monthly for two years and then followed up with annual sessions for four additional years. Annual assessments were gathered yearly. The primary outcome was the improvement in parenting skills, child outcomes (e.g., socio-emotional, behavioral, academic, health-related) and reduction in family stress factors, such as maltreatment and delinquency. Secondary outcomes included reduced stress, improved physical activity and increased family economic self-sufficiency.

Background: Malaria remains one of the top infectious killers worldwide, and the development of a safe and effective malaria vaccine is considered a public health priority. One vaccine candidate is a RH5.1 recombinant malaria protein designed for use with the adjuvant AS01B (Matrix-M) to elicit protective immune responses against the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum.
Hypothesis: This study will evaluate the safety of the vaccine candidate (Matrix-M with RH5.1) when administered as either a delayed or fractional regimen. In this study the investigators will administer higher doses of the vaccine than in previous studies to explore the dose-response relationship in relation to vaccine safety and immunogenicity.
Study Objectives: To assess the safety of RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-M in healthy adult volunteers by 1) assessing the occurrence of local and systemic reactogenicity following each vaccination, 2) assessing the occurrence of unsolicited adverse events following each vaccination, 3) comparing safety laboratory measures following each vaccination, 4) assessing the occurrence of serious adverse events during the whole study duration.
To assess the humoral immunogenicity of RH5.1 soluble protein with Matrix-M.
To compare the anti-RH5 serum IgG functional immunogenicity between the two groups receiving soluble RH5.1 at different doses.
To compare differences in the innate immune responses between the first and third vaccinations and correlation to adverse event data and adaptive immune responses.
Design: The study will be a randomised, parallel group and multi-centre study. 24 healthy volunteers (12 males and 12 females) will be recruited at each of two sites in the UK to receive 12 vaccinations in total, 4 vaccinations of different doses of 10 or 50 µg of RH5.1 delivered by intramuscular (IM) injection. At each study visit 2 vaccinations will be given on separate days. There will be two treatment groups: Group 1 (delayed regimen): 12 vaccinations given on days 0, 28 and 182 (10 µg or 50 µg RH5.1, 50 µg Matrix-M on days 0 and 28 and 10 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg Matrix-M on day 182). Group 2 (delayed fractional regimen): 12 vaccinations given on days 0, 28 and 182 (2 x 50 µg of RH5.1- Matrix-M on days 0 and 28).
Participants will be followed for 341 days post vaccination in total for each cohort to assess safety and reactogenicity.
Participants will be followed up at specified time points to measure safety laboratory measures, adverse events, reactogenicity and efficacy over 18 months.

The study focuses on multiple system atrophy (MSA), a rare adult-onset neurodegenerative disease with an average life expectancy of 7.9 years. It often results from an autosomal recessive mutation affecting the DNA coding for the alpha-synuclein protein, a protein with a complex role in the nervous system. There is no cure to MSA to date, and symptoms are currently treated with medication, which often results in intestinal malabsorption and gait and balance impairment, among many other non-motor and motor symptoms. The severity of gait impairment often results in falls and, with the progression of the disease, individuals may have problems with swallowing, speaking, writing, walking and handling of hygiene tasks. The overall mortality is high, with sudden death as a consequence of heart failure or autonomic dysfunction. In the latter case, sudden death may occur as a result of aspiration pneumonia secondary to the development of unintelligible speech, a common late-stage symptom of MSA.
In Germany, patients with MSA receive their neurological care at the neurology clinic of the Tirol Kliniken, an academic hospital which acts as a national MSA reference center within the German National Parkinsonism Disease Registry (PPPDR). The overall annual workload related to the out-patient care of people with MSA at the Neurological clinic of the Tirol Kliniken is, despite the rarity of the disease, higher than that of any other neurodegenerative parkinsonism-related disease. In practice, this means that people with MSA have difficulties gaining access to healthcare, a situation with significant emotional and psychological burden on informal caregivers (family members, partners, friends) and with severe socioeconomic impact. The overall quality of care within the national and international MSA community is currently hampered by the lack of evidence-based, structured symptomatic treatment, especially in Germany.
While there are numerous national and international clinical guidelines for the treatment of people with Parkinsonism, there are currently no specific guidelines for the management of MSA. Furthermore, the lack of structured care protocols and clinical training programs has already prevented the standardization of care for people with Parkinsonism, which resulted in significant variations in clinical decision-making and in the treatment and care of people with Parkinsonism and their caregivers in Germany and beyond. Such inter-regional variability in the availability and quality of care and rehabilitation, along with delays from the time of diagnosis to first comprehensive interdisciplinary treatment, may account for the poor prognosis of MSA compared to Parkinsonism, which is associated with a significant reduction in the patients' quality of life and an increase in healthcare-related expenses. This study will provide high-quality clinical recommendations for symptomatic treatment and rehabilitation to people with MSA, which will benefit not only the patients but also the healthcare professionals and caregivers involved in their care.
Objectives: 
Primary objectives of this study are: 
• To evaluate the feasibility of implementing a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment model based on the Medical Model of Care Recommendations for People With Parkinsonism (MaCRoP) Guidelines and, if needed, adapted to the local healthcare provisions, legal and psychological framework, as well as local patient needs and preferences. The model includes neurological, psychological and neuro-rehabilitation care delivered on an out-patient basis via mobile palliative care, neurological and neuro-rehabilitation telemedicine strategies, in case individuals with MSA are bedridden or wheelchair-bound, as well as personalized neuro-rehabilitation programs based on the individualized healthcare preferences of the participants. 
• To define and implement outcome measures for future randomized controlled MSA-clinical trials. 

Second objectives of this study are: 
• To assess the efficacy of the multidisciplinary, personalized treatment protocol in improving the quality of life of patients with MSA and their caregivers. 
• To assess the impact of the multidisciplinary, personalized treatment protocol on the number and severity of medical complications and healthcare-related costs in patients with MSA and their caregivers. 
• To provide high-quality treatment and care for people with MSA in Germany, which may benefit not only the patients and caregivers, but also the healthcare professionals involved in their care.

The investigator proposes to undertake genome-wide association studies (GWAS) for height response to GH replacement therapy to examine genetic determinants of growth hormone (GH) treatment response for children with idiopathic short stature (ISS). The proposed study, will recruit 200 patients with ISS that is diagnosed by the treating physician with the following characteristics: they have had a minimum of one year of GH-therapy, have been prepubertal at start of and throughout the first year of GH therapy and have responded (or not) to GH treatment at least 1.0 standard deviation(SD) and have had no prior exposure to growth promoting therapy. Children will be recruited from the Department for Paediatrics, Medical University of Vienna, Klinikum Melchior, Children's Hospital Zurich and the Royal Women's Hospital Melbourne, Australia.
Blood samples will be collected from individuals of all ages at the study start and a detailed medical and family history will be recorded. Research will take place at the hospital.
In each patient, blood samples will be collected to identify genetic variants in candidate genes using genome-wide association studies. DNA of affected individuals will be analyzed for genetic variations in genes associated with growth. Samples will be stored in a local biobank.
This study will provide important information regarding the genetic determinants of height response to GH replacement therapy for children with ISS. This information will facilitate personalized approaches for patients with ISS based on the response to GH treatment.

The purpose of this study is to assess if hourly neurochecks impact sleep parameters in critically ill adults following aneurysm clipping. A randomized controlled clinical trial will be used.
Critically ill patients requiring post-operative intensive care unit admission after aneurysm clipping may be included. Cerebral aneurysm clipping is a surgical procedure for an acute subarachnoid hemorrhage resulting from rupturing or "leaking" of an intracranial aneurysm.
The primary hypothesis of this research is that patients who receive neurochecks every-other-hour will have better sleep quality, as measured by sleep efficiency, less wakefulness, less disruption of slow wave and REM, and higher REM and slow wave percentages.
The primary outcome of this research is the assessment of sleep parameters via standardized polysomnography monitoring following randomization of neurochecks to those performed every hour versus every other hour. Polysomnography measurement at the bedside will take place in a research quality sleep study room within 24-hours post-ICU enrollment.
The secondary outcome of this study is the assessment of sleep quality via the patient's recollection of their sleep experience. This will be obtained using a validated sleep questionnaire (Richards Campbell Sleep Questionnaire) within the 24-hour post ICU awakening window.
A one-group assignment for neurocheck frequency allows the evaluation of both the every hour and every other hour groups to the same group of patients.

The investigators will examine data from consecutive patients at each site treated between 1/1/1999 and 12/31/2020. Patients must fulfil all these criteria: i. Been treated for oral cavity, oropharyngeal, carcinoma of unknown primary, laryngeal, or hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma and be over the age of 18. ii. The participants must have been treated with curative intent via surgery, radiotherapy, or chemoradiotherapy or a combination within the study inclusion period. iii. The participants must have had CT or/and MRI scans of the neck, performed within 12 weeks before the start of treatment. iv. Results for the presence or absence of extranodal extension on CT or/and MRI scans, or ability to report them within the deadline period. v. For surgically-treated patients: Results for the presence or absence of both extranodal extension on histopathology and on radiology, or ability to report them within the deadline period. vi. Must have had at least two years of follow-up, or death. vii. Data on staging must be available at least in TNM 7th edition or later editions. Exclusion Criteria: i. Patients who were diagnosed with distant metastasis at presentation. ii. Patients treated palliatively at first presentation iii. Patients presenting with recurrent disease who don't meet all the eligibility criteria above -

Diabetes mellitus is a major risk factor of amputations worldwide. Diabetic foot osteomyelitis (DFO) is an important cause of amputations. Management of DFO requires appropriate antimicrobial treatment according to the causative microorganisms. However, medical therapy of osteomyelitis depends on an invasive and uncomfortable technique called bone biopsy which might be done surgically or radiologically. In order to overcome these barriers, clinicians have designed a bedside blind bone biopsy procedure that could be performed by the physician at the bedside in a simple manner. The bedside technique is cheaper, safer and seems to be as efficient as the conventional techniques. For these reasons, we propose to compare outcomes and costs between the use of this bedside bone biopsy and the conventional methods.
The primary objective of the study is to estimate the difference in remission of DFO between the 2 groups of biopsy at 12 months. Remission is defined as the epithelization of the ulcer with absence of infection or pain and no loss of limb function. The second objective of this study is to estimate the costs associated with each procedure and to describe the quality of life of patients with diabetic foot using quality of life scores.

Study Overview

How is the study designed?

Design Details

Arms and Interventions

| --- |
|Device: UBaND platform|Mothers are given a smart phone to answer a survey and to provide their contact information. Mothers are invited to answer surveys at specific intervals (typically bi-annually) up to 1 year. Surveys are based on a smart phone app developed for this study. One survey after birth, a survey at one month post-partum, and others after that (at 3, 6, and 12 months). If the mother agrees to participate, she is given the smart phone along-side a rechargeable power bank to provide the phone with power. The phone contains the study app, which is used to collect information from the mother. The app has been developed to ensure that surveys are answered in a step wise fashion. At the start of the survey, there are one or two questions which have to be answered in order to unlock the next set of questions. The app requires a mother to provide contact information. This contact information is used to send a link to a survey. Once the previous survey has been completed and submitted (via the app) a new survey link appears. If a mother fails to answer the survey within 5 days of the survey link being sent (up to five times), she is considered to have dropped out of the study. The app is in English and Swahili, and each survey is presented in the language preferred by the mother. The survey questions are standard questions about maternal and child health, collected through smart phones throughout the world. The mother's personal information is stored in the phone (name, home address, contact information). Mothers are not identified by anything other than a survey unique identifier, and the study team has no ability to see a mother's identity, as this information is encrypted and stored in the phone.|

Although alveolar bone loss following tooth extraction occurs in both the gingival and the interproximal regions, the interproximal bone loss is a significant concern. There are three ways of preserving the alveolar ridge after the extraction of multi-rooted teeth: 1) implant placement without flap elevation; 2) coverage of the tooth extraction socket with a blood clot; 3) coverage with various soft tissue flaps and grafts. The aim of this study is to compare the effect of alveolar ridge preservation based on connective tissue grafting and using a freeze/thaw bone particle allograft combined with an acellular collagen membrane with the alvografted with membrane and collagen membrane only for interproximal bone loss. A secondary aim of the study is to characterize the alterations after alveolar ridge preservation procedure and after implant placement in the same ridge.

Background: The emergence of coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has brought challenges to patients with liver diseases, including autoimmune liver diseases such as primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) and autoimmune hepatitis (AIH). As an effective drug, UDCA may have antiviral and antagonistic effects. To investigate the incidence of COVID-19 infection, clinical manifestations, and outcomes of PBC and AIH patients infected with COVID-19 and treated with or without UDCA.
Objective: To observe the incidence of COVID-19 infection, clinical manifestations and outcomes of UDCA treated and non UDCA treated PBC and AIH patients, and to observe the clinical prognosis, laboratory indicators and imaging changes of COVID-19 in patients with UDCA during the treatment period.
Methods: Prospective, open-label, two-way (retrospective + prospective) cohort study, including 1000 cases of PBC and AIH diagnosed and treated in Beijing Ditan Hospital, Capital Medical University from January 2021 to December 2023.
Patients with autoimmune liver disease diagnosed during the observation period from January 2021 to December 2023, and PBC and AIH infected by SARS-Cov2 (COVID-19 positive diagnostic criteria: positive nucleic acid or presence of specific IgM and IgG antibody) were included.
Patients were divided into UDCA treated group and non UDCA treated group, then UDCA dose was further subdivided.
After enrollment, baseline information and clinical manifestations of COVID-19 patients and liver disease patients were observed, and the difference of UDCA use was analyzed in the treatment of COVID-19 infection.
During the prospective observation period, the occurrence and incidence of COVID-19 infection were observed. And the difference of UDCA use was analyzed in the treatment and prognosis of COVID-19 infection in patients with autoimmune liver diseases.
Discussion: This study will provide important insights into the incidence of COVID-19 infection and clinical manifestations in patients with liver diseases with or without UDCA, and may inform the treatment of this patient population during future outbreaks of COVID-19. As a retrospective and prospective study, it can provide basic data for the treatment of other coronavirus related viral diseases.

Background: The laparoscopic colorectal surgery can reduce the trauma of operation compared with traditional open abdominal approach, but some complications still occur. Postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) are common, which lead to increased morbidity, mortality , length of postoperative hospital stay and medical consumption. The present study aims to investigate effect of prone position training in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery.
Methods: This is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial guided by the standards of good clinical practice. All eligible participants are divided into two groups: group PPT and group C, and primary outcome the incidence of pulmonary complications after laparoscopic colorectal cancer surgery.
Objective: 1) Assess the reduction in the incidence of PPCs after laparoscopic colorectal cancer surgery performed in the prone position group compared with the control group; 2) Evaluate the effect of intraoperative prone position on arterial blood gases and the requirement of postoperative ventilator support; 3) Investigate the influence of intra-operative prone position on intensive care length, postoperative mechanical ventilator requirement; 4) Observe the complication of pulmonary complications after laparoscopic colorectal cancer surgery.

Official Title:  Effect of Preoperative Prone Position Training on Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery

Conditions: Pulmonary complication

Intervention / Treatment:
- Behavioral: Prone Position Training
- Behavioral: control group


Patients and Methods: The present study is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial conducted in the First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University from October 2018 to April 2019. Two group of patients were allocated into the study. All patients were divided into two groups: group PPT and group C. Patients in the intervention group (PPT group) received the prone position training (PPT) daily in the hospital, three times a day, and about 1 hours every times, for at least 3 days before surgery. Patients in the control group (C group) received standard perioperative care without any prone position training. The primary goal of the PPCs was the main measure in this study. It included pulmonary infection, atelectasis, pleural effusion, bronchospasm, respiratory failure, and unplanned intubations within 7 days after surgery. Secondary outcome measures were the arterial partial pressure of oxygen, oxygenation index, extubation time, peak airway pressure, and arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide.

Statistical Analysis: Baseline characteristics were presented as mean ± standard deviation or median and interquartile range. Categorical data were presented as frequency and percentage. The differences among groups were tested by the independent sample t-test or Mann-Whitney U test for continuous variables and by the Pearson chi-squared test, or Fisher's exact test for binary variables. All statistical analyses were performed with the SPSS software (Statistical Product and Service Solutions (SPSS) for Windows, Version 19, IBM, Armonk, NY). A p-value less than .05 was considered statistically significant. All statistical analyses were performed with the SPSS software (Statistical Product and Service Solutions (SPSS) for Windows, Version 19, IBM, Armonk, NY).

A phase I/II open label clinical trial is expected to launch to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 combined with chemotherapy drugs Pemetrexed and Cisplatin in patients with advanced Inoperable or Metastatic EGFR wild-type Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer. The maximum daily dose of BLEX 404 that will be tolerated by these patients will be determined in this phase I study. The dose obtained in phase I will be used as the therapeutic dose in the phase II study. The purpose of this clinical trial is to find the right dose and to collect information on the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 combined with Pemetrexed and Cisplatin. The findings will contribute to determining the most appropriate dose to advance further into clinical development.

<|assistant|> This study focuses on the effect of AGE SELF CARE, a novel group-based program tailored to the social and physical needs of community-dwelling older adults. The investigators will evaluate preliminary evidence of the feasibility, acceptability, participation rates, and impact of this novel approach to healthy aging. The long-term goal of this project is to improve the quality of life in older adults aging with frailty and enhance efforts to move aging individuals toward the robust end of the aging spectrum. This project will increase understanding of the ways in which group-based, lifestyle-focused interventions may improve quality of life and functional independence in older adults with frailty. The investigators will utilize a novel 8-week multi-disciplinary group visit program targeted to those individuals pre-frail and living in their communities. The program will be evaluated using a self-report survey, quantitative frailty measures with objective measurements, and qualitative interviews with participants. This project addresses the need to implement, monitor, and adapt lifestyle interventions that can improve the quality of life and functional independence of older adults affected by frailty. In addition, the program will generate evidence critical for the effectiveness of the future implementation of community-wide programs for older adults. If effective this program will support healthy aging by empowering individuals to take a proactive role in leading active, engaged, and healthy lives. By conducting a pilot study, we will be able to build a strong foundation for future trials. The proposed study will lay the groundwork for a larger randomized clinical trial (RCT) to further build momentum for this community-based behavioral intervention for healthy aging in older adults with frailty. Eighty-five percent of the adult population over 65 in the United States lives in their homes. Individuals with frailty-the stage between robust and very old-have a higher risk of dying, functional decline, hospitalization, and institutionalization. Frailty occurs across the age spectrum, beginning as early as age 45 and progressing with age. The goal of this program is to promote healthy behaviors of older adults to build resilience to the social and physical risk factors associated with aging. Aims: The long-term goal of this project is to create an optimally formulated, high impact community-based group visit program tailored to the needs of older adults as they age with frailty. The investigators will conduct a pilot trial (n=12) of the Adaptation, Growth and Engagement; Socialization, Empowerment, Learning, and Function; and Community Activation for Resilience in Elderhood (AGE SELF CARE) group visit program for pre-frail older adults living in their communities. The investigators will recruit pre-frail adults aged 65 and older who reside in the community to participate in AGE SELF CARE. The following specific aims will be addressed to lay the groundwork for a future, larger multi-center randomized clinical trial (RCT). - Aim 1: Evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a one-year multi-disciplinary group visit program for pre-frail older adults to inform future interventions for this population. - Aim 2: Evaluate the impact of AGE SELF CARE on self-efficacy, health behaviors, depressive symptoms, anxiety, sleep, physical function, and social connectedness by using a self-report survey and objective quantitative frailty measures with pre- and post-program assessments. Participant Group/Arm | Intervention/Treatment | | --- | | Experimental: AGE SELF CARE group visit program
Participants will take part in 8 weekly 90-minute virtual group visit program sessions | Behavioral: AGE SELF CARE group visit program

It includes education and behavioral change elements in the broad areas of self/health, home environment, and community. There are 8 weekly 90-minute virtual sessions facilitated by an aging expert (e.g., geriatrician). Examples of topics include Aging Well: The Power of Movement, People Can Change, Homes Can Too, and Social World.

The majority of patients that are admitted to the hospital are older (>70 years), and some of them have been, or are being, admitted to Intensive Care Units. Many patients stay on the ICU/hospital for weeks. To get back to the highest state of functional independence, these patients will need specialised care and treatment, therefore Geriatric Rehabilitation (GR) will be very likely required. We know from the first lessons from Italy, that the rehabilitation process is difficult, and the course is capricious. Before being able to assure the best outcomes for older post-COVID geriatric rehabilitation patients, we will have to be informed about the specific clinical characteristics, treatment modalities, and outcomes of these patients. Therefore, we decided to conduct this study into usual care data on the course of functional and clinical outcomes in post-COVID-19 geriatric rehabilitation patients, in several large European countries.

This study will investigate the benefits of resistance exercise for partially burned patients with a specific area of burning. The research aims to compare the level of plasma liver enzymes level between patients receiving resistance exercise with a group who receives routine physical therapy program. The study will include 30 patients in a randomized blind study. The group that receives the resistance exercise program will receive three circuits of exercises three times a week using dumbbells and sands bags for eight weeks in addition the routine physical therapy program. The group that receives only the routine therapy program will also receive treatment for eight weeks and will have no resistance exercises. The study will assess the plasma liver enzymes levels pre and post the eight weeks exercise program and compare it between both groups.

Neck pain and associated problems are prevalent among cervical spondylotic patients, and it is the most common complaint made by patients with chronic neck pain. Different interventions have been tested for the treatment of neck pain in general and for cervical spondylosis in particular. Although the evidence is limited, physical therapy interventions appear to be beneficial for such pain. However, there is a need for high quality evidence using specific intervention protocols.
The upper fibers of trapezius muscle is considered to be a common cause of pain and disability of patients with cervical spondylosis. Stretching the upper fibers of the trapezius muscle has been suggested to improve cervical spine and shoulder range of motion, reduce pain, and improve function in patients with cervical spondylosis. However, there is very little evidence to support or refute the efficacy of this treatment. This study aims to compare the effects of trapezius upper fibers stretching with a control group, with respect to neck pain, cervical range of motion, neck disability, cervical kyphotic angle and cervical dorsal extension flexion angles between groups.
Fourteen patients will be randomly allocated to one of the two groups: intervention group (trapezius upper fibers stretching) or control group (control stretching).
Patients will attend to a rehabilitation center for 3 months for daily therapy with trapezius upper fibers stretching or control stretching. The intervention group will perform trapezius upper fibers stretching exercises three times daily, while the control group will perform control exercises three times daily. Each session will take approximately 30 minutes. The study therapist will closely monitor the exercises and assist the patients if necessary.
This study is designed to evaluate the effects of upper fibers of trapezius stretching on neck pain, cervical range of motion, disability and cervical mobility in patients with cervical spondylosis. We will also assess the feasibility of applying trapezius upper fibers stretching exercises in patients with cervical spondylosis.

Deep thermotherapy (heat applied to the skin in the form of radiofrequency, diathermy or electromagnetic devices that generate currents at high frequencies) has been traditionally used in rehabilitation for the treatment of muscle, bone, ligament and tendon injuries.
Recently, the increase of temperature has been observed in deep tissues during the passage of electrical currents. Based on this, Cret Therapy (Deep Tissue Capacitive Resistive Electrical Transfer, Tecar) is a new technology derived from the traditional use of superficial thermometry.
The aim of this study is to characterize a non-invasive therapeutic device based on the application of radiofrequency (TECARTHERAPY). The purpose is to assess the effects of this type of therapy on sportsmen, specifically on functional variables such as 30-meter sprint, maximal isometric contraction and jumps, in relation to their training load in a 1-month follow-up. It also aims to determine whether the effectiveness of this therapy is due to the increase in muscle temperature, increased blood flow, or increased cell proliferation.

<|assistant|>
In France, about 10 to 15% of couples wishing to procreate are affected by primary or secondary sterility, which most often leads them to resort to Assisted Reproductive Techniques (ART) including in vitro fertilization (IVF). Endometriosis appears as a major factor of infertility in women. Estimates show that about 20% of women who consult for infertility are affected by endometriosis, and that almost half of women suffering from endometriosis are infertile.
The pathophysiology of endometriosis involves the appearance of cells of endometrial origin (endogenous endometriosis) outside the uterus. When these cells penetrate through the peritoneal lining, they colonize the peritoneal walls, the surface of the ovaries and the internal surface of the uterus causing peritoneal adhesions and the appearance of cysts. Endometriosis often compromises ovarian function by inducing subclinical or silent inflammation. This inflammation and oxidation can compromise the oocyte quality and its competence to be fertilized and then develop in vitro.
It is important to underline the poor prognosis of women suffering from endometriosis but wishing to procreate: the rate of pregnancy is 10% lower in women with endometriosis in comparison to women without endometriosis with ART and the rate of live-birth is only 20% lower.
The main goal of this study is to investigate the link between endometriosis and cell free DNA (cfDNA) quantification in blood and follicular fluids.
Thus, the hypothesis of our study is that patients with endometriosis have a higher level of cfDNA quantification in their follicular fluids before IVF stimulation in comparison to other infertility causes. The level of cfDNA quantification in blood may be related to the number of oocytes retrieved, the fragmentation rate of these oocytes, the blastulation rate of embryos, and the number of clinical pregnancy before IVF stimulation.

Methodology: Design: Randomized clinical trial (RCT). Subjects' criteria: Fifty adult sickle cell disease patients who are aged more than 18 years with different socio-economic and educational levels. Patients with sickle cell anemia will be distributed into two groups. All personal data will be collected. Group-1: Twenty-five adult patents with SCD will receive a designed exercise program of physical therapy for relief pain and improve sleeping quality (experimental group). The designed exercise program will be distributed on everyone. The recommendations will be to train from 30 to 45 minutes, 3 days per week for 6 weeks in addition to walking daily 30 minutes on the ground surface. Group-2: Twenty-five adult patients with SCD will participate as a control group they will not receive exercise program. Assessment instruments: Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index: The (PSQI) is a 19-item instrument created to measure different aspects of sleep quality and sleep disturbance (Buysse, Reynolds, Monk, Berman, & Kupfer, 1989). The scale reports quality of sleeping over the past month. The PSQI is divided into 7 subscale scores: subjective sleep quality; sleep latency (time of full sleep); duration; habitual sleep efficiency (proportion between total sleep time and time in bed); sleep disturbances (waking up during the night); use of medication to sleep; and daytime dysfunction (difficulty staying awake during daytime). The overall score ranges between 0 and 21, and a total score of more than 5 indicates poor sleep quality(Al Maqbali et al., 2020). WHOQOL-BREF: The World Health Organization (WHO) identified Quality of Life (QoL) as an individual's perception of his or her position in life, within the context of the culture and value systems in which they live, and in regard to his or her goals, expectations, standards and concerns . QoL is consist of multiple aspects, including psychological health, physical well-being, social relationships, and environmental conditions. Although health professionals are trained on attending to these aspects during studies, own QoL might decline during the years in medical schools(Bani-Issa, 2011). Visual Analog Scale: VAS: It is a safe, valid, and reliable measurement instrument used to evaluate pain severity. It was designed by Huskisson to quantify values that could not be measured in numbers. The most important advantage of the test is the lack of a language barrier and simplicity of application. The definition of the parameter to be assessed is written at the two ends of a 10 cm line, and the patient marks on the line the point that they feel represents their perception of their current state. The VAS score is determined by measuring in millimeters from the left hand end of the line to the point that the patient marks (Kazak and Ozkaraman, 2021, Crichton, 2001). Randomization type is blocking randomization. It will be taken by the main researcher using a random number generator by computer program software http://mahmoodsaghaei.tripod.com/Softwares/randalloc.html#Generate. Ethical approval: It will be obtained from the Institutional Review Board (IRB) at Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University. Confidentiality: All data of participants will be saved in a personal computer locked with a password. All questionnaires' papers will be kept with the main researcher in a locker. Patient's rights: All recruited patients will sign a consent form before their participation, and they will be informed that the collected data will be published. Inclusion criteria: SCD patient, aged < 18 years, have no communication problems, did not regularly perform relaxation exercises, and able to perform the exercises. Exclusion criteria: Patients with SCD who are aged less than 18, unable to do the exercises and had communication problems. Procedures of the study: Fifty adult patients with SCD, will be randomly assigned to either experimental or control group. All patients will receive face-to-face instructions and explanations about the procedure of the study and assessment tools. The training period will take 6 weeks (details pertaining to the program which will be specified below) and the post-test including the same measures of the VAS, PSQI, WHOQOL-BREF, The Fatigue Scale and The PSS at the end of the 6-week program. Group-I: Every patient will practice on exercise program for 30 to 45 minutes day other day for 6

There is currently no way to prevent dementia. This study is a two-arm randomized pragmatic (non-blinded) trial to assess the effectiveness and usability of V-CST (tele-CST). We will offer all participants with the opportunity to participate in tele-CST.

The primary goal is to compare the outcomes between those who attend V-CST and those who do not. These outcomes will include cognitive decline (i.e. clinically meaningful cognitive decline, and clinically meaningful cognitive improvement), referral acceptance, attendance, and attrition of participants' at V-CST sessions. We will assess these outcomes at 6 months after baseline.

The secondary goal is to assess how tele-CST is perceived by the participants. A participant survey will explore the following topics: their experience with the treatment process, the technology used to conduct the tele-CST sessions, the content of the classes, and impact of COVID-19 on their ability to participate.

GERD is one of the most common gastroenterological disorders with a reported prevalence of 10% to 20% percent in Europe and the USA and less than 5% in Asia. GERD manifestas heartburn, regurgitation, retrosternal pain, cough, and in some cases dysphagia and holds the possible complication of a Barrett´s esophagus. Anxiety and depression have been reported to be independent risk factors for GERD and are associated with higher levels of anxiety and depression, and women are more likely to have these symptoms. Furthermore, the higher somatic symptom load is known to increase anxiety related to health issues, psychological distress and health care utilization. The modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms has been discussed as visceral hypersensitivity. Patients with GERD have a higher incidence of anxiety, depression and sleep disturbances than those without GERD, and GERD is considered to be an independent source of stress. The aim of the study was to assess anxiety and depression levels of patients with physiological as well as with pathological DeMeester scores. Furthermore, the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms such as fullness, heartburn and dysphagia is examined. In evaluating the HADS scores were grouped into subscales of HADS-A and HADS-D of =8 and >8 as anxious and those on the subscale of HADS-D of 8 and over 8 as depressed. It is differentiated between mildly (HADS score on the subscale 8-10), moderately (HADS 11 - 14) and severely (HADS 15 - 21) anxious or depressed. The DMS was differentiated between negative (physiological) (< 14.72) and positive (pathological) (> 14.72). The positive scores were differentiated into mild (14.72 - 30), moderate (30 - 80) and severe (<80). The HADS score, GERD questionnaire and DMS scores showed significant differences between the group with NERD and the group with ERD in age, anxiety and depression. The DMS scores in the subgroup of patients with severe depression and anxiety showed the highest DMS scores. In both subgroups of patients with severe anxiety or severe depression there were significantly higher DMS scores and more pathological DMS scores than in patients with negative DMS scores or in those with mild anxiety or depression. Severity of the DMS is significantly associated with anxiety and depression. In conclusion, there are interdependencies between GERD, anxiety and depression. Anxiety and depression increases the severity of reflux symptoms and higher levels of anxiety and depression are associated with higher levels of anxiety and depression. Higher levels of anxiety and depression intensify the sensation of reflux symptoms such as fullness, heartburn and dysphagia. Furthermore, anxiety and depression show an interaction with the severity of reflux symptoms.

GERD, Anxiety, Depression

Background: 
The adenoma detection rate (ADR) is a validated screening criterion that is used to evaluate the quality of colonoscopy examinations. Routine colonoscopy using chromoendoscopy and cap-guided colonoscopy has demonstrated a superior ADR compared with standard colonoscopy (33.6%vs. 15.5%, respectively). However, these methods are expensive. The implementation of a new system based on artificial intelligence (AI) could be valuable for a better ADR.
Lynch syndrome is a genetic syndrome where mutated genes increase the risk of developing colon cancer due to the accumulation of somatic mutations. People with Lynch syndrome have an 80% risk of developing colon cancer during their lifetime, most commonly a proximal neoplasm. Accordingly, the American society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy (ASGE) guidelines recommend colonoscopy screening for Lynch syndrome from 25 to 35 years. The diagnostic method for Lynch syndrome is currently based on blood relatives or mutational analysis of MLH1 or MSH2 genes. However patients at risk may have a mutation of one of the other gene involved in the mismatch repair and for that reason it has been proposed to change the guidelines to include a screening colonoscopy at age 20-30 years by using new detection methods for colorectal polyps. 
In case of Lynch syndrome, the adenoma detection rate (ADR) using 0.1% or 0.4% indigo carmine is around 45%. However, with the implementation of 0.4% indigo carmine, the cost of the screening colonoscopy would be more important. As a matter of fact, each examination would required at least three doses and the cost would be at least 50% higher. Moreover, 0.4% indigo carmine may not be available in certain regions of the world and patients may not agree to its application. Thus, using artificial intelligence might be a more cost-effective approach to improve adenoma detection rates
Study design: 
The CAD EYE system is a fully automated computer-assisted recognition of polyp and cancer that uses deep learning to analyze the 2D colonic image and detect the presence of abnormal lesions. In this study, the investigator wish to evaluate the performance of CAD EYE for a better adenoma detection rate in Lynch syndrome. The aim is a prospective randomized controlled study (Phase 4), consisting of an evaluation of the CAD EYE system in patients diagnosed with Lynch syndrome undergoing screening colonoscopy with white light and CE (0.4%). CAD EYE system will be switched on for the Lynch syndrome's patients in the study arm. The investigator also want to compare the detection rates of typical and atypical serrated lesions in each group. For that purpose, the investigator will collect a subsample of polyps (10%of the total polyps resected) that will be analyzed according to the Villanueva classification. The investigator also want to perform a retrospective pilot analysis of the reect and discard strategy for polyps with low risk of malignancy, using CAD EYE prediction and endoscopist's prediction. 
The investigator hope that this study will provide the following evidence: 
to evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD EYE system in screening for neoplastic lesions in Lynch syndrome, in terms of sensitivity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value for the characterization (adenoma/hyperplastic) of colonic polyps and rate of resect and discard strategy, and compare it with the indigo carmin chromoendoscopy, the reference technique for the detection of neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch syndrome.

Use of contrast-based protocols to assist in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO) remains poorly defined. We hypothesize that the use of water-soluble contrast protocols will reduce the need for operative intervention in this population.
At the start of the study, only 4 of 9 sites included had a contrast protocol for ASBO. During the course of the study, contrast protocols were developed and implemented at all sites. Study inclusion criteria were children 1-20 years diagnosed with ASBO on admission to the hospital by an attending pediatric surgeon and who underwent a trial of non-operative management. Exclusion criteria included peritonitis, suspicion of incarcerated or internal hernia, active intra-abdominal malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, <4 weeks since the most recent abdominal operation, pneumatosis, pneumoperitoneum, or known contrast allergy. If the attending surgeon made the decision to take a child directly to the operating room (OR) with no attempt at NOM, these children were excluded. Children under one year of age were excluded as the rate of successful NOM is lower in this age group.
The use of contrast agents is widely varied, no standardization exists regarding the use of contrast agents, protocols for administration, or timing of radiographs. Diatrizoate meglumine, with an osmolality of 1940mOsm/kg, was used preferentially at eight sites and ioversol (702mOsm/kg) at one site. Patients received 30-200ml (based on age or weight) of enteral contrast followed by X-rays at 8-12 hrs and 24 hrs after contrast administration. The investigators measured the need for laparotomy and overall success of non-operative management.
Logistic regression will be used to assess the association between need for operation and contrast. Subsequently, a subset analysis will be performed among patients who received enteral contrast. Comparisons will be made between those who received contrast and those who did not. In addition, based on volume and type of contrast agents used, a comparison will be made between those patients who received enteral contrast. Finally, a comparison will be made based upon contrast status between only those patients who were successfully managed non-operatively and then between those patients who required abdominal operation.
At enrollment, the enrolled patient population is small and this limits our ability to draw firm conclusions about the impact of contrast. Study recruitment will continue. Patient data will be collected and managed using the Research Electronic Data Capture (REDCap) software tool hosted at the University of Colorado. As of the time of analysis, 227 patients are enrolled into the study.

The pharmacokinetic study is designed to compare itepekimab exposures (e.g., concentration of serum Itepekimab [Cmax]) when subcutaneously administered with a novel Autoinjector (AI) (Cohort 1) compared to a prefilled syringe (Cohort 2) in healthy participants. The primary objectives are to assess the pharmacokinetic (PK) parameter of itepekimab including 1) Maximum plasma concentration of itepekimab (Cmax), 2) Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve calculated using the trapezoidal method from time zero to the real time tlast (AUClast) and 3) area under the plasma concentration versus time curve extrapolated to infinity (AUC). Secondary objectives include 1) time to reach Cmax of itepekimab (tmax), 2) bioequivalence comparison of itepekimab exposure data between AI versus PFS, 3) area under the serum concentration versus time curve calculated using the trapezoidal method from time zero to 28 days (AUC0-28days), 4) terminal half-life associated with the terminal slope (λz) (t1/2), 5) Apparent total body clearance of a drug from the serum (CL/F), 6) Apparent Volume of Distribution at the steady state (Vss/F), 7) Incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses and 8) Number of participants with Adverse Events (including injection site reactions), Serious Adverse Events (SAE), Adverse Event of Special Interest (AESI).

Background: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), National Cancer Institute (NCI), and Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have set a 2021 deadline for 60% decrease in combustible cigarette consumption among all U.S. cigarette smokers and a corresponding, 81% reduction in the number of smoking-attributable deaths. The purpose of this multi-site, randomized, open-label, prospective observational study (Actual Use Study) is to assess the relative impact of availability of different ENDS (e-cigarette based) flavors on changes in cigarette consumption over eight weeks among US adult combustible cigarette smokers, who will have the freedom to use the assigned TNPs for ad libitum consumption during this period of time. By exposing combustible cigarette smokers to a range of e-products, from a standard tobacco flavor, to menthol flavors, non-tobacco/non-menthol flavor profiles and nicotine-containing formulations, insights may be gained into: the relative impact of different types of TNPs on cigarette substitution patterns; potential risk reduction benefits of these products (i.e. harm reduction); and consumer satisfaction with various TNP flavors.  The study has been designed to evaluate the impact of 6 different TNP flavor variants (13 total flavors), using 2 different nicotine levels (1.5% and 5%) within two tobacco flavors (tobacco and menthol) and four non tobacco/non menthol flavors (including three single flavor variants and one flavor blend variant) on cigarette consumption and the perceived product performance (including ease of use, flavor intensity and duration, and satisfaction levels) among US adult, current combustible cigarette smokers.

Background: Changing patterns in the gut-flora-microbiome have been implicated in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The microbiome is a composite of commensals bacteria that are both beneficial and harmful to health. Preclinical studies suggest that dysbiosis can contribute to the onset and persistence of inflammatory diseases. It is conceivable that early therapeutic interventions may offer a treatment option for IBD. Objective: Primary objectives of this study are clinical remission and endoscopic response (based on CDAI score <150 points and Simple endoscopic score for Crohn's disease score ≤2) at week 26. Secondary targets are clinical remission at multiple time points and deep remission defined as absence of ulcerative lesions in the small or large bowel of those with endoscopically visible inflammation at baseline. Methods: This is a multicenter, open-label, two-arm prospective non-inferiority study. Moderate to severe Crohn's disease patients are treated with subcutaneous infliximab (IFX) 240mg at week 0 and 2 and then from week 4, 120mg s.c. The IFX monotherapy group starts with IFX 240mg at week 0 and 2 and then from week 4, 120mg s.c. EOW. The combination therapy group starts with IFX 240mg at week 0 and 2 and then from week 4, 120mg s.c. EOW. And 6mpt/MPA/TGN is started from week 0 at a dose of 12-25mg if the patient has not been treated before with an immunosuppressive. If intolerable, methotrexate is started. Clinical remission, endoscopic response, adverse events, IFX trough levels, anti-drug antibodies (ADA), histological healing is assessed at week 0 and 26. Endoscopy is performed at week 0 and 26 or if clinically indicated. Quality of life is assessed using EuroQol-5Dimension-5Level (EQ-5D-5L); the IBD questionnaire (IBDQ); patients with perianal disease are evaluated using the Fistula drainage assessment. Results of this study will help to design future studies. Prospective multicenter studies are required to establish this concept further in the future. Aim: A Multicenter prospective non-inferiority study to compare the efficacy (clinical and endoscopic response) by week 26 of induction therapy in IBD of subcutaneous Infliximab monotherapy with IFX and concomitant immunomodulators.

Background: Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) is described as a lung disease characterized by obliteration of the small airways and subsequent loss of the affected lung volume. The true incidence and cause of BO is unknown, although there is an association between BO and previous infectious diseases, radiation or drug toxicity. BO presents as slowly progressive disease or pulmonary dysfunction leading to a reduced quality of life (QOL), especially when associated with chronic hypoxemia. According to the European Society of Respiratory Disease and the American Thoracic Society/European Respiratory Society (ERS/ATS) 2001 consensus document, the diagnostic criteria of BO are: The main diagnostic feature is a chest X-ray appearance, which is consistent with bronchiolitis but the degree of obstruction cannot be demonstrated by pulmonary function testing (PFT). The lack of response to corticosteroid therapy, and the radiological disappearance after repeated therapy, may be considered supportive evidence. However, BO has been reported to be associated with BDR.
Methods: The study arms consist of four groups: A healthy control group will serve as an internal control group. This group is deemed to be healthy and does not have any previous medical conditions that indicate any type of obstructive or restrictive lung disease. A chronic lung disease group which includes different types of ILD that may obstruct lung function. This group is deemed to have obstructive lung disease. A BO group which is composed of participants who have been diagnosed as having BO. The fourth group includes participants who have been diagnosed with other types of obstructive lung disease and may serve as another internal control group. These participants will serve as both an external and internal control group.
Our primary goal is to compare the bronchodilator response in healthy controls, individuals with obstructive, and restrictive lung disease, and individuals who have been diagnosed as having BO.
Significance: This study is important in characterizing the airway obstruction in the obstructed lungs of patients with different types (and severity) of lung disease, in comparison to the healthy lung. Additionally, it will be valuable in determining if there is any bronchodilator responsiveness in patients with bronchiolitis obliterans; as this may help in the management of this difficult disease.

The presence of sex, gender, and hormones influence pain perception and expression in healthy volunteers and chronic pain patients. Despite this, there is very little research on this topic, and we have no knowledge of how the pain experience (i.e., thresholds and tolerance) might be influenced by gender identity, hormonal status, and genetic sex. These factors interact in complex ways, and their contributions to pain sensitivity remain under-explored.
Transgenderism involves gender-affirming medical transition, and this has a well-documented impact on pain sensitivity. Transgender individuals experience a number of psychiatric and psychosocial difficulties, including anxiety, depression, poor body image and social support, and negative life events, including discrimination (i.e. perceived societal stigma and rejection) that may impact pain perception and expression. The hormonal changes (e.g., decreases in estrogen or increases in testosterone) that accompany medical transition can influence immune function, and, in turn, alter the response to acute and chronic pain. A better understanding of the role of gender identity in pain sensitivity is important in order to provide better pain management for this population.
It is widely accepted that sex differences are the result of a complex interplay of genetic, hormonal and environmental influences. Females have higher pain sensitivity and experience higher rates of chronic pain conditions than males, including fibromyalgia, tension headaches and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Conversely, males have higher rates of traumatic brain injury and chronic musculoskeletal disorders resulting from workplace injuries and sports-related injuries. While these sex differences may reflect actual biological differences, they may also reflect cultural expectations and gender-associated differences in pain report and treatment seeking behaviour, as well as differences in physical activity.
The primary goal of this study is to examine how self-reported gender identity and hormone levels affect endogenous pain modulation. We hypothesize that gender identity will impact pain sensitivity and will not be related to hormone levels or genetic sex. Our secondary aim is to examine the role of social and psychological factors (e.g., levels of sleep, depression, social support and perceived discrimination) as potential predictors of pain sensitivity in trans and cisgender individuals. The immune system is also affected by these variables and may influence how individuals respond to pain. Our third aim is to examine immune cell populations and their activity in order to understand differences between our groups. If differences in pain sensitivity are found, we also aim to identify a potential blood-based biomarker that would allow clinicians to predict pain sensitivity in transgender individuals.
If you are interested in participating in this study, please contact the investigators.

The feasibility of technology enriched stroke rehabilitation for in-patients post acute stroke will be evaluated within the NHS setting at University Hospital Wishaw, in order to assess the practicalities of implementing this intervention within routine clinical practice. The study aims to test the acceptability of using technology to increase stroke rehabilitation activity and assess feasibility of the model; patient recruitment, adherence, feasibility of participant's/families using the technology, acceptability of the equipment and space, staff feedback, and acceptability of outcome measures among participants, families, and staff. It is hoped that this study will demonstrate the practicalities of implementing a scaled up technology enriched approach to stroke rehabilitation. If successful, the development of this feasibility study could support the development of a full-scale, multi-site trial powered to detect effects on functional recovery. Ultimately, it is our vision that this model of rehabilitation will lead to more rapid recovery for patients after stroke, improve health service efficiency and reduce costs, and lead to better outcomes for patients across Scotland and beyond.
The conditions we are focusing on are stroke, and we are targeting a specific population of adults (aged 18 and over) hospitalised with stroke who are deemed to be medically fit for rehabilitation by the multidisciplinary NHS team. Exclusion criteria are based on factors such as active delirium, excessive pain or tonal problems.
The intervention we are exploring is the technology enriched stroke rehabilitation model, which involves supported use of stroke rehabilitation technology such as robotic devices, virtual reality, and mobile digital devices (such as smartphones, tablets and wearable sensors) as part of routine care. Participants will be supported by NHS staff to use the technology under the supervision of therapy professionals, with the intention of enhancing standard NHS care.
The methodology of this study involves a feasibility phase, with both quantitative (time and movement repetitions) and qualitative measures being deployed to assess the intervention. We will recruit a convenient sample of inpatients into the study and will evaluate the acceptability, adherence and feasibility of implementing this care model in the NHS. We will be working in collaboration with UoS research and NHS occupational therapist colleagues.

In this study, 20 ALS patients undergoing treatment by NIV with persistent dyspnea are planned to be included. Patients will undergo the following tests: collection of sociodemographic data and data related to the disease (respiratory function tests, polysomnography) and the functional state (sclae of physical activity and fatigue, sclae of anxiety and depression). Then, patients will be randomized into two groups: one will be tested first by immersive virtual reality (IVR) and the other by music therapy (music). Each session will last 15 minutes. These interventions will be evaluated in terms of their effect on respiratory discomfort and preference of one treatment rather than the other. Finally, the effect of these treatments on the overall quality of life and the acceptability of immersive virtual reality (IVR) by the patients will be evaluated. The main outcome of this study is the decrease in dyspnea perception at rest evaluated by the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile questionnaire in two dimensions: sensorial (QS) and affective (A1, A2).

The purpose of this study is to assess the effectiveness of a selective reporting on broad-spectrum antibiotics consumption for women with E. coli urinary tract infection. Selective reporting consists in sending antibiotic susceptibility testing results for a population subset (those with E. coli susceptible to narrow-spectrum antibiotics) which, for the others (mostly E. coli extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) producer), only recommends the use of broader antibiotics.
The primary endpoint is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing (defined as the rate of urine cultures associated with a prescription to broad-spectrum antibiotics in the period from 3 days before to 5 days after the antibiotic susceptibility testing result) among patients for whom antibiotics were prescribed.
The secondary endpoints are the rate of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, the antibiotic de-escalation rate, the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing as a function of the number of selective antibiotic susceptibility testings received per practice, as a continuous variable (dose-effect) and ordinal variable (threshold-effect), the characteristics of patients and general practitioners, and the E. coli antimicrobial susceptibility profiles.
The trial has the two-arms design: 1. The intervention group that will receive the selective antibiotic susceptibility testing and 2. The control group which will receive the usual antibiotic susceptibility report. The primary analysis will be the comparison of the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing in the control and intervention arms.

Ischemic stroke is one of the leading causes of disability and mortality worldwide, which imposes a huge burden on families and society. Currently, the effective treatment strategies of ischemic stroke are limited. It is of great clinical value and significance to explore effective neuroprotective medications besides reperfusion therapy. Sodium valproate is widely used in clinical practice, and its safety and tolerability has been confirmed. It is mainly used in the treatment of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain and other diseases. In recent years, a number of preclinical studies have found that valproic acid has a potential neuroprotective effect in acute ischemic brain injury, which can decrease infarct volume, reduce blood-brain barrier damage, and improve neurological function. However, the neuroprotective mechanism of sodium valproate has not been fully revealed, and there is still a lack of clinical studies to clarify the neuroprotective effect of sodium valproate in patients with ischemic stroke. The goal of this study is to test whether sodium valproate could become a new therapeutic approach to improve the functional outcome after ischemic stroke. This prospective pilot study is intended to clarify whether the use of sodium valproate in patients with acute ischemic stroke can improve clinical outcomes, and to explore the mechanism: whether valproate could increase peripheral anti-inflammatory CD177+ neutrophils levels to reduce neuroinflammation caused by the infiltrated peripheral immune cells. Patients with acute ischemic stroke included in the study will be randomly assigned to low-dose sodium valproate group, high-dose sodium valproate group and placebo group. Besides receiving conventional treatment for stroke, 10mg/kg sodium valproate, 20mg/kg sodium valproate or normal saline were given intravenously for 3 consecutive days, respectively. The investigators evaluate whether sodium valproate can improve clinical outcomes and increase peripheral CD177+ neutrophil levels.

Recent studies have demonstrated that patients with Ventral Hernia (VH) have high rates of obesity, with rates as high as 80% and morbidity rates from the initial surgery of up to 37%. Obesity is also associated with poor wound healing, increased risk of incisional hernia formation, higher rates of re-operation, and increased morbidity and mortality of any surgical intervention. Multiple attempts have also been made to decrease these poor outcomes with pre-operative weight loss, but with low compliance rates. Studies have demonstrated that a well-designed virtual coach is an effective tool to help patients adhere to weight loss recommendations and aid in weight loss while awaiting a primary repair for VH. With the advent of MyChart, an easy to use, free resource for most patients, a similar type of study can now be conducted to evaluate its effectiveness in the pre-operative setting of ventral hernia repair.

The purpose of this study is to assess the effectiveness of utilizing MyChart enabled virtual coaches via a patient-centered app versus the use of standard pre-operative weight loss tools. There is little current data to suggest what the most effective measures are to promote pre-operative weight loss in patients with VHs. Recent data published by our own institution showed that only 37% of patients achieved weight loss (>10%) with standard weight loss advice, and few studies have ever demonstrated a significant impact of pre-operative weight loss in patients with VH. The primary hypothesis is that the virtual Coach will result in more weight loss in patients presenting for repair of VH compared to the control group. It is also hypothesized that patients in the virtual coach group will show significant improvements in satisfaction with weight loss compared to standard care measures. Ultimately, improved satisfaction may correlate with higher compliance rates.

Inclusion criteria: Subjects between 18 and 90 years of age with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30 and above and diagnosed with Obesity by the ICD 10 Code: E66.9 who have been evaluated by a surgeon and offered elective ventral hernia repair. Also, participants must have a complete medical record that allows for all statistical calculations to be performed.

Exclusion criteria: Pregnant females, patients with severe mental disorders, prescribed psychiatric medications associated with weight gain, a history of Substance Use Disorder, patients on long-term steroid therapy, and patients with insufficient medical records.

Participants will be randomized into two groups: A Control Group - where patients will receive standard weight loss tools. The control group will be provided with standard tools for weight loss (i.e. hand outs, pamphlets on healthy eating, advice from medical providers, etc.). A virtual Coach Group - where patients will utilize the newly designed MyChart enabled virtual coach to aid pre-operative weight loss. COVID-19, also known as the novel coronavirus pneumonia, is sweeping the world. To date, there is no known effective drug to deal with COVID-19. Many countries and regions have adopted lockdown, isolation, and quarantine, in order to limit the spread of this disease. In recent years, there have been a number of clinical studies using stem cell interventions to treat infectious diseases including COVID-19. These studies have provided an alternative strategy to conventional therapies aimed at alleviating the complications caused by COVID-19. Therefore, in response to the current epidemic, this project proposes the clinical application of mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes for the treatment of moderate, severe and critically ill COVID-19 patients. This is through the evaluation of the safety and effectiveness of intracerebrally injected exosomes in combination with conventional COVID-19 therapy to achieve the goal of reducing disease progression and duration of hospitalization in COVID-19 patients, especially in severe cases. It is a multicenter, randomized controlled trial of moderate, severe and critically ill COVID-19 patients. Based on the current treatment plan, the experimental group will be treated with mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes, while the control group will be treated with a medical sterile saline solution. The time frame for this project is three months, and 300 cases are expected to be enrolled during this time. After the treatment, the condition of each patient will be compared with the clinical treatment guidelines formulated by various countries to evaluate their effectiveness. After the completion of this project, it will be easier for subsequent researchers to carry out advanced research in other directions, and the findings can be used in more in-depth clinical trials of MSC-exosomes for the treatment of COVID-19. The project has profound significance both for the promotion of basic research on stem cell technology and in the current fight against COVID-19.

One visit root canal therapy is one of the most accepted endodontic treatments and aims to achieve an immediate aseptic and painless treatment. Endodontic sealers are materials used to fill all root canals spaces after root canal preparation and obturation. Many types of endodontic sealers have been suggested, but calcium silicate-based sealer and Epoxy resin-based sealer are the most commonly used. Calcium silicate-based sealer can be used for emergency root canal treatment since it has biocompatibility and physiologic stability. However, Epoxy resin-based sealer can be used for routine root canal treatment since it has good working and sealing properties.
So the purpose of this study was to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of the two types of sealers; calcium silicate-based (White Mta) and Epoxy resin-based E-SEAL (Sybron Endo, USA) in one visit emergency root canal treatment.
Methods: A randomized clinical trial was carried out with the inclusion criteria of being patients referred for pain who received two-dimensional periapical radiographs and two-dimensional CBCT radiographs in the Department of Endodontic at the Faculty of Stomatognathic Science, Tay Do University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Vietnam National University. The participants were randomly divided into two groups: Epsiloy F group and White MTA group, where Epsiloy F was Epoxy resin-based sealer, and White MTA was Calcium silicate-based sealer. Both patients and observers were blindfolded to the treatment. After root canal preparation, root canal obturation followed by coronal sealing and temporary restoration was performed. The clinical outcomes were evaluated using Strindberg criteria, and patient pain was assessed using the VAS scale.
Results: A total of 154 teeth (154 patients) were included in the study, consisting of 156 Epsiloy F treated teeth and 158 White MTA treated teeth. The difference in the percentage of initial success and non-cultured success between groups was statistically significant. The average pain intensity (VAS) at the first 24 hours after treatment (p<0.05) showed no statistical difference between the two groups. In addition, there are no statistically significant differences in tooth pain at each follow-up assessment by VAS (p<0.05) and the tooth evaluation scores assessed according to Strindberg's criteria (p<0.05) between group Epsiloy F and group White MTA in the final assessment at 6 months.
Conclusions: The use of epoxy resin-based Sealer (Epsiloy F) in emergency root canal treatment does not lead to more adverse reactions than Calcium silicate-based sealer (White MTA). Therefore, Epoxy resin-based sealer can be used in clinical practice.

Research Background: Based on the new vaccine policy in China that focuses on reducing the risk of cervical cancer, the domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) was developed and approved for use in adolescent girls aged 9-14 years in 2016 years. The domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (Wozehui®) was granted a marketing authorization in July 2016 years, and the domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (Cecolin®) was granted a marketing authorization in August 2016 years. The domestic cervical cancer vaccines (Wozehui®) and international cervical cancer vaccines are the two most commonly used HPV vaccines worldwide. These two different HPV Vaccines have different antibody immune response mechanisms. In order to make the most of the policy and strengthen the use of local vaccines, it is necessary to confirm the effectiveness of the two domestic HPV vaccines, establish the immunological superiority of domestic bivalent HPV vaccines or domestic quadruple HPV vaccines, and finally determine the localization of HPV vaccines in the future. The study aims to: 1) Evaluate the immunogenicity of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) versus imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old; 2) Evaluate the immune persistence of two different domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) versus imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years old.
Official Title: Two Domestic HPV Vaccines (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) and Imported HPV Vaccines in Women Aged 13-14 Years Study on Immunogenicity: A Multi-center Cohort Study in China;
Conditions: HPV Infection, HPV Vaccine, Cervical Cancer Prevention;
Intervention / Treatment: * Other: Follow up;

Participation Criteria:

Eligibility Criteria

Eligibility Criteria are based on the condition that the participant's vaccination history must be known, as well as the inclusion and exclusion criteria for clinical trials.
Inclusion Criteria:
-Participants who have completed all procedures of domestic bivalent HPV vaccine or imported HPV vaccine are 30-60 days from the last dose of vaccination at the time of enrollment;

Homeopathy is a popular complementary therapy for patients with cancer. Aim of the study is therefore to evaluate the feasibility of the process of integrating homeopathy as a potential supportive approach in a comprehensive cancer center. 
In this observational study, participants will receive a consultation with a certified Homeopathic practitioner for 15-30 minutes while waiting at a cancer center in Rambam Health Campus. A questionnaire will be used to gather information regarding demographics and medical history. Participants will be able to choose their treatment plan. Three groups will be studied: 
1. Patients receiving a placebo pill (sugar pill)
2. Patients following the suggested homeopathic approach as indicated (dietary considerations, diluted remedies)
3. Patients receiving only dietary considerations (no remedies will be given). Retrospective subjective information will be gathered from the patients through questionnaires. (MYCaW, Distress Thermometer, and ESAS-R) Measures which are used routinely in Integrative Oncology encounters, at the initial visit, and during follow up visits. 

This feasibility study will evaluate three main ingredients: 
1. Obtaining main concerns of patients that agree to utilize the Homeopathic approach Patient acceptance of this supportive approach will be reflected in the number of patients that will accept this type of treatment. Retrospective subjective information will be verified though the following validated questionnaires: MYCaW, Distress Thermometer, and ESAS-R. Measures which are used routinely in Integrative Oncology encounters, at the initial visit, and during follow up visits. (Obtaining retrospective subjective information) Obtaining retrospective subjective information from the patients through validated questionnaires. (e.g., MYCaW is a brief (25 items) self-questionnaire measuring the quality of life in cancer survivors. Distress thermometer is a 11-item questionnaire of the National Comprehensive Cancer Center (NCCN) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events and Esas-R (e.g., ESAS-R: This is a reliable, valid measure of multiple cancer-related symptoms in hospitalized patients. ESAS measures pain, fatigue, nausea, depression, anxiety, sleepiness, drowsiness, tiredness, shortness of breath, and appetite (in 3 questions).).
