Patients with a central venous device or a midline and bacteremia (central or peripheral blood) are included. Doppler ultrasound is performed at D8, D15, D30, D45, D60 and D90. Two groups are created: presence and absence of thrombosis. The study population is 270 patients, each arm is 135 patients. Thrombosis at D8, D15, D30, D45, D60 is more frequently present in patients with stent thrombosis (68% vs 39%).
The ultrasound signs of thrombophlebitis disappear after a median time of 5 days in patients with stent thrombosis and 7 days in patients without stent thrombosis; the evolution is favorable in 97% of cases and does not require the use of antibiotics.
The Doppler ultrasound allows to quickly identify the presence and absence of thrombosis on the catheter, the evolution is frequently favorable and does not require prolongation of antibiotic therapy.

Follicular lymphoma (FL) and indolent lymphomas are generally characterized by relapsing disease, leading to treatment burden and potential morbidity. Lenalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug indicated for previously treated FL and indolent lymphomas and is often combined with rituximab. As lenalidomide-based regimens become standard of care and rituximab treatment is limited by inability to cross the blood-brain-barrier, it is important to find new treatment approaches. Recently a bispecific antibody against CD20 was developed, which can cross the blood-brain-barrier. This potential to target a tumoral lesion in the CNS has led to an investigation of the potential role of the bispecific antibody, odronextamab, an anti-CD20 x anti-CD3 bispecific antibody, in NHL that express CD20 and CD3. The safety and efficacy of odronextamab in combination with lenalidomide in subjects with R/R indolent lymphomas is being evaluated.
The investigators would like to compare the safety, efficacy and durability of response between OLYMPIA-5 and the OLYMPIA-3 trial evaluating the use of REVLIMID®(Len) + Rituxan (RR) in subjects with R/R indolent lymphomas and determine whether adding odronextamab to Len has an overall benefit in PFS over RR.

The Effect of Proliverenol Supplementation on Liver Function in Patients With Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) : Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common disorder globally, with a prevalence between 3 and 30%. NAFLD can progress to advanced liver disease including steatohepatitis (NASH) and cirrhosis. There are no approved treatment for NAFLD. Although weight loss has been shown to positively impact on the course of NAFLD, the majority of patients with NAFLD are not obese and fail the conventional standard treatment with medical nutrition or dietary regimes. Thus, the search for a more specific targeted therapy is necessary to improve NAFLD treatment and long-term patient outcomes. There have been several potential therapeutic agents for NAFLD, but the most extensively studied drug for NASH to date has been Vitamin E. Several randomized placebo-controlled trials evaluating the use of high-dose Vitamin E for 12 months have been halted prematurely due to excess adverse events and risk of death in the treatment group. In this context, there is thus a need for alternative approaches to treat NAFLD. Proliverenol® (PLRN) acts as a hepatocyte growth factor receptor (HGFR) agonist, which is not affected by nutrients. In addition, PLRN has been reported to be non-carcinogenic in rodents and the liver is the main site of drug absorption, suggesting that PLRN would be absorbed in the liver. Based on this pharmacokinetic profile, we hypothesized that PLRN may stimulate liver growth and regeneration as well as improve the metabolic profile in patients with NAFLD. The purpose of the current study is to evaluate whether daily administration of PLRN supplements may lead to metabolic and functional improvement in patients with NAFLD and to assess the safety profile of PLRN during such treatment. For this purpose, we conducted a randomized, double‐blinded, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging treatment study to evaluate the efficacy of 2 different dosages (1 x 1 caplet twice daily vs. 2 x 1 caplet) of PLRN versus placebo in patients with NAFLD. The investigators plan to recruit 80 patients and they will receive the study medication for 12 weeks.

Periodontal disease is a common inflammatory disease that affects the connective tissue and alveolar bone that support the teeth. Non-surgical periodontal treatment is the first therapeutic modality in the periodontal therapy. Although periodontal treatment is an established procedure, a significant number of patients do not respond adequately and, at a long-term perspective, many patients may be relapsing after nonsurgical periodontal treatment.
As a consequence of disease progression or patient refusal to periodontal surgery, the periodontal supporting structures may not be restored, and long-term failure can lead to tooth loss. Despite the development of innovative therapies that can provide more predictable long-term results, periodontal treatment outcomes remain unpredictable, and relapses after non-surgical periodontal treatment remain a clinical challenge despite all efforts. Furthermore, non-surgical periodontal treatment is not an optimal treatment approach for individuals with a limited lifespan or for patients who refuse surgery due to the extensive number of surgical sessions. In these patients, non-surgical periodontal treatment may fail or the success of such procedures will be limited and short lived. In the last decade, new treatment modalities have been developed and tested to improve the outcomes of periodontal treatment such as ozone. Ozone is considered a non-pharmacologic, inexpensive, and safe alternative to conventional antimicrobial agents for periodontal treatment.
The investigators will use Ozone Generator for ozone producing, and 1/8 standard periodontal probe for probing pocket depth measurement. Patients will be categorized into two groups: (1) Group A: patients who will be treated by non-surgical periodontal therapy and ozone therapy. (2) Group B: patients who will be treated by non-surgical periodontal therapy only. Each treatment will be completed within one week. The effectiveness and impact of ozone application on periodontal therapy will be assessed using clinical parameters (pocket depth, bleeding index, and plaque index) and biochemical markers (proportion of bacterial species and levels of inflammatory parameters in gingival crevicular fluid in periodontal pockets at baseline, 1st, and 3rd month after therapy) and will be compared to the control group.
The null hypothesis: There is no additional benefit of ozone treatment when compared to periodontal treatment alone in providing better clinical responses and changes in the microbiome.

While the exact mechanism of ptt development is unknown, recent studies highlight the role of genetic factors and inflammation. The loss of E-cadherin leads to the dissolution of cell contacts and the invasion of tissues.
The aim of this study is to investigate the expression of cell membrane proteins in patients with pterygium, whose alterations are associated with cell invasion and increased motility. Immunohistochemical method to detect protein expression by tumor cells, and to evaluate the cell proliferative index of the pterygium. Aging is associated with loss of nasal T cells and an increased risk of infections. However, the underlying mechanisms and consequences of this loss are still unclear. Therefore, the proposed research focuses on the following two research questions: 1) Why do T cells leave the nose of aging individuals?
2) Do lost/absent T cells affect the ability of the nose to fight infections, thereby increasing the risk of respiratory infections for frail elderly individuals?
This research will be performed in a clinical-epidemiological study with 150 participants, consisting of a mix of age cohorts and frail status. We hypothesize age-mediated differential alterations in T cells that associate with the loss of T cells from the nose and that T cells and other immune populations in the nose may have a functional defect during an infections. The ultimate goal of this research is to identify T cell populations and their functions that are altered in aging individuals and frail elderly individuals to identify potential immunological markers that allow early detection of at-risk individuals. Once identified, it would be possible to test whether these nasal T cell populations are able to serve as therapeutic target (e.g., immunotherapy) and whether this improves the immune protection and reduces the susceptibility of nasal infections in (frail) elderly individuals.

Background: cirrhotic patients with ascites have a greater risk for bacterial infection because of loss of the normal intestinal barrier function that leads to accumulation of bacteria in their body, and this is called spontaneous infection of ascetic fluid (SIAF) or spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). It has been reported that there is an increase in white blood cells that consist of polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) and other white blood cells (monocytes, lymphocytes) and this mixture may help in predicting the severity of SBP and its prognosis. The study is to identify the platelets to lymphocytes ratio and monocytes to lymphocytes ratio as a predictor of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with SBP. Methods: Cirrhotic patients with ascites who fulfilled our criteria were recruited and were randomized into two groups according to platelets to lymphocytes ratio (<5 and >or =5) and the monocytes to lymphocytes ratio (<2 and >or =2). The patients were treated by ceftriaxone and then tigecycline (2-3 g/day) according to the antibiotic sensitivity results of the isolated bacteria in ascetic fluid. The primary outcome is the percentage of sterilization of ascitis. Secondary outcomes are ascitic fluid bacterial eradication, 6-month rate of death, 90-day rate of death, and 90-day rates of hospitalization, re-hospitalization, 5-day hospital re-admission, and SBP re-admission. Patients who were non-sterility of their ascitic fluid were recruited for a second antibiotic therapy with tigecycline. The patients who responded in the second antibiotic therapy were continued with tigecycline as prophylactic therapy till the end of the study period and the other patients were recruited for a second antibiotic therapy with colistin when the ascitic fluid was not eradicated. The same patients were again treated with tigecycline 2-3 g/day if the ascitic fluid become sterile or become eradicated. Logistic analysis will be used to measure the variables in predicting the percentage of sterilization of ascitic fluid . SPSS program version 22 will be used for the data analyses. The investigators will compare the data between the groups and the variables that give significant results will help in increasing the patients' outcome in SBP.

Postoperative radiotherapy is widely practiced and highly effective in enabling breast conserving therapy in early stage tumors, and decreasing recurrence while improving survival in patients with advanced-stage breast cancer, the most common cancer in women. However, these benefits of radiotherapy are associated with a long-term risk of cardiac morbidity and mortality in breast cancer survivors. The unintended cardiac radiation exposure due to the heart's proximity to the treatment target has been well recognized, particularly in left-sided breast cancer. Because there is no lowest safe threshold radiation dose level for radiation-induced cardiac complications, the dose to the heart must be kept as low as possible to reduce the complications risk. Recent advances in high-precision 3D conformal and intensity-modulated radiotherapy techniques have enabled better protection of the heart. Treatment in deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) is indispensable to realize these technological capabilities by taking advantage of the greater distance created between the radiotherapy target and the contralaterally and inferiorly displaced heart during deep inspiration. While many studies have demonstrated reduction of the heart dose with DIBH, challenges in decreasing heart dose to a minimum remain. Radiotherapy in DIBH requires active and complex cooperation from the patient, and its success critically depends on how well patients are capable to perform the prolonged extended deep breathing maneuver on a repetitive basis every day during their weeks-long treatment course. Both the physical demands and profound anxiety and stress, which are highly prevalent in breast cancer patients, additionally interfere with patients' DIBH performance. Anxiety is well known to directly adversely affect breathing patterns, thereby challenging patients' ability to perform DIBH optimally. Preliminary research explored the role of physical training and showed that targeted DIBH training improves patients' cooperation and the ease of the DIBH procedure, and reduces the radiation dose to the heart. However, while DIBH training regimens may improve patients' physical respiratory skill levels, they do not address their mental stress and anxiety. Relaxation techniques to alleviate anxiety and stress have been rarely used in complex radiotherapy procedures, particularly not in DIBH. Preliminary studies in diagnostic radiology procedures suggest that advanced communication and relaxation techniques, targeted to relieve anxiety and stress, improve patients' procedural performance, anxiety and comfort. The investigators hypothesize that implementing both, DIBH Respiratory Training and advanced communication and Relaxation Training (R&R), improve patients' DIBH performance skills and further reduce heart dose, while alleviating anxiety and stress and improving quality of life during and after radiation therapy. The investigators propose to test this hypothesis in a clinical trial randomizing R&R vs. standard-of-care management in patients with radiotherapy in DIBH for left breast cancer. The investigators primary endpoint will assess heart dose (Dmax), and secondary endpoints include longitudinal anxiety and quality of life assessment and clinic workflow efficiency. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to develop a validated patient-centered training and integrative health regimen to further improve the success of advanced-technology-based cardiac dose reduction, and improve cardiac health in breast cancer survivors.

Background: Over the past decade, many new therapies (immunotherapy, targeted agents, and biologics) have shown clinical activity. Combination of these agents with established agents (chemotherapy) is emerging as a new treatment paradigm for cancer. This approach involves the testing of combinations of new modalities (immunotherapy or targeted agents) in the clinic with the goal of determining if the combination helps patients more than either therapy alone.
Cancer of the pancreas remains a difficult disease to treat by surgical removal. Despite advances in surgical techniques and therapies, only 10-15% of patients with pancreatic cancer are eligible for curative surgery. Those with early stages of the disease have the best outcomes; however, only 20% of patients are diagnosed at resectable stage. For those patients eligible and undergoing potentially curative surgery, the median overall survival (OS) is approximately 13 months due to the high rate of local and systemic disease recurrence. Although gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel (gemox) have made a significant impact on the treatment of pancreatic cancer, there is a clear and urgent need to develop improved therapies for this disease, and to use biology and immunotherapy research to help identify those with a pancreatic tumor that has the best chance of being cured by surgery. As a result, there is great interest from the medical community in learning more about how immunotherapy medicines and the drugs (like gemox) that are currently used to treat metastatic pancreatic cancer can be used prior to surgery.
Cancer Treatment Centers of America (CTCAE) have launched a national clinical trial that is exploring the use of nab-paclitaxel, gemcitabine, and immunotherapy for patients diagnosed with pancreatic cancer with the goal of determining whether the patient has an opportunity to have all of the tumor removed with a procedure called surgical resection. The CTCAE clinical trial is called "A Phase IB Study to Determine the Safety and Tolerability of Canakinumab and Tislelizumab in Combination With Nab-Paclitaxel and Gemcitabine in the Neo-adjuvant Treatment of Patients With Pancreatic Cancer".

Using Participatory Design and Community Partnered Participatory Research (CPPR), UCLA and UCR psychiatry research centers with Los Angeles Trust for Children's Health aim to: (1) Fully co-design (with youth, caregivers, clinicians and other stakeholders) an innovative mental health digital tool, called Connected for Wellness, to implement algorithmically supported mental health + social determinants, resiliency app based tools and navigation activities AND help support the clinical workforce within schools and primary care clinics (PCCs); (2) Study the implementation of mental health navigation models (family and youth navigation) plus the Connected for Wellness app, and their effectiveness for improving connecting and matching youth to the right level of care and supports. We will accomplish these aims through three strategies: (1) Use community participatory informatics to co-design a mental health digital tool called Connected for Wellness, to support mental health navigation, linking youth to a range of mental health services, evidence-based prevention resources referred via the app, and other school, clinic, community, and social supports; (2) Integrate mental health self-assessments and artificial intelligence (AI) in Connected for Wellness to individualize app resources, optimize engagement and recommendations for addressing mental health and social needs; (3) Using a stepped wedge design, test the implementation of the app supported by mental health navigation models (peer navigators, family navigators) for improving connections and access to prevention resources, mental health services and social supports, for youth and families. This project will be initiated with youth 13-22 years old and their family and community members across 10 Los Angeles County Schools and 10 Riverside County/University of California Riverside primary care clinics, which serve mostly Black, Latino, and Asian youth. A successful outcome of the project is a CPPR developed app-based intervention implementable in school-based and primary care services for access to wellness resources and improving mental health services access along the cascade of care. Outcomes are measured using the cascade of care model with the following key stages: (1) need identification, (2) referral to care/ linkage to resources, and (3) care initiation.

Cesarean section (CS) is the most common operation during childbirth. Worldwide, CS rates are increasing due to the improvement in maternal health care in modern societies. Because of the increase of CS rates, the number of cesarean hysterectomies (CH), due to primary CS-related complications such postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), have increased exponentially in the developed community. PPH is a common, life-threatening and potentially fatal condition of maternal morbidity and mortality that occurs after maternal birth either during or within 24 hours post-delivery. PPH is the main factor that prolongs hospitalization, causes obstetric complications and death in the mother. PPH is a major problem with potentially serious outcomes and is responsible for an estimated 5% of maternal mortality. Most CS are performed on women who have normal pregnancies and are in term pregnancy. PPH is defined as blood loss greater than 500ml after cesarean delivery while severe PPH greater than one liter with signs of volume depletion or hemodynamic instability PPH is a major public health problem and a major contributor to maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. PPH could be estimated through various methods. Intraperitoneal blood estimation in (mg) during surgery is the most appropriate method and it's more acceptable by most obstetricians. The objective of this study is to compare and evaluate the safety of intramyometrial oxytocin injection with intra-myometrial tranexamic acid injection in reducing the risk of PPH after CS. It's a double-blind randomized comparative clinical trial. Two hundred primigravida women at term pregnancy, undergoing elective CS-will be allocated randomly in two groups. Group 1 (n = 100): women will be allocated to receive 5 cc of placebo 5 I.U of oxytocin (nonartis-egypt) injection. Group 2 (n = 100): women will be allocated to receive 5 cc of Tranexamic acid (kapron®, Amoun, Egypt). In both group, after fetal birth (10 minutes maximum), patients are allocated to the two groups by injecting in each uterine corn before the placental separation 5cc (2.5 cc/uterine corn) of either tranexamic acid or oxytocin according to the study group

<|assistant|> The vaginal microbiome plays a substantial role in the success of IVF treatments by influencing the establishment and development of the endometrium during the window period for pregnancy. However, there is a lack of knowledge how to address the negative effects of unfavorable vaginal microbiome composition on pregnancy rates and what kind of strategy a physician and patient should use. Therefore, we have identified the need for a tool that can measure and assess vaginal microbiome composition for IVF/ICSI and determine reproductive success. In this investigator-initiated multicenter clinical study, called ReceptIVFity, we will test whether the ReceptIVFity microbiome profile in combination with the Shared Decision Making Model results in a higher pregnancy rate (≥ 35%) compared to not using the ReceptIVFity system. An additional benefit is an increase in knowledge about the influence of the vaginal microbiome on the establishment and development of the endometrium during the window period of implantation. By testing the efficacy of a combination of ReceptIVFity and SDM we can provide the evidence to determine the use of the ReceptIVFity system as a diagnostic test in the clinic setting for IVF. After recruitment of patients and randomization in a control group or an SDM group, all patients will get information about the influence of the vaginal microbiome on fertilization and implantation using the ReceptIVFity microbiome profile. We want to analyze whether knowledge transfer improves reproductive success. Furthermore, we hypothesize that by using the SDM method we can offer personalized treatment, i.e. tailored to the patient's vaginal microbiome profile, increase the probability of a successful IVF treatment and reduce the number of cycles until a successful IVF treatment for the individual patient. Patients in the control group will be offered frozen or fresh cycles in which randomization towards a SDM treatment in case of non-European vaginal microbiome profiles will be part of the intervention. In the observational part of the study, the results will be used to identify potential personalized interventions aimed at favoring an establishment of an optimal endometrium profile to improve and support the efficacy of IVF/ICSI treatment. Hyperlipidemia is characterized as the overproduction of very low density cholesterol and low density lipoprotein (LDL) (i.e. bad cholesterol) and decreased high density lipoprotein (HDL) (i.e. good cholesterol). Amongst individuals with mild to moderate hyperlipidemia, lifestyle changes is the first treatment option, such as a healthy diet. Therefore, seeking to develop food-based approaches for hyperlipidemia therapy is a timely endeavour. Fenugreek has been suggested as an attractive option, as it is a spice throughout the world which possesses medicinal properties in regulating human nutrient metabolism. In a recent review of the overall effects of fenugreek on hyperlipidemia in humans with diabetes and prediabetes, this analysis suggested that fenugreek has total cholesterol-lowering efficacy. The effects of fenugreek on triglyceride and LDL-cholesterol showed a trend towards reduction and an incremental trend for HDL-cholesterol but needed further confirmation. The effect of fenugreek in human subjects with hyperlipidaemia without diabetes has not been investigated. This research aims to investigate the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed consumed as a tea in patients with hyperlipidaemia, but without diabetes over an 8-week intervention period. Changes in plasma microRNAs will be analysed to establish non-invasive therapeutic biomarkers of hyperlipidemia. Participants without pre-existing CVD or diabetes aged 18-70 years old will be included if they have hyperlipidaemia (plasma triglyceride level between 1.7 - 4.5mmol/l) not on any lipid-lowering treatment or on a stable lipid-lowering treatment (last six months) but still have confirmation of high triglycerides within the range required for study. 114 participants will be randomized into two groups (57/group) to receive either fenugreek seeds or control tea, respectively. Treatment allocations will be placed into sealed envelopes and this will be opened at the baseline study visit with the participant. Fenugreek seeds will be delivered at a dose of 5g/day, drunk as a tea (2.5g/per tea bag), p.o. twice a day at a 12-hour interval) for 8 weeks (56 days). The tea bags will be brewed in a cup (200ml) of boiled hot water for 10 minutes before drinking. This will be self-administered by the subjects, twice a day at a 12-hour interval. The rationale for choosing the dose and intervention time course were based on the previous studies where metabolic effects have been detected. Literature reports from 12 human studies on diabetic and pre-diabetic subjects gave doses of fenugreek seed ranging from 1 to 100g/day, with the median treatment dose being 6.3g/day, to the participants; the intervention time course ranged from 1 week to 3 years, with the median treatment time being 60 days. The dose and duration in this study was therefore designed as being similar to these studies where metabolic effects have been detected, and also, where participant burden will not be too onerous, at a dose of 5g/day, twice a day at a 12-hour interval for 8 weeks (56 days). For the control group, a control black tea (2.5g/bag), self-administered by the subjects, twice in a day at a 12-hour interval. Black tea is a type of fermented tea that has been found to possess much less cardioprotective and lipid profile improving effect compared to green tea due to the different manufacture process. Consumption of black tea has been found not associated with a reduced risk of coronary heart disease in the United Kingdom. Recruitment will be via outpatient hyperlipidemia clinics, primary care and advertisements. Study visits will take place at the Centre for Public Health at baseline, 4 and 8 weeks and will involve the collection of demographic information, anthropometric measurements, blood pressure and fasting blood samples.

Panoramic imaging is an extraoral imaging technique used to visualise dentofacial structures. Over the years, dental panoramic imaging has become an essential clinical tool for diagnosing dental diseases and treatment planning. The quality of radiographic images is important for successful diagnosis and treatment planning. However, it has been shown that the quality of panoramic images is often compromised by patient positioning errors. These errors can affect all types of radiography, but they are most commonly seen in panoramic images, where as many as 80-95 percent of radiographic images may include one or more positional, patient movement errors or artifacts (Vadaparasa et al., 2019). One of the common mistakes is the tongue not being in contact with the palate, known as the Palatoglossal airspace (PGA) error, which is also the most frequent of these errors.
The palatoglossal airspace error causes a radiolucent band that obscures the image of the maxillary cusp tips and anatomical landmarks in the anterior area of the upper jaw, resulting in poor overall image quality. This image artifact can affect the diagnostic accuracy significantly, which can lead to delays in treatment, poor decision-making, and repeat imaging, resulting in an increased dose of radiation to both the patient and the operator. In addition, PGA can be confused with a fracture in the mandibular region.
The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of using celluloid matrix tape or strips of food material as simple, inexpensive, and effective methods to reduce PGA error. This is a randomized, triple-blinded study involving three groups: a control group with no intervention, a celluloid matrix tape group and a group using strips of fruit leather.
All data were analysed using the SPSS 26 software. Chi-square test was used to compare the qualitative variables. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used for the quantitative analysis. The intervention outcomes were evaluated using the logistic regression model. The differences with P<0.05 were considered statistically significant for all tests.
The results showed that in comparison with the control group, the PGA error in the celluloid matrix tape group and fruit leather group was significantly less (p<0.001). Furthermore, there was no significant difference between the two study groups (celluloid matrix tape group and fruit leather group) in terms of PGA error (p>0.05).
In conclusion, PGA error is a common mistake in panoramic imaging and has a negative impact on the success of dental radiographic imaging. Different methods can be used to overcome this obstacle, such as the use of celluloid matrix tape or strips of food material. In the present study, both methods were successful and reduced the PGA error effectively, with high accuracy and reproducibility.

Background: Adults with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) frequently encounter interpersonal challenges to their romantic relationships. They often encounter a significant amount of distress caused by their partner's behavior, as well as difficulty expressing their views and feelings about the relationship.
Objective: The aim of this cross-sectional survey was to provide a preliminary investigation of the effects of a couple group therapy program on an adult couple, in which one person has either an autism spectrum disorder (ASD) diagnosis or above-average level of Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ) Score.
Method: Twenty couples, which were either married or in a romantic relationship, of which one participant had a formal diagnosis of ASD, participated in 8-week couple group therapy. The assessment of the couples before and after therapy was conducted using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule, Autism Spectrum Quotient, Empathy Quotient, Quality of socialization questionnaire, and Social Responsiveness Scale.
Result: The couples that completed the therapy showed significant improvements in self-awareness and emotional expression. Furthermore, the couples that attended a higher number of sessions indicated superior levels of empathy towards the partner than the control group. However, no significant changes were observed with regards to the couple's levels of social isolation, social inadequacies, and quality of socialization.
Conclusions: Couples with either a history of ASD or high levels of AQ score can receive benefits from couple group therapy. Further investigations with larger numbers of couples are needed to establish the efficacy of the couple group therapy program.

This is a randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint study that aims to compare the efficacy and safety of intravenous tirofiban with standard antiplatelet therapy based on Chinese stroke guideline for the patients with acute branch atheromatous disease related stroke within 48 hours of onset. It includes 472 eligible patients randomly assigned into 2 groups with 236 patients in each group. The primary efficacy outcome is the comparison of the excellent functional outcome (modified Rankin Scale score: 0-1) at 90 days. Based on the results of our stroke prevention trial (J.Lancet 2019; 394:1234-48) target trial level is 85%, type I error is 5%, and type II error is 10%. The time frame of outcome assessment is 90 days. Tirofiban is a second generation receptor antagonist that inhibits platelet aggregation by blocking the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GPIIb/IIIa) receptor. It is widely used in the treatment of acute coronary syndrome and acute cerebral ischemia in China, which may be a suitable drug for patients with branch atheromatous disease related stroke within 48 hours of onset. The standard antiplatelet regimen that recommended in the Chinese stroke guideline include aspirin and cloplicogrel. It can reduce the risk of stroke and is more cost-effective.

Background: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a breathing problem during sleep that can cause daytime sleepiness, sleepiness, depression, diabetes, cardiac events, accidents and death. OSA is very common. However, the overall awareness of OSA is quite low. OSA is often underdiagnosed and undertreated as well. OSA is now known as a major public health problem, and a growing public and professional health care cost. Treatment of OSA will improve the quality of life of patients, but it is expensive. Telemedicine technology can be used for remote diagnosis and remote sleep monitoring, and is very convenient. However, at present there are no randomized controlled trials to prove that remote diagnosis combined with OSA treatment is clinically useful for OSA patients who are prone to OSA symptoms. This randomized controlled study is expected to determine the feasibility, safety and efficacy of telemedicine technology combined with standardized Obstructive sleep apnea positive airway pressure (APAP) treatment in the management of Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) patients. Aims: The purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness with telemedicine technology compared to normal treatment and to explore the differences in compliance and costs between the two. Telemedicine technology can save OSA patients a lot of time and travel expenses in remote areas, providing more convenience for patients, and improving the compliance of patients. The telemedicine technology can also achieve cost control for OSA cases. Methods: This research is based on a randomized trial. After patients with OSA symptoms confirmed by clinical experts, the sleep center randomly assigns them into two groups. One group is treated in the sleep center, which is called the outpatient treatment group, and the other group is treated remotely, which is called the remote treatment group. Telemedicine technology was applied to provide remote diagnosis, remote sleep monitoring, telemedicine follow-up, APAP treatment, education and training, so as to compare the effectiveness of telemedicine technology and traditional treatment in the management of OSA patients. During the treatment period, we will follow up the symptoms and changes in blood pressure rhythm of patients after remote treatment. We will measure the cost of the two groups, analyze the differences in compliance with the treatment in the two groups, the changes in blood pressure rhythm, questionnaire results, sleep patterns and costs of patients between the two groups. We will also establish an electronic subject database to obtain electronic medical record information. Investigators will determine the cost-effectiveness of telemedicine technology compared to traditional methods. Based on previous studies, the number of participants required for this research is 178, and the study period is 12 months. The main conclusions of our study can be achieved through this.

Elective cesarean sections under spinal anesthesia cause moderate to severe postoperative pain. Inadequate pain control can lead to undesirable effects such as low motivation to breastfeed, postoperative complications and sleep disorders.
Past research showed that non-pharmacologic methods are effective in the management of postoperative pain. Communication is an important non-pharmacological tool in pain management that have been found to be efficacious, however the nature of the communication was not specified in these studies.
Accordingly, the purpose of this study is to investigate how communication influences the efficacy of analgesics in patients following Caesarean section.
The study is conducted in a single center prospective, randomized, clinical trial. Eligible participants are female patients aged 18-50 who will undergo an elective caesarean section under spinal anesthesia. There are two study arms - study arm A undergoes a high communication style and study arm B undergoes the normal communication style.
The primary outcome is the effectiveness of postoperative analgesia - change in pain intensity - one hour after the administration of analgesics. The second outcome is change in the state anxiety level one hour after the administration of analgesics. These outcomes are assessed by the patients' self-evaluation on the 0-10 pain scale and a questionnaire, respectively.

This research is being conducted to help develop a better test to identify lung cancer in people aged 55-74 years old. This research is also looking at other medical conditions that could affect the results. We call these conditions comorbidities. Researchers hope that new tests can help reduce lung cancer deaths. The researchers would like to work with the general public to help develop lung cancer screening using the Combe Lung Health Check (TLHC) Programme. The information in this leaflet will help us understand what would be expected and what you need to know about any extra tests and/or samples you agree to take part in. When you have read, keep the leaflet and return it to the TLHC nurses if you agree to take part in this research study. It is completely your choice, based on the information you have been given, and you can change your mind at any time before, during, or after the research has taken place. It is important that the researchers get information from individuals who do not have lung cancer about factors that could make a difference to developing lung cancer. The researchers will be using data about blood pressure, body weight and lung disease history. In some cases, investigations such as scans and blood tests will be taken as part of routine TLHC clinical care. In other cases, researchers plan to repeat some of these tests (for example CT-scans). Your previous medical history and routine tests/ scans taken at visits 1 and 2 are already being used. If you agree to take part, the researchers will be using the scan images, blood samples, and measurements from these routine tests to analyse the results. They will be using this information for the period from your previous visit until the end of this study period, which is up to 5 years but could be for longer. Some people may have a further scan or blood tests as part of this study. These tests may help make screening tests more accurate and could help diagnose lung cancer by comparing images or looking for changes in the blood. The researchers think that it is necessary to collect information about smoking history, other medical conditions, and lifestyle factors from participants who are not able to speak English. This is important to help researchers test the ability of the screening test to work in a population where participants may speak other languages. The researchers also need to gather information about the family history of lung cancer. This will be gathered by asking participants to fill in a form or with the help of an interpreter. These forms ask questions about their family history of cancer over the last 80 years.

Hypertension is a public health problem and a risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality and is also associated with cognitive, renal and metabolic impairments and with fractures in the elderly. In addition, one of the challenges for clinical practice among the elderly is the control of arterial hypertension and pharmaceutical care for treatment has proved to be effective.
Therefore, the objective of this study is to study the effectiveness of pharmaceutical care via telepharmacy and usual care on the clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension in the elderly and to compare these outcomes with the pharmaceutical care in-person protocol. The secondary objectives are to study the clinical outcomes by socio- demographic and clinical variables; the factors that can positively influence the outcomes such as adherence to treatment, drug consumption; satisfaction and factors that hinder the progress; and to establish the clinical importance and the acceptability of the intervention.
The study will be conducted with elderly patients referred by the hospital pharmacy at the Geriatrics and Gerontology Hospital of the Federal University of Sao Paulo and will compare the data collected from patients submitted to pharmaceutical care via telemedicine to hospital pharmacy professionals and those who received pharmaceutical care in-person. Inclusion criteria are as follows: elderly patients with diagnosis of arterial hypertension according to the treating physician, controlled or uncontrolled systolic pressure of 140-159 mmHg and/or diastolic blood pressure of 90-99 mmHg and who meet at least one of the following: the patient does not know how to administer the medication correctly, does not understand the medication indications, does not have the medication in hand, does not need a new prescription, is not using the medication properly evidenced by the low prescription index and/or does not need to start a new medication or does not need to add or change the medication.
The sample size was calculated based on the prevalence of arterial hypertension among the elderly and considering significance of 5% and a statistical power of 80%, resulting in 135 patients. For the statistical analysis, inferential tests will be used and the normality of data will be assessed by the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test.
Through this study, the investigators believe it is possible to strengthen pharmaceutical care and the use of telepharmacy in clinical practice in the elderly; contribute for health care teams and patients to have more alternatives with the best possible results that can be achieved with the tools available, making health care more rational and cost-saving; expand the knowledge about the effectiveness of telepharmacy in clinical outcomes of patients with arterial hypertension and evaluate the feasibility and acceptance by users.

ARDS is a condition associated with hypoxemia due to noncardiogenic causes with bilateral lung infiltrates on chest X-ray or CT imaging. ICU survival (30-day mortality rate) and 6 months mortality rate of survivors are higher than those of patients with sepsis. In other words, the mortality rate of ARDS is about 40%. Furthermore, the condition is associated with various disabilities, such as physical impairments, cognitive impairments, depression, anxiety, and PTSD. Patients with ARDS have many functional impairments even one year after discharge, and their ADL and QOL have also been impaired (Post Intensive Care Syndrome, PICS). Therefore, the development of effective strategies for patients with ARDS that take into account not only mortality but also functional prognosis is strongly needed. Recent studies have revealed that several treatments such as neuromuscular blocking agents, prone position, noninvasive and invasive mechanical ventilators, and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) have improved outcomes, including mortality, in ARDS patients. However, the mortality rate of ARDS patients is about 40%. In addition, more than 50% of ARDS patients become PICS patients at 1 year after discharge. Recent studies have revealed that there are many factors that affect patients with ARDS after successful treatment such as ventilator weaning difficulty, pain, sedation, cognitive impairment, delirium, lack of patient activity during ICU stay and after ICU discharge . Adequate analgesia, sedation and rehabilitation in a prone position, SATs and SBTs have been reported to suppress the development of delirium, prevent long-term ventilator weaning difficulty, improve outcomes, and reduce the frequency of hospital admission. These are known as the ABCDEF bundle, and have been reported to improve outcomes of ICU patients, including ARDS patients worldwide. However, the implementation of the ABCDEF bundle in ICU patients, including ARDS patients, is too low. Patients with ARDS in ICU frequently receive mechanical ventilator therapy, and there are many reasons why the ABCDEF bundle cannot be applied: (1) Excessive sedation due to the use of sedatives and sedative antagonists (2) Excessive analgesia due to the use of opioids (3) Absolute bed rest for ventilation control (4) Routine use of muscle relaxants and benzodiazepine antagonists, (5) Use of restraints during ventilation control, and (6) Delay in SBT trials due to the risk of desaturation. As a result, the rate of complications such as delirium, ventilator weaning difficulties, and poor outcomes increases. Furthermore, there is insufficient evidence to determine the optimal content to be adopted in ABCDEF bundles for patients with ARDS, and the current results do not necessarily apply to all ICU patients. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to investigate the current epidemiology and treatment strategy given to the patients with ARDS after the recent epidemic event of new coronavirus, clarify the actual implementation rate of ICU care for ARDS patients who require ventilators at a high frequency, and evaluate how the implementation of evidence-based ICU care is associated with patient outcomes in order to assess the current status of ICU care for ARDS patients and improve the outcomes of ARDS patients worldwide.

Inclusion criteria: Patients on an invasive or non-invasive ventilator within 24 hours of ICU admission Patients who are expected to be on an invasive and/or non-invasive ventilator for more than 48 hours in total Patients who meet the diagnosis of ARDS according to the Berlin Definition within 24 hours of ICU admission Exclusion criteria: Patients who are younger than 16 years old Patients with terminal conditions at the time of ICU admission.

Background: Gliomas are the most common cerebral tumors, constituting 33% of primary brain tumors. Among them, diffuse gliomas are a major public health problem. The classification of gliomas rests primarily on the histological aspect. In 2007, the World Health Organization published new classification criteria based on the genetic profiles of the tumors. The distinction between glioblastoma (GBM), anaplastic glioma (AGBM) and diffuse low-grade glioma (LGG) has become important. The identification of these genetic subtypes is based on the discovery and analysis of two biomarkers, isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation (gene) and 1p19q deletion (chromosome), responsible for the occurrence of glioma and metabolic modifications. IDH1/IDH2 mutations are associated with a better prognosis compared to IDH-wildtype (WT) tumors.
Objective: Describe 2-hydroxyglutarate (2HG) and cystahionine plasma concentrations measured by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) in patients with diffuse gliomas and to determine the impact of IDH mutational status (gene) on this. Then characterize for the first time the modifications of the choline MR signal and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values in gliomas.
Eligibility criteria: Inclusion Criteria: Affiliation to a social security scheme (beneficiary or entitled) Signed consent informed and unanimous
Main exclusion criteria: Contraindications to magnetic resonance imaging (IRM) Pace maker or stimulator neural, body foreign intraocular or intracerebral, cochlear implant, cardiac valve or vascular prosthesis incompatible maternal compatible with MR imaging, foreign metal body compatible with MR imaging, claustrophobia Pregnant or breastfeeding women Women of childbearing potential not using effective contraception Test of pregnancy in women of childbearing age (non-exclusion criterion).
Design and methodology: The study includes MRI examinations using MRS for the measurement of 2-HG, cystahionine plasma concentrations and DTI acquisition in 48 patients, including 36 newly-diagnosed tumors and 12 previously-treated tumors. Tumor progression will be objectified according to the criteria of the Response Assessment in Neuro-Oncology (RANO) consortium. The results will be correlated with the results obtained from an analysis of the genetic profiles of the patients (IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion).
Statistical analyses: Normality of non-normally distributed data will be analyzed using the Shapiro-Wilk test. Univariate and multivariate analyses will be performed using Student's t test, Wilcoxon (or Mann-Whitney) and Pearson chi-square test (or Fisher exact test).
Expected results: This study aim to evaluate 2-HG and cystahionine plasma concentrations in LGG and GBM patients. A high concentration of 2HG has previously been detected in patients with IDH mutation. We hypothesize that patients harboring the IDH mutation will have higher 2HG and cystahionine plasma concentrations as compared in patients without IDH mutation. Second objective is to highlight the changes of choline concentration and apparent diffusion coefficient in gliomas and the impact on their changes within the brain in correlation with the IDH mutation, 1p19q codeletion and treatment. This study will highlight how these noninvasive modalities could help the clinicians to predict and better differentiate these genetic subtypes and will be of great value in the stratification of populations for better management and therapies.

Beta-thalassemia is the most common genetic disorder worldwide, with an estimate of 180,000 patients in Turkey. The current medical protocol that can relieve many morbidities is the transfusion of erythrocytes (red blood cells) that contain hemoglobin. However, this treatment carries risks such as infections, iron overload, and iron deposition in the heart, liver, and pancreas. Hydroxyurea is widely used in the medical treatment of β-thalassemia patients, as it stimulates red blood cell formation in the bone marrow. Hydroxyurea has side effects such as myelosuppression, thrombosis, and teratogenicity. Since its use has been limited because of these side effects, new agents have been sought as a therapeutic option. Thalidomide is a drug that has been used successfully in the treatment of several neoplastic (cancer) conditions through the past few decades. There have been few reports on the therapeutic use of thalidomide with no adverse side effects in beta-thalassemia patients in the literature. This pilot trial is aimed at assessing long term tolerance and efficacy of combination thalidomide and hydroxyurea in beta-thalassemia patients and to test its effectiveness in relieving some of the morbidities related to the therapy, such as high transfusion requirements and iron overload.

A pilot project to address the inequalities in venous leg ulcer services across the UK, from primary to secondary care. As a pilot, the aim will be to determine if more targeted and efficient use of diagnostic services can improve patient care and outcome in both primary and secondary care settings. The study will assess the clinical and cost effectiveness of current primary and secondary care practice compared with a set of proposed standardised processes based on evidence. This will include an analysis of current NHS UK services and diagnostic modalities, establishment of a national diagnostic criteria and set for this patient group, including ultrasound imaging and ultrasound guided micro-fracture in clinical practice. This will include a questionnaire, an online Delphi consensus, a multicentre cross population observational study on the clinical effectiveness of ultrasound scanning in patients with suspected or active venous leg ulcers and review of the costs of treatment in both primary and secondary care. Primary care practitioners: A one off questionnaire to be sent to primary care practitioners via qualtrics. Questionnaire based study. Vascular Scientists: A Delphi consensus questionnaire will be performed via Qualtrics. Questionnaire based study.

The goal of this project is to create an application for virtual reality (VR) that uses an avatar to address poor prospective thinking skills in outpatients with stimulant use disorder (SUD). Impulsivity and related issues with delayed reward are associated with the development of early relapse. This research will test the effect of interacting with a virtual avatar on impulsivity and reward-related behavior to aid in the prevention of early relapse.
The study will be conducted at the Clinical Neuroscience Division (CND), which is an outpatient, academic facility located in the Brain Institute at UCLA. Subjects will be adults (age: 18-65) who meet criteria for current stimulant use disorder (SUD) and meet criteria for at least one additional psychiatric disorder (e.g., mood disorders, anxiety, etc.). In addition, subjects will be in outpatient programs of addiction medicine and/or psychoeducation and psychotherapy with a UCLA provider for a minimum of one month prior to initiation of the study and will receive these services for the duration of the study. This is a behavioral, phase-not-applicable study that will have two study arms (Experimental: Virtual Reality Avatar, Placebo Comparator: Treatment as usual). Participants will be randomized to receive the Virtual Reality Avatar experience.
Specific Aim #1: Use VR avatars to promote prospective thinking skills. The aim of this research is to use a novel VR approach to improve prospective thinking. By interacting with a virtual avatar, the intervention will target and train impulsive responses that have been shown to lead to relapse through improved planning of future events. This study will evaluate the impact of this intervention on prospective thinking skills, delay of reward decisions, and addiction-related health outcomes.
Study #2: Test the utility and cost-effectiveness of VR interventions to improve prospective thinking skills in SUD patients. This research will test if using this avatar-based intervention can be used and implemented in the clinical setting to aid in patient recovery. In summary, studies like this are essential to develop VR interventions that can be used in outpatient or inpatient settings for SUD patients.

Hematopoietic progenitor cell transplantation from haplo-identical donors remains the only available treatment for patients with hematological disease refractory or relapsed after standard chemotherapy.
Unfortunately, this treatment is often complicated by significant side effects. The main risk involved is the occurrence of Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD), an adverse event whose severity and toxicity are often increased with a haploidentical donor.
To prevent or attenuate GVHD, various strategies have been tried, with encouraging results. Among them, mesenchymal stromal cells (MSC) are among the most promising.
The aim of this study is to study the effect of injection of Wharton's Juxta-Chorionic membrane-derived Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (WJ-MSC) to prevent or attenuate acute and chronic GVHD in patients undergoing a non-myeloablative allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from a haplo-identical donor. To define the optimal therapeutic dose of this treatment, three dose levels are proposed: 1.5x106, 3x106 and 10x106 WJ-MSC/kg (250ml) of patient body weight for three successive injections each 72 hours. For the first time, this study offers the possibility to define the optimal therapeutic dose of WJ-MSCs in this indication. This study aims to assess the feasibility, toxicity and efficacy of WJ-MSC in preventing or attenuating acute and chronic GVHD.

Background: Clinical deterioration occurs in approximately 5% of hospitalized adults. Delays in recognition of deterioration heighten the risk of adverse outcomes. Machine learning algorithms enhance clinical decision-making and can improve the quality of patient care. However, their impact on clinical outcomes depends not only on the sensitivity and specificity of the algorithm but also on how well that algorithm is integrated into provider workflows and facilitates timely and appropriate intervention. Preliminary Data: eCART has been built upon more than a decade of ongoing scientific research and chronicled in numerous peer-reviewed publications. eCART was developed at the University of Chicago by Drs. Dana Edelson and Matthew Churpek. The first version (eCARTv1) was derived and validated using linear logistic regression in a dataset of nearly 60,000 adult ward patients from a single medical center. That model had 16 variables in it and was subsequently validated in silent mode, demonstrating that eCART could alert clinicians more than 24 hours in advance of ICU transfer or cardiac arrest. eCARTv2, derived and validated in a dataset of nearly 270,000 patients from 5 hospitals, improved upon the earlier version by utilizing a cubic spline logistic regression model with 27 variables and demonstrated improved accuracy over the Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS), a commonly used score that can be hand- calculations by nurses at the bedside (AUC 0.77 vs. 0.70 for cardiac arrest, ICU transfer or death). In a multicenter clinical implementation study, eCARTv2 was associated with a 29% relative risk reduction for mortality. In further development of eCART, the University of Chicago research team demonstrated that upgrading from a cubic spline model to a machine learning model, such as a random forest or gradient boosted machine (GBM), could increase the AUC. In the most recent development - eCART v5 - the research team has advanced the analytic using a gradient boosted machine learning model trained on a multi-center dataset of more than 800,000 patient records. Now with 97 variables, this more sophisticated model increases the accuracy by which clinicians can predict clinical deterioration.

This proposal is to rapidly deploy a clinical decision support tool (eCARTv5) within the electronic health record of multiple medical-surgical units. eCART combines a real-time machine learning algorithm for identifying patients at increased risk for critical illness or death with clinical pathways to standardize the care of these patients based on a real-time, quantitative assessment of patient risk. The investigators hypothesize that implementing such a tool will be associated with a decrease in critical illness resource utilization, such as ICU length of stay, ventilator usage, and mortality among high-risk patients. This project will enable the investigators to test the clinical impact of eCARTv5 on clinically important outcomes, including mortality, length of stay, and ventilator use. The investigators also plan to describe the cost-effective of eCARTv5 implementation and to analyze barriers and facilitators to widespread implementation of new machine learning algorithms in the EHR.

Objectives: Primary Objectives: 
1. To implement eCARTv5 and other standard-of-care tools for identifying and managing clinical deterioration in patients admitted to participating hospitals, to test the clinical value of this tool in reducing critical resource utilization and improving clinically relevant outcomes.
2. To analyze barriers and facilitators to implementation in a multi-center setting and to estimate the cost savings from eCARTv5 implementation.

Eligibility: Patients admitted to participating medical-surgical units, who are 18 or older, will be eligible for inclusion in the eCART intervention.

Design: This will be a multi-center, observational study with a parallel assignment study design. All participating hospitals will have eCARTv5 deployed using a standardized "train-validate" methodology in the electronic health record.

Data Analysis: The primary analysis will be an intention to treat analysis comparing the pre vs. post-implementation data. It will focus on differences between the pre-implementation and post-implementation cohorts within the intervention hospitals, as well as the differences in outcomes between the pre- versus post-cohorts at control hospitals that do not implement eCARTv5. This will limit the analysis to patients who were ever elevated by the tool (patients were considered to have been elevated as long as they ever had an eCART elevation score of 6, 7,

Mother's depression is the most common complication of the perinatal period affecting 10-15% of mothers. It negatively impacts maternal and infant outcomes and disrupts family functioning. AA women have a poorer healthcare experience and lower healthcare utilization compared to Caucasian women. A structured intervention focused on fathers who are the most direct influence on the family's adaptation and health can help supplement and support individual treatment for mother's depression. Moreover, the fathers can alleviate the mother's socio-environmental stressors. This pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) is designed to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the ASSET-PPD intervention to improve maternal and infant health outcomes with the goal of promoting breastfeeding and parent-infant secure attachment in the African American population. Participants will be cohabitating or non-cohabitating fathers with AA mothers receiving individual depression treatment. Mothers will complete measures of depression, anxiety, parenting, perceived social support and other measures at baseline and 1, 3, and 6 months. Fathers who are assigned to participate in the 6-module intervention will complete a measure of depression, anxiety, stress, interparental communication, coparenting relationships, fathers' parenting self-efficacy and parenting stress before and after the intervention. We predict that fathers assigned to the intervention group (n=25) will provide better mental health and parenting skills support and show greater improvements in depression, anxiety, stress, interparental and coparenting relationships relative to the fathers not receiving the intervention (n=25). In addition, mothers in the ASSET-PPD group will be better adjusted and less depressed at 3- and 6-month follow-up. Based on the previous evidence, our preliminary goal for the current study is to enroll 100 participants and retain 70% or higher of eligible dyads. The results of this pilot RCT will be used to design a larger follow-up study to evaluate more robust treatment effects.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) survivors face frequent emotional distress due to cancer diagnosis, treatments, and ongoing survivorship period. Identifying unmet psychosocial needs at the time of cancer diagnosis and survivorship care is important as it helps address psychosocial needs as early as possible and before problems escalate. Screening for depressive symptoms is critical to identify those who may benefit from additional clinical support or referral to mental health specialists.
Moodivate, a mobile app, utilizes a behavioral activation treatment approach and is being evaluated for its effectiveness in treating depressive symptoms among CRC survivors. Moodivate supports participants in identifying values and meaningful activities, provides guidance for completing activities, monitors progress on goals, and prompts reflections on mood throughout the day. Moodivate also connects users to social support from caregivers, friends or family, and to mental health specialists.
The study aims to evaluate the feasibility of a proactive depression screening process to systematically identify CRC survivors and deliver the Moodivate treatment to those with self-reported depressive symptoms. We also aim to evaluate participant interest and acceptance of the Moodivate app. Additionally, the study strives to compare the feasibility and outcomes of using Moodivate for mood management among those with depressive symptoms to usual care.

Objectives of the Study: The goal of this project is to retrospectively test the ability of computable algorithms to detect insulin suspension, simulating a fault related to insulin pump malfunction or failure. This goal is part of a larger effort of improving the safety of current artificial-pancreas systems. Our algorithm will be tested in real cases documented by the study team.
Methods: The study consists of three phases:
Phase 1: Preliminary Data Collection (Free-living data) In this phase, data related to glycemic trends and insulin administration in free-living conditions are collected from the patient's automatic insulin delivery system. This data is obtained from a download form the patient's artificial pancreas. The one-month session is designed to gather a substantial amount of patient-specific data to enable the algorithms to learn how insulin and meals affect the patient's glycemia as recorded by the CGM sensor.
Phase 2: Induction of Hyperglycemia The second phase involves the patient visiting the clinic, where, according to a specific protocol and a defined schedule, insulin infusion is temporarily suspended to simulate a pump malfunction. The resulting episode of hyperglycemia is closely monitored under medical supervision. At the end of the experiment, the study team assists the patient in restoring euglycemia before returning home.
Phase 3: Retrospective Data Analysis In this phase, the collected data is retrospectively analyzed to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension, simulating a pump malfunction. The sensitivity of the tested methods is assessed as the fraction of insulin suspensions (simulating a malfunction) correctly detected by the algorithm. 
The uniqueness of this dataset lies in the controlled induction of malfunction, achieved by disconnecting the insulin pump and monitoring the resulting hyperglycemic episode. The presence of malfunctions in this data is certain and precisely characterized in terms of the start time and duration. The dataset resulting from this experimentation will be a valuable tool for the scientific community, enabling the retrospective testing of fault detection algorithms.

<|assistant|> PMS is a debilitating condition that affects 80% of women in menstruating age. Premenstrual symptoms can negatively affect a woman's quality of life; these include depression, mood swings, irritability, fatigue, bloating, pain, and/or acne. Current treatments, such as exercise, diet modification, and hormonal treatments, have been shown to have limited efficacy. Therefore, many women are seeking alternative and safe forms of PMS relief. Several research studies have discovered the use of herbal remedies - some containing anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and/or anxiolytic properties - as effective alternatives to treat PMS. While some are available in tablet or capsule form, many people prefer a daily snack to consume these remedies. Ginger and cinnamon both contain anti-inflammatory properties, making them ideal to reduce menstrual pain associated with PMS. Acai berry, ginkgo, goji berry, and pomegranate are shown to have high levels of antioxidants, which may help reduce oxidation stress, one of the primary causes of acne. Lastly, Funk It Cycle bites contain a few other ingredients that can provide additional benefits. These snack bites have potential to treat several aspects of PMS, such as menstrual cramps and hormonal acne, without any side effects. Objective: The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of taking Funk It Cycle Bites (a non-prescription, plant-based herbal snack) over the course of 4 months on symptoms related to premenstrual syndrome (PMS) in menstruating women. Hypothesis: Funk It Cycle Bites will significantly reduce the severity of PMS-related symptoms. Design: This will be an open-label, single participant group study and participants will consume 1 Cycle Bite per day for 4 months. At the beginning of each menstrual cycle, participants will complete a survey that will assess their PMS-related symptoms, energy levels, mood stability, acne, and overall experience with the product. Expected outcome: It is expected that participants will report improvements in these areas by the end of the study. Specifically, we anticipate participants experiencing a 25% reduction in PMS-related symptoms. Participant Group/Arm: Experimental: Cycle Bites
Participants will consume 1 Cycle Bite per day.

Childhood caries is one of the highly prevalent chronic diseases in children aged 2 to 5 years, which affect mainly the primary teeth. It is a serious public health issue that results in considerable pain, impaired growth and development along with poor quality of life for the children. Caries is a complex multifactorial disease caused by biological, behavioral, environmental and microbiological factors. A high rate of caries in Jordanian children has been observed in previous studies that emphasized the growing problem of early childhood caries that have significant implications on public health worldwide and in Jordan. Therefore, the aim of this study 1) is to report the prevalence of early childhood caries in children attending kindergartens in Jordan and its associated risk factors, and 2) to determine the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material for children suffering from early childhood caries and its acceptance among parents of children with ECC. 2) Objectives of the study: 1. To determine the prevalence of early childhood caries and its associated risk factors. 2. To evaluate the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride in caries control of children suffering from ECC. 3. To assess parental acceptance of SDF in a sample of randomized controlled trial. 4. To evaluate the long-term sustainability of the application of SDF in children with early childhood caries over an extended period of 1 year. 5. To determine the cost effectiveness of SDF as a caries control material for children experiencing early childhood caries. 6. To provide a strong foundation for implementing an ECC prevention program in Jordan. This study proposed a cross-sectional epidemiological design for obtaining data for a) prevalence of early childhood caries b) early childhood caries risk factors and c) early childhood caries prevention via single application of SDF and its long term sustainability. Consecutive sampling method was used as children were selected from kindergartens that represent different social and economic classes. Data collection was achieved through administration of questionnaires that covered basic demographic, socio-economic, social and behavioral questions on children and their parent. A total of 847 children were examined to detect incidence and prevalence of early childhood caries in Jordanian children. A number of 159 children (18.9%) were detected to have early childhood caries and were randomly assigned into a sample of a randomized controlled trial to receive SDF. These children were examined after 1 year to assess long-term caries control, caries arrest and parental satisfaction.

The Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a common cause of severe lower respiratory tract infections, especially among older adults. Although these patients are at increased risk of death and disability, there are limited treatment options available, and the best prevention strategy remains unclear. Vaccination is the most promising risk reduction approach, but the evidence for effectiveness is limited.
This study investigates the effectiveness of the ABRYSVO vaccine against RSV in older adults in a real-world setting. As one of the largest investigations to date on RSV vaccine effectiveness, this retrospective study will provide valuable insights to inform future prevention strategies and help better protect high-risk populations from severe RSV-related respiratory infections.
To conduct the study, the Kaiser Permanente Southern California (KPSC) Research Program will utilize electronic health data, including members' medical records, laboratory test results, and administrative data on reimbursement and utilization. The investigators will include 400,000+ KPSC members who are 65 years or older, who received the ABRYSVO vaccine between 2014 and 2022, and who had at least 1 year of membership prior to end of study period. This population allows the investigators to gather critical information about vaccine utilization and impact in a real-world setting.
The study will take place from 2015 to 2024 and will fall into two phases: Phase 1 and Phase 2. To identify potential cases (RSV-related LRTI hospitalizations), the investigators will use administrative claims data, while also collecting clinical data to confirm RSV testing and positive results.
To describe vaccine utilization, study investigators will focus on members' use of ABRYSVO, its timing (e.g., preseason vs. postseason) and frequency (e.g., once, twice, incomplete series, or never).
The key outcome of effectiveness will be based on the Test Negative Design (TND). TND combines a case-control study (CCS) with data from medical records, testing, and administrative claims. The TND will be conducted from November 1st of each study year (e.g., 2016 for 2016-2017 study season) until May 31st of the next year (e.g., May 31, 2017 for 2016-2017 study season) in 2 phases. The first phase will assess RSV-related lower respiratory tract infection hospitalizations during the 2016-2017 study season, and the second phase will assess these same events during the 2017-2018 study season.
We will also conduct an additional prospective cohort study (PCS), using KPSC medical record data and administrative claims data. The PCS will estimate the vaccine effectiveness against all-cause outcomes (hospitalizations and ED visits) to further describe the clinical impact of ABRYSVO outside of the traditional definition of LRTI.
Through this study framework, our team will provide estimates of vaccine effectiveness by studying: a) ABRYSVO-vaccinated vs. non-vaccinated members, b) the overall incidence of RSV-related ARI and LRTI for members at high risk vs. low risk, c) ABRYSVO safety and effectiveness across key demographic subgroups (e.g., frailty, comorbidity, age, sex, race, seasonality), and d) member characteristics that will inform future studies.

STATISTICAL ANALYSIS Baseline data will be expressed as a proportion(%), the continuous data will be presented as mean+-SD OR mean ± SD or median ( IQR). To compare between the groups, either, Student's t-test/ Mann Whitney test will be applied, as appropriate. The categorical data will be analysed using χ2test or Fisher's exact test. The change between pre- and post-values will be analysed using paired t-test or McNemar test. Significance defined as 2-tailed p-value of less than 0.05. Survival curves will be represented using Kaplan-Meier method. ITT/ Per protocol analysis will be carried out for final result assessment. Music therapy is a non-pharmaceutical strategy that improves anxiety in several pathologies, and may help alleviate the anxiety and other related symptoms experienced by cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. Despite its many advantages, the use and assessment of music therapy for anxiety reduction in the pathology of breast cancer has not been studied. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of music therapy on anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant or neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. 
The protocol is a monocentric randomized, controlled and non-blind study. It is composed of three study arms: an arm of standard care (control group) and two arms respectively with music therapy before the first 3 sessions of chemotherapy (arm 1) and before the first session and before the end of chemotherapy (arm 2). The evaluation of the impact of music therapy includes biomedical evaluations (blood count, albumin, blood chemistry, and blood pressure) as well as the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) for anxiety evaluation, questionnaires measuring quality of life and other symptoms, and interviews.
The hypothesis tested is that, in comparison to standard care, the effectiveness of music therapy to alleviate anxiety in cancer patients undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy is measured primarily by the reduction in anxiety in patients included in the study and offered music therapy.

The Busulfan included group (Group A, n=88) included patients with high risk factors of mixed chimerism (age < 18 years old or pre-transplant ferritin level ≥2500ng/ml) received conditioning regimen with Busulfan and a total dose of 13.2 mg/kg (ranging from 12 to 14.2 mg/kg).The control group (Group B, n=91) includes patients with low risk factors of mixed chimerism received conditioning regimen with Flu/Cy/ATG or Cy/ATG, depending on the patient's risk factors of regimen related cardiotoxicity.The transplantation related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, incidence of mixed donors, incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation, incidence of graft versus host disease, and overall survival were evaluated by Kaplan Meier method and a two-sided log-rank test.The 1-year progression-free survival was 69%, 70% for CMT group and Busulfan group respectively (p=0.760).The 1-year overall survival was 81% for CMT group and Busulfan group respectively (p=0.653).The 1-year incidence of CMV and EBV reactivation was higher in Busulfan included group comparing with the control group (p=0.018).The transplantation related toxicity and graft versus host disease are similar between two groups (p=0.772, 0.978).In conclusion, the regimen with Busulfan and a total dose of 13.2 mg/kg could reduce the incidence of graft failure. The myeloid and platelet engraftment were similar between transplantation group and control group.The results indicated that the conditioning with Flu/Cy/ATG in patients with low risk factors of mixed chimerism might be the preferential choice for HSCT in SAA.
