Hemophilia A (HA) is classified as a mild, moderate severity, or severe congenital bleeding disorder due to a deficiency of factor VIII (FVIII). People with HA are at risk of experiencing bleeding episodes (of which about one third are joint bleeds), which can be a frequent occurrence. The introduction of Emicizumab Prophylaxis (EP) has been shown in Phase III studies of Hemophilia A (Coagulation Factor VIII Substitute-Bleeding [HEMO-Hemostatic Assessment, FXIII and Von Willebrand] Factor [FIX] Clinics Bleeding [FIXCAB] and Hemophilia European Research Society (HERS) Harmonization Study 7) and Phase 4 (Trial in adults with haemophilia treated in a real-world setting prior to prophylaxis), to decrease the frequency of bleeding episodes. Factor VIII (FVIII) activity was assessed at the beginning of the study as a measure of deficiency to help determine the severity of the condition.
In this study, Emicizumab Prophylaxis (EP) is being used as a treatment for a minimum of one year. This study will describe the safety and tolerability of switching from EP to fitusiran prophylaxis.
Study Population
This is a non-randomized, open-label, single-arm study. A total of 30 participants are planned to be enrolled in this study, which is an expansion from the planned randomized study population of 6 participants to address recent guidance from Health Canada. A subgroup of participants (n = 15) may also be enrolled during a separate dose expansion cohort period if they have previously participated in a fitusiran trial. The participant group/arm is a single treatment arm. The participants are adults aged ≥18 years with severe HA, regardless of their inhibitor status.
Procedures
Participants will receive on demand or prophylactic treatment with intravenous clotting factor concentrates (IV CFCs) or bypassing agents (BPAs) from Month -2 until Day 1. Starting on Day 1, participants will receive subcutaneous (SC) fitusiran prophylaxis once every 2 months (scQ2M) or once monthly (scQM) for 1 year from Day 1 until Month 18 + up to 14 months of extension period (Month 22). Fitusiran dosing period: From Day 1 until Month 18 of fitusiran treatment. Upon clinical need, participants may receive IV antithrombin concentrate (ATIIIC) during the fitusiran treatment regimen. Participants will be followed up until at least 60% of the pre-fitusiran AT levels are achieved (per Central Laboratory).
During this study participants will be followed up for 1 year to evaluate the safety and tolerability of switching from EP to fitusiran prophylaxis. Participants may receive a single dose of fitusiran (1,000 mg) to assess the safety and tolerability of fitusiran as an extension to the study. Subsequently the participants will be monitored after switching to fitusiran. The study will also assess the incidence of treated bleeds during the fitusiran treatment regimen; the severity of bleeding as measured by the Hemorrhagic Episode Assessment; the change in bleeding tendency over a time frame of 1 year, while receiving fitusiran prophylaxis; the change in hemophilia-related health outcomes over the study period, and the impact of switching to fitusiran on participants' quality of life, overall treatment satisfaction, pain intensity, and physical functioning. Following the completion of the fitusiran treatment regimen, participants will receive standard of care (SoC) treatment practices, which include receiving prophylactic treatment with FVIII or BPAs until the bleeding tendency is assessed to be insignificant or at pre-fitusiran levels, or 60% of the pre-fitusiran values have been observed during follow-up. For participants who do not have sufficient pre-fitusiran AT, SoC follow-up will also include receiving IV ATIIIC upon clinical need to help maintain AT levels until the bleeding tendency is assessed to be insignificant and no more than 66% AT levels are observed during follow-up.
Potential Risks and Side Effects: Based on the study, fitusiran prophylaxis was associated with bleeding tendencies and decreased von Willebrand factor function,

The objective of this study is to translate and determine the validity and reliability of the Malay version of PDQ (PDQ-M) to screen patients with chronic pain, following the standard rules for cross cultural adaptation and validation.
Study Population: 40 male and female patients with neuropathic or nociceptive pain who meet the inclusion criteria of the study will be recruited from the tertiary pain center in Prince Of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong and National University Hospital, Singapore.
Study Design: In this cross sectional study, data of 40 patients will be collected and analyzed at once instead of separately by condition (neuropathic pain or nociceptive pain) and/or study phase.
Procedure: Patients with neuropathic or nociceptive pain diagnosed by clinicians will complete an initial questionnaire comprising 3 sections: socio-demographic data, PDQ-M and NRS. In the beginning of questionnaire administration, an information sheet will be given to all patient to encourage them in asking the investigator questions.
Inclusion Criteria: Patients who are male or female, aged ≥18 years, diagnosed to have neuropathic or nociceptive pain by clinician, stable disease condition, pain duration of at least 4 weeks. Exclusion Criteria: Acute illness, poor mental health status that prevents them from understanding or responding to the proposed questions. Subjects with cultural or language barrier in understanding the questions/instructions.
Design: Study was planned for neuropathic pain group and nociceptive pain group simultaneously. Each group will have 20 participants. Therefore, the total number of participants is 40 (20 in each group which is divided into 10 male and female).
Power Analysis: Based on previous studies, the sample size is 40 patients, which will be sufficient to establish the reliability of the PDQ-M.
Statistical Methods: For data analysis, data will be stored on a secure computer and analyzed using Statistical Package for the Social Science (SPSS) software version 18. Normality of the numerical data will be analyzed using Kolmogorov-Smirnov's test. Paired sample T-test or Wilcoxon signed rank test will be employed where appropriate. Spearman's rank correlation test will be used to examine the relationships between the PDQ-M score, NRS and socio-demographic data. Cronbach's Alpha and Intra Class Correlation Coefficient (ICC) will be calculated to assess the reliability of PDQ-M.
Expected Results: It is expected that the translation and validation process of the PDQ-M questionnaire will result in the PDQ-M questionnaire being an efficient tool to assess the level of neuropathic pain in participants with chronic pain. 
Public Health Implication: The use of PDQ-M questionnaire in patients seeking medical service in hospitals or clinics, can provide effective tool in screening patients with neuropathic pain to assist clinicians during the consultation. 
Ethical Approval: This study has received full ethical approval from the Prince Of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong and National University Hospital, Singapore. 
Confidentiality: Confidentiality of the data collected will be maintained at all times. Data will be processed by the Principal Investigator and research team. Results of the research will be summarized in abstract, tables and figures and will not contain any information that can be easily traced to specific individuals.

The purpose of this study is to verify the effectiveness and safety of the Korean Community-based Complex Exercise Program for Stroke Patients (KCoC) and the safety of the exercise intensity of the KCoC for elderly patients.
- Inclusion Criteria: Stroke patients residing in the community aged 30 years or older with a score of 3 or higher in Functional Ambulation Category (FAC) of the lower extremity
   Those with no or mild stiffness of the affected upper and lower limbs according to the Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS)
   All 3 major joints of the affected upper and lower limbs (MMT) are 3 to 5 points (F grade) or higher in scale
   Ruler, and a healthy subject who can communicate orally or by proxy and perform normal activities of daily life, without any contraindications
- Exclusion Criteria: those who are moderately or severely cognitively impaired, those who have difficulty in understanding the intervention exercise program or expressing symptoms due to severe language impairment, those who cannot perform the proposed intervention exercise due to serious cardiovascular disease or those who have musculoskeletal disorders that prevent exercise
Through this study, it is expected that the validity and value of Korean Community-based Complex Exercise Program for Stroke Patients (KCoC), which can be effective for elderly patients as rehabilitation after stroke, will be objectively recognized.

<|assistant|> The liver is one of the vital organs in the body. It plays a crucial role in metabolism and detoxification. The liver has excellent reserve and functional capacity so diseases affecting the liver develop slowly and are generally slowly progressive. These changes may be so subtle that they can exist for years before being recognized. Acute liver disease (ALD) is defined as the presence of clinical jaundice accompanied by coagulopathy and altered liver enzymes. The main complications of ALD are hepatic encephalopathy and variceal bleeding. Severe acute liver disease (SALD) is an umbrella term which includes acute liver failure (ALF) and acute on chronic liver disease (ACLF). ALF is defined by the presence of jaundice, coagulopathy and altered liver enzymes in a patient with no history of chronic liver disease. ACLF is the presence of jaundice, coagulopathy and altered liver enzymes in a patient with known chronic liver disease. ALF is a syndrome with a poor prognosis, a high mortality rate and limited or poor treatment options. In-hospital and early six-month all-cause mortality rate in ALF is 70-80%. The liver acts as a detoxifier to remove drugs from the body, in patients with poor liver function such patients are susceptible to adverse effects from drugs. Studies have shown the effect of the use of prophylactic lactulose and rifaximin administration on the incidence of hepatic encephalopathy in the first days in patients presenting with ALF or acute on chronic liver disease. The objective of this study will be: • To determine the causes of ALD. • To determine the complications of ALD in intensive care unit (ICU). • To find the 30-day mortality rate. • To assess the prognostic accuracy of models of mortality rate in ALD patients. Endometrial cancer is the 5th most common cancer in reproductive-aged women. In some instances, women with endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer may undergo a hysterectomy, which affects fertility and leads to a decrease in the quality of life. There is a significant unmet need to identify effective, non-surgical treatments for these women to preserve fertility. The investigators aim to determine if a telemedicine cognitive behavioral weight loss intervention improves uterine preservation and results in better outcomes in women with endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer.

The aim of this study is to evaluate our new effective laparoscopic technique to perform safely cholecystectomy for the patients affected by acute cholecystitis. Three to four cuts (coconut technique) of the gallbladder wall allow the identification of the cystic duct which represents the way to determine if the procedure was safely completed. After successful identification, the cystic duct is clipped allowing a safe cholecystectomy without performing the Calot triangle procedure.

Athletes' psychological problems after serious injuries have been studied extensively in the last decade. In particular, psychological problems resulting from sports injuries such as anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) can delay physical recovery, affect the quality of rehabilitation, and eventually lead to problems or reinjuries in returning to sports. Re-injury anxiety, poor rehabilitation adherence, poor rehabilitation self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia are the most important psychological problems encountered in this research. Although various interventions have been proposed for the resolution of these problems, structured intervention protocol has not been presented yet. This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of the Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with virtual reality (VR) usage for the solution of psychological problems that arise after ACL operation. It is thought that a holistic protocol including virtual intervention that is tested for the first time in the literature and will be a novel contribution to the psychological problem arising from sports. In the study, which is planned as a 4X5 mixed factorial design model (groupsXmeasures) in a randomized control trial framework, the athletes will be filled with psychological assessment scales in order to collect the first data within the first week of entering physical therapy after surgery. The CBT+VR protocol, which includes 10 sessions in total once a week, will be applied to the athletes in both the experimental groups and the first intervention group. In the second intervention group, only the behavioral intervention part of the protocol will be applied in the VR environment. The CBT protocol will be applied without a VR environment for the third intervention group. In all the intervention groups and the control group, 5 sessions in total once a week will be applied. In addition to the scales to be filled by the athletes, the biofeedback system will be used to record the increase or decrease in anxiety levels in the VR environment at the end of the research.

The role of physical therapists in acute care hospitals in patients' post-acute care is currently inadequate. To improve this system, the investigators have developed a patient-level decision support tool, the Physical Therapy Frequency Clinical Decision Support Tool (PT-PENCIL) that facilitates referrals for physical therapy by identifying patients who may benefit from daily physical therapy sessions. The trial will assess the effect and feasibility of using this tool to predict risk versus benefit of physical therapy services.
A hybrid 24-week, stepped-wedge, patient-oriented randomized controlled trial with three phases, is being conducted: enrollment (Weeks 1-2), 24 weeks of implementation (Week 3-24), and follow up (week 24-26). During the enrollment and implementation periods, patients hospitalized on the participating units and meeting inclusion criteria will be eligible for enrollment. Only the inpatient physical therapist assigned to the patient care team responsible for the patient will have access to these data to guide their referral for physical therapy.
All inpatient physical therapists and patient referral sources including attending physicians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants will be eligible to participate in the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility measures. During the follow up period, a control cohort of patients with similar clinical characteristics to those treated with the PT-PENCIL during the trial will be examined to determine the effect of having the PT-PENCIL and BPA alerts available in the electronic health record.
The primary goal of this study is to show that the PT-PENCIL reduces the percentage of patients discharged to post-acute care rehabilitation at the 24-week mark. The secondary goals include testing the feasibility and acceptability of the trial and documenting the effect and feasibility of the system outside the study environment.

Background: The elbow being a highly constrained synovial hinge joint has a high propensity for degeneration and stiffness. There could be functional losses seen with even less severe loss of range of motion (ROM) at the elbow. The stiff or contracted elbow is defined as an elbow with a reduction in extension greater than 30 degrees, and/or a flexion less than 120 degrees. Although supination and pronation are often reduced as well, this will not be considered further as contracture of the elbow is not related to forearm rotation.
Objectives: The aim of this study is to establish whether there is any difference between the Maitland mobilization and the Post facilitation stretch in improving functional outcomes such as ROM and pain in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients.
Methods: This study was a randomized, controlled trial, conducted among post-traumatic stiff elbow patients. Sample size was 32 by using G Power Calculator. Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention or control group after a baseline assessment with a lottery ticket and an opaque envelope. All participants in both groups were evaluated on two occasions: (i) baseline (ii) After 4 weeks of intervention.
Results: The results of this study suggest that in the immediate terms, there is no difference between Post Facilitation Stretch and Maitland Mobilisation in terms of ROM and Pain in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients. In the long-term both the techniques can be utilized in clinical practice.
Conclusion: This is the first study of its kind, to establish whether there is any difference between the Maitland mobilization and the Post facilitation stretch in improving ROM and pain in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients.
Clinical Applications: This study provides new information to the clinician on the different interventions available to restore the ROM in post-traumatic stiff elbow patients. It was seen that PFS and MM has different immediate effects both in terms of ROM and pain. Further studies with a larger sample size are required for its conclusive results.

The use of intravenous fluids is crucial in maintaining adequate volume status. However, the mechanisms by which intravenous fluids improve haemodynamic variables are often unpredictable. Recently, the use of LBNP as a model of central hypovolemia has been reintroduced. LBNP has been used for more than half a century and has been shown to be a good model for studying hypovolemia in human participants. However, there are few studies comparing volume effects following intravenous fluid bolus in LBNP compared to baseline. We therefore aim to compare two types of intravenous fluids following the use of LBNP. Intravenous fluids are necessary to ensure adequate extracellular volume status, however it is less known which type of fluid that best ensure rapid adequate volume expansion.
We have shown in our previous work that the use of LBNP (1 liter) reduces intravascular volume compared to baseline in healthy male volunteers, and the reduction is larger without intravenous fluids (no intravenous fluids) compared to the group with continuous Ringer´s Acetate infusion. Based on our previous findings we will conduct this randomized clinical trial to explore which type of fluid (Ringer´s Acetate) that best ensure adequate hemodynamic response during experimental central hypovolemia.

Perioperative pain is defined as pain from the time of surgery and before discharge or discontinue of analgesic. Perioperative pain requires a combination of analgesia and a method of analgesia to reduce opioid use to prevent postoperative nausea, vomiting and constipation. Ultrasound-guided interfascial plane block/erector spinal plane/lidocaine anesthesia has become the focus of research in postoperative analgesia, which is beneficial to reducing opioid use and other adverse reactions of systemic analgesics. However, there is still no strong recommendation for them. A series of clinical trials found that the incidence of adverse reactions of these three methods are not significantly improved compared with lidocaine anesthesia. Based on the above, this study mainly focuses on the application of three interventions in perioperative analgesia, and compares their effects on perioperative analgesia, postoperative complications and satisfaction of patients, and to provide scientific support for clinical analgesic techniques.

In some populations, pulse oximeters' readings may be inaccurate due to skin pigmentation variations. The investigators' novel device, the Wearable Melanin-Adjusted Biological Oximetry Sensor (MABOS), was developed to address this issue. It is a pulse oximeter that compensates for skin pigmentation variations of up to 10 shades of skin tone and could, in turn, save lives. The device has been granted clearance by the U.S. FDA. It is crucial to assess the device's safety, comfort, and accuracy. There is the chance that the device could harm participants, cause discomfort or not be effective. Therefore, this study aims to assess the safety of our novel pulse oximeter, including the possibility of causing discomfort or rashes, as well as its accuracy. The investigators will conduct the feasibility study in healthy individuals with differing levels of skin tone, such as those with skin tones associated with those of African or East Asian descent. Healthy individuals, defined as those with no significant medical illnesses and/or medications that would interfere with the study, will be recruited. Following approval of the study by the Institutional Review Board, participants will be asked for verbal consent and then asked to complete two surveys: one regarding safety/comfort and another regarding accuracy/performance. They will be informed that they have the option to quit, should they choose not to continue. To determine the effect of the device on skin integrity, participants will wear both the novel pulse oximeter and the FDA-approved device simultaneously on the same finger(s). Participants will not receive any personal benefit from this study, only possible satisfaction through an active effort towards a worthy, non-profit goal.

This study will evaluate the efficacy and safety of Camrelizumab Plus Chemotherapy + famitinib compared to Camrelizumab Plus Chemotherapy, without famitinib, in participants with early or locally advanced, histologically confirmed Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC). Patients in the study will be randomized to receive either Camrelizumab Plus Chemotherapy + famitinib or Camrelizumab Plus Chemotherapy alone. All patients will be treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy comprising Albumin-paclitaxel plus carboplatin regimen for approximately 4 cycles. Patients in the experimental arm will receive oral famitinib (40mg QD) after the first cycle of chemotherapy. Patients receiving the intervention arm will receive 3 doses of camrelizumab (200mg, IV, Q3W) after the first cycle of chemotherapy. After 6 cycles of neoadjuvant therapy, patients will undergo definitive surgery. Patients will continue to receive camrelizumab postoperatively, up to 6 cycles (18 weeks). All patients will receive supportive care as part of their treatment regimen. Approximately 5 years after randomization, patients will be followed up to assess disease-free survival and overall survival. A subset of patients on each treatment arm will also undergo liquid biopsy at specified time points to monitor changes in tumor DNA.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) occurs in approximately 10% of pregnancies, and postpartum persistence of hyperglycemia is reported in about a quarter of patients with impaired glucose tolerance at 6 weeks to 4 or 6 months postpartum. However, there is no clear understanding of the pathogenesis pathways of hyperglycemia or the mechanisms by which GDM increases the risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) postpartum. This study attempted to establish a method to identify hyperglycemic women with GDM at high risk of postpartum abnormal glucose metabolism by performing a metabolomics analysis with lipidomics, amino acidomics, and glycerolomics. This is the first study to comprehensively analyze the differences in lipids, amino acids, and glycerol in the serum of GDM patients and non-GDM pregnant women. Additionally, the researchers searched for markers with significant statistical differences and strong correlations with postpartum abnormal glucose metabolism. In addition, the results are verified by a large number of data: 24-28 weeks of pregnancy or delivery, the results are verified by follow-up of 6-12 weeks. The results showed that the lipid profile, amino acid profile, and glycerol profile at 24-28 weeks of pregnancy were significantly correlated with the 2-hour blood glucose standard in OGTT at 6-12 weeks postpartum. These abnormalities can be used as early warning indicators for GDM at high risk of abnormal glucose metabolism. This study provides new ideas and research methods for the prevention and intervention of postpartum type 2 diabetes mellitus in women with gestational diabetes mellitus.

Patients hospitalized in intensive care unit are frequently interrupted during their sleep by procedures or by caregivers interventions which disturb their physiological sleep process and induce fatigue and adverse outcomes including delirium, myopathy, metabolic disorders and even death. Sleep disturbances of these patients lead to poor outcomes. The purpose of this project is to evaluate the feasibility and interest of a new method of sleep management by continuous EEG registration in critically ill patients in the medical intensive care unit (MICU) of the University Hospital of Tours. Patients may benefit from an algorithm that allows to differentiate sleep states from care needs and to provide non urgent cares when the patient is asleep and urgent care according to medical needs when the patient is either asleep or active but not under sedation. The primary objective is the improvement of sleep quality in this specific population by protecting sleep. Secondary objectives are the prevention of delirium, the improvement of weaning time from mechanical ventilation, the reduction of workload for caregivers and the improvement of patient compliance and satisfaction. The primary hypothesis is: "In comparison with control condition, EEG guided sleep prioritization scheme will improve sleep quality of critically ill patients". If it is confirmed, we will use this technique in daily patient management. Another hypothesis is that it may promote less anxiety.

Another objective is to compare the safety and tolerability of SAR441566, in comparison with placebo. Background: The performance of tests used to rule out HIV, HBV and HCV is usually poor especially in the case of finger prick. The MaGIA IBC test is a qualitative rapid test designed for capillary but has been successfully adapted to veinous blood, serum and plasma. Such an adaptation could facilitate and improve the screening of HIV, HBV and HCV. Aims: To perform a monocentric, descriptive study in order to evaluate the performance of the MagIA IBC test in different matrices compared to standard laboratory test. To assess the safety of the MagIA IBC test in different matrices compared to standard laboratory test. Methodology: This study is opened without any limit of inclusion. It is a single arm study. The study performance includes 125 days maximum from the inclusion of the first patient to the inclusion of the last patient. On the day of the study, patients will be asked to give all necessary information and sign a consent form if they agree to participate to the study. A finger prick is taken to perform the MagIA IBC test and a safety venous blood sample for standard laboratory tests. Then, venous blood may be taken in a 6mL plastic tube approved for the test and in a second tube (6mL) for a standard laboratory test to confirm preliminary results. If there is no HCV, HBV or HIV infection, the patient will leave the study and will be contacted in the next month for a follow up. If the result is positive, an extended blood sample and an HIV, HBV and HCV genotype will be taken and will be sent to the laboratory for confirmation.

Endocalyx, the food supplement currently being tested, is developed for the daily supplementation of glycosaminoglycans. The primary objective is to 
1. Determine whether Endocalyx can reduce sodium and water excess in patients with chronic heart failure and 
2. Evaluate whether Endocalyx will improve physical limitations and reported symptoms of excess of fluid; quality of life; and patient-reported symptoms. The secondary objectives are to 
3. Determine working mechanisms of Endocalyx in heart failure patients and 
4. Evaluate whether Endocalyx can positively affect cardiac and vascular parameters, tissue sodium and hydration, body weight, blood pressure, heart rate, micro-vascular function and inflammatory status. Endocalyx is expected to safely reduce sodium and water excess in these patients, which has important cardiovascular consequences.

-----------------
Safety and efficacy of a dietary supplement of glycosaminoglycans (Endocalyx) for patients with chronic heart failure: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study

-----------------
Heart Failure

* Other: placebo

=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: Documented or suspected heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF and HFmrEF according to ESC guidelines). Signs of congestion, defined as: a. Elevated NT-proBNP levels: i. >450 pg/ml in subjects aged <55 years. ii. >900 pg/ml in subjects aged 55-75 years. iii. >1800 pg/ml in subjects aged >75 years. AND b. Use of diuretics, OR c. Presence of peripheral edema, OR d. Complaints of orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, OR e. A chest X-rays with sings of volume overload, OR f. Hypertension, as defined by an office blood pressure >140/90 mmHg. Stable diuretic and antihypertensive treatment for the previous 3 weeks. Subject, or legal representative, has voluntarily signed and dated an Informed Consent Form, approved by an Institutional Review Board (IRB)/Independent Ethics Committee (IEC), after the nature of the study has been explained and the subject has had the opportunity to ask questions. The informed consent must be signed before any study-specific procedures are performed. Rationale for the inclusion criteria: (1-3) To select the adequate subject population with appropriate disease severity for the evaluation. NT-proBNP levels are known to increase with age.(21, 22) The cutoffs of NT-proBNP levels were selected according the 2021 European Society of Cardiology Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic heart failure. (23) (4) In accordance with GCP. Should inclusion prove difficult, we will lower required NT-proBNP levels by 25% to respectively 338, 675 and 1350 pg/ml. We will notably notify the METC of this decision. Exclusion Criteria: Age <18 years. Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) <15 ml/min/1.73m2 measured by the Chronic Kidney Disease Epidemiology Collaboration (CKD-EPI) formula. Systolic (<105 mmHg) or diastolic hypotension (<60 mmHg) as measured by office blood pressure measurements. Severe symptoms of (orthostatic) hypotension. An acute coronary syndrome, stroke, transient ischemic attack or cardiovascular surgery in the last 3 months. Hospitalization for heart failure in the past 3 weeks. Dialysis treatment or expected initiation of dialysis within 3 months of screening. Women of child bearing potential. Planned surgery in the next 8 weeks. Major surgery in the previous 4 weeks. Use of any other investigational drug. Presence of any other clinically significant disorder that would compromise the subject's safety or the study's integrity.

<|assistant|> Background: Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction (aSBO) is a common complication of abdominal surgery with an overall recurrence rate of 2.7%. The only definitive treatment shown to reduce the frequency of recurrence in a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is operative adhesiolysis; however, the majority of patients presenting with aSBO can be treated non-operatively with a nasogastric tube (NGT) and fasting or total parenteral nutrition (TPN) until bowel function returns. Recently, a small study suggested that aSBO can be treated with a combination of NGT and water soluble oral contrast without the use of either fasting or TPN, however, this study was not powered for outcome analysis and only included eight patients. Objectives: The primary aim of this study is to compare the use of NG tube with versus without NG tube with water-soluble contrast in patients presenting with non-incarcerated aSBO. Additional aims include comparing the use of NG tube with naso-jejunal tube (NJ) with and without water-soluble contrast, assessing the effect of water-soluble contrast on recovery of gut function, determining the incidence of post-operative complications in aSBO presenting patients and determining the impact of water-soluble contrast on recovery of normal gut function, quality of life, and patient satisfaction in patients undergoing surgical treatment for aSBO. Study Design: This study is an international, multi-centre, randomized controlled trial of consecutive adult patients presenting with aSBO. Patients will be randomized into treatment with NG tube with water-soluble contrast (WSC = 100cc Gastrografin), NG tube and saline or NG tube alone. Patients randomized to the NG tube alone study arm will be followed prospectively. Official Title ----------------- Use of Nasogastric Tubes and Water Soluble Contrast in the Management of Small Bowel Obstruction: A Feasibility Study Conditions ----------------- Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction Intervention / Treatment ----------------- * Drug: Gastrografin * Drug: Saline * Procedure: SBO Treatment Without NG Tubes Participation Criteria ================= Eligibility Criteria ----------------- Inclusion Criteria: Male or female ≥18 years of age. Documentation of aSBO as evidenced by one or more clinical features meeting the following criteria: Nausea, emesis, abdominal pain, distended abdomen CT evidence of aSBO Exclusion Criteria: Pregnant, breastfeeding, or unwilling to practice birth control during participation in the study. Presence of a condition or abnormality that in the opinion of the investigator would compromise the safety of the patient or the quality of the data. Achieving sustained HBsAg negative rate in a single group of patients after nucleic acid analogues (NAs) based treatment is one of the major challenges in chronic hepatitis B (CHB) treatment. Immune therapy is another novel treatment strategy for CHB treatment. In recent years, many new drugs based on immune therapy have been investigated for prevention and treatment of HBV including immune checkpoint inhibitor, immune cell transplantation and immune agonist etc. Many researchers believe that immune therapy may increase the ability of NAs to achieve functional cure of HBV infection. At present, combination of these three methods is widely used in the clinic of hepatocellular carcinoma treatment, which may lead to a better effect on CHB. In this study, the efficacy and safety of sustained viral negative rate after NAs combined with anti-programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) antibody and pegylated interferon(PEG-IFNα) in different regimens are investigated, which may provide a novel combination strategy for the treatment of chronic HBV infection and functional cure of HBV infection.

Children with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), especially those treated for the disease with nusinersen or risdiplam, may still experience motor difficulties that lead to decreased physical activity and time spent in upright positions. The present study aims to learn more about the use of a portable, in-home body weight support harness system for these children. The long term goals of this project are to identify (and quantify) the benefits of such an intervention in this population, but first, to test the usability and practicality of using the harness system in the home environment. Our initial focus is on 3 key questions: (1) Can a caregiver use the harness system with their child(ren) with the appropriate supports in place? (2) Do children with SMA enjoy the use of the harness system? and (3) Does the harness system lead to more time spent in upright positions compared to a child who uses only physical therapy exercises?
We will use a variety of questionnaires and motor assessments to answer the previously mentioned questions. Families who participate will be asked to fill out a survey after each use of the system to assess their perceptions (perceived benefits, perceived ease of use, etc). We will also ask the participant and caregiver to record how often and for how long they use the harness system. Physical therapists will administer a variety of motor performance tests prior to, and after, the use of the system. We expect that families will be able to use the harness system at home and that this will lead to more upright, functional activities in affected children. With more research, we hope to develop and refine ways to use this or other mobility aids so that children with SMA can continue to move, play, and interact with the world around them.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common compression neuropathy. The main symptoms include pain and other unpleasant sensations in hand and wrist. In more advanced stage, weakness and wasting of the thenar and other muscles innervated by median nerve occurs, which may lead to permanent impairment of manual performance. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) remain the method of choice in diagnosing CTS. However ultrasonography (US) is increasingly used along with or instead of NCS. Most frequently, the increase of the cross-sectional area of the median nerve at the inlet to the carpal tunnel is regarded as the marker of CTS. A number of other measurements such as median nerve mobility, volar bulging of flexor retinaculum and others were also studied to increase diagnostic sensitivity and specificity. In this study the investigators aim to assess the utility of measurements made at the point of the maximal stenosis of the median nerve in the tunnel to diagnose CTS. So far, there were only few studies, which visualized the maximal nerve stenosis, which is the essential pathological feature of CTS. In general, the group of patients with CTS and controls will undergo NCS of symptomatic median and ipsilateral ulnar nerves and US of the symptomatic median nerve with measurements of the cross-sectional area, diameter and echogenicity at various points, including the point of the maximal stenosis. The location of the maximal stenosis with respect to external (distal crease) and internal (wrist and hand bones and thenar musculature) will also be evaluated. Subjects will also be asked to fill out the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) and a demographic questionnaire. US measurements will be compared between patients and healthy volunteers. US measurements, especially those made at the point of stenosis will be correlated among patients with clinical severity of CTS, reflected by the score in BCTQ and with the grade of electrophysiological severity as introduced by Padua et al. [1].

Infertility is a worldwide epidemic. One common form of male infertility is severe oligoastheno-teratospermia (OAT), which is characterized by sperm concentrations of less than 15 million/ml and motility and/or morphology less than 40%. Another form of male infertility is male factor infertility with high sperm DNA fragmentation. DNA fragmentation is associated with lower fertilization rate, lower embryo quality and lower implantation rate. Infertile couples with OAT who are undergoing in vitro fertilization cycles have to use donor sperm or the technique of testicular sperm aspiration (TESA). TESA is associated with lower ovarian response rates. Another approach of sperm selection is based on the selection of sperm with the lowest DNA fragmentation. Here, microfluidics technology is used. The microfluidic devices used within one of these systems are called Zymot. Based on the observation that male factor infertility with high DNA fragmentation is responsible for more than 50% of all ICSI cycles, the investigators have started to evaluate the results of a single center, prospective, multicenter, non-interventional study (AOP_35_A). The aim of this study is to collect information from couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation undergoing TESA ICSI or zymot ICSI. From 10 study centers the following data will be collected: patients' age, sperm concentration, sperm motility, sperm morphology, sperm DNA fragmentation and endometrial preparation. Finally, clinical endpoints will be assessed in relation to the performed technique (TESA ICSI vs. zymot ICSI). Thus, the investigators will evaluate the outcome of the treatment in couples with oligoastheno-teratospermia and high sperm DNA fragmentation and compare the results of both techniques (TESA ICSI vs. zymot ICSI). This study will support the evidence-based decision on the sperm selection method for couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation.

Archery can be described as a comparatively static sport requiring strength and endurance of the upper body, in particular the forearm and shoulder girdle. Skill in archery is defined as the ability to shoot an arrow to a given target in a certain time span with accuracy. The discipline is described as a three-phase (the stance, the drawing and the sighting) movement. Shooting can be divided these phases into six: bow hold, drawing, full draw, aiming, release and follow-through. Each of these phases represented a stable sequence of movements and was ideal for studying the motor control and skill acquired during this voluntary kinematic process. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance at the cervical, lumbal and scapular levels in archery athletes. A total of 40 archery athletes aged between 10 and 18, who have been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year were included in the study. Demographic information and musculoskeletal system evaluations of the athletes were done. Performance of the athletes via Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test; presence of scapular dyskinesia was evaluated via the Lateral Scapular Slide Test. Cervical region stabilization was evaluated via Craniocervical Flexion Test, scapular level stabilization was evaluated via Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, lumbar region stabilization was evaluated via Abdominal Drawing-in Test and Sahrmann's Core Stability Test. As the parameters related to stabilization, postures via Corbin Postural Rating Scale; balances via Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test; pain was evaluated via the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. Shooting performances were evaluated with 72 target shootings and a total of 720 points.

The research question this study aims to address is: Can an artificial intelligence text chatbot enhance sexual health communication and contraceptive counseling between pediatricians and adolescent-mother dyads? The study has three specific aims in staged, qualitative and quantitative research. A mixed-methods design will be used for this purpose. Stage 1: Characterize communication content and styles of pediatrician-adolescent-parent triads on contraception discussions with 50 real-life clinical encounters using validated scales to describe overall quality of the interactions, communication (confidence, comfort, self-efficacy, confidentiality) and decision-making (perceived autonomy, ownership, and power). Stage 2: Upload de-identified and anonymized vignettes to an AI communication training tool to develop and refine the tool through prompt engineering and performance evaluation with adolescent, parent and pediatrician advisory boards to tailor the tool for the needs for adolescent contraceptive care. Stage 3: To compare evaluation results of 50 pre-training and 50 post-training real encounters to test if an AI communication intervention tool can improve reproductive health encounters and communication interactions with pediatricians, adolescents and mothers. This study aims to improve reproductive health encounters and empower adolescents and mothers by engaging all parties in the communication process (i.e. by training pediatricians to improve skills in contraceptive counseling with adolescent-mother dyads). The investigators will also evaluate how cultural and family factors influence the communication process. With a novel approach of using AI-assisted communication training, this research proposal has the potential to advance science by addressing the implementation needs for better contraceptive counseling and communication between pediatricians, adolescents and mothers.

Vitiligo is an autoimmune disorder that causes patches of white or yellow skin. There is growing evidence to suggest that the burden of vitiligo may not be uniform across patient/public populations. We will analyse real-world data to determine the burden of disease for vitiligo in the UK population, and to investigate health disparities in this group.
The first aim of the study is to establish the lifetime risk of developing vitiligo, along with its associated sociodemographic factors (age, sex, ethnicity and deprivation). This work aims to determine if the risk of developing vitiligo is not equal.
The second aim is to understand any differences in mental health, healthcare utilisation and work-related impact between different patient groups.
By understanding if disparities exist in vitiligo care, patients and healthcare providers can tailor support plans to improve patient outcomes and quality of life.

This is an early-phase study, a so-called "phase I" study, where BMS-751866 will be used in the treatment of patients with breast cancer.

The purpose of this study is to investigate if acute dietary nitrate ingestion, provided as beetroot juice, elicits improvements in various neuromuscular performance parameters during resistance exercise performance when compared to supplementing the diet with a nitrate-depleted beetroot juice placebo. The project will provide information on the dose-response effect of beetroot juice on resistance exercise performance by providing low, moderate, and high nitrate dose of concentrated beetroot juice. This project will provide insight to practitioners [coaches/athletes] aiming to enhance performance in settings where high power and speed are key determinants of success and to scientists exploring the efficacy of beetroot juice as a form of dietary nitrate supplementation to improve muscle contractile function.
                A total of 30 recreationally active and strength trained males will be recruited for this study. Participants will complete 4 experimental trials to consume 4 beetroot juice shots with a volume of 140 ml ingested at different times before performing strength training exercise. Each condition has 20 minutes between the consumption of the beetroot shots and the start of the test exercise. The duration of this study is estimated to be at least 1 year or until the enrollment of 30 participants is achieved.

Postoperative complications are frequent complications that follow surgical operations. Postoperative respiratory complications (PPCs) are among the most common surgical complications seen as postoperative complications. The need to protect the organs inside the thorax during surgical procedures, especially in abdominal and thoracic surgery, increases the use of artificial ventilation devices in the intensive care unit and increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications. Intra-abdominal hypertension can be seen due to abdominal hypertension at intra-abdominal pressure values of 15-20 mmHg in patients in the intensive care unit following major surgery. Abdominal compartment syndrome can be seen at intra-abdominal pressure values above 20 mmHg. The need to press the lungs inside the thoracic cavity due to the air space of the abdomino-pelvic cavity increases the application of high ventilation pressures to ensure mechanical ventilation. In the results obtained in the research published; increased mechanical force has been associated with increased in-hospital mortality and prolonged hospital stay and increased need for ICU follow-up. The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of two different intra-operative intra-abdominal pressure levels applied to patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia; The mechanical power (MP) of the patients and to determine whether there is a difference between the mechanical power values when laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed using intra-abdominal pressure of 12 mmHg and 14 mmHg.
The investigators think that studying the effect of two different intra-operative intra-abdominal pressure levels aimed in laparoscopic cholecystectomy operations will contribute to the literature in this field.

The purpose is to evaluate the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) with a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead (Solia S lead) for ventricular pacing in symptomatic bradycardia patients. This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized, multi-center study to investigate the feasibility and stability of LBBAP for ventricular pacing in symptomatic bradycardia patients with a conventional bipolar, active-fixation pacing lead (Solia S lead). This study aims to determine whether Solia S leads can provide both appropriate sensing and lead stability for LBBAP. The investigators also aim to evaluate the feasibility of the delivery system and compare the clinical outcomes at 12-months post-implant to those in previous clinical trials where LBBAP with other leads has been performed. At least 120 patients will be implanted with the Solia S lead and followed for 1 year. The main study endpoints will include implant success rate, intracardiac EG recordings, serial changes of echo data, safety, and pacing parameters. The average QRS duration, pacing-QRS interval, and intra-operative fluoroscopic exposure time will be included and analyzed. Other clinical outcomes such as procedural efficacy, device failure rate, and left ventricular systolic function will be monitored and recorded as secondary endpoints. Additionally, the potentials of the Solia lead for left bundle branch area pacing will be explored in further electrophysiological mapping studies and multi-center comparative studies for longer-term follow-ups.

<|assistant|> Yogic breathing styles are practiced in yoga and are known to have an impact on the human body and brain. This effect is now assumed not to be limited to yoga and meditation but could also be elicited by everyday-life yoga-based breathing styles. In comparison to other breathing techniques like hyperventilation, the aim of this study is to investigate the effect of controlled yoga-based breathing styles on memory performance and to reduce the amount of distraction which may occur on a daily basis. This study was designed to verify the hypothesis that yogic breathing styles can improve both the memory performance of learned visual information and the subjective stress level. A randomized controlled trial on 60 healthy volunteers in three groups to improve their learning and memory performance and to reduce the subjective stress level during the learning process. The test measures performed in a memory test with the aid of neuroimaging. After the initial measurements, the participants will take part in a memory improvement test. The results will be used as a first status of the cognitive and stress-related performance. During the two weeks of the test, group I will perform 5-10 breaths per day for 15 minutes using controlled nose-breathing, group II will perform 5-10 breaths per day for 15 minutes using controlled mouth-breathing and group III will not do any intervention. After the two weeks of training, the memory improvement test will be performed again. <|assistant|> Background: Burn injuries can lead to liver damage. Currently there is no recommended exercise program and physiotherapy for patients, who often suffer from liver disease. As a result, treatment approaches in the post-acute phase that include regular exercise have been proposed to counteract these negative effects. Pulsed electromagnetic fields (PEMFs) have also been recently used for the treatment of osteoporosis, arthritis, muscle soreness, and for the improvement of rehabilitation after orthopedic surgeries. The objective of the present study is to determine the immediate and long-term effect of calisthenics exercises program and PEMF therapy protocol on liver function after burn injury in comparison with other therapy protocols. Study Hypothesis: - Participating in a calisthenics exercise program and pulsed electromagnetic field therapy protocol will not have a significant difference on liver function. Methods: 90 burned patients will participate with equal distribution in the three groups. Each group will consist of 30 burned patients who will meet the inclusion criteria: age ranges between 20-45 years, male and female patients, all patients have burns with BBSA about 30% to 50%, all patients enrolled on the study will have their informed consent. All patients will be evaluated with serum biochemistries before recruitment and the same blood sample will be taken from the burned patients before starting calisthenics exercises program, pulsed electromagnetic field therapy protocol or placebo therapy protocol in the 3 groups. Also in between in 3 months and at the end of the study in 6 months, a blood sample will be taken for the evaluation of liver enzymes. Participators in the groups 2 and 3 will apply their own treatment protocols of calisthenics exercises program and PEMF therapy protocol and their physiotherapist will record the number of patient sessions. Patients in control group 1 will apply placebo therapy protocol for the same periods of time as the other groups. All patients will follow a low calorie high protein diet of less than 2000 Kcal/day. Patients will be informed that they will be allocated to their own protocol groups randomly. Data will present as mean ± standard deviation (SD). The two-tailed Student-t test (t-test) will be used to compare means between groups if the distribution was normally distributed. The Mann-Whitney test will be used in case of departure from normal distribution. The statistical significance will be considered as p < 0.05. This preliminary study provides a novel alternative to the traditional methods of treatment, calisthenics exercise program and PEMF therapy, for the counteraction of liver damage of burned patients, and can be used as an adjunct treatment after burn injury. History of liver diseases. Body mass index (BMI=kg/cm2)<30%. Background: The investigators have previously hypothesized that high energy/high protein nutritional supplements may decrease protein clearance including drug clearance. This can be beneficial for increasing bioavailability of the immune checkpoint inhibitor pembrolizumab (Pd1 inhibitor) in patients with cancer receiving immunotherapy, leading to increased clinical efficacy of PD-1 ICIs as well as increased patient survival. This has not been studied in cancer patients before.
Objectives: The primary aim is to investigate the variability of clearance during a 12-weeks nutritional intervention period. The secondary aim is to investigate the feasibility for the subjects to comply with the study protocol. Lastly, the investigators aim to study the feasibility of gathering data on a number of exploratory parameters that may link nutritional intake to clinically relevant outcomes.
Study design: NutriCim is a feasibility study to gather information on NSCLC patient recruitment, data collection and compliance of patients receiving a 12-weeks nutritional intervention before and during their first treatment cycle of immunotherapy. Blood samples, questionnaires and faecal specimens will be collected on several time points during this treatment, to examine the effects of a nutritional intervention on the patient's nutritional, immune, and microbiome status with a primary focus on the anti-PD-1 ICIs' efficacy, immunogenicity, and patient outcomes.

The Investigators are designing a multifactorial study, called GAPsy (GliAma signaling in Anxiety and Protocadherins in depression for Psychiatry), to identify common molecular targets implicated in anxiety and depression disorders.
Investigators have recently discovered two novel markers of brain circuitry in psychiatric populations, protocadherin 9 (Pcdh9) and the integrin β3.
The presence of Pcdh9 has been detected in cortical networks involved in the generation of anxiety and depression in mice; integrin β3, instead, is highly expressed within the prefrontal cortex where it controls the number and morphology of excitatory synapses, and its activity is regulated by stress.
In preliminary studies, the investigators have discovered that Pcdh9 modulates the binding of integrin to the brain, and is downregulated in cells within the cerebral cortex of patients with MDD, in both acute and chronic phases.
In addition, a genetic variant of Pcdh9 has been associated with MDD susceptibility.
The Investigators also have recently shown the interaction between integrin β3 and Pcdh9 in brain cortical networks, and their association with anxiety and depressive symptoms that affect the daily life of millions of people in Europe.
The goal of the GAPsy study is to assess whether changes in glutamatergic transmission are specifically modulated by alterations of these two proteins.

The gut microbiome and human genes interact in multiple ways, involving complex regulatory mechanisms, such as metabolic and signaling pathways. Gut microbiota-encoded proteins (MEPs) are a class of host-microbe interaction proteins. Previous studies and our research team's own data have found that compared with the human genome, the gut microbes contain more proteins, many proteins are related to human diseases. The proteins of the human genome are involved in regulating the gut microbial composition; The proteins of microbial genomes are also associated with the development of human diseases. Combining clinical data with proteomic data, genomic data, and microbial composition data of human gut flora and cardiovascular-related diseases to study its pathogenesis mechanism in microbial regulation, and to seek early diagnosis and treatment options.
The cardiovascular and nervous system are closely related to each other. The gut microbes are expected to play a role in treating diseases of the cardiovascular and nervous system.
The investigators propose to set up research cohorts of cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and healthy controls, and collect blood and fecal samples. Based on the multi-omics detection results, the researchers propose to use machine learning methods, including multi-layer graph networks and artificial neural networks, to jointly analyze the big data of blood and bowel samples, and then to identify potential interaction pathways between the human genome and the gut microbial proteins, and then propose a multi-omics multi-dimensional model for early diagnosis of cardiovascular and nervous system diseases.
In order to verify the authenticity of the study results and to propose a targeted prevention and treatment method for cardiovascular and nervous system diseases, the research team proposes to use fecal transplantation technology (including oral and nasal transplantation) to test the effectiveness and safety of fecal transplantation.
This research plan aims to establish a multi-omics big-data database of cardiovascular and nervous system diseases, to establish human blood and gut microbiome proteome libraries, to find disease-related gene/protein/metabolic signatures, to conduct mechanistic studies based on biological and physical experiments, and also to verify the clinical diagnostic and treatment value of disease risk prediction models and diagnostic tools based on multi-omics big data. The study may have a broader impact in improving early diagnosis and disease prevention, and will provide new direction for the study of gut microbiota associated diseases.

Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is an area of active investigation for immunotherapy, and treatment decisions are more difficult for patients with a high tumor burden or extensive tumor involvement. In these patients, combination treatment provides the greatest benefit, but the definition of criteria for subsets of patients that can benefit from one arm or another remains a major challenge to researchers.
In the KEYNOTE-024 study evaluating pembrolizumab versus chemotherapy in first-line advanced NSCLC with PDL1 TPS ≥50%, the response rate in the pembrolizumab arm alone was 45%. This result led to the approval of pembrolizumab for first-line advanced NSCLC with PDL1 TPS ≥ 50%, which nevertheless represents only 22% of patients with stage IIIB/IV NSCLC. Early identification of biomarkers for patients unlikely to benefit from first-line pembrolizumab is therefore a crucial step in selecting suitable candidates. Furthermore, in cancer, genomic alterations in NFE2L2, KEAP1 and CUL3 result in constitutive activation of NRF2-dependent gene transcription, which promotes cellular resistance to oxidative stress, xenobiotic efflux, proliferation and metabolic reprogramming. Somatic mutations in NFE2L2 and KEAP1 are found in 3% and 12% of NSCLC patients respectively. NFE2L2 is a transcription factor that directs the expression of free radical defense genes that may interfere with radiation-induced DNA damage. KEAP1 is an adaptor protein that targets NFE2L2 for ubiquitination and proteasomal destruction as part of normal homeostasis. These new biomarkers are of clinical interest, as KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations predict radiation resistance in patients with localized NSCLC treated with radiotherapy but not surgery. Some data also suggest a role for the KEAP1/NFE2L2 axis in response to immunotherapy. Establishing a predictive model for the presence of the KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutation would provide a tool for predicting survival (progression-free and overall), even before the patient starts immunotherapy. Proposed study: A multicentre prospective cohort study involving 150 patients. Patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (stage IV; some stage III) with a programmed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) status ≥50%. Participants will receive a first-line treatment as defined by a multidisciplinary board. In addition, they will undergo FDG-PET/CT imaging as a routine assessment and radiomic analysis in order to generate data before starting their therapeutic treatment. The impact of radiomic analysis (derived features from conventional CT imaging) will then be evaluated to assess if it is a better predictor for patient prognosis than clinical-biological parameters alone. The same analysis will be proposed for KEAP-1 and NFE2L2 mutations.
Official Title
-----------------
Prognostic Value of Combined Approach Based on KEAP1/NFE2L2 Mutations and Pre-therapeutic FDG-PET/CT Radiomic Analysis in Advanced Non-small-cell Lung Cancer PDL1 ≥ 50% Treated With Pembrolizumab.

This study is targeting patients (both male and female) with rare carcinomas of the urinary system not eligible for chemotherapy. It is using two drugs, sacituzumab govitecan and/or atezolizumab. Sacituzumab govitecan is administered on days 1 and 8 of each 21-day cycle, and atezolizumab on day 1. The duration of study participation varies depending on the occurrence of study therapy delays. For patients with disease progression, treatment with sacituzumab govitecan and/or atezolizumab may continue as long as the patient is getting clinical benefit. The study continues as long as patients are benefiting from the treatment based on radiological disease assessment. This study will evaluate safety, tolerability, and clinical activity of sacituzumab govitecan in combination with atezolizumab in this patient population. It is an open-label, single-arm, multicenter Phase II study. The primary objective is to evaluate objective response rate (ORR) of sacituzumab govitecan in combination with atezolizumab in patients with rare carcinoma of the urinary system in the second-line setting. Secondary objectives are to evaluate the duration of response (DoR) and progression-free survival (PFS).

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) in the improvement of ankle dorsiflexion range in professional padel players. As a secondary objective of this research, the authors want to evaluate the effectiveness of eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation on improving the dorsiflexion range and jumping force, as well as the effectiveness of these exercises on pain improvement and preventing injuries.
This study will consist of two groups. One group will receive the PNF treatment and another with a protocol of eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation. Participants from group one will undergo stretching, as well as strengthening and relaxation techniques, while participants in group two will undergo eccentric exercises and strengthening currents. The authors will compare the values with pre and post tests to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of these techniques.
This research will have three phases: initial evaluation (week 0), follow-up evaluation (week 1 and week 2; 30 minutes after treatment) and final evaluation (week 3; 30 minutes after treatment). Participants will have to perform each treatment once a week on Mondays and Thursdays for 3 weeks. All participants were randomly assigned to the various groups. At the initial phase all participants were submitted to ankle circumference, vertical jump and ankle range of motion tests. At the follow-up phase (week 1 and 2) the tests were repeated, in the same order as before. During this phase, the eccentric exercises group will perform the stretching protocol, but they will not perform the strengthening and relaxation process. At the final test of the follow-up phase (week 3) the participants will be submitted to the same three tests before receiving the therapeutic stretching program and strengthening. The intervention will be repeated one more time for both groups on the last day of treatment and the final evaluation.

Background: There is a great need for community-based family support programs that are easily implemented in low-resource settings. These programs should be culturally-adapted and developed in partnership with the families they aim to serve. Moving away from existing models of care that are based on deficits and individual interventions, this study will develop a curriculum for parenting and children mental health skills, which is adapted for refugee families in Tijuana, Mexico and developed in partnership with refugee communities, using a participatory research design.
Methods: This study is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to assess the impact of a 4-week parenting intervention in two shelters in Tijuana for refugee families. Eight focus groups among shelter residents (n=96) identified priority domains for parenting skills. Via a community-based participatory research (CBPR) process involving leaders from the two shelters, the curriculum was then adapted using a Learning by Observing and Pitching In (LOPI) model. In a 2-arm RCT intervention and waitlist control group will participate in learning sessions 2 times a week for 4 weeks, following completion of the surveys and observations. Intervention groups will complete the surveys and observations at the conclusion of the baseline period. The waitlist-control group will also receive the intervention after the intervention group. Both groups will receive the same intervention. The primary outcome measure will be parenting knowledge using a tool translated from English. Secondary outcome measures will include child behavior and parental efficacy scales and qualitative observations of parent-child interactions and interviews. Follow-up assessments will occur 2 months after the intervention.
Impact: This project will provide an accessible parenting curriculum which could be integrated into many programs. By incorporating input gathered from refugee families in Tijuana, the intervention has the potential to be applicable to other low-resource refugee settings, increasing the accessibility of culturally-adapted community-based parenting interventions to address mental health disparities.

We have an excellent opportunity to further our understanding of the challenges faced by people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC) and their families in the UK. Research shows that they experience significant adverse effects on daily living, mental wellbeing and quality of life, and more information is needed to identify how these adverse effects can be addressed. To date, little is known about the complex dynamics and the role of multi-professional healthcare services for this patient group. Through a qualitative observational study design, and a co-design approach with patients, carers and healthcare professionals, it is proposed to gather patient and professional experiences, and then collect views as to how the care received and future potential solutions might be improved. The team will use findings from patient and professional interviews and focus groups, to prioritise areas for future intervention development. Future interventions/solutions will then be developed and tested with end-users as a result of this research.

Introduction: With the accelerated pace of the global aging society, the prevalence of degenerative diseases is increasing. At present, spinal degenerative diseases caused by body degeneration have become the most common type. With the continuous deepening of the research on spinal degenerative diseases and the continuous development, update and promotion of minimally invasive surgery technology and instruments, minimally invasive surgery has attracted more and more attention of spine surgeons due to its advantages of rapid recovery, small trauma and fewer complications. The core of endoscopic spinal surgery is nerve root decompression. The procedure is centered on the nerve roots, which can be damaged with the slightest carelessness. According to statistics, the incidence of nerve root injury under spinal endoscope is 1.8-2.5%. Most of the injuries include the stimulation and edema of the nerve root during the operation, which may lead to postoperative sensory retardation and motor weakness, which will damage the patient's physical function and reduce overall satisfaction. The intraoperative nerve exploration is time-consuming and critical, and the variability of the patient's nerve anatomy will also add difficulties to the operation. A real-time auxiliary intraoperative nerve identification technology is necessary. With the progress of optical technology, fluorescent-guided surgery has shown considerable prospects in assisting in identifying nerves. Indocyanine green (ICG) is the only fluorophore approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for intraoperative near-infrared imaging. It can emit near-infrared light after being irradiated by excitation light, which has the characteristics of high penetration depth, low spontaneous fluorescence and high sensitivity. At present, ICG near-infrared fluorescence imaging has been applied to clinical research of thoracic sympathetic ganglion, facial nerve, phrenic nerve and pelvic nerve.
In this study, the investigators will include patients who meet the indications of lumbar spinal endoscopic spinal surgery (lumbar disc herniation) and investigate the relationship between fluorescent imaging and nerve roots in endoscopic spinal surgery. Clinical trials with a single-arm design of ICG near-infrared imaging in identifying lumbar nerve roots will be conducted at the study site. The efficacy of intraoperative fluorescent imaging by ICG in the lumbar surgery of endoscopic spinal surgery will be evaluated by clinical outcomes. The study hypotheses are: 1) fluorescent imaging has a positive effect on lumbar nerve root exposure; 2) low doses of ICG will not have a significant effect on the visual quality of fluorescence and the quality of surgical vision of doctors; and 3) the low doses of ICG do not increase the incidence of side effects to the patient in the lumbar surgery of endoscopic spinal surgery.
Methods: The study is a multicenter investigator-initiated study. The patients received one dose of icg 0.5mg/kg/b.wt., 1 mg/kg/b.wt. or 2 mg/kg/b.wt. intravenous injection 5-10 minutes before the operation, and the surgical team used a spinal endoscopic fluorescence imaging system to assist with nerve root identification during surgery. The time spent for operation, fluorescent imaging rate of nerve root, fluorescent signal ratio, surgical complications, and patients postoperative pain and functional assessment, will be investigated and analyzed by statisticians blinded to the operation.
This study has obtained the approval of the ethics committee of Shanghai No. 1 People's hospital, and the patients will receive full explanations about the study. This research is conformed to the requirements of the Declaration of Helsinki, and the investigators will ensure that the study is conducted under GCP.
Discussion: With the continuous deepening of endoscopic spinal surgery, the surgical experience of surgical teams has undergone rapid changes. It is necessary to have real-time intraoperative lumbar nerve anatomical observation. The present study will investigate the potential role of intraoperative fluorescence imaging by near-infrared ICG to improve the intraoperative exploration of lumbar nerve roots. If the application of low-dose ICG fluorescence image to assist researchers to explore the lumbar nerve root can effectively improve the speed and quality, then it will have a practical application value in clinical application.
Official Title
-----------------
Clinical Application

<|assistant|> Background: In a Nordic-Baltic comparison study, it was found that parents with intellectual and developmental disability (IDD) in the Nordic countries reported low levels of access to support and less support overall compared to similar parents in the Baltic region. At the same time, parents in the Baltic countries reported less satisfaction with the support provided as well as lower levels of social support from their families and friends. Based on these results, it is reasonable to assume that parents with IDD and other cognitive disabilities in the Nordic countries lack the access to support that they need, and that there is a need for evidence-based treatment programs for these parents. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of the Norwegian Parenting Young Children (PYC) home-based intervention program for parents with IDD and their children aged 0-9 living at home. PYC is part of the national support and service programme provided by the municipalities to parents with IDD and their children, including children with disabilities. The program is designed to focus on three primary components. First, to improve parenting skills. Second to improve the child's development, health, and safety. And third to reduce the burden on social services and caregiving services. The aim of the present study is to determine if the PYC intervention program improves children's development, health, and safety, as well as reduces the burden on social services and caregiving services in home settings for families with low-functioning parents with IDD and children aged 0-9 living at home, thereby contributing to a more cost-effective and efficient approach. Methods: We will conduct a prospective randomized controlled trial with a non-randomized (control group) sample of one in three participants. This means that all parents and their children will be recruited to the PYC intervention program, while half will be allocated on a randomized basis to a treatment or control group. Parents and their children (aged 0-9 years) with a main residence in the municipality of Oslo and its surroundings participate in the study, which is conducted in cooperation with Oslo municipality, a social service agency working with families with IDD, and several NGO´s working with parents with IDD and their children. Background: 68Ga-NOTA-H006: A new PET/CT diagnostic agent with a positive response to PET/CT imaging, which can be used to evaluate the expression of 5T4 receptors on cancer cells, and the expression of H006 in tumor tissues can be used as a predictor of the efficacy before the first 2nd 5FU-containing chemotherapy. This research uses two types of PET tracers, 68Ga-NOTA-H006 and 18F-FDG, in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, lung cancer, colon cancer, etc.
H006 is synthesized with 68Ga-NOTA. 68Ga-NOTA-H006 was intravenously injected and scanned with Siemens Discovery 690 PET/CT. 68Ga-NOTA-H006 was synthesized with 68Ga- NOTA.
Objective: The purpose of this clinical study was to design an imaging system suitable for H006. Compared to 18F-FDG, the standardized uptake value (SUV) of tumor imaging in the body is calculated, and the SUV value can reflect the expression level of 5T4 in tumor tissue, which can predict the therapeutic effect before anti-tumor treatment. Thus, it can be used as a new PET diagnostic marker suitable for clinical diagnosis, evaluate the expression level of 5T4 in new and old lesions for lung cancer and pancreatic cancer patients, evaluate the diagnostic value of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 in new lung cancer patients and evaluate the tumor treatment response.
Methods: Patients diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, lung cancer, colorectal cancer and other patients have undergone multi-detector spiral CT, PET and magnetic resonance imaging.
Results: The experimental results showed that the 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET/CT imaging system could clearly show the anatomical characteristics of the tumor and normal tissues. The detection of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 on the lungs, kidneys, livers, gastric cavity, abdominal cavity, urethra and small intestine is good, and the detection is stable, the contrast between normal and tumor tissues is obvious, there is no false negative. Through quantitative analysis, it is found that there is a positive correlation between SUV value and the number of positive lesions. The accuracy of SUV in predicting 68Ga-NOTA-H006 expression status in tumor tissue is 87.5%.
Conclusion: 68Ga-NOTA-H006 can non-invasively detect the expression status of 5T4 in the body, and its accurate detection can predict the therapeutic effect of anti-tumor treatment after examination.
Economic Benefit: 68Ga-NOTA-H006 has a faster half-life than 18F-FDG (111 min vs. 110 min), and the cost per patient is lower, which is conducive to the popularization of PET/CT detection and the improvement of diagnostic efficiency in clinical application.
