Heart failure is one of the deadliest diseases worldwide, with a high incidence of heart failure especially in the elderly. In patients with heart failure, the heart cannot pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the body's metabolic demands. One common mechanism for dysfunction in heart failure is inefficient pumping, also called cardiac dyssynchrony. Dyssynchrony refers to an uncoordinated heart and results in prolonged electrical activation and contraction of the ventricles and dilatation of the heart chambers. Dyssynchrony can be alleviated with a pacemaker called cardiac resynchronization therapy, CRT. However, not all patients will respond equally well to CRT. We are currently performing a large clinical trial (STIR-HF) to determine why some responders to CRT better than others. We have found that the success of CRT depends on the severity of the dyssynchrony and the strength of the heart muscle. In a subgroup of patients the strength of the muscle can be predicted by measuring the force required to induce calcium release in heart muscle cells. In CRT responders, the force is generally very high, which means that they have a high energy requirement during the energy-consuming processes of the heart muscle. The high force requirements will affect the signaling pathways that regulate energy production, mitochondrial function, protein metabolism and cellular structure that are regulated by mitochondria. Therefore, we have started a new project, SIRC-HF, to study the underlying mechanisms of CRT response. Our hope is to find biomarkers that will help predict which patients will respond well to CRT and to unravel the signaling pathways that regulate cell function in heart failure.
Heart failure patients that receive a CRT will be biobanked for future studies of CRT response. We will focus on proteins, miRNA and red blood cell (RBC) properties from blood samples. Additional measurements will focus on cardiac structure/function, energy metabolism and contractility in the heart's biopsies. We will also study endothelial function. An endothelium is a layer of cells that cover the inside of all blood vessels. The endothelium has contractile functions and can also release substances that will regulate blood flow. Dysfunction in the endothelium is common in heart disease, and endothelial function can be measured non-invasively using peripheral vessels like fingers and toes. Patients in the control group will be followed with clinical examination, blood samples and echocardiography. This will give us the opportunity to compare patients who are treated with CRT with patients who are on medical treatment without CRT-devices. This will reveal what can be measured in heart failure patients treated with CRT and what distinguishes patients who respond well from those that do not respond well to CRT.

Care teams at leading cancer centers are struggling to implement PRO management tools, which may perpetuate disparities in patient-centered care. Addressing barriers to care team engagement is the foundation of this proposal, and leveraging behavioral strategies to facilitate patient-level PRO use is critical to the sustainability of any program. Informed by insights from pilot studies, this proposal will employ implementation science methods to conduct a pragmatic RCT with randomization across patients, clinicians, and practice levels. The goal of this proposal is to improve the adherence of patients to PRO monitoring and ultimately enhance the timeliness of clinician response to patients' symptoms and treatment experience. This will be accomplished through: (a) a stepped wedge design randomizing clinicians to a sequential roll-out of implementation strategies; and (b) randomizing patients to a parallel controlled trial comparing two PRO administration methods. This proposal aligns with the vision of a national cancer registry (CARAT) to promote data-driven improvements in patient-centered care.

Prognostic awareness among patients with life limiting diseases has been shown to be associated with less depression, better quality of care and earlier referral to palliative care. Early palliative care has become mainstream in the UK, but still, a large proportion of patients remains unaware that their disease is not curable. This is important as studies have shown that there is a discrepancy between what patients want and expect from palliative care (focusing on improved quality of life, support for physical and psychological symptoms) and what they actually get (focussing mainly on symptom control). A deeper knowledge of the factors and patient characteristics associated with prognostic awareness is an important first step to develop interventions to improve prognostic communication and thereby to facilitate the delivery of high quality ESC which can support patients to be able to make informed decisions about the future. This is necessary to improve care and quality of life in patients with advanced cancer in the UK.

Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a highly debilitating headache, which represents a major concern for women who undergo pain management with epidural or spinal analgesia during labour or childbirth. However, the incidence of PDPH is variable, ranging between 0.5 and 10%, being probably related to the difficulty in interpreting some of the classical symptoms of PDPH that are reported only by a minority of affected women. PDPH is probably a consequence of the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that occurs into the epidural or subarachnoid space. The incidence of PDPH can be reduced by minimising the amount of CSF leaked during the insertion of epidural or spinal needle, as demonstrated by the use of epidural catheters in labour. However, this method requires an epidural needle insertion close to CSF level, making this technique difficult to perform as well as time-consuming. Recently, a novel method has been described, the use of a spinal needle to create a subarachnoid catheter in the epidural space. However, to our knowledge, this method has been never tested in order to reduce PDPH occurrence. 
The aim of this study is to compare the occurrence of PDPH in obstetric women who undergo epidural analgesia using either the classical method or the new method after a dural puncture, as well as their satisfaction of the labour pain and chronic headache or chronic low back pain occurring at 1 and 3 months after labour.

This research will evaluate the difference between sectional and circumferential matrix in achieving optimum proximal contact in class 2 restorations.
Class 2 restorations are the most common ones due to their great prevalence as carious lesions and restoring them with composite restorations is not the easiest task due to the difficulties in achieving a secure proximal contact.
The aim of this research is to evaluate the two different matrices used during indirect resin restoration.
A part of a previous study by Morsi and Nawari [7] in clinical trial (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier NCT03296253) was used as pilot study in order to evaluate the two matrices and to design this study with higher power and number of samples. 
A sample size of 40 patients divided in 2 groups was obtained. The samples were allocated randomly in each intervention: sectional matrix vs. circumferential matrix.
Proximal contact will be evaluated by applying tightness of proximal contact by unwaxed dental floss and proximal contact on restored teeth will be divided into three categories: optimum, tight, or open contact.
The results of this study should help clinicians to select a successful proximal contact method for class 2 restorations in clinical practice.
If you are interested to know more about this study, you can follow it the next four month.

This clinical trial, which is a randomized hybrid effectiveness/implementation trial, will enroll 300 high utilizers of County mental health services over 36 months. The participants will be assigned to one of two study arms: 1) County-paid Wraparound Services (WWS) tailored to the individual needs of the participant; 2) Usual County services. Study participants will receive a comprehensive package of wraparound services, including assertive community treatment, crisis intervention, medication management, substance abuse treatment, family and peer support, and coordination of all services. As a result of this tailored care, the investigators hypothesize that participants receiving WWS will be more likely than the participants receiving usual County services to: 1) Achieve their most important life goals; 2) Reduce the number of days spent in 24-hour psychiatric hospital settings, including State Hospitals, county contract hospitals and locked residential care programs; 3) Reduce the number of days spent in state and county prisons and jails; and 4) Reduce the costs of psychiatric hospitalization and incarceration.
In addition to these participant outcomes, the investigators will survey County mental health staff members to gather their opinions about the program, and also conduct focus groups with patients and families to examine their satisfaction with the program.
This study is important because it represents an innovative approach to improving care for people with severe and persistent forms of mental illness. The investigators propose to combine high-quality psychiatric care with traditional forms of care to help County residents whose mental illnesses have previously severely disrupted their lives.

<|assistant|> Family Intervention (FI) and cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) are among the most efficacious psychosocial interventions to prevent relapse in schizophrenia. However, there is limited evidence from low- and middle-income countries (LAMICs) that supports the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of delivering these psychosocial interventions to individuals with first episode psychosis (FEP) in LAMICs. We aim to determine the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of culturally adapted cognitive behavioral therapy (CaCBT) and culturally adapted family intervention (CuFI) compared to Treatment as Usual (TAU) in reducing overall symptoms of psychosis in individuals with FEP in Pakistan. The study will include 390 participants with FEP from psychiatric units of hospitals in ten centres (i.e. Karachi, Lahore, Rawalpindi, Hyderabad, Qambar Shahdakot, Shaheed Benazirabad, Sukkur, Peshawar, Quetta and Multan). Consented participants meeting eligibility criteria will be randomised in a 1:1:1 allocation to CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU or TAU alone. Participants in CaCBT intervention group will receive 12-weekly one-to-one sessions. Participants in CulFI group will receive 10-weekly one-to-one sessions. Sessions will be delivered by trained psychologists who will receive regular weekly supervision to maintain fidelity. Assessments will be carried out at baseline, months 3, 6, and 12 by trained, blinded assessors. Process evaluation will help to build the implementation knowledge base for proposed interventions across study settings. We will conduct economic evaluations (i.e., the cost-effectiveness and cost-utility analyses) of the CaCBT and CulFI interventions, as add-on to TAU. This study is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), pharmacodynamics (PD), efficacy, and clinical performance of IMPT-314 (axicabtagene ciloleucel) in participants with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) (including diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) not otherwise specified, DLBCL arising from follicular lymphoma, primary mediastinal (thymic) large B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), high-grade B-cell lymphoma with or without MYC and BCL2 and/or BCL6 rearrangement). The study consists of two parts. The dose escalation/estimation part (Part A) enrolls 20 participants in 2 cohorts (CAR T experienced, CAR T naïve) to estimate the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and the recommended Phase 2 (RP2) dose. The dose expansion part (Part B) enrolls 40 additional participants at the RP2 dose level to evaluate the safety, efficacy, clinical performance, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of IMPT-314.
For participants in Cohort 1, a single dose of IMPT-314 will be administered. Participants in Cohort 2 will receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy (in the absence of active CNS disease) followed by lymphocyte infusion. Up to 11 participants will be enrolled in Cohort 1 in dose level 1 or 2, and up to 9 participants will be enrolled in Cohort 1 in dose level 2. Participants who have previously received a genetically modified T cell therapy other than a product targeting CD19 with an FMC63-based CAR (e.g., axicabtagene ciloleucel (axi-cel (YESCARTA®), tisagenlecleucel (tisa-cel (KYMRIAH®), or lisocabtagene maraleucel (liso-cel (BREYANZI®)) at any dose) will be enrolled into Cohort 1 based on dose level 1. Participants who have received a genetically modified T cell therapy targeting CD19 with an FMC63-based CAR at a dose level that did not result in any infusion related toxicities (including cytokine release syndrome (CRS) and/or neurologic toxicities (including immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (ICANS)) will be enrolled into Cohort 2 dose level 1. All other participants will be enrolled into Cohort 2 dose levels 2 or 3. Up to 27 additional participants who have received prior CAR T therapy (Cohort 2) will be enrolled as specified. For participants in Cohort 2, they will be treated with lymphodepleting chemotherapy (in the absence of active CNS disease) followed by lymphocyte infusion of the genetically modified IMPT-314 autologous T cells. Up to 27 additional participants (Cohort 2) will receive lymphocyte infusion in Part B at the RP2 dose level. For Cohort 2 participants who are 18 years of age or older and female and have childbearing potential, a pregnancy test is required prior to lymphodepleting chemotherapy and before cell infusion to confirm she is not pregnant and agree to use highly effective contraception for 30 days prior to cell infusion and to continue using highly effective contraception for 7 months after cell infusion. Additionally, participants must agree not to donate ova during the study for a period of 6 months post-infusion.

The aim of the present study was to examine whether individuals with Metabolic Syndrome (MetS), when all the components (waist circumference, fasting glucose, triglycerides and HDL cholesterol) were considered collectively, were more likely to have cognitive disturbance and a low level of physical activity compared to healthy individuals. Another aim of the study was to research whether the number of MetS component values and the severity of MetS were correlated with cognitive functions and physical activity. Participants were divided into two groups. There were individuals diagnosed with MetS in the intervention group and healthy individuals who did not have any problems in the control group. In the intervention group, individuals diagnosed with Metabolic Syndrome by meeting 3 of the NCEP-ATP III criteria were assessed for clinical and physical performance and cognitive performance. In the control group, healthy individuals aged 10-40 years who underwent a general health examination within the last 6 months. The assessment consisted of anthropometric measurements, assessing the severity of MetS, collecting demographic data, determining cognitive functions, determining physical activity levels and the relationship between the number of MetS components and cognitive functions, and the relationship between MetS and physical activity was aimed. The physical performance of the individuals is evaluated with the Stroop Test TBAG Form, the Visual Reaction Test and the Pedometer. As a result, it was found that MetS had a negative effect on both physical performance and cognitive performance. It was found that individuals with MetS had a lower level of physical activity and lower cognitive performance than healthy individuals.

<|assistant|> There has been an increasing interest in the use of binaural beats (BB) to improve sleep quality among people with poor sleep quality. In the present study, we assessed the effectiveness of an 8-week BBM music intervention on sleep quality and emotional wellbeing among older people with poor sleep quality in one particular long-term care institution. A total of 60 participants completed the study. Participants were randomly assigned to the intervention (BBM) group or control group. In the experimental group, an 8-week binationally beats music intervention was conducted, while the control group received the same familiar music without BBM embedded. The intervention had no adverse events. The intervention group showed a significant improvement after the music intervention, and in comparison to the control group on depression severity, sleep disturbance, subjective sleep quality, and sleep latency. The intervention group had significantly higher subjective sleep quality after the music intervention in comparison to the score at baseline and as well as the scores recorded in the control group. These findings suggest that a relatively short-term BBM music intervention may be a suitable and low-cost solution on improving sleep quality and depression in older adults in a long-term care institution (LTCI) setting, and the research provides valuable evidence on the benefits of music intervention for sleep quality among older people. Implications for future research and clinical practice are also discussed. Exclusion Criteria: Exclusion criteria were those with hearing loss, history of bipolar disorder or schizophrenia diagnosed by a physician, and had an acute physiological disease, such as cold, fracture, or trauma. The Personalised Follow-up Pathway (PFU) is a patient-centred treatment approach that aims to provide cancer survivors with individualised follow-up pathways based on their individual risk of recurrent cancer. Head and neck cancer will be used as the first pilot study for PFU. The researchers have developed a PFU treatment pathway that meets the quality standards required for this pilot study. The aim of the project is to evaluate the implementation of this PFU pathway through (i) quantitative and qualitative research to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of the proposed personalised follow-up pathway, (ii) to explore patient and service provider experience, as well as the sustainability of the pathway, on a local basis. This mixed data collection strategy will help to evaluate the key outcomes of the proposed pathway.

The hypothesis of this randomized study was that DEXMEDETOMIDINE-bupivacaine may provide a longer motor blockade after elective Caesarean section compared with neostigmine added to bupivacaine.
Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenoceptor antagonist, the primary central nervous system sites of action being limbic, hypothalamic and periaqueductal grey matter. There are no reports of systemic haemodynamic or respiratory side effects of this drug. It blocks the release of stress hormones such as noradrenaline, which are known to accelerate the intra-operative rise in blood pressure during a spinal anaesthesia. Neostigmine prolongs the duration of spinal anaesthesia by increasing the concentration of spinal endogenous ACh thereby, increasing the concentration of endogenous ACh without adding any systemic effects.
An equal, statistically power of the two study groups was performed by the software package for computer generated allocation of subjects to test groups.
The primary end-point in the present study was length of motor blockade. Secondary end-points were duration of sensory blockade, time of recovery of sensory and motor blockade, onset of complete motor blockade, intra-operative and post-operative blood pressure values and heart rate.
Patients were placed supine on a standard operating table in the operating room, with their heads over the edge, which has been elevated by 25 degrees. The spinal anaesthesia was to be performed with the patient in the sitting position. Spinal anaesthesia was achieved in the sitting position with a 25-gauge, 10-centimeter-long Whitacre spinal needle. After sterilize the area with povidone-iodine (70%), the inter-spinous process was marked with a ballpoint pen, with a reference system 5 cm lateral to the midline and 2 cm caudal to the L2-L3 spinous process. A 25-gauge, 10-cm-long Whitacker spinal needle was advanced with the patient in lateral position (5 cm lateral to midline) through the vertebral space identified using a loss of resistance technique. The spinal anaesthesia was achieved in the sitting position, with the patient in the flexed position, then the patient was returned to the supine position. No epinephrine was added to the preparation solution of either drugs.
The spinal anaesthesia level was measured with a pin prick needle from caudal to cephalic direction till achieving T10. The T10 dermatome represented full extent of spinal sensory blockade for the purposes of anesthesiologists.
The time from the end of intrathecal injection till achievement of full sensory blockade was recorded as primary outcome measure. Secondary outcome measures included length of complete motor blockade, duration of complete and incomplete sensory blockades, time to the recovery of complete motor blockade, maximum level of sensory blockade, any need for bolus opioid (fentanyl) as rescue analgesia, BIHS classification, time to the recovery of two-point discrimination test (T10 level), time to the return of bowel sounds and time required to first pass flatus, and time to the first oral intake. Heart rates and blood pressure values were recorded before spinal anaesthesia, immediately, at 15, 30, 45 and 60 minutes after spinal injection and every 5 minutes till 2 hours after spinal injection and then every 30 minutes till the end of operation. The study group was divided in 2 group,18 patients in each group, Group 1 were received 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.1 ml (10 μg) DXM and 0.1 ml normal saline and Group 2 ( 18 patients ) were received 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.1 ml (50 μg) neostigmine and 0.1 ml normal saline. Group 3 ( 18 patients ) were received 10 mg (2ml) hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.2 ml normal saline. The primary end-point in the present study was length of motor blockade. Secondary end-points were duration of sensory blockade, time of recovery of sensory and motor blockade,

White spot lesions (WSLs) and gingivitis are frequently encountered in patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances. Oral hygiene can contribute to the onset and maintenance of WSLs and gingivitis in this context. The aim of this study is to evaluate if supragingival plaque control with air-polishing could provide benefit by reducing the development of WSLs and gingivitis. Therefore, patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment will be divided into two groups (test and control) for the application of air-polishing or ultrasonic scaling, respectively. The primary outcome will be the number of patients who will develop WSLs during the 2-years period of orthodontic treatment. The secondary outcomes will be the changes in gingivitis in both groups. The efficacy of oral hygiene will be evaluated with clinical and microbiological parameters. After 2 years, all patients will be treated with fixed appliances only and the appearance of WSLs and gingivitis will be recorded until the end of the active fixed appliance treatment, an average of six months.

Atrial fibrillation has a high burden of disease, associated with stroke, heart failure, and death. It is thought to be caused in part by the formation of fibrous scar tissue in the atria, including scar from prior heart surgery. Surgery to remove the left atrial appendage is the most common cardiac surgery associated with AF and is known to reduce this risk. This study will examine tissue from patients with and without AF, who are having surgery to remove a part of the lung or heart, to try and identify the differences in the scar tissue associated with AF development. This will allow better understanding of the role of scar tissue in AF and potentially help identify better treatments or preventative measures.

Resistance training is one of the most popular training approaches adopted by coaches professionals. The basic purpose of this research is to find and compare the effects of integrated and isolated training on strength, power and endurance in gym beginners. The study can help coaches and trainers to identify the most effective training methods for improving strength, power and endurance. Previous literature show that resisted exercises play effective role in gym trainer for strengthening, power and endurance. But there is a limited literature on comparing the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise so our focus is to measure the role of these techniques for strength, power and endurance in gym beginners.

It has been found that these factors stimulate the production of inflammatory cytokines, which in turn cause liver damage. On the other hand, it has been reported that various factors such as acute renal failure, infectious diseases and ischemia-reperfusion injury cause the production of anti-inflammatory cytokines in the body. In our study, some inflammatory Interleukin-2 , Interleukin-6, Interferon-γ, Tumor Necrosis Factor-α and anti-inflammatory Interleukin-4 and Interleukin-10 cytokine genes expressions and Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid Cells-1, which contributes to the pathology of acute and chronic inflammatory diseases; Human Leukocyte Antigen-G5, which suppresses the immune response; the expression levels of transcription factor Forkhead box-P3 expressed in regulatory T-lymphocytes and Cluster of Differentiation (CD)14 genes, which are thought to be biomarkers in various infectious diseases and expressed in monocytes, will be measured from peripheral blood samples obtained from liver transplant patients before, 1 month and 6 months after the operation. In the light of the data to be obtained, it is aimed to find biomarkers with high predictive value for rejection and infection after liver transplantation.

Introduction: Geographic atrophy (GA) secondary to Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is a retinal condition characterized by the progressive loss of photoreceptors and supporting retinal cells, which leads to functional blindness and impaired quality of life in patients. While many therapeutics have been effective in treating early-stage of AMD, there are no approved specific treatments for GA.
Objectives: The purpose of this study is to determine how well BI 771716 is tolerated and what its effects are on geographic atrophy in a single rising dose (SRD) and a multiple dose (MD) study of increasing doses of the investigational drug administered by intravitreal injection monthly in patients with GA secondary to AMD for 4 months. An additional purpose is to determine the pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of a single and multiple intravitreal administrations of BI 771716 in patients with GA secondary to AMD.
Eligibility: Key inclusion criteria include: signed informed consent, males and females aged 50 or older with GA secondary to AMD in the study eye.
Design: This is an open-label, non-randomized, multi-center, sequential assignment study. Study drug BI 771716 will be administered by intravitreal injection in the study eye at increasing doses. Primary endpoints include the number of participants who experienced ocular Dose Limiting Events (DLEs) in the low dose single dose (SRD) part and the number of participants who experience drug related adverse events (AEs). Secondary endpoints include various PK measurements.
Patient benefits: This study will provide valuable information on how BI 771716 is tolerated in patients with GA secondary to AMD and help us determine dose levels to be evaluated in future studies.

Rationale: Fluid overload is present in the vast majority of acute heart failure (HFd) patients. Current guidelines recommend dehydration, aiming for a moderate negative fluid balance (NFB) (250 - 700 ml), on hospital daily fluid balance to ensure symptom relief and improve patient prognosis. The optimal timing and intensity of dehydration, however, remain unclear, with concerns raised on whether diuretics may cause acute kidney injury (AKI).
To date, no study has directly compared a protocol aiming for a lower daily (average) negative fluid balance (167 ml) with a higher daily (average) negative fluid balance (700 ml) during the first 3 days of hospital admission. Also, no prior study has compared continuous infusion of furosemide, aimed at reaching a moderate NFB (600 ml) without dehydration to standard diuretic treatment. We hypothesize that matched dehydration with continuous furosemide infusion, as opposed to matched dehydration with conventional diuretic treatment, is a more efficient way to diurese patients with acute HFd and overt fluid overload. Moreover, it may prevent acute kidney injury compared to the standard diuretic therapy.
Study Objectives: Our primary aim is to assess the rate of development of acute (AKI KDIGO) in acute HFd patients receiving matched dehydration during 72 hours of hospital admission, between furosemide infusion with the RenalGuard System and conventional diuretics. Secondary objectives are to evaluate fluid overload reduction, all-cause mortality and readmission at 15 days.
Study Design: All patients (both men and women) referred to the emergency department as part of the National Heart Failure Study (NaHF) who meet the criteria for acute decompensated HFd with peripheral fluid overload, estimated weight gain >4 kg, will be screened for the present protocol. All enrolled patients will be randomly assigned to diuretic treatment, either matched dehydration with conventional diuretics or matched dehydration with continuous intravenous furosemide infusion.

Around 70,000 children and adolescents visit emergency departments with chest pain each year in the United States. When idiopathic or functional in nature, chest pain has significant consequences on the child’s quality of life and utilizes significant health care resources. Children with chest pain are often subjected to unnecessary and expensive medical tests to exclude a life-threatening condition.
This pilot study addresses a gap in the literature by determining the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness program. We hypothesize that the mindfulness-based intervention will help decrease the frequency of chest pain and improve overall quality of life.
The investigators will conduct a pilot feasibility and acceptability trial of N=60 children and adolescents who are diagnosed with idiopathic chest pain. The primary outcome is the feasibility of recruitment, retention, and program completion measured by participant recruitment and retention rates, intervention program adherence, and survey response rates. Secondary outcomes are feasibility of outcome assessments and acceptability of intervention adherence and completion. Chest pain frequency and intensity will be used to compare the treatment effects of the mindfulness and control groups.
The intervention involves a 4-week mindfulness-based intervention completed through the Headspace application. This program includes guided meditations, body-scanning meditations, and talks about the science of mindfulness and how to incorporate mindfulness into daily life.
The control group will follow the standard of care recommended by their cardiologist, which typically just includes reassurance that their chest pain is related to normal heart function. The control group will be asked to complete all outcome assessments.
The primary objectives of our study are to determine the feasibility of conducting research on mindfulness for pediatric chest pain and to document the effects of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention on pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain and determine if the intervention improves mental health outcomes and patient-reported outcomes of chest pain.
This is a pilot study; therefore, the statistical power and generalizability will be limited. We seek to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effects of mindfulness on pediatric patients with idiopathic chest pain.
Study design and arms. A 2-arm, parallel-group, randomized control trial with each arm consisting of: 1) the intervention group using a mindfulness application on the phone and 2) the control group following standard medical recommendations. Participant Group/Arm: No Intervention: Standard of Care Control Participants in this arm will receive the standard of care. For patients with idiopathic chest pain, the standard of care is typically just reassurance of the benign nature of their pain. Intervention/Treatment: Mindfulness-Based Intervention Participants in this arm will partake in a 30 day mindfulness-based intervention on the mobile app Headspace. Behavioral: Mindfulness-Based Intervention * Participants in the mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) group will be asked to use the Headspace app to sequentially complete the Basics, Basics 2, and Basics 3 courses. Each of these courses lasts 10 days, and participants have the ability to choose how long daily sessions last. Participants can choose between 3, 5, or 10-minute sessions for the Basics course; 10 or 15-minute sessions for the Basics 2 course; and 10, 15, or 20-minute sessions for the Basics 3 course. These daily sessions are audio recordings that prompt users to engage in a variety of mindfulness techniques, including focusing on their body and breathing, as well as acknowledging thoughts and emotions in a non-judgmental manner.

COVID-19 vaccines such as those using the Novavax spike protein have the potential to address many of the limitations of mRNA-based vaccines, including cold chain storage, delivery via a more commonly used vaccine route (MNI/SCD) and the development of novel antivirals to treat SARS-CoV-2 infection. 
This trial will test the non-inferiority of combination vaccination with the Novavax vaccine and the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) in adults aged 60 years or older by assessing the immunogenicity and safety of these vaccines when given at the same time. A total of 420 individuals in this age group will receive either combinations of NVX and PCV vaccines or placebos. Primary Objective: To demonstrate non-inferiority in terms of pneumococcal serotype-specific serum IgG Geometric mean concentrations (GMCs) for the NVX vaccine given in combination with the PCV20 vaccine, or the PCV20 vaccine given in combination with the NVX vaccine, at Day 28 compared with NVX (NCT04874131).
Secondary Objectives:
- To demonstrate non-inferiority in terms of pneumococcal serotype-specific serum IgG GMCs for the PCV20 vaccine given in combination with the NVX vaccine, or the NVX vaccine given in combination with the PCV20 vaccine, compared with PCV20 (NCT04449346).
- To demonstrate non-inferiority in terms of SARS-CoV-2 Serum IgG GMCs, SARS-CoV2 Binding Antibodies and Neutralising Antibodies GMTs for the NVX vaccine given in combination with the PCV20 vaccine, compared with NVX vaccine alone (NCT04874131).
Safety and reactogenicity: 
- To demonstrate non-inferiority in terms of Solicited Adverse Events (SAEs) for the NVX vaccine given in combination with PCV20 compared with NVX alone.
- To demonstrate non-inferiority in terms of Unsolicited Adverse Events (AEs) for the NVX vaccine given in combination with PCV20, or the PCV20 vaccine given in combination with the NVX vaccine, compared with NVX vaccine alone.
Participants aged 60 years or older (N=420) will receive either NVX or placebo according to a 1:1 randomisation followed by NVX or placebo via intramuscular injection according to a 1:1 randomisation. The first vaccine (NVX or PCV20) will be given via intramuscular injection in one upper arm. The second vaccine will be given at the same time in the other upper arm. If an individual experiences a Serious Adverse Event (SAE) at Day 30, or their clinical condition deteriorates (ie, the Investigator decides that the individual should receive additional treatment), they will be moved to another cohort to receive the alternate treatment in combination with the first one.

Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is one of the prevalent metabolic disturbances of pregnancy. The prevalence of GDM is rising globally, in part due to the increase in the rates of obesity and obesity-related disorders in a reproductive age group. Studies have shown that suboptimal status of vitamin D may be associated with a high risk of GDM. However, the data is largely cross-sectional and there is a need for randomized controlled trials to confirm this association. Moreover, the investigators did not find any randomized controlled trial regarding the effect of vitamin D supplementation on GDM prevention among high-risk pregnant women. Therefore, the investigators aim to design and perform a randomized controlled trial to investigate the effect of vitamin D3 supplementation on GDM risk among high-risk pregnant women.

The clinical presentation of the patient is consistent with the known symptoms of a left MCA infarct. Cerebral angiography demonstrated significant 90% stenosis of the left M1 segment with distal occlusion of the left ACA and right ACA. The left ACA and right MCA have collateral vessels. The left MCA has patent distal vessels as well. The LAD was patent with no significant stenosis.There are several clinical trial options in this patient's case for both revascularization and medical management. Based on the patient's desire to undergo revascularization, the following treatment options would be appropriate: Cerebral Revascularization using Carotid Stenting1) Carotid Endarterectomy2) Cerebral Revascularization using Carotid Artery StentingThe most effective revascularization method and its time frame for this patient is unclear at this time and additional testing should be performed to more fully evaluate this patient's brain circulation, including either a TCD or a Cerebral MRI/CT Perfusion study with contrast enhancement. Once the patient is medically cleared for the procedure, and the patient is also psychologically prepared to undergo surgery, if warranted by the investigating physician, a specific treatment plan will be offered to the patient and his family for consideration. Once the treatment plan has been offered, the patient will have at least 24 hours to consider it and the patient's family will also be allowed to consult with their own physicians for further advice. If all testing results indicate that the patient will benefit from either carotid endarterectomy or cerebral artery stenting, and if the patient consents to undergo either of these procedures, then the patient will be offered these treatment options. If the patient elects to proceed with surgery, medical therapy including aspirin, clopidogrel, and statin therapy will be continued, as appropriate, in addition to the indicated surgical therapy.

The primary goal of this study is to test the feasibility and safety of a Nordic Walking (NW) intervention for community-dwelling older adults. The study will recruit fifty older adults, and they will be randomly assigned to either the NW intervention group or a control group. This will allow for a comparison between the two groups. The intervention group will receive supervised NW training, including group sessions and one-on-one training. They will also be taught how to practice independently. The control group will receive regular phone calls to discuss healthy lifestyle habits. Outcome measures include the number of participants who experience an adverse event, TUG Test, Four-Square Step Test (FSST), Falls Efficacy Scale-International (FES-I), and Activities-Specific Balance Confidence Scale. This study is necessary to help determine whether incorporating NW into standard care can be helpful for community-dwelling older adults.

Sexual and Gender Minority (SGM) youth are more likely to have depression, anxiety and related disorders (ADRDs) compared to their non-SGM peers. Evidence shows ADRDs onset early in adolescence, and that SGM youth do not routinely seek mental health treatment, including from specialized mental health providers such as psychologist, counselors or therapists. However, many SGM youth do go online to seek support around their mental health. In-person treatment and online treatments for SGM youths typically have different components that they engage with to provide help. The purpose of this research study is to generate a new online tool specifically designed for providing personalized and tailored messaging to help SGM youth seek mental health treatment.

Patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) has been used in the sedation and analgesia for short surgeries in recent years, and has been applied in anesthesia for colonoscopy. But there is not yet a reliable anesthesia method to ensure patients for colonoscopy are satisfied with the sedation and analgesic effect, and it is easy to make patients feel discomfort and anxiety during the procedure. According to the theory of PCA technology, we can set up the patient to give themselves some medicine according to their sensation when they feel discomfort. Compared with the general anesthesia method, patients can give some medicine before it is not necessary, reducing the drug's impact on patients and reducing the complications caused by anesthesia. Therefore, this study mainly evaluates the patient's satisfaction with the anesthesia effect and the patient's side effects under the two anesthesia methods, and then selects the appropriate anesthesia method for colonoscopy in the future.

Radiation induced acute intestinal injury (RAII) develops after radio-chemotherapy (NCRT) and can progress into chronic RAI after NCRT and radical surgery. According to the literature, the prevalence of chronic RAI was up to 24.2% after 12 months of follow-up. Unfortunately, there is no effective treatment for chronic RAI, which may lead to a decrease in quality of life, and even loss of intestinal function. Therefore, there is an urgent need to predict chronic RAI before radical surgery.
The main aim of this project is to create a prediction model of chronic RAI based on the expression levels of immune factors in tumor tissue. We found that the proportion of infiltrating CD4+FOXP3+regs in tumor tissue was significantly higher in RAI patients than in non-RAII patients. Moreover, the levels of CD8+T, CD4+T and tumor-associated macrophage (TAM) were significantly reduced in RAI patients. In this project, we will find a combination of immune factors that can better predict chronic RAI and then establish a prediction model. This prediction model can be used to make medical suggestions, and to reduce the number of patients to undergo unnecessary surgery.

Omicron has rapidly become the main circulating variant and is now the main variant of SARS-CoV-2 causing infections globally. As Omicron variant continue to evolve and become more immune-resistant from previous vaccination or previous infection, including the immune escape variant Omicron subvariant BA.2 and BA.4/5, developing vaccines against the Omicron, especially Omicron BA.4/5 variant, is urgent to prevent the spread of SARS-CoV-2, reduce severe cases and alleviate the pressure on medical services. Recombinant single-domain antibody or vaccines composed only of the antigen domain of the Omicron virus spike protein can enhance its specificity to the Omicron virus, while ensuring that it can neutralize other new strains caused by mutation. The S gene is the key gene of the spike protein; The recombination of BA.4/5 and delta virus is in the S gene, with the S protein sequence identity level of 99.98%, and the S protein immune escape points of Omicron and Delta are almost identical. The safety, tolerability and immune stimulation of the vaccine have been comprehensively evaluated. The vaccine may bring new options for preventing infection and further spread of Omicron BA.4/5 variant.
The Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) based on the Omicron BA.4/5 strain, we hope it can provide a safe option for the prevention of Omicron-related new crown pneumonia. The study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary immunogenicity of the Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (CHO cells) after vaccination.

We are commencing the evaluation of the safety and performance of the SEPIOLA closure device through a single-arm, non-randomized, prospective registry.
The study will be undertaken in the United States for the treatment of atrial fibrillation in subjects with at least two risk factors for thrombo-embolic complications. The risk is assessed using the CHA2DS2-VASc score. Subjects with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater, who are eligible or have an appropriate rationale for seeking a non-pharmacologic alternative to chronic oral anticoagulant therapy, are eligible for inclusion.
The SEPIOLA closure device intends to offer a viable alternative to traditional anticoagulant therapies by using an investigational device to mitigate the risk of blood clots forming within the left atrial appendage region (LAA) and moving into the bloodstream to potentially cause embolic events.
The primary objective of this study is to determine the safety of the SEPIOLA device.
The study design comprises an ongoing single-arm study population consisting of subjects treated with the SEPIOLA device in the LAA. All enrolled subjects contribute to the safety analysis.
The primary endpoint of SEPIOLA System safety will be evaluated by assessing device and investigational procedure-related serious adverse events (SAEs) in the full study population.
The assessment of safety and technical success are key to the overall goals and success of this study.

In this acute phase of psychotic disorders, patients often experience a poor therapeutic alliance and are reluctant to ad-here to psychiatric outpatient treatments. Motivational interviewing (MI) has been developed as an evidence-based method which increases patient's intrinsic motivation and should enhance treatment ad-herence in this setting. This study will assess whether patients in a psychotic state benefit from these therapeutic sessions.
                In the Swiss Society for Psychiatry and Psychotherapy treatment guidelines, psycho-education plays a central role in the acute phase. In the psychotherapeutic approach, which is recommended in the acute phase during in-patient stays, patients should be offered a psychotherapy with cognitive-behavioral background. Because the acute phase is characterized by a poor therapeutic alliance and only 28% of patients adhere to out-patient psychotherapy, this study aims at developing a psychotherapeutic concept especially designed for the acute phase which improves therapeutic alliance and treatment adherence. With this pilot trial the results from the first project phase (R01) have to be confirmed, which showed an increased therapeutic alliance in patients with acute psychosis treated with motivational interviewing during one-year-outpatient treatment. Therefore this study examines whether additional two sessions of MI have a greater impact on therapy adherence and therapeutic alliance in the acute setting of a psychiatric hospital.
                Consecutively recruited patients with a diagnosis of ICD-10/F2.x and good knowledge of the german language will be screened for eligibility by experienced clinical psychologist at the outpatient units of the psychosis section of the Psychiatric hospital Zurich. A total of 34 patients will be randomized into an intervention group (receiving 2 MI sessions and 2 supportive sessions) or an active control group (receiving 2 MI sessions). The interventions (MI or supportive sessions) will be carried out by professional clinical psychologists who have received several hours of specific MI training. As a measure of therapeutic alliance, we will use the German version of the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship (STAR) which is rated by patients and clinicians at baseline and week 3 (or after 4 sessions of psychotherapeutic intervention. Treatment adherence is measured with an interview and the Brief Adherence Rating Scale (BARS). Additional measures include symptom severity (measured with the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS)), motivation and self-efficacy (assessed by the General Self Efficacy Scale).
                If our hypothesis is correct and motivational interviewing is superior to simple supportive conversations, we will develop an inpatient model of psychotherapy in the acute phase for psychosis which specifically increases intrinsic motivation, therapeutic alliance and adherence to psychiatric treatment in the acute setting. This concept will be essential to improve long-term out-patient adherence to psychiatric treatments.

The aim of this study was to show whether the success of lumbar plexus block applied in lower extremity orthopedic surgeries can be evaluated by Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS), which is used to measure tissue oxygenation. A total of 70 patients who applied for elective lower extremity lower extremity orthopedic surgery were studied. Lumbar plexus block success was measured by regional oxymetry using NIRS non-invasively in the postanesthesia care unit for 1 hour. Intraoperative narcotic consumption, vital signs, sensory block level and oxygen saturation values were recorded. Surgical site NIRS device application showed success in 53 patients (75.7%) and failed in 17 patients (24.3%). NIRS values in the extremity to be operated on were comparable between the two groups after comparing all patients. When the NIRS value on the normal side of the operated extremity was accepted as a landmark, the NIRS values of the operated extremity of patients whose NIRS values were higher than this value were higher on the other side (p<0.000). In such a way, lower values were observed on the other extremity (p<0.001). In patients whose NIRS values were less than this value, lower values were observed on both extremities (p<0.001). Sensory block level was realized using algometry with an isoternic cold test. Comparing the sensitivity and specificity of NIRS in predicting the sensory block level obtained with the cold test, AUC of NIRS was calculated as 0.956 (0.968-0.944) and the specificity was calculated as 94.44% (81.78-97.75) (p<0.001). In addition, the sensitivity of NIRS was calculated as 97.75% (91.86-99.02) (p<0.001). We think that NIRS may be used as an indicator of the success of lumbar plexus block, or to make the block more successful in cases where the success is insufficient. NIRS can be added to postoperative follow-up protocols as a non-invasive marker of success, complication, postoperative analgesia and narcotic consumption.

To mitigate the impact of the COVID pandemic, the Indian Ministry of Health has approved a remote, digital implementation support system as part of its COPSI (Community care for People with Schizophrenia in India) program. The aim of this trial is to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and implementation outcomes of using a digital platform for delivering training and ongoing support to the implementation team. This will include using digital videos to deliver the initial training to the Community Health Worker (CHW) team, providing on-demand support and feedback to the CHWs, and using a mobile application to support training, ongoing supervision, and monitoring. Digital training will reduce travel costs and time, increase flexibility to fit training around the daily activities and schedule of the implementation team, promote standardization of COPSI delivery, and potentially improve the quality of COPSI delivery. Digital on-demand supervision and feedback will further minimize the logistical burden on the implementation team and provide access to a wider pool of clinical support, as digital content can be shared with clinicians across multiple facilities. The outcome of this project will provide valuable data and insights that can be used to develop sustainable models of remote training and supervision for scaling up task shared psychosocial rehabilitation for schizophrenia in primary care in India.

Temporomandibular disorder (TMD) is a multifactorial pain disorder involving the muscles of mastication, the temporomandibular joints, and the teeth. Involved joints are synovial hinge-type joints whose movements are guided by a disk. Temporomandibular joint dysfunction is associated with an increased production of inflammatory mediators. Cytokines can play a role in the pathogenesis of temporomandibular joint disorders. The aim of the present study is to examine the influence of the occlusal splint therapy on the level of inflammatory markers with a special focus on gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) and blood. The hypothesis is that the use of an occlusal splint reduces the activity of inflammatory processes in TMD patients. A prospective uncontrolled study will be carried out. Patients with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMP and painful disc displacement (with and without reduction) according to Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders (DC/TMP) will be assessed. A total of 20 patients will be recruited in the study. The inclusion criteria include signed informed consent and age 18 - 65 years. The exclusion criteria include degenerative joint disease and subluxation of the temporomandibular joint, head trauma orofacial pain not associated with TMD, patients with fixed or removable prostheses, patients undergoing orthodontic therapy, and patients using occlusal splints during data collection. Participants will be asked to complete self-assessment questionnaires: Graded Chronic Pain Scale (v2); Jaw Functional Limitation Scale-20; Patient Health Questionnaire-9; General Anxiety Disorder-7; Patient Health Questionnaire-15; Oral Behaviors Checklist; Oral health Impact Profile; and Perceived Stress Scale-10. Occlusal splints will be made from hard acrylate resin by the same dental technician in the dental laboratory. The GCF will be collected with paper strips at baseline, immediately after adjustment, and after three months of therapy (after one month of wear). Cytokines levels will be measured in gingival crevicular fluid and whole blood with the use of special multiplex assays. The level of inflammatory markers will predict treatment outcomes and provide insights into potential new treatment options for TMD.

This study offers digital training on an evidence-based, individual treatment known as Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT), for counselors working with families affected by Opioid Use Disorder (OUD). Participants will be offered three levels of digital training, including a tutorial of an overview of CRAFT, tailored digital training modules, and feedback and coaching. If shown to be effective, this scalable and cost-effective approach has the potential to dramatically impact the lives of those families impacted by OUD. This training and coaching program is designed to give counseling care-providers the tools, knowledge, and skills necessary to implement evidence-based individual treatment (CRAFT) to help them get their clients with OUD into treatment and help them stay there. CRAFT (Community Reinforcement and Family Training) is a short-term outpatient treatment that helps those dealing with loved ones who have OUD, and in its most recent form, helps those struggling with SUDs (Substance Use Disorders). It uses a combination of motivational enhancement therapy, information about substance use disorders, substance-free activities and rewards to help families cope with the impact that substance use has on their lives and the life of their loved one. This study, like a study we completed on the effects of the same digital tutorial (T) for CRAFT on CRAFT knowledge in counselors, will evaluate the effects of three levels of digital training on the content knowledge of counselors in CRAFT skills, as well as their ability to engage treatment seeking loved ones of individuals with OUD in treatment entry and treatment. This study will not include the CRAFT family member.

Inclusion criteria: The study is recruiting licensed counseling professionals in the U.S. who work with affected families who have people in their lives with OUD. Participants must not have been trained in CRAFT and they must work with or be planning to work with at least 5 clients each week.

Design: This is an experimental clinical group study with a pilot randomized clinical trial on the effects of three levels of digital training on content knowledge of counselors in CRAFT skills.

Training: Participants will receive either an overview of CRAFT or the full training series or access to both, with and without a coaching component of this training.

Following 3-months of training, participants will complete an assessment including questionnaires, interviews, and an assessment of their skills in treating patients with OUD, by using recorded audio or video sessions of meetings with patients.

After training, participants will complete questionnaires every month until the 3 month marker. Following the 3 month marker, participants will complete questionnaires every 3 months for 1 year.

This study will follow a research design known as a parallel assignment. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three training levels. This is done by using a computer randomization process and an internet survey vendor to create an allocation key. Using this allocation key, the system will randomize participants to one of the three training groups. Participants will be told which training program they are assigned to upon completing the assessment of their pre-training knowledge. Blinded assessors will not know who is in which training group.

Cardiac transthyretin (ATTR) amyloidosis is an infiltrative cardiomyopathy with an inexorably progressive clinical course and poor prognosis. The disease is caused by misfolding of the liver-derived precursor protein transthyretin as a result of an acquired wild-type variant (ATTRwt) or as a hereditary mutant variant (ATTRm). Application of single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) provides greater anatomic resolution, enabling the assessment of amyloid burden within individual left ventricle segments. This study aims to describe the pattern of regional myocardial distribution of 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanedicarboxylic acid (DPD) SPECT uptake among patients with ATTRwt and ATTRm. It will investigate the clinical, biochemical and echocardiographical, including left ventricle longitudinal strain profile in ATTRwt and ATTRm. Moreover, we will evaluate the presence and extent of DPD cardiac uptake among asymptomatic ATTRm variants carriers. This is a prospective multi-center observational study. The study, after obtaining prior written informed consent, will include consecutive patients who have Grade 1-3 cardiac DPD retention in scintigraphy. In addition, first-degree relatives of patients with ATTRm are going to be enrolled. Patients are going to undergo TTR gene sequencing to assess the presence of pathogenic variants associated with ATTRm. Both planar scintigraphy, SPECT and speckle-tracking echocardiography will be reviewed and interpreted using visual and quantitative approaches. The collected data will be analyzed statistically to verify research hypotheses. Approval from the local Bioethical Committee will be obtained before carrying out the study. All procedures performed are going to be in accordance with the ethical standards of the 1964 Helsinki declaration and its later amendments, or comparable ethical standards.

Rationale: Falls are common in older adults after total knee replacement (TKR). One reason is that older adults often lose muscle mass and strength in their lower extremities after knee joint replacement owing to an extended period of inactivity and muscle disuse. This muscle weakness places them at an increased risk for slips and trips, that can result in loss of balance and falls. We propose to address these deficits with the use of a perturbation training device to mimic tripping or stumbling and to provide older adults with task-specific training that will enhance the safety of the postoperative period.
Method: We will recruit 374 older adults who are scheduled for primary (elective) unilateral total knee replacement and will undergo a baseline assessment that includes both clinical and objective measures of upper and lower extremity function. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. One group (training) will receive a brief training program on balance disturbances delivered on a treadmill. The other group (control) will receive written materials on fall prevention. Following the randomization, participants will undergo a follow-up assessment at two weeks, six weeks, and six months after their initial assessment. All assessments will be in-person except for the phone assessment, which will be made at two weeks, six weeks, and six months to monitor for falls during these periods.
Expected Results: Compared to the control group, the training group will have better upper extremity function at two weeks, six weeks, and six months, better lower extremity function at two weeks and six weeks, and fewer falls one year after total knee replacement. The improvement in upper extremity muscle function and greater reduction in postoperative fall rate will reflect the effectiveness of the perturbation training program in addressing the fall risk that may arise from lower extremity weakness after total knee replacement. These findings may be applicable to other surgeries (e.g., hip-replacement surgery) and to age-related decline in mobility.
Importance: This research has potential to dramatically reduce fall rates and improve outcomes for older adults undergoing total knee replacement. These patients present to their orthopedic surgeon's clinic before their scheduled surgery to discuss the risks of postoperative problems like deep-vein thrombosis or pneumonia. However, fall risk is rarely discussed with most orthopedic surgeons considering falls to be an inevitable consequence of knee osteoarthritis rather than a modifiable problem. Our proposed study will change this perception to encourage more physicians to consider modifiable factors such as muscle weakness and balance difficulty before the patient undergoes knee-replacement surgery. Improving postoperative training will provide a model for addressing other functional deficits after knee replacement, such as quadriceps muscle weakness and decreased function in the operated knee. Furthermore, the strategies employed in our study (perturbation training; postoperative assessment and monitoring for falls) may be useful in reducing the fall rate of older adults who do not wish to undergo knee-replacement surgery for hip-related osteoarthritis or hip replacement.

This single-centre, retrospective, open-label study is a cohort database analysis of vital signs/electronic anaesthetic record data, using data from the Royal Sussex County Hospital, Brighton. Included patients will have sustained a unilateral hip fracture, and received surgery (hemiarthroplasty, dynamic hip screw, cortical screws, proximal femoral nail) under low dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine, following fascia iliaca block + sedation of the Royal College of Anaesthetists recommended standards for anaesthesia) between 3rd March, 2017 and 1st January, 2020. Exclusion criteria are those for whom crude vital signs data have not been stored on secure computers. In total, approximately 600 people are expected to be included. Hypotension is very common during surgery, and appears to be significantly linked to a greater chance of death within a month after surgery, but this association remains uncertain because most prior studies do not have accurate blood pressure information or sufficient numbers of older, frailer people with dementia who have hip fracture. This study will quantify the actual prevalence, depth and duration of this hypotension in those who have received surgery for hip fracture. Outcomes will also be correlated with recorded demographic, clinical and procedural factors, including mortality and length of inpatient stay.

A post hoc analysis is planned, to further improve the cohort. The investigator will extract data from the electronic anaesthetic records of people (over the age of 18 years) who have received surgery for any fracture (other than traumatic hip fracture) at Princess Royal Hospital, Brighton under low dose spinal anaesthesia (1.3mls 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine, following fascia iliaca block + sedation) between February 2019 and January 2020. This will allow evaluation of broader applicability by including data from people who have had hip fracture surgery as well as many other fracture types, whilst remaining consistent with the primary analysis by focusing on this specific procedure and anaesthetic.

The investigators hypothesize that malaria, intestinal parasitic diseases, and vitamin A and folate/B12 deficiency may result in enhanced or tolerogenic innate immune responses that decrease the risk of symptomatic COVID-19. The research team will test these hypotheses using the data collected in this protocol, by evaluating the innate immune phenotypes, antibody responses, and immune memory that differentiate uninfected Malawians from well matched Western controls, and whether those responses correlate to SARS-CoV-2 transmission and development of symptomatic COVID-19. Background: 
Postoperative urinary retention (PUR) can develop after any surgical procedure. This complication is more common in elderly male patients, trauma, and emergency cases. The prevalence of PUR in orthopedic surgeries varies between 6-40% in the literature. The application of hot and cold to muscles, tendons, and joints is very common in orthopedic surgeries. This practice has a significant impact on the physiological activities of the bladder muscles. As nurses, it would be useful to determine the effect of this application applied to the bladder on the prevalence of PUR in orthopedic surgeries. 
Objective: 
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of hot and cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients. The secondary purpose is to evaluate the hot and cold application applied to the bladder in the management of postoperative urinary retention.
Study Design and Methods: 
The prospective, randomized, single blinded study was conducted at the Physiotherapy and Rehabilitation Service of a university hospital affiliated to the Ministry of Health. The population of the study was composed of individuals between the ages of 18-60. The sample of the study consisted of 105 individuals.
Descriptive statistical methods will be used to evaluate the data. Independent sample t test, Mann Whitney U, chi-square test, and McNemar test will be used as the parametric test for comparison between groups. The level of significance for the study was p<0.05.
Conclusion: 
It is thought that studies will contribute to the increase in the awareness of nurses and the literature about the effects of hot and cold application on postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients.

Pancreatitis is a multifactorial disease of the pancreas, characterized by inflammation and necrosis. Acute pancreatitis (AP) is an acute exacerbation of the pancreatic parenchyma, which is manifested by a persistent or episodic abdominal pain, accompanied by elevated serum amylase or lipase concentrations. Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is a pathological process of chronic relapsing or persistent inflammation of the pancreas. 
Acute pancreatitis is a highly heterogeneous disease with a wide range of clinical prognosis and severity. It can progress from mild gall stone pancreatitis to severe acute necrotizing pancreatitis (ANP) with rapid progression, multi-organ failure and mortality. Severe ANP is typically characterized by local complications, such as pancreatic necrosis and peripancreatic inflammatory changes, systemic complications, such as multiple organ failure and severe infection, or by persistent organ failure that lasts more than 48 hours, which may extend to 1 year or more. The current global incidence of acute pancreatitis is estimated to be about 25 per 100,000 people, of which about 20% have moderate or severe acute pancreatitis, leading to high morbidity and mortality.
An important subgroup of adult acute pancreatitis (aAP) is gall stone pancreatitis (GSP), which represents about 30% to 40% of aAP; It usually has a good prognosis and high recovery rate, often requiring non-specific conservative treatment. However, aAP is often considered as a heterogeneous disease, with the risk of recurrence after its remission, which may lead to recurrent pancreatitis, permanent organ dysfunction and chronic pancreatitis. In recent years, with the continuous improvement of medical treatment technology, the survival rate of acute pancreatitis has increased year by year, but the overall burden of the disease has been increasing. Studies show that 10% to 15% of adult patients with acute pancreatitis during hospitalization have recurrent pancreatitis, and the mortality rate can reach 10%. In addition, some patients with severe pancreatitis may develop into long-term complications, and even have a higher risk of organ failure and mortality.
Studies have shown that at least 14% of patients with acute pancreatitis have multiple events of recurrent acute pancreatitis. According to relevant reports, the recurrence rate of acute pancreatitis is different at different stages of the disease. The recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis within 24 to 48 hours after the first onset is extremely high (about 35.8%). The first recurrence during hospitalization is high, with a recurrence rate of 15%, and the recurrence rate reaches 20% within 1 year after the first onset. The overall recurrence rate of patients with moderate acute pancreatitis is 25%, and the recurrence rate of severe acute pancreatitis is as high as 50%.
The recurrence of acute pancreatitis imposes a significant burden on patients and society. According to reports, the risk of pancreatitis within 5 years after the first episode was 28%, and the cumulative risk of recurrence in 30 years after the first episode was 41%. Therefore, how to predict and control the recurrence of acute pancreatitis is an urgent clinical problem, which is also an important aspect of the follow-up care of acute pancreatitis.
Traditional clinical risk factors and imaging data have a shortage in predicting acute pancreatitis. On the one hand, traditional clinical risk factors only consider the prognosis and development of acute pancreatitis through the characteristics of the disease itself and the complication rates associated with the disease. On the other hand, the evaluation of pancreatic morphology and function through imaging data provides only a general qualitative assessment, which is limited by the quantification and prediction of the disease.
Radiomics feature (RF) refers to the set of quantitative and semi-quantitative features that were extracted from the imaging data. This feature includes a large number of continuous features, which are more comprehensive, accurate and quantitative than the traditional qualitative image features. There are not currently any drugs that reduce the number of red blood cells (polycythemia) of individuals with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The number of red blood cells in OSA patients is increased. Sleep apnea leads to intermittent hypoxemia, which can increase the formation of red blood cells. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment improves sleep apnea and night-time hypoxemia, but its effect on the number of red blood cells in these patients is unclear. The investigators believe that CPAP treatment may reduce the number red blood cells in OSA patients by reducing night-time hypoxemia. To determine this, the investigators will compare the number of red blood cells in OSA subjects between those treated with CPAP and those treated with usual care. The investigators will also study the relationship between CPAP treatment and daytime sleepiness and quality of life.

This study aims to compare magnetic resonance imaging images (MRI) in three different surgical methods (lateral suspension by mesh, pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation) in patients undergoing surgical treatment for apical prolapse. This study is planned with the hypothesis that these three different surgical methods will not give significant difference in the changes in the vaginal axis, which is a significant reason for the recurrence of these surgeries.
The main objective of the study is to compare the vaginal axis change after the three different prolapse surgeries. The secondary objectives are to assess whether the surgery selected causes a change in the patient's pain level, patient-perceived prolapse symptom severity, and the quality of life of patients undergoing any surgery to correct the apical prolapse.
If the surgical procedure provides a change in the vaginal axis, this may lead to a decrease in the recurrence of symptoms. However, if the changes in the vaginal axis do not vary significantly among the three different surgical methods, it is possible that all three procedures can be used to correct the apical prolapse with the same efficiency. When it comes to pain control and improvements in sexual experience, the study is expected to provide results with a low probability of Type I error.

To evaluate the effectiveness of scenario-based standardized patient simulation training and electronic fetal monitor management of midwifery students, the participants in the study will be exposed to electronic fetal monitor management and patient care activities in theoretical lessons for 5 weeks; the theory lessons of the participants in the experimental group will be applied only with high, realistic scenario-based standardized patient simulation training. The control group will be given theory lessons, while in the experimental group, only high realistic scenario-based standardized patient simulation training will be given. In addition, the satisfaction of the students from their own simulation training experiences and their ability to perform a specific task when given a task they have never tried before will be evaluated with their own self-efficacy scales (Self-efficacy Scale in Monitoring and Management of Electronic Fetal Monitoring).

Background and Rationale: Prolonged mechanical ventilation with respiratory failure has become an increasingly common problem in the ICUs. The prevalence of mechanical ventilation (MV) is relatively constant at between 30-40% of admissions. Among critically ill patients that required invasive mechanical ventilation (MV), an average of 75% of patients required prolonged mechanical ventilation. These patients consume a disproportionate amount of healthcare resources and clinician time. There are no specific criteria for discharge from MV. The discharge criteria are based on the decision of the attending clinicians. However, the length of MV stays is quite variable among ICUs. The decision to discontinue MV is often influenced by the availability of long-term care for patients. Patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy require a different level of care for which the family or caregivers require training to provide appropriate care. Several studies reported prolonged weaning period, multiple failure and reintubation, and a poor long-term outcome of patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation. Patient with prolonged weaning failures have up to 10 times higher mortality risk than those with uneventful or straightforward weaning. The prevalence of multiple hospitalization days is higher in those requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation. Many patients undergoing prolonged MV face the need for long term care (long term oxygen therapy (LTOT), home care, or rehabilitation) and are associated with increased family burden and costs. There is a variation in prolonged mechanical ventilation between different parts of the world. Thus the duration of MV varies from five to seven weeks in the United States and 16-21 days in European countries. In a retrospective chart audit of 12150 ICU patients from 40 UK intensive care units, 16% patients required ICU length of stay (LOS) more than 19 days. Prognostic factors for prolonged mechanical ventilation: Several studies reported the prognostic factors for prolonged mechanical ventilation are age, gender, underlying diseases, initial severity of disease, the number of life support devices used, length of stay in ICUs, acute organ failure, the number of ICU re-admission, and the need for re-intubation. Objective of the study: The investigators plan to compare the clinical outcomes in patients with and without severe organ dysfunction using prolonged mechanical ventilation. To study the clinical outcomes and predictors of death in critically ill patients undergoing prolonged MV. To determine the frequency of re-admission to the ICU with prolonged mechanical ventilation. To study the long-term outcome of patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation. To assess the family needs and resource availability in providing care for patients following prolonged mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy. To develop a training package for health professionals with the help of tracheostomy patients and their caregivers.

Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor represents the standard of care for the prevention of atherothrombotic events in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). However, in ACS patients undergoing PCI, more potent P2Y12 inhibitors (namely, prasugrel or ticagrelor) are preferred over clopidogrel based on results of large-scale clinical trials. Nevertheless, such ischemic benefit occurs at the expense of increased bleeding compared with patients receiving DAPT with clopidogrel. However, accruing evidence from recent studies propose the use of pharmacodynamic guided therapy to reduce bleeding complications without jeopardizing ischemic efficacy. Such bleeding reduction approaches include 1) DAPT de-escalation (the switch from potent P2Y12 inhibitors to less potent agents with clopidogrel while maintaining aspirin) and 2) potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy (i.e., the maintenance of potent P2Y12 inhibitors with prasugrel or ticagrelor while dropping aspirin). The purpose of this study is to compare for the first time these two strategies in ACS patients undergoing PCI treated with DAPT with at least one month with prasugrel or ticagrelor. We hypothesize that the 30-day thrombus formation in patients treated with potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy is non-inferior to that seen with DAPT de-escalation.
