Increasing age is associated with a decline in the number of larger, HDL subparticles that are primarily responsible for removing cholesterol from the arteries.  This is a major risk factor for heart disease.  Eggs have been shown to increase HDL particle size, and we hypothesize that higher intakes of eggs, especially egg yolks, can improve HDL function in older adults.  To determine the effect of diet on large HDL subparticles, we will enroll 65 (32 young and 33 older) participants in a 10-week crossover study in which we will measure immune and lipid responses to a run-in period of 2 weeks without eggs, followed by 4 weeks of whole egg (n=21), egg white (n=21), or egg yolk (n=23), which will be provided as a liquid egg supplement.  The supplements will be followed by a 4-week washout and then the participants will consume a different type of egg for another 4 weeks in random order.  The primary focus of the research is on larger HDL subparticles, which are more effective at removing excess cholesterol from the body and are declining with age in both men and women.  In addition, we will measure markers of immune function and the effect of egg intake in these sub-groups.  The findings of this research will provide valuable information for public health recommendations regarding the role of eggs in preventing disease, improving longevity, and optimizing health outcomes.

<|assistant|> Background: Prosthetic myoelectric control can provide patients with greater functional autonomy and prosthesis independence. However, it is typically accompanied by increased time for upper limb function as amputees need more time to plan their movements, select the correct movement, and initiate and control the prosthesis. Therefore, upper limb amputees require substantial motor learning and re-learning effort to operate myoelectric prostheses. One strategy to improve this process is functional task training, in which amputees have an opportunity to practice operating myoelectric prostheses in real-world tasks. However, clinical-level myoelectric prostheses that offer such realistic training experiences are typically cost-prohibitive. Augmented reality (AR) offers an opportunity to create a high-fidelity simulation of the prosthetic myoelectric control process in a lower-cost manner; furthermore, an AR simulation can offer additional opportunities for visualization and training. To address this gap, the purpose of this study is to improve the functionality of individuals with upper limb amputations using a patient-driven AR simulation. Methods: 25 unilateral trans-radial amputees will be recruited for this study. Participants first complete baseline assessments, which take the form of a detailed evaluation of everyday activities with a Certified Prosthetist and a clinical assessor (ACMC). They are then randomized to one of two conditions: experimental or sham control. Sham Control will receive motor imagery (imagining performing tasks with their missing limb) while experimental participants will complete functional task training using the MyoTrain AR system. In addition, both groups will undergo functional task training to improve their capacity for control (CFO) with their current prosthetic control strategy. Outcome measures will assess both lower limb function (walking and standing performance) and upper limb function (capacity to control a prosthesis and perform real tasks). Assessments will also explore the impact of augmented reality training on the patients’ prosthetic use and motivation to use the prosthesis. The primary objective of this multicenter prospective randomized controlled study is to evaluate whether electrical stimulation of the stomach is able to reduce the incidence or duration of postoperative ileus in patients undergoing extensive oncological surgery including or without hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) as in the appendiceal neoplasm. The investigators will include approximately 109 patients (55 randomized to both the intervention and sham-control group).
Cytoreductive surgery in the treatment of advanced gastrointestinal tumors is often combined with intraperitoneal chemotherapy (IPC), which results in reduced quality of life by ileus and ileus-related complications that result in prolonged hospital stays and delayed initiation of systemic chemotherapy.
The investigators will evaluate whether or not the electrical stimulation of the stomach is able to reduce the need for naso- or naso-gastric tube insertion in postoperative period from an average of 21, 6 days to a maximum of 8-9 days. In total, the investigators will include 109 eligible patients. The investigators will evaluate the time to a first passage of stool.
Cytoreductive surgery of patients is associated with an increased risk of ileus. The risk factors for ileus are often related to patients´ anatomy and the extent of the surgery. Postoperative complications as in ileus lead to a prolonged hospital stay (average 23 days), need for postoperative interventions (24- 30 %) and delayed initiation of systemic adjuvant chemotherapy (10-13 days). 
The investigators believe that electrical stimulation of the stomach and thus facilitating bowel motility postoperative can reduce ileus by shortening the time to a first stool passage, reducing complications (length of intensive care unit (ICU) stay, surgical site infections (SSI), ileus-related complications including aspiration pneumonia) and length of hospital stay and the risk of ileus-related complications.
This randomized controlled trial will examine whether electrical stimulation of the stomach (electrical pace maker) initiated within 48 hrs after surgery can reduce the risk of postoperative ileus and subsequent complications.
Inclusion criteria: Patients planned for elective cytoreductive surgery due to either colorectal or appendiceal cancer or with peritoneal metastases or due to pseudomyxoma peritonei will be evaluated for eligibility. Other conditions may be included on the principal researchers discretion. If inclusion is possible, the patient will meet for oral and written information and written and oral informed consent. Patients aged > 18 years.
The intervention group will receive electrical pacing of the stomach via a gastric electrical pacemaker (Gastric Electric Pacing, GEP) initiated within 48 hrs after surgery
The sham control group (SCG) will receive a placebo GEP initiated within 48 hrs.
The investigators will collect patient registry. Data on gender, age, comorbidities, reoperations, surgery type, time for ileus, antibiotic prophylaxis and complications will be collected via electronic medical records (EMR). The investigators will collect information through the GEP-app.
The investigators will use a daily patient diary with information on stool, flatus and bowel movements.

Patients will be admitted to the palliative care service at the hospital and 20 patients will be included in the study and data will be collected. The research is planned as a randomized controlled trial. The individuals in the research group are divided into four groups as music group, aromatherapy group, music and aromatherapy and control group. The patients in the experimental group will listen to music with headphones for 20 minutes for three consecutive days. The music group listened to specially composed MusiCure® compositions in soft rhythm, including melodies with harp, cello, strings and natural sound elements (eg rain, bird, forest sound). The patients in the aromatherapy group will inhale lavender oil. The investigators evaluated the effect of aromatherapy, music and their combination on the pain, anxiety and vital parameters of patients. To compare the pre and post pain and anxiety levels in the music and aromatherapy group, pain, anxiety and vital parameters were recorded before the intervention and at the end of the intervention with data collection tools.

- This is a randomized controlled study.
- No adverse events were observed in individuals who applied music and aromatherapy.

Conclusion: Listening to the relaxing music group and aromatherapy group significantly affects pain and anxiety status in patients with palliative stage cancer. Using music and aromatherapy together can improve these parameters. Further Studies need to involve larger samples of participants and more diverse music and aromatherapy interventions.

Amputees experience reduced feedback and sensitivity from the lower limb, which contributes to falls and instability during activities of daily living. The Somatosensation Device (SD) aims to improve feedback and sensation in the residual limb for amputees experiencing sensory deficits. The goal of the SD is to provide improved somatosensory input to subjects, in order to promote and maintain gait stability in the absence of proprioceptive feedback. This project is the first step in developing an effective neuroprosthetic device to prevent falls in lower limb amputees. We will be testing the effectiveness of the SD in improving functional balance and gait through a repeated measures, crossover design, where participants will have the opportunity to wear the device and perform a series of gait tests at different time points.
By wearing the Somatosensation Device, participants will engage in a three-minute walk at baseline (no device), post-intervention (with the device), and one month follow-up (with the device). Gait parameters collected include walking speed, stride length, time in stance phase, and more.
The Somatosensation Device consists of a waistband electrode unit providing electrical stimuli to the skin and dura over the lumbar region, which are designed to increase the excitability of dorsal root ganglia neurons, promoting input through the spinal cord. In addition, tactile stimulators in the sleeve of the device provide inputs to the skin and dura over the lower limb(s).
By increasing somatosensory input from the lower limbs for subjects with unilateral or bilateral sensory deficits, the Somatosensation Device has the potential to benefit the target population by reducing gait instability in everyday activities and maintaining independent ambulation.

This study is a proof-of-concept study that utilizes a new, lightweight, self-contained, non-invasive OtoBand (experimental device) that has received a Therapeutic Breakthrough Device designation by the FDA that is designed to provide temporary relief within one hour of starting use of an episode of vertigo. This study will be conducted in multiple groups and arms will be determined by data collected during the two week baseline phase of the study. 64% of the participants will be randomized in moderately worse condition (MoW) groups and 36% will be randomized in high vertigo symptom (QoL) groups. Participants will each receive either the OtoBand (experimental device) or sham. The purpose of this study is to determine if the OtoBand provides temporary relief for vertigo in participants with vestibular vertigo, a highly prevalent condition which is one of the 10 most common medical problems. Participants will be enrolled in a virtual manner, and will complete a one day enrollment meeting and an approximately 14 day Baseline Phase. After the Baseline Phase, participants will be placed in one of two groups Moderate or Worse (MoW) or Quality of Life (QoL) groups based on the data collected about their vertigo during the Baseline Phase. Participants will then be randomized within their assigned group (MoW or QoL) at a 2:1 ratio to an active arm or sham arm to begin the Treatment Phase of the study. Participants will be sent a study device to use when they have a vertigo episode. Participants that enroll in the study are expected to participate up to 49 days with virtual meetings at the approximate intervals: MoW Group: Day 21, Day 24, Day 31, and Day 42 QoL Group : Day 16, Day, 24, Day 36, and Day 49 Participants will be required to complete the DHI (Dizziness Handicap Index), VSS (Vertigo Symptom Scale), Global Impression of Symptoms, and Global Impression of Change questionnaires.

BACKGROUND: Chitin-Glucan dietary supplement has been proven to be a good alternative for the management of active Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's disease in the absence of specific therapy, but its effects on abdominal pain, bloating, quality of life, and inflammation in Crohn's patients in remission under a stable medical therapy are still unclear.
An increasing body of evidence suggests that there is a substantial overlap between Crohn's disease and Irritable Bowel Syndrome. Patients with Irritable Bowel Syndrome often suffer from debilitating symptoms and a low quality of life. In some cases, these patients may be difficult to differentiate clinically from Crohn's patients, even under the assumption of having a normal bowel endoscopy.
HYPOTHESIS: In Crohn's patients with IBS-like symptoms during a stable maintenance therapy, the inclusion of a daily chitin-glucan supplementation may reduce subjective symptoms of abdominal pain, bloating, and dyschesia, while improving functional and emotional aspects of patients' daily lives.
MATERIAL AND METHODS:
It consists of a 10-week randomized double-blinded crossover trial using BK003 (chitin-glucan) as an investigational product and Placebo as a comparator (1:1), at a single center in Lille, France. Thirty four Crohn's disease patients will be included in this double-blinded trial. The inclusion criteria are: Adult patients ≥ 18 years old and ≤ 75 years old, Clinical remission (according to the investigator), Absence of inflammatory markers at Visit 1, Presence of IBS-like symptoms according to Rome IV criteria, Likert scale ≥ 3 for abdominal pain at Visit 0, Patient with correct and complete reporting of the study questionnaires and scores during the run-in period (≥ 75% completion). Patients who will agree to use acceptable methods of birth control (oral, transdermal, systemic contraception, intrauterine device, condom) for the duration of the study. Patients capable of communicating with the investigator, replying to the questionnaires, and understanding the requirements and constraints of the study protocol, Possession of a digital device (i.e., smartphone or tablet), Patient willing to adhere to the study visit schedule and able to understand and comply with protocol requirements and product administration. The primary objective is to compare the effect of BK003 on the subject's global assessment (SGA) of relief responder rate. Secondary objectives include weekly change from baseline in mean 7-point Likert scale for each of the symptoms, 7-point Likert scale for individual stool symptom for each patient, BSS score, number of stool per day, IBS-related quality of life score, Anxiety and depression, serum CRp, fecal calprotectine, alpha diversity and the relative abundance of bacterial, viral and fungal taxa in stools, and occurrence and severity of adverse events. The assessment will be performed for 7 days before the randomization visit, during the 6-weeks intervention period and for 3 weeks after the crossover, representing a total follow-up period of 10 weeks.
68 patients will be randomized in a 2:1 ratio to either BK003 or Placebo 1:4:4, corresponding to a 60% chance of each patient receiving both BK003 and Placebo period during the crossover period. Patients will be instructed to take a daily dose of 3 grams of BK003 or Placebo during randomization visit, with one week of wash-out before switching to the other treatment during period II. The outcome assessments will be performed during this 2-times 6-weeks period.

In a previous study by our center, we demonstrated the value of a novel personalized chimera DNA as a liquid biopsy for the detection and monitoring of HBV-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Our findings implied that the DNA released from HBV-infected liver cancer cells is more abundant than its HBV-coding DNA. We proposed to capture and quantify these non-coding DNA fragments as a tumor-specific biomarker. The investigators now plan to explore a new type of chimera DNA, the HBV-human junction DNA (vh-DNA), as the potential biomarker using the next-generation sequencing (NGS), and ddPCR technology. In order to generate the vh-DNA, viral genomic DNA integrates into the host genomic DNA at many positions during HBV replication. The investigators expect that vh-DNA can be generated exclusively from the original hepatocellular cancer cells and is different from DNA released from normal liver or regenerated cancer cells after transarterial chemoembolization (TACE), which is crucial for early evaluation of treatment response and post-radiotherapy recurrence/metastasis. Since vh-DNA are from individual patients, it has the potential to be considered as personalized liquid biopsies reflecting the clonality of HCC. To confirm whether this novel vh-DNA provides a more potent biomarker than previous traditional ctDNA, the investigators will analyze 100 HBV-related HCC samples, collected from patients who have undergone curative-intent liver-directed therapies. The investigators will further prospectively study the clinical value of this biomarker in 270 patients treated with radiotherapy. The investigators aim to explore the value of pre- and post-RT changes of vh-DNA in predicting the response of anti-tumor therapy and prognosis of the patients. The investigators will collect 6-12 samples at the 1st, 4th, and 7th month after RT, and at recurrence or metastasis up to 6 years. In 54 recurrent or metastatic tumors, the investigators will correlate clonality assessed with vh-DNA with the pattern of failure as the original or a de novo one, and explore the genetic changes associated with the development of recurrent/metastatic tumor. These findings will be the basis for the establishment of a new clinical trial involving combination treatment. In summary, the investigators hypothesized that vh-DNA could predict treatment response better than contemporary images, and it may serve as a personalized biomarker for the evaluation of treatment response, prediction of prognosis, and differentiation of clonality at tumor recurrence/progression. The investigators will collect the blood samples at routine follow-ups to explore the novel use of this biomarker and its impact on clinical practice. The investigators expect that the novel biomarker of personalized vh-DNA would allow earlier evaluating the therapy response and detect early recurrence/metastasis, which is crucial for individualizing the treatment for HBV-related HCC patients.

In a number of clinical and non-clinical studies, the results of the interventions based on the Meaning Making Model have shown the efficacy of this model in reducing distressing psychological symptoms and supporting people who are in critical and difficult situations to gain a positive sense of meaning in their lives. Based on these findings, the current study aimed to develop and implement an online individual intervention program based on the Meaning Making Model and to examine its effectiveness. The study was planned as a randomized controlled trial and the researchers aimed to examine the difference between the intervention and control groups in order to answer the questions, "Is the MCCP more effective in creating better meaning and meaning of life as well as post-traumatic growth experiences and psychological flexibility, compared to a control group that waits for the intervention?" and "Are MCCP participants show better improvements in cognitive appraisals (intrusion, avoidance) and psychological distress (anxiety, anxiety, and depression)." In the current study, the final form of the MCCP was applied to 22 women diagnosed with breast cancer after the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic took place in Turkey. To evaluate the process of implementation, we will provide a detailed description of the implementation process of the MCCP in future articles. The results of the evaluation will be reported in two other papers.

People requiring an LLA are at high risk for adverse clinical outcomes. Undernutrition and low physical activity level may affect clinical outcomes negatively. However, little is known about the nutritional intake, nutritional status and physical activity level in the LLA population, and their association with clinical outcomes. This study aims to:
1) investigate nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in rehabilitation after a major dysvascular lower limb amputation (LLA)
2) assess the impact of LLA on nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level
3) explore the association of nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level with LLA outcomes/complications (e.g., mortality, wound healing, health-related quality of life)
4) provide evidence-based nutrition advice for this population.

This prospective, randomized, controlled, open-label, crossover, proof-of-concept study assesses the feasibility and efficacy of a decentralized clinical trial employing remote continuous remote data collection for monitoring treatment effects of the SGLT2 inhibitor empagliflozin after the addition or substitution of the mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist finerenone in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and proteinuria. The feasibility of conducting a personalized, remote data collection study is assessed from three perspectives: The patient's perspective, the usability of remote monitoring devices (capillary blood pressure, body weight, and urinalysis), and the logistic and administrative aspects. Data will be collected at the screening visit and from the baseline and end of the treatment with empagliflozin +/- finerenone (4 weeks treatment, 4 weeks follow-up, with a one-week washout) study phase. The total study period is 13 months. Participants will continue the treatment with empagliflozin +/- finerenone until their personal target is reached or until they develop unacceptable adverse events or if they are unable to continue the treatment on the grounds of study completion criteria.

The study is a prospective, randomized, controlled, open-label, crossover, proof-of-concept study on 60 participants, with 30 participants randomized in arm A receiving empagliflozin 10 mg once daily with or without finerenone (10 mg/day or 20 mg/day) for 4 weeks, and with 30 participants randomized in arm B receiving empagliflozin 10 mg once daily with or without finerenone (10 mg/day or 20 mg/day) for 4 weeks. After the initial phase, both arms receive a 1 week wash-out and subsequently the treatment groups will be switched and administered the alternative treatment for 4 weeks. Primary outcomes are feasibility (determined by patient acceptability, monitoring device usability, and logistic feasibility), and treatment effects (determined by changes in UACR, systolic blood pressure, body weight, creatinine clearance, and fasting plasma glucose from the start to final visit). Secondary outcomes are the treatment effects measured after an additional 4 week period.

Participants are screened based on a medical history, physical examination, and laboratory values. Inclusion criteria are as follows: aged ≥18 years; treatment with empagliflozin for at least 3 months prior to inclusion; confirmed diagnosis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus; screening UACR between 55 and 330 mg/g Albumin:Creatinine Ratio (UACR); estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-eGFR) ≥30 mL/min/1.73 m2 at screening; treatment with empagliflozin 10 mg (10 mg once daily or 10 mg twice daily) during the study according to the respective label recommendation; treatment with finerenone 10 or 20 mg once daily. Exclusion criteria include pregnancy, known hypersensitivity to finerenone or empagliflozin, estimated glomerular filtration rate (MDRD-eGFR) <30 mL/min/1.73 m2 at screening, and current treatment with oral antidiabetic drugs (with the exception of metformin) in addition to empagliflozin during the screening visit.

Participants are randomized in stratified fashion, with random allocation for each participant based on the presence of micro- or macroalbuminuria. Randomization is done centrally using a computerized randomization procedure. Treatment allocation is balanced across study groups on the basis of sex and initial microalbuminuria. Treatment groups are assigned sequentially after stratification and after informed consent has been signed by the participants. The full study arms are disclosed by the study staff after randomization. The intervention model is a prospective, open-label, crossover trial, and the participants will not be masked for the treatment. All participants undergo a one-time run-in period of 8 weeks with the administration of empagliflozin (10 mg once daily or 10 mg twice daily) prior to randomization at Visit 3. The purpose of the study was to test the effectiveness of the training method by intervening in the selective fitness, skills, and tactical performance of college students using a high-intensity interval training method on the ice. The study consists of two groups, with 20 students in the experimental group and 20 students in the control group, to compare the differences between the two groups. The study selected ice hockey players from the undergraduate college of a sports teacher training school in Hubei Province as the research objects, and the experimental group was trained using a high-intensity interval training method, while the control group was trained using the training method. A variety of sports skills were used for high-intensity interval training, including repeated sprint training, sprint interval training (on-ice 45-s shift length conditioning drill), a long-pass tracking drill, and a chase-the-rabbit tracking drill. The control group used varied-pace skating (1 minute accelerated skating, 2 minutes even pace), dribbling and shooting drill (30 m), passing and catching training (20 m), and 2 on 1 offensive drill (full rink). As in the experimental group, the same three phases were used to gradually increase the intensity.

Oral morphine equivalents (OMEQ) consumed during the first 6 weeks after hospital discharge are 45% lower in patients following accidental injury who have a PAC-plan compared to patients in the control group. OMEQ consumption, pain, depression symptoms, perceived injustice and quality of life are reduced and physical activity is increasing, for participants with a PAC-plan compared to the control group. No major impact is seen on substance use. No other serious negative outcomes are reported, and there are no indications of increased risk for addiction. No major impact if any on time to recovery, readmission, costs, and overall mortality and morbidity is seen. The findings indicate that a PAC-plan provides a feasible, safe and effective intervention to reduce opioid use, and to improve health-related outcomes for patients after accidental injury. The results of the present study, and from other studies on the use of PAC-plans in patients undergoing surgery for a variety of different reasons, can help increase safe pain management as well as a reduction in the overprescription of opioids. Further studies on the use of PAC-plans, its development and implementation, should explore the perspectives of health care providers, patients and their next of kin.

Study Abstract
-----------------
Introduction: Ischemic and bleeding events always occurred during antiplatelet therapy. It is crucial to optimize the antiplatelet treatment to improve the clinical outcome. Intracranial aneurysms (IA) are at risk of rupture, bleeding events that occur during antiplatelet therapy significantly increase mortality. Intracranial stent-assisted coil embolization (SCE) and flow diversion (FD) are effective treatments for IA, but they are associated with more antiplatelet drug use. The purpose of this study is to explore the appropriate dosage of antiplatelet drugs in patients with IA after different types of antiplatelet therapy. The study was performed as a cluster randomized controlled study design was used in multiple hospitals, with the LTA of patients with IA after SCE and flow-diverting treatment as the basis for guiding the dosage of antiplatelet drugs.
Method: In this study, we will use a cluster randomized controlled cohort study, 180 patients need to be screened to enroll 160 patients per study arm who meet the inclusion criteria. All patients underwent intracranial stent-assisted coil embolization and flow-diverting treatment for intracranial aneurysms after 2021.06.01.00. A cluster randomized controlled study design was used, 9 hospitals were selected and divided into control and test groups, with cluster randomization allocation. In the control group, continuing to use dual antiplatelet drugs (aspirin 100mg/d + clopidogrel 75mg/d) is a standard antiplatelet treatment scheme. The test group adjusts aspirin and clopidogrel (clopidogrel overdose: 37.5 mg/d; ticagrelor overdose: 60 mg/bid; ticagrelor resistance: adjustment 90 mg/bid), then test the LTA of patients again (48 hours after adjustment) and re-adjust the antiplatelet drugs if necessary.
Ethics statement: The study was approved by the Medical Review Institute of Guangdong First Military Medical University (0821655), and informed consent was obtained from patients and families.
Official Title
-----------------
Guided Versus Standard Antiplatelet Therapy in Intracranial Aneurysm Intervention With Stents: a Cluster Randomized Controlled Cohort Study

Conditions
-----------------
Intracranial Aneurysm

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Adjustment of Antiplatelet Drugs


Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: Patients with unruptured intracranial aneurysms who received intracranial stenting, Standard dualantiplatelet therapy for at least 5 days before stent implantation, Patients aged 18-80, on the day of registration patients with a Modified Rankin Scale lower than 2, patients who agree and sign the consent form. Exclusion Criteria: Patients with recurrent aneurysms after interventional therapy or clipping therapy, Patients with a history of allergy to aspirin, clopidogrel or ticagrelor, Patients who used tirofiban prophylactically before surgery, Possible active bleeding Patients with high blood pressure, such as symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage or active gastric ulcer; or patients with bleeding tendency or coagulation dysfunction, Any abnormal platelet count (normal value is 100-300 × 10^9/L), Patients using anticoagulants, Pregnant or lactating women, Suffering from liver disease, kidney disease, congestive heart failure, malignant tumors and other malignant diseases.

Maximum Age: 80 Years

A cross-sectional study will be conducted in 75 children with CP. The children will be examined individually and divided into two groups:
Ambulant (n= 37) or non-ambulant (n = 38) classified in two different groups according to the Gross Motor Function Classification System(GMFCS). Body Mass Index (BMI) will be calculated for all children. BMD will be assessed in both groups using DXA. Motor function will be assessed according to GMFCS. Quality of life will be assessed by Childs Version of The Child Health Questionnaire (CHQ90(C)). For all children, bone mineral content will be assessed, and results will be normalized for skeletal size by Total Body Less Head (TBLH) bone density.

This is a multi-method clinical and brain-imaging study examining the effects of the dopamine D2/3 antagonist sulpiride on working memory gating, learning, motivation and striatal activity. Based on previous results, the investigators will examine whether sulpiride enhances the ability to selectively input- and output-gate working memory, which is important in the selection and updating of relevant information in the environment and leads to better task performance. The investigators predict that sulpiride will have enhanced effects on working memory gating. Furthermore the use of a pharmaco-fMRI (magnetic resonance imaging) protocol allows the investigators to identify whether stimulating D2/3 dopamine antagonist leads to an enhanced recruitment of striatal BOLD response and a better behavioral outcome and to identify the underlying neurobiological, pharmacological and motivational substrates of these relationships.

<|assistant|> This study focuses on adolescents to gather important information and identify the prevalence of hypertension in this age range. The researchers plan to recruit a total of 2,000 adolescents from different high schools in different parts of Italy, ranging in age from 13 to 19. During the 2009/2010 school year, 1,500 adolescents aged between 13-15 years will be included in the "Cross-sectional study" and then followed-up after 2009/2010 school-year to carry on the "Longitudinal study". The aim is to investigate whether specific genetic polymorphisms found in certain genes may affect the propensity of adolescents to develop high blood pressure. The researchers hypothesize that the selected genes might play a role in the development of high blood pressure among adolescents. Furthermore, they aim to study the following: 1. Determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension (HT) in a cohort of adolescents. 2. Perform genetic studies to determine a link between specific polymorphisms of Adducins and EO-related genes with the prevalence of HT and genetic factors associated with cardiovascular risk factors. 3. Explore whether urinary sodium excretion and urinary markers of inflammation and oxidative stress are linked to the prevalence of HT and selected cardiovascular risk factors. The students will be provided with a full explanation of the study, including the aim, the procedures involved, and the possible risks and benefits. Once the student has received all the explanations, s/he will be given a written and verbal consent form and an information leaflet. If the student is willing to participate, they will be required to bring back the signed consent form the next day. For the purposes of this research, a blood test to measure blood pressure will be performed at the school, either in the morning between 8:00 and 10:00 am, or in the afternoon between 2:00 and 4:00 p.m. The students will be asked to wear their normal clothing (e.g. jeans, T-shirt, etc.) on the day of the visit. They will be instructed to empty their bladder, sit in the chair, cross ankles and lean forearms on a table to rest their arms on it. They will be measured twice and the average of the two readings will be taken. The investigators are unable to measure blood pressure during lunch or gym hours, and hence school hours are used. At the study visit, students will be asked to complete two validated questionnaires (Questioniario del Nutrizione Italiano - ONI-V e QOLMIS 99). Moreover, students will be provided with a urine cup to collect a first (or second in cases of large discrepancies) early morning urine sample to measure the presence of specific inflammatory and antioxidant markers, which are likely to affect blood pressure. A further test to measure the specific inflammatory and oxidant markers will be conducted in a subgroup of adolescents. Finally, after the urine sample is collected, the students will be advised about the importance of hypertension and cardiovascular risk factors, and how lifestyle modifies the risks. The EPIVA Study is a feasibility study exploring the epigenetic and metabolic changes in children undergoing anaesthesia for hypospadias surgery. Hypospadias is a congenital disorder where the urethral opening is not in the right position of the penis. Anaesthesia for hypospadias surgery is typically performed through one of two methods (inhalational or intravenous) that are currently routine anaesthetic clinical practice in the NHS and around the world.
This study aims to explore the molecular changes (epigenetics, biochemistry, redox) caused by anaesthesia and surgery in children and to compare whether the two methods of maintaining anaesthesia have different effects.
Children presenting to the paediatric surgical out-patient clinic at Liverpool Women's NHS Trust with an indication for the diagnosis and/or correction of a hypospadias lesion using anaesthesia will be assessed for age eligibility (6 months - 3 years). The participants will be randomised to receive either intravenous or inhalational anaesthesia for surgery and they will not know which form of anaesthesia they have until the results of the trial are available. Parents/guardians of all participants will be asked to provide written informed consent before their child is included in the trial. The child will be included in the trial if their parent/guardian provides written consent, and the legal representative (parent/guardian) consents. If the parent/guardian refuses consent, or the child is not suitable for the trial, the child will not be eligible to enter into the study.
The participants will be seen in the outpatient clinic, and if eligible, their parent/guardian will be provided with a copy of the participant information sheet. Informed consent will be obtained from the parent/guardian of the child if they are deemed eligible, and a screening visit booked with the clinical research team. A legal representative for a child is the person who has been given the responsibility by law to make decisions on behalf of that child. This is usually the parent/s or guardian/s. The child will be seen in the outpatient clinic by a clinical research nurse (usually in addition to having a standard outpatient clinic consultation with the surgeon). A brief clinical screening check will be performed, and the participant information sheet given to the parent/guardian for a period of one month to allow for consideration. When the legal representative of the child is happy and ready to proceed, they will enter the trial in agreement with the consultant surgeon and anaesthetist.

The study aims to investigate whether a variety of additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in patients with hypothyroidism receiving L-T4 in whom TSH cannot be used as a reflection of thyroid hormone status (e.g. central hypothyroidism). Alternatives are proposed and evaluated: fT3 and the derived fT3/fT4 ratio, but TT4, TT3, rT3, SHBG, acylcarnitines and several amino acids may be interesting parameters as well. Healthy controls must be included to obtain valid results.

Patients with systemic sclerosis (SSc) are at increased risk of severe infection with Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Indeed, immune dysregulation occurs in systemic sclerosis contributing to severe lung fibrosis. It is assumed that immunization in systemic sclerosis patients can be more effective if the immune system is rebuilt by autologous hematopoietic stem cells transplantation (AHSCT). To date, no study has addressed the issue of COVID-19 vaccine effectiveness in these patients and the influence of previous AHSCT and immunoglobulin replacement therapy on vaccine efficacy.
The objective of the study was to compare the rates of anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccines in subjects with systemic sclerosis (SSc) previously treated by AHSCT versus non AHSCT SSc patients.

The aim of the multi-year, multi-site study of the eHealth implementation intervention, called Chez NICU Home (CNH+), is to address two fundamental barriers to the provision of Family-Centered Care in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) for extremely preterm or small born infants: (1) low-income and families from disadvantaged backgrounds often are unable to enroll in traditional NICU Family-Centered Care Support; (2) the COVID-19 pandemic has necessitated drastic changes in the delivery of neonatal care. The investigators hypothesize that offering parents of infant(s) who are eligible for enrollment in the CNH+ intervention with a choice of home delivery or having their infant transferred to a nearby centre with the use of a Virtual Prenatal Suite (VPS), will increase parental engagement, parent self-efficacy, maternal and infant mental health, and improve parent satisfaction. The investigators will measure impact through the implementation goals: parent uptake, retention of support, and overall caregiver satisfaction of the intervention. At the 1-year follow-up (infant 1 month corrected gestational age), the investigators will measure improvement in infant physical, neurodevelopmental, and mental health outcomes.

The investigators will carry out an integrated implementation science-randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing CNH+ to standard NICU practice through a parallel, multi-centre, mixed-methods, RCT design. This design enables the investigators to assess if the CNH+ intervention can increase enrolment and engagement in parent caregivers of low-income, premature or small for gestational age (fetal growth retardation), infants. The primary goal of the study is to compare the effectiveness of the CNH+ intervention on caregiver outcomes (including engagement in care of the infant at the NICU, parent presence during care and care provision, parent satisfaction, and parent mental health). The secondary goal is to assess the impact of the CNH+ intervention on infant-related outcomes (including infant physical, neurodevelopmental and mental health outcomes). The study will examine the feasibility of the CNH+ intervention, focusing primarily on recruitment and enrolment processes. This will be addressed through preliminary work with the development of an Implementation Committee (IC) and through the measurement of implementation impact.

Osteoporosis causes physical weakness, which significantly reduces the quality of life. Exercise is a non-pharmacological method of increasing muscle mass and physical fitness, reducing the risk of falls and fractures. Studies conducted with this subject in the literature have been conducted in older age groups, but there is a lack of evidence in the postmenopausal period due to hormonal changes occurring in the postmenopausal period. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate the effects of a specific exercise program on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age and quality of life in women at medium-high risk of osteoporosis in the postmenopausal period. Eighty women aged 54-73 at medium-high risk of osteoporosis have been evaluated. The patients were divided into two groups as Experimental: Otago Exercise Program and Control Group. The Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Women (OST) was used to calculate the medium and high risk levels of the patients. Physical fitness parameters were evaluated with the Senior Fitness Test before and after the treatment. According to the results, it was observed that both groups were significantly improved in terms of lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, cardiovascular endurance, agility, and upper extremity flexibility. After the training program, the control group's agility was lower than the experimental group. It was observed that the experimental group's agility increased compared to the control group. Additionally, the functional fitness age and Quality of Life for Osteoporosis Questionnaire (total score) were significantly improved in both groups compared to pre-treatment. In conclusion, it was thought that an individualized exercise program can be applied to the individuals at medium-high risk of osteoporosis due to its significant impact on functional fitness ages and increase in the quality of life, especially in terms of lower extremity strength, upper extremity strength, cardiovascular endurance, agility, and functional fitness age. (Copyright 2019 Huseyin Arikan, Arzum Arikan, Selva Basar)

This proposal is for a randomized controlled trial (RCT) of a digital-based diet quality intervention in adolescents with overweight or obesity. The study aims to determine if using text-based technology to address diet quality in adolescents with overweight or obesity is feasible and can improve diet quality and blood glucose control. Improving diet quality is an essential component for the management of adolescent obesity. However, low levels of diet quality persist, and little is known about how to improve it in a sustainable and scalable way. Few digital-based interventions targeting diet quality have been tested in a population at-risk for obesity, and the use of nutrition recommendations in a clinical setting is time-consuming. One strategy to increase nutrition recommendations is through text messages, and adolescents and young adults are receptive to text-messaging interventions. Therefore, this pilot RCT will evaluate the feasibility of testing a personalized digital-based intervention for diet quality targeting adolescents with overweight and obesity using an iterative multi-stage optimization strategy pilot RCT (MOST-RCT). Using data generated from a series of pilot studies and qualitative studies, we will target five evidence-informed themes to develop a digital-based intervention: a personalized goal, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies. The primary goal of this pilot RCT is to determine if the digital-based diet quality intervention is feasible and acceptable. The secondary goal is to determine if the intervention can improve diet quality and blood glucose control among an adolescent population at risk for overweight and obesity. The study will enroll a convenience sample of 14 adolescents at risk of poor diet quality and have a history of overweight or obesity (aged 14-17 years). Participants will be randomized to either the intervention or control arm. The intervention will consist of 5 evidence-based and feasible themes: 1) personalized goal, 2) meal timing, 3) nutrition skills 4) home food environment, and 5) engagement strategies. The control arm will receive usual care. Data will be collected in two clinical settings and three surveys. In the home setting, continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) data as well as two 24-hour diet recalls will be collected at baseline and follow-up. CGM has been shown to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes and adolescents with type 1 diabetes. In the research setting, one additional 24-hour diet recall will be collected, as in the home setting, and the first void of morning urine will be collected. The outcome related to feasibility will be calculated and compared between groups. All other outcomes will be compared between groups and analyzed as a one-tailed t-test to evaluate changes between groups from baseline to follow-up. A pilot RCT is an excellent way to determine feasibility, improve acceptability and usability, and prepare for larger trials. Findings will assist in tailoring the intervention to adolescents at risk for overweight and obesity and improve intervention acceptability and usability.

The investigators expect to identify the potential factors related to CH post CAS and analyze the relevant characteristic parameters of cerebral blood flow dynamic autoregulation to provide a basis for the early detection and prevention of CH and CHS.This study recruited 400 Carotid Artery Stenosis patients, and all patients received preoperative and postoperative CDU and TCD examination to establish the standard of cerebrovascular reserve. The investigators analyzed the characteristics of cerebrovascular reserve in patients with and without CH after CAS. The researchers also analyzed the incidence of CH post CAS, and investigated the potential factors related to CH post CAS to establish a diagnostic model for the occurrence of CH after CAS. Finally, the incidence of CHS after CAS was analyzed to provide reference for early detection and treatment of CH and CHS in patients after Carotid Artery Stenting. The investigators expect to identify the potential factors related to CH post CAS and analyze the relevant characteristic parameters of cerebral blood flow dynamic autoregulation to provide a basis for the early detection and prevention of CH and CHS.

In the United States, cancer is the second leading cause of death (American Cancer Society 2021). People who are not diagnosed with cancer but instead care for someone diagnosed with cancer (e.g., family and friends helping out with tasks of daily living, transportation, assisting with meals, and keeping the person company during medical appointments) are often called caregivers. The impact of being a caregiver is not trivial. Caregivers often experience a heavy burden from the stress of knowing that at any moment their loved one may face challenges related to their medical condition. Caregivers also have to take on extra roles to help keep their loved one healthy. Despite their efforts, caregivers often struggle to cope with the burden of caregiving. For example, caregivers may experience high levels of psychological distress from anxiety, depression, or other types of distress. Other negative impacts may include physical symptoms (e.g., sleep disturbances and pain) and social impacts (e.g., reduced social participation, loneliness, and social isolation). Caregivers often report feeling that no one understands their burden and find it difficult to balance their caregiver role with their own responsibilities and interests. Thus, it is not surprising that there is a need for supportive interventions that reduce the negative impacts of caregiving.
One type of supportive intervention that has shown promise in reducing the negative impacts of caregiving has been expressive writing (EW). Although there are many different techniques used to help people cope with stress, EW is an option that can be done easily wherever there is a computer or paper, a writing tool, and a little bit of time. It has been recommended for people going through difficult times. In general, EW involves writing about a traumatic event or personal problem on a regular basis. The specific approach to EW has been tested in groups of people that have dealt with physical and mental illnesses such as Cancer and PTSD, and chronic pain. Writing about personal emotions and experiences in a private setting has allowed many people to have improved mental and physical well-being, and feel less alone and isolated.
However, EW has not been tested with cancer caregivers, and research has not explored the different ways that caregivers can benefit from EW. The present project aims to provide a group-based, videoconference-delivered writing intervention for caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer.
Using a randomized wait-list control design, 240 caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer will be recruited over a 12-week period. Participants who are interested in the study will complete two brief video chats to confirm eligibility. Participants will be randomized to one of two study arms; the intervention group will receive the videoconference-based expressive writing intervention. The control group will wait 4 weeks before being entered into the intervention. The intervention itself consists of four video-conference-delivered expressive writing sessions. Each session will last 60 minutes and include: (a) 20 minutes of expressive writing, (b) a 20-minute group-led discussion of the writing content, and (c) a 20-minute debriefing. During the writing sessions, caregivers will be assisted to write about the burden of their caregiving role. This will be done based on the participant's understanding of their stressors and the themes that typically arise when caregivers process their experiences. At the beginning and end of the 4-week intervention, study participants will be asked to complete online surveys that measure changes in emotional well-being, physical well-being, and quality of life.
The overall study aims to: 1) Examine the effects of a group-based video-conference-delivered expressive writing program in improving the emotional, social, and physical well-being of informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer, 2) Identify social and linguistic mechanisms by which participation in the group-based expressive writing intervention leads to improved psychological adjustment. This is important to better understand the processes that create positive outcomes related to self-expression, 3) Test whether certain variables (e.g., age, gender identity, relationship to the patient, and baseline social constraints) moderate the effects of expressive writing in a way such that some people may benefit more or less than others, and 4) Test whether the expressive writing intervention can have a positive impact on the quality of the care provided by caregivers to their loved ones, including improved communication and shared decision-making about medical treatments, symptom management, and overall well-being. By addressing these aims, this project will provide important insights into the use of EW for caregivers, as well as inform future efforts to test the efficacy of expressive writing with

The overarching goal of this study is to investigate the use of IV TXA in Gender Affirming Mastectomy (GAM). The hypothesis of this study is that IV TXA will be effective in reducing blood loss, the risk of postoperative hematomas and seromas, and the time to drain removal. This study will evaluate the primary outcomes of hematomas, seromas, and drain output in patients who undergo GAM with or without IV TXA. The secondary outcomes will include thromboembolic events and surgical site complications. This study will assess the impact of IV TXA on postoperative outcomes in this unique population. The primary outcome are the following: 1) Hematoma: Blood that accumulates outside of blood vessels. The definition of hematoma will be developed for this study and will be assessed through routine physical exam and ultrasound. A hematoma will be defined as a collection of blood outside of the vasculature that requires intervention such as aspiration or surgical drainage. 2) Seroma: Fluid accumulation occurring after surgery. The definition of seroma will be developed for this study and will be assessed through routine physical exam and ultrasound. A seroma will be defined as a collection of fluid that accumulates in the surgical site after mastectomy. 3) Total Patient Drain Output: The volume of drainage will be recorded by patients daily. Drains will be removed per standard practice at our institution which is when they have produced < 30cc/day for at least 3 days. 4) Time to Drain Removal: The time between mastectomy surgery and the time of drain removal. These measures will allow us to evaluate if IV TXA improves postoperative outcome markers. The second outcome measurements will be the incidences of thromboembolic complications and surgical site complications. It is well-documented that IV TXA in total joint arthroplasty reduces the risk of deep vein thrombosis. In this study, the incidence of DVT, DVT and pulmonary embolism, and other thromboembolic events will be recorded through routine patient care. The occurrence of surgical site complications will also be recorded through routine patient care.

Primary insomnia is a common clinical sleep disorder, which seriously affects the physical and mental health of patients and reduces the quality of life. The traditional Chinese medicine treatment is simple and easy to integrate into the modern medical system. However, it has not yet been studied to make clear the effectiveness and mechanism of treatment. The purpose of this clinical study is to determine whether the new auricular point treatment method for auricular acupuncture treatment of primary insomnia can reduce the disease burden of patients with primary insomnia, improve the quality of sleep of patients with primary insomnia, improve the quality of life of patients and relieve the depression and anxiety symptoms of patients. It is also hoped to explore the clinical efficacy and mechanism of the new auricular point treatment method, to provide a reference for the clinical treatment of primary insomnia, and to promote the integration of traditional Chinese medicine and Western medicine in China.

This project seeks to evaluate a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP) (PCAP-1) in preventing the need for foster care and promoting reunification. PCAP is a three-year, intensive case management intervention for pregnant and postpartum individuals who have used substances during their current or most recent pregnancy. PCAP provides mothers with a case manager with whom they meet biweekly, in the home or in other community settings. Case managers coach mothers in setting their own goals and taking steps to achieve them, provide practical assistance, serve as role models, and offer emotional support and encouragement. They connect mothers to community resources and recovery supports tailored to the participant's needs and goals. On average, case managers carry a caseload of 16 mothers/families, receive at least biweekly individual clinical supervision by a master's-level clinician, biweekly group supervision, and individual consultation with their supervisor whenever needed. Case managers work with the mother and the child with prenatal substance exposure and other family members in support of the participant's goals and recovery. The investigators now theorize that the most significant changes happen within the first year, and a one-year program may be a better fit for many clients, especially those who are child welfare-involved. A shorter duration may also serve as an external motivator to clients in completing their goals, as they will know they have a one-year time frame during which they will have assistance, and they will sooner begin anticipating the post-intervention period. A one-year intervention is also indicated under the parameters of the FFPSA as the FFPSA provides matching funds for one year of evidence-based in-home services to child welfare-involved families to prevent the need for foster care. Eye care professionals recommend the use of optical coherence tomography (OCT) scans for assessing the lens position in eyes with cataract and pseudophakia. This test measures the eye shape but requires manual segmentation. Other optical biometers measure the same shape but are faster than OCT. The FDA approved these biometers for measuring the position of the iris, but not for measuring the position of the lens.
This study will establish how well these instruments measure lens position.

Thoracotomy is one of the most morbid procedures associated with moderate to severe pain that persists for several weeks after surgery. Traditional methods of pain management in thoracic surgery are insufficient to satisfy patient's needs. This study will compare the effectiveness of continuous thoracic serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) with epidural analgesia. SAPB is a new peripheral nerve block (PNB) that was introduced recently for treating post-operative pain especially after breast cancer surgery. SAPB is performed under ultrasonographic (US) guidance and provides sensory-only analgesia by injecting local anesthetic solution into a subcutaneous plane between the serratus anterior and the latissimus dorsi muscles at the level between the 3rd and 9th thoracic ribs ,This study aims to compare the continuous Serratus anterior plane block with epidural analgesia in patients with thoracic oncology surgeries to determine if the serratus anterior plane block provides satisfactory analgesia.
Thoracic SAPB is a relatively new regional analgesic technique in which a local anesthetic solution is injected into the interfacial plane between the latissimus dorsi muscle and the serratus anterior muscle via a 22G, 135 mm Tuohy needle under US guidance. The purpose of the current study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAPB compared with thoracic epidural analgesia as a routine pain modality for patients undergoing thoracotomy.
The primary outcomes of this study are to compare the effectiveness and safety of SAPB and thoracic epidural analgesia in patients undergoing lung cancer surgery. The secondary outcomes will assess the effectiveness and safety of SAPB compared with thoracic epidural analgesia in terms of the following outcomes: Intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to the first analgesia requested by the patient, pain scores according to the visual analogue scale (VAS) score, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), patient satisfaction, and the total dose of additional analgesics (fentanyl and morphine) required in the 6 hours after discontinuation of thoracic epidural analgesia or SAPB.
Our study will determine whether patients with thoracotomy surgery can achieve satisfactory analgesic outcomes by using serratus anterior plane block as a pain modality.

The proposed study is a pilot study testing a 2 year randomized controlled trial of the PICU Journal intervention, which aims to enhance parent/caregiver engagement in the PICU by providing participants with a journal to document their child's experiences in the hospital. The study will include 75 parent/caregivers of patients admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt. Data will be collected from multiple time points to assess parent/caregiver perceptions of the intervention, post-intensive care syndrome symptoms, and the feasibility of the intervention. This project addresses a significant gap in the literature and has the potential to improve outcomes for children in intensive care.

In this study, the investigators compare two engagement methods, Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG), to gather input on the facilitators and barriers to accessing therapy for autistic children. The study focuses on Hispanics and Latinos, a growing group of autistic children for whom therapy resources are limited. The investigators' long-term objective is to improve the functional skills and health of Hispanic/Latino autistic children and their families by improving access to an evidence-based intervention called Occupational Therapy/Ayres Sensory Integration (OT/ASI), which is used to improve daily living skills, socialization, and quality of life. Outcomes are evaluated following each step to understand the most effective method of engaging Hispanic/Latino stakeholders. The study results will help improve access to therapy for autistic children, which can help reduce disparities in health outcomes, such as lower school readiness, higher rates of school suspension, and lower rates of employment and independence for Hispanic/Latino autistic children.

Background: While the best method for smoking cessation is to stop smoking completely, it is estimated that less than 8% of smokers quit on their first attempt without the use of assistive methods such as nicotine replacement therapy (NRT). Unfortunately, when NRT fails, some smokers have turned to novel tobacco products to try to quit smoking. While newer "alternative nicotine" products are often used in an attempt to quit smoking completely, a growing body of literature suggests that these products may serve as a less harmful alternative to combustible tobacco when NRT fails. This study will evaluate one alternative nicotine product (e-cigarette) and one oral nicotine product (pouch) compared to remaining on NRT, in adults who do not quit tobacco smoking with NRT alone.
Sites and Design: Study centers will be located at the University of Medicine & Dentistry of New Jersey, the University of California at San Francisco, the University of Southern California, the University of Buffalo, the University of California at Davis, and the University of Kansas. This will be a randomized clinical trial with subjects randomized in a 1:1:1:1 ratio to one of the arms. It will compare 4 different arms of treatment. There will be 4 treatment groups: 1) Group A: NRT responders that will remain on NRT at their discretion, 2) Group B: NRT Non-responders that will switch from NRT to an oral nicotine product (pouch), 3) Group C: NRT Non-responders that will switch from NRT to an e-cigarette (electronic cigarette), and 4) Group D: NRT Non-responders will remain on NRT.
Participants: Up to 500 participants will be enrolled in the study. Inclusion criteria include regular tobacco smokers who have failed to quit using NRT during the first 4 weeks of the study and report a preference for trying an alternative nicotine product. The first 10 participants will be placed randomly into the groups. After the first 10 subjects, subjects will be assigned to a group based on non-inferiority margins for abstinence. It is anticipated that 220 subjects will serve as the NRT responders, 100 subjects will serve as the NRT non-responder controls, 100 subjects will serve as the oral nicotine product group, and 80 subjects (NRT non-responders) will serve as the e-cigarette group.
Intervention/Treatment: The study involves a 5 week transition from NRT to one of the alternative nicotine products. Study products include: 1) NRT products, 2) an oral nicotine product (pouch), 3) Electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) and the corresponding control groups.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the flipped classroom model in nursing education. This research will be conducted via an innovative method named Flipped Classroom Model, and the effect on student success in the process of learning fundamental principles about asepsis will be revealed. The study will be conducted with 3rd year nursing students participating in the course called Infection Control. Students' video records will be obtained and they will be divided into 4 groups as a result of the K-means Clustering Method at the end of the video. Based on these groups, there will be a single experimental and single control group. Videos containing the principles of asepsis will be presented to the experimental group students 2 weeks before the infection control course (11/11/2023). Normal lesson and practice periods will begin between (11/11/2023-12/12/2023) and the education will last 4 weeks in total. There will be no video records in the control group and the course content will be conveyed only during the normal course. The effect of the flipped classroom model in nursing education will be evaluated by comparing knowledge acquisition and learning skill scores before and after the course, as well as re-evaluating these scores 2 weeks later.

This is a prospective study to quantify Epitel's™ Remote EEG Monitoring System's (REMI™) ability to record electroencephalography (EEG) of seizure events in an ambulatory setting for extended periods. Patients presenting with questionable seizure characterization that are scheduling a conventional at home ambulatory EEG (Amb EEG) and who meet the study inclusion and exclusion criteria will be prescribed a REMI system. Patients may be prescribed the device for up to 14 - 28 days. The purpose of this study is to demonstrate that the REMI system is able to record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify ictal events over extended periods, and that extended clinical EEG data is valuable in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure related symptoms. Patients with epilepsy or suspected seizure disorder who meet the inclusion criteria are included. The device is CE marked and approved for commercial use in Japan.

<|assistant|> Hypertension (HT) is a public health problem that involves more than a third of the population worldwide. The main objective of the study is to analyse and compare the effect of a MCT programme versus a CVT programme on BP levels in adult hypertensive subjects. The study will consist of a controlled, randomised, longitudinal and prospective clinical trial, with several simultaneous study branches. These branches will involve exercise control, exercise continuity and exercise change (MCT vs. CVT). Hypertensive patients (n = 180) with different risk factors involved in HT, regardless of the antihypertensive medications and treatments they may receive, will be included in the intervention programme. The MCT will consist of two daily training sessions, EMC (15 minutes) and CEV (15 minutes), for 12 weeks (3 months), divided into two weekly training units; the first will be applied in a gym and the second in an educational sports hall. Within EMC a total of 10 exercises will be applied, with 6 focusing on strength training, using 2 free weights and 4 in the machine. On the other hand, the CEV will only be carried out with a treadmill, without load. The intervention will be based on a model of exercise change with an immediate changeover (changeover 0) (MCT vs. CVT) and will last for 12 weeks (3 months), with a frequency of 2 sessions per week and a duration of 60 minutes per session. Throughout the programme, strength testing will be carried out to estimate the 1RM of the bench press and squat, progressing from 50% to 85% 1RM, and cardiovascular testing through a clinical test on a cycle ergometer, increasing the intensity every 4 weeks between 50% and 89% VO2peak. Background: Many Appalachians die more frequently and at younger ages from obesity-related conditions than those living elsewhere. High prevalence of overweight, obesity, and extreme obesity in Appalachian children increases the severity of diabetes. In rural Appalachia, the diabetes mortality rate is 11% higher than the national rate. The purpose of this research project is to test the effects of the Mentored Planning to be Active (MPBA)+F intervention on physical activity and health outcomes among rural Appalachian 7th grade children suffering from overweight and obesity. The MPBA program has previously been successful in reducing BMI in overweight to obese 7th grade children in a 2-year trial.
In rural Appalachia, high blood glucose levels and diabetes are growing concerns as rural populations suffer from the highest rates of overweight, obesity, and associated conditions (Kaiser Family Foundation, 2020). In rural Appalachia, the death rate from diabetes is 11% higher than the national average (CDC, 2015). Overweight and obesity in youth places children at risk of becoming obese adults. Adult obesity is a risk factor for chronic diseases, including: type 2 diabetes, hypertension and cardiovascular disease (CDC, 2017). Adolescent obesity is associated with numerous medical problems, such as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, asthma, and sleep apnea (Kumanyika, et al., 2005; Wylie-Rosett, et al., 2007). The physical health problems of these rural Appalachian children places a high burden on tax payer-funded medical care for a chronic disease that is largely preventable.
Recent research has shown that physical inactivity contributes to 20% of all-cause mortality (Sallis et al., 2013) and that obesity exerts a far more powerful influence on premature death than does smoking (Lakka et al., 2002). The U.S. Healthy People, 2020 initiative has set a national goal of making regular physical activity more culturally accepted, more accessible, and more conveniently available to a person of any age, gender, or health status.
The study is a community-based randomized controlled trial which aims: 1) To test the effects of the Mentored Planning to be Active + Family (MPBA+F) intervention on physical activity and health outcomes among rural Appalachian 7th grade children suffering from a body mass index (BMI) above the 85th percentile. The 24-month intervention is delivered during the 2021-2022 school year in southeastern Ohio counties, and; 2) To evaluate the process of disseminating the community-wide disseminated intervention through peer mentor recruitment and delivery.

<|assistant|> Background: To evaluate the effects of virtual reality (VR) and ice massage on labor pain, duration of labor and birth satisfaction of primiparous women in the active first stage of labor. Method: This is an obseratonal study applied between April 2019- November 2019 to primiparous women who applied to the gynecology and obstetrics department. The sample of the study consisted of primiparous women whose cervical dilatation was 0-3 cm and who gave birth vaginally, and who agreed to participate in the study. Primiparous women were randomly divided into three groups: Group 1: Ice massage group, Group 2: Virtual Reality group, Group 3: Labor without intervention group. Pain of primiparous women was measured by Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) I. Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised (BSS-R) were completed immediately after delivery. The data were evaluated using SPSS version of statistical program. In the literature, there are studies that have implemented ice massage during delivery, but in the present study, it was not found to be studied in terms of ice massage. In conclusion, the virtual reality animation to be used in the present study is expected to be effective in reducing the labor pain in the first stage of labor for primiparous women. It is concluded that further studies are needed for the validity of the results and to use it in clinical practice. This is a multi-center (3-5 hospitals in China) observational study, with the duration being 31 months. The study's primary purpose is to describe the epidemiology of CMV disease after the first liver transplantation in children and adults in China.
The investigators will collect and analyse demographic, medical history, clinical data, data relevant to CMV diagnosis and treatment, data and outcomes relevant to post-transplantation, and data related to hospitalisation and CMV infections of transplant recipients during their early postoperative period.
The data of adult and children liver transplant recipients (aged ≤18 years) will be collected and processed uniformly according to the study protocol.
For children patients aged <=18 years, we will evaluate the CMV status 1, 2, 3, 12 and 22 months after liver transplantation. For adults patients, we will evaluate the CMV status 3 and 12 months after liver transplantation, and then every 6 months until 24 months after initial liver transplantation, and then annually until 5 years.
The investigators will review medical records and telephone interviews or outpatient visits to ensure that the data collection of the study can be completed in 2 years.

The application addresses the formidable treatment gap for cognitive rehabilitation of spatial neglect (SN), defined as asymmetric orienting, perception, and responding to left space after right brain stroke, causing functional disability. Despite treatment for spatial neglect, patients remain functionally impaired and the care gap remains huge, with a half-life of 5 years or longer. The Veteran population is especially at risk for SN, with 28% of right brain stroke survivors having severe SN and functional problems associated with this. Spatial neglect contributes to poor functional recovery after stroke, longer lengths of stay in rehabilitation, and increased reliance on others for activities of daily living. Patients with spatial neglect require 3x as much caregiver supervision after returning home, and have increased fall risk and health care encounters compared with similar right brain stroke survivors. A personalized approach to spatial neglect rehabilitation is not available in Veteran-specific systems of care, and a validated biomarker would allow a more personalized approach to spatial neglect care. In 180 patients, the investigators will define and validate biomarkers in blood markers, brain imaging and brain physiology, along with behavior, predictive of spatial neglect type. The investigators will determine if adding behavioral predictors (such as fatigue and impulsivity), to biomarker predictors (such as brain imaging biomarkers) accounts for additional variance in the trajectory of functional recovery. These studies will identify a biological parameter that can be used to routinely identify patients with right brain stroke who are the best candidates for spatial neglect rehabilitation. Armed with a validated biomarker-based algorithm, the investigators can then carry out a large clinical trial of prism adaptation therapy (PAT), to personalize spatial neglect rehabilitation, eliminate clinician uncertainty, reduce reliance on specialized SN assessment, facilitate Veteran-centric care, and improve stroke care efficiency.
This project is significant to a large cross-section of healthcare providers and patients because spatial neglect occurs in 1 in 5 right brain stroke survivors, and the investigators have previously found that the PAT treatment is the only treatment that reliably reduces the symptoms of spatial neglect. Spatial neglect may last for years and causes patients to have difficulty carrying out their daily self-care activities independently, including bathing, dressing or using stairs. Spatial neglect also disrupts family functioning, and contributes to healthcare use among stroke survivors.
Because the investigators discovered that people with SN related to damage in parietal brain regions respond best to PAT, the investigators will identify biomarkers predictive of whether PAT improves their functional independence. The goal of the investigators' research is to determine if biomarkers that predict functional improvement are associated with the specific parietal region implicated in their studies of spatial neglect, and whether these biomarkers will improve the prediction of PAT treatment response. The investigators also expect these clinical findings to expand the scope of application of the investigators' biomarkers to other brain diseases that involve parietal lesions, including Alzheimer disease.
The investigators will recruit 30 stroke survivors without spatial neglect, 15 stroke survivors with the subtype of spatial neglect that does not respond to PAT, 110 stroke survivors with the subtype of spatial neglect that responds well to PAT, 30 stroke survivors who have recovered from spatial neglect, 30 healthy people who have never had a brain disease but might be at risk for stroke and develop spatial neglect due to predisposition to develop parietal damage, and 30 healthy controls that have never had a brain disease or spatial neglect. Brain imaging biomarkers predictive of aiding spatial neglect in response to PAT will be examined in the participants' first fMRI testing.
The investigators' study is significant to the field of stroke neurorehabilitation because it will determine if a biological parameter can be used to assign right brain stroke survivors to treatment with PAT. Identifying brain biomarkers that can be used by clinicians will change the paradigm for spatial neglect care, allowing for early referral to intensive treatment, reduction in reliance on specialized SN assessment, and reduction in clinician uncertainty about SN diagnosis and appropriateness of PAT. Armed with a validated biomarker-based algorithm to personalize spatial neglect rehabilitation, the investigators can then carry out a large clinical trial to test the efficacy of prism adaptation therapy (and other treatments) for Veterans with spatial neglect after right brain stroke.
