Gliomas are a complex group of tumors with no curative treatment. Their diagnosis is currently made by conventional clinical studies based either on the presence of contrast-enhancing abnormalities on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
However, these brain lesions can simulate the appearance of other types of lesions as brain lymphoma or a large number of inflammatory lesions, making the diagnosis difficult. Currently, biopsy of the surgically removed tumor is the only reliable option to confirm the diagnosis, but this is not always possible due to: an increased risk for patients with tumors located in specific eloquent regions (including the brain stem) or involving large volumes of functional cortex.
Liquid biopsy, which detects and quantifies circulating DNA (ctDNA) fragments of tumor cells, opens up an alternative option to obtain tissue samples and avoid the risks involved in the conventional biopsies.
This technique was developed in liquid tumors (lung, prostate or ovary cancer) and has been proven to be more sensitive than conventional methods in detecting tumor cells and/or circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) even 2 years after treatment.
ctDNA can be detected by different genotyping methods, including real-time PCR and next-generation sequencing (NGS). The ddPCR technique is the most used worldwide due to its precision, sensitivity and cost.
ctDNA detection, compared to the conventional diagnosis that involves biopsies, has as an advantage a higher sampling, thus increasing the number of potential cells for analysis, as well as a higher level of sensitivity in diagnosing the underlying tumor and its possible evolution. As a result, the diagnosis achieved would be more accurate and provide real-time information, being essential for the prognosis and therapeutic decision making.
The main aim of the study is to analyze the blood samples obtained from those patients with brain lesions in the resonance images compatible with a glioma-type tumor, to detect and quantify the circulating DNA of tumor cells on it. The circulating free DNA will be extracted from 5 ml of whole blood drawn of the patient. The ctDNAs will be analyzed in the department of pathological anatomy using ddPCR, which allows the quantification of the tumor ctDNA at the molecular level if present.
It is important to note that the study focuses on a homogeneous sample of patients with a previous diagnosis of glioma, and who are hospitalized for surgery.
The investigative team, in view of the potential importance of their results, are committed to completing this prospective, observational study within one year of the first blood draw.

Background: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is one of the most rapidly lethal solid tumors, and surgical resection is the only potentially curative intervention. However, less than one-third of resections can be accomplished, and surgical resection alone does not provide an adequate overall cure rate due to locally advanced (LA) or borderline resectable (BPR) disease. Currently, systemic therapy is not recommended as a standard of care before surgical resection in either setting because of relatively poor response rates to chemotherapy and high systemic toxicity. Zimberelimab, a humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits the expression of cluster of differentiation 73 (CD73) using the WBC-14 platform, has demonstrated tolerability and has shown promising anti-tumor activity in patients with solid tumors. Furthermore, in a human xenograft model of pancreatic cancer, zimberelimab has induced a significant increase in cytotoxic T lymphocyte (CTL) activation by targeting CD73 to allow antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) to occur. The use of quemliclustat, an oral cyclin dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK-4/6) inhibitor, as a monotherapy did not result in an increase in CTL activity. In combination with oxaliplatin and either irinotecan or 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), CDK-4 blockade resulted in increased CD8+ T cell activation, decreased regulatory T cell numbers and increased CD73 expression, while also modulating the tumor microenvironment (TME) and increasing PD-1 expression. Based on these findings, the investigators propose that combining quemliclustat, an oral CDK-4/6 inhibitor, with the anti-T cell-co-stimulatory ligand CD73 inhibitor, zimberelimab, and anti-tumor therapy, will induce more specific CTL activations that will improve the TME to result in better treatment results in patients with locally advanced or borderline resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Objectives: 1) Demonstrate the safety, tolerability and the number of patients with adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) of zimberelimab when administered in combination with quemliclustat, and modified FOLFIRINOX (mFFX) chemotherapy in patients with locally advanced (LA) or borderline resectable pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 2) Demonstrate objective response rate to combination treatment with zimberelimab, quemliclustat and mFFX in patients with LA or BPR pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 3) Demonstrate the percent increase in absolute number of tumor-infiltrating CD8+ T cells/tumor size and the percent reduction in absolute number of tumor infiltrating regulatory T cells (Treg) after at least 6 weeks of combination treatment with zimberelimab, quemliclustat and mFFX in patients with LA or BPR pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 4) Demonstrate the effect of combination treatment with zimberelimab, quemliclustat and mFFX on CD73 expression in tumor tissues after 6 weeks of treatment in patients with LA or BPR pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 5) Demonstrate the change in PD-L1 immunostaining and PD-1 expression after at least 6 weeks of combination treatment with zimberelimab, quemliclustat and mFFX in patients with LA or BPR pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 6) Assess the concordance of pathology reported by the study pathologist with the pathology reported by the Clinical Laboratories Improvement Amendments (CLIA)-certified pathology laboratory in the same patient in patients who are subsequently assessed by resection for BPR or for tumor down-staging following LA pancreatic carcinoma. 7) Assess the concordance of pathology reported by the study pathologist with the pathology at an independent reference laboratory for patients who are subsequently assessed by resection for BPR or for tumor down-staging following LA pancreatic carcinoma.

The purpose of this study was to determine whether the consumption of 1 g MIYAIRI 588(Nisshin Bio Sciences Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) daily for 3 months reduced depression scores in maintenance hemodialysis (HD) patients and improves risk factors of cardiovascular disease (CVD). Also, it explored the correlation between depression score, inflammatory factors, and CVD risk factors in the whole study population. This study was conducted in the form a randomized 3 months open, controlled study. A total of 106 subjects who were diagnosed with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and maintained HD more than 3 months were recruited. These were randomly divided into two groups: the intervention group and the control group (1:1). After baseline assessment, the intervention group was given MIYAIRI 588 (each package contains 1g per meal), while the control group was given a placebo. The primary outcome, the change of depression score, was evaluated with Beck Depression Inventory score (Chinese version 2.0). The serum inflammatory markers, endothelial activation markers, and biomarker of bone and mineral metabolism, were quantified by ELISA or chemiluminescence techniques. BMI was calculated as the weight in BW divided by the height in meter squared. All subjects were followed up for three months after baseline. The result demonstrated that the consumption of 1 g MIYAIRI 588 for three months significantly decreased serum C-reactive protein level (5.65±0.94mg/dlvs 2.71±0.42mg/dl，P<0.001), E-selectin (10.37±0.54 ng/mlvs 57.49±2.20pg/ml，P<0.001), interleukin-6 (11.19±0.56pg/mlvs 48.37±1.89pg/ml，P<0.001), TNF-α (23.91±0.74ng/mlvs 11.59±1.0ng/ml，P<0.001)，and decreased depression score (15.56±0.57vs 10.23±0.43，P<0.001). The consumption of 1 g MIYAIRI 588 for three months could improve depression score (r=-0.30, p<0.001)，decrease serum C-reactive protein Level (r=-0.39, p<0.001)，E-selectin levels (r=-0.29, p<0.001), increase serum high-density lipoprotein level (r=0.21, p<0.001)，and decrease serum TNF-α level (r=-0.19, p<0.001). Additionally, there was a negative correlation between depression score and high-density lipoprotein level (r=-010, p<0.05), but a positive correspondence between depression score and triglyceride level (r=0.09，p<0.05). The result suggest that the consumption of 1 g MIYAIRI 588 daily for 3 months is an effective way to improve risk factors of CVD and depression score in maintenance HD patients. Since previous studies have shown significant differences of inflammatory response in depressed patients with CVD, further study should be explored to confirm the intervention effects on depressed HD patients with specific outcomes.

The Effect of Probiotics on Depression Syndrome and Risk Factors of Cardiovascular Disease in Hemodialysis Patients

The purpose of this project is to develop CM-PST (PST integrated with CM) and test its feasibility and acceptability in college-going young adults with mild-moderate AUD over a 9-month period. We hypothesize that CM-PST will (i) result in high acceptability and feasibility, (ii) significantly reduce alcohol-related negative consequences assessed by Rutgers Alcohol Problem Index (RAPI; average RAPI score decreasing from 25 at baseline (range = 8-45) to 17 on average at 6-month follow-up), and (iii) significantly reduce alcohol use assessed by total number of drinks (15 drinks on average per week on weekdays, 43 drinks on average per week on weekends at baseline, 10 drinks on average per week on weekdays, 22 drinks on average per week on weekends at 6-month follow-up). Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either CM-PST or CM in the R00 phase. Eligibility is based on AUDIT and AUDADIS scores, plus completion of written informed consent, and baseline screening study visit including a medical history/physical exam, urine alcohol screening, and fMRI. The study design takes into account the following considerations: (i) the high demand for college-based CM treatment, (ii) the need to assess the feasibility and acceptability of adding PST to CM, and (iii) CM-PST will likely be most effective for individuals with lower AUD severity, but it is difficult to detect a difference between less severe alcohol users and moderate-to-severe AUD. After K99 funding, we will move forward with the R00 Phase, which will help us address the following research questions. We will also continue to seek funding for additional projects such as a pilot efficacy study (R21) and a larger 2-arm RCT (R34).

Inclusion Criteria: Eligible participants must be (i) male and female young adults aged 18-24 yr with current alcohol use at 1 day/week via phone screening), and meet criteria for (past year) mild, moderate, or severe AUD on the AUDIT and AUDADIS surveys. (ii) English-speaking, (iii) able to provide informed consent, and (iv) willing to comply with screening/baseline and follow up assessments and urine drug and alcohol screens, and receive CM-PST or CM treatments. Exclusion criteria include: (i) current severe AUD, (ii) past 6-mo. participation in AUD or substance use treatment, (iii) current use of medications used to treat AUD (e.g. naltrexone), and (iv) lifetime DSM-5 diagnosis of schizophrenia or other psychotic disorder, current use of psychoactive drugs, or conditions that could interfere with fMRI indices of reward. Eligible participants will be invited to our clinical lab at University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) for informed consent, baseline self-report measures, and fMRI/screening, and then randomized to either CM-PST treatment group (42 participants) or CM only control group (42 participants) for up to 8 sessions of treatment. All participants will complete follow-up assessments at 3 and 6 months from their baseline visit, with blinded outcome assessors.

The purpose of the study is to compare the efficacy of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, pembrolizumab) versus a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab). Participants will have metastatic or unresectable locally advanced BRAF V600E/K-mutant melanoma, which progressed during or after prior treatment in the adjuvant or first-line metastatic setting, with an approved anti-PD-1 monotherapy (pembrolizumab or nivolumab), Approximately 150 participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to the triplet or the doublet/control therapy (75 participants in each arm). Randomization will be stratified by baseline serum LDH level, and by type of PD-1 resistance. The study is an open-label study of the investigational drug (ENCORAFENIB) and/or binimetinib.
Study Type
=================
Interventional

Phase
-----------------
Phase 2

Criteria
=================
Inclusion Criteria: Male or female participants ≥18 years of age at the time of informed consent. Histologically confirmed unresectable (Stage IIIB, IIIC, or IIID) or metastatic (Stage IV) cutaneous melanoma, according to the AJCC 8th edition. Documented evidence of a BRAF V600E or V600K mutation. Submission of adequate tumor tissue for central laboratory testing of BRAF V600E-mutation and biomarkers is required for all participants during the screening period and prior to randomization. Must have received only 1 prior line of systemic therapy for melanoma (either adjuvant therapy or first-line anti-PD-1 monotherapy (ie, nivolumab or pembrolizumab) Must have anti-PD-1 resistant disease (primary or secondary) with confirmed disease progression per RECIST v1.1 either during or after receipt of an approved anti-PD-1 monotherapy (ie, nivolumab or pembrolizumab) for melanoma, defined according to the SITC Immunotherapy Resistance Taskforce (Kluger et al, 2020). Have at least one measurable lesion per RECIST v1.1. ECOG PS of 0-1, and adequate organ and cardiac function, including LVEF ≥50% by cardiac imaging. Exclusion Criteria: Mucosal or ocular melanoma. Diagnosis of immunodeficiency or an active autoimmune disease that required systemic treatment with chronic systemic steroid therapy or any other form of immunosuppressive therapy within the past 2 years. Clinically significant cardiovascular diseases. History of thromboembolic or cerebrovascular events ≤12 weeks prior to randomization. History or current evidence of RVO or current risk factors for RVO. Concurrent neuromuscular disorder that is associated with the potential of elevated CK. Active bacterial, fungal, or viral infection requiring systemic therapeutic treatment within 2 weeks prior to randomization. Current non-infectious pneumonitis/interstitial lung disease or history of noninfectious pneumonitis/interstitial lung disease requiring steroids. Prior or current symptomatic brain metastasis, leptomeningeal disease or other active CNS metastases. Participants who permanently discontinued prior anti-PD-1 therapy due to toxicity or will be unable to tolerate combination therapy based on investigator judgement are excluded. Prior or current treatment with ipilimumab; prior combined immunotherapy blockade with anti-PD-1/L-1; prior treatment with a BRAFi and/or MEKi; or previous administration of an investigational anti-cancer agent for the adjuvant or first-line treatment of melanoma prior to randomization.

The aim of the study is to examine the effects of two different simulation application methods (high fidelity simulation and high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation application) on the simulation learning experience, reflective thinking skills for problem solving, and therapeutic communication skills of second-year nursing students in terms of their nursing care and health education skills on patients with diabetes mellitus. The effect of these methods on students in terms of self-knowledge, problem solving and communication will be examined. To this end, students who meet the inclusion criteria and have volunteered to participate in the research will be approached. Face-to-face information will be given to the participants who will be included in the research. The students will be randomly divided into two groups (experimental and control groups) according to the block randomization method with a control group (Experimental: High fidelity simulation, Other: Virtual reality, N=38) and a high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation application group (Control: High fidelity simulation, Other: High fidelity and virtual reality, N=38). After being informed, they will be asked to fill out the Personal Information Form, the simulation-based learning evaluation scale, the reflective thinking skill scale for problem solving, and the therapeutic communication skills scale for nursing students in order to complete the PRE-TESTS. Following the completion of the Pretests, participants will be assigned to one of two groups, Group-1 (high fidelity simulation application) or Group-2 (high fidelity and virtual reality-based simulation application), according to the block randomization method to be carried out in a computerized environment. Evaluation of Data The data obtained from the research will be evaluated by transferring it to IBM SPSS (Statistical Packages for the Social Sciences) Statistics 23 program. Descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, median, minimum, maximum) will be used for continuous variables and frequency distribution will be used for categorical variables. Differences between categorical variables were evaluated using Chi-square test and Fisher Exact test, numerical variables were evaluated using Chi-square test and Fisher Exact test. The relationships between them will be evaluated with Spearman Correlation Analysis. The suitability of the data for normal distribution will be evaluated with the Shapiro Wilk normality test and Q-Q graphs. Accordingly, if the parametric test assumptions are met, the Significance Test of the Difference Between Two Means is used to compare independent group differences; When parametric test assumptions cannot be met, the Mann-Whitney U test will be used. In dependent group comparisons, if parametric test assumptions are met, Repeated Measures Variance Analysis and Significance Test of the Difference Between Two Spouses; When parametric test assumptions are not met, Friedman Test and Wilcoxon Paired Two Sample Test will be used. In all analyses, a p value of ≤0.05 will be considered statistically significant.

During hemodialysis (HD), the blood of the patient passes an extracorporeal circuit that contains a dialyzer for rinsing and a venous chamber (air trap) to prevent from air embolism through the return blood into the patient. However, air traps in clinical use have limited capacity to prevent from microemboli of air to enter the return bloodline and deposit as emboli in the body such as lungs, heart and brain. The Investigator developed the air trap Emboless that was patented in Europe, USA and India. In vitro studies showed significantly better reduction of microemboli contaminations than air traps compared to that in clinical use. The present clinical trial (cross-over design (as pairs), 2 x 30 min, two different air traps used by the same patients) compares two different air traps used by the same patients in a cross-over design (as pairs) using the Emboless compared with the Fresenius 4008/5008 (F5008). The safety committee will evaluate if sufficiently less air emboli appear especially with the Emboless. During HD the microbubbles will be counted by a GAMPT ultrasound device using two probes. One probe is set at the inlet side of the air trap and the second at the outlet side. The outlet side represents data of microbubbles in the blood that is entering into the patient. Comparative non-parametric paired analyses are performed between the air traps. Monitoring of the study is performed.

The aim of this study is to use a novel non-invasive brain stimulation intervention using Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) to improve postural control and injury risk biomechanics following athletic trauma (e.g., Mild Traumatic Brain Injury). The researchers will investigate the influence of brain stimulation on postural control by manipulating two cognitive tasks during the task: performing Serial 7s or keeping attention on the task. The researchers will also manipulate the repetitive TMS conditions (sham, experimental) by applying the magnetic stimulation to the left side of the head in the presence of an interfering cognitive task (serial subtraction). By combining the effects of repetitive TMS and cognitive tasks on postural control, this study will provide an innovative approach to injury risk reduction and prevention.

Laparoscopic pancreatic duodenectomy (LPD), also known as Whipple procedure, is the operation of choice for resectable pancreatic head cancers. During operation, the pancreatic neck transection, the crucial procedure for LPD, can decrease the chance of pancreatic leakage. The conventional pancreatic neck transection (CPNT) is to transect the pancreatic neck at 1-2mm behind the pancreatic neck root. A recent prospective randomized trial has demonstrated that the extended pancreatic neck transection (EPNT) at ≥5mm beyond the left side of the portal vein is associated with low chance of pancreatic leakage.
The study aims to clarify the outcomes of EPNT and CPNT during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenumectomy. We hypothesize that EPNT can improve postoperative outcomes by the pancreatic neck transection level.

The goal of this study is to investigate the effects of two types of concurrent training (traditional and dance-fitness) with older adults aged 65-75 years. Sixty sedentary and frail individuals will be included in the study. The main hypothesis is that both training programs will be effective in decreasing the fall risk by increasing muscle strength and quality of life in older adults.
In relation to physical activity, older adult have a tendency to be inactive, which places them at risk for morbidity and mortality. Exercise training can reverse the reduced functional capacity associated with physical inactivity or sedentary lifestyle, and a better level of physical capacity may reduce the risk of falls.
Research and training in sports and exercise medicine has shown that older adults are able to take part in various physical activity programs. Several studies suggest that older adults who are sedentary can participate in different exercise programs, including combined training programs in order to increase their physical capacity.
Recently, dance training for older adults has been studied and its benefits have been demonstrated. In addition, it has been shown that the dance practice have positive effects in the cognitive domain in frail and sedentary adults.
This proposal is the first to compare the effects of two types of concurrent training in sedentary and frail older adults. Given the fact that falls and decline in cognitive function are the main problems for sedentary/frail older adults, it is necessary to know which training modality has a greater effect on functional performance and cognition.

The purpose of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of a Virtual Reality-based intervention to prevent delirium in intensive care units (ICU).
Delirium is a common health problem in ICU patients. Around 27-60% of ICU patients are diagnosed with delirium. The ICU environment and treatments make patients vulnerable to developing delirium.
Patients with delirium are also at increased risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety, and depression. They also tend to have prolonged length of hospital stay, poor functional outcomes, and higher mortality.
Therefore, it is important to find a way to prevent delirium. Sensory stimulation with music and videos in ICU patients has been found to reduce delirium incidence and improve patient outcomes. However, these interventions can be cumbersome for the staff and often require the same stimulation repeatedly. Also, patients may have some preferences in the types of stimuli they like.
Virtual Reality (VR) is an innovative and popular technology that may improve patient engagement with sensory stimulation. This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of 14 days of VR-based sensory stimulation in preventing delirium in ICU patients.
Participants will be screened for eligibility and randomized to either the VR-based intervention group or the usual care group. Patients in the intervention group will receive the VR-based sensory stimulation. Patients in the usual care group will receive routine clinical care. Patients in both groups will be followed up for 6 months to assess the long-term effects of this intervention.
This study will assess the effectiveness of this intervention in preventing delirium and evaluate its impact on patient outcomes and quality of life. The study will also examine whether the intervention reduces the risk for developing PTSD, anxiety, and depression in ICU patients.

Introduction: Stress is an adaptive response to a physical, psychological or social stimulus. Stress exposure can impact the immediate, short-term and long-term functioning of the body. The physiological stress response is typically measured objectively via neuro-endocrine (i.e., saliva cortisol) and cardiovascular stress markers. The aim of this study is to compare the physiological stress responses elicited by three different laboratory stress tests (MMST, TSST and control): In a population of healthy participants:
Examine the psychobiological responses to a) the MMST (a computer based psychological stress test), b) a traditional TSST protocol (consisting of a simulated speech task in front of a panel consisting of two observers), and c) a Control test (a 60 second quiet rest period).
The primary hypothesis is that: i) The MMST and TSST induce acute physiological stress responses, whereby stressors elicit the release of saliva cortisol and heart rate acceleration; ii) The psychobiological responses will be independent of the specific laboratory stress test conditions. 
Design: A sample of 60, healthy, physically active recreationally active male and female adults aged between 18-35 years with varying levels of trait anxiety (low STAI-trait scores <40 or high STAI-trait scores ≥40) will be recruited and invited to the Biological and Exercise Sciences Building at the University of Sydney Camperdown to complete a short physical test, before taking part in the experimental session.
The experimental session will occur between 10 AM to 3 PM. Participants will complete a questionnaire related to their menstrual cycle (females only), their daily food, drink and exercise levels, and anxiety levels.
Participants will then complete a control test (a period of quiet resting), followed by either the MMST or the TSST. The TSST or MMST protocols will be randomised in a cross over design within the limits of 48hrs. Each participant will complete 1 of the 2 tests on day 1, and then the alternate test the following day (i.e., Day 2), on average 24 to 72 hours respectively. Participants will first complete a baseline test (5 minutes pre-stress test), before completing a stress test of either the MMST or the TSST. For the MMST or the TSST, participants will be asked to perform the computerized laboratory stress tests while lying comfortably on a bed in a quiet laboratory room, and will have a small camera placed at the foot of the bed, and a chest strap to measure heart rate. During the MMST or the TSST, participants will be exposed to standardised acoustic and visual stressors over a 20-minute period. Following the completion of the TSST or MMST protocol the participant will be asked to perform the same baseline test (5 minutes pre-stress) under the control conditions (lying on the bed without stressors). Following, the participant will be asked to lie down on the bed for a 110 minute period to assess any post-stress test outcomes.
Saliva samples will be collected by asking participants to swallow, and when comfortable to salivate into a small sample container. A member of staff will stand next to the participant to ensure compliance and monitor any swallowing or production errors. For the MMST, saliva samples will be collected before (5 minutes pre), during each 5 min test period (pre, 5 min 1, 5 min 2, 5min 3, peak post) and post-test (10 minutes post-test, 40 minutes post-test, 100 minutes post-test). For the TSST, saliva samples will be collected pre-test (5 minutes pre), during each 5 minute test period (pre, 5 min 1, 5 min 2, peak post) and post-test (10 minutes post-test, 40 minutes post-test, 100 minutes post-test). Saliva samples will be collected using a Salivette device which has a 2ml saliva sample collection.
All collected saliva will be immediately stored in 2ml cryotubes and stored at -20°C until analysis, in the Biological and Exercise Sciences laboratory at the University of Sydney. Saliva samples will be analysed for free cortisol using ELISA, as well as for alph-amylase concentration.
Measures: The primary outcome will be to assess the impact of laboratory stress tests on saliva cortis

Aim 1: To examine the effectiveness of VR plus standard medical therapy in reducing the experience of pain in patients 6 to 21 years with sickle cell VOC who present to the emergency department (ED), compared to historical standard medical care alone.
Aim 2: To examine the effectiveness of VR plus standard medical therapy in reducing hospital admission rates for patients 6 to 21 years with sickle cell VOC who present to the ED, compared to historical standard medical therapy alone.
Participants with sickle cell VOC will be invited to trial during their emergency department visit and will be randomized to either receive VR along with standard medical care, or standard medical care alone. The primary hypothesis is that patients who receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy will report lower pain severity when compared to historical control patients who received standard medical therapy alone. The second hypothesis is that patients who receive VR in addition to standard medical therapy will have a decreased rate of hospital admission compared to historical control patients who received standard medical therapy alone. Secondary hypotheses related to impact of VR on length of stay and time to ED disposition will be examined.

Post-Acute Myocardial Infarction empOwerment and digital ENGAGEment (PREVEN-IAM) is a single-centre, pragmatic, randomised controlled trial in post-Acute Myocardial Infarction patients, that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of web-based empowerment compared to usual care in a 12-month follow up. The preventive intervention will consist of educational, motivational and coaching actions of patients post-AMI through a web-based interaction with the prevention team (a cardiologist, a nutritionist, a psychologist, a clinical research nurse). The intervention will be applied for a year.
Inclusion criteria: 18 years of age and older; STEMI and NSTEMI patients; availability of digital communication devices (smart-phone, tablet or personal computer) and internet access; informed consent.
Exclusion criteria: active malignancies (except for skin tumors other than melanoma) with life expectancy <5 years; absolute clinical indication to undergo hospital rehabilitation cycles; cognitive status undermining digital communication devices use (even after proper training), low understanding of Italian language (either oral or written) by clinician's judgement, patient not foreseeing to undergo cardiology follow-up at the site.
The primary outcome will be efficacy on measurable risk factors at 12 months. Secondary outcomes will be efficacy on lifestyle changes and cardioprotective treatment adherence at 12 and 48 months; efficacy on cardiovascular events at 48 months. All participants will be assessed by the Atherosclerosis Prevention Unit, and the lifestyle questionnaires administered at baseline will be repeated at 12 and 48 months.

The purpose of this study is to examine the effect of toe separation orthosis and dynamic orthosis on the hallux valgus angle and plantar pressure. Foot pressure analysis will be evaluated after the participants use the toe separation orthosis, the dynamic orthosis and after using it for one month. Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a severe psychiatric disorder, and probiotics have been reported to be feasible and effective for the treatment of AUD. This study aimed to address the limitation found in previous studies concerning study type, the quality of the experimental probiotics, the absence of specific control group, sample size, and the lack of data on acceptability and effect size. The study is a three-armed, parallel-group, single-blind, randomized control trial. A total of 120 AUD male volunteers will be recruited from the hospitalized AUD patients admitted to the Hospital of the People's Liberation Army 244 Hospital and XX Hospital in China and assigned into 2 intervention groups and an inert placebo group. All subjects will be given the fecal collection tube and rice paper and be asked to collect their feces before the baseline measurement. The researchers will collect serum samples from all subjects through the procedure used for blood donation. The probiotics or placebo group will undergo daily probiotics or placebo administration for 12 consecutive weeks. The other group is the acceptance and commitment therapy group, where the subject will meet the therapist for one 1-hour session weekly, for a total of eight sessions. The primary clinical endpoints are alcohol consumption, alcohol craving, and the severity of alcohol withdrawal symptoms. The secondary clinical endpoints are depression, anxiety symptoms, ERP in the EEG monitoring, and fecal microbiota analysis, the modulation of the serum immunological parameter including TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-1 beta, and the gut microbiota.

Gambling addiction is a psychiatric disorder characterized by aberrant patterns of gambling behavior, leading to adverse consequences for personal, family, and social life. It remains a major public health concern affecting more than 2% of the adult population worldwide. Despite important progress in developing effective treatments, gambling addiction remains stubbornly resistant to most of the currently available therapeutic strategies. The proposed project aims to address this issue by developing two new therapeutic targets, one based on cognitive dysfunction, another on the overconsumption of alcohol and other drugs. To do this, we will design, in a collaborative effort between research organizations and the gambling industry, novel clinical trials in a large population of gamblers with a variety of comorbidities. These studies will test, in a first step, whether existing cognitive or addictive treatments can be used to enhance the treatment outcomes of gamblers. In a second step, our team will test the efficacy of innovative treatment strategies, including cognitive-behavioral therapy for gambling addiction, interventions targeting alcohol and other substance use, and brain stimulation techniques such as repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS).
The clinical studies proposed here will be built on a novel theoretical model of gambling addiction, which combines the concepts of impulsivity, addiction, and reward processing dysfunction, as well as individual differences in social motivations that are likely to affect relapse. This theoretical framework proposes a radical re-conceptualization of the neurobiological model of gambling addiction, and can be summarized as follows: the excessive gambling behavior of gamblers is caused by (1) deficits in reward processing, which lead to (2) deficits in impulse control. These deficits interact with (3) socially mediated risk factors, such as social expectations and peer modeling, which are likely to explain why gambling addiction is more prevalent in some sub-populations of gamblers. By combining the concepts of impulsivity, addiction, and deficits in reward processing, this model can shed light on the complex and heterogeneous nature of gambling addiction.

Trial is currently recruiting subjects.

Obesity is a widely spread and rapidly developing disease with increasing incidence worldwide. Adequate weight reduction in the adult population cannot be achieved with dietary and drug measures.
The most effective method is bariatric surgery, which is performed by laparoscopic technique with a low mortality rate.
As different methods are used in different centers, it is therefore necessary to make a standardized approach to obtain the best possible result.

Currently, the investigator team is working on a new imaging system for bariatric operations and has already used several methods (2D vision with HD quality and 3D imaging). These systems are currently not the standard for bariatric surgery in Germany. In addition, they have no clear advantage for the surgeon compared to the 2D, HD laparoscopic visualization system currently standard in Laparoendoscopic surgery in Germany.

It was therefore decided to carry out this controlled prospective randomized trial to objectively assess the advantages and disadvantages of each system in a prospective, controlled study in a large patient population. The investigator's clinical experience suggests that the new systems have a similar effectiveness, but offer the surgeon additional possibilities. There is a high degree of subjective acceptance. It is therefore to be expected that due to the advantages of the new imaging systems, more surgeons will use these methods in the future.
In this prospective controlled study, the investigator tests the safety and performance of the new systems in a blinded, randomized and controlled study. All procedures are carried out by the three operators involved in the study. This procedure allows for an optimal comparison of the new methods with the standard procedure. The results of this study are expected to improve the quality and safety of bariatric care.

<|assistant|> The aim of this study was to investigate whether exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) is present following exercise in patient after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and if so, if it changes with exercise intensity. Patients were randomized into two groups. Sixty-five patients were enrolled in this study, however the mean age of patients were 57,4±6,4 years and their BMI 31,4±4,2 kg/m2. Exclusion criteria were: Medically stable patients who used glucocorticoids or strong analgesic drugs, Patients with medial collateral ligament insufficiency, patients had severe contracture and loss of range of motion, patients were diagnosed with chronic pain condition. An exercise program was applied to patient groups to see if EIH appeared. Before exercise the baseline values were determined. Pain severity was assessed using a visual analogue scale (VAS; scored from 0, no pain, to 100, the worst pain ever) and pressure pain threshold (PPTs) was measured over quadriceps and biceps brachii and muscles immediately before and after exercise. Pain severity decreased in both exercise groups but EIH was not found. Pain of TKA patients increased with exercise intensity which was in parallelism with increasing muscle pain. Pressure pain threshold was not significantly different from the both sides. The EIH phenomenon was not demonstrated in patients following TKA but increased muscle pain was associated with increased pain with exercise intensity. These findings can contribute to the rehabilitation program, but further studies are needed to conclude about EIH phenomenon in post TKA patients. The purpose of this study is to determine the disposition and effects of efavirenz on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and clinical effects of methadone and tizanidine in healthy volunteers. A total of 160 participants aged between 18 to 65 years will be enrolled with at least 52 women in this study. Efavirenz has been marketed for highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) in anti-human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). Efavirenz inhibited the cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP1A2) system which may impact on the disposition of methadone. Methadone is a central nervous system (CNS) depressant used to treat chronic moderate-to-severe pain and addiction to opioids. Tizanidine is an alpha2 delta ligand approved for the treatment of restless leg syndrome (RLS) and for adults with spasticity associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) or with spinal cord injury (SCI). Tizanidine is metabolized by enzyme in the liver of 2B6 catalyzed.

INTRODUCTION:
Sarcopenia is a process that occurs in elderly with low muscle mass or strength. It is a clinical syndrome which related to physical performance and increased fracture risk, hospital stay, and mortality. As a multifactorial problem, it is associated with protein metabolism disorders, hormonal changes, chronic diseases leading to muscle damage, and nutrient deficiency including the micronutrient zinc.
Ophiochepalus striatus is a plant native to Indonesia that contains a protein source called VipAlbumin. VipAlbumin is a protein with rich leucine content, thus it has a high ability to increase muscle mass as a result of protein synthesis. Leucine in VipAlbumin is involved in the regulation of IGF-1 in the body. IGF-1, a growth factor, has an important role in regulating muscle development, repair, and maintenance.
O. Striatus extract (VipAlbumin) is a source of micronutrient zinc. Zinc is involved in the synthesis of proteins and IGF-1. Zinc is also involved in gene expression for muscle development. Recently, studies have revealed that serum inflammatory markers such as IL-6 is associated with muscle mass and physical performance in elderly.
Thus, this study aimed to evaluate the effects of O. Striatus extract on serum IGF-1 and IL-6 levels in elderly patients with sarcopenia. 
RESEARCH DESIGN:
This study is a randomized, controlled, double masked, parallel designed study. A total of 65 elderly patients who suffer from sarcopenia, diagnosed based on AWGS criteria will be recruited in this study. The study will be divided into two groups, intervention and control group, with 34 subjects in each group using parallel assignment. The intervention group will receive dietary supplementation with Ophiochepalus striatus extract, 2x5 grams a day for 14 days. Meanwhile, the control group will receive placebo, 2x5 grams a day for 14 days.
Sociodemographic data will be collected through simple questionnaire, the participants will undergo nutritional and muscle strength evaluation, as well as measure for SARC-F score, to evaluate the severity of sarcopenia. Blood samples will be taken at inclusion and 2 weeks after supplementation, to analyze the serum creatinine, estimated GFR, serum zinc and vitamin B12 levels, as well as IGF-1 and IL-6 levels.
All analysis will be done using SPSS statistics software version 22. Data will be presented as mean score ± standard deviation. The comparison between post test intervention and control groups will be analyzed using Student t test. A p < 0.05 will be considered as statistically significant.

Official Title
-----------------
Effect Of Ophiochepalus striatus Extract On Serum IGF-1 And IL-6 Levels In Elderly Patients With Sarcopenia

Robotic intracorporeal neobladder reconstruction is a valid oncologic approach for the treatment of muscle-invasive bladder carcinoma with a relatively low morbidity. However, it is still burdened by relevant rates of mid-term complications. In the literature, 45% to 72% of patients postoperatively develop complications, with a median incidence of 20% to 50%, mainly of the urological type. Uretero-neobladder anastomosis (UNA) and stented vs stentless configuration could have influence both on the success of neobladder creation and on postoperative complications.

In the context of the robot-assisted radical cystectomy and neobladder reconstruction, UNA represents a critical point for the surgeon. The presence of a long, tension-free anastomosis was shown to be correlated to bladder-emptying issues. In addition, uretero-neobladder anastomosis remains the last step of a long procedure with the potential to induce ureteral tissue damage.

We hypothesize that 2 different steps of the surgical process could influence the outcomes of reconstructive surgery: the technique for neobladder configuration and if the ureteral anastomosis is stented vs stentless.

The novelty of our hypothesis is constituted by the aim to compare the stentless vs stented technique in robot-assisted radical cystectomy with intracorporeal neobladder creation, focusing also on uretero-neobladder anastomosis complications.

Objectives: Describe and compare our experience of stentless Florence Robotic Intracorporeal configuration compared to stented configuration in terms of complication rates and incidence of postoperative complications.

Inclusion Criteria for patients are:
- Patients with diagnosed Bladder Cancer with clinical stage T1-T4N0-N1M0
- Patients who were amenable to radical cystectomy with eligible to orthotopic neobladder reconfiguration, curative intent and FloRIN reconfiguration were included.
- Patients were randomized in two group: Stentless Florence Robotic Intra Corporeal Neobladder configuration and Stented Florence Robotic Intra Corporeal Neobladder configuration.
 
- Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of one or multiple tumor metastases at preoperative staging
- Histopathological confirmation of bladder tumor at the level of prostatic urethra;
- Treatment without curative intent (cT4b, salvage or palliative cystectomies);
- Presence of urethral stricture.

Design:
An observational study will be performed on consecutive patients submitted to robot-assisted radical cystectomy, with or without intracorporeal neobladder reconstruction. Patients are divided into 2 groups: the stentless-florence uretero neobladder group and the stented-florence uretero neobladder group. All patients in both groups underwent the same surgical steps with the exception that in the stentless group the ureteral anastomosis was performed directly while mono J ureteral catheters were employed in case of stent placed in the stented group. Comparison results will be evaluated in terms of complications rate up to 6 months since surgery.

The investigators propose a study to test a new model of continuity of nutrition care across settings with malnourished older adults who are discharged from acute care hospitals.
Malnutrition is a prevalent condition in older adults. Malnutrition adversely affects their physical, social, functional and economic well-being. Malnutrition is also associated with increased risk of death from any cause. Hospital and community meal provision organizations, when working collaboratively, can provide needed nutrition care in the community at low cost. This is particularly important for older adults who are malnourished at discharge from the hospital. This proposed study seeks to examine this new model to determine if a more coordinated approach to nutrition care results in improved food security, improved outcomes for malnutrition and higher referral to meals programs.
Altered food environments, reduced cooking capacity, declining financial resources and declining income may all lead to food insecurity and malnutrition in older adults. Malnourished older adults (60 years and older) 1.5 million each year, with higher rates in specific populations. In the US, malnutrition is more prevalent in older adults in the following population groups: women, individuals with mental health or cognitive impairment, individuals who smoke, individuals with mental health and/or cognitive impairment and individuals with high health care use. Malnourished older individuals can have higher rates of hospital readmission. When older adults enter the hospital, they are typically managed for the medical conditions for which they are admitted. While in the hospital, they receive the appropriate nutrient support, but after discharge, the patient may not have adequate access to the required nutrients needed to maintain their physical well-being, leading to a higher likelihood of adverse outcomes such as re hospitalization, decreased quality of life, increased risk of death from any cause, increased risk of falls, reduced ability to function independently with activities of daily living. Currently, hospital discharge personnel and community meal providers are not required to have nutrition care provider staff to support those who leave the hospital. There is a paucity of research which examines the continuity (or lack thereof) of nutrition care between the hospital and the community. As such, when patients are discharged from the hospital and their nutrition problem has not been addressed, there is no structured mechanism for the continuity of nutrition care to ensure health and wellness post discharge.
The investigators propose that an enhanced continuity of nutrition care for adults 60 years and older discharged from the hospital with malnutrition improves food security, food intake and quality of life. The goal of the investigators is to improve food security, increase access to nutrition care and meals, and improve outcomes for malnourished older adults.

Essential Connections: How Improved Referrals From Hospital to Community Meal Provision Can Impact Malnutrition Outcomes in Older Adults

Exclusion Criteria: Patients are receiving hospice care or care for end stage cancer, Unable to consume meals (e.g., using enteral or parenteral to meet nutrition needs), Do not live within the meal provision organizations catchment.

<|assistant|> Overview ================= This study is to investigate the effects of increased levels of ketone bodies (3-OHB), in particular a ketone-like molecule called 1,3-butanediol (1,3-BK), on cardiovascular hemodynamics in patients with chronic heart failure. It is anticipated that these molecules will lead to improvements in blood flow to the heart as well as to the body, and that there will be effects on blood pressure control, endothelial function, and energy metabolism. The hypothesis is that 1,3-BK will increase cardiac output by up to 1 litre/minute through the stimulation of sympathetic drive to the heart. This change will be independent of any changes in stroke volume or venous return, which will be measured non-invasively using standard cardiovascular measurements. This is an investigator-initiated, randomised, counter-balanced, double-blind, crossover intervention study. The proposed sample number 12 in each study, 4 in each blood pressure category (hypotension, euthyroid and hypertension) will allow significant effects to be shown for a statistically significant difference of the mean outcome variables. Each patient will participate in three separate study sessions (each lasting >1day) 6 weeks apart. Inclusion Criteria: Inclusion criteria include all patients with chronic symptomatic heart failure who had been referred to cardiology clinic for worsening symptoms secondary to LV systolic dysfunction. These patients present across the BP groups and cover the wide spectrum of heart failure symptoms and severity, thus ensuring they are representative of patients seen in out-patient clinic. Exclusion criteria (as below) are necessary to avoid potential confounding effects. Exclusion Criteria: Patients with significant cardiac valve disease, severe stable angina pectoris (Canadian Heart Association [CHA] cardiac functional level II-IV) or severe comorbidity are excluded from the study because these patients would require different management strategies that may confound the interpretation of study results. A more definitive exclusion is diabetes and/or poor glycemic control, as patients with diabetes may require different medical support. Patients with very low cardiac output may be excluded from the study in case they are too unwell to cope with the intervention or suffer side-effects. However, patients in the euthyroid (high-normal BP) group will be offered participation. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of using subpectoral bupivacaine in adolescent females undergoing reduction mammaplasty on pain control outcomes and recovery after surgery.
Reduction mammaplasty is a common surgical procedure performed on patients with excessive breast heaviness or macromastia. The procedure aims to reduce the size of the breast to improve the symmetry of the breast and/or to improve the appearance of sagging breasts. Reduction mammaplasty is typically performed in an outpatient setting under general anesthesia. Many adolescent females who undergo this surgical procedure require narcotics and extended recovery times with delayed return to full activity and school.
The current study is a pilot study performed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of subpectoral bupivacaine as well as the feasibility of conducting a larger multi-center prospective trial. The subpectoral bupivacaine is injected into the fascia below the pectoralis muscles to provide analgesia for up to 48 hours in the immediate post-operative period.
This will allow patients to have decreased pain for the first few days after surgery, which will translate into reduced narcotic use, shorter duration in the post-anesthesia care unit and out of the hospital.
The primary outcome measure will be comparing the difference in post-operative pain score between the two groups of patients who receive either saline or subpectoral bupivacaine.
The overall objective is to determine if the administration of subpectoral bupivacaine provides effective analgesia for up to 48 hours post-operative in this patient population with decreased narcotic use.

Introduction: The most effective way to cope with a chronic problem is to be proactive in adopting new lifestyle habits and routines that will prevent or alleviate the condition.
Purpose: This study will investigate the implementation strategy, in terms of feasibility and the possible benefits, of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program to reduce back pain and improve sleep and quality of life among those with chronic back pain.
Study Design and Methods: The study will be a prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: a t'ai chi and qigong exercise (treatment) group and a waitlist control group. The waitlist control group will simply be a comparison group. The study team will conduct a single-centered, single-blind, parallel design, randomized controlled trial with 300 participants randomly allocated to one of two arms: a waitlist control or a 12-week, twice per week, T'ai Chi and Qigong exercise. Consent for participation in the t'ai chi classes and completion of the baseline and three additional surveys will be included in the Survey. The Informed Consent for participation in the study will be prompted before the start of the initial Survey in Qualtrics. Potential participants of the t'ai chi classes cannot advance to the survey or participate in the t'ai chi program without accepting consent for participation. In the event consent is declined, the survey is prompted to end.
Feasibility Outcomes: We will assess attendance and retention rates among participants throughout the 3-phase of the study: (phase I baseline; phase II 4-weeks after completion of class; phase III 4-weeks later).
Primary Outcomes: We will conduct telephone interviews with a number of participants in the t'ai chi classes who completed all 12 classes. A post-intervention Survey will also be completed by all individuals, with assessments conducted immediately after completion of the 12th class, at 4 weeks post-class, and at 4 weeks post-Study Baseline. The following measures are the primary outcome measures for this study:
1. Change in ODI 3 months after intervention. The Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) is a commonly used outcome measure for individuals with low back pain. The ODI includes 10 questions about pain intensity, personal care, lifting, walking, sitting, standing, sleeping, sex life, social life and traveling, each based upon a 6-item Likert scale. Each section is scored on a 0-5 scale, 5 representing the greatest disability. If a respondent does not answer all 10 questions, then average scores and levels of disability are adjusted to account for skipping. If all 10 questions are answered, then the maximum score possible is 50 (10 x 5). We will measure the change in ODI levels from the pre-survey baseline survey (Phase I) to the post-intervention survey immediately after the completion of the final class.
2. Change in VAS back pain. The visual analog scale (VAS) is a validated, subjective measure of pain that is commonly used in research. The VAS measures pain intensity on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 representing no pain and 10 representing the worst pain imaginable. We will measure change in back and leg pain from Phase I to Phase III.
3. Change in VAS leg pain. The visual analog scale is also used to assess leg pain intensity with a scale of 0 to 10.
4. The SF-36, Short Form Health Survey questionnaire. The SF-36 is a widely used tool for assessing Health-Related Quality of Life. The SF-36 assesses eight scales: (1) Physical functioning, (2) Role limitations due to physical health, (3) Role limitations due to emotional problems, (4) Energy/fatigue, (5) Emotional well-being, (6) Social functioning, (7) Pain, and (8) General health. We will measure change in these eight scales from baseline to follow up.
5. 19-Item Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a self-rated questionnaire which assesses sleep quality and disturbances over a 1-month time interval. Nineteen individual items generate seven component scores: subjective sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, habitual sleep efficiency, sleep disturbances, use of sleeping medication, and daytime dysfunction. We will measure change in these seven component scores from baseline to 4-week and 8-week follow up.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) during the application of direct electrical current (DC) for accelerating the retraction of upper anterior teeth in a randomized controlled clinical trial.
                Patients with class II division 1 malocclusion will be randomized into two groups. Group one, the traditional retraction group, will undergo retraction of upper anterior teeth using 250 g of force per side from NiTi closed coil pre-activated springs, and the force will be monitored using a force gauge at every appointment for 3 months. Group two, the accelerated retraction group, will receive both direct electrical current applied on the upper anterior teeth area by a removable intraoral device containing a small electrical circuit beside the retraction using the same springs system.
                Patients will be informed about a scale from 0 to 100 measured by visual analog scale (VAS) that is used to evaluate the following PROMs: perception of pain, discomfort, burning and swelling in the upper anterior teeth area, chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, satisfaction with orthodontic treatment, ease of the procedure, the possibility of repeating the procedure, and a recommendation of the procedure. PROMs will be evaluated one day before the placement of the mini-implants (T0), at the end of the first, second, and third months of the retraction of the upper anterior teeth (T1, T2, T3). PROMs will also be evaluated at the end of the retraction period after 3 months (T4), and at the end of the fixed appliances treatment (T5).

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) 2019 Turkey Report published, Turkey is among the top ten countries with the highest number of diabetic individuals. In the world, children aged 8-12 years constitute a substantial portion of the diabetic population according to the data of 2019. In a study conducted in Turkey and published in 2016, it was determined that there are approximately 250,000 children under the age of 18 diagnosed with type 1 or type 2 diabetes in Turkey (Tuncer et al., 2016). Type 1 diabetes in children is a chronic disease in which the immune system attacks the pancreatic cells. These cells are responsible for producing insulin. Therefore, children diagnosed with type 1 diabetes have to inject insulin at least 8 times a day. According to the Diabetes Foundation, Type 1 diabetes is diagnosed most frequently between the ages of 5 and 18, with the peak rate of diagnosis between the ages of 6-9 (Diabetes Foundation, 2020). Children cannot continue their normal activities after diagnosis, even during routine check-ups for other health issues. According to the findings of the research conducted in Turkey and published in 2016, children diagnosed with diabetes between the ages of 8-12 can have problems such as depression, anxiety, stress, and eating disorders due to diabetes and its complications (Tuncer et al., 2016). Children are exposed to a variety of social problems because of these problems. Smartphones are the technological devices of our age that are constantly developing and their use is becoming more widespread every day. Smart phones, which make positive contributions to daily life, attract great attention by individuals of all age groups, especially young people. According to Newzoo's report, the number of smartphone users, which was 3.5 billion in 2020, is expected to reach 4.1 billion in 2023. Smartphones, which are preferred by almost everyone for reasons such as being easily portable, providing fast access in transactions, ease of use and sometimes a status indicator, can pose a risk for addiction when used uncontrolled. Smart phone addiction, although not yet clearly defined; It can manifest itself with symptoms such as constantly checking the phone, feeling restless when staying away, withdrawing, mood changes, not being able to control the duration of use, disruption in daily life due to problematic use, constant desire to use and pleasure from use. As in all risky behaviors that threaten public health, the public health nurse provides consultancy services to the society as a requirement of education and consultancy in smart phone addiction and informs the society about the problems that may arise with the trainings it will organize. Based on all this information, the reason for the selection of nursing students in the research universe; To raise awareness among students and contribute to public health, since nursing students are candidates to provide health services to the society, they are role models for the society with their healthy lifestyle behaviors, they interact with individuals from all parts of the society in business life, and there are institutions that provide service on addiction among their work areas. This study, which was planned to determine the effect of Transtheoretic Model and motivational interview-based online intervention program on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels in nursing students who are in the risk group for smartphone addiction, was carried out. The study included 119 nursing students in the risk group for smartphone addiction. Among the participants; 88% were female and 12% were male, 60.8% were first-year students, 27.5% were second-year students, 6% were third-year students and 5.9% were fourth -year students. The groups were randomized through randomization method using a randomization list. The motivational interviewing group, which was trained on smart phone addiction, was provided a motivational interviewing program based on the Transtheoretical Model. The final data of the participants were collected and evaluated before the intervention and at the end of the intervention using the smart phone addiction scale, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and classification of stages of change scale. The scores obtained from the Smartphone Addiction Scale (P = .003), and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (P = .003) were found to be significantly different in the analysis of variance. It was observed that students' smart phone addictions and sleep quality were positively affected by the motivational interviewing program. In this study, it was determined that the motivational interviewing program based on the Transtheoretical Model had a positive effect on the smart phone addiction and sleep quality levels of nursing students in the risk group for smart phone addiction.

<|assistant|> Background: Rosacea is a complex vascular disorder characterized by facial erythema and telangiectasia of uncertain etiology. Treatment options are limited and not always effective. KTP laser is a selective device that reduces erythema. Ivermectin 1% cream reduces the severity of rosacea. This study aims to assess whether the combination of KTP laser and ivermectin 1% cream provides better results compared to laser alone. Methods: This will be a randomized split-face controlled trial. The study sample will consist of 36 patients affected by erythematotelangiectatic rosacea. All patients will be treated on half of the face, using 532 nm KTP laser. The other half of the face will be treated with the combination of KTP laser and ivermectin 1% cream. 8 months of follow-up are planned. Efficacy will be evaluated by clinical tests, in order to assess changes in erythema, telangiectasia, papules, and pustules. Results in terms of tolerability and patient satisfaction will also be considered. Hypothesis: Cerebral metabolic alteration can represent a sign of neurodegenerative disease even in an early stage.
The presence of these modifications could have a diagnostic or prognostic value for neurodegenerative diseases and Head trauma.
For this purpose, the investigators will carry out a retrospective review of the FDG-PET images previously acquired at PET-CT of University Hospital of Modena. From the image of the FDG scan, a diagnostic test based on the evaluation of cerebral metabolic patterns was done.
Moreover, the investigators will carry out a comparison between normal patients and those with neurodegenerative diseases to identify the brain areas of hypo or hyper regional metabolism and to identify the differences between the disease specific metabolic patterns and the typical signs of Head trauma.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a rare, autosomal recessive genetic disease with an estimated incidence of 1 in 900-1000 among UK Caucasians. This disorder is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene that encodes a multifunctional protein that helps maintain balance of salt and water within the body. The most commonly cited symptoms of CF are coughing and sputum production, a build-up of thick mucus, severe breathing problems, salt imbalances, and malnutrition and stunted growth. Although 90% of pwCF in the UK are treated with a combination of enzyme replacement therapy (ERTh) to correct intestinal malabsorption and inhaled medications, including antibiotics (e.g. tobramycin), the life expectancy for people with CF is on average only about 50 years. In addition to pulmonary complications, CF patients are at risk for bone damage, digestive issues, hormone deficiencies, cancer and other health problems. Given the increasing availability of COVID-19 vaccines, it is now paramount that we understand the impact of SARS-CoV-2 infection on pwCF and how they develop protective antibody responses. Despite the importance of these studies, no robust study data are currently available for CF patients with regards to SARS-CoV-2 immunity in the CF population, who may have underlying factors that affect vaccine responses or COVID-19 infection outcomes in populations without CF. It is anticipated that such studies will contribute to the knowledge base in relation to immune responses and potential clinical complications in pwCF post SARS-CoV-2 vaccination. Thus, the investigators aim to conduct the first prospective study to provide comprehensive insights into the magnitude and nature of immune responses to natural COVID-19 infection and COVID-19 vaccines in pwCF. Through the measurement of SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies (SARS-CoV-2 Seroprevalence) and detection of changes in COVID-19 related clinical outcomes such as clinical symptoms, clinical complications and death rate, the investigators will describe the antibody responses following natural infection in pwCF. The study will also assess any differences in antibody responses and clinical COVID-19 outcomes by age, vaccination history and geographic location. Furthermore, the investigators will investigate the proteomic and genetic responses of pwCF, who are SARS-CoV-2 seropositive and seronegative. This will provide valuable information on the complex interplay between the innate, adaptive immune and proteomic responses in pwCF. Ultimately, the data generated by this study will enhance our understanding of the immune responses in pwCF to SARS-CoV-2 infection and vaccination.

The purpose of this study is the evaluation of symptomatic convergence insufficiency in patients with myopia.
All consecutive symptomatic (dizziness, headache, fatigue, eyestrain, reading difficulties, double vision, blur vision and trouble with accommodation) or asymptomatic myopic patients who will be diagnosed by convergence insufficiency will be enrolled. The patients will be screened in the department of Pediatric and adolescent Medicine. If convergence insufficiency is found the patient will be applied to the department of Ophthalmology with symptomatic treatment of optical correction of glasses (monocular distance and near glass) and near training of one eye. The training group received visual training in hospital. And then the quality of life of patients before and after the treatment (optical correction and near visual training) will be evaluated by EuroQol 5D-5L(EQ-5D-5L) and Short Form 6D(SF-6D). And the visual performance of patients will be assessed in terms of accommodation, convergence, sensory and motor functions.
Myopic patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency should be seen in terms of disease severity and quality of life. After the diagnostic evaluations to be made by optometrist, myopic patients will be divided into two groups according to Near Point Convergence (NPC) (NPC<6cm, the patient will be applied to the treatment group and the patients with NPC≥6cm, the patients will be applied to the control group). Control group had not received visual training. Then EQ-5D and SF-6D questionnaires were used to evaluate the quality of life scores of myopic patients before and after the treatment (optical correction and near visual training) of the patients.

Vulvar cancer is a cancer of the vulva, which is a woman's external genitalia. Most vulvar cancers are squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) which tend to stay localized and can be cured. However, the localized tumor of SCC can spread or metastasize to the lymph nodes in the groin (inguinofemoral lymph nodes) which can worsen the prognosis of SCC. An operation to remove the tumor and some lymph nodes in the groin (lymphadenectomy or pelvic lymph node dissection) is the standard way to treat SCC that has spread to the lymph nodes, but it is not always needed for patients' early-stage cancer based on their lymph node mapping. Sentinel lymph node mapping and biopsy (SLN mapping and biopsy) can help identify the sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) that are likely to be involved with the cancer. The SLN mapping and SLN biopsy are usually done during surgery. Patients can have fewer long-term side effects if they do not have surgery on the lymph nodes (lymphadenectomy) because the surgery can cause complications such as lymphedema and leg swelling.
This pilot study will evaluate blue dye and ICG dye methods currently used for SLN mapping and compare the sensitivity and accuracy of these two methods in vulvar cancer. A blue dye (patented commercial blue dye) has been used routinely for over 20 years, while indocyanine green (an FDA-approved drug) used for SLN mapping has been used for other cancers but only for a small number of women with vulvar SCC. We want to study the effectiveness of these two methods.
This study is an observational study and will provide initial results on the use of ICG dye to detect and remove vulvar cancer that may spread to the lymph nodes. By comparing the effectiveness of these two methods, we hope to make it simpler for women with vulvar cancer to have SLN mapping and less unnecessary surgery without compromising staging and oncologic outcomes. This study will also help us understand if ICG dye combined with blue dye can be more accurate, less costly, and more convenient for patients if proven to be effective. This study also involves testing the Spy-Phi handheld camera. By doing this test, we hope to collect data to guide future clinical trials.
This study will only be done to see if the ICG dye combined with blue dye methods are effective. The results from this study will not directly benefit individuals involved in it except for improved knowledge. This study does not offer new or promising benefits to the patients. It only tries to provide a different method for sentinel lymph node mapping. The results from this study might help patients by offering less invasive or surgical options in the future or might change how the procedures for SLN mapping are done in the future.
The study participants include women with early stage vulvar cancer and clinically negative inguinofemoral lymph nodes. Before being enrolled in this study, we will test if an individual has early-stage vulvar cancer that has not spread to the lymph nodes. The purpose of this study is to improve our understanding of ICG dye combined with blue dye. Participants will have a one-time procedure, which will include having a sentinel node biopsy using both blue dye and ICG dyes, possibly during a surgery for treating early stage vulvar cancer. This procedure involves using blue dye and ICG dye as a diagnostic test and a physical exam with a special camera without exposing participants to additional risks.

The aim of the study is to determine the effects of a Lactate and Ketone Body Esther (LaKe ester) on insulin sensitivity and the regulation of eating behavior.
The study will be done as a randomized crossover study with a 4-week feeding of the LaKe ester or a matched isocaloric placebo. The participant will be recruited from the general population with a BMI 30 - 40 kg/m2 and an HbA1c level < 48 mmol/mol. All participants will undergo an initial screening consisting of: medical history, examination of vital signs, physical examination, blood test, ECG.
The primary outcome of the trial will be the change in insulin sensitivity, measured by the hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp. This procedure involves an intravenous infusion of insulin together with a dextrose solution to keep blood glucose constant.
The secondary outcome measures include measurements of body weight, composition and lipid metabolism, gastric emptying rate, cardiac output and function, levels of hunger, satiety, fullness, energy, and desire to eat in response to consumption of the LaKe ester, as well as tests of mood and cognitive function. Additionally, safety endpoints will be measured, such as blood chemistry and clinical tests of kidney function, echocardiography, and blood pressure.
All measurements will be taken before and after the four-week feeding of the product and an additional three times during the feeding of the product (week 1, 2 and 4). Thus, all measurements will be performed a total of four times. The participants will serve as their own control. For each study day, participants will come to the laboratory around 8.00 am when they will, for example, provide a spot urine sample, have a blood draw and undergo a measurement of body weight, composition and fat oxidation.

The aim of this trial is twofold. First, to assess the impacts of personalized lifestyle instructions based on both genetic data and lifestyle data (such as diet or exercise habits) on mental and physical well-being. The World Health Organisation (WHO) Well-being Index is used to assess psychological health and overall well-being. Second, to explore how users perceive both their genetic results and the personalized recommendations they receive. The perception will be captured using questionnaires with a rating system, alongside semi-structured interviews to understand how these pieces of data are being perceived by healthcare staff. The final aim of the trial is to assess whether the benefits seen by participants continue beyond the 3-month mark, which will be determined by a follow-up questionnaire.  A 6-week long trial will be conducted to explore the impact of FitnessGenes' platform, with a follow-up after 3 months. NHS staff will be recruited to partake in the trial. Following consent to partake in the trial, participants will be asked to complete a pre-trial questionnaire which will explore health and wellbeing interests and motivations, alongside taking a baseline measure of mental and physical wellbeing using the 5-item World Health Organisation Well-being Index (WHO-5) which has been clinically validated. Participants will undertake a DNA test provided by FitnessGenes, free of charge. Following consent participants will be asked to spend a week exploring this upgraded information. A feedback questionnaire will be completed, 3 weeks after receiving the results, to assess participant's experiences of the platform and their results. At the 3-month follow-up, after the baseline measures were taken, a final questionnaire will be completed to assess whether the platform has had any long-lasting impacts on participants' health and wellbeing. This will be done using the 5-item World Health Organisation Well-being Index. Participants will also be asked to complete a satisfaction questionnaire, exploring the perceived value of the product. Semi-structured interviews may also be conducted.

It is often difficult to accurately diagnose and treat cases of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, which is an infection where the fungus Aspergillus colonizes in the lungs after reaching the bloodstream during immunodepression. Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is often a highly lethal medical condition - the case-fatality rate may reach 90% in patients with acute leukemia - but its specific signs and symptoms in the body are variable and nonspecific. Therefore, it can be difficult to detect early on. Currently, invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is diagnosed only if a microbiology culture or a specific marker (such as a d-galactomannan serum test) proves an active infection with the pathogen. These diagnostic methods, however, are costly and time-consuming, and thus pose an obstacle in the timely treatment and management of patients with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Other methods, such as CT scans, may show characteristic lung lesions in cases of active aspergillosis, but no characteristic sign can be relied upon to rule out the disease.
