Hip pathology will be responsible for 480,000 arthroplasties in 2012 and 600,000 in 2018 in France. In 25% to 50% of cases after total hip replacement surgery, ilio-psoas complications occur due to the ilio-psoas sheath. These complications are responsible for a delay in physiotherapy, a decrease in patient compliance with physiotherapy and consequently an extension of hospitalization and a high rate of rehabilitation. The objective of this study is to develop an effective and reproducible technique for the performance of psoas tenotomy under ultrasound. This technique could change the practice of hip replacement by avoiding the occurrence of this complication and improving the success of early postoperative rehabilitation. The investigators propose to compare the following 3 groups: Group A: Patients who are having a psoas tenotomy under ultrasound. This new group will include 20 patients in whom the psoas tendon will be tenotomized. The psoas tenotomy in the new surgical technique does not involve cutting tendons of the iliopsoas muscle complex, it consists in cutting its sheath using a hook blade. Group B: Patients randomized to have a psoas tenotomy with a standard surgical technique under general anesthesia (group B +). This group will represent the current standard of care for tenotomies of the iliopsoas tendon. Group C: Patients for whom a psoas tenotomy is not performed (group C +) and are randomly assigned. The study will be carried out immediately after obtaining informed consent from the patient and approval from the competent ethics committee, the Commission de l'Investigation en santé (Nantes and Rennes). It is an investigator-initiated, multicenter, open-label, non-comparative, mono-center, retrospective and prospective study, with a follow-up on the day of surgery, and at 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months and 6 months after surgery, and will involve a total of about 70 patients.

In thoracic surgeries, acute postoperative pain may complicate the perioperative period. In order to increase the quality of life of patients after thoracic surgeries, local anesthetic agents can be used as a basic method for analgesia. In this study, it is aimed to compare the efficacy of three different volumes of 0.25% bupivacaine application in ultrasound-guided thoracic paravertebral blocks in patients undergoing elective thoracotomy. This study will create evidence on the comparison of efficacy and side effects of parvertebral block application in patients with elective thoracotomy. The study group includes 135 patients who will undergo elective thoracotomy surgery. The participants will be randomized into three groups (n = 135; 45 patients each group) as follows: 20 ml local anesthetic group (GA1), 25 ml local anesthetic group (GA2), 30 ml local anesthetic group (GA3); paravertebral block will be applied to the patients in each group with the respective injection volumes. The primary outcomes of the study are pain levels at rest and coughing at 1st, 2nd, 4th, 12th, 24th, and 48th hours after surgery. Secondary outcomes include morphine consumption and side effects during this period.

Background and aims: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by focal or multifocal demyelination, causing both motor and sensory deficits. It is the most common cause of neurological chronic disability in young adults. Fatigue is one of the principal symptom in this disease. Fatigue is prevalent in the MS population and is a significant health problem, negatively impacting activities of daily living, ability to work, social life and quality of life.
                In recent years much has been studied fatigue in multiple sclerosis and have developed a complex neurobiological network that can explain its development but also some of the therapeutic interventions to reduce and treat this problem. It is known that a variety of factors play a role in the etiopathogenesis but, as often happens in complex diseases, there are no precise causes that justify it.
                Several studies have shown that the vibratory treatment of the musculature would favor improvements in the movement control and postural. Moreover, there are some studies demonstrating how the use of vibrations can induce positive effects on the mobility of patients with MS.
                For all these reasons we believe it is essential to study the effects of the vibratory treatment on patients with multiple sclerosis because the therapeutic techniques adopted in rehabilitation, especially for a subject in an earlier phase of the disease, could lead to improvements that would improve their quality of life.
                The purpose of this study is to verify how the use of vibrations can induce positive effects on the mobility and postural control of patients with MS, as well as reduce fatigue.
                The study is an interventional type. The subjects are undergoing to baseline examinations (T0) including 3D gait analysis and a battery of neuropsychological assessments. Subsequently, eligible subjects are undergoing to intensive multidisciplinary training for a total of 5 sessions per week for 4 weeks, with a total of 20 treatment sessions. The experimental group receive additional vibration treatment. At the end of the treatment cycle (T1), the patients will undergo the same evaluation tests as at baseline.
                The Clinical and instrumental exams used for this study (as per normal clinical practice) are: Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS), Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS), Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS), Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Functions (FSMC), Borg scale, Medical Research Council Scale (MRC), 6 minutes walking test, Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life-54 (MSQOL-54), Beck Depression Inventory-II, Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced (COPE).

Transbronchial cryobiopsy is a new technology to obtain lung tissue in patients with chronic lung diseases. Lung trancarpal lung cryobiopsy (TBCB) can obtain more sample tissue in different parts of the lung, helping early identification and early intervention of lung injuries after transplantation, especially the early detection of lung transplantation rejection. The purpose of this study is to verify the diagnostic efficacy of TBCB for lung transplantation complications, and to explore the sample size of TBCB. The study also aims to explore the correlation between the sample size of TBCB and the number of lung samples obtained through transbronchial lung biopsy with biopsy forceps, and to analyze the incidence of complications of TBCB and its influence on the success rate of obtaining lung samples.

Selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) in monochorionic twins can result in a poor prognosis with a substantial risk of intrauterine fetal demise, neonatal morbidity, and impaired neonatal development. Current diagnostic classification based on three different umbilical artery flow patterns is not sufficient; it does not cover a continuum of reduced fetal-placental circulation and does not take into account other ultrasound parameters. Furthermore, predicting fetal deterioration is crucial for an adequate management of sFGR.
An international, prospective, multicenter observation study (TiME-sFGR) has been designed in collaboration with several experts in the field of perinatal medicine. The main goal is to improve the diagnostic- and outcome-management of sFGR by focusing on the predictive power of diagnostic and ultrasound parameters. TiME-sFGR combines state-of-the-art ultrasound modalities, a large patient set, and detailed placental analysis.
TiME-sFGR is a prospective, longitudinal, international observation study on women with monochorionic twin pregnancy (diamniotic/dichorionic) complicated by selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) defined by the absence of fetal thrive for at least two consecutive ultrasound scans prior to 28+0 weeks of gestational age (GA), irrespect of Doppler flows. Women are eligible if they meet the above mentioned inclusion criteria, have signed informed consent, and their partners have signed informed consent as well.
Mothers may have a 5-year follow-up when their children are 2-7 years old. 
Fetuses may have a 3-year follow-up when they are 1, 3, and 5 years old.

Background: Suicide rates have increased for transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) individuals across gender identity. Lack of access to appropriate mental health care contributes to high rates of suicide and self-harm (e.g., NSSI) among TGD youth. We propose that providing TGD adolescents and their caregivers with an interactive educational platform will improve access to information, improve levels of mental health literacy, and facilitate communication between health-seeking TGD youth and their caregivers, reducing mental health distress, NSSI, and suicidal ideation. Methodology: 500 TGD youth and 500 caregivers will be recruited into TransHealthGUIDE (THE GUIDE), an 18-month randomized control trial that assesses the feasibility, acceptability and efficacy of THE GUIDE, a web-based and mobile platform. THE GUIDE is an evidence-informed digital platform that allows youth to access evidence-based content to improve knowledge, skills, and strategies to care for themselves, navigate families and the community, and communicate with health professionals. The intervention is currently in development and informed by a literature review and expert stakeholder focus groups. Data collection, data management, ethical considerations, and an a priori data monitoring plan will be employed to assess feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of THE GUIDE. At each data collection point (baseline and at every 3-month interval), 10% of the sample will be invited to participate in in-depth qualitative interviews to explore key reasons behind successful versus unsuccessful adaptation. This will provide insights for the development of a user guide and the optimization of the intervention for scale.

The researchers will assess changes in levels of alcohol and cannabis use during a 12-week treatment period. Participants in both the alcohol and cannabis groups will have the option of 12 weeks of group psychotherapy and have the option to receive evidence-based medications for addiction. Additionally, they will collect biological specimens (blood and saliva) from participants in this study to better understand the biological processes involved in the development of alcohol and cannabis use disorders. Background: The term contextual effect has been used to reinforce the view that the placebo effect should be understood as an effect related to the therapeutic context, and not restricted to the use of inert treatments. Thus, the placebo effect is inherent to any therapeutic context and also can be used to enhance the effects of treatment with active components. There is evidence of the effectiveness of manipulative therapy in the treatment of chronic low back pain (CLBP), however, for most physical therapy interventions, its effect is small. Thus, strategies to enhance the effects of this therapy, such as through the use of context factors, may contribute to better therapeutic outcomes. The literature describes that positively induced expectations can trigger a placebo effect. There are previous studies that investigated the effect of different speech on SMT in patients with chronic neck pain, but there is no study in CLBP. In addition, no previous study investigated further the perceptions of patients regarding the content and perceptions of the videos. The objective of this study will be to identify the short-term impact of positive, neutral, or negative speech on pain intensity (primary outcome). The secondary outcomes assessed will be the global perceived effect of improvement, patient's expectations regarding spinal manipulative therapy (SMT) intervention, and perception of empathy in the therapeutic encounter in patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP) Methods: it will be a randomized controlled trial with a blinded assessor. It will be investigated the effect of the use of a hidden conditioning procedure and the induction of positive expectations on pain intensity after the administration of a manipulative therapy approach. This is an exploratory randomized clinical trial. The three groups will receive one session of SMT after watching the video proposed for their group. First participants will be assessed for pain intensity, low back pain disability, psychosocial aspects, and expectations related to treatment. Secondly, a researcher not involved in the recruitment of patients will randomly allocate the participants into three different groups (G1- group submitted to positive expectation speech, G2- group submitted to neutral expectation speech, and G3- group submitted to negative expectation speech). After the allocation, the participants will watch a short video (no more than 3 minutes) delivering positive, negative, or neutral messages regarding SMT. And finally, a physiotherapist will administer one session of SMT and participants will be re-assessed to investigate the immediate effect of the videos on the pain intensity, global perceived effect of improvement, and expectations. Ultimately, patients will be submitted to a semi-structured interview in which their perceptions about the videos will be investigated. It will help to understand if the content of the videos actually causes an impact on the expectations of the patients. The main hypothesis of this study is that the group submitted to the positive expectation speech will have a higher hypoalgesic effect, greater perception of improvement, and higher expectations regarding SMT than the other groups immediately post-treatment. Outcomes will be assessed just immediately after one SMT session.

Diabetes is a risk factor for atherosclerotic ischaemic and/or intracranial vascular disease. There is a higher degree of ischaemic stroke in patients with type 2 diabetes. 
Diabetes has been shown to be associated with alterations in the vascular structure and function of the brain via changes in blood-brain barrier permeability, microvascular function and neuroinflammation. Therefore, it is important to identify treatments that may reduce blood-brain barrier permeability and improve micro-vascular function. There is evidence to suggest that improving microvascular function may be associated with a reduction in stroke incidence. The investigators propose to conduct a one-year, randomized, double-blind and placebo-controlled MRI study to investigate the biological basis of the observed stroke reduction with glucagon like peptide 1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 Ra) with two separate groups of T2D patients receiving either GLP-1 Ra or placebo. The primary purpose of this study is to investigate the mechanism through which the new treatment class (GLP-1 Ra) improves intracranial blood flow condition and blood-brain barrier permeability in patients with T2D. The secondary purpose is to examine whether the improved cerebral vascular conditions results in stroke reduction in patients with T2D, and thereby validate the results from our previous clinical trial, which showed that treatment with T2D lowering drugs is associated with significant reduction of ischaemic stroke incidence. The investigators hypothesize that treatment with GLP-1 Ra improves the cerebral micro-vascular function and reduces blood-brain barrier permeability. A reduction in cerebral micro-vascular dysfunction and improvement in cerebral blood flow condition can potentially result in a reduction in cerebral small vessel disease (SVD), thereby reducing the risk of stroke. The investigators will perform imaging with contrast-enhanced MRI to evaluate the effects of the intervention on cerebral blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability and will follow up the subjects for 12 months to evaluate the long-term effects of the intervention on the risk of stroke.

The research question of the study is to compare the outcome of a screw tent pole technique to the standard gold standard of bone augmentation using intraoral bone block. This study aims to assess the amount of bone gain of both techniques over a period of 6 months. The study design is a randomized controlled trial, with two parallel arms: tent pole technique versus autogenous bone block technique. The primary purpose of the study is to examine the bone gain between both techniques, while the secondary purpose is to evaluate the bone quality through core bone biopsy. This study evaluates the screw tent pole method and its ability to provide adequate bone gain, which will ultimately be used for implant placement. By following through with clinical and radiographic success of patients who use the two methods, this study will provide valuable information about whether the screw tent pole technique is a viable alternative to autogenous bone block technique in patients with atrophied anterior maxilla.

This study is a part of a global initiative to establish optimal algorithms for the evaluation if a CD4/CD8+ Interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) is suitable for the monitoring of tuberculosis (TB) treatment in high burden countries. This project of the WHO is called the Evaluation of IGRA as a Component of TB Treatment Monitoring: Global Registry of Cohort and Cross-sectional TB Treatment Studies. This work will be conducted in a cohort of patients with confirmed pulmonary TB (PTB) and at least one negative sputum smear and/or M. tuberculosis culture.
The main specific objective of these studies is to assess if the CD4/CD8+ IGRA response to M. tuberculosis specific antigens improves over time and to what extent the change in IGRA response correlates with culture conversion in the cohort of drug-sensitive PTB patients. In a small number of patients culture conversion will be compared when the IGRA is performed against M. tuberculosis specific antigens in the CMT of the IGRA and against purified M. tuberculosis derived (PPD) antigens.
In a subsequent arm of the study, a limited number of TB patients with at least two negative sputum smear and/or M. tuberculosis culture and good response to treatment will be monitored with the IGRA and culture at different points during the course of treatment.
In this study both healthy and TB patients will complete a brief questionnaire and a blood test will be taken for further analysis. For the purpose of this study, blood will be collected up to four times during a 9 months time period. At a specific time-points all patients will complete a brief questionnaire and blood will be collected. This means that each patient will have the opportunity to contribute to the study over a period between 6 - 9 months.
If you have any questions about the study we would be happy to talk to you about them before you decide to participate.

This study will investigate the variability and reproducibility of brain responses evoked by mechanical and radiofrequency stimuli in healthy human volunteers. For this, EPs will be evoked in six different areas of the body with each stimulus: 100 Hz sinusoids, radiofrequency, mechanical needle stimuli, and pinprick. Subjective responses will be evaluated at each stimulus, and psychophysical questionnaires will be performed. The results are intended to serve as a reference for future applications in the areas of pain, neurophysiology, and biomedical engineering.

In the aftermath of traumatic brain injury (TBI), the brain of the injured patient is susceptible to further damage from future hits. In some patients, this is attributed to an abnormal increase in fluid in the space surrounding the brain (subarachnoid space) with no obvious evidence of damage to blood vessels, known as traumatic meningeal injury (TMI) or meningeal enhancement (TME). This fluid causes a sloshing of the brain, which can damage the blood vessels in the brain and may contribute to prolonged recovery. The current study proposes to measure this fluid using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and a novel device called the MR Elastography (MRE), which measures the motion of the brain relative to the skull. The MRE images can be used to define the biomechanical coupling of the brain and skull (S-BI). Although this has not been previously described in patients with TMI, we predict that there will be a higher degree of motion and lower coupling of bone and brain in TMI patients. Understanding the S-BI could reveal new strategies for treatment and protection of the brain after TBI. In this study, our goal is to use MRE to compare the S-BI in three groups; 25 mild TBI patients with a history of TMI, 25 mild TBI patients without TMI, and 35 healthy volunteers. We anticipate that patients with a history of TMI will have lower S-BI when compared with patients without TMI and healthy controls. Although a small study with only 80 participants, the study requires a 2-year study period to enroll and perform the imaging analyses. However this will allow the study team to explore a new aspect of neuroimaging to develop protective measures that will lead to improved outcomes after TBI.

The primary objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness of a novel program of community pharmacist care and home blood pressure monitoring in improving blood pressure control in women.
The secondary objectives are to assess the feasibility of the program, changes in knowledge, satisfaction and self-efficacy and the impact on health care utilization.
Study participants will be women who have at least one blood pressure reading in the pharmacy at or above 140 mmHg systolic or 90 mmHg diastolic or at or above 130 mmHg systolic if they have diabetes or at or above 120 mmHg diastolic if they have diabetes.
Participants will be recruited from community pharmacies in Ontario, Canada. Approximately 315 women will be enrolled in this randomized controlled trial.
Participants will be randomized to one of two groups: an intervention group, which will receive pharmacist care in conjunction with Home Blood Pressure Monitoring (HBPM) and Usual Care group, which will receive Usual care in addition to HBPM. Both groups will receive the same intervention if they choose to remain in the crossover arm after the initial 6-months.
The intervention group will have a BP assessed at baseline in the pharmacy by the pharmacist and will receive an approved home BP monitor. Participants in this group will measure their BP every 4 weeks for 7 days using the approved home monitor and enter their readings into the data management system. The pharmacist will review readings with the patient and send BP readings to the patients prescribing clinician along with suggestions for changes in antihypertensive therapy. Follow-up with the participant will occur every four weeks to obtain additional BP readings.
Outcome measures will include 24 hours Out Of Range monitoring of systolic BP readings, change in Systolic Blood Pressure between the two groups, BP control, use of medication, changes to antihypertensive therapy, changes to lifestyle factors such as physical activity, diet, weight, blood pressure medication or smoking cessation. A standardized questionnaire will also be provided to participants to assess their satisfaction and self-efficacy concerning their BP control. Data on adverse events and healthcare utilization will be collected throughout the study duration.

Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida
-----------------
Hypertension, Blood Pressure, Women, Home Blood Pressure Monitoring, Community Pharmacist

The purpose of the study is to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and acceptability of Lactulose as compared to 3L-polyethylene glycol (PEG) in patients with inflammatory bowel disease who require bowel preparation for colonoscopy. 
All patients with confirmed IBD or suspected IBD for at least 3 months, aged between 16-75 years and requiring a colonoscopy are invited to participate in our study. The diagnosis of IBD is based on recognized standards, including clinical symptoms, endoscopy, radiology, pathology and surgical history. 
Patients are encouraged to stop any medications that may affect bowel preparation and liver function two weeks before colonoscopy. All medications such as proton pump inhibitor (PPI), aspirin, anti-platelet agents, and anticoagulants are stopped seven days before colonoscopy. Patients will receive lactulose or 3L-PEG one-time through oral in the evening prior to colonoscopy. 
The primary aim of the study is to compare the outcomes of the two groups, including the effective preparation rate, incidence of adverse events, taste score evaluated by patients, effects of bowel preparation drugs on liver function and serum electrolytes. In addition, stool samples, stool culture tests, and fecal calprotectin determination will be performed regularly during the trial visit. 
After having bowel preparation, the taste score evaluated by patients will be assessed using a five-point scale in both groups. All patients must maintain a fasting state for 8 hours after each bowel preparation. 
The incidence of adverse events will be compared within forty-eight hours after each bowel preparation. Stool samples, stool culture test, and fecal calprotectin will be evaluated on the same day. 
Overall the purpose of this study is to test if Lactulose will give a satisfactory bowel preparation when used in patients with inflammatory bowel diseases. Safety, efficacy, and acceptability will be compared with 3L-polyethylene glycol, the current gold standard.

Background: The metabolic syndrome is a medical condition that includes several risk factors, including hypertension, abdominal obesity and diabetes. Metabolic syndrome has become a major public health concern, affecting about 7 million people in Taiwan. As people age, they become at higher risk of chronic diseases such as metabolic syndrome. It was found that sleep quality influences the physical and mental health of the elderly. The purpose of this study is to understand the sleep status and quality of life of the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community and the potential contributing factors, and to explore the effect of aromatherapy on improving the sleep quality and quality of life of the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. Objective: The purpose of this study is to understand the sleep status and quality of life of the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community and the potential contributing factors, and to explore the effect of aromatherapy on improving the sleep quality and quality of life of the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. Methods: This study is a longitudinal study with a prospective randomized control design. A total of 64 elderly people were recruited from 2 community bases in the East District of Hsinchu City. The two bases were determined as the experimental group or the control group by simple randomization. The experimental group received aromatherapy, an intervention using lavender essential oil compound, while the control group received a placebo, sweet almond oil. The research tools include: Basic Demographic Information,  The Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, CPSQI , The World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -Taiwan Version and The World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire -old. Expected results: Older Adults in the experimental group (use aromatherapy) had better sleep and quality of life than those who use placebo.
Participating in this study can be very helpful to understand the sleep status and quality of life in the older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community.

Inadequate soft tissue thickness has a detrimental effect on implant treatment in terms of the loss of implants and the development of inflammation, pain and discomfort, and decreases aesthetic satisfaction of patients. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the aesthetic and clinical effects of the transplanted graft and xenogeneic collagen matrix as a graft of connective tissue on the soft tissue thickness of the alveolar ridge around prosthetic implants. 60 subjects with an implantable defect in the lower jaw were included into prospective randomized controlled study within the Clinical Center for Specialist Medical and Surgical Providers of the East Ural Scientific Center of Russian Academy of Sciences in Oral Surgery and Implantology Department. Subjects were randomly assigned into 2 groups each with n=30. The first group underwent soft tissue augmentation and implant placement using the free connective tissue graft obtained from the maxilla tuberosity area. The second group underwent soft tissue augmentation and implant placement using the xenogeneic collagen matrix Fibro-Gide. Clinical evaluations included the measurement of vestibular soft tissue thickness, the evaluation of pain severity using a visual analogue pain scale, the evaluation of the volume of edema in the early period postoperatively, the assessment of anesthesia quality, the evaluation of complications, and the evaluation of implant survival at 90 and 180 days postoperatively. 31 subjects completed the study protocol in the study group and 31 in the control group. Results of the study indicate that the transplanted graft and xenogeneic collagen matrix provided significant soft tissue thickness gain with a mean value of 1.32 mm and 0.6 mm, respectively. Further, it was established that both methods improved pain reduction, quality of life and implant survival. The authors concluded that both methods are effective for increasing soft tissue thickness around dental implants.

Myofascial pain is one of the important reasons of oral pain. Various methods such as massage, injection of steroids and trigger point injections are commonly used methods in the treatment of myofascial pain. Injection of trigger points by Botulinum toxin is reported in the literature as the most successful method for the treatment of myofascial pain. The aim of this study is to compare the success and duration of ultrasound sonography-guided transcutaneous and intraoral trigger point injections in patients with myofascial pain.
Patients will be included in the study who have definite diagnosis of myofascial. In the study, patients will be monitored for a week to evaluate the pain scores and to exclude other pain causes. Patients with pain scores higher than 7 will be included in the study and the patients will be divided into two groups transcutaneous and intraoral trigger point injection by Botulinum toxin. There will be 40 patients in each group. The pain scores of patients according to McGill Pain Questionnaire and the Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14) scale will be followed during the period up to 8 weeks.

Depression is a leading cause of the global disease burden. The World Health Organization's (WHO) mhGAP interventions advocates the use of brief psychological therapies, such as behavioral activation (BA) or antidepressant medications (ADM) as first-line options for the treatment of moderate to severe depression in primary care settings. But they might not work for all patients. The investigators hypothesize that patients randomized by chance to their optimal intervention will be more likely to remit and recover than patients who are not. This study aims to generate a precision treatment rule (PTR) based on patients' characteristics and to evaluate the effectiveness of optimization via generating a PTR on patients with moderate to severe depression randomized to either HAP (based on BA, a brief psychological therapy) or ADM (fluoxetine). The investigators will assess whether patients randomized by chance to their optimal intervention will have a higher chance of remitting and recovering compared to patients who are not. The investigators will also determine the cost-effectiveness of this approach compared to the existing standard of care that does not take treatment-specific responses into account. The project will be carried out by a team of multidisciplinary investigators from Harvard Medical School and Harvard School of Public Health who will collaborate with colleagues from Harvard University, the University of California, Davis Health System, and the WHO Secretariat for Mental Health and Substance Use. Primary and secondary analysis will be carried using an intention-to-treat approach, with no interim analysis.

Background
Pulmonary hyperinflation with neutrophil and macrophage invasion and T cell depletion are common features of the acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), but it remains to be elucidated whether the T cells in the lungs of patients with ARDS are hyperactivated and/or exhausted, and to which extent this contributes to neutrophil invasion and thus lung tissue destruction. Furthermore, the pulmonary microbiome has shown a reduction in diversity and interactions in ARDS, which may be important for normal T cell function. At present, immune cell-microbiome interactions and their relation to disease severity and progression have not yet been studied in ARDS.

                Our overarching hypothesis is that the composition of the pulmonary microbiome and the immune cell composition and function is altered in ARDS compared to non-COVID-19 ARDS, and these alterations is an essential pathogenic mechanism in the development of pulmonary dysfunction, and that these derangements can be predictive of the severity of lung dysfunction and mortality in the critically ill COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 ARDS patient population.
                We have previously shown that the pulmonary T cell dysfunction can be improved by repletion of T regulatory cells (Tregs), which may be a novel therapeutic approach in patients with ARDS. Furthermore, the pulmonary microbiome and its interaction with the immune cells have recently been implicated in several respiratory and systemic disorders. Thus, the overall aim of the present study (ILLUMINA-1) is to investigate the impact of the pulmonary inflammatory and microbiome composition on immune cell dysfunction and disease severity.

                Overall design
In 20 mechanically ventilated patients with none-to-mild and 20 with moderate-to-severe non-COVID-19 ARDS according to the Berlin definition an endotracheal aspirate (ETA) and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) from separate lung segments will be obtained. Furthermore, an oral and nasal swab and blood samples will be collected. This will be done within 72 hours after intubation, and again after 7-10 days if the patient is still intubated. Patient's electronic health record The following is obtained after inclusion: diagnosis codes and medication (type and dosage, including vasopressors and sedatives), and smoking history (current/previous/never smoker; pack years); admission time; blood pressure, heart rhythm and heart rate, temperature, ventilator settings, supportive care (dialysis, ECMO), blood tests results at admission and on the study days (blood cell counts, coagulation parameters, renal, liver, and electrolyte panel; arterial and mixed venous blood gases); clinical scores at admission and on the study days (SAPS3, APACHE II, SOFA), death within 30 days Blood sampling Arterial blood samples are drawn from the patient's invasive arterial catheter (inserted at ICU admission for clinical purposes: for continuous invasive blood pressure monitoring and repeated arterial blood gas collection) immediately before BALF collection. Bronchoscopy with BALF collection This procedure is performed in a standardized fashion according to current clinical guidelines. Immediately prior to the procedure, an oral swab, nasal swab and an endotracheal aspirate (ETA) are obtained. FIO2 is then increased to 1.0, and the bronchoscopy procedure is performed using a disposable videoscope with an outer diameter of 5.0 mm). Three successive 50-ml aliquots of prewarmed (37°C) isotonic saline are instilled in the medial segment of the right middle lobe, aspirated immediately with low negative suction pressure (< 100 cm H2O), and pooled into a sterile glass container on ice to obtain a BALF specimen. Afterwards a mini-BAL is performed in the upper and lower lobe of the right lung with a single installation of 20 ml isotonic saline in each lobe with immediately aspiration into a sterile container. Lateral abdominal wall defect is very common, and 20% of abdominal wall incisional hernias develop a recurrence of the hernia following repair. However, according to various reports , the rate ranges from 5% to 30%. In a study on incisional hernias in Chinese patients, the recurrence rate was as high as 22%. Patients with incisional hernias have more complications compared with patients without incisional hernias, the quality of life is reduced to the same degree as malignant tumors. Studies have shown that recurrent incisional hernia may be related to changes in pulmonary function before surgery. As chronic inflammation is associated with recurrent hernia and pulmonary dysfunction.
Recurrent incisional hernia requires additional surgical treatment, and after surgery, the patient's pulmonary function is further damaged. Recurrent incisional hernia can occur within 7 days after surgery to a few years. To reduce the rate of recurrence, the investigators believe that improving preoperative pulmonary function is one of the strategies to reduce the recurrence rate of incisional hernia. As patients with recurrent incisional hernia generally have chronic inflammation with pulmonary dysfunction.
However, the investigators focus on whether there is a difference in pulmonary function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia, and hope this difference can find a target for intervention, improve the incisional hernia surgery to reduce the recurrence rate. In this cross-sectional study, the investigators collected the clinical data of primary incisional hernia and recurrent incisional hernia patients who underwent incisional hernia repair during the same period in our hospital, including clinical data, preoperative pulmonary function data, postoperative pulmonary function data, and follow-up data on recurrence; The investigators hope that this study will provide evidence for improving the quality of life of patients, reducing the burden of recurrence, reducing the cost of reoperation, and providing new ideas for the clinical treatment of incisional hernia.

This is a non-interventional study in a single center to evaluate patients presenting with an intermediate and high risk of coronary disease following a calcium score and a PET scan.
The inclusion criteria are: age strictly above 45 and strictly below 80 years old; having provided informed consent; presenting with no coronary history consulting for suspicious chest pain; patient discharged with a diagnosis of unstable angina, stable angina, effort ischemia or coronary stent placement. The exclusion criteria include: patient undergoing pregnancy, breastfeeding or of child bearing age unwilling to use a reliable method of contraception; patients with cognitive disorders; patients with claustrophobia or unwilling to undergo investigations; patient wishing to initiate therapy for coronary primary prevention.
There will be three groups following calcium score determination: group I with no atheromatous plaque; group II (intermediate risk) with calcium score above 0 classifying the patient below the 40th percentile of a similar population; and group III and IV with calcium score classifying the patient equal or above the 40th percentile and less than the 65th percentile and more than 65th percentile, respectively. The calcium score is a simple non-invasive scanner which measures coronary calcifications and estimates the patient's percentile classifying the patient in high and low risk. In addition, 18F-Na PET will be required to identify the plaque(s) prone to change in patients of group III and IV presenting an intermediate and/or high risk profile. 
The investigators will evaluate the number of patients having received the follow-on tests for these intermediate risk patients, number of signs of progression of coronary involvement, and number of persistent symptoms that increase and lead to the implementation of a secondary prevention type treatment. The investigators will also compare the study cohort with an historical local cohort with respect to the number of new tests and/or signs of persistent coronary symptomatology increasing and leading to the implementation of a secondary prevention type treatment. Additionally, the rate of occurrence of these events will be compared. Based on the results obtained, the investigators will evaluate the rate of occurrence of cardiovascular events of interest in the study cohort. This is a prospective study involving 1,618 patients with approximately a 5-year follow up for 90% of subjects.

This research proposal focuses on exploring the relationship between the shape of white matter hyperintensities and neurodegenerative pathology. The investigators will determine if the amount of white matter hyperintensities (WMH) shape in the brain, as assessed by MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging), can provide additional valuable information about the severity of dementia and can predict future risk of cognitive decline. Dementia with cerebral small vessel disease often involves white matter changes on MRI. It is known from autopsy studies that white matter changes are closely related to small vessel lesions in the deep white matter. In the brain, there are many blood vessels that are especially vulnerable to the aging process. These small blood vessels are found in the deep white matter of the brain. If these blood vessels show abnormalities, this is then called cerebral small vessel disease. When this happens, these small vessels lose volume and become wider, resulting in more fluid in the brain (e.g. leaking or leaks), damage to the neighboring white matter and nerve cells. This process is also known as leukoencephalopathy or cerebral small vessel disease. This disease can also lead to dementia with cognitive decline, which can progress very rapidly. The investigators think that a more complex shape of the white matter could possibly be an important feature of the disease. This shape could be visualized with MRI by the investigators and this information can be linked to the degree and speed of cognitive decline over time. The investigators can also analyze the white matter shape for other important features of the disease. In this way, the researchers want to achieve more insight into the cause of the disease by combining clinical data, MRI data and genetic data. The researchers also want to investigate whether certain proteins, for example beta-amyloid and tau, play a different role in different types of white matter hyperintensities that shape will reveal. In order to achieve this, the researchers will perform blood tests for the detection of beta-amyloid and tau, study the genes of the participants and evaluate several biomarkers on MRI. White matter hyperintensities have previously been shown to change independently of general cognitive status. By focusing on both, they hope to be able to identify whether complex or irregular shapes of white matter hyperintensities can better predict the development of cognitive decline.

Esophageal gastric junction adenocarcinoma (EGJA) is a common tumor of the esophagogastric junction (EGJ). With the development of endoscopic technology, endoscopists can obtain a lot of information for the diagnosis of EGJA through endoscopic examination, which is of great significance to the treatment effect of patients. However, the incidence of EGJA diagnosis is still not high, and accurate examination is relatively low. Accurate diagnosis has a great influence on the prognosis of patients. In recent years, the development of artificial intelligence (Artificial Intelligence) technology has gradually attracted attention and is expected to improve the diagnostic accuracy of EGJA. Due to the small amount of clinical data, the performance of endoscopic images is not ideal for training the artificial intelligence (AI) model. 
Therefore, an artificial intelligence detection system based on deep learning technology was established using the large data of the gastric section of the EGJ anatomical site in the database. Through the training of the model, the accuracy of the model in the detection of esophagogastric junction adenocarcinoma is higher than that of endoscopists, which has a high application value for clinical endoscopic diagnosis.
In this study, we will conduct a prospective, randomized study on patients with EGJA admitted to the Department of Gastroenterology of the Second Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University from October 1, 2018 to December 1, 2019. In the case group, EGJA patients underwent endoscopic examination, and endoscopic images were sent to the deep learning diagnostic system for detection. At the same time, the diagnostic results of endoscopists were compared with the diagnostic results of the deep learning diagnostic system, and the sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value and accuracy were evaluated. The investigators also recorded the pathological type, tumor size, invasion depth, differentiation degree, and treatment methods. In the control group, patients without EGJA underwent endoscopic examination or biopsy, and endoscopic images were sent to the deep learning diagnostic system. The investigators also recorded the age, gender, lesion size, location, and diagnosis of the lesion. From the results of this study, the investigators will evaluate the effectiveness and reliability of the deep learning diagnostic system in the detection of EGJA.

Tolerance and acceptability play a crucial role in the utilization of music therapy in palliative care populations. The study investigates differences in acceptance of music therapy live versus versus a recording. The aim of music therapy in palliative care is to facilitate the alleviation of emotional distress. 
The investigators intend to recruit twenty palliative care patients at the University Hospital Zurich. All patients will receive two identical music-therapy sessions, each lasting for 40 minutes, at a weekly interval. The research protocol is separated into two consecutive study arms. During the first study arm, the intervention session will proceed in two consecutive parts: music played by a music therapist live, followed by a musical recording of the same selection played to the patient. In the second study arm, the intervention session will also proceed in two consecutive parts, but in reverse order. Patients will start with a music selection played to them from a recording, followed by music played live. The study arms are randomized in order to ensure that the order of occurrence of the two modes of listening to music is different from patient to patient.

Background: Cataract surgery, especially phacoemulsification, produces greenhouse gas emissions and waste. Alcon Infiniti and Alcon Centurion are among the phaco machines having the smallest carbon footprint of 5.9kg and 10.9kg of carbon emissions for every cataract surgery, respectively. The Aravind Eye Care System (AECS), a charitable and private sector organization with operations in India, has performed 12 million cataract operations at an affordable cost without compromising surgical quality. According to the most recent reports from the American Academy of Ophthalmology, the National Health Service in England, and the CDC in the United States, topical Moxifloxacin is used as intracameral antibiotic prophylaxis. Despite being frequently used, the optimal regimen for intracameral antibiotic prophylaxis remains inconsistent. The Aravind Eye Care System in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, India performed 1.8 million consecutive nonpenetrating cataract operations with no report of toxic anterior segment syndrome or endophthalmitis.
In AECS, endophthalmitis was 0.02% despite the observation that cannulas, irrigation/ aspiration tubing, gowns, surgical gloves, irrigating bottles, as well as topical and intraocular drugs, are normally recycled to cut cost and waste. On the other hand, health care plays a key role in climate change, as well as financial and environmental waste. Furthermore, the recycling of gowns, gloves, and surgical dressings should be addressed, as well as the optimal use of anesthesia, antibiotics, surgical instruments, and other supplies, such as cassettes, cannulas, and tips of the phacoemulsification machines.
Objective: This study sought to examine if reusing gowns, gloves, and other supplies, such as cassettes, cannulas, and tips of the phacoemulsification machines, will increase infection after cataract surgery and increase the financial cost of the operation.
Methods: This prospective randomized clinical trial was conducted in a single eye center in Egypt in 2016. A total of 89 patients undergoing phacoemulsification cataract surgery from January 2016 to August 2016 were randomly divided into two groups, each with 44 cases. The other group had a change in gloves only between cases, and the same gown was used for all cases (22 males, mean age of 62.34 ± 10.2 years). After opening the face drape, a drop of povidone-iodine 5% was also installed in the conjunctival sac and washed thoroughly before starting the operation. Topical Gatifloxacin (Tymer) and Prednisolone (Optipred) drops were instilled four times daily in the first 10 days following the surgery. Hand sterilization of the surgeon and the assistant was done once before starting the first case with povidone-iodine and alcohol. The American Heart Association recommends that children consume no more than 4% of calories from added sugars and less than 10% of calories from added sugars for long-term health. However, little information is available on the effect of reducing intake of added sugars to < 10% of energy on physiological risk in adolescents who are overweight or obese, who are at high risk for developing diabetes. The World Health Organization recommends avoiding the use of low calorie sweeteners in foods, instead they advise eating whole foods and vegetables, and limiting sweetened beverages and foods. In the U.S. in the year 2011, intake of water decreased, and consumption of added sugars in beverages and sugary foods have increased since 1988. Sarc and colleagues found that in adolescents, there is a strong correlation between the high carbohydrate intake that is a major contributor to risk of the adult T2D. Based on the premise that substituting a non-sweetened beverage for sugar sweetened beverages (SSB) will reduce high carbohydrate and energy intake, the current study proposes to demonstrate whether substituting sparkling water for SSB has benefits for in vivo physiological measures of glucose metabolism while maintaining flavor acceptability to adolescents who are at risk for diabetes. The investigators will substitute sparkling water for flavored and sugar-sweetened beverage consumption among overweight/obese adolescents living with diabetes or a family history of diabetes and find whether there is a change in sweet taste perception. Sweetness perception is the perception of sweetness in response to a stimulus in the oral cavity, and previous studies in adults show that taste perception changes when energy consumption declines. T2D in youth occurs with increasing frequency, and the rates of youth-onset diabetes are disproportionately high in overweight and obese adolescents who consume high amounts of added sugars. Replacing SSB with sparkling water could have the added benefit of reducing added sugar intake without increasing caloric intake via artificial sweeteners, and this could be an important strategy to reduce diabetes and cardiovascular risk in adolescents, as well as in adults who have lost their sweet tooth.
The proposed study is a before and after cohort study that is prospective. All enrolled participants will reduce their SSB consumption by > 50% by substituting unsweetened sparkling flavored water. Study participants will complete three visits to the Clinical Research Unit (CRU) at St. Jude. During the third visit, participants will be screened with a 2 hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and continuous glucose monitoring system, and will have measurements of blood pressure, glucose control (Hemoglobin A1c), body composition (dual energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DXA), and cardiac function (Electrocardiogram). In addition, at each visit, the participants will rate the sweetness of beverages using a visual analog scale. Finally, all participants will be asked to bring a list of the sparkling water brands and flavors they have tried to date, and any new beverage tastes they have tried during the last month.

Background: When evaluating the early wound healing after the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick monofilament suture material (Sinogut/NoviGut, Johnson & Johnson, USA) in resective periodontal surgery (RPS) in the presence of monofilament suture material, Monosyn® Quick (Braun, Germany), clinical signs of re-epithelization (CSR), haemostasis (CSH) and inflammation (CSI) in patients with moderate to advanced generalized chronic periodontitis and/or localized aggressive periodontitis (LAP) undergoing resective periodontal surgery was assessed. The aim of this study was to verify if the utilization of NOVOSYN® Quick could result in faster wound healing compared to the already well-known monofilament suture material, Monosyn® Quick.
Methods: a monocentric, randomized, double-blinded clinical trial (RCT) was performed in patients undergoing RPS. 40 participants were enrolled in the study, and randomized in a 1:1 ratio to either NOVOSYN® Quick (control group) or Monosyn® Quick (treatment group). The primary end point to evaluate the primary objective of the study was the determination of the early wound healing score (EHS) according to CSR, CSH and CSI. Data were collected before surgery and 10 ± 5 days post-operatively, and consisted of clinical signs of wound healing and of the assessment of the handling of the suture material. Additionally, bacterial contamination of the thread and the number of systemic complications were both determined 10 ± 5 days post-operatively.
Participants and results : 40 patients underwent RPS (Novosyn: 21 and Monosyn: 19). For Novosyn and Monosyn, the mean age was 43.5 ± 10.0 years and 43.7 ± 12.5 years, respectively. The mean age range for the participants was 30 (lower quartile) to 60 years (upper quartile). The mean EHS for the NOVOSYN® and Monosyn® group were 8.10 and 8.64, respectively. The 95% Confidence Interval (CI) for the mean EHS for the Novosyn® group was 6.92 - 9.28 and for the Monosyn® group 8.07 - 9.20, showing no relevant differences between Novosyn and Monosyn. Additionally, no relevant difference concerning the assessment of systemic complications could be found between the two groups.
No relevant differences were found in terms of the pain assessment and satisfaction of the patient between the two groups.
For the handling of the suture material, only a few differences between the two groups could be observed with regards to 'first throw knot holding', 'knot security', 'knot tie-down smoothness', the overall handling of the suture material and the knots. Intra-operatively, 85.7% of the participants noted that with regards to ease of passage through the tissue, 90.5% of the participants considered the Monosyn® thread to be excellent and 69.2% the Novosyn® thread. 47.6% of the participants found Novosyn® as being more difficult to handle than Monosyn®, and 17 participants considered both suture materials to be equally difficult to handle. A fray to be observed at the ends of the thread, more frequently in the Monosyn® suture.
Conclusion: Within the context of this pilot RCT, no significant differences in terms of wound healing score have been noticed between use of NOVOSYN® Quick and Monosyn® Quick, after resective periodontal surgery. A significantly lower satisfaction of the participant regarding the handling of Monosyn® suture material can be observed as well as a slightly lower degree of fraying observed at the ends of the Monosyn® suture. The results of bacterial colonization of the suture material, the number of systemic complications and assessment of clinical wound healing parameters were also in accordance with the study hypotheses regarding the absence of differences between the two groups.

Sudden deafness is a common otolaryngology disease that seriously affects the hearing rehabilitation effect and social economic development of patients. According to previous studies (Zinevich et al. 2014; Yang Yuan et all. 2016), the pathogenesis of sudden deafness is not clear, and it is closely related to various factors such as blood flow in the inner ear, blood supply to the cochlea, and metabolism and apoptosis of the cochlea.
NAD+ is an important coenzyme to maintain intracellular metabolic balance and mitochondrial aerobic metabolism. Studies have found that it is a crucial neuroprotective factor involved in mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation (Cassidi BJ, Waller GD, Chappell BA. 2006; Mills JY, Rufino E, Liptak G. 2001; Mills JY. 2016; Mills JY, Waller GD, Rufino E. 2014). Due to the special anatomical structure and unique microcirculation mechanism of the inner ear, the lack of efficient vasoactive substances in the inner ear makes the inner ear prone to local ischemia, hypoxia damage, and the decline of oxidative phosphorylation, but there are many studies that found that NAD+ is also involved in local blood supply and oxidative phosphorylation of the inner ear .
When the NAD+ in the inner ear was depleted, the blood supply of the cochlea was decreased (Hsu KL, Chen CC, Chung HC, Chiu WY. 2014). Some researchers believed that this is due to the lack of vasoactive substance and metabolic substance (Yang Yuan et al. 2016; Yin Zhiqiang et al. 2014; Wang Xiaoqin et al. 2016). Therefore, the lack of NAD+ may be one of the mechanisms of sudden deafness.

Sodium NAD+ solution is a new noninvasive drug. According to recent studies, intravenous injection of NAD+ solution can relieve the symptoms of sudden sensorineural hearing loss, increase the blood flow volume of the cochlea, and enhance the phasic and tonic response of the inner ear, which can improve the hearing loss caused by sudden sensorineural hearing loss (Yin Zhiqiang et al. 2015; Yang Yuan et al. 2016). At present, there is no consistent drug intervention protocol in the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss. The current common drug intervention protocol is mainly general treatments, such as: corticosteroids, antiviral drugs, anti-inflammatory drugs, and so on (Tanaka Y, Otsuki T, Nakauchi T. 2005; Kimura S, Chiba T, Uchida T, Shimizu K. 2005; Chang YJ, Lu CC, Shieh ST. 2005; Liu H, Wang D, Xie J, Liu G. 2006; Shu J, Zhang KR, Hou J, Guo ZF. 2013; Zheng CH, Li SH. 2017).

However, there is still a lack of relevant data on the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss. Therefore, this study wants to test the feasibility and effectiveness of NAD+ (0.5mg/ml, 1mL, im) in the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss through a small and randomized sample size clinical trial. The study expects:
1) The treatment group has a better hearing recovery effect than the control group 3 months after treatment, the hearing improvement rate is greater than 5db, and 1 month after treatment, the tinnitus disappearance rate will be significantly higher than that of the control group.
2) The treatment group has a better disappearance of tinnitus than the control group.
3) The treatment group has a higher improvement rate of hearing and tinnitus than the control group 1 month and 3 months after treatment.
4) The treatment group has a higher recovery rate of ear fullness compared with the control group.
5) The application of NAD+ is feasible and has a good safety profile.

Newborn screening (NBS) can detect over 40 diseases that are severe or with the potential to be severe. In addition, there are approximately 40 disorders that, although there is no specific therapy currently available, NBS could prove to have a high positive predictive value. An improved selection of treatable genetic diseases is based on new findings and technological progress. These include the eligibility, i.e., the fact that patients affected by these diseases can be treated at an early stage. Based on an updated NBS guideline, the criteria for eligible diseases will be supplemented and existing criteria will be reviewed and updated. The aim of this new German guideline is to increase the reliability and accuracy of the selected diseases and thus improve the benefit-risk ratio, and subsequently to improve the scientific basis and, if possible, to extend or establish NBS for additional diseases in Germany.

A first pilot project was carried out for NBS on cystinosis. This proved to be feasible. In the population screening, the prevalence of 1:100,000 could be confirmed, and it could be shown that the disease can be diagnosed within a week of birth and immediately treated. It is very important for the affected newborns that they are diagnosed and cysteamine treatment initiated shortly after birth, in order to achieve the best possible disease course. This must be compared with the diagnosis and initiation of therapy when the disease becomes clinically visible, which usually occurs in the 2nd or 3rd year of life. By the end of the last reporting years (2017), there were 22 NBS centers in which genetic NBS was performed, which is sufficient to continue NBS for cystinosis in a routine manner.

In addition, molecular-based NBS is increasingly feasible. DNA can be extracted from a dried blood spot and can be analyzed by NGS (NEXT-Generation Sequencing). The high accuracy of the genetic screening has already been demonstrated in two pilot projects in German NBS laboratories. Both studies also showed the high acceptance of the parents for genetic NBS. In addition to the genetic screening for cystinosis (Molecular based NBS II.1), molecular-based NBS for PH can be established based on the scientific basis of the first pilot project.

Therefore, this further pilot project is intended to lay the scientific basis for introducing a genetic NBS for PH. A further focus is to compare the outcome of the affected children after screening with those diagnosed after manifestation. Based on the results obtained, we intend to continue with the introduction of molecular-based NBS for cystinosis and PH, as well as to establish a further genetic NBS in this pilot project. These diseases, as well as other NBS-suitable diseases, will be included in the German NBS system.

Neoadjuvant therapy provides a window to obtain tissue samples before treatment, during treatment, and after treatment. This study is to compare the immune modulation effects of palbociclib, ribociclib, abemaciclib, all approved CDK4/6 inhibitor, and letrozole on estrogen positive and human epidermal cell growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)- negative early breast cancer.
All eligible patients with early breast cancer are randomly assigned in 1:1:1 ratio to receive palbociclib, ribociclib or abemaciclib combined with letrozole in neoadjuvant therapy. We will collect tumor tissue, blood, and stool samples prospectively before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12 weeks of treatment at the time of surgery. Immune modulation effects will be compared between 3 treatment groups from breast tumor RNAseq analysis.

The ultimate aim of this initiative is to test, on a larger scale, the effectiveness of implementing the intervention in primary care practices that serve people living with dementia (PLWD) and their caregivers, evaluate its impact on persons served (i.e., PLWD) and caregivers, and ultimately improve outcomes of PLWD and caregivers. The investigators have developed the Dementia Care Quality at Home intervention and will examine whether it:
1) is feasible to be implemented by health care practice staff and caregivers,
2) is experienced as acceptable by PLWD and their caregivers, and
3) has a positive effect on caregiver well-being.
The proposed project includes two phases. Phase 1 is the open pilot. It will assess preliminary results of the intervention to determine its feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity in two participating practice sites. Caregivers will be asked to complete questionnaires at baseline and at the end of the study.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the potential of using modern diagnostic techniques to distinguish between different subtypes of breast cancer, known as intrinsic molecular subtypes, and to determine which breast cancer patients benefit most from new targeted therapies. This study takes data from routine clinical practice and applies this in a new, scientific way to explore patterns and relationships in subtypes of breast cancer that may lead to new treatments and better outcome for patients.
Participants in the study will be divided into different subgroups for their specific type of breast cancer, and they will be given either a standard treatment or targeted therapy based on the subtype. Some of the participants will be given standard chemotherapy plus hormone treatment, and some of the participants will be given targeted therapy, a newer treatment that works in different ways, including attacking the tumor through the immune system.
Participants will be asked for a small amount of blood and excess tumor tissue from their operation. The information collected from blood and tissue samples and the outcome of their cancer treatment will be used to build up new knowledge about the best treatments for each subtype of breast cancer.
It is hoped that this study will improve the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer by providing more information about each subtype and helping to match new treatments to women whose cancers have specific genetic features.
Participation in the study will begin at participating hospitals. Participants are contacted by their doctor or at one of the hospitals participating in the study. After the initial consultation meeting, each participant joins a subgroup for their specific breast cancer subtype. This group is determined by the pattern of genetic variations in their cancer cells. This step is called molecular profiling.
Next, if the initial consultation does not uncover specific reasons to change treatment after molecular profiling and discussion, the participant will be randomized to different study arms based on the subtype of their breast cancer.
Depending on which breast cancer subtype the study arm is for, the woman and her doctor will choose a treatment from the group of treatments available for that subgroup. Some of the treatments are standard chemotherapy plus hormone treatment, and others are targeted therapy. The targeted therapy will be given by a vein (through an IV) and is not for people with lung or breathing disorders.
Participants then join the group of specific study arms according to their breast cancer subtype, and they can start the treatment of their choice for their specific breast cancer subtype, including the standard chemotherapy plus hormone treatment or targeted therapy.
When the treatment has finished, the participant again visits one of the hospitals. The patient's clinical notes are reviewed, and she completes another consultation with the doctor. After the end-of-treatment visit, the patient will be followed up periodically by telephone over a five-year period. The purpose is to discuss recurrence of the cancer and new treatments.
The results of the study are expected to improve the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer by providing new information about the different types of breast cancer and the most appropriate treatments for each subtype. The study will investigate many aspects of a tumor's behavior, including how a tumor is likely to respond to therapy. In future, these findings could lead to further improvements in diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer.

The purpose of this prospective double-blinded random controlled study is to compare the effects of the propofol and sevoflurane on the prognosis of primary brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer patients undergoing elective thoracoabdominal surgery to detect the differences in survival between the groups and to determine the mechanisms by which they have different effects. A total of 100 patients undergoing elective thoracoabdominal surgery for the treatment of cancers diagnosed as primary brain cancer, primary brain, primary liver, primary lung, or primary ovarian cancer will be performed. Eligible patients with primary brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer treated within 1 month of surgical treatment will be randomized to undergo either total intravenous anesthesia with propofol or the same dose of sevoflurane inhalation anesthesia intraoperatively. The main endpoint of the study is overall survival, and the secondary endpoint is the presence of disease progression detected by various examinations such as brain CT or abdominal CT, MRI, and chest X-ray, as well as serum tumor markers (CEA, CA-125, CA 19-9) within 30 days after surgery. Furthermore, postoperative complication, hospital days, and 6-month, 1-year, and 3-year Karnofsky performance status (KPS) will be evaluated.

One of the significant issues that hinder the application of VATS and RATS to most early-stage NSCLC patients is the difficulty of recognizing lung nodules located deep in the lung parenchyma and, consequently, not visible on the surface of normal, uninvolved tissue. Several approaches have been developed to enhance the localization of indeterminate lung nodules and decrease the time to diagnosis and rate of conversion to open surgery. Nevertheless, none of these is 100% sensitive or without complications, also of severe grade. Numerous pre-operative methods are being employed, including percutaneous CT-guided placement techniques, encompassing the use of microcoils, hook-wires, and spiral-wires. These devices can support nodule localization during minimally invasive lung procedures; nevertheless, they could be easily displaced during patient transport and positioning, intraoperative atelectasis, single lung ventilation, and surgeon manipulation.

The additional value of pre-emptive antibiotic treatment after pancreatoduodenectomy is undetermined as evidence reported conflicting results regarding infectious complications. Prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis might reduce the rate of surgical site infections in patients with a high risk for contaminated bile (predominantly patients with preoperative biliary drainage). In a multicenter randomized controlled trial, we will compare a strategy with perioperative antibiotic treatment versus a strategy with perioperative antibiotic treatment followed by five postoperative days of antibiotic treatment. Patients at risk for contaminated bile undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy are eligible for this trial. The rate of clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infection between patients with perioperative versus prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis is the primary outcome. This trial will clarify whether prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis after pancreatoduodenectomy is beneficial to patients at risk for contaminated bile.

This is a Phase 2 interventional basket trial targeting patients with advanced solid tumors who have the KRAS G12C mUtation and who have a clear indication for a first-line treatment with anti-cancer therapy according to the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer and the Korean Society of Medical Oncology (IASLC and KSMO). The participants will voluntarily enroll in the KRAUS trial after receiving the diagnosis of advanced malignancy with the KRAS G12C mUtation in a medical institution participating in this clinical trial.
In recent years, the KRAS G12C mMutation has been identified to be closely related to the development of cancer and has been reported as a major independent cause of poor prognosis. In patients with lung cancer and colorectal cancer, drugs targeting the KRAS G12C mMutation are being actively developed and have been reported to be effective in inhibiting tumor growth.
As sotorasib is a novel drug of this class that has a different mechanism from existing EGFR inhibitors and TKIs, it will be possible to predict a therapeutic effect at an early stage of tumor progression. The current study investigates the safety, efficacy, and potential biomarkers, including the mutation status of the KRAS gene in solid tumors that show efficacy after treatment with sotorasib.
In this study, we plan to determine the safety and efficacy using sotorasib as an anti-neoplastic drug for patients with advanced solid tumors who carry the KRAS G12C mUTation.

Purpose of the study The investigators conducted nutritional risk screening for patients with gastrointestinal tumors, gave different nutritional support methods to patients with different nutritional status, and analyzed the changes of various nutritional indexes of patients before and after nutritional intervention.
Methods: Totally 302 consecutive patients with gastrointestinal tumors admitted to First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023 were divided into an intervention group (NRS2002≥3 and PG=SGA≥4, n=204) and a control group (NRS2002 < 3 or PG=SGA < 4 ), n=98) by random assignment. The patients in the intervention group received different nutritional support methods, and the patients in the control group received traditional nutrition support. Nutritional risk screening, dietary supply, anthropometric measurements, grip strength, walking distance, and other indicators were studied. After propensity score matching, different nutritional support methods were given to analyze the changes of nutritional risk screening, grip strength and walking time, dietary energy, dietary protein, nutritional energy, nutritional protein, and other nutritional indexes before and after administration between the two groups and their effects.
Outcomes: This will provide a scientific explanation for individualized nutritional support for patients with gastrointestinal tumors, improve the ability of patients to tolerate resection surgery and postoperative recovery quality, reduce postoperative complications, and minimize the financial burden of patients and their families. The results of the study are of great significance to improve the efficiency of clinical treatment and the overall situation of patients with gastrointestinal tumors.

Non-invasive blood flow monitoring of arteries is typically done with transcranial Doppler (TCD), a device that needs to be inserted into the temporal bone. Due to the insertion, it may be difficult for the patient to participate for an extended period of time. Recently, a new method of monitoring blood flow in the brain has been developed using a conventional method of ultrasound. It requires a small patch worn behind the ear and is called a wearable ultrasound patch. The purpose of this study is to compare the blood flow measurements from this method with a conventional transcranial Doppler device in a group of individuals with a broad range of physiological parameters. If the agreement between the devices is good, this new method may open up a new era of monitoring brain blood flow in people who are unable to participate in TCD studies for extended periods.

Study Overview
=================
The incidence of liver cancer is increasing worldwide. HCC is highly associated with chronic liver disease caused by hepatitis virus infection, metabolic disease and alcohol abuse. Liver transplantation (LT) is the best curative treatment for HCC, but the 5-year cumulated rate of developing new tumors after LT was 24.8%, and the 5-year cumulative rate of overall mortality was 19.0%. In addition, the 5-year recurrence rate of HCC at high risk of recurrence after LT was significantly high, reaching about 50%. Multiple previous retrospective studies have suggested that postoperative adjuvant treatment with regorafenib, sorafenib, lenvatinib or bevacizumab may significantly improve RFS in patients with HCC at high risk of recurrence after LT, which provides some valuable evidences for the survival of patients after LT. However, there are no prospective clinical studies that confirm the efficacy of postoperative adjuvant treatment. As the best curative treatment for HCC, LT has become a research hotspot, but the recurrence rate of HCC after LT is still too high. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of multi-kinase inhibitors in combination with bevacizumab for the treatment of HCC at high risk of recurrence after LT, to provide a high-quality randomized controlled trial for the development of postoperative adjuvant treatment, and to provide reliable evidence for the improved management of postoperative adjuvant treatment.

Inclusion criteria:
1. Age and sex: Age ≥ 18 years, no gender limit.
2. Pathology and criteria for LT: Conform to Milan criteria and meet at least one of the following criteria for liver transplantation after LT, HCC patients included in this study are all patients at high risk for recurrence after LT:
   - Pre-operative imaging or post-operative pathological confirmation of HCC exceeding Milan criteria, with at least one of the following characteristics: a) Pre-operative imaging or post-operative pathological confirmation of the presence of MVI . b) Imaging evidence of vascular invasion or abdominal lymph node metastasis (liver-specific lymph node metastasis, such as the left portal vein, the abdominal inferior vena cava adjacent to the liver, the right diaphragm near the liver, abdominal lymph node metastasis). c) Pre- or intra-operative pathological confirmation of HCC with a tumor size (longitudinal or transverse diameter) ≥ 5cm. d) Pre- or intra-operative pathological confirmation of HCC with 3 or more tumor nodules. e) Intra-operative pathological confirmation of HCC with high incidence of MVI. f) Imaging evidence of tumor extension into the hepatic vein, right and left hepatic arteries, and retrohepatic inferior vena cava of the liver.
3. Other conditions: Patients who have received continuous antiviral therapy post-transplantation (using first-line antiviral drugs such as entecavir, tenofovir, or tenofovir alafenamide).
4. Physical condition: Patients who have not experienced thrombosis or thromboembolic events within the past 6 months, such as stroke and/or transient ischemic attack, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, etc.
5. Adequate hepatic function:
   - Biochemical tests (no use of albumin within 14 days prior to screening): Serum albumin ≥ 28 g/L. Total bilirubin ≤ 2 times ULN. AST and ALT ≤ 5 times ULN. ALP ≤ 5 times ULN. Creatinine ≤ 1.5 times ULN or CrCl > 50 mL/min (calculated using the standard Cockcroft-Gault formula) .
