Study investigators and collaborators of ILBS have reported that decompensated cirrhosis has a deranged coagulation profile as evidenced by deranged prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), fibrinogen and Thrombelastogram (TEG) in such patients. The aim of the study was to study the effect of human albumin on coagulation parameters and other surrogate markers like inflammatory markers, endothelial dysfunction, echocardiography, pulmonary function, renal function in patients presenting with decompensated cirrhosis. It was a prospective single-center randomized placebo-controlled trial, where 53 patients with decompensated cirrhosis were divided into two groups according to randomization. To begin with, serum Albumin level was measured in all patients. The patients in Group A received human albumin infusion, at a rate of 1 g/kg body weight if their serum albumin level was 3.0 g/dl or less to maintain the serum Albumin levels above 3.0 g/dl. The patients in Group B were given conservative treatment, i.e. standard treatment. After randomization, serial investigations like hematocrit, liver function tests, renal functions, ABG, coagulation parameters, fibrinolytic markers, inflammatory markers, echocardiography, pulmonary function test and 2D ECHO were done in both groups. In group-A , Albumin increased from 3.0gm/dl +/- 0.8 to 4 gm/dl +/- 0.94 (mean +/- SD) (P<0.001). It was noted that though clotting time was prolonged in both the groups, but the prolongation was significantly more in the group-B (p=0.04). The same is true for clot formational time (p=0.02), clot maximum (p=0.006) and fibrin generation time (p=0.16). The mean change in clottability as measured by Riet-veld units of alpha value was significantly more in group B ( p=0.03) as well as coagulability as measured by clot formation time and clot maximum. The mean inflammatory markers (ESR,CRP,IL-6 and TNF-alph), Endothelial dysfunction (vWF, ADAMTS-13) were also significantly higher in Group-B as compared to Group-A. Ejection fraction was found to be significantly lower in group A as compared to group B (ejection fraction 69% +/- 6 vs 71% +/- 6). Pulmonary function test showed reduced DLCO in group A as compared to group B. There were no adverse effects of Human albumin infusion in the study.
In conclusion, Human albumin infusion to patients with decompensated cirrhosis improved coagulation profile of the patient. Human albumin infusion also results in lowering of inflammatory markers, improved ejection fraction and higher rate of oxygen delivery to the tissues.

Lung cancer is a common disease in the world, causing the most deaths among malignant tumors. The 2017 World Health Organization cancer research institute data suggest that the occurrence of lung cancer ranks first in men and women. The number of new patients with stage Ⅲ non-small cell lung cancer (stage Ⅲ NSCLC )accounts for about 35% of the total incidence of the disease. Surgery is currently the most effective treatment for stages ⅢA, ⅢB. However, due to the invasion and metastasis of lung cancer, 47% of patients are positive for para-axillary lymph node metastases or mediastinal lymph node metastases in the middle group of stage III, which cannot be removed by surgery, and the total resection rate is only 20%.
Currently, the prognosis and overall survival (OS) of patients with NSCLC in stages ⅢA, ⅢB have significantly improved, but patients with different N stages in stage Ⅲ still have significant differences in prognosis. To explore the risk of lung cancer recurrence after surgery, the research of the clinical target lesion (CTV) volume and the impact of the clinical target lesion (CTV) on the lung cancer recurrence after surgery is the focus of NSCLC research. This clinical study is a prospective multicenter observational study. It is an intra-operative study, in which the lung cancer in the stages ⅢA, ⅢB confirmed by histology or cytology has potential surgical opportunities and has not been identified by driving gene EGFR/ALK mutation, which is carried out for a long time: 2016 - 2019.
Study enrollment and intervention/treatment:
1. Group 1: Group 1 patients were those who underwent complete resection. After complete resection, patients were treated with immunotherapy alone or chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy. It is expected that the total number of patients is 59 in the operation group, and the follow-up duration is at least 2 years. They collected patients' baseline puncture tissues, peripheral blood samples from multiple nodes after new adjuvant treatment, surgery, adjuvant treatment, and follow-up, and carry out for 1021-MRD analysis through tumor-informed personalized monitoring MRD test kit, so as to analyze the patient's recurrence status and the correlation of clinical data, treatment response and patient's prognosis.
2. Group 2: Group 2 patients were those who underwent concurrent radio-chemotherapy. After concurrent radio-chemotherapy, patients were treated with immunotherapy alone or chemotherapy combined with immunotherapy. The expected number of patients is 35, and the follow-up duration is at least 2 years. It is for the analysis of MRD status and correlation of treatment response and prognosis of patients with concurrent radio-chemotherapy.
3. Group 3: The expected number of patients is 39, and the follow-up duration is at least 2 years. It is expected to analyze the MRD status and the correlation of treatment response and prognosis of patients with surgery in stage III NSCLC.
4. Group 4: The expected number of patients is 39, and the follow-up duration is at least 2 years. It is expected to analyze the MRD status and the correlation of treatment response and prognosis of patients with concurrent radio-chemotherapy in stage III NSCLC, and then guide the individualized treatment scheme for the patient through the MRD status and the correlation of treatment response and prognosis.

Axillary hair is a common concern among Brazilian women, and different physical methods are used to remove or decrease its density and quantity. In general, physical techniques of hair removal produce more visible result in the short term and can be costly. Thus, this study aims to compare the effect of intense pulsed light (IPL) versus diode laser therapy on axillary hair, being their effectiveness and safety as a function of the energy delivered on the dark body hair and the color and thickness of the hair in relation to the skin. Fifty patients (volunteers, n= 50; age ranging from 38,6 ± 3,8 to 44,6 ± 4,3 years) will be recruited. Participants are assigned into two groups, IPL or diode laser in parallel for the duration of the study. IPL and diode laser sessions will be 25 minutes and one session per month will be given, totalizing four sessions of IPL and diode laser for each female patient selected for the study. Treatments will be carried out through a four-hour window on an average of forty patients per day, being completed in approximately two months. Assessments will performed at the first procedure (S0), four weeks after the first procedure (S1), four weeks after the third procedure (S3) and approximately six weeks after the last treatment (S4), that is, at the end of the fourth session. Secondarily evaluations will be performed at 24 weeks after the end of therapy (S5). Hair count (%) and hair thickness (µm) obtained through photographs in a 4cm² quadrant in the central axillary region will be evaluated. Evaluation of global aesthetic improvement scale 5% reduction and quality of live will be performed by two independent and blind evaluator. Visual analogue scale of pain will be assessed as self-esteem scale and satisfaction level score.

Ischemic stroke remains a leading cause of death and long-term disability worldwide,1 despite major advancements in reperfusion therapies.2,3 While neuroimaging modalities have expanded patient eligibility for reperfusion therapies by estimating ischemic core and salvageable tissue,4-7 their assessments are mostly single-timed. Currently available clinical algorithms lack the capacity to continuously track the dynamic evolution of how the primary core progresses to a final infarct, which, however, is a major determinant of functional outcome.8-10 Monitoring infarct trajectories could support therapeutic decision-making in patients with large vessel occlusion stroke and unveil determinants of stroke progression, aiding in patient selection for trials evaluating cytoprotection11 and targeting clinically ineffective reperfusion.12 Previously studied blood-based biomarkers such as Neurofilament Light Chain (NfL),13 neuron-specific enolase (NSE),14 glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP),15,16 and S 100 calcium-binding protein B (S100B)17 either failed to capture the extent of brain injury within the acute phase of stroke or lack specificity. Plasma levels of brain-derived tau (BD-tau) were recently found to show high value for monitoring brain injury in patients with acute ischemic stroke: In 502 patients with acute IS, plasma BD-tau was associated with imaging-based metrics of brain injury upon admission, increased within the first 24 hours in correlation with infarct progression, and at 24 hours was superior to final infarct volume in predicting 90-day functional outcome.18 While informing on the relation of BD-tau with imaging-based metrics of brain injury, this large cross-sectional study was restricted to BD-tau assessments upon admission (median time from onset: 4.4 hours) and at day 2 (median time from onset: 22.7 hours) and could not inform on key characteristics of the evolution of plasma BD-tau, including when exactly it starts to rise, how long it continues to rise, and how it is determined by infarct characteristics as well as comorbidities. That knowledge would be of great value to determine the responsiveness of plasma BD-tau to brain injury after onset and to evaluate whether BD-tau plateaus at different time points after onset indicating no further infarct progression. PROMISE-BD-100 will thus assess BD-tau levels every hour from admission to 48 hours from stroke onset in patients that present with the clinical diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke due to a large- or medium-vessel occlusion within 9 hours from symptom onset.

Thyroid nodules are common diseases among patients. Ultrasound is often used to detect thyroid nodules. But there are some limitations, such as the high incidence of thyroid nodules, various manifestations of thyroid nodules, low sensitivity of thyroid ultrasound, poor interobserver agreement in ultrasound features etc, so it is necessary to improve the accuracy of thyroid ultrasound examination.
Imaging Reporting and Data System (THYRADS) was proposed as an important tool for thyroid ultrasound examination. In 2018, THYRADS v2.0, the American Royal College of Radiology (RCR) proposed a new standardized thyroid ultrasound reporting system, which is more comprehensive than the traditional THYRADS. The RCR standard is currently used internationally.
The main defect in the RCR standard system is that it is necessary to master the features of all thyroid nodule benign and malignant characteristics and to accurately summarize various features in a text description. Although THYRADS has many advantages, the standardization of ultrasound reporting by RCR is too simple, and it is difficult to learn in the early stage of training.
Contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) have been confirmed to be useful in evaluating thyroid nodules and have been widely accepted. The results of previous studies have found that RCR standardized ultrasound reporting system is simpler than the contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) reporting system, but it also has some limitations, such as the inability to use ultrasound artifacts, poor interobserver agreement and limited application value.
The aim of this study is to improve accuracy of THYRADS standardized ultrasound reporting system, reduce the level of learning of the THYRADS standardized ultrasound reporting system in the initial phase of training, and improve teaching quality through AI assistance.

Neural prosthetic devices allow electrically stimulated patients with severe vision loss to see phosphenes with electrical stimulation. Phosphenes are patterns of flashing lights that appear as the electrode-nerve interface detects light or electrical currents. The neural prostheses (NP) rely on algorithms (that process electrical signals from electrode stimulation) that encode and decode scenes, often based on edge detection. There are no known computational models that accurately predict and control the appearance of perceptual experiences in response to these artificial devices. The investigators hypothesize that different encoding/decoding algorithms will result in different visual experiences. For example, a scene containing a light blue box on a dark green background might be detected and decoded by an edge-detection algorithm, but it will more accurately be detected and decoded by a machine learning algorithm that is specifically trained to detect and decode objects. The investigators aim to test this hypothesis by asking patients to view an artificial vision display (screen or monitor) from which stimuli are projected onto their natural eyes, and ask them to report the appearance of the objects displayed. The investigators expect that patients will be better able to identify objects, perceive their salient features, and describe the objects when their retinal or cortical prosthesis responds to images that are machine-computed. This study will provide a novel opportunity to test different scene-encoding/decoding algorithms (including machine learning) and test whether these algorithms provide more accurate visual experiences. The investigators hypothesize that different encoding methods will give rise to different perceptual experiences. For example, a scene containing a light blue box on a dark green background might be detected and decoded by an edge-detection algorithm, but it will more accurately be detected and decoded by a machine learning algorithm that is specifically trained to detect and decode objects. Therefore, the investigators will ask patients with visual prostheses to view an artificial vision display (screen or monitor) from which stimuli are projected onto their natural eyes, and ask them to report the appearance of objects displayed. The investigators expect that patients will be better able to identify objects, perceive their salient features, and describe the objects when their retinal or cortical prosthesis responds to images that are machine-computed. This study will provide a novel opportunity to test different scene-encoding/decoding algorithms (including machine learning) and test whether these algorithms provide more accurate visual experiences.

Adenoid cystic carcinomas (ACCs) of the sinonasal tract (SNT) are rare neuroendocrine tumors derived from pluristratose neuroepithelial cells that make up the epithelium of the sinonasal mucosa. They are typically slow growing and locally invasive tumors of the sinonasal tract, and frequently metastasize to regional lymph nodes and distant sites. Due to their indolent nature, ACCs are often diagnosed in an advanced stage, which can complicate the management of these tumors. Patients with ACCs are typically followed long-term due to their risk of recurrence, and their prognostic factors are still unclear. There is limited literature regarding the overall survival and disease-free survival (DFS) for patients with ACCs of the SNT treated over the past 20 years. The investigators propose an observational retrospective study of patients with primary ACCs of the SNT treated in the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Sinus Center from 2003-2019, as well as a retrospective cohort study of patients with ACCs of the SNT and other sinonasal mucosal sites treated in the MGH Otology and Neurotology Department from 1985-2019. In addition the investigators propose evaluating the effectiveness of surveillance with MR/CT and clinical examination in the postoperative period compared to traditional follow up. The investigators also propose using a retrospective database of patients treated in the Ear and Hearing Institute of MGH to evaluate the effectiveness of radiotherapy versus surgical resection.

Gastroesophageal Reflux (GER) is one of the most frequent gastrointestinal disorders in children, characterized by the reflux of gastric acid and gastric content from the esophageal sphincter and into the esophagus. Although in most cases the clinical manifestations are non-specific or minimal and in which GER is defined as functional gastrointestinal disease (FGID), the term inadequately characterized GERD (iGGERD) includes children who develop more severe symptoms and who are at risk of developing complications of esophagitis or aspiration. The diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux is usually made by endoscopic or radiological examinations, but these techniques have limitations, are invasive and uncomfortable for the subjects studied, and are often associated with poor tolerance and difficulties for the parents or caregivers, especially for infants. For this reason, the use of non-invasive diagnostic methods would be of particular interest for infants, as well as for the parents and caregivers. The presence of GER or GERD can lead to a number of symptoms. Symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, vomiting, irritability, and sleep disorders are more frequently observed in infants with GER. It has been shown in literature that the salivary analysis of pepsin and sodium, together with the measurement of pH, can provide valuable data for the diagnosis and differentiation of GERD and other causes of reflux, so that it has a role in determining the presence of GERD and in managing the treatment of GERD and GER. No studies have ever investigated the circadian variation of salivary pH and the content of salivary pepsin, pepsinogen and sodium in infants with gastroesophageal reflux. The hypothesis that led to this study is that salivary pH and the pepsin/pepsinogen ratio have circadian variation and that it is possible to detect a change in saliva parameters during the circadian day cycle that could identify different patterns of reflux in infants, and that these parameters could be particularly useful in identifying patterns of reflux in infants with various symptoms. GERD SYMPTOMS: In 2008, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) established the first pediatric panel on GERD in infancy, reporting that a prevalence of GERD of 47.3% should be used as an estimation for the use of pH-metry in the diagnosis of GERD in infants <1 year old. In the literature, the prevalence of true GERD in infants is between 10 and 40%, while non-specific or minimal symptoms of GERD are between 24 and 60%. It is reported in the literature that the detection of GER does not correlate with symptoms severity and even in infants with minimal or no symptoms, GER does not necessarily progress to GERD. It is reported in the literature that the detection of GER does not correlate with symptoms severity and even in infants with minimal or no symptoms, GER does not necessarily progress to GERD.

NAFLD is the most common chronic liver disease worldwide, and it is associated with increased risk for cardiovascular complications and mortality. Obesity, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus constitute the most important risk factors for NAFLD. There is insufficient data regarding the efficacy of the novel, non-insulin glucose-lowering medications in NAFLD. The investigators hypothesize that the two GLP1 agonists, Dulaglutide and Empagliflozin will be effective in improving liver fat fraction in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and NAFLD, and they want to compare their effect on liver steatosis. The investigators will measure improvement of liver fat fraction by Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Percutaneous Fat Quantification, as well as by comparing the change in the Fatty Liver Index (FLI), the Fibrosis-4 Index (FIB-4), as well as the Aspartate Aminotransferase to Platelet ratio Index (APRI) and the NAFLD Fibrosis Score (NFS). The investigators will also compare the effect of Dulaglutide vs. Empagliflozin in glycemic control improvement and weight loss.

Canine impaction affects the development of the dentition and has various negative effects on the patient's occlusion and the esthetic outcome. Canine impactation rate is around 2.1-3.6%.
In this study the investigators developed a technique to assist surgeons in locating and removing the palatally impacted permanent canines with minimal damage to the neighboring structures. The investigators hypothesize that using a surgical template in the extraction of palatally impacted canines will lessen the duration of the exposure procedure, reduce the amount of bleeding, lower postoperative pain, and improve treatment efficiency.
The investigators designed a surgical template based on the Digital Imaging and Communication in Medicine (DICOM) data of the pre-operative cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) reconstruction by fusing it with the digital impression of the patient's maxilla. This approach allows for the creation of a custom surgical template for each patient. On the day of the surgical operation the fit of the template is checked by the surgical operator who then uses a surgical laser to uncover the tooth using the template as a stencil. The impacted canines are exposed under local anaesthesia during an appointment, which lasts around 10 minutes. After removing the overlying mucosa the tooth is bonded with an orthodontic attachment to allow for the extrusion of the tooth.
Canine impaction has a variable prevalence rate, therefore, the investigators designed a prospective two-armed single-centre randomized clinical trial with a pre-defined primary purpose to assess the application of surgical templates for the surgical exposure of impacted canines. The investigators hypothesize that using the template will increase the accuracy of the exposure protocol, shorten the time required for the surgery, and reduce postoperative pain. The investigators will also evaluate the cost-effectiveness of this approach in an intra-country setting.
The investigators conducted a pilot study comparing the standard procedure with the surgical template technique on the exposure of 5 palatally impacted upper canines under the supervision of experienced orthodontists in July 2017 without the involvement of a surgeon from Semmelweis University Department of Periodontology. To date 6 more patients are included in the study.
The main study variables are the success of the surgical intervention, the duration of the surgery, postoperative pain on a 100 mm visual analog scale (VAS), complications, and time frame for the eruption of the impacted canines to its correct place. The investigators also investigate the excess costs of the design and manufacture of the surgical guides using Euro on a total of 20 patients.
During the trial the investigators will evaluate the time, costs and the accuracy of the exposure technique using a surgical template in comparison to the standard free-hand surgical protocol. The investigators expect that the trial will contribute to the development of new surgical techniques for the orthodontic correction of canine impaction.
The investigators plan to conduct this trial from September 2017 to August 2018 and the outcome of the study is to submit the results to a scientific journal for publication.

The safety of the treatment will be determined by assessing the alterations of the ERG and B-scan evaluation. The retinal function will be tested through serial ERG examinations to monitor for signs of ischemia on the outer retinal layers. Any findings considered abnormal will be documented using the International Reference Group for Electroretinography (IRG-ERG) criteria. The ERG examinations will be performed on the same day in the same place as the B-scan ultrasonography, according to participants' preferences. Each ERG will include a background check, a dark adaption of 5 minutes, and photopic and scotopic stimulations. B-scan ultrasonography is a diagnostic test conducted by specialized physicians and is the gold standard imaging technique for choroidal melanomas. The procedure is carried out by trained ophthalmologists with expertise in ocular ultrasound scans. The examinations are performed in a comfortable supine position under topical anesthesia (tetracaine) and will be done on both eyes to compare pre and post-treatment imaging. The initial scan will be performed in the enrolled eye only, and subsequent B-scans will be performed on both eyes for comparison purposes.

LSS patients are often instructed by their care providers to limit physical activity that increases symptoms. However, this often puts them at an increased risk of physical deconditioning. This trial focuses on older LSS patients who have symptom improvement with continuous flexion posture. Patients in this trial will be given tools to maintain flexion posture (a back support wedge and knee scooters) and will receive training in how to adjust their posture using DME as part of their treatment.
The aim of the study is to demonstrate feasibility of the intervention. The study uses actigraphy and mobility assessment to see if patients continue to maintain the necessary flexion after the 6-week pilot trial. This will demonstrate the acceptability of the intervention and the ability of LSS patients to self-manage.
This study has an estimated enrollment of 30 patients, who will be recruited from the Spine Clinic at the VA Palo Alto campus, San Francisco, CA. Each 6-week patient will have 3 study visits - baseline, week 3, and week 6.
Patients may find their self-management of pain and activity improvement and therefore may wish to participate in future studies on this intervention for a greater duration and at multiple medical sites.
Patients will be referred to participating therapists or physical trainers who will be trained to instruct patients in flexion and assist LSS patients in using knee scooters. In Phase 2, the investigators will work closely with Rehabilitation Research & Development Service to assess the need for a therapist or physical trainer for each participant.
In-home measurements of walking will be utilized to evaluate differences between treatment groups. The investigators will use 4 actigraphs (worn on the head, wrist, thigh, and calf) to capture frequency of walking, distance of walking, frequency of sitting and duration of sitting. During Phase 2 an interviewer will call patients 3 days after completing the 6-week period to address questions or concerns.
Data analysis will be compared between the treatment and control group, to assess the feasibility of DME-supported self-management using a continuous flexion posture for relief of symptoms.

Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the second and third cause of cancer-related death in men and women, respectively. For the detection of lesions in the mucosa (premalignant and malignant), colonoscopy has been considered the gold standard. Lately, published data evaluating the AI-assisted polyp detectors has demonstrate high sensitivity, specificity, and interobserver agreement. Due to the importance of CRC diagnosis and prompt treatment and taking advantage of the newly introduced DiscoveryTM AI system the investigators aim to assess the real-world effectiveness of this system in clinical practice and compare the results between expert and non-expert endoscopists. The study is a single-center crossover trial design. In this way patients will be submitted to 2 diagnostic colonoscopies, a conventional white light colonoscopy followed by a white light colonoscopy assisted by an AI system (DiscoveryTM). The first procedure will be performed by an expert or non-expert endoscopist. The second procedure will be performed by an operator with the same-level-of -expertise in comparison to the initial procedure and blinded to the results of the previous intervention. The diagnostic performance of the AI-assisted system will be assessed by sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values (PPV and NPV) and observer agreement. The ADR and PDR will be determined by every new colonoscopy, the ADR will be determined by at least one adenoma histologically proven/NBI NICE classification, and the PDR will be determined by at least one polyp.

Pregnant people with epilepsy and their healthcare providers have concerns about the effects of certain anti-seizure medications (ASM) on the growing fetus. Epilepsy-related complications increase the chances of a difficult birth, and some ASM can be toxic to the developing fetus. In particular, the use of anticonvulsants (like Depakote) in some cases can be very dangerous and lead to fetal demise. However, seizure control and ASMs are essential for both maternal and fetal safety as well as preventive long-term neuropathological effects. The goal of this study is to investigate the feasibility and tolerability of initiating a low glycemic index (LGI) diet in pregnant people with epilepsy in the first half of pregnancy. The LGI diet is a popular and flexible diet that has proven to be effective for treating seizures in people with epilepsy when compared to the Mediterranean diet. The LGI diet is also associated with a decrease in fasting insulin, HbA1c and blood pressure, as well as the reduction of the risks of cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and diabetes. People with epilepsy who follow a low glycemic index diet before pregnancy show improvements in glycaemic control, which is a positive side effect that we hope to recreate in pregnant women with epilepsy who follow the diet through pregnancy. Participants will choose to go on the low glycemic index diet or to remain on their standard diet. All participants will fill out diet questionnaires throughout the intervention and provide a maximum of three stool samples and three blood samples. Dietary intervention will end when pregnancies end, and stool and blood samples will be collected for up to three months postpartum. Outcomes will include diet tolerability, seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolite alterations. Our findings will help us predict the tolerability of the low glycemic index diet in pregnant people with epilepsy and provide a potential non-pharmacological option for a healthier pregnancy.

Pancreatic cancer is the ninth most common cancer worldwide with incidence rates of 2.2/100,000 and mortality rates of 4.1/100,000 (8). About 330,000 patients were diagnosed with PDAC, and the mortality rate was over 90% in the same year (9). PDAC usually presents with metastasis, and the main sites of metastasis are the liver, peritoneum and abdominal lymph nodes. Neoadjuvant therapy can improve overall survival (OS) and the rate of R0 resection in borderline resectable (BR) and resectable PDAC (4). According to the National Comprehensive Cancer Network guideline (11), neoadjuvant therapy is recommended before surgery for patients with stage IB and II A-B PDAC. The most effective treatment for PDAC with low tumor burden is surgery. However, most patients are diagnosed at a very late stage of the disease. This emphasizes the importance of developing effective non-invasive treatments to increase resectability of PDAC.
This feasibility study will investigate neo-adjuvant MSLN-targeted CAR-T therapy in patients with borderline or resectable PDAC. The investigators would like to examine whether the neo-adjuvant therapy can improve the rate of R0 resection, downstage the tumor, and increase the proportion of negative margins or other indicators of pCR after neo-adjuvant CAR-T therapy. CAR is a technology for gene editing, and CAR-T cells expressing chimeric receptor can target specific antigens on tumor cells. Mesothelin (MSLN) is a transmembrane antigen that is highly expressed in PDAC, ovarian cancer, lung cancer and other tumors. In a current randomized control trial of PDAC (NCT02466964), third-generation MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells have proven to be safe. Based on promising result of the trial, the investigators propose a pilot study to examine the safety and efficacy of endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided injection of MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells in PDAC patients with borderline resectable or resectable PDAC. The investigators will include a total of 50 patients as a first cohort. MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells will be injected using EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound) on PDAC. The investigators will evaluate the tumor response 4 weeks after MSLN-targeted CAR-T injection and the safety and feasibility of MSLN-targeted CAR-T therapy by follow-up for 1 year. After confirming the safety and feasibility of neo-adjuvant therapy with MSLN-targeted CAR-T cells, the study will be further expanded into second cohort and conduct a formal Phase II trial which will enro 100 patients with PDAC to examine the safety and efficacy of the EUS-guided MSLN CAR-T.
The overall outcome of the trial may help us to determine the role of neo-adjuvant therapy before surgery in PDAC patients.
This study is registered on www.clinicaltrials.gov and the registration number is NCT03548423.

Background: Children with Down Syndrome have a specific neuromuscular pattern with high prevalence of static quadriceps muscle hypertonicity and weakness of abdominal, trunk, and pelvic muscles.
Down syndrome children demonstrate decreased proprioceptive sense and muscle strength which leads to poor postural control in the weight-bearing position including standing and walking. Core stability exercises play an important part in training posture and maintaining balance. The current gold standard of core stability exercises is the Jaffrey Core Stability exercise.
However, there is concern that children with Down syndrome cannot follow the instructions given in a core stability training program, and children with Down Syndrome prefer more physical activity-oriented exercises. For this reason, the aim of this study is to compare the effects of Weight Bearing Exercises with Jaffrey's Core stability exercise training programs in 25 children with Down Syndrome on functional balance and trunk muscles strength.
Methods:
45 children with Down Syndrome were recruited from a state-funded elementary school in Sivas city, Turkey and assessed for the study. Children were randomly allocated into 3 groups. There were children in Group Jaffrey (25 children) and Group WBE (25Children) who were trained and Group C (25 children) who received no training for a 4-week period.
After the pre-tests were completed, the training program was began. Group WBE received weight bearing exercises training and group Jaffrey received Jaffrey's core stability exercises training. The children were evaluated at the end of the program (at 4 weeks).
The Berg balance scale, Pediatric balance scale, and Trunk control Measurement Scale were used for balance and trunk control assessments. The Berg balance scale is a widely used assessment tool of balance in children with Cerebral Palsy. The Pediatric balance scale is used to assess functional balance skills in school aged children. Trunk Control Measurement Scale is a clinical tool to measure trunk control in children.
Statistical analyses
After the normality of the data was evaluated with the Shapiro Wilk test, the descriptive statistics of the variables were calculated. The analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Kruskal Wallis analysis of variance (for non-parametric data) were used to compare the groups. If the significant difference was detected by the main effect of the group x time, post-hoc analyses using Tukey test for the parametric data and Friedman test for the non-parametric data were performed. p<0.05 was considered significant.
Results:
There were no statistically significant changes in dynamic balance at the end of the program, despite of the statistically significant increase of Berg balance scale scores with weight bearing exercises and Jaffrey's core stability training programs. Pediatric Baalance Scale scores did not show statistically significant increase in both groups. However, in the group WBE, there was a statistically significant increase of Pediatric Baalance Scale scores. Trunk Control Measurement Scale scores showed statistically significant increase in both groups, with greater statistically significant increase in the Group Jaffrey.
Conclusion:
As a conclusion, 4 weeks of training on weight bearing exercises with or without Jaffrey's core stability exercises did not affected the dynamic balance, however 4 weeks of training with Jaffrey's core stability exercises may effectively increase the trunk control in children with Down Syndrome.

Dialysis patients are at a higher risk of cardiovascular disease and bone fractures. Some of the risk factors for this include uncontrolled blood pressure, high lipids and high uric acid and a pro-inflammatory state. Some studies have shown that melatonin reduces cardiovascular risk factors such as blood pressure and inflammation. However data on its effect on lipids, oxidant markers, renal markers and patient quality in dialysis patients are limited. The aim of this clinical trial was therefore to investigate the effect of melatonin on glycemic parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, markers of renal bone metabolism and patient quality in continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) patients over a period of 10 weeks.
In this double-blind randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial, 120 CAPD patients were randomly assigned to melatonin (group M) or a placebo (group P). Outcome measures included biochemical parameters assessing fasting glucose, lipids, kidney and bone markers, quality of life, depression and sleep quality questionnaires.
In group M patients had lower levels of markers of cardiovascular and kidney damage, reduced insulin-resistance and inflammation compared to the placebo group. Quality of life scores improved in the melatonin group compared to baseline. Melatonin had no effect on markers of bone metabolism or sleep quality.
Melatonin improved several markers of cardiovascular risk in CAPD patients and may reduce the risk of cardiovascular events. Improved quality of life in patients receiving a dietary supplement of melatonin. Long term studies are required to determine the role of melatonin in CAPD patients.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common postoperative complication in cardiac surgery. Despite some improvements in the management of the hemodynamic status under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), the incidence of AKI remains high (up to 40%). Furthermore, AKI has significant adverse effects on both morbidity and mortality, and it is associated with significant increase in postoperative hospitalisation costs. In our tertiary centre, we recently initiated a strategy that aims to optimize oxygen delivery under CPB to better understand its impact on the incidence of AKI. However, this hemodynamic management strategy remains very complex and is not currently integrated into routine clinical practice. The objective of this pilot study is to design and develop a patient-level decision support system that uses optimization strategies for oxygen delivery in patients undergoing cardiac surgery under CPB. This system will help to individualize oF DO2 to prevent the incidence of AKIS. This study is focused on patients with cardiac disease submitted to cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass. The clinical utility of this new system will be tested in a future multicenter randomized controlled trials and should be used as the basis of a clinical decision support system. The objective of the project is to design and develop a system integrating optimization strategies for oxygen delivery in patients undergoing cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass.
This pilot study will be developed in three phases.
The first phase starts with the systematic review of the related literature to provide the basis for oxygen delivery recommendations. This phase will end with a set of recommendations about oxygen delivery under cardiopulmonary bypass.
Subsequently, we shall develop a software to calculate oF DO2 in real time, using both hemoglobin and CPB output as inputs. This program will be used off-line in a database to compare real-time oF DO2 values with recommended oF DO2 values defined during the first phase.
The second phase starts with the construction of our database, consisting of cardiac surgery cases with cardiopulmonary bypass in our hospital. This database will include hemoglobin values, CPB output and oF DO2 calculated in real time, using hemoglobin and CPB values.
We shall design a database using real-time oF DO2 values and defined oF DO2 recommendations using offline data during the CPB procedure in cardiac surgery without AKI. The objective of this phase is to assess the accuracy of the defined guidelines in this database.
After this phase, we shall develop a decision support system to calculate oF DO2, in real-time, and the software will help to reach our defined guidelines using all the data of the database.
In the third phase, we shall evaluate the decision support system on a database including 294 cases with cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass and the incidence of postoperative AKI. This will allow us to assess the effectiveness of our oF DO2 recommendations in reducing the incidence of AKI.
We anticipate the development of this decision support system can be performed in two years.
Trial-level eligibility: 580 adult or pediatric patients admitted for extracorporeal circulation in the cardiac surgery unit of the University Hospital of Lille from 2017 to 2020.
Individual-level eligibility: 300 patients admitted between 2017 and 2020 in the cardiac surgery unit of the University Hospital of Lille and treated with CPB and post CPB hemofiltration.

The auricular acupressure procedure on specific regions is a simple, non-invasive and low-cost method applied to prevent diseases and accelerate healing. In addition to being an alternative medicine method, it is one of the methods preferred for rapid healing. It was emphasized that pain relief in the treatment of painful problems and postoperative pain reduction were observed in clinical trials. In a study evaluating the effect of auricular acupressure on the lumbar region in adults, it was observed that the pain in the lumbar region was significantly reduced after 5 minutes of auricular acupressure in the first and second groups. In another clinical study, it was observed that the average heart rate and body temperature increased at a single auricular acupressure point and decreased at another point. It was determined that the heat released by the body as a result of auricular acupressure at certain acupoints is an indication that it was effective in many diseases (Acupuncture).
This study was planned to evaluate the effects of auricular acupressure and sham auricular acupressure on temperature and skin conductance values in the lumbar region. The objective is to determine whether changes in core body temperature occur during auricular acupressure.

Background: Hyperglycemia continues to be a substantial factor related to diabetic complications. Recent evidence shows that type 2 diabetes is also a consequence of intestinal microbial dysbiosis in addition to obesity. One factor involved in the complex pathophysiology of obesity is the A-kinase anchoring protein 1 (AKAP1). Dysbiosis of the intestinal microbiota may be associated with increased levels of serine protease tryptase (SPT) and its activating protein A-kinase anchoring protein 1 (AKAP1) in the bloodstream.
A-kinase anchoring protein 1(AKAP1) is a serine protease that has been shown to increase insulin resistance.
Objectives: 1. Evaluate the effect of the intervention with Nitazoxanide (NTX) on glycemic control and insulin resistance of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus; 2. Determine the effect of the intervention with Nitazoxanide on lipid profile.
Material and Methods: This is a pilot study in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). All participants must attend an in-person visit and will be instructed on the proper use of the 2 week-diaries. Glycemic control will be assessed with fasting blood glucose levels and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels. Serum insulin levels with HOMA-IR calculation will be used to evaluate insulin resistance. Blood lipid levels (total cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL, and HDL) will be measured. Serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin will be determined.
Results: Preliminary data after 2 months of intervention with nitazoxanide 500 mg twice daily show an improvement in glycemic control and a decrease in serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1(AKAP1).
Conclusion: The current study could provide helpful insights into the potential beneficial effects of nitazoxanide supplementation in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Larger and longer-term studies are necessary to evaluate the effectiveness and long-term impact of nitazoxanide supplementation.

The overall prevalence of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is increasing worldwide, and it affects about 1% - 1.5% of children. The pathogenesis of ASD is multifactorial and there is a role for environmental, genetic, and microbiome factors. This project aims to investigate clinical risk factors of autism such as the dietary history, maternal use of medications, obstetric, and birth history and then investigating the microbiome and metabolome of autistic and their siblings. 16S rRNA genes sequencing and the non-targeted comprehensive analysis by ultra-high performance liquid chromatography (UHPLC)/time of flight-mass spectrometry (TOF-MS) will be perform to identify possible dysbiosis and microbiome changes related to autism. This project will provide a good insight into possible clinical microbiological risk factors of autism and their possible relation with the severity of ASD.

Inclusion criteria: a) children aged between 3-9 years based on DSM V Exclusion criteria: Past or present history of seizures or any other neurological illness Past or present history of any psychiatric illness Those patient will be excluded to avoid confounders because those diseases also affected by microbiome.

Many individuals with severe mental illness (SMI) are at risk of poverty due to a number of reasons: lack of employment opportunities, a high prevalence of financial exploitation, and social isolation or stigma. Financial insecurity may contribute to a state of uncertainty and anxiety that can hamper recovery. Hence, intervention to improve participant’s ability to achieve financial security may help prevent poverty-related poor outcomes and promote recovery. Currently, there are very few intervention studies for people with severe mental illness that focus on providing individual-level financial self-help, to address the high rate of poverty in this group. This study will evaluate the effectiveness of an internet-based intervention model for improving incomes, financial self-efficacy, and well-being among adults with SMI. With a randomised controlled trial design, we will compare the intervention with a wait-list control.

Participants will be grouped into the experimental group (Arm I) or the control group (Arm II). Patients in Arm I will receive 177Lu-DOTATATE. Patients in Arm II will receive everolimus. There is also the option for cross-over between the two arms if patients experience disease progession.
Treatment cycles will be repeated for 2 cycles or until objective disease progression occurs.

There are many techniques of spinal manipulation being performed to get the desired pain relief results and improvement in ROM. The aim of the this study is to compare the effects of McKenzie extension exercises program versus Mulligan techniques for chronic unilateral radicular low back pain in terms of pain reduction and ROM. The two techniques were evaluated for the improvement within the group with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain in terms of pain reduction and ROM. The investigators intend to evaluate the outcome of Mulligan method vs. McKenzie method for four weeks period on a single blinded randomized trial. Mulligan technique SNAGS in sitting and standing position in patients with chronic radicular low back pain is very effective and produces fast pain relief results. Mulligan SNAGS may be considered as a first choice therapy for chronic radicular low back pain.

Atrial fibrillation has been regarded as a major social health problem in Hong Kong in view of its rapid progression, high health expenditure and poor prognosis12. Compared to the general population, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation patients have a higher risk of heart failure and stroke, and atrial fibrillation is associated with poorer quality of life36. The present study is based on the conceptual framework of the self-regulation model proposed by Lazarus and Folkman78, which emphasizes individuals' subjective perceptions and response strategies to challenges. Self-regulation theory focuses on subjective perception of illness as well as an individual's perceived cognitive resources and response strategies to cope with illness13. Illness perceptions are the ways in which individuals construe an illness and its impact and implications, including the perceived causes of the problem, its duration and impact, and the extent to which the person feels able to manage the symptoms of their conditions and have some control over them13. In coping with the uncertainties presented by chronic health conditions, individual characteristics, social factors and the nature of the disease are influenced by individuals' perception of their illness, including their cognitive appraisal, emotion, health care resources and social support29. At present, no study has been designed to study the interventional factors associated with the quality of life of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The investigators proposed to study the following possible factors affecting the quality of life of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation patients: illnes perceptions, coping strategies and self-efficacy. We will further investigate the indirect and direct effects of illness perceptions and coping strategies, and the moderating effects of self-efficacy in the paroxysmal atrial fibrillation patients. The aim of this study is to study the interventional factors that affect the quality of life of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation patients and to identify the factors that can help to prevent these problems and thereby improve patients' quality of life.

Rectal cancer is the second most common cause of colon cancer and the fourth most common cancer. Treatment of early rectal cancer is a multidisciplinary approach, and one of the main problems is the high morbidity rate in patients who are candidates to organ preservation. Transanal endoscopic surgery, with the development of endoscopic resection and transanal endoscopic microsurgery (TEM), has increased the indication for local excision of rectal lesions. However, there are no prospective randomized studies that demonstrate the quality of organ-preserving strategies. In the literature, the risk of locoregional recurrence ranges between 5% and 23% for early rectal cancer after transanal local excision. It is not known if there are enough tumors that cannot be removed that justify a total treatment plan vs. a watch and wait approach.
In March 2023, the local ethics committee will begin the recruitment process of centres that will participate in the LORENA project, and the project will begin in January 2025.
In a prospective manner, the project will include all patients who have early or locally advanced rectal cancer, defined as M0 tumors, located more than 4 cm from the anal verge which are candidates for transanal local excision, or T1 or T2 tumors that are clinically deemed unresectable and that meet the inclusion criteria. The study´s main objective is to study in situ rectum preservation in rectal adenocarcinoma through local excision. Demographics, tumor characteristics, type of intervention, complications, histological details and further necessity of treatments and rectal preservation will be recorded for each patient, along with the number of patients who have to perform total surgical excision after initial local excision. Surgery, histology, complications, radicality of salvage TME and morbidity rate will be the outcome measures.
Expected results: 5% of patients with early rectal cancer may avoid the need for total surgical excision with complications and functional results similar to those obtained after total surgical excision, although it is not known which clinical characteristics are associated with the success of local excision.

Type A aortic dissection involves an acute tear in the innermost layer of aortic wall, leading to the formation of a "false" lumen at the ascending aorta. The blood pressure then forces flow through the tear, into the false lumen, causing a tear in the outer layer, eventually leading to rupture of aorta and rapid death.
Over a two year study period, the investigators will enroll 2,000 patients operated on for a type A aortic dissection in participating hospitals. The investigators will document patient characteristics, concomitant procedures performed, procedural methods, procedural results, mortality, and early and late major complications. Patients will be tracked every year for life/death and any events related to their aortic dissection.
Overall, this study has a two-fold focus. One is to compare outcomes among various types of procedures. The second is to examine risk factors for adverse outcome. The data will determine the impact of current and developing repair strategies and it will help identify important risk factors for poor outcome. These may influence future strategies for the management of aortic dissection and may contribute more generally to the scientific understanding of aortic diseases.

Stress refers to a psychobiological state response to the demands of a situation that are perceived as excessively taxing or threatening, where a change in the behavior and physiological responses to allow the person to meet those demands takes place. Many factors have contributed to a more complex understanding about the role of stress in the human body; however, it is necessary to underline stressors such as academic stress, which may involve the perception of the subject about the relevance of an exam to meet the expectations of their loved ones and, subsequently, personal failures. Students in undergraduate degrees, especially in health-related disciplines such as physiotherapy and nursing are an example of situations that may cause anxiety by the constant demand of academic development and expectations of the profession itself.
Nowadays, there are different methods to manage stress, such as pharmacological, psychological and alternative therapies, as guided visualization (also known as imagery) is a procedure that consists of a mental focus on a specific image or scene, in order to evoke positive sensations and, potentially, lower stress levels. Based on the aforementioned, the objective is to design a single-blind randomized controlled study with two different groups of students who will be attending an academic test in Health Sciences. The effectiveness of virtual reality vs. traditional guided visualization to manage stress prior to the examination will be evaluated by the assessment of perceived stress in the last month, physiological stress responses (blood pressure and heart rate, both in rest and stress, and salivary cortisol, just before starting the exam), and academic performance.

<|assistant|> Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), a cancer arising from the epithelial lining of the nasopharynx, is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). In children, adolescents and young adults (CAYA), NPC is often treated with radiation therapy, resulting in late side effects, such as loss of hearing. A study is being developed to see whether combining chemotherapy with an immune drug called nivolumab improves outcomes with fewer side effects. It will be combined with standard chemotherapy to treat newly diagnosed patients, followed by treatment with nivolumab alone for up to 5 years. Patients receive nivolumab IV over 30 minutes on day 1 of each cycle, gemcitabine IV over 30 minutes on days 1 and 8 of each cycle, and cisplatin IV over 3-6 hours on day 1 of each cycle. Treatment repeats every 21 days for 3 cycles in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Patients also receive concurrent radiation therapy on trial. After completion of study treatment, patients are followed up periodically and have repeated tumor evaluations. Patients receive nivolumab IV over 30 minutes on day 1 of each cycle. Treatment repeats every 28 days for 6 cycles in the absence of disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Patients also undergo echocardiography (ECHO) or multigated acquisition scan (MUGA) during screening and as clinically indicated on trial. Patients undergo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), fludeoxyglucose F 18 (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET), and computed tomography (CT) throughout the trial and chest x-ray during follow-up. Patients also undergo dental x-ray imaging on the trial. Patients may optionally undergo tissue biopsy, blood and stool sample collection during screening and on trial. Upon completion of study treatment, patients are followed up every 3 months for 12 months, every 6 months until 24 months off therapy, and then yearly until 5 years off therapy. The aim of this study is to use imaging techniques to assess liver and lung function, as well as digestive system issues in children with CF who are beginning treatment with a new drug called the CFTR modulator (ETI).
The study will include 3 phases.
In Phase 1, we will test to see if the new imaging protocols can be carried out with very young children (aged 6 to 11 years), as well as with healthy volunteers who are the same age and gender as the participants.
Phase 2 will recruit 12 children with CF who are aged 6 to 11 years, and they will have MRI scans taken at 3 time points determined by the ingestion of a meal. These scans will help us to measure how the gut moves and releases the nutrients it obtains from food into the body. The patients will also be asked to complete questions about their stomach and bowel symptoms, and a 3-day food diary for each of the 3 study days.
Phase 3 will require the participants to return to the hospital for a repeat set of the MRI scans. This will be between 6 months and 1 year after children have started ETI. Phase 3 is essential to see how the CFTR modulator (ETI) is affecting the children's gastrointestinal systems and liver and lung function.

Hypospadias repair surgery is an invasive surgery that results in significant postoperative pain. Pain alters the quality of life and satisfaction of the patients and results in manipulation of wounds, infection, bleeding, and wound dehiscence leading to unfavorable surgical outcome. As a plan for postoperative pain prophylaxis in children, different analgesic techniques have been used as preemptive analgesia such as local infiltration of anesthesia, penile block, epidural block and caudal block in addition to general anesthesia. Caudal block is found to be one of most succeeded technique in hypospadias repair and decreases the postoperative analgesia consumption. Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic commonly used via caudal epidural route but gives limited duration of analgesia. Therefore, the addition of other drugs in an attempt to improve the quality and duration of analgesia given by bupivacaine has been studied. Examples of additives drugs used in the caudal epidural are opioids, alpha 2 agonist as dexmedtomidine and clonidine which produce prolongation of the duration of the analgesia, but their undesirable effect may limit its use as nausea, vomiting, pruritus, urinary retention and respiratory depression. Epidural corticosteroids have a long history of safe and effective use in the treatment of low back and radicular pain due to their strong anti-inflammatory effect encouraging use in management of acute postoperative pain. In pediatric surgical patients presenting for mainly lower abdominal surgery, a meta-analysis revealed clinically meaningful prolongation of the duration of analgesia from caudal blockade by adjuvant dexamethasone versus placebo. In addition to doubling to tripling the duration of analgesia, adjuvant dexamethasone has a rescue analgesia sparing effect and reduces post postoperative nausea and vomiting. A vast majority of literature supports the efficacy of particulate steroids like methylprednisolone over dexamethasone in providing longer analgesia in management of chronic pain conditions. Aim of the work and hypothesis: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study that will evaluate the analgesic efficacy and safety of caudal methylprednisolone in pediatric patients. This randomized, double-blind, controlled bi-center study was designed to compare the postoperative analgesic efficacy of dexamethasone and methylprednisolone in caudal block for children undergoing hypospadias surgical repair using the duration of analgesia as the primary outcome. The investigators hypothesize that methylprednisolone will provide superior postoperative analgesia than dexamethasone when added to bupivacaine for caudal block.

This is a prospective randomized controlled pilot trial. It is a single-center trial to address our primary research question. Marginal donor organs are lung organs with the potential to be transplanted yet rejected conventionally due to low pre-transplant functional test parameters. Lungs from this category of donors are offered to hospitals and transplant centers for evaluation and the decision whether or not to transplant these organs is subjective. Based on preliminary evidence, EVLP has shown to be a potential tool to repair 'marginal' organs and provide a second chance for transplantation. However, this approach is not without risks and currently not available in all transplant centers. Several authors demonstrated the value of additional treatment strategies, such as HDF prior to lung transplantation. The combination of both techniques should lead to improved outcomes; nevertheless, there was no randomized evidence. We hypothesize that combination of EVLP and HDF will improve the lung function in the transplanted lungs. We also hypothesize that organ repairs by EVLP/HDF will lead to a reduced need for donor lungs with better outcome after transplantation. These assumptions were not evaluated in a systematic way. This prospective pilot trial is therefore designed to compare the functional testing parameters of donor lungs in EVLP versus EVLP/HDF. Furthermore, we will evaluate the impact of EVLP/HDF on the recipients by clinical parameters.
A prospective randomized open-label three-armed study is designed to investigate this hypothesis. The study group consists of 24 pairs of lungs for transplantation at the Medical University of Vienna, all other parameters are similar to clinical routine application.
Lung grafts (n=24 pairs) that are initially offered to our center for transplantation are identified based on their organ-procuring coordinator report and ISHLT criteria. After the initial consent and organ offer at the Organ Procuring Coordinator in Austria, the coordinator will get in touch with the investigators to identify eligible recipients. We will screen potential recipients for their suitability to participate in the clinical trial. Based on our inclusion criteria, patients on the intensive care unit prior to transplantation, with mechanical ventilation and/or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation support will not be able to participate in the study. Lung transplant criteria of the Medical University of Vienna are accepted and follow the guidelines provided by ISHLT. Recipients with a life expectancy of less than nine months will not be considered.
Donor organs are offered to 3 different study arms. Inclusion criteria and organ-offering decisions are left to the investigators. 24 lung pairs will fulfill the criteria for acceptance to the Medical University of Vienna. If a lung pair cannot be transplanted in our center due to the subjective decision of our local team, it will be considered lost to follow-up. 24 pairs of lungs will undergo the randomization process.

Premature infants are known to be more susceptible to discomfort and pain than term infants during clinical examinations. Procedures such as retinopathy of prematurity examination are commonly experienced causes of distress and discomfort in premature and low birth weight infants. Several attempts have been made to optimize the retinopathy examination procedure by administering procedural pain relievers, such as topical sucrose administration and skin-to-skin contact with parental figures. However, most attempts have been primarily focused on analgesia and pain reduction, and have limited success in addressing distress and discomfort.  The present study aims to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensorial stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. Previous studies have shown that auditory and multisensory stimuli might be helpful in reducing anxiety and pain in clinical settings. However, the effect of auditory stimuli on the outcomes of retinopathy of prematurity examinations has not been investigated. Thus, the present study aims to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. It is hypothesized that the use of multisensory stimulation during retinopathy of prematurity examination will contribute to a more comfortable experience for the infants and will increase the overall examination success rate.

Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) is a common ocular surface disease that is associated with abnormalities in the eyelid. It was previously known as meibomianitis and is a challenging disease for eye care professionals and patients. The prevalence of MGD was reported to range from 6% to 89%, depending on the criteria used, location of subjects and diagnostic tools used. A simple grading system would be useful when screening and managing patients who may have MGD, but current grading systems had certain limitations. The current grading systems, which rely on the eyelid morphology and lid structure, did not quantify the meibomian gland dysfunction.
During recent years, non-invasive imaging tools, such as in vivo confocal microscopy (IVCM), Scheimpflug imaging and optical coherence tomography (OCT) had been developed to quantify MG health and dysfunction. The aim of this project was to quantify Meibomian glands (MG) health by in vivo confocal microscopy (IVCM) and develop a simple grading system based on the MG density and thickness. This was important as it would allow quantification of MGD and standardise the diagnosis. The investigators hypothesised that MG thickness and density could be used as biomarkers quantitate MGD and a simple grading system for MGD would be useful. They developed a modified formula for quantifying Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD), based on the average MG thickness, MG density, tear meniscus height, eye morphology and tear film lipid layer thickness.

The aim of this project is to study the effects on oral mucositis and on the quality life of subjects undergoing radiotherapy for oral cavity, pharynx or head and neck cancer. The oral mucositis is a common side effect of radiotherapy for head and neck. Radiotherapy induced Oral Mucositis (OM) is characterized by mucosal inflammation, severe pain and it can lead to several complications such as infections, feeding problems and malnutrition. The investigational product is based on zinc gluconate and bicarbonate. This combination has strong anti-inflammatory potential.
Previous studies have already proved that zinc is able to protect against radiation-induced toxicity such as mucositis and oral disorders. It is also considered one of the most powerful anti-inflammatory agents present in the food and it contributes to oral health.
It’s well known the importance of oral health in the quality of life of patients, because the oral cavity is considered a key point for social interactions. Patients affected by Oral Mucositis often experience a lot of pain and discomfort, and it can interfere with self-esteem and body image. Therefore the impact of this complication can be significant for patients.
In recent years different devices and products aiming to protect against OM have been tested and are commercially available, in most cases as rinses containing alkaline substances that help the formation of a barrier on the oral cavity. Nonetheless, no device or product based on antioxidants has been yet studied and tested.
It’s important to highlight that the effects of these products on oral health have never been studied in terms of prevention of OM. The objective of this project is to compare the effectiveness of the investigational product based on zinc and bicarbonate with a new rinse based on sodium chloride and bicarbonate to prevent the OM in patients submitted to radiotherapy for head and neck cancer.

Heel lance is performed in all neonates, regardless of gestational age, to determine the complete blood count and the presence of metabolic diseases.
The purpose of the study is to determine the effect of white noise, heart sounds, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance.
The design of the study is a randomized controlled experimental design.
The sample of the study consisted of 84 infants with a gestational age of 28-42 weeks.
The infants were exposed to white noise, heart sounds, or the music that the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy, for 10 minutes before the heel lance, during, and 20 minutes after the procedure.
The pain of the infants before, during, and after the procedure was measured using the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS).
The crying time of the infant was also evaluated.
Data were analyzed using independent samples t test, repeated measurement and Chi-square test.
Results of the study suggest that music intervention in the heel lance process can be used to reduce the pain of neonates, reduce the duration of the procedure and reduce the crying time of the infants.
Although heart sounds are also among the alternatives, the music intervention is preferred by mothers and may be more effective.
It is recommended to perform further pain minimizing studies in neonatal period by creating different music scales for neonates from different cultures.

The impact of early experience on brain development is well-established. In recent years, intensive early intervention has shown promise in mitigating the adverse effects of early experience in high-risk infants and toddlers. One example of such intervention is the NIH-funded Caregiver Skills Training (CST) initiative. CST is a family-centered, in-home parent development intervention designed to improve early behavioral and language outcomes for young children who are at-risk for negative outcomes. Caregivers of young children with risk profiles are trained to use evidence-based strategies to positively influence the children in their care. Results of CST have been positive, with reports of improved parenting, improved child behavioral and language outcomes, and improved child cognition. In fact, two randomized clinical trials of the CST intervention show promise with respect to reducing the risk of later-occurring mental health and behavioral challenges. While there is strong support for CST, many agencies lack the resources to offer such an intervention. This includes lack of staff time to administer the intervention and lack of funds to send staff members to face-to-face training.  In light of these limitations, the investigators have created a remote version of this intervention model. In this study, the investigators' objective is to offer to two agencies the opportunity to participate in either the remote CST model or the more traditional in-person CST model. To accomplish this, the investigators will compare the relative efficacy of CST when implemented remotely versus in-person. Staff will be trained in the CST curriculum and the process by which they facilitate CST groups. They will also receive supervision throughout the duration of the study. The investigators expect that the skills CST imparts to caregivers will be comparable regardless of how the staff was trained. The investigators also expect that the implementation of CST via a remote modality will be as effective as the traditional in-person model.

Physiotherapists play a pivotal role in functional rehabilitation of musculoskeletal disorders. Current practice is based mostly on empirical evidence; despite being evidence-based, our current practice have many limitations. For this reason, physiotherapist must have a critical interpretation of new scientific evidence that could change the practice and improve the clinical outcome. Recently, one new physical therapy intervention has emerged: Transcranial direct electrical stimulation (tDCS). This treatment presents some advantages and limitations that may vary depending on the intensity of the stimulation and the duration between stimulation sessions. It seems to be an effective therapy for the relief of neuropathic pain, but there seems to be controversy when it comes to the chronic joint pain pathologies. However, the physiotherapeutic approach to the rehabilitation of chronic shoulder pain syndrome (SDS) usually includes the use of non-pharmacological techniques such as exercises of specific strengthening of the shoulder muscles, or therapeutic exercises of the scapular and glenohumeral complex. In this case, therapeutic exercise has a good level of scientific evidence (in the long and medium term) and is highly recommended by the official practice guidelines recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). The aim of this clinical trial is to explore whether the addition of transcranial direct electrical stimulation (tDCS) to a standardized physiotherapy program (consisting of specific exercises of strengthening and scapular repositioning) in patients with unilateral pain of the shoulder and disability, improves the functional disability of such patients, as well as their pain intensity, compared to another physiotherapy program plus placebo (sham-tDCS) transcranial electrical direct stimulation and standard physiotherapy..

All children aged 2 to 17 years, diagnosed with ASD who completed a verbal test every six months (either Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program or the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills), received applied behavioral analysis at ORC were screened for inclusion. There were 25 subjects in the control group who were only assessed with 1 score each. Data from 8 subjects were incomplete (2 were only evaluated at baseline for verbal testing and had no available change score). Lymphoedema can develop after lymph node removal (1), mastectomy (4,5) or radiation therapy during breast cancer treatment.

Burns are the fourth cause of mortality after trauma, cancers and cardiovascular diseases. Burned patients suffer both functional sequelae and cosmetic difficulties. The management of hand burns remains a challenge. In our practice, releasing incisions are performed to reduce the dead space and the surface burned. The main advantage of this technique is to reduce tension at graft application to increase survival and avoid scarring contractures. However, some patients may complain of functional sequelae such as hand weakness, limitation of range of motion and finger stiffness. The objective of this study is to describe the cosmetic and functional sequelae associated with hand burns requiring releasing incision. The objective of functional and aesthetic score is to have a quick assessment of patient hand condition and return to activities after hand deep burns that required releasing incisions.

The Stanford Plant-based Educational Study (PLANT) is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a flexible, multimodal WFPBD educational program for 6 weeks for providers at Stanford in any department. The trial is looking to determine if the intervention changes provider and patient mindset and practice of WFPBD in the context of diabetes care. To date, no one has tested this hypothesis. Providers at Stanford and other institutions have shown interest in WFPBD as a dietary strategy, however, there have been no systematic methods for physician adoption of this diet. We will measure changes in Diet ID score, a novel tool assessing diet type/quality, and assess mindset towards adopting WFPBD using the validated Survey of Mindset, motivation, and confidence for behavior change in the Transtheoretical model. The study will consist of a pre- and post survey and a WFPBD educational program. We will assess measures of motivation and confidence for adoption of a WFPBD and for prescribing a WFPBD to patients. Intervention: Participants will receive an educational intervention on whole food plant-based nutrition that will last 6 weeks and include an interactive didactic session, cooking classes, and weekly emails with suggested resources and activities including movies, recipes, and websites. Providers will then be surveyed at week 6 to assess if the intervention changed their provider and patient practices.

Rates of early postpartum depressive symptoms following childbirth are particularly high among Black birthing parents. Furthermore, in the U.S. most postpartum mental health care receives low rates of engagement (e.g., <20% accept referrals), with Black parents experiencing the lowest rates of engagement in maternal mental health care. Recent theoretical contributions within the field of developmental psychopathology link parental depressive symptoms in the postpartum period to an associated decrease in caregiver responsivity, which influences infant emotional regulation. The proposed study seeks to build on the evidence of short-term, manualized group psychotherapy, developed for Black postpartum women by Dr. Brody, for the management of depression and anxiety symptoms in the postpartum period. The primary aim of the study is to adapt the 12-session mentalizing-focused group therapy, known as Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE), for the support of parents and their children from birth through 12-months of age. The proposed study will assess the efficacy of this group-based parenting support intervention for the management of depression, anxiety, parenting stress, and parent-child bonding within the first year of the child's life.

Stroke is a major cause of death and significant disability in the world. Rapid recanalization treatment remains the priority for the treatment of patients with anterior circulation large vessel occlusion. After successful recanalization treatment, the outcome of patients with basilar artery occlusion is still poor and the mortality rate is still high. To explore a better access approach for endovascular thrombectomy of basilar artery occlusion.
