Maternal medical mistrust in this population is common and has direct impact on adverse maternal health outcomes. Objectives: This proposal aims to develop and test a novel integrated prenatal care model where a community doula is partnered with the prenatal healthcare provider team to deliver perinatal care in the Black AA population. Aim 1: Develop an integrated prenatal care model of medical providers and community doulas in Southeastern Wisconsin Approach: The investigators will conduct six focus groups with Black/AA birthing people and prenatal healthcare providers to elicit feedback on models of doula/medical provider integration with the overarching aim of building trust and improving maternal health outcomes. Aim 2: Compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement and trust and reducing adverse maternal outcomes Approach: In a two-arm randomized controlled trial conducted at Froedtert and MCW, the investigators will randomize Black/AA pregnant people to BUNDLE or standard prenatal care. Aim 3: Disseminate findings to scholarly and community-based forums and actively pursue opportunities for systems- and policy-level change Approach: The investigators will actively disseminate the findings to policymakers, the healthcare system, and community leaders to implement the developed strategies to sustain successful program outcomes through policy changes at the system and statewide level by advocating for doula coverage and healthcare system sustainability of the integrated prenatal care model. BACKGROUND: Chronic low back pain (CLBP) is defined as low back pain lasting for at least 3 months and is still present on some days. Massage therapy has been shown to decrease pain and disability in patients with CLBP in several studies. Connective tissue massage (CTM) applied only on the lower extremities has shown effective results in this group of patients, and classical massage (CM) has shown effective results in patients with CLBP. In this study the aim was to compare the effectiveness of CTM, CM and control group on pain, functional status and quality of life in patients with CLBP.

METHODS: Participants were recruited from among the patients who applied to the physical therapy and rehabilitation outpatient clinic of Çanakkale Onsekiz Mart University Faculty of Health Sciences between April 2020-June 2020. Thirty patients were randomly divided into three groups. Group I (n = 10) was given connective tissue massage intervention group . This technique includes a series of special movements called METS: Mobilization - Elongation - Tension - Separation. Each of them is performed in both directions and is performed for 30 seconds. Group II (n = 10) was given classical massage (CM) intervention group. In this technique, patients were positioned lying supine with their upper body and arms covered with a towel. The treatment began with a general stroking movement by using the entire back and upper leg. It continues by applying an up and down massage to the lumbar region. These strokes are performed in the direction of the spine. After the 1st month of the research, measurements were taken again.

FINDINGS: The results revealed that there was a statistically significant improvement in pain (VAS), lumbar forward bending and sit and reach flexibility (MST), trunk mobility/flexibility (SRT), daily activities/living functions (BPFS), functional disability (RMDQ) and physical function component (SF-36) in Connective Tissue Massage (CTM) and Classical Massage (CM) patients compared to the control group.

IMPLICATIONS: Connective Tissue Massage and Classical Massage are effective in improving pain, mobility/flexibility, disability and the quality of life of patients with chronic low back pain. The findings of this study provide practical recommendations for future applications and future research in this area . Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. Despite screening rates below national targets, Veterans Administration (VA) patients are more likely to be up-to-date with CRC screening when compared with the general population. In our institution's Gastroenterology outpatient clinic, the current overall adherence rate to surveillance colonoscopy is 58% up-to-45-days after initial appointment date. The purpose of the current study is to examine the impact of a reminder/assistance phone call and text message intervention on increased adherence to scheduled colonoscopy appointments in patients due for surveillance colonoscopy.
Patients (≥ 45 years of age) due for a surveillance colonoscopy will be randomized to either an Intervention arm (receive text messages/phone calls) or No Intervention arm. Participants in the Intervention arm will receive a series of instructional and motivational text messages, which will be sent starting 7-14 days before and until the day of the colonoscopy procedure. Participants in the No Intervention arm will not receive text messages. The primary goal of the text messages is to assist with bowel preparation and remind patients of their scheduled appointment time. In addition to collecting data on attendance at scheduled appointments and clinical outcomes, the study will evaluate patient satisfaction with the text message messages using a survey developed specifically for the study. It is theorized that the use of reminders/assistance messages will increase adherence to recommended screening programs among patients due for surveillance colonoscopy.

Incomplete miscarriage is defined as early miscarriage with persistent intrauterine material on ultrasound. These retained products of conception may be responsible for persistent metrorrhagia and endometritis. This symptomatology often accentuates the psychological distress of patients mourning the pregnancy. Incomplete miscarriages are mainly managed by the gynecological emergency department. The recommendations of the Collège National des Gynécologues et Obstétriciens Français (CNGOF) suggest as a first line of treatment: either surgical management or expectant care. The choice between the two is left to the discretion of the doctor and the patient. There are no clear recommendations as to the choice between hysteroscopy and aspiration. Within the teams, the choice is often made according to the habits and protocols of the service, according to the equipment available and the skills of the gynaecologists.
Aim: The main objective is to compare the efficacy of management by endo-uterine aspiration versus management by hysteroscopy of trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage, at 6 weeks after surgery, by endovaginal ultrasound. The secondary objectives are: the comparison of the rate of complications of the two techniques, during and after surgery the comparison of the rate of recourse to a second line surgical management between the two arms, the comparison of the rate of synechiae diagnosed by hysterosonography between the two techniques at 6 weeks after surgery, the comparison of the time to conception in the two arms during the 2 years after surgery the comparison of the fertility rate at 2 years after surgery in the two arms. Methods: This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-arms, parallel therapeutic clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after spontaneous miscarriage. Patients will be randomized (110 per arm) after verification of eligibility criteria and signature of consent, on the day of the operation: Arm A: 110 patients treated by operative hysteroscopy Arm B: 110 patients treated by endo-uterine aspiration Randomization will be stratified by center, age (<35 years, 35 years and over), size of trophoblastic retention (<30mm, 30mm and over) and scheduled by random size block. It will be centralized (Ennov-clinical software) and parameterized by the Unité́ de Recherche Clinique & Biostatistiques of the Montpellier University Hospital. Statistics: The effectiveness of operative hysteroscopy is expected to be 100%, and that of aspiration 90%. To show this difference with an alpha risk of 5%, and with a power of 90%, 98 patients per arm will have to be analysed (exact binomial distribution calculation, epiR package of R implemented in biostatgv). To take into account a 10% loss of sight rate, 220 patients will be recruted. Patients will be included in the study on the morning of the procedure, after verification of the selection criteria. The expected number of lost to follow-up is estimated at 10%; in fact, the main criterion is evaluated relatively early (6 weeks), in patients having a desire for pregnancy and therefore relatively compliant, the rate of lost to follow-up will be a fairly low. A flow-chart will be constructed to describe the evolution of the populations during the study. It will detail the causes of non-inclusion and the causes of loss to follow-up. All study data will be described according to the randomization arm, in the randomized population: mean, standard deviation, median and quartiles, extrema and number of missing data for quantitative variables, numbers and percentages of each modality for qualitative data. The clinical comparability of the randomized population and the ITT population for the primary endpoint will be assessed. Primary analysis: The uterine vacuity rate will be compared between the two arms in the ITT population for the primary endpoint by a Chi-square test or by a Fisher exact test if the conditions for Chi-square validity are not met. The significance level was set at 5%, two-sided. This study will investigate ways humans make decisions by asking them to draw balls with computerized tasks. In these tasks, participants will be presented with two differently filled jars, one with more blue balls and one with more red balls. They can then make inference from the current jar to determine the colors of the next pair of jars.
The goal is to see how people make decisions when presented with these kinds of jars, and how they can use the information in them to better understand future outcomes.
The study hypotheses are that:
1. In short-term inference, visual and/or haptic cues increase decision making speed.
2. In long-term inference, visual and/or haptic cues decrease decision making speed relative to short-term and single-trial inference.
3. In multi-timescale inference, subjects can use short-term and long-term information to make the best prediction.

Lemborexant is a novel insomnia medication that has shown promise in helping adults achieve a restorative sleep. There is a growing body of literature indicating that this drug has a favourable side effect profile compared to conventional sleep aids, including benzodiazepines, and may have less of an impact on night-time blood pressure. There is no literature on the use of lemborexant for the treatment of insomnia in adults with dementia. Insomnia can wreak havoc on the lives of people living with an early onset dementia, their families, and caregivers since they often lack insight into the extent of their dysfunctional sleep patterns. Many of the treatment options for insomnia in dementia have high incidences of rebound insomnia. With lemborexant, clinicians may be able to treat insomnia without precipitating the problem they are trying to solve. Given the benefits lemborexant may provide, it behooves clinicians to consider it as a reasonable alternative to conventional sedatives prescribed for insomnia in older adults with dementia. A prospective trial of lemborexant will evaluate its tolerability, safety, and effectiveness in individuals that have been diagnosed with an early onset dementia.

Patients suffering from KOA in early stage with knee pain lasting for more than 6 months and whose X-rays show grade 2 or 3 osteoarthritis are eligible. The study is a prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled clinical trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to the Sinomenine group and the glucocorticoid group, each receiving a single intra-articular injection every 4 months. 24 months after enrollment, all enrolled patients will be evaluated by X-rays of the affected limb, questionnaires and MRI of the affected knee (only the patients in Beijing TCM hospital). 
All eligible subjects will return to the outpatient clinics of all research centers twice a month for 3 months and 0.5 months after each injection for assessment of their conditions and adverse reactions. The final follow-up will be in the 24th month after the first injection.
The primary outcome measures are the change in the total WOMAC score from baseline, change in tibial cartilage volume from baseline, improvement in OA symptoms, improvement in lower extremity function, and improvement in quality of life. A total of 120 patients will be recruited, taking into account the possibility of loss to follow-up. The results are expected to show that Sina treatment is as effective as glucocorticoids, but may play an important role in the treatment of early KOA.

Neck pain is one of the most common and painful musculoskeletal conditions. As for most other musculoskeletal disorders, nonspecific neck pain is multifactorial. A variety of different types of exercise have been explored to treat chronic nonspecific neck pain, including low-to-moderate intensity aerobic exercise, high intensity aerobic exercise, stretching exercise and muscular strength exercises and isometrics. However, the most effective form of exercise as a method of rehabilitation non-specific neck pain is unknown reflecting its complexity and more research is require. The rationale of the study is to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion and functional disability in chronic nonspecific neck pain. The main purpose of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy is to release the cervical trigger points, improving end ranges and lengthening of muscle. MDT helps draw toxins out of the muscles and to the superficial veins to be removed by the body. This leads to decreased pain and tension in the tissues. The ultimate goal is to achieve pain free end ranges and flexibility of muscle in nonspecific neck pain patients.

Complications of stoma occur commonly after rectal surgery with extraction of specimen via ileostomy; the most common one is obstruction, accounting for 52%-81%) of all stoma-related complications, of which abdominal skin necrosis is the most common cause, ranging from 11%~35%. The current international standard of stoma closure is the skin-fold method. This method is simple without any special equipment, but stoma complications are significantly higher than that treated by using a prosthesis made of silastic rubber (HANS) and the Ileostomy Dumpling suture method.
The Dumpling suture method with a double-layer sutures that are inserted radially from the stoma opening, making the sutures like Chinese small dumplings, which is expected to decrease the incidence of skin complications. This study is a randomized controlled study to compare the incidence of stoma complications between Dumpling suture method and conventional suture method in rectal cancer surgery with stoma, and evaluate the effect of Dumpling suture method in promoting early wound healing, relieving pain, and improving quality of life of patients with stoma.
For the inclusion criteria: the patients should be scheduled for rectal cancer operation with stoma. There are also limitations such as serious systemic infection, immunosuppressive disease, low expectations of survival more than 6 months, and unsuitable subjects. 
The intervention method is to use traditional suture method or Dumpling suture method; the former is a process similar to traditional suturing with no prosthesis used. Whereas the Dumpling suture method is to use 3-0 silk sutures progressively to close the incision at the lower right abdomen, leaving a gap at the upper and lower edges of the incision. The suture needles are inserted from the middle to the edge of the abdominal wound, and then the needle is pushed out from the bottom along the skin fold towards the abdominal cavity. This is designed to facilitate the reduction of stoma wound edge incision and hiding it.
The research design is a single-center, single-blind, randomized parallel control trial. The study evaluates the incidence rate of stoma, stoma DET score, stoma pain score, quality of life score, stoma revision and restitution rate, and wound healing. The results of this study are expected to provide a basis for improving the rate of stoma complication reduction and improving the quality of life of patients.

Research has shown impaired cognition and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL) in PD patients (Pfeffer et al., 1995; Leurgans et al., 1999; Schneider et al., 2011). The impact of cognitive impairment on everyday functioning depends on the complexity of activities performed by cognitively impaired patients (Ivory et al., 2007). Several tools have been used to assess the impact of neurodegenerative diseases on daily life (Schmitt-Sorend et al., 2002; Lange et al., 2010). However, the applicability of these measures in PD needs to be assessed. Our goal is to determine how well motor symptom severity and cognition predict difficulties in IADL function in PD patients. Therefore, we aim to investigate the correlation of performance in several motor subscales (including freezing of gait), cognitive subscales, and IADL scores. Based on our results, we will develop a questionnaire to assess the difficulties in everyday IADL performance in PD patients. These results will also help to understand which cognitive domains are affected when motor problems occur.

Myofibrillation after succinylcholine injection can cause anesthesia patients to be unable to breathe, and even death. The incidence of anesthesia-related myofibrillation is relatively low, but anesthesiologists have to deal with many patients, causing a large number of patients to be at risk of anesthesia-myofibrillation. The incidence of myofibrillation associated with neuromuscular blockade is directly related to the dose of succinylcholine applied. The incidence of myofibrillation will be increased by the dose used. Nowadays, when anesthesiologists need to prevent myofibrillation, they generally use rocuronium as a prophylactic agent. Rocuronium has excellent muscle relaxation, a short action time and few cardiac side effects. However, the doses used in different age groups are different. The incidence of myofibrillation in the elderly is higher than that in young people. The dose of rocuronium in the elderly is higher than that in young people. Based on preliminary studies, we designed this study to observe the minimum effective dose of rocuronium in preventing myofibrillation in different age groups of patients. We hope that the minimum effective dose of rocuronium can be used to prevent myofibrillation in different age groups in the future.

Pollutants, particulate and volatile organic compounds and microplastics, are ubiquitous in the environment and have been implicated in carcinogenesis, inflammation, and oxidation.
Evidence has emerged recently on the role of air pollution, particulate and volatile organic compounds, in the development of atherosclerosis through the recruitment on monocyte and the promotion of the proinflammatory and oxidative phenotype of atheroma. Moreover, several recent reports suggest a possible role of microplastics in the pathogenesis of several chronic diseases, including cardiovascular disorders. The investigators postulate that these pollutants may act via similar pathways.
The aim of the study is to investigate whether the presence and the burden of volatile organic compounds and microplastics from atherosclerotic plaques would be associated with major clinical outcomes in patients undergoing surgery for the removal of carotid stenosis. To this purpose, 300 consecutive patients with asymptomatic disease will be enlisted and will be followed up for 2 years after surgery. Carotid plaques will be retrieved with high precision during the procedure through micro-scissors or atherectomy catheters and will then be analysed for the presence and the amount of organic pollutants. Corroboratory analyses will be performed by electron microscopy to identify the pollutants under the microscope.
Plaque-derived samples will also be analysed through immunohistochemistry, ELISAs, and Western Blot to quantify inflammatory markers and assess the plaque stability. In addition, patients will be categorized (post-hoc) as having polluted plaques (having detectable levels of at least one microplastics) or non-polluted plaques, and Cox regression analysis will be used to examine the association between the presence of pollutants and the composite outcome, adjusted for age, sex, BMI, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, the prevalence of diabetes, dyslipidaemia, and smoking. Among those with polluted plaques, the burden of microplastics will be used to categorize patients into terciles, and Cox models, adjusted for the same variables, will be run to explore the relationship between the burden of microplastics and the outcome. In this manner, the study will be capable of exploring the role of these environmental pollutants in the clinical evolution of patients with atherosclerosis.
Patients will be further followed up and monitored for the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality. The groups of patients with polluted plaques vs non-polluted plaques will be compared for the expression of all these markers.
At present, the effects of environmental pollutants on the incidence of cardiovascular events in patients with atherosclerosis remain unknown. By providing novel insights on the role of these pollutants, either individually or as a group, in atherosclerotic plaques, it may provide new insight to identify patients with greater risk of cardiovascular events.  The insights obtained from the study may help to identify new therapeutic targets and guide future interventions to improve cardiovascular health.

Inclusion Criteria: patients with carotid stenosis (according to North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial classification ) enlisted to undergo carotid endarterectomy for extracranial high-grade (>70%) internal carotid artery stenosis.

Exclusion Criteria: All patients with clinical or laboratory evidence of heart failure, valvular defects, malignant neoplasms, or secondary causes of hypertension will be excluded from the study.

To learn more about this study, you or your doctor may contact the study information by visiting this website.

Transarterial radioembolization (TARE) is a palliative therapy for unresectable liver metastases in patients with colorectal cancer. It is performed by the transarterial delivery of small microspheres made of medical glass. To date, therapeutic decision-making based on effective tumor doses in TARE treatments is based solely on the size of the tumor. However, we now have a precise, high-resolution technique that allows to obtain additional important information about the state and the behavior of tumors at very low doses of radiation.
The investigators propose to conduct a national multicenter retrospective study to determine the relationship between effective tumor dose and healthy tissue dose on the response of patients to TARE treatment in liver metastases of colorectal cancer. This will help to find a correlation between dose delivered to metastatic lesions and their response to treatment. To determine this, the investigators will examine the effective tumor dose and, consequently, the effective healthy tissue dose in 18 patients.
Additionally, the investigators would like to study the response to treatment in the first six months post-TARE in 108 patients with at least one additional follow-up PET-CT examination. Based on a comparison of dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships after TARE in these patients, it is intended to calculate the response-effective dose.

The performance of conventional glass ionomer cements (GICs) are inferior compared to resin composites due to their poor mechanical and physical properties for restoration of carious cavity. However, recent studies revealed that improvement in GICs can be obtained by radiant heat transfer. This study aims to evaluate the influence of light-emitting diode (LED) radiant heat energy transfer enhancement on clinical performance of high-caries-risk patients, restoring the carious cavity with chemically cured conventional glass ionomer after 12 months. Eighteen healthy patients aged 21 to 45 years, with two oclusso- mesial cavities will be selected . The patients will be randomly divided into two groups; Group M1 will be restored with chemically cured conventional GICs (KetacTM Universal AplicapTM) without any enhancement (M1 group), while group M2 will be restored with chemically cured conventional GICs enhanced with LED radiant heat (M2 group). The clinician who performed the restorations was blinded to type of enhancement used. Restoration of all the selected cavities will be performed following manufacturer instruction and all clinical evaluations will be carried out using the FDI criteria at baseline (T0), 12 months (T1) and 24 months (T2). Data collected from this study may provide evidence in predicting the success rate of conventional glass ionomer after enhancement with LED radiant heat energy transfer.

The FAPO SI³ digital telemonitoring platform aimed to provide patients with a wearable device to track post-operative activity, heart rate, and sleep. Patients were required to monitor their heart rhythm through the smartwatch, as well as answer simple questions and respond to educational messages displayed on their smartphone app. Remote monitoring was conducted through the cloud platform, and alerts were automatically sent to the physician when abnormal readings were detected. If alerts were raised, a protocol for clinical intervention was determined with guidance from the telemedicine physician. In the six-month follow-up evaluation, the control group did not differ from the telemonitored group in rehospitalization rate, attendance at scheduled consultations, extra occurences, or any other outcome parameter assessed. The overall findings showed that the platform was efficient, with good participant adherence and engagement throughout the study. No patient developed any complications, and the 30-day evaluation of the primary outcome, which assessed rehospitalization rates, revealed no difference between standard care and telemedicine telemonitoring. However, further studies with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up are needed to determine the long-term impact of the intervention.

Specifically, the aim of this study is to test whether the adoption of HSMonitor solutions by healthcare professionals and patients improves the management of patients with high blood pressure. This will be a randomised controlled trial where patients with hypertension will be randomised either to one of the two digital solutions or to standard care. The present pilot study is planned to be carried out within the framework of the EU project HSMonitor - Pre-commercial Procurement of innovative ICT-enabled monitoring to improve health status and optimize hypertension care (Grant Agreement Nr. 856698). The two solutions are referred to as: Solution 1 - HSmartBPM (developed by a supplier consortium led by GNOMON) Solution 2 - HyperHealth (developed by a supplier consortium led by TECH4CARE)

This will be a randomised controlled trial with participants that are patients with uncontrolled high blood pressure followed within secondary care in the General Hospital of Valida. A sample size of 46 subjects in each intervention arm is estimated in order to have a power of 80% and alpha of 0.05.
To control for confounding variables (e.g., other comorbidities), a stratified randomisation approach will be followed to randomise participants across treatment arms.
Patients randomised to the intervention will be followed for six months. They will attend four training sessions with the digital solutions.
The outcome measure that will be used is the change in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. The assessment will be done at enrolment (T0), at three months (T1) and at six months (T2).

The purpose of this study is to conduct a randomised controlled trial focusing on screening for liver disease. The trial intends to invite participants to liver stiffness measurement (Transient Elastography), blood sampling and a leaflet on alcohol-related disease. The participants are recruited on their way to treatment for their alcohol use disorder. We aim to assess whether it is possible to conduct additional investigations on patients with alcohol use disorder and the effect of this additional screening on alcohol consumption and liver disease progression. We will invite around 500 individuals aged ≥ 18 years to liver stiffness measurement (Transient Elastography). Individuals will be enrolled in a randomised controlled trial with random assignment to either a control or an intervention group. Participants allocated to the control group will serve as a comparison group. The investigators have no knowledge of the group-assignment until all groups are constructed.
All participants get an invitation by mail inviting them to participate in the study and an invitation to the first intervention or control visit. The study participants meet either in a public place or at the clinic if invited for liver stiffness measurement or blood sampling. Participants will receive a brochure on their alcohol-related liver disease, and participants who were invited for liver stiffness measurement and/or blood sampling get this as part of the control- or intervention group. In the intervention-arm we will conduct Transient Elastography or blood sampling if the participant is randomised to this arm. Based on the liver stiffness measurement results a discussion on alcohol consumption is held with the investigators. Afterwards the participant is offered participation in a screening program at one of the centres. At 6- and 12-months follow-up, all participants will receive a survey by mail. The same data is collected from all participants at all follow-up data collections, including an alcohol screen based on the AUDIT-C. Thus, this will form the follow-up period of 12 months.

Study of the Value of Trio Exome Sequencing in the Etiological Assessment of Specific Non-syndromic Language and Learning Disorders
=================

Detailed Description
-----------------
Introduction: Despite the progress made in the genetics of SLLDs, the genetic mutations are identified before in more than 50% of people. It is therefore possible that these mutations represent the first step of a path towards the development of personalized medicine in the sector. There are however some rare syndromes where progression is slower and less frequent than in the rest of the population. Indeed, among a cohort of 100 probands with SLLDs, 84% of cases are not syndromic. Among the 16% of syndromic subjects without phenotypic abnormalities, about half are already diagnosed. A first group of syndromes corresponds to known syndromes such as Fragile X syndrome and Down syndrome, which are more often described and recognized. A second group of syndromes corresponds to syndromes of a less recurrent pathophysiological origin, including the mitochondrial encephalomyopathies, for example. Other rare syndromes, less pathogenically known like Rett syndrome, represent less than 5% of severe SLLDs. It is therefore unlikely to detect these diagnoses by a whole genome or whole exome sequencing (WES). These SLLDs are thus considered as non-syndromic, even if they are often characterized by several anomalies on neuropsychological assessments suggesting the possible contribution, even if minor, of a variant present on the genome or in mitochondria. The goal of our project is to identify the genetic cause(s) of SLLDs. For this purpose, trio exome sequencing will be carried out in a cohort of 400 SLLD patients whose phenotype is characterized by neuropsychological examinations, including the use of specific scales (language, reading, calculation, non-verbal intelligence, memory, executive function, visual perception, motor and visuo-motor praxia ), but also a battery of tests in the health fields and the psychosocial field (assessment of the child's behavioral and emotional profile and the psycho-educational impact of the SLLD). A second battery of biological tests will be carried out simultaneously: array-CGH and karyotype as a first step in a systematic form, and exome sequencing as a second step for patients with a negative array-CGH, an FMR1 mutation or a mitochondrial pathology with a non-diagnostic array CGH. A positive genetic result (presence of a single or multi-gene mutation) will mean that this mutation is the one responsible for the phenotype in question. If the genetic analysis does not reveal a significant result, phenotypic data will have to be completed by expert medical and psychological examinations. A biological study of exomes (exome sequencing) and mitochondrial DNA will be carried out in 400 children and their parents or siblings. This strategy, which involves the analysis of the genetic status of the three people concerned (index case + parents), offers the opportunity to obtain a result likely to provide an answer in the case of a negative result on a trio or on specific syndromes (Fragile X, Down). The study will be carried out on parents and a child for whom they are parents. The index case is defined as any child suffering from a severe learning disorder (major educational support in school, learning disorder of reading or arithmetic or major difficulties in language or non verbal communication) and a neuropsychological or speech therapy assessment that certifies an abnormality. The index case must have one genetic parent or sibling who will be selected as biological parents for this study. The exome sequence will bring a double advantage: to detect a variant responsible for the phenotype, and to test its pathogenicity, even if it is not the only responsible. This will help better understand the mechanisms of inheritance and identify familial, familial + unknown genetic causes. The analysis of exomes includes the study of the 20 000 genes, making it possible to identify the abnormalities responsible for the learning disability. The sequencing and processing of 400 trios will be carried out by the Molecular Genetics-Cancer platform of the University Hospital Saint-Etienne - CHU of Saint-Etienne (the largest platform for biomolecular analysis in France). Biological samples will be transported and stored in this center. The medical, neuro-psychological and genetic data will be collected and

The use of antibody therapy for cancer treatment has been increasing to help improve the survival rate of cancer patients. However, existing drugs cannot target the tumor to accurately kill the cancer cells while avoiding damage to normal cells. Postoperative sleep is one of the most important factors in postoperative recovery and an important part of the sleep/wake cycle. Although sleep difficulties occur in the perioperative period as short-term or long-term, sleep disorders can impair physical, cognitive and emotional functions, complicate postoperative recovery, and increase mortality and morbidity rates. It is necessary to determine the factors that affect postoperative sleep disorders for an early intervention. In surgery, the type of anesthesia is also important in preoperative sleep assessment. It was thought that the method of epidural anesthesia in orthopedic surgery may not cause sleep disturbance. Recent studies have shown that regional anesthesia is more advantageous than general anesthesia in terms of postoperative sleep disturbance and pain control. It is not clear whether regional anesthesia affects the circadian rhythm. The hypothesis of the investigator is that the difference in pain control between the anesthesia types plays a role in postoperative sleep quality.

The investigators hypothesize that regional anesthesia does not disrupt the circadian rhythm compared to general anesthesia, is more successful in pain control, and thus provides better sleep quality for patients. The primary objective of this study is to evaluate postoperative sleep quality in patients who undergo total hip arthroplasty with regional or general anesthesia and the secondary objective is to evaluate the effect of anesthesia type on circadian rhythm disruption.

Background: Atogepant is an anti-calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) monoclonal antibody approved as a preventive treatment in episodic migraine.
Objective: This study will assess if atogepant can reduce migraine headache days and overall frequency of headache days with oral dosing.
Study design: This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study in Japanese subjects with episodic migraine. Following a placebo run-in period (3 weeks), subjects were randomized to atogepant dose A (75 mg QD), dose B (255 mg QD) or dose C (505 mg QD), or placebo for 12 weeks. After Week 12, subjects in the placebo group will continue to receive placebo, while subjects in the atogepant dose groups will continue at their randomly assigned dose of atogepant for an additional 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures were the change from baseline in the mean monthly migraine days, and the percentage of participants achieving ≥ 50% reduction in the 3-month average of monthly migraine days. The safety of atogepant was also evaluated.
Sample size: A total of approximately 870 participants are planned to be enrolled.
Expected results: The study will determine the efficacy and safety of atogepant in Japanese subjects with episodic migraine for up to 24 weeks in preventing migraine headaches, supporting the evaluation of its potential as a new therapeutic option for this indication. It will serve as a basis for the registration of atogepant for the management of episodic migraine in Japanese patients.

One common and significant problem during liver transplantation is a shortage of blood and related products, mainly red blood cells (RBCs). This leads to the need to transfuse massive amounts of RBCs and blood components. This is an important issue because in spite of advances in surgical techniques, immunosuppressive drugs, and intensive care, surgical complications are still the leading causes of death after liver transplantation, and patients are prone to developing transfusion-associated immunomodulation and transfusion-transmitted pathogens in large part due to immunosuppression and transfusion. Blood salvage has been increasingly used in the last two decades. The technique is used for collecting large volumes of blood lost during surgery and processing them to concentrate of red blood cells in a single process. In order to avoid the use of massive amounts of allogenic blood, it seems reasonable to collect blood during organ procurement and to transfuse it back to recipient after processing. However, there are no reports in the literature on the feasibility of collecting such amounts of blood from liver donors.
In this context, the investigators propose a feasibility study to collect donor blood for processing and transfusion to the recipient at the time that the liver is procured from cadaveric donors.
Objective: To collect, process and give back to recipient a large amount of RBCs recovered from liver donor during organ procurement.
Main outcome Measure: The primary outcome is the rate of successful and problem free LT using autologous donor RBC concentrates.
Secondary outcome Measure: To compare the rate of adverse events.
Study design: All adult patients receiving a liver transplant from deceased donors at Fondazione Policlinico A. Gemelli IRCCS (Rome, Italy) will be eligible for the study. All patients will be screened and a written informed consent will be required to enroll patients to the study.

The purpose of this study is to investigate where the 'cut off' is in terms of the minimum of tissue samples needed in order to establish a reliable diagnosis using CESB in women with ROLs. CESB is not part of the regular clinical workflow but has to be performed in case a suspicious lesion is only visible on the enhanced image of a CEM examination. The reason for this study is to improve efficiency of this procedure by enabling us to determine the minimum amount of breast parenchyma that needs to be sampled for an accurate diagnosis.
In this prospective, observational study, CESB is performed in a structured fashion enabling the chronological order of tissue specimens to be determined and correlate such specimens to the final histopathological result. Each lesion will be sampled using a 9-guage VAC, and using a standardized specimen collection protocol, 6 separate cassettes will be filled per specimen. These specimens will subsequently be processed in a standardized fashion, including H&E staining and immunohistochemistry (if necessary). By correlating the final histopathological result with the number of biopsies performed and their order of sampling, we aim to determine the minimum number of biopsies required in case a patient presents with an ROL.
The main outcome measure of this study will be the 'cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen', which will enable us to determine the minimum amount of tissue to be sampled during CESB in order to obtain a reliable diagnosis for women with ROLs. Secondary study endpoints can provide additional information regarding the quality and accuracy of CESB-based diagnoses, including the technical details of the sampling procedure (e.g., rate of technical failures, complication rate), lesion characteristics (e.g., biopsy outcome of benign vs. malignant CESB biopsies, BI-RADS score of the initial CEM examination), as well as patient comfort as assessed by pain scores.

Introduction: Septate Uterus (SU) is the commonest congenital uterine anomaly. It occurs in 3% of women with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss or subfertility. Hysteroscopic septum incision is the mainstay of treatment for SU to increase fertility potential and to reduce the incidence of preterm birth in cases of pregnancy. Hysteroscopic septum incision can be performed by different modalities including scissors or resectoscope with the aim of comparing results of these modalities in women with septate or subseptate uterus.
Objectives: The purpose of our work was to compare the operative time, fluid deficit, complications and number of revisions and number of live births of septum incision by scissors versus by monopolar resectoscope in the same group of women with septate or subseptate uterus.
Study design: Prospective randomized clinical trial
Study duration and place: For at least 24 months, Patients admitted to Obstetrics and Gynecology department at Mansoura University Hospital.
Study method: At baseline, the following will be done:
History taking: personal history, menstrual history, obstetrical and gynecological history, present and past history.
Patient presentation (subfertility or pregnancy loss)
Physical examination: General, abdominal and local examination.
Diagnosis of uterine septum either by hysterosalpingogram (HSG), Three dimensional transvaginal ultrasound or office hysteroscopy.
Thereafter:
Patients will be prospectively recruited and randomized by computer program to 2 groups
Group A: Patients in this group will undergo resection of the septum with hysteroscope and scissors. Saline will be used as a distending medium in the scissors group. Septal incision will be carried out using a thinning technique by which incisions will be made along each side of the septum alternately from one cornual end to the other
Group B: Patients in this group will undergo resection of the septum with Monopolar 26 French resectoscope Dilation of cervical os with Hegar's dilator (up to hegar 8 or 9) , incision of the septum using a resectoscope with the Collins knife, monopolar energy (cut 40-70 Watt) and glycine 1.5% as the distension medium, using shortening or thinning incision. The operation was stopped if the fluid deficit exceeded 1000 ml of glycine. The delivery of distension media was conducted by automated pressure delivery system. All patients were prescribed cyclic estrogen and progesterone for two months.
Inclusion criteria: Women of reproductive age Seeking conception Diagnosis of a septate or subseptate uterus
A history of one of the following: Recurrent pregnancy loss Subfertility Preterm Birth
Exclusion criteria: Not seeking conception Diagnosis of septate or subseptate uterus with no history of any of the following: Recurrent pregnancy loss Subfertility Preterm Birth
Contraindications for surgery Those who refused to participate.
The study will provide valuable data for those who are still debating this issue, hence they can base their decision on objective data.

Long COVID is a new public health issue that affects as many as one-third of patients recently infected with SARS-CoV-2 and one-sixth of the population. The severity of these symptoms is variable, and the main symptoms are fatigue, dyspnoea, anxiety and depressive disorders, cognitive disorders, pain, sleep disorders. There are currently no effective treatments available.
The aim of the study is to assess the effectiveness of a respiratory training to cardiac coherence on the reduction in the symptomatology of patients with Long COVID at the Reunion University Hospital.
The study will include 124 patients with Long COVID who have been infected with SARS-CoV-2.
Patients will be randomized in two groups, one with complementary respiratory training to cardiac coherence during 7 weeks and the second without training.
We will evaluate the efficiency of this intervention in reducing and delaying the symptoms at 3 months and 6 months, as well as its impact on daily life.
The training will be in the form of breathing and paced breathing, in addition to 10 minutes of cardiac coherence daily, for a total duration of 7 weeks. Cardiac coherence is a simple paced breathing device that uses a metronome.
We will evaluate the impact of the disease on activities of daily life using the Long COVID Impact Tool.
We will also evaluate the intensity of physical fatigue using the Long COVID Symptom Tool (ST).
The study will be monocentric, single centre, double blind, randomized, controlled trial (RCT) with no masking.

The recent success of targeting Janus Kinase (JAK) in the management of hematological malignancies has led to an increasingly prevalent use of oral JAK inhibitors, such as ibrutinib. Ibrutinib has significantly broadened the treatment armamentarium and improved the outcome of patients with hematological malignancies. Despite the high efficacy, ibrutinib is also associated with several adverse events that may, in some cases, limit its use. Indeed, it has been associated with several cardiovascular complications that may be either cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., hypertension, peripheral artery disease and venous thromboembolism) or cardiovascular complications (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Given the long use of ibrutinib to be expected, it is now essential to address the main challenges of this treatment, which include the development of atrial fibrillation, thromboembolic events, and peripheral artery disease. Although several studies and case series have addressed the incidence of atrial fibrillation or peripheral lesions during ibrutinib treatment, there is still limited data on the frequency and mechanisms of thromboembolic events. Based on these facts, we will establish a cohort including 100 patients treated with ibrutinib for B cell hematological malignancies. During the follow-up period, which will last twelve months after the beginning of ibrutinib treatment, we will monitor their cardiovascular status by ophthalmological examination (to detect atrial fibrillation and retinal changes), a blood test for biomarkers of cardiovascular events, and clinical controls to evaluate the development of cardiovascular complication. As stated by the pharmaco-vigilance reports of ibrutinib, the monitoring of these parameters should help in the detection of both early complications and those related to long-term follow-up. Moreover, it opens new avenues in the field of research by identifying possible markers of predisposition to thromboembolic events in patients under ibrutinib treatment and paving the way for the introduction of preventive measures to increase the safety of ibrutinib. Overall, the establishment of this cohort is expected to benefit both patients and the healthcare delivery system by better monitoring thromboembolic events and to contribute to new ways of thinking about the management of ibrutinib.

Phosphate retention and acid-base disturbances are common in patients with end-stage renal disease on maintenance hemodialysis (HD). The aim of the study was to test the hypothesis, that modifying dialysate bicarbonate does affect both phosphate removal and blood acid-base in HD patients and whether the blood phosphorus concentration change (Δ) can be maintained in the range of 1.0. The hypothesis is based on the fact, that phosphate removal is directly dependent on the blood pH during HD, as dialysate H+ ions compete with phosphate for binding sites in the hemolymph membrane. The study was designed as an open, two period, randomized, controlled, crossover study with three groups. Phosphate removal was significantly lower during the Dbic change than it was during the constant Dbic periods. Blood phosphorus Δ during Dbic change treatment was significantly higher and more rapid with smaller inter-individual variability, although only in the B type change period. However, the blood phosphorus concentration was maintained in the target range of pH in all groups. These results confirm the direct relationship between the blood phosphorus concentration change and the bicarbonate concentration change in the dialysis fluid during HD. These data, if proven to be clinically relevant, will lead to the recommendation that, in order to remove more phosphate, it might be necessary to change the dialysate bicarbonate concentration during HD, but it will be necessary to avoid blood acid-alkalosis or alkalosis, respectively.

Recent studies have shown that in patients with chronic radicular low back pain, lumbar traction improved pain, function and range of motion. However, the optimal position of application of traction is not known in such patients. The aim of this study is to determine the effect of vertical sitting versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain. This study design and methods are based on the recommendations of the Cogill-Lombardi-Moseley (2015) et al. for the best practice clinical trial.
                This study is a randomized controlled prospective clinical trial. The sample includes 40 subjects with chronic radicular low back pain and aged between 20 and 50. The sample will be randomized into 2 groups. Group-A will be exposed to vertical sitting traction, and group-B will be exposed to vertical supine traction with the help of continuous mechanical traction. At the initial and final assessment, their pain will be measured with the use of the NPRS scale. Disability will be measured with the use of the Oswestry Disability Rating Scale. The range of motion will be measured with the use of FLEXICAPTE range of motion device.

The result of this study will provide a useful measure of pain, function, and range of motion, also provides information about the superior therapeutic position, and it can be adopted by physiotherapists after the completion of this study.

Introduction: Coeliac disease (CD) is a chronic immune disorder that affects the small intestine and can lead to malabsorption of nutrients. CD often presents with unspecific symptoms and can remain undiagnosed for prolonged periods of time. Diagnosis is confirmed by a combination of intestinal biopsy, CD specific serology and histology of the small intestine. Intestinal biopsies serve as a gold standard to obtain pathological diagnosis but have well known complications. In recent years, commercial kits for rapid testing of CD specific antibodies such as IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase 2 (IgA-tTG2) have been developed.
Here we propose an alternative approach to identify patients with CD or IgA-deficiency using an anti-EMA, E179 monoclonal antibody assay performed on supernatant of mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimen. This test has not been previously evaluated and therefore the aim of this study is to evaluate the diagnostic values of anti-EMA and rapid anti-TG2 (E179) assay performed on supernatant of mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimen and to assess their concordance with the standard approach to CD diagnosis (Histology + serology).
Methods: This is an observational study where patients selected for elective esophagogastroduodenoscopy, for clinical indications such as suspected coeliac disease, eosinophilic esophagitis, autoimmune enteropathy, inflammatory bowel disease, gastritis, gastric or duodenal ulcer, gastroesophageal reflux disease will be recruited. Participants will undergo standard upper endoscopy to collect biopsies from the duodenum, which will be lysed mechanically and tested for anti-EMA and rapid anti-TG2 assay (E179) against a commercial control (Cell Line Reference Tissue Human Fixed Paraffin Embedded Section). Participants will also receive standard serology testing in the routine clinical laboratory (Immune system, Tissue Transglutaminase, IgA/IgG). These assays will be performed at the time of the endoscopic examination.
Main study variables will be the diagnostic values (sensitivity & specificity) of EMA assay and rapid anti-TG2 using supernatant of mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens against the reference standard (histology and serology). The concordance of these assays will also be evaluated against the standard of care (culture and EMA). Patients with and without IgA-deficiency and IgA-CD patients will be also analyzed separately to identify differential biomarkers.
Study size will be determined by power analysis and 700 patients will be recruited within 6 months.
Expected benefits: This study will provide novel, non-invasive diagnostic tools for CD diagnosis which are faster and safer than the current clinical practice. A rapid and rapid on site EMA antibody assay would facilitate point of care diagnosis of CD in patients with unclear gastrointestinal symptoms. The study may be also applied to other CD biomarkers as well as to other immunologic disorders (eosinophilic esophagitis or autoimmune enteropathy etc.). These results will provide important data which will impact the clinical decision-making and may lead to future diagnostic approaches for patients with unclear gastrointestinal symptoms.

Patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) are at risk of stroke. The most effective treatment for stroke prevention in AF is a class of drugs called anticoagulants. Many clinicians and patients underestimate the stroke risk in AF, and many at-risk patients are not treated with anticoagulants. We have developed and performed initial testing for a new web-based decision aid for AF patients called Risk Assessment and Personal Preferences to Improve Decisions for Atrial Fibrillation (RAPID AFib).

This study represents the next step in this program of research, by conducting a formal evaluation of the performance of one of the functions of the RAPID AFib decision aid in a real-world clinical setting. The goal is to determine if using the RAPID AFib in shared decision-making discussions between AF patients and their providers is acceptable and leads to more effective shared decision-making than standard care.

Participants will be patients with a new diagnosis of atrial fibrillation who have not yet selected a stroke prevention therapy. During their visit, they will complete a brief survey, take a 25-minute web-based survey, receive information about strokes in AF, then review the RAPID AFib decision aid. After the visit, they will complete an online survey for which they can win a prize (receipt of their choice valued up to $100).

Participants will return to clinic in 3 months for a second visit. During the follow-up visit, they will perform a brief survey, then review their prior Summary Report and report any side effects of treatment. Then, they will complete another survey on the website that can be won, and then they will be discharged from the study.

Heart failure (HF) is an increasingly common chronic disease with high morbidity and growing societal costs in Africa, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. In Uganda, the prevalence of HF is 2.9%, with the majority of patients being undiagnosed and receiving sub-optimal care. The investigators' multi-component implementation strategy (MediLY Uganda) will be developed, evaluated and refined during the MedLY Uganda project, an intervention-based study. The intervention includes Medli Uganda, a digital health intervention, and Core HF, evidence-based HF clinical care. Medly Uganda consists of a patient-facing mobile health application which processes patient-reported symptoms and generates algorithm-driven self-care and symptom response management advice. It utilizes a clinician-facing digital platform that identifies patients requiring further intervention and facilitates nurse-guided management recommendations and physician backup support. The Medli Uganda clinical trial (ISRCTN27319012) was registered on 5/29/2017. The Medli Uganda intervention will be evaluated in 4 public referral hospitals in rural Uganda. The investigators will conduct a pretest-posttest quasi-experimental design over 3 years, which aligns with the national multi-year healthcare strategy. The evaluation will be guided by the Framework for Improving Complex Health System Interventions. Data will be collected in person at the participating hospitals by research assistants. All data will be recorded on a computerized web-based REDCap system. The investigators will track study recruitment, conduct surveys with patients and healthcare providers, and measure patient adherence to HF medication. Additionally, the investigators will collect patient blood samples for natriuretic peptide levels, ECG data, and cardiac ultrasound data. The investigators will track patient vital signs (weight, blood pressure, and pulse rates) using digital health metrics incorporated in the digital health intervention. The data collected will be linked using patient consent. The investigators will also conduct a process evaluation to assess the implementation process and identify challenges to the implementation process. The investigators will also conduct a cost evaluation to evaluate the cost effectiveness of the intervention. 30 patients will be recruited at each of the 4 study site hospitals, resulting in a total of 120 patients enrolled over 36 months. The investigators will enroll 30 patients each during 2 phases, one before the digital intervention is introduced and one after. These data will allow the investigators to evaluate the effect of the digital health intervention on HF clinical outcomes compared to the control arms receiving CoreHF. This pilot study will evaluate the initial feasibility of introducing and maintaining a novel digital-first care deLivery model to improve outcomes for people with HF in resource-limited settings.

In the last 10 years, the understanding of pediatric rhabdoid tumors has evolved significantly; however, the natural history of therapy-naïve or recurrent/progressive pediatric rhabdoid tumors (rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS), atypical teratoid/rhabdoid (AT/RT), and extra-cranial (ECR) malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT)) remains very poor, and most patients either never achieve remission or have a very short remission duration. Therefore, for patients with rhabdoid tumors beyond first relapse (progressive disease), only experimental therapeutic approaches are available within clinical trials. A promising strategy is to identify and target key tumor-intrinsic vulnerabilities of therapy-naïve and recurrent rhabdoid tumors for the development of novel therapeutic strategies. An important feature for the development of rhabdoid tumors is the recurrent mutations in several core histone genes, encoding the histone proteins H4K17, H3K34, or H3K34, which play roles in chromatin structure, gene expression, and regulation. These mutations have several functional consequences, including reduced methylation on lysine 64 of histone H3 (H3K64me), leading to increased methyltransferase complex formation and elevated expression of transcriptional elongation factors (MEFs), including Mediator complex subunit MED1. MEFs promote cancer-specific gene expression programs, such as enhanced proliferation, increased angiogenesis, and enhanced glucose metabolism and therefore offer an important therapeutic target opportunity. Inhibition of the MED1 by small molecule compounds such as selinexor (KPT-330) is currently an established therapy for adults with multiple myeloma. However, in patients with rhabdoid tumors, selinexor alone has no effect on tumor growth, and it rather seems to provide an important mechanism of resistance in response to chemotherapy or radiotherapy in these patients.
This multicenter phase II study (phase 1 in the dose finding/safety phase) aims to explore the combination of selinexor as an oral, once daily compound with a histone acetyltransferase inhibitor, idasanutlin, which has been shown to re-establish H3K64me and inhibit MEFs in adults with myeloid malignancies as well as inhibit tumor growth in an orthotopic AT/RT preclinical model. The overall aim is to test whether combination treatment with oral idasanutlin and selinexor can overcome MEF resistance in children with recurrent or progressive AT/RT or MRT and thereby open a new therapeutic avenue for these otherwise untreatable types of tumors.

Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma is a devastating cancer that mainly affects males and females over the age of 65 years. About 20% of newly diagnosed PDAC have neo-adjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection. Surgery represents the only potentially curative treatment. The overall perioperative morbidity and mortality are about 50%. Several retrospective studies reported that the preoperative functional status of a patient strongly influences the postoperative morbidity and consequently the oncological outcome. These aspects are particularly relevant in PDAC patients who have comorbidity and impaired nutritional, immunological and physical status. Prehabilitation is a multimodal intervention including physical, nutritional and psychological training specifically designed to counteract or improve these aspects. So far, in the oncological context, prehabilitation has been used mainly in patients undergoing hematopoietic transplantation or gastrointestinal surgery, demonstrating beneficial outcomes on morbidity and mortality. There are only few prospective studies in cancer patients who undergo major surgery, including PDAC surgery. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week long preoperative intervention on the outcome of patients affected by localized pancreatic cancer who will undergo chemotherapy followed by surgical resection. More specifically we will compare a multimodal intervention including exercise training, nutritional therapy and anxiety Reduction Techniques , with usual standard of care preoperative care.

The early loss of pregnancy is very common with an incidence rate of approximately 15% from all clinically recognized pregnancies. The etiology of early pregnancy loss is largely unknown, although both fetal and maternal chromosomal and anatomical abnormalities of the uterus have been implicated. Miscarriage often arises before the expected gestational age without symptoms. There is no effective therapeutic remedy for it. The rate of spontaneous abortion can be affected by numerous factors such as maternal age, previous pregnancy history, uterine malformation, and immunological factors. Ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA) is one of the treatment options for managing with miscarriage or termination of pregnancy (TOP) in first trimester loss. It has been considered to be a viable option in women who are not good candidates for surgical operations, as MVA is performed outside the standard surgical settings.
The immunological profile in the decidua may affect the receptiveness of the uterus, with the ultimate aim for the establishment of pregnancy. Changes in decidual T-cell subpopulations have been reported in women with recurrent miscarriage, but little correlation with karyotypic abnormalities have been found. It is important to study the immunological profile of women after miscarriage.
In recent years, next generation sequencing (NGS) technology has revolutionized the genetic diagnostic field, enabling the assessment of numerous candidate gene variants associated with clinical or laboratory phenotypes from as little as 1µg of DNA sample. Previous work from our team has optimized a novel computational model for the detection of chromosome-level and sub-chromosome copy number variants, named low-pass genome sequencing (GS).
It has been found that up to 8% of spontaneous abortions have no detectable genetic abnormality, known as pregnancy of uncertain etiology (PUCE). A subset of PUCE may have a genetic etiology, which is masked by the limitation of current technologies or an improper analysis of data obtained from the previous test. With the development of new sequencing technology and computational methods, it is possible to detect cryptic structural rearrangements, SNVs, and AOH.
This is an observational study, with the primary aim of histopathologic diagnosis of chorionic villi. In this study, POCs obtained from MVA procedure were rinsed in normal saline thoroughly in the kidney basin to minimize maternal blood. Chorionic villi were considered as a proxy of fetal genetics, appeared to be yellowish in color and tree-projection-like in appearance, floating on the surface of the waterline. Decidua are originated from the mother, appeared substantive in structure and sank in the basin. The two different types of tissues are separated from each other for different testing. The secondary aim of immunohistochemistry staining of maternal decidua was also set to correlate the immunological phenotype of uterine decidual tissues to the underlying karyotypic aberrations.
POCs derived from first trimester miscarriage or TOP were collected from women having first trimester loss (5-12 weeks of pregnancy). The karyotyping of POCs were performed using array-based comparative genomic hybridization (aCGH). Maternal decidua were collected from women of uncomplicated pregnancies matched for clinical-biological characteristics (CBC) of patients with miscarriage. The histopathology of POCs and the immunofluorescence staining of maternal decidua were assessed to study the tissue morphology and the immunological phenotyped.

For the karyotyping of POCs, the following chromosomal abnormalities will be determined:
- trisomy 16 (47XY+16 or 47XX+16), since the chromosome abnormality trisomy 16, which occurs in 26% of all spontaneous abortions, is incompatible with life and would thus be an undisputed cause of spontaneous abortion.
- POCs of normal male conceptus (46XY), which is a comparator group to understand the baseline chromosomal abnormality rate.

Patients or their relatives would be asked if they would agree to provide some blood sample for genetic testing. Informed consent would be obtained from them before any blood tests would be carried out. DNA would be extracted from a 3ml blood sample following the standardized laboratory protocol

It is estimated that about 45% of patients with COVID-19 develop long COVID, and its prevalence appears to be increasing as well as the number of chronic symptoms, such as anxiety, depression, sleep disturbances, and cognitive impairment.

Research has shown that Osteopathic Manipulative Treatment (OMT) can improve many of the above mentioned symptoms. However, the role of OMT in the management of long COVID has not been evaluated in the literature and it is unknown if OMT could be effective in reducing the signs and symptoms of this challenging condition.

The aim of this study is to determine the feasibility of a pilot randomized trial evaluating the effect of a single course of OMT on the signs and symptoms of long COVID. This includes the assessment of: 1) patient recruitment, 2) data completion rates, 3) improvement, or worsening of the signs and symptoms; 4) changes in neurocognitive function; 5) changes in anxiety and depression; 6) impact of COVID-19 on return to work, school, and quality of life; 7) healthcare use.
Patient recruitment, data completion rates, and the results of questionnaires at specific time points will be evaluated as the primary end points for the feasibility study.

Frostbite has been a significant cause of morbidity and mortality for as long as humans have experienced cold winters. When frostbite occurs, there are two primary mechanisms through which tissue damage occurs, though the main mechanism focused on here is systemic cooling. Frostbite is a multiphase process that starts with systemic cooling. As the body cools, blood is shunted from the extremities to the core to maintain heat in the vital organs. During this shunting, there is extensive vasospasm in the extremities and the tissue becomes ischemic. Upon further cooling, tissue ice crystals form within the cells and interstitial spaces causing desiccation and cell destruction. This occurs in the soft tissues and also affects the endothelium of the micro- and macro-vasculature. Clots form in the microvasculature, worsening the ischemia. All ischemic tissues release pro-inflammatory factors, which increase inflammation and worsen clotting. Upon rewarming of the frozen tissues, the reperfusion can worsen the inflammatory state as these factors released by the ischemic tissue are now able to circulate. Rapid rewarming is used as a tool to mitigate this reperfusion injury, but it does not eliminate the damage. After rapid rewarming, the tissue is assessed for the extent of damage to determine next treatment steps. Diagnosis varies by institution, but the main goal of all diagnostic modalities that have been used is to determine if there is a vascular cutoff causing tissue ischemia.
Indocyanine green (ICG) microangiography is a technology that has had rapidly expanding applications in recent decades. These have included retinal imaging, determining perfusion of colorectal anastomoses, biliary imaging, and assessing the blood supply of tissue flaps. It has recently been used in diagnosis of frostbite with good correlation with severe final amputation levels. It is easy to use, non-radiating, can be performed at the bedside, and cheaper than other imaging modalities. Given that every hospital has different diagnostic and treatment algorithms, these different imaging modalities have rarely been compared in the same patient. This research application provides a unique opportunity to compare two imaging modalities head-to-head in the same patient and determine their concordance or discordance.

The purpose of this protocol is to describe the toxicities of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) PET in patients who are undergoing stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) to oligo-progressive metastases of solid tumor malignancies. A second goal of this trial is to describe changes in 64CDP uptake in patients undergoing SBRT to 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) PET scans prior to and following SBRT to radiated metastases. This protocol is also designed to determine the incidence of adverse events that were possibly related to protocol therapy. The primary objective of this clinical trial is to characterize the safety and toxicity associated with 64CDP PET imaging and treatment with standard of care of pembrolizumab-NHS-DOTA in patients undergoing SBRT for radiated metastases to oligo-progressive metastatic solid tumors. The secondary objectives of this clinical trial are to describe changes in 64CDP uptake in patients who are undergoing SBRT to oligo-progressive metastatic solid tumors, and to describe the incidence of adverse events (AEs) possibly related to 64CDP PET and standard of care pembrolizumab.

A follow-up study to describe the safety of study participants who received RSVPreF3 maternal vaccination (any dose) or control (placebo, Tdap or influenza vaccine) from previous RSV MAT studies during any pregnancy conceived post-vaccination/control. The study is non-randomized, and no intervention is provided in this extension study. The study population consists of prior RSV MAT participants who were vaccinated with RSVPreF3 or a control from prior RSV MAT studies conducted in the United States, European Economic Area, Canada, and Japan. Participants who had not reached 2 years+2 months post-vaccination prior to or at enrollment who are women of non-childbearing potential or have received bilateral tubal ligation prior to study enrollment are included to establish safety endpoints. Participants from prior RSV MAT studies are being followed up for approximately 27 months post-delivery.

This study investigates the feasibility of using a novel low dose, non-radioactive, 19FMRI technique to measure lung function and ventilation in children with CF. Children with CF will undergo 19F MRI imaging at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), where the technique has been previously validated in adults (Bolanos 2022, PJ) and healthy children (Morrissey 2022). In addition to the MRI, participants will have standard lung function testing, as recommended by the CF Foundation (CFF), including spirometry and body plethysmography. The MRI is considered investigational and has been used in previous studies in adults with and without disease. This study will use the MRI to characterize lung function specifically in children with mild CF.
In previous research in adults with mild or moderate CF, researchers found a close correlation between lung ventilation patterns and the distribution of CF-causing gene defects within the lungs of adults. It seems that airway obstruction occurs early on in the progression of cystic fibrosis (CF), and abnormal airflow results in abnormal ventilation patterns throughout the lung. Based on these findings, new CF treatments that improve ventilation patterns, could serve as an early biomarker of CF therapeutic progress and treatment efficacy. In addition, 19FMRI has been used in adults to follow lung ventilation patterns of the airways in the lungs over time (McColum 2019, PJ) and will allow the researchers to see where changes are happening in the airways. This information is extremely informative as physicians and researchers alike have always been interested in understanding early changes within the lungs of children in order to optimize and assess CF therapies, including new drugs, and to prevent and/or slow the progression of disease in children that are born with CF.
The goal of this study is to examine the feasibility of using this novel gas-based, low-dose 19F magnetic resonance imaging technique in children with CF to understand how the lungs ventilate. To accomplish this goal, two groups of children will be recruited. The first group will be children with mild CF, where mild disease is defined as age <18 years, and Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1) >80%, with a FEV1:FVC ratio >0.7, and in whom there is no evidence of respiratory symptoms during routine clinical care. The second group will consist of age-matched healthy children from parents or other family members that are participating in other clinical studies or who have no prior medical history. Participants from both groups will be imaged using a combination of CT, 19F MRI imaging, and standard lung function tests including, spirometry, impulse oscillometry (IOS), and body plethysmography.
Children will perform multiple CT exams under anesthesia to determine the CT density of all of the lung lobes using a CT density map that will help the researchers quantify how much lung ventilates and how air is distributed within the lungs. CT densitometry is considered the gold standard measurement of lung ventilation, and this procedure will serve to validate the 19F MRI measurements. Once the CT procedure is completed, the child will receive a biologically inert, non-radioactive gas called perfluoropropane (PFP). The patient will then be placed into the MRI scanner and undergo 19F MRI lung imaging. The investigators will track how the lungs ventilate, i.e. which lung segments inhale or exhale gas the fastest. A portion of the MRI study will also assess how efficiently gas is leaving those parts of the lungs by tracking the gas washout rate. The 19F MRI study time will vary based on the time the patient is able to hold their breath (typically 2-3 minutes), and the number of breath-holds needed.
Overall, this research has the potential to uncover new markers of disease progression and treatment response; help understand disease variability and optimize CF treatments for children, and inform future trials to improve CF care in children.
The information obtained will help researchers understand the mechanisms of CF and potentially guide treatment strategies for children with CF.
