<|assistant|> Left Bundle Branch Resynchronisation Therapy or left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) is a new transvenous cardiac pacing technique that paces the left ventricle. A new lead designed specifically for this purpose was introduced in December 2012 (Biotronik® Solia S60 ™ lead). We previously published a retrospective real-world clinical registry of LBBAP in patients with ejection fraction less than or equal to 50% and the data showed that LBBAP in this particular subset of patient is feasible and safe, and LBBAP has the potential in reducing the incidence of heart failure hospitalisation. In order to further evaluate the feasibility and safety of LBBAP in patients with ejection fraction less than or equal to 50% and to further elucidate its benefit with regards to hospitalization, we designed a multicentre registry with two cohorts, one prospective and one retrospective. The prospective study aimed to evaluate the acute and medium-term complication, including the outcome of the acute procedure itself and the procedure-related complications that might occur 30 days later. The retrospective group will be used to control for the change of practice between the prospective and retrospective groups. Aims: - To determine the acute success rate of left bundle branch area pacing in heart failure patients with left ventricular ejection fraction of 50% or less. - To determine the incidence of procedural complication during or within 30 days after LBBAP in this group of patients. - To determine the clinical outcomes in this group of patients in terms of heart failure hospitalisation, cardiovascular mortality, all-cause mortality and left ventricular function. Expected Benefits: - To contribute to the body of literature highlighting the use of LBBAP in patients with heart failure and left bundle branch block in left ventricle. This should reduce the risk of procedure-related complications that has been shown before. - To provide data on the acute and mid-term complication of LBBAP in these patients. - To add evidence supporting the usefulness of LBBAP in this group of patients. The primary objective of this study is to determine the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of single intravenous (IV) doses of CSX-1004 in healthy male and female subjects after administration of single doses of CSX-1004 for up to 6 days at one site.
Each treatment day will be followed by a minimum of 3 non-treatment days in the subject's residence in the Treatment Unit. Treatment is followed by follow-up visits on Day 8 and Day 30.
The secondary objectives are to assess PK parameters of CSX-1004 and its major metabolite, CSX-1004 metabolite #1 (CSX-1004-m1) and to study the impact of CSX-1004 on acetaminophen pharmacokinetics (PK) and its major metabolite p-hydroxymidazolum.
This study will be a randomized, double-blind, single-site, single-ascending dose study in healthy volunteers. In this trial, subjects will be randomized to a single dose of CSX-1004 or placebo delivered by IV infusion by either a pharmacy technician or nurse. Approximately 30 subjects (20 females, 10 males) will be randomized in a 2:1 ratio to receive CSX-1004 at doses up to 3 mg/kg or placebo, with three subjects receiving placebo on each treatment day.
An increase in the total daily dose of the first cohort (up to 0.005 mg/kg intravenously) will only occur if it is assessed by the investigator that there are no safety concerns with previous administrations, at the discretion of the investigator in accordance with the dose escalation table. Otherwise, if there are unacceptable safety concerns, the next cohort of subjects will test a placebo administration.

Background: The management of dysfunctional prostheses is a real challenge for orthopedic surgeons, often complicated by pain, reduction of mobility and/or mechanical implant failure, all causes of functional limitation and degradation of patients' quality of life. Moreover, the diagnosis and management of the infectious prosthetic complications is a medical and surgical complexity. The accuracy of the diagnosis of septic prostheses is the first step in the management of patients; it is classically based on clinical, biological and sometimes radiological data. This diagnosis is complicated by the absence of specific symptoms and the non-specific biological data, with many false positive and false negative results in clinical practice. Moreover, the use of standard biomarkers (C-RP, Leukocyte Esterase, alpha defensing) in the diagnosis of chronic infectious prosthesis complications has shown limits in terms of sensitivity and specificity, and the use of new biomarkers does not improve these results. Joint fluid aspiration (JFA) remains the gold standard, but it is invasive, with risks associated with the procedure. The literature provides very heterogeneous data about the proportion of JFAs concordant with those of the perioperative samples, ranging from 20 to 100%.
The objective of this cohort prospective study will be to evaluate the bacteriological concordance (positive or negative) of the JFA with the perioperative samples.
Secondary objectives:
- Identification of new biomarkers and the definition of threshold for early diagnosis
- Identification of bacteria strains in JFA in an attempt to classify them according to their propensity to complicate the artificial joint
- Identify biomarkers to predict the rate of complications in the immediate post-operative period (in case of mechanical complication of the implant).
This study will also be part of a European project (SEPTICORE PROSTHESIS) and will use standardized protocols to compare the concordance between JFAs and perioperative samples in Europe.
Conclusions: In the absence of any biomarker with high sensitivity and specificity to differentiate septic from aseptic prosthesis cases, joint fluid aspiration remains the reference test. The objective of this study is to study its concordance in terms of bacteriological results with that of perioperative samples. A joint fluid aspiration negative on bacteriological results will lead to the abandonment of any additional investigations and will suggest sparing surgical treatment. Any JFA positive on bacteriological results will confirm the suspicion of infection and will lead to the appropriate surgical management, as well as the choice of appropriate antibiotic therapy. The concordance between JFAs and perioperative samples will be studied in different groups of prosthesis complication (primary classification), the groups defined according to the current literature and in our center (secondary classification). The final objective may be a reclassified patients groups thanks to JFAs and perioperative bacteriology results, which will help to manage these prosthesis complications more effectively. Other secondary objectives, such as the identification of new biomarkers, or the definition of thresholds, will also be studied.
Keywords Provided by Centre Hospitalier Valida
-----------------
Joint Prosthesis, Joint Fluid Aspiration, Arthroplasty, Joint Infection, Perioperative Samples, Biomarkers

This study is a randomized, open, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-cross design bioequivalence study. 32 eligible subjects will be randomly assigned to TR group and RT group in a 1:1 ratio. Subjects in the TR group will take the test preparation (T) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 1 (D1) and the reference preparation (R) 200 mg/ pill × 1 pill on day 8 (D8). The sequence of medication in RT group is reversed from TR group. Wash for at least 7 days between doses. The trial drug STI-1558 should be taken with approximately 240 ml of water after fasting overnight for at least 10h. Except for drinking water, water should be prohibited for at least 1h before and after administration, and fasting should be at least 4h after administration. Test drugs (T and R) must be swallowed whole and not chewed, crushed or separated. In order to ensure the subject's compliance with the medication procedure, the staff should check the subject's mouth after taking the medication.

Endobronchial intubation is an essential technique performed in patients undergoing thoracic surgical procedures. Correct endobronchial intubation of the two bronchi is essential for ensuring one-lung ventilation during surgery. The malposition of the double-lumen endobronchial tube causes bronchial obstruction and complications during surgery, thereby impacting the success of the operation. Thoracic surgery is the main operation performed on the patient's lateral decubitus position, and the position adjusts the anatomical position of the thorax, lungs and bronchi, posing a high risk of malposition. Currently, no studies have confirmed the most effective method to avoid malposition. The purpose of this study is to conduct a prospective, single-center, randomized controlled study to evaluate the effect of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endobronchial tube malposition when the position of the patient changes.

This research aims to evaluate the efficacy of a telemedicine monitoring based on digital tools on the treatment of a depressive episode after an enrollment in a MCO and a referral to a care unit in Medicine or Surgery.
A total of 214 patients will be randomly assigned to an experimental group and the standard of care group. The primary endpoint will be the clinical response rate at 6 months and the secondary endpoints will include clinical and epidemiological variables and cost-effectiveness, both during the patient hospitalization in a MCO and in the year following. The main hypothesis is that telemedicine monitoring will lead to a reduction in the level of depression and increase in the secondary prevention of depressive relapse compared to standard care.
Data collected from patient hospitalized in a MCO during a period of 1 week will be used to select eligible patients, including those receiving psychopharmacological prescription in the context of a depressive episode. Patients will be excluded if there is an indication for hospitalization in a psychiatric environment, if they under guardianship or curatorship, if there is a non-psychiatric condition with a 3-year vital prognosis and refusal to participate.
Through a protocol of randomization with a 1:1 ratio, patients will be divided into the experimental group "Telemedicine" and the control group "Standard".
The experimental group will receive a 6-month telemedicine monitoring, with 6 individual sessions by videoconference, supported by digital tools in order to follow the evolution of the patient and its psychotropic prescription. Patients will be contacted (or their legal representative or patient's designated person or a designee) by e-mail by the nurse / psychologist of the telemedicine platform. The digital tools proposed to the patients are an intelligent chatbot for psychotherapeutic and psychoeducational interviews and mobile applications for monitoring mental health (mood or mood-anxiety syndrome, physical activity and psychoeducational material on mindfulness). The nurse/psychologist will be able to use complementary methods and tools to adapt the frequency and intensity of the sessions according to the patient's needs. Patients assigned to this experimental arm will be subjected to the standard care and telemedical monitoring in addition to it. The standard care consists in the prescription of psychotropic drugs by the physicians of the MCO and the usual care after discharge from the hospital.
The care pathway will be structured and assessed for the main outcome measures.
An economic evaluation will be done in a parallel prospective manner using a cost-utility approach.
This study will provide an assessment of the efficacy of telemedicine monitoring on depressive symptoms and its influence on clinical variables, stigma and overall patient satisfaction, also will evaluate the economic impact of this approach in the long term and its feasibility and social acceptability.

The purpose of this research project is to investigate whether adding extra MRI scans can increase the accuracy of using MRI to differentiate between a benign or malignant soft tissue mass using artificial intelligence (AI).
This will be carried out by developing AI algorithms which will be trained to differentiate between patients with benign or malignant masses by analysing their MRI results. The hypothesis is that the AI algorithm will perform better if trained on MRI scans that include extra imaging sequences and quantitative measures.
The research team will gather MRI and clinical data from patients who are having a scan for a suspected soft tissue sarcoma as part of their routine care, with additional MRI sequences acquired during the same scan. The researchers will record the patients' diagnosis (whether they have a sarcoma or not), along with their age, ethnicity, body weight and body mass index. Patients are likely to be invited to participate in the research as part of their routine follow-up.
This research aims to improve the diagnostic accuracy of determining whether a lump is benign or malignant using MRI by AI algorithms. By conducting a feasibility study in two hospitals (Leeds and Manchester) and then validating the findings at a third hospital (Sheffield) the researchers will lay the groundwork for a future randomised clinical trial.

Gingival phenotype refers to gingival thickness (GT) and keratinized tissue width (KTW). Gingival phenotypes can be classified as scalloped and thin or flat and thick gingiva. Thin gingival phenotype are very friable and might be prone to recede in response to traumatic insults, such as plaque-related inflammation and traumatic toothbrushing. Studies have believed that HA accelerates the wound healing process, and promotes regeneration, as it maintains the viability of oral fibroblasts, increases their proliferative and migratory abilities, and enhances the expression of genes encoding type III collagen and transforming growth factor-β. Study has shown a statistically significant increase in gingival thickness when microneedling was performed along with i-PRF in comparison to standalone i-PRF. Given these characteristics,this study will be conducted to comparative evaluation of microneedling alone and along with hyaluronic acid on thin gingival phenotype. The present randomized controlled clinical trial will be conducted in the Department of Periodontics and Oral Implantology,Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences,Rohtak.Study design is of 24 months. Total 20 patients will be recruited on the basis of inclusion and exclusion criteria with thin periodontal phenotypes who had consulted to the Department of Periodontology, Post Graduate Institute of Dental Sciences, Rohtak. 20 systematically healthy patients having thin gingival phenotypes will be included in this split-mouth randomized controlled trial. For each patient, each side of the anterior mandible will be randomly allocated to one of the two procedures (MN or MN with Hyaluronic acid)using chit system. In the MN group microneedling will be done 1 mm below the gingival margin with 30-gauze lancet needles. In the HA with MN group, the selected sites of the gingiva will injected with cross-linked HA using a 30-gauge microneedle followed by microneedling. This described procedure will be repeated in both groups three times with intervals of 10 days. The GT, KTW, and periodontal indices: gingival index (GI), bleeding on probing (BOP), and probing depth (PD) will be measured at baseline, 1 month, 6 months and 9 months.

Background: Perioperative nutritional status may affect surgical outcomes of major abdominal surgery and the risk for postoperative surgical site infection. Preoperative nutritional support may play a role in reducing the risk of perioperative complications, but evidence to support this practice remains inconsistent and poorly defined. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of pre-operative immunonutrition on patients who undergo elective abdominal surgery, assessing surgical and nutritional outcomes considering adipose tissue metabolic features.
Objectives: The investigators hypothesize that 10-day preoperative immunonutrition may increase the percentage of patients who undergo elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm without complications and reduce postoperative mortality rates, as well as surgical site infections. Adipose tissue metabolic features may predict postoperative outcomes and contribute to personalized ERAS guidelines.
Methods: This is a pragmatic, single-blinded, parallel group randomized controlled trial. Two hundred patients from two major Italian centers performing colorectal surgery are randomized into two groups: a group receiving Impact® oral supplementation (A group) and a placebo matched group (B group).
Patients are stratified by age (<70 and ≥70 years old), sex and location of tumors. All participants will undergo colorectal surgery according to Italian ERAS guidelines. The intervention will be initiated 10 days before surgery.
The investigators will collect blood, adipose issue, parietal fat and surgical specimens for routine analysis and metabolomics studies. Inflammatory cells and fibroblasts in subcutaneous adipose tissue and visceral adipose tissue will be identified, as well as adipocytes cross sectional area. Subset of patients will participate in an ancillary study to analyze blood metabolites. Additionally, clinical outcome measures such postoperative mortality, length of hospital stay, surgical site infection, anastomotic leakage, need of re-operation and postoperative mortality will be collected after discharge, 30 days later.
The investigators will assess whether the intervention modified postoperative complications and nutritional and immunologic outcomes to potentially modify surgical guidelines related to colorectal cancer surgery.
Significance: The study will provide data to promote personalized ERAS guidelines for patients undergoing colorectal surgery, considering adipose tissue metabolic features.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a condition that can reduce a man's quality of life. HoLEP (Holmium Laser Enucleation of the Prostate) is a surgical procedure used to treat BPH, but can occasionally cause urinary leakage. The purpose of this study is to see if starting pelvic floor exercises before HoLEP surgery can reduce urinary leakage following surgery.
Inclusion will be done by the urology team, who will be blinded to the study. We will enroll 112 patients at Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH). 
Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 2 groups for this study. Group assignment will not be based on the age of the patient or any other characteristic, such as how severe their condition is. Group A will start pelvic floor exercises 1 month before surgery. Group B will start them after surgery (in line with routine practice). Each group will be asked to perform pelvic floor exercises 5 times/week for 5 months after surgery.
During hospitalization, patients in both groups will be instructed on how to perform 3 different pelvic floor exercises, and will be asked to use a handheld, vibrating device to help with exercise performance and tracking through a mobile application for 5 minutes, 3 times a week.
All subjects will have 6 monthly evaluations and complete 1 urinary diary and 4 self questionnaires (on the day of surgery and at 1, 3, and 6 months).

DETECT-IP is a study designed to reduce the incidence of acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia in older patients based on a clinical decision support system and specific procedures. The pharmaceutical validation of ADEs (adverse drug events) will be supported by a computerised decision support system (CDSS) developed by the team of Cuvelier and which has already been set up in the hospital of our study (Centre hospitalier Valida).
This prospective study is a step-wedge cluster randomised controlled trial (RCT). Centres and periods will be randomly selected. Clinical pharmacists, clinical care physicians and nurses will be involved in the detection intervention. Randomisation will be stratified according to the centres, taking into account their size and the number of wards where older patients are hospitalised. In each centre, the period during which the intervention will take place is defined by two phases, intervention and control. The intervention period will be the month in which the intervention will be carried out. Intervention and control periods will be balanced following the randomisation of the centres in a ratio of 1:1. The order of the intervention's introduction (ADEs alerts, i.e. acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia) during periods will be randomised.
Older hospitalised patients (> 65 years) will be admitted to an MCO (medicine surgery obstetrics) participating in the study and will be the object of the intervention. Patients who give oral consent and whose socio-professional situation allows them to do so will participate in the study. The presence or lack of an adverse drug event (acute renal failure or hyperkalemia) will be taken as an outcome measure. During the intervention period, each alert will be evaluated by a clinical pharmacist and according to their own expertise and data available in the hospital information system (HIS/RIS), the clinical pharmacist will propose pharmaceutical interventions by modifying the prescription (change of treatment, discontinuation, dose change). If there is an alert, the clinical pharmacist's intervention will be recorded in their usual practice.
The primary outcome measure is the number of ADEs in older hospitalized patients. At the individual patient level, the ADEs considered in the study are those resulting from a medical prescription, acute renal failure (ARF) and/or hyperkalemia diagnosed within 30 days of the prescription. The intervention will be compared to the usual care. The analysis at the individual patient level will be done at the beginning of the study, at the end of the intervention period and finally 30 days after implementation. A mixed model of random effects will be carried out at the patient level, within a multi-level analysis framework. Randomisation of centres and periods will be done by calculating the intra-class correlation coefficient. The intra-class correlation coefficient will be calculated at baseline, in the first phase of the study, in order to estimate the average intra-class correlation coefficient over 3 years. The random effects that will be used in the model will be the hospital, the month and the patient (with a random distribution). The primary analysis will be done without adjustment on the average intra-class correlation coefficient. Primary analysis will be supplemented with confidence interval calculation and tests of the difference in means between intervention and control. The primary endpoint will be a statistical test of hypothesis (p < 0.05), with the calculation of the absolute risk reduction and the number needed to treat defined as the inverted ratio of the differences (ARF vs Hyperkalemia) between the two groups. A sensitivity analysis will be conducted taking into account the clustering in the intervention to analyse the possible differences in the estimates between the different approaches. 
Secondary endpoints are therapeutic adaptations (dosage, stop ...) following an alert; the presence of an alert of acute renal failure or hyperkalemia considered as relevant after qualitative processing, the pharmaceutist's decision (intervention or not intervention) and finally, the work process (ADEs prevention and management) supported by the setting up of alerts.
In addition, the team will assess the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of the intervention at the patient level.
Finally, qualitative research on the effect of the intervention on work processes will be conducted by: interviews with clinical pharmacists, managers and physicians, observation of the work of these professionals and semi-structured interviews with patients hospitalised in the care units concerned and their relatives. All will be collected at baseline or at the end of the intervention, but not at both times. The work system will be studied descriptively on three dimensions: activities (tasks: number and

<|assistant|> Crohn Disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract caused by an abnormal immune reaction resulting in gastrointestinal inflammation. The exact reason why the immune system of some people makes abnormal reactions in the digestive tract is unknown. It affects about 0.5% of the population in which the average age of onset is between 20 and 30 years. Surgical treatment is necessary for 15 to 20% of patients. However, it is not clear why some patients develop the disease in the surgical site after this treatment. The purpose of our study is to analyze and compare the bacterial microbiome of the mesenteric fat, small intestine tissue, and blood of patients with CD who have undergone surgical treatment (ileocecal resection) and compare it with that of patients who do not have CD but have come to surgery for the same cause. Blood samples will be used to identify genetic variations that could favour the development of the disease in postoperative CD patients. Based on these data, we will be able to distinguish between healthy fat and those with a bacterial microbiome similar to that of intestinal tissue, which could explain the recurrence of the disease in postoperative CD patients. This will also allow us to identify immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory treatments based on the results obtained. In addition, this study will provide a better understanding of the factors involved in the pathophysiology of Crohn's disease. LY3437943 is a humanised immunoglobulin G1 (IgG1, hIgG1) monoclonal antibody in clinical development for the potential treatment of various immune-mediated disorders. Phase 1 pharmacokinetic (PK) studies have shown that the drug administered intravenously (IV) is eliminated rapidly with an intermediate terminal half-life and is widely tissue distributed, including to the central nervous system (CNS). The objective of Part A of this study is to characterize the PK profile of IV and subcutaneous (SC) routes of administration compared to IV administration. The aim of Part B of this study is to assess the impact of SC injection site on absorption and bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943.

The aim of the PRECAM-R study is to evaluate the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate in middle and lower rectal cancers using preoperative chemoradiotherapy and immunotherapy as neoadjuvant therapy. The PRECAM-R study is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study to confirm the efficacy and safety of preoperative short-course radiation treatment followed by Envafolimab plus CAPEOX for patients with pMMR / MSS type of stage III mid to low rectal cancer.
The main purpose of the study is to demonstrate that there is no statistically significant difference in recurrence-free survival and side effects between immune combined treatment group and chemoradiotherapy alone group. Compared with the short-course chemoradiotherapy group, the pCR rate of the immune combined treatment group will be increased more than 10 percent, and the number of side effects will be the same or decreased.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate 2 interventions to increase effective depression care in India. In this study, the first intervention is to adapt a psychological intervention (the Health Activity Program (HAP)) currently used by counsellors in the health centres, delivered by the existing healthcare workers (counsellors). This intervention will be implemented in two study arms in this cluster randomised controlled trial. The second intervention is to introduce community volunteers (Sangathis) into 3 study arms. They will deliver the same HAP treatment as the counsellors. The third study arm will receive the usual care provided prior to the trial.
The community volunteers will conduct psycho-education activities, facilitate identification of depressed people in their communities, encourage them to seek care, and help facilitate their continued engagement with HAP.
This study will have 7 study arms -
1. Facility Model
2. Community Model - Healthy Activity Program (HAP)
3. Community Model - HAP+Community Intervention
4. Community Model -- usual care
5. Facility Model -- usual care
6. Community Model - HAP+Community Intervention + usual care
7. Community Model -- usual care + usual care

Hypoxia is the partial or complete lack of oxygen in air. Severe hypoxia can lead to death via a lack of oxygen supply to the brain. However, moderate hypoxia can have beneficial effects for performance, inducing favorable acute (during exposure to hypoxia), sub-acute (after 1 or 2 weeks exposure to hypoxia), and chronic (after more than 1 week) physiological and biochemical responses in tissues. One of these responses is the increase in secretion of counter-regulatory hormones, including catecholamines and cortisol, which are involved in the stimulation of growth and protein synthesis in the muscles and the regulation of blood pressure. Hypoxia exposure has also been shown to increase muscle protein synthesis. The beneficial effects of hypoxia exposure in humans have been studied through high-intensity resistance training or the combination of training with high-intensity intermittent exercise. However, the responses to low-intensity resistance training in hypoxia exposure are currently unknown. Based on these considerations, the aim of the present study was to verify and compare the acute and chronic physiological, biochemical, and functional responses associated with hypoxic exposure and low-intensity resistance training in both normobaric hypoxia and normoxia conditions. 
                The present study will be conducted using resistance exercise (back squat) with a load of 20-30% of the one-repetition maximum in a normobaric hypoxia (3500 meters above sea, FiO2 13%) with blood flow restriction (80% of total occlusion pressure), and normobaric hypoxia with sham application at the same time of the day and in the same conditions, combined with low-intensity resistance training, to a group of physically active adults. We will also compare our findings with high-intensity resistance training (80% of one-repetition maximum) and low-intensity resistance training.

The purpose of this study is to test the safety and effectiveness of a drug called BET and MEK inhibition in advanced uveal melanoma. It is conducted is two parts: dose-finding and treatment. The first part is called Dose-finding and the second part is called Treatment.
The first part, called Dose-finding, has 2 stages. In the first Stage (Cohort I), we give the lowest dose of the combination and gradually increase the dose until a maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is found. In the second Stage (Cohort II), we use the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) found in the first stage and confirm the efficacy of this dose. In the second part, Treatment, we test the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) from Stage II of the Dose-finding in 27 study participants that will be newly enrolled.

In the Dose-finding stage, you start on the lowest dose of the combination for 14 days. Then we give you the next dose. Depending on whether you have side effects, we may decrease, remain at, or increase the dose of the combination. We check you regularly on days 1, 8, 15 and at 28. After the Dose-finding stage is over, we monitor you for about 2 years. In the Treatment stage, you get about 2 years of trametinib at the MTD dose found in the Dose-finding stage.

Objective: This study is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability and preliminary antitumor activity of disitamab vedotin injection formulation for adults with HER2 positive and HER2-low solid tumors which have previously been treated with standard of care therapies.
Eligibility: Participants will be eligible for this study based upon their tumor type and specific condition history.

Location: The study will be conducted by investigational sites in the United States. Participants will be required to complete all procedures in the study clinic.

Background: There are more than 50 million older adults licensed to drive in the United States. Driving is a complex task that requires cognitive and sensorimotor skills. Survivors of critical illness experience cognitive, psychological and physical impairments, known as Post-Intensive Care Syndrome (PICS), that can last months to years following critical illness. PICS is associated with driving deficits in critically ill survivors. Few studies have studied driving safety concerns among older ICU survivors. Objective: To characterize the driving behaviors of older ICU survivors and identify cognitive and physical risk factors for automobile crashes. To develop novel methods to assess and monitor ICU-acquired cognitive declines in the context of driving outcomes and behavior. Eligibility: English speaking adults, age 55 and older, who have survived a critical illness with a stay in the medical or surgical intensive care unit who have a driver's license and a vehicle of any kind.
Eligible subjects will have delirium that lasted more than 2 calendar days during the ICU stay based on the electronic record or confirmation by a physician member of the research team. Design: Cohort studies are observational studies during which we will recruit volunteers to participate in the study for 6-months. Subjects will complete multiple assessments and undergo multiple longitudinal vehicle sensor deployments. Data from the assessments will be compared with driving patterns identified via in-vehicle sensors. We will recruit a convenience sample of 24 post-intensive care unit survivors with risk factors for ICU-acquired cognitive declines.
Six months later, we will recruit a convenience sample of 8-12 stakeholders to review insights from the kinematic and neurocognitive data. The investigators believe stakeholder feedback will determine the relevance of the sensor technology for a broader dissemination and the feasibility of a large-scale implementation strategy focused on ICU-survivors with driving declines. Study arm: An eligible subject who agrees to all study procedures will complete all study activities according to the study schedule. Subjects will complete multiple assessments and undergo multiple longitudinal vehicle sensor deployments.
Outcomes Measures: The investigators will measure driving time and driving behaviors using vehicle sensor data. Cognitive domains will be measured using neurocognitive assessments. Health-related quality of life will be measured using a standardized measure (EQ-5D). The investigators will measure depression, anxiety and self-perceived health using standardized measures. Study participants will complete these assessments at the time of enrollment and 3- and 6-months after enrollment.
Pilot study: To refine study materials, test enrollment procedures, and obtain user feedback on the in-vehicle sensors. The investigators will enroll 3 participants in this phase to gather feedback for future implementation.
Main study: To test the feasibility of an observational kinematic driving study, pilot the development of a driving rehabilitation program and obtain stakeholder feedback on results. The investigators will enroll 24 participants from the Medical, Neurological, and Surgical Intensive Care Units at University of Michigan Hospitals and Health Centers. Data collection will occur in the outpatient setting as participants complete assessments and deploy in-vehicle sensors. Participants will complete 2-3 assessments and multiple longitudinal vehicle sensor deployments at the hospital-based Movement Disorders Clinic 3- and 6-months after enrollment. Results from the in-vehicle driving assessments will be compiled, anonymized, and presented to the stakeholder advisory panel at the 9-month data analysis visit. The investigators will present study results in a series of stakeholder meetings with clinicians, caregivers, and community advocates and with the research community.

Liquid biopsy of circulating tumor DNA-MRD (ctDNA-MRD) is the main indicator to detect the existence and quantity of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in the body fluids, and it is also the main evaluation index for the efficacy of targeted therapy for patients with malignant tumors. ctDNA-MRD has been studied in a variety of malignant tumors, including breast cancer, cervical cancer, colorectal cancer, lung cancer, and prostate cancer. It is expected that the analysis of ctDNA-mrd will become the cornerstone of the early diagnosis and evaluation of tumor recurrence and drug resistance. In GIST patients, it has been shown that in patients with complete resection of colic GIST before surgery, ctDNA-mrd examination can predict tumor recurrence. In the adjuvant therapy of advanced colorectal cancer, the use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy can reduce ctDNA-mrd and predict the response to chemotherapy before surgery. In patients with non-small cell lung cancer after surgery, adjuvant therapy combined with EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor monitoring based on ctDNA-mrd can achieve better efficacy. There are also other studies, which showed that the change of ctDNA-mrd during adjuvant treatment can indicate the response, monitoring progress, monitoring drug resistance and providing guidance for treatment.
Recently, several studies have explored the use of ctDNA-MRD as a basis, and assist patients to adopt drug-free treatment mode after patients have achieved disease control after surgery. Based on this, this study will also adopt this drug-free treatment mode based on MRD detection, including selecting patients suitable for this mode of treatment, adopting this mode of treatment and evaluating the effect of drug-free mode treatment in GIST patients after surgery.

The prevalence of balance and coordination related problems among children with Down syndrome is often higher than that of the general population. In this study the objective is to evaluate the effects of an intervention, Dohsa hou exercises, on functional mobility of children with Down syndrome by comparing with the standard treatment protocol.
Dohsa hou exercises are a type of psychomotor therapy, which has shown better improvement in postural control and functional mobility in people with Down syndrome. Due to the positive effects of Dohsa hou exercises on the functional mobility of children with intellectual disabilities, this intervention will be compared with standard treatment protocol.
Study population: The study population will consist of children with Down syndrome aged 6-12 years old. A total of 30 children will be enrolled with equal number of male and female. Children with Down syndrome will be recruited from the pediatric outpatient department at the University of Indonesia and Cipto Mangunkusumo Hospital. Inclusion criteria includes children diagnosed with Down syndrome, aged 6-12 years old, with BMI within normal limits. Exclusion criteria includes children with visual impairment, hearing issues, uncontrolled seizure, neurological or orthopedic problems in addition to Downs syndrome or any type of psychiatric problem.
Interventions and treatments: Children with Downs syndrome who meet the inclusion criteria will be enrolled in the study. Subjects will be assigned to one of three groups by using simple randomization method. Group one will receive standard treatment protocol including soft tissue massage therapy, task specific training interventions and bicycle training, Group two will receive Dohsa hou activities and Group three will serve as a Control group and will not receive any intervention. Assessment: Children with Downs syndrome will undergo a functional mobility assessment using the Test of trunk impairment scale and the Time up and go test.
Time up and go test will be performed two times: At the beginning of study to determine baseline (T0) and again at the end of the intervention. The test results will be used to evaluate and compare the effect of Dohsa hou exercises with the standard treatment protocol. Dohsa hou activities will be conducted three times a week for six weeks and the total duration for the intervention will be 18 sessions. This study is the first attempt to assess and compare the effect of Dohsa hou activity with other treatments on functional mobility of children with Down syndrome. It is anticipated that results of this study will provide new perspectives to physical therapists, parents and educators for the intervention of children with Down syndrome.

Low levels of physical activity (PA) among youth remain a significant public health problem, with most U.S. children falling short on the recommended 60 minutes of daily moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA). Research shows that this gap disproportionately affects population subgroups, particularly children who are female, overweight/obese, or from low socioeconomic areas. Interventions are needed that can equitably increase children's PA. To address this gap, there has been a focus in the U.S. and abroad on increasing children's physical literacy (PL), which can be defined as the ability, confidence, and motivation to be physically active for life. While PL-focused interventions hold promise in concept, there is little empirical evidence of effectiveness and differential effects by subgroups are not understood. Thus, the overall objective is to increase children's PA through a multilevel, comprehensive PL-focused program that will reach children both at school and at home. The overarching hypothesis is that the PL-focused program will have positive effects on elementary schoolchildren's PL and, in turn, PA. Aims include testing the multilevel Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program using a 2-arm, group randomized controlled trial (RCT) with n=400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools receiving either the multilevel RNYRR program (n=4) or delayed-intervention control (n=4). Aims include: 1) Testing the multilevel RNYRR program through a group randomized, two-arm, controlled RCT, n=400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools receiving either the multilevel RNYRR program (n=4) or delayed-intervention control (n=4). 2) Evaluating the effects of the multilevel Rising New York Road Runners program on physical literacy (PL) and physical activity (PA) over one school year. The primary hypothesis is that children attending schools with the RNYRR programming will increase physical literacy (PL) and PA (total daily volume and MVPA) relative to children in control schools. 3) Evaluating whether RNYRR program effects on children's PL (assessed at the level of competence in fundamental movement skill (FMS) domains) and PL subdomains (e.g., ability, confidence, motivation) mediate changes in daily total PA volume or MVPA over one school year.

Tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy are performed for many reasons such as recurrent tonsil and adenoid infections, sleep apnea, symptomatic adenotonsillar hypertrophy, halitosis, peritonsillar abscess, and it is one of the most performed surgeries. During these operations, there may be fluid and blood accumulation in the stomach. Investigators wondered whether the amount of blood and fluid accumulated in the stomach after tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy in children will increase the risk of aspiration. For this purpose, the aim is to compare the results with values considered risky for aspiration by evaluating the pre- and postoperative gastric volume with ultrasound in children who underwent tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy. This study will include ASA 1,2,3 patients under the age of 18 who will undergo tonsillectomy and/or adenoidectomy in the operating rooms of Istanbul University, Istanbul Medical Faculty, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, after the approval of the ethics committee. All the patients will be given oral midazolam 0.3 mg/kg as standard in the preoperative preparation room. After standard monitoring (ECG, NIBP, SpO2) is performed in the operating room, gastric volume will be evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position before the operation. After induction of general anesthesia (sevoflurane + 02 + NO2 inhalation, 1 mcg/kg fentanyl, 0.5 mg/kg rocuronium) patients will be intubated. After intubation, gastric volume will be re-evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position. anesthesia will be maintained with a mixture of sevoflurane + 40%/60% O2/NO2 for a MAC of 1.0. At the end of the surgery, before the patient is extubated, the gastric volume will be evaluated by ultrasound in the right lateral position. Afterwards, the patients will be extubated and taken to the postoperative recovery room. Nausea and vomiting of patients during awakening and for the next 24 hours will be recorded. Patients' age, gender, height, weight, duration of surgery will also be recorded in the follow-up form.

Cardiac surgery is the most important treatment for serious coronary heart disease, valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease and other heart diseases. Its postoperative mortality and serious complications have also been widely concerned, especially in patients with pulmonary hypertension. The persistent pulmonary hypertension and systemic vascular paralysis during the perioperative period are the main causes of early postoperative death and serious complications such as organ failure.
Catecholamine vasoactive drugs commonly used in cardiac surgery may aggravate the condition of pulmonary hypertension, while the use of drugs to reduce pulmonary hypertension, such as nitric oxide, prostaglandins and phosphodiesterase inhibitors, may worsen the state of systemic vascular paralysis. Vasopressin and oxytocin are two effective components in pituitrin, and vasopressin is the main component that exerts strong vasoconstrictive effect.
Vasopressin binds to receptors distributed in vascular smooth muscle, pituitary and kidney, and exerts its effects by regulating adenosine triphosphate sensitive K+ channel function, nitric oxide production and enhancing vascular response to catecholamine.
In addition, oxytocin can also bind to the receptors distributed in the heart and vascular endothelium, and play a role by releasing atrial natriuretic peptide and nitric oxide.
Therefore, pituitrin can not only constrict systemic circulation vessels and increase systemic circulation pressure, reduce pulmonary artery pressure and pulmonary vascular resistance, but also protect the heart and kidney. Therefore, this study intends to explore whether pituitrin has an impact on the prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension after cardiac surgery, so as to provide reference for its clinical application.

Children with medical complexity (CMC) are increasingly prescribed noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) for chronic respiratory failure. NiPPV effectively corrects abnormal gas exchange, improves sleep quality, and reduces symptoms of chronic respiratory failure. The use of NiPPV has been associated with increased survival and improved health-related quality of life (HRQOL). To ensure effectiveness, NiPPV must be used for all periods of sleep and settings must be individually-titrated. Unfortunately, poor adherence results in many CMC being undertreated for chronic respiratory failure. Successful NiPPV initiation is critical because early negative experiences are commonly reported barriers to adherence6 and early usage predicts longer term use. Standard of care is the initiation and titration of NiPPV during a one-night in-hospital polysomnography (PSG). A PSG is challenging for CMC and families due to their medical fragility and lasting effects of travel and a disrupted routine, the significant amount of equipment and supplies that must be brought to the study as well as the financial implications and additional psychosocial stress for caregivers. In addition, negative experiences with NiPPV may be exacerbated by introduction of the therapy in an unfamiliar PSG laboratory with burdensome monitoring. Furthermore, a one-night PSG provides limited sleep data that may not be representative of dynamic and variable sleeping patterns that occur in the comfort of one's home. Recent technological advances in remote NiPPV monitoring coupled with a shift to virtual care models has enabled a patient and family centered opportunity to bypass the PSG laboratory and initiate NiPPV at home. Remote NiPPV monitoring extends data collection beyond discrete health care encounters and provides real-time data on adherence and efficacy that can be wirelessly transmitted to facilitate setting adjustment by clinicians. Home NiPPV initiation is increasingly being requested by patients and caregivers. The potential benefits of this innovative care model include increasing patient and family empowerment, improving the delivery of high quality patient-centred care at home, and optimizing NiPPV use. Although there is growing data in the adult population to support home NiPPV initiation via telemonitoring, this cannot be simply extrapolated to CMC. There are key differences in the etiology and manifestation of chronic respiratory failure in CMC compared to adults. Furthermore, family caregivers play an important role in NiPPV acceptance and adherence. Canadian guidelines acknowledge the lack of evidence for the setting in which NiPPV is initiated. Home NiPPV initiation in CMC is a novel model of care that may result in large health system impacts, but requires a feasibility study before embarking on a large-scale trial.

Official Title: 12-Week Feasibility and Safety Study of Home Initiation of Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NiPPV) in Children With Medical Complexity

Conditions: Sleep-Disordered Breathing

Intervention / Treatment: Other: Home Initiation of NiPPV

Participation Criteria: Inclusion criteria: Age 5-17 years old Newly prescribed NiPPV Tolerated awake NiPPV trial Provides informed consent Exclusion criteria: Cardiac disease at risk of hemodynamic instability with NiPPV initiation (e.g. cardiac dysfunction (ejection fraction <45%), pulmonary hypertension (mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 20 mmHg on right heart catheterization or suggestive echocardiogram findings in the opinion of a pediatric cardiologist), or single ventricle) At high risk of complications with NiPPV in the opinion of the child's physician (e.g. pneumothorax and aspiration risk) Severe sleep disordered breathing with peak CO2 ≥ 60mmHg or apnea-hypopnea index (AHI)≥ 30/hr (AHI measures the number of respiratory events per hour) Participation in concurrent research study that may affect NiPPV adherence (proposed primary outcome of full study) Exclusion of study participants if the caregiver or participant is not English speaking

The aim of this study is to analyze the effect of dry needling (DN) on latent myofascial trigger points related to gastrocnemius on vertical jump performance (VJP) in female athletes. VJP is a functional and multijoint movement that depends on neuromuscular control during the stretch-shortening cycle. The neuromechanical hypothesis proposes that MTPs causes functional alterations in the muscle structure. The DN can decrease myofascial pain and improve the range of motion, contracture, blood and lymph flow, and therefore improving muscle strength (1-3). The current study hypotheses that the VJP will increase after DN treatment in latent MTP areas. This study is designed following two main criteria: it is an intervention study in healthy volunteers with non-structural myofascial dysfunctions with the intention of determining the effectiveness of the DN technique.

This is a single center, prospective, control study.
Society of Child and Adolescent Health Pediatric Gastroenterology in Renmin Hospital of Wuhan University from July 2020 to December 2021.
Inclusion criteria:
1. Diagnosis of HSP according to the diagnostic criteria of WHO/ISN;
2. The digestive tract was involved. Acute diffuse abdominal colic, including intussusception and gastrointestinal bleeding, is found during the course of disease;
3. The age range is 3-18 years old;
4. There is refractory gastrointestinal type HSP according to the criteria of 4 or more abdomen and 3 or more stools with pain, hematochezia or mucus in the past week, and who have received treatment with oral and intravenous steroids (at a dose of 2 mg/kg for 3 days or a total dose of 40 mg) to treat abdominal pain but with no effect or a relapse occurred during the weaning phase;
5. Parents or guardians agree to treatment and sign a written informed consent form.
The study population consisted of 18 patients with refractory gastrointestinal type HSP, of which 18 patients with refractory digestive symptoms participated in the MMF treatment group, and 18 cases in the observation group.
In MMF treatment group, 18 cases have the above symptoms for more than 4 days, have received treatment with oral and intravenous steroids (at a dose of 2 mg/kg for 3 days or a total dose of 40 mg) to treat abdominal pain, but with no effect or a relapse occurred during the weaning phase. The course of illness was 2 weeks.
The dosage of MMF is 3 times a day, 5 mg/kg/d during 5 days, then 2 mg/kg/d during 14 days, then 1 mg/kg/d for 28 days.
Observation group: 18 cases have the above symptoms for more than 4 days, have received treatment with oral and intravenous steroids (at a dose of 2 mg/kg for 3 days or a total dose of 40 mg) to treat abdominal pain, but with no effect or a relapse occurred during the weaning phase. The course of illness was 2 weeks. No treatment group is treated with MMF.
The incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis and bloody stools is determined by checklist, red blood cells in the Stool with test for every week.

Trauma and chronic stress may lead to psychological stress disorders. This study evaluates the safety, feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a novel adjunctive treatment for PTSD. It will assess the ability of the treatment, electroencephalograph (EEG) enhanced repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS), given daily over six weeks (three hundred sessions), to improve brain rhythms, reduce symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder, and promote health related quality of life.

Acute head and neck infections are responsible for a significant number of outpatient attendances to hospitals, emergency admissions to hospital and readmissions due to hospital discharge. These infections include cellulitis, soft tissue infections, abscesses, necrotising fasciitis and osteomyelitis. Recent studies have shown that in almost one-third of these infections the causative bacteria are not bacterial species normally associated with these infections. Thus they are difficult to treat as a consequence of the bacteria commonly used are often ineffective and sometimes can exacerbate the infection. This is of concern in some cases as these infections can seriously affect patient wellbeing and are sometimes fatal. There are no clinical tests used to look for the bacteria usually responsible and the bacterial species of infecting bacteria can only be determined by growing the bacteria under laboratory conditions (culture). Unfortunately the use of antibiotics can prevent the laboratory growing of the underlying causative bacteria and culture is usually unhelpful if the patient has already been treated with antibiotics. This limits our understanding of the range of bacteria causing these infections and may mean that antibiotics given to patients with head and neck infections are not always appropriate and do not offer the benefits they should provide.
This study aims to examine the bacteria associated with acute head and neck infections and aims to develop tests which can accurately predict the likely cause of the infection and direct antimicrobial drug therapy where needed. The study will collect bacterial samples from inpatients with head and neck infections presenting to hospital, this will provide samples to be used for laboratory research. These samples will be used to identify the bacterial species present and this will enable the researchers to predict the species present using newly developed diagnostic assays. These assays will be correlated with clinical factors known to be associated with acute head and neck infections. This information will be used to develop further tests which can accurately detect specific bacterial species commonly associated with head and neck infections, and direct antimicrobial therapies when needed in the future.

This study was performed in the period of 07/21/2021-30/10/2021. With the help of random sampling, 48 women ≥29 years old who gave birth and applied to the gynecologist and obstetric clinic of Tekirdağ University Hospital were included in the study. Using the questionnaire method, women who have not experienced involuntary urinary leakage under conditions of physical activity, lifting weight, coughing and sneezing for at least 4 weeks, women who have given birth and signed the consent form were taken, while women who complain of vaginismus, suffering from urinary tract infection, cancer, epilepsy or skin conditions with implanted pacemakers, metal implants and pregnant women were excluded from the study. Before the intervention and repeated after 6 weeks, subjects were evaluated by general questionnaire, International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) and Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7) to assess the symptoms of urinary incontinence and their impact on the quality of life. The strength and endurance of the subjects' pelvic floor muscles were assessed with a Pelvexiser perineometer. With the help of an intervention model consisting of two groups, functional magnetic stimulation group (n=24) and pelvic floor muscle training program group (n=24) were formed. The study was started with pelvic floor muscle exercises after functional magnetic stimulation on the first day for the first 20 minutes. Then, the first week was completed in the study of functional magnetic stimulation, and the second, third and fourth weeks were performed with 3 functional magnetic stimulation and 1 pelvic floor muscle training program. On the last day of the fifth week, the study was completed for the first time. Subjects were evaluated for the second time in the 6th week. Functional magnetic stimulation was applied on the first day of the week for 20 minutes, the first week was completed during the functional magnetic stimulation day, and the second, third and fourth weeks were performed with 3 functional magnetic stimulation and 1 pelvic floor muscle training program. In the 6th week, the study was evaluated again for the last time after completing the 5th week of the treatment plan. The data obtained were evaluated using independent t-test, chisquare test, Fisher exact test and Mann-Whitney U test. It was found that the two treatment options positively affected all parameters analyzed. The study suggests that both functional magnetic stimulation and pelvic floor muscle training are effective for urinary incontinence in women and their effectiveness appears to be similar (ScienceDirect, 2022).

Current pharmacological treatments, while beneficial for many patients, do not achieve good long-term outcomes or sustain functional improvements in a large proportion of individuals. Moreover, 40% of PsA and RA patients are seronegative for rheumatoid factor (RF), with the same high burden of disease and same need for treatment. Therefore, the study main hypothesis is that the pathogenesis of psoriatic rheumatoid diseases can be stratified on a molecular level, leading to more accurate molecular targeting. The investigators aim to:
- Define molecular profiles to predict individual responsiveness to therapy to guide treatment decisions in patients with seropositive and seronegative RA and PsA.
- Determine disease development trajectories and predictive biomarkers of PsA in PSO at risk of developing PsA, in order to tailor preventive measures and monitor disease occurrence.
- Quantify the pathogenesis of different joint phenotypes by detailed characterization of cellular and molecular atlases of PsA and RA patients.
- Determine the molecular determinants of remission and disease activity through detailed characterization of cellular and molecular atlases of PsA and RA patients at a cellular and molecular level.
- Analyze the association between arthritis/joint phenotype and extra-articular manifestations and pathophysiology of PsA and RA and vice versa.

<|assistant|> Background: Some degree of scleral and corneal toxicity is common after radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy as a treatment for Thyroid Cancer (TC). These side effects can be managed with topical lubricants, including artificial tears. Anecdotal evidence from several centers suggests that nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) may develop after RAI, which may have a direct impact on patient quality of life, in particular leading to epiphora (tear overflow). Treatment of NLDO may be challenging for patients, requiring multiple, time-consuming outpatient visits and invasive procedures. Objective: This study aims to evaluate the role of prophylactic Artificial Tears (AT), in reducing the incidence of new-onset NLDO in patients following RAI therapy. Study arm: All TC patients referred for RAI therapy will be asked if they consent to participate in this study. A total of 392 candidates for RAI due to thyroid cancer will undergo RAI therapy. Study participants will present to the M.S.K. ophthalmology clinic two weeks (±2 days) prior to RAI therapy for a baseline ophthalmic examination (including Schirmer I test and tear duct irrigation). Then, participants will be randomized to one of the following two groups: Group I (Experimental) will undergo a prophylactic treatment with AT, using artificial tears with preservatives (0.5% methylcellulose) for 4 days following RAI. The instillation schedule will be as follows: Day 1 (Day of RAI therapy): Every 15 minutes for 2 hours, then every 30 minutes for at least 4 hours or until bedtime at night, then repeated at day 2: Once every hour for 12 hours, Day 3: Four times (morning, lunch, dinner, evening), Day 4: Two times (morning and evening). Group II (No intervention) will not receive any treatment with AT in the 4 days immediately following RAI. This is a randomized, double-blind, phase II investigation comparing atorvastatin oral tablets to placebo in patients with a history of resected high-stage melanoma to decrease the risk of disease recurrence in these patients. There are two treatment arms - one receiving atorvastatin and the other receiving placebo in addition to standard of care treatment. The primary outcome measure is recurrence-free survival, with the secondary outcome measures being distant metastasis-free survival and overall survival. The study also aims to assess gene expression profiling related to melanoma clinical outcomes, as well as to gather data on patient costs and quality-of-life.

Rural, low-income, and women of color are at greatest risk for complications of high blood pressure in pregnancy and postpartum. To improve maternal health outcomes for these patients, the Alliance for Innovation on Maternal Safety (AIM) developed the Severe Hypertension During Pregnancy and Postpartum Period Safety Bundle (HTN bundle) which includes five areas of focus: (1) Readiness of clinics to change practices (2) Recognition of high blood pressure (3) Response to patients with high blood pressure during pregnancy or postpartum, 4) Reporting/Systems Learning to track data related to clinic changes and (5) Respectful Care to ensure equity and respect in care of patients. Initially released in 2015, The HTN bundle has been used by hospitals to improve recognition and treatment of high blood pressure in birthing people. The ACHIEVE (Advancing Community and Clinical Care for Childbirth-related Hypertension through Implementation, Engagement, and Valuing Equity) Initiative was developed to support outpatient clinics in providing more effective care to pregnant individuals with high blood pressure. Adapting this bundle for community clinics providing pregnancy care has the potential to reach more birthing people outside the hospital setting who are most vulnerable to complications. In the initial phase of ACHIEVE, the study team partnered with three rural Piedmont Health Services (PHS) clinics that serve mostly White and Latinx patients. The inpatient HTN bundle was adapted to fit their setting and re-named the Outpatient Hypertension (O-HTN) bundle. Additionally, a coalition was established to engage patients, clinic providers/staff, and the broader community to: (a) understand factors influencing maternal health including economic stability, education, health care access, and community context, (b) assess what makes it easier or harder to implement the O-HTN bundle in community outpatient clinic settings, (c) adapt the O-HTN bundle to fit those settings and populations, and (d) select and tailor changes to clinic practices using continuous cycles of learning, measuring and adapting to be the most effective and sustainable for the organization. Building on this formative work, the goal of the clinical trial is to determine the impact of three implementation strategies (training, coaching, facilitation) in 20 outpatient clinics in central North Carolina. Usual clinic care for severe hypertension will be compared to the care provided after a practice has 12 months of implementation support from the ACHIEVE Nurse Coordinator. ACHIEVE partners include healthcare leadership, clinic providers and staff, community-based organizations, and individuals with lived experience who will work together on this project. If the project succeeds in improving care, the ACHIEVE model will be shared across the state and nationally to support healthier birthing people and communities.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety of [18F]-Fluselenamyl and its capacity to image beta-amyloid in the brain of healthy participants as well as in human participants with mild cognitive impairment of Alzheimer's dementia. The imaging agents used in this study include [18F]-Fluselenamyl for PET Imaging and [11C]-Pittsburgh Compound for PET Imaging. It is anticipated that these imaging agents will be non-invasive and have high spatial resolution thus enabling the investigation of disease specific biomarkers. This study will assess the sensitivity and specificity of these PET imaging agents in healthy participants and participants with Alzheimer's disease. The study will also investigate the ability to directly correlate these radiotracers with established biomarkers of Alzheimer's disease. The results of this study will have an impact on improving our understanding of the underlying pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease and potentially uncover biomarkers to diagnose the disease earlier thereby aiding the development of targeted therapy to reverse the disease.

The aims of this study are to determine if active TMS, combined with behavioral therapy, is more effective than placebo to treat aphasia in Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) and to improve daily-living activity, and mood and cognitive symptoms. 
The study aims to include 80 patients aged 18 to 80 with PPA who will be randomized in real conditions of diagnosis and treatment. The TMS protocol will be adapted from our previous clinical work with 4 sessions of active TMS and 4 sessions of sham TMS repeated 5 days in 2 weeks. The sessions will finish with a behavioral therapy specifically focused on reading and writing. All the patients will receive the treatment at home. The effect of treatment will be measured by FDG-PET imaging (standard uptake ratio), linguistic assessments and scales for daily-living activities, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and global cognitive ability (Mini Mental State Examination). The evaluations will be done prior to the initiation of the protocol and 3 months after the treatment to verify the long-term effects of the treatment.
This is a real-world proof of concept study in PPA but a controlled evaluation of the long-term effects of TMS in PPA.

Patients with post-COVID syndrome (PCS) are characterized by persisting symptoms such as fatigue and various cognitive deficits. Neurological symptoms are particularly common and have been suggested to be due to an autoimmune component. Since no treatments for PCS are proven, there is an urgent need to conduct well-designed studies. In this study the investigators aim to investigate the impact of a well-established immunosuppressive drug, Methylprednisolone, on the resolution of fatigue and cognitive deficits in PCS patients. Since many symptoms of PCS may have non-immunological underlying mechanisms, the investigators will use a placebo-controlled design to account for potential placebo effects. Subjects will be screened by clinical investigation and a cognitive battery comprised of the Montreal Cognitive Assessment Scale (MoCA) and the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ). Randomisation will be conducted in a 1:1 ratio to receive either Methylprednisolone (including a tapering phase) or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open treatment phase with Methylprednisolone after a 6-weeks treatment pause. The general IMP (investigational medicinal product) titration regimen will be followed to achieve consistent conditions with the verum (Methylprednisolone). Participants will be assessed at baseline, week 8, week 20 and week 52 by the respective questionnaires regarding cognitive, physical and mental impairment, anxiety, depression, mood, fatigue and quality of life. Investigators will check all participants at week 8 and week 20 for occurrence of adverse and side-effects. This clinical trial is of significant importance as it has the potential to benefit individuals with post-COVID syndrome (PCS) by exploring the effects of Methylprednisolone on cognitive impairment, fatigue and quality of life. Additionally, it may provide crucial insights into PCS's pathophysiological processes, leading to the development of more effective therapies and improved patient outcomes.

The main objective of the study is to analyze the causative factors of malnutrition in inflammatory conditions that complicate a chronic disease. It is a prospective, multicentre study in which patients over 18 years of age with DRM (Disease Related Malnutrition) and inflammatory condition caused by chronic disease are characterized. Patients who meet the selection criteria will be recruited, and 60 subjects will be enrolled. In each patient, blood parameters, nutritional status, body composition and physical performance will be studied at the beginning and after 3 and 6 months of clinical follow-up. An intestinal permeability test will not be performed due to the risk associated with the procedure.
The secondary objective is to measure the efficacy of an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 fatty acids, such as EPA and DHA, and the polyphenols of the olive tree (phenolic oleanolic acid) (EPOCH, POLEN) in improving nutritional status, body composition and physical performance in patients with both conditions of low energy (14 kcal/kg/day) and with a low protein diet (0.5 g/kg/day) and in patients with low protein supplementation (0.5 g/kg/day) and maintenance diet (25 kcal/kg/day).

The investigators aim to investigate the effects of targeted financial support to healthy foods and food security on outcomes for high-risk, low-income Kaiser Permanente Southern California members with Type II diabetes.
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:
1. Intervention Group: The participants will receive monetary support for choosing healthy foods such as vegetables and fruits plus free home delivery of their food choices through the Instacart platform for 6 months.
2. Control Group: The participants will receive free home delivery of their food choices through the Instacart platform for 6 months.
The investigators will evaluate glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels at 6 months and 12 months and other study outcomes at 3 and 6 months after enrollment.
All participants will complete surveys on diabetes quality of life, diabetes self-efficacy, food security, health behaviors, and diabetes-related knowledge after 6 months and 12 months. Those participants who do not finish the study can choose to complete only the post-intervention survey. Participants who finish all study assessments will have their HbA1c at baseline (Enrollment Month) and at 3, 6, and 12 months after enrollment. Participants who do not finish the 12 months of the study will have their HbA1c at baseline (Enrollment Month) and at 3 and 6 months after enrollment.
The investigators hypothesize that participants in the intervention Group will have lower HbA1c levels, less food insecurity, improved dietary habits and quality of life, and reduced hospitalizations and emergency visits.
The investigators will examine associations between targeted financial assistance programs and health behaviors and outcomes at 1 and 2 years.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of the prolonged evaporation time of the solvent of two universal adhesives used in non-carious cervical lesion (NCCL) restoration. The hypothesis is that prolonging of the evaporation time of the solvent of the universal adhesive decreases the surface area and volume of non-carious cervical lesion restored with composite. This study will be conducted on forty healthy volunteers older than 18 years who present, in the anterior half of their oral cavity, 140 NCCL that need to have an occlusal restoration. Each volunteer will present 4 of NCCLs. The non-carious cervical lesions will be randomly divided into experimental and control groups. Four universal adhesives systems with water/alcohol and acetone solvents, respectively, will be submitted to the evaporation protocol of 5 seconds (scenario control group) and 25 seconds (scenario experimental group). Volunteers will receive 4 NCCL restorations in which they will be submitted to different evaporation times for universal adhesives (control group: 5 seconds and experimental group: 25 seconds).

Grounded on the increasing incidence of novel coronavirus mutant strains around the world, especially the prevalence of Omicron (BA.II, BQ.1,XBB) variants with strong evolutionary advantages, it is necessary to carry out an in-depth research, development and evaluation of new COVID-19 vaccines, especially its immunogenicity and safety assessment in previously vaccinated populations. The aim of this trial is to investigate the immunogenicity of the new mRNA vaccines, SWIM816, for immunized individuals compared to the reference mRNA vaccine (Pfizer Bivalent vaccine). This will establish the immunogenicity of SWIM816, and provide the first line of defense for individuals who were previously vaccinated and boosted. Therefore, the study will make an important contribution to the development of global mRNA vaccines for the prevention of the Omicron and other circulating strains.

During the day people are performing physical tasks. These physical tasks can have an effect on the musculoskeletal system. The physical tasks and physical work demands can have a negative impact on health and work ability. This negative impact is especially significant when workers get older. Among senior workers, low physical work demands and low participation in physical activities are major factors to decline work ability. But there is no knowledge of whether these physical demands affect senior workers' health status and musculoskeletal pain differently. Work ability is one of the most important predictors of disability, presenteeism, absenteeism and the need for early retirement. This study investigates how work ability is affected by physical work demands and physical capacity among workers 55- 70 years old. The knowledge of how work ability is affected among seniors is necessary for better treatment, better counseling to the oldest group of workers and for improved guidelines on how to optimize the balance between the physical work demands and the capacity of the worker.

<|assistant|>
Small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer (SCNPC) arises in male patients with pre-existing adenocarcinoma of the prostate gland. There are no established therapies for SCNPC since most clinical trials have been limited as they require specific diagnostic criteria. Additionally, SCNPC is rare and occurs in patients that are generally less fit or of advanced age compared to those with adenocarcinoma. This study will evaluate the safety and feasibility of infusing autologous CAR T cells into patients with SCNPC. This therapy involves re-directing the patient's own blood cells to target their SCNPC resulting in shrinkage or regression of the disease. The investigational drug Bx (bone marrow harvesting) will be used to collect the patient's cells and lymphodepletion chemo-therapy will prepare the patients to receive CAR T cell immunotherapy. Patient's will first undergo a clinical assessment to complete the necessary study procedures and complete blood draws. Within 4 weeks of the screening visit, patient's will undergo leukapheresis to collect an adequate number of T cells. At the time of leukapheresis, patients may receive bridging therapy as determined by the treating physician. Once the leukapheresis is completed, patients will proceed to the next phase of the study and receive cyclophosphamide and fludarabine chemotherapy prior to CAR T cell infusion. The CAR T cells will be infused through a catheter (frequently called a port) or IV. Patients will also undergo repeated imaging (including x-rays, CT scans, PET scans, MUGA tests) and blood work during the course of the study. Patients will also be contacted regularly to check in on their condition. Patients will continue to receive follow-up blood work and imaging throughout the study.

The traditional treatment for pancreatic ductal cell adenocarcinoma (PDCA) which involve both the gastroduodenal and splenic arteries is total pancreatectomy. However, recent studies have shown that distal pancreatectomy with excision of splenic vessels and gastroduodenal artery can safely be performed without compromising survival outcome. In this study, the investigators evaluated safety and efficacy of the new technique, Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA), compared with total pancreatectomy. This is an uncontrolled before and after study. There are few limitations of this study since only the short term outcomes such as the changes in volume of remnant pancreas are measured. This study showed that the majority of PDCA could be resected en bloc by WOTSA.
