The study's purpose is to evaluate the effect of breastfeeding education given via whatsapp messaging application to the fathers in the postpartum period on the mother and father's support for breastfeeding and its duration. The study will be conducted using a randomized parallel assignment design. The intervention group will consist of 2 groups of 82 fathers receiving breastfeeding education. The study will be carried out with the fathers who are registered in the postpartum clinic of the relevant hospital and whose partner has delivered in the relevant hospital. Data will be collected with the Breastfeeding Support Scale, The Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale, Breastfeeding Duration of Newborns Scale, and Postpartum Breastfeeding Diary. Research data will be collected on the 3rd day, 42nd day, and 12th week of the fathers with one phone call.

This non-interventional observational post-trial study aims to evaluate PIK3CA testing frequency, treatment patterns across various lines of therapy, and to explore the characteristics of patients with advanced breast cancer who received treatment that targeted PIK3CA (PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway) from the end of 2013 to the beginning of 2020. Secondary objectives are to assess the number of CDK4/6 inhibitor treatments and the change in treatment from alpelisib (PiqrayTM) or others to CDK4/6 inhibitors. 
All patients diagnosed between 1 January 2015 and 30 June 2020 with HR+ HER2- metastatic breast cancer who had at least one PIK3CA mutation test, who received at least one line of systemic treatment, and who participated in an international Phase III interventional study of PIK3CA inhibitor were included. 
Participants provided a written informed consent to access their medical records to facilitate data collection. Medical records were retrospectively collected for the following time stamps: from the first time PIK3CA testing was performed in the metastatic setting to the end of study (maximum of 65 months after the first test); from the first PIK3CA tested line (if different from the metastatic diagnosis) to the last line administered prior to the first line where metastatic PIK3CA was detected (maximum if 65 months); from the first line where metastatic PIK3CA was detected to the end of study or to the end of each line of treatment that followed (maximum of 65 months after the first tested line in the metastatic setting); from the first line where metastatic PIK3CA was detected to the initiation of CDK4/6 inhibitor in the metastatic setting or to the end of study or to the end of each line of treatment that followed (maximum of 65 months after the first tested line in the metastatic setting); and in the case a patient received both PIK3CA and CDK4/6 inhibitors, from initiation of alpelisib/others to CDK4/6 inhibitor start date or death, to the end of study or to the end of each line of treatment that followed (maximum of 65 months after the first tested line in the metastatic setting). Statistical analyses were done using SAS v9.4 or later (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA).

Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) often experience significant sleep disturbances. Sleep disturbances can exacerbate the symptoms of ASD and have a negative impact on their quality of life and learning. A commonly observed sleep disturbance in individuals with ASD is a reduced frequency and density of sleep spindles, which are an important aspect of sleep organization. Preliminary research has suggested that melatonin supplementation can increase the density of sleep spindles in children with ASD and improve sleep quality. However, this research only included male participants. It is crucial to test the efficacy of melatonin supplementation on female individuals with ASD as they may respond differently to the treatment, making the research findings difficult to generalize to a wider population.

The purpose of this study is to assess the effects of melatonin supplementation on sleep spindles in a diverse population of individuals with ASD. As part of this study, 50 (22 +/- 8 yrs) autism spectrum disorders (ASD) will be enrolled. All subjects will consist of 50% male and 50% female. Subjects will be on a stable regimen of stimulant therapy and will continue taking their ADHD medication as prescribed. Baseline sleep spindle data will be collected for four nights using a portable EEG device. Subjects will then take 5mg of melatonin for two nights and again have sleep data recorded for four nights using the portable EEG device. Sleep spindle data will be calculated using Artiste software and the change in spindle density during NREM sleep will be statistically assessed based on two group analysis (male vs female) using ANOVA. Sleep quality will be assessed using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). This study aims to provide preliminary data describing the effects of melatonin supplementation on sleep spindles in children with ASD, including both male and female subjects. By using a portable EEG device to measure sleep spindles over multiple nights, this study aims to provide direct measurements of changes in sleep spindle density, a key aspect of the study hypothesis. Additionally, the inclusion of female participants will be crucial for understanding the potential differences in response to melatonin supplementation between genders. This study may provide important insights into the efficacy of melatonin as a sleep aid in individuals with ASD.

Introduction :
Persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) is a frequent problem in children with cleft palate (CP) that may negatively affect the quality of their speech. Although velopharyngeal incompetence is still reported in 30% of this population post operative (1), it is difficult to define which anatomical abnormalities that may be present pre or post operative, will expose an increase of this insufficiency.
Despite anatomical abnormalities like a small velum, posterior and lateral wall abnormalities, a short or a high velum, it appears that the true determinant of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency, which may affect speech, is not a question of anatomy, but rather one of muscle dysfunction.
In adults, this dysfunction can be well appraised by electromyography. In children, the only way to study it is by analyzing the anatomy and the physiology of the velopharyngeal sphincter, which may lead to an increase of VPI.
Few studies have characterized the motor skills of the velopharyngeal sphincter using magnetic resonant imaging (MRI) during articulation. Moreover, no study investigated a population of children that present different severity of velopharyngeal insufficiency. The aim of the present study will be to study this motor skills statically (resting state) and dynamically (articulation during phonation) by the MRI by analyzing different anatomical abnormalities of the CP. It will also be the opportunity to determine a relationship between these motor skills and the severity of velopharyngeal insufficiency and its anatomical causes.
Methods :
This is a prospective and monocentric study on children aged 7 to 12 years with Isolated cleft lip and palate (Isolated CLP) or Isolated velopalatine cleft (VPC), without syndrome and treated surgically before first or second year of age.
In this experimental study, the subjects will be divided into 4 groups :
- Isolated CLP subjects operated for isolated lip with a myo mucous flap will be scanned in a supine position.
- Isolated VPC subjects operated for complete or subtotal VPC at the age of 12 to 24 months will be scanned in a supine position. Two groups will be included : those with a soft velopharyngeal insufficiency and normal velum anatomy compared to those with a severe velopharyngeal insufficiencies and abnormal anatomy of the velum.
- Isolated VPC subjects with a normal velum anatomy and a soft velopharyngeal insufficiency will also be scanned in a supine position.
All the subjects will be scanned with a 3T MRI system (ACHIEVA 3T TX Dstream Philips®) and a 33 channels head and neck coil in the supine position using the 3D T1 MPRAGE sequence and the 3D VELO 3.0 sequence (echo time 40 ms, repetition time 254 ms). An elastic strap will be fixed to the forehead to limits movement during scan. A headset will be used to cancel the loud MRI noise and to communicate with the subjects.
On these acquisitions, the motor skills of the velopharyngeal sphincter will be analyzed statically, at rest, and dynamically, during articulation, by a radiologist specialized in the field of head and neck imaging. This analysis will be realized through measurement between anatomical points (sagittal and frontal planes in mm) (velopharyngeal closure distance, ratio between the diameter of pharynx at rest and during phonation) and by measuring the muscles involved by an elastic measuring tape (correlation between VPI and the muscles mass, thickness and surface) (sphincter muscles mass, thickness and surface). The measurements will be assessed 1 mm accuracy.
In addition, all the subject will be assessed by a speech therapist for velopharyngeal insufficiency using the VPI Scale with a score ranging from 0 to 5 (score 0 represent complete velar closure and score 5 represents complete velar incompetence with nasal emission). The subjects will also be evaluated by the pediatric orthopedist for the existence of an orthodontic treatment.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an immune-mediated and neurodegenerative disease of the central nervous system. Older adults with MS present with a wide range of health conditions such as chronic pain, fatigue, depression, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease. MS also presents with cognitive impairments, walking difficulty, disability, exercise intolerance, and reduced physical activity participation. The common approach for managing MS involves disease-modifying drugs, yet this first-line approach for medical management has little efficacy in older MS age groups (i.e., those 50+ years of age). Exercise training has been recognized as a promising approach for managing symptoms and improving physical and cognitive health in older adults with MS. A recent systematic review reveals limited evidence of moderate-intensity physical activity programs among older adults with MS. Notwithstanding, this review did not examine the effects of exercise training on cognition and mobility in older adults with MS. To date, there is a dearth of research examining the benefits of exercise training among older adults with MS. The current study proposes a remotely-delivered exercise training program for improving cognition and mobility among older adults with MS. The proposed research adopts an innovative intervention approach (via telerehabilitation) with rigorous design for evaluating the feasibility and efficacy of a home-based exercise intervention program in older adults with MS who have cognitive and walking impairment. This exercise training program adopts an innovative intervention approach via telerehabilitation and is convenient and accessible for older adults with MS. This research may have practical relevance for improving physical activity among older adults with MS through alleviating travel concerns and reducing environmental/social barriers. If successful, the proposed project will provide foundations for implementing larger, high-quality RCTs using remotely-delivered exercise intervention for managing the consequences of aging and MS and ultimately contributing to successful living with MS.

This study focuses on the effects of using an oXiris membrane for haemofiltration in patients who have vasoplegic shock requiring vasopressin support. The study aims to test the hypothesis that vasoactive angiotensin metabolites are cleared with haemodialysis using blood purification and to determine whether or not this clearance has an impact on mortality. The aim is also to test the in vivo stability of renin in intensive care patients with vasoplegic shock. The hypothesis is based on the results of experimental studies showing that the stability of the circulating renin is directly dependent on the concentration of renin available at the level of the renal circulation. These results demonstrate the major importance of the angiotensin metabolism in maintaining blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance as well as the ability of patients receiving oXiris treatment to decrease vasopressor support and reduce the severity of shock. The aim of the study will be to correlate these clinical observations with the results of in vivo and in vitro biological analyses.

Knee osteoarthritis (Osteoarthritis) is a chronic disease that affects mainly joints of middle-aged and older adults, particularly in those who work physically and who are overweight individuals. Knee osteoarthritis causes pain, reduced physical activity, and the impairment of function with a consequent negative impact on work ability and employment prospects.
The management of knee OA includes medication, joint replacement surgery, education, and exercise that includes strengthening and range-of-motion exercises for knee girdle and ankle-foot.
There have been many trials of physical therapy for patients with knee osteoarthritis, however, most of which have not paid attention to the important role of extra-articular muscles in the management of such patients.
Extra-articular muscle imbalance may have a major role in the pathogenesis of knee osteoarthritis as their imbalance may lead to biomechanical abnormalities that have been associated with joint dysfunction. The imbalance of extra-articular muscles may lead to decrease in range of motion and muscle strength, and increased pain through mechanisms such as triggering nociceptive neurones in the joint that convey pain to the spinal cord. Moreover, weakness of hip rotator muscles can lead to excessive load on the ipsilateral knee girdle while walking, resulting in degenerative changes at the knee joint. Weak, inactivated muscles at calf and ankle plantarflexors may lead to insufficient knee extension while walking that can result in altered kinematics and pain.
Although previous studies have proven the beneficial effects of exercise in patients who suffer from knee osteoarthritis, only few were focusing on the role of extra-articular muscle strengthening in this patient population.
Hence, the main aim of the current study is to investigate the effect of adding exercise for hip rotators and calf muscles to knee exercises on functional level, pain level, strength of muscles, and knee proprioception in patients who suffer from knee osteoarthritis.
The hypothesis for this study is that the addition of exercises for hip rotators and calf muscles, in addition to knee exercises, would provide better improvement in functional level of knee girdle, decreased pain level, improved strength of muscles, and improved knee proprioception than knee exercise alone.

Providing cancer care closer to home presents challenges for providers, with the need to balance the goals of increasing patient access to care and improving patient quality of life. Prior to the creation of the Cancer Center at Siteman Cancer Center (SCC) at Barnes-Jewish Hospital (BJH) and the expansion of its regional network of clinics (satellites), the SCC catchment area included most of east Missouri and all west and central Illinois. Now that cancer care is accessible throughout these areas, patients and providers have had the opportunity to consider whether or not care is being optimally provided at these sites. This study will test the hypothesis that patients prefer treatment at their primary clinical site, thus reducing the burden of travel, and that these patients and their providers are able to continue a successful treatment and monitoring relationship at the primary site. Eligible patients with multiple myeloma who are currently undergoing treatment at SCC sites will be offered a survey at the time of their next regularly scheduled visit by their provider. If the patient lives within the catchment area of an SCC satellite site and expresses an interest in exploring the possibility of care transition, patient and provider discussions to consider care at the satellite site will occur. At the same time, the patient is asked to complete a baseline survey evaluating demographic characteristics, disease status, number of symptoms, and preferences regarding care site. There is also a question to determine whether the patient can easily access their usual provider's office at the satellite site in regards to distance. A follow-up survey to measure disease status, symptoms, provider visits, and patient satisfaction will be distributed to each participant approximately two weeks prior to the participant's routine appointment. At that time all participants will receive a comprehensive questionnaire to obtain information on whether the patient completed the care decision as originally intended. Additionally, a sample of patients who transitioned to the satellite site, and a sample that declined the opportunity, will complete a survey asking for their reasons for their initial treatment site decision and their current preference. This information will be analyzed with a sub-study.

Introduction: Virtual reality has been used successfully in fields of physical and emotional rehabilitation, treatment of anxiety, and analgesia, as well as pain reduction in medical and dental settings. It is thought that Virtual reality can reduce pain and anxiety by providing a digital distraction for patients during procedures. Nitrous oxide is a standard treatment in dentistry to reduce pain during dental procedures or anxious patients. The aim of this study is evaluate the effectiveness of Virtual reality distraction for pediatric patients undergoing routine dental treatment compared to nitrous oxide.
Methodology: This will be a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional study.
Design: Participants will be randomized to one of two groups based on which treatment they wish to explore first. The first group being, the control group receiving Nitrous Oxide and then the Virtual Reality distraction, and the second group being, the treatment group receiving the Virtual Reality distraction first and then the Nitrous Oxide. Participants will be evaluated before, during and after dental treatment using a behavioral scale, pain scale, and survey. The FLACC scale, Wong-Baker Pain Scale, and Houpt Crying and Movement Scales will be used to assess the severity of pain and behavior during the procedure.
Reasoning for study design: It is important to include both forms of analgesia to compare their effectiveness. The crossover design between the two groups helps further evaluate the relative efficacy of virtual reality distraction compared to nitrous oxide, and allow for a fair comparison. Repeated use of the same procedure is difficult in pediatric dental patients as they may require additional intervention or may refuse treatment on subsequent visits, therefore, the use of a crossover design provides the option of using both modes of analgesia in a reasonable time frame. A randomized design was chosen to ensure that participant treatment allocation was unbiased.
Outcomes: The rate of effectiveness, pain and anxiety levels will be measured using the FLACC scale, Wong-Baker Pain Scale, and Houpt Crying and Movement Scales. This will help determine whether the use of virtual reality distraction provides analgesic effects comparable to the use of nitrous oxide.
Significance: The results of this study may potentially lead to a reduction in anxiety and pain for pediatric dental patients. Further studies are needed to determine the long-term effects of virtual reality distraction compared to nitrous oxide and to compare its cost-effectiveness.

Malnutrition is a highly prevalent and complex metabolic disorder that affects over 1 billion people worldwide each year. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines malnutrition as a state of altered nutritional status arising from deficient intake of energy or specific nutrients, malabsorption, infections or inflammation, or imbalance between energy intake and expenditure. Malnutrition is usually associated with deficiency of macro- and micronutrients, infections and inflammation, or alteration of the gut microbiota. These conditions are related with chronic diseases, such as obesity, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, and cancer. In addition, malnutrition in the critical period of early growth is associated with poor brain development, with permanent developmental problems.
Current diagnostic methods for malnutrition and metabolic disorders can detect nutrients as amino acids, micro- and macronutrients, but are very expensive and time-consuming. Other biomarkers that can indicate malnutrition include inflammatory markers or gut microbiota, but these diagnostic tools still have limitations, especially for specific nutritional deficiencies and infections.
A novel and innovative approach could be the use of microRNAs (miRNAs) as specific biomarkers of malnutrition. MiRNAs are small non-coding RNAs that are able to regulate gene expression and impact on numerous metabolic processes, including cellular differentiation, proliferation, and metabolic rate. The expression of miRNAs is often deregulated in pathological conditions, making them very interesting candidates as a tool for diagnosis and prognosis in many diseases.
However, a significant barrier for translating miRNAs into clinical applications is the high cost attached to large-scale miRNA profiling. Next generation sequencing (NGS) technologies allow for the high-throughput sequencing of small RNAs, making it possible to analyze miRNAs in a much more affordable and reproducible manner than old techniques.
Using NGS technologies, the investigators want to generate a non-exhaustive and non-random set of 300 miRNAs using miRNAs array platforms and to identify biomarkers of malnutrition and specific metabolic disorders associated with infectious diseases for their association with inflammatory and infectious processes.
These biomarkers will also be analyzed in saliva and extracellular vesicles as these biological fluids reflect changes in the oral and intestinal microbiota and in host nutrition-derived signals.
To do so, the investigators will recruit 600 patients affected by malnutrition due to nutrient deficiency or excess and sex- and age- matched healthy controls, without malnutrition.
Clinical data will be collected via anamnestic clinical data collection form that will be administered to the participants, including general information (age, sex) and specific information about the onset and characteristics of malnutrition.
Blood, stool and saliva samples will be collected for the study using specific protocols to ensure the quality and integrity of samples for further analysis.
The investigators will analyze the expression of miRNAs in blood samples using a TruSeq Small RNA Sample Preparation Kit (Illumina), and extract and quantify salivary extracellular vesicles, which will be analyzed for their morphology, composition and content.
The investigators will also conduct a metagenomic analysis of fecal and saliva samples, including the metabolic profile and gut microbiome.
Additionally, the researchers will perform specific immunostaining to study the metabolic phenotype and metabolic capacity of different cell types.
The investigators will not use any specific drugs and will only collect samples and clinical data.
All patients will undergo a full clinical examination under the guidance of a physician, to avoid any harm during the collection of samples and data.
In summary, malnutrition is a highly prevalent metabolic disorder resulting in significant health expenses and loss of quality of life. miRNA profiling is a reliable and affordable method to identify biomarkers of malnutrition and of specific metabolic disorders. Understanding these changes will help us comprehend how malnutrition modulates nutrient- and energy-related signals and how the composition and phenotype of the gut microbiota drives the onset and development of metabolic disorders. This knowledge could be used to predict and treat the effects of severe malnutrition on human health, to minimize the risk of associated infectious disease and to improve clinical outcomes from nutritional interventions.

Perioperative stroke is a significant complication after surgery. Unfortunately, covert stroke occurs in one out of fourteen elderly patients after non-cardiac surgery and is associated with an increased risk of long-term cognitive decline. In addition, overt stroke is associated with an 8-fold increase in perioperative mortality, prolonged length of hospital stay, and decreased quality of life. For shoulder surgery performed in the beach chair position, due to systemic hypotension and reduction in cerebral perfusion pressure, cerebral desaturation events and impaired cerebral autoregulation can occur in up to 80% of patients. To address these limitations, this project employs multi-channel time-resolved (tr) functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) (tr-fNIRS) to detect specific brain regions at risk of ischemic injury with greater spatial resolution and less signal contamination from extracerebral tissue.

The aim of the MI-E cycle is to mobilize and clear bronchial secretions and reduce the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The objective of this study is to determine if MI-E sessions can be safely and successfully given to critically ill adult patients using a standardized protocol. This study will estimate the proportion of complete sessions of MI-E in critically ill adult patients without a contraindication for MI-E for up to seven days invasive ventilation. Patient outcomes are monitored regularly. The secondary outcomes include safety, patient satisfaction, respiratory therapy delivery, and clinical outcomes. These outcomes will be used to inform a full-scale study. Functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) presents in patients with heart failure (HF) with preserved or reduced ejection fraction, which is caused by left ventricle (LV) systolic or diastolic dysfunction. TR increases cardiac filling pressure and causes right ventricular dilation, remodeling, and dysfunction. Despite the adverse outcomes of TR, there are few evidence-based therapies available for this condition. Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors improve cardiac and renal outcomes in patients with HF and diabetes. However, there is no evidence for the use of SGLT2 inhibitors in patients with functional TR. This study will investigate whether enavogliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, would improve clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in patients with HF with functional TR and preserved ejection fraction. In a prospective, randomized, multicenter, open-label, placebo-controlled clinical trial of 18 months duration, 554 patients with echocardiographically confirmed moderate or severe functional TR and worsening of TR on follow-up echo during the screening period, will be randomized to receive enavogliflozin or matched placebo. The primary composite outcome will be a clinically meaningful deterioration of the echocardiographic parameters of TR (i.e. tricuspid valve regurgitant jet area ≥20 cm2 or increase of jet area from baseline by ≥ 50%) in addition to hospitalization for HF or all-cause death. The study will evaluate the safety, efficacy, and effectiveness of enavogliflozin therapy in patients with functional TR and HF. To this date, no study has investigated the safety and efficacy of SGLT2 inhibitors in HF and functional TR. If our hypothesis is true, enavogliflozin therapy would be transformative for patients with functional TR.

Women's health services are provided by nursing and midwifery departments in health institutions. In addition, nurses have an important responsibility in terms of informing and giving information to the individual. Nurses who provide a health education service that focuses on the prevention of diseases gain important skills in terms of raising awareness about the importance of health to the individual.
In this context, people who work on health by guiding people to health are called health promoters. Health promotion is an approach that covers individual, social and environmental factors that shape health and that aim to strengthen the abilities of individuals and communities to prevent diseases.
It should be emphasized that as a whole, health is defined as the state of physical, psychological and social well-being. Nurses, who have a significant role in health, work to ensure that people remain in good health throughout their lives in all areas.
Premenstrual syndrome is one of the hormonal changes in women's health and is seen in almost all women. About 50% of the women who have premenstrual syndrome are between the ages of 18-30. Premenstrual symptoms affect about 70-90% of women's daily life. Problems caused by premenstrual syndrome are also seen in the work environment.
People with premenstrual syndrome may experience a series of symptoms during the premenstrual period. Changes that gradually disappear with the onset of menstruation in women are called premenstrual syndrome.
In this syndrome, anxiety, irritability, lack of concentration, depression, mood swings, drowsiness, sleep disturbance, breast tenderness, appetite change, bloating, headache, weight gain, abdominal pain, fatigue and gastrointestinal symptoms are observed.
Since these symptoms negatively affect both the work and personal lives of women, safe and effective treatments are needed. In this case, many women report using exercise as a strategy to help them cope with PMS, and exercise is often recommended for symptom management.
Premenstrual symptoms can also play a role in symptoms by affecting the individual's food choices. Emotional eating behavior is defined as a person's use of food as an escape from negative emotions and can lead to many conditions such as obesity, eating disorders and hormonal problems.
Perceived stress is a state that is defined by an individual's perception of whether the stress levels they have experienced recently have been high or low. When the perceived stress is high, this situation puts the individual under physical, emotional and social stress. It is a state related to the stress one experiences.
The health promotion model proposed by Mc Leran et al. In the 1980s, health education was given based on this model. This model was researched by the researchers in the field of health promotion. This model is based on the fact that people have the right to have control over their physical, mental and social health.
This model is based on the fact that individuals have the ability to control their own health. The factors that the person encounters within the society are within the reach of the individual and can be changed. This model was created by nursing staff to meet the training needs of nursing staff.
The purpose of health education given by the health promotion model is to guide people in the best possible way, to ensure that they choose the path that is good for their physical, mental and social health. Since the trainings given with this model are based on the perception of individuals to their problems, it is possible to determine the success of the training.
The study will be conducted as pretest-posttest randomized controlled research and it is thought that the training given according to the health promotion model will both create a resource for nurse candidates and contribute to the literature with the findings obtained by applying this training to people experiencing PMS.

The prevalence of mental health complaints is high within the prison population. This is problematic because mental health complaints are associated with recidivism. The prison context offers an opportunity to help individuals with mental health issues as treatment needs to be readily available. A problem solving intervention PM+ can contribute to a more effective delivery of treatment. The PM+ program is a brief, scalable approach which is a valuable addition to the current Dutch prisons service. The aim of this study is to investigate the feasibility and acceptability of implementing PM+ for individuals imprisoned in Dutch prisons.
Based on the description of the outcome measures, it seems that the study is focused on evaluating the effectiveness of PM+ in improving symptoms of various psychological disorders such as depression, anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability. Additionally, the study will also examine the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention, including factors such as adherence to the intervention, implementation process, recruitment, and consent rates. The results of this study will provide valuable information on the feasibility and effectiveness of PM+ in improving mental health outcomes among incarcerated individuals.

The Combinations of Olaparib and Alpelisib for Breast Cancer (COMBIBE) study is enrolling patients in a phase II trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the combination of the drugs alpelisib (BYL 719) and olaparib in patients with advanced breast cancer and no remaining effective treatment options.
Participants receive oral alpelisib and oral olaparib (PARP inhibitor) in Phase I; participants receive oral alpelisib and oral olaparib (PARP inhibitor) in Phase II. Genomic analysis of tumor tissue and circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) are also required. Eligible patients will be those with advanced breast cancer and no remaining effective treatment options. The study consists of the following cohorts:
1. Cohort 1: Parallel Assessment of Olaparib + Alpelisib vs. Olaparib with no prior exposure to PARP inhibitors (i.e., PARP inhibitors-naive).
- Experimental: Cohort 1, Arm A (olaparib, alpelisib)
- Patients receive olaparib PO BID and alpelisib PO daily on days 1-28 of each cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days for up to 5 years in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or bone marrow findings consistent with MDS or AML. Patients also undergo MRI, CT, and/or PET scans throughout the trial and a biopsy prior to treatment start.

2. Cohort 2: Randomized comparison of Olaparib - based combinations (olaparib+alpelisib vs. olaparib alone) in patients with BRCA-mutated or PIK3CA-mutated relapsed/refractory advanced breast cancer
- Experimental: Cohort 2, Arm B (olaparib, alpelisib)
- Patients receive olaparib PO BID and alpelisib PO daily on days 1-28 of each cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days for up to 5 years in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or bone marrow findings consistent with MDS or AML. Patients also undergo MRI, CT, and/or PET scans throughout the trial and a biopsy prior to treatment start.
- Experimental: Cohort 2, Arm C (olaparib)
- Patients receive olaparib PO BID on days 1-28 of each cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days for up to 5 years in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or bone marrow findings consistent with MDS or AML. Patients experiencing disease progression have the option to migrate to Cohort 3, Arm D. Patients also undergo MRI, CT, and/or PET scans throughout the trial and a biopsy prior to treatment start.

3. Cohort 3: Olaparib + Alpelisib in BRCA/PIK3CA relapsed/refractory advanced breast cancer patients who have progressed on 1 prior PARP inhibitor
- Experimental: Cohort 3, Arm D (olaparib, alpelisib)
- Patients receive olaparib PO BID and alpelisib PO daily on days 1-28 of each cycle. Cycles repeat every 28 days for up to 5 years in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or bone marrow findings consistent with MDS or AML. Patients also undergo MRI, CT, and/or PET scans throughout the trial and a biopsy prior to treatment start.

This study will provide valuable information about the efficacy and toxicity, and impact on molecular features of breast tumors, of the combination of alpelisib and olaparib in patients with advanced breast cancer.

The prevalence of depression is continuously increasing worldwide. In Denmark, depression is the most prevalent syndrome in the population and a main cause of early retirement. While a clear majority of people who have experienced a depressive episode do recover within a few months, about 30 - 50% of persons still suffer from depression for many years, even for some decades. The syndrome of chronic depression is a serious burden to the individual who suffers and often also has significant adverse effects for the close environment, the society and the economy. People with chronic depression often report that their depression feels intolerable, even though they have been offered various medical and psychological treatments throughout the years. Moreover, there is a high risk of suicide ideation and suicidal attempts among those who suffer from chronic depression.
The current treatment protocol for people who do not recover from depression within a few months has not been evaluated systematically and consists of a broad range of psycho- and somatopharmacological agents, along with psychotherapy of various lengths and modalities. A recent review on interventions for chronic depression reveals a substantial lack of systematic and rigorous evaluation research in this field, despite an increasing body of evidence from meta-analyses and systematic reviews suggesting that psychological treatment might be more suitable than medication treatments for this population. However, so far no single psychotherapy approach has succeeded in changing the course of the illness and to make depressed people fully recover.
The last decade has seen the increased use in clinical practice of Schema Therapy (ST), an integrated modality of therapy that combines cognitive-behavioural and psychodynamic methods and has been developed for the treatment of personality disorders and related problems, such as chronic depression. ST addresses the development and maintenance of schemas, which are stable, habitual and overgeneralized beliefs, memories and emotions that guide the way individuals interpret situations and interact with others. ST is a long term therapy, in the sense that typically the participant attends weekly sessions for a number of years. However, ST has not been scientifically evaluated in a large scale for chronic depression yet, i.e. depression with resistance to treatment that results in more than 12 months of severe depression.
This project has two main aims. Firstly, to investigate whether ST is effective in reducing depression symptoms and improving psychological functioning and quality of life in the treatment of chronic depression. Secondly, to examine the mechanisms of change in ST, especially with regard to ST as a treatment option for individuals with early maladaptive schemas, i.e. those who have developed maladaptive beliefs about themselves and others.
The investigation is designed as a randomized controlled trial, comparing Schema Therapy with TAU (Treatment As Usual) as the comparator (i.e. the control condition). Both types of treatments that are typically available to individuals with chronic depression at the Capital Region Psychiatric Centre in Denmark and at the participating private clinics will be used as TAU. We expect that ST will be superior to TAU.
This trial also focuses on two possible mechanisms of change in ST. Firstly, to explore whether ST improves subjective functioning via changes in specific maladaptive schemes (self-critical, self-sacrificing, overgeneralizing/absolute schemas). Secondly we will investigate whether individual schema patterns, such as early maladaptive schemes, predict the treatment response. Thus we will examine whether schema mode patterns and the quality of schema experiences predict the change in depression and functioning in ST.

Acute respiratory failure is a frequent reason of admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) and mechanical ventilation. The ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome) is a respiratory condition characterized by persistent hypoxemia, even with a large volume of oxygen. The treatment of ARDS has improved since the 80s, with the decrease of lung mechanical ventilation, a treatment itself risky of inducing parenchymal and pulmonary ventilatory overload. In addition to conventional mechanical ventilation, various techniques can be used to increase patient comfort, facilitate pulmonary gas exchange and reduce morbidity and mortality associated with mechanical ventilation, such as recruitment, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or prone positioning. However, they must be performed by specific healthcare specialists or in the context of a high-level center having developed them for a long time. Some studies have suggested an association between the quality of ventilatory management in the context of ARDS and a higher survival rate. In addition, some studies have reported an increase in survival with the use of a protocol by an "ad hoc" nurse. However, many of these studies are of modest quality or have important limitations. In a randomized, prospective multicenter controlled (RCT) with a cluster design, we therefore assessed the impact of a respiratory protocol used by nurses on ventilatory parameters in patients with acute respiratory failure.

Background: The South has the highest rates of new HIV diagnosis with disproportionally high rates among Blacks in the United States. Haitians are disproportionately affected due to social determinants including stigma, poverty and homelessness. This disparity is compounded for Haitian immigrants with HIV due to their unique health care and cultural needs. Haitian immigrants also lack representation in most of the existing HIV interventions. An engagement and retention intervention for Haitian immigrants called iENGAGE (implementing Engagement and Retention Gain with Education) is a structured and standardized patient-centered behavioral intervention, which includes a comprehensive, motivational, and interactive intervention delivered over multiple sessions. The iENGAGE intervention has been developed and tested for African American men and women as part of the first study arm in the proposed study. A culturally adapted iENGAGE to be delivered to Haitian immigrants is a novel and timely research agenda. Objective: The proposed research project seeks to investigate the efficacy of a culturally adapted iENGAGE to improve HIV outcomes (viral suppression) among newly diagnosed or nonvirally suppressed HILWH. The proposed research project builds on knowledge gained from the first study arm and focuses on the adaptation of the iENGAGE to the unique needs of Haitian immigrants with HIV living in the South. Rationale and significance: The proposed study is vital to the health and wellbeing of Hiltonians with HIV in the U.S. The proposed study is critical in identifying key facilitators and barriers to achieving viral suppression and will help to disseminate the culturally tailored iENGAGE intervention. The proposed project will have significant and far-reaching public health impact to promote health equity among this underserved population. Hypothesis: In comparison to existing care received, participants in the HILWH iENGAGE intervention for improving retention in care with optimal viral suppression will have improved engagement in care, viral suppression and outcomes compared to standard care at baseline and post-intervention (week 12 to 14 post baseline). Specific Aims: Aim 1: Conduct a needs assessment to identify barriers and facilitators to engagement in and retention in HIV care and identify key sociodemographic and psycho-social factors at community and individual level of HILWH. Aim 2: To pilot test a culturally adapted iENGAGE HIV engagement intervention by demonstrating feasibility, acceptability and preliminary efficacy for viral suppression among HILWH. Project Design and Approach: This project is both formative and intervention study. Quantitative and qualitative data will be collected from health care service providers and HILWH (AIM 1). The pilot health intervention (AIM 2) for 6 months will be evaluated pre- and post-intervention. A total of 30 HILWH will receive individualized coaching with motivational interviewing techniques. In addition, photovoice will be used as AIM 3 to gather qualitative data.

Endodontic treatment is the mainstay of clinical dentistry. When non-surgical endodontic treatment fails, the alternative is an apicoectomy. This is a procedure, in which the tip of the root is removed and resected, to provide an easier access and complete cleaning of the root. Successful apicoectomy requires complete debridement and a good seal during the final root-end filling process. Complete irrigation and cleaning of the root canals is the crucial aspect for the success of endodontic treatment and root canal apicoectomies. The traditional passive ultrasonic irrigation (PUI) is the current golden standard in root canal cleaning and irrigation procedures. It is considered the most effective non-surgical technique for providing irrigation and cleaning of the root canals to facilitate better access of the root canal fillers. However, PUI is associated with several drawbacks such as its inability to remove the debris and irregularities present on the root canal walls. Also, PUI is a time-consuming and operator technique. This study is aimed at evaluating the effectiveness of hydraulic inertial cavitation (Endoclean) device compared to the passive ultrasonic irrigation protocol in cleaning and debridement of the root canals for routine endodontic treatment.
This investigation is a prospective multicentre study, enrolling 109 patients with symptomatic apical periodontitis of permanent anterior or posterior teeth. Patients were randomly assigned to either the PUI or Endoclean group as arms 1 & 2, respectively. Arm 3 includes the conventional protocol as the control group. The effectiveness of these approaches will be evaluated using the Periapical Index Radiographic Score at 12 months and up to 2 years to ensure healing of periapical lesion. Safety parameters will also be monitored through pain assessment using a Visual Analogue Scale score and the need for pain alleviation medications for up to 7 days of follow-up.

-----------------
A Comparative Evaluation of Effectiveness in Root Canal Debridement Using Inertial Cavitation Device vs Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation and Conventional Preparation: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

* Device: Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation (PUI) group

* Device: Conventional group

Example: Patient with no functional limitations and a well-controlled disease (e.g., treated hypertension, obesity with BMI under 35, frequent social drinker, or cigarette smoker). Patients presenting with symptomatic and/or asymptomatic apical periodontitis and radiographic evidence of apical periodontitis in anterior or posterior teeth larger than 1.5 mm in diameter. Mature tooth with closed apices Tooth that has never been treated with root canal therapy. Presence of fractured instrument in the root canal Pregnant women Patients unable to understand the study procedure.

A number of studies from emergency medicine, anesthesiology and clinical oncology have highlighted the effectiveness of the Z-track and Airlock techniques for reducing pain and drug leakage in patients treated with intramuscular injections. There are no studies on these injection methods in psychiatric practice. In addition, no study has examined the effectiveness of these techniques together in adult patient with schizophrenia on the same drug, Haloperidol decanoate. Furthermore, no study on schizophrenia has highlighted the factors facilitating or hindering the implementation of these methods and their consequences on therapeutic alliance.
Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of combining the Z-track and Airlock injection techniques in order to: reduce pain for patients treated with Haloperidol decanoate at Mental Health Community Centres; reduce leakage of the active product; improve patient satisfaction and therapeutic alliance; identify levers and obstacles to nurses' change of practice (feasibility and acceptability of the Z-track and Airlock).
The study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled, study, in 2 parallel groups. Experimental and control administration protocols will be standardized to harmonize injection practices between the different nurses providing care, and to control some variables. Nurses will have been trained in these protocols and in experimental injection techniques.
The experimental group will be offered an intramuscular injection using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will have an usual injection.
The object of the research is the intramuscular administration technique of an injection - Haloperidol decanoate.

The Feasibility Trial of Preoperative 5-Day Hypofractionated Radiotherapy for Primary Soft Tissue Sarcoma (STS) is the first international randomized study (RRCT) comparing 11+5 fraction preoperative radiotherapy to preoperative conventionally fractionated radiotherapy (CFRT) in primary extremity STS. By accruing patients from 20 cancer sites in the US and Europe, this feasibility trial addresses two challenges with conducting RRCTs in STS, the small numbers of patients with localized disease and the inability to achieve high accrual rates in non-commercial/academic clinics in North America. This study's goals and objectives are to determine the feasibility of accruing a 2:1 randomized RRCT. Achieving a 30% accrual rate of 120 patients (60 evaluable in each arm) within the projected 4 years will enable a conclusive comparison of the two fractionation schedules and allow investigators to design a definitive RRCT with the 5-year accrual rates of less than 7%. The trial's overall hypothesis that preoperative 5-day HFRT is safe non-inferior in efficacy to CFRT for primary non-metastatic extremity STS, is supported by evidence from a phase II trial at UCLA and an open label comparative analysis of 636 patients undergoing preoperative hypo and conventional fractionation published from the International Rare Cancer Initiative Group. The proposed trial involves a 4-year feasibility phase followed by a 4-year definitive trial if feasibility criteria are met. Preoperative 5-day HFRT is a promising approach that could increase the efficiency of care delivery for the treatment of STS. The proposed trial will evaluate if it is feasible to investigate a novel hypofractionated radiotherapy approach in primary extremity STS and inform the design of a potentially transformative study in this patient population.

Background: Hip replacement is a very effective and safe treatment for hip osteoarthritis. Total hip replacement is usually painless, but during the first day after the surgery, severe pain is common. The causes include surgery, the anesthesia used and other reasons. Pain and opioid use in the first day cause gastrointestinal disorders, depression, increased risk of thrombosis and urinary retention.
Objectives: To analyze whether the combination of Pericapsular Nerve Group Block (PENG BLOCK) and lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block are safe and effective to relieve pain after hip replacement surgery.
Methodology: This is a single-center, double-blinded randomized study. The patients who admitted to hip replacement surgery will be included in the study. The cases are PENG BLOCK group and control group.
The PENG BLOCK group receive pain relief through PENG and lateral femoral cutaneous nerve block using intra-operative ultrasound in the operating theater. Pain control is post-operative pain relief through patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) group. This group is morphine PCA.
Measurement: Pre-operative data: collected information including general characteristics of the study patients including age, gender, weight, height, diagnosis, health classification according to ASA. Information was collected including pulse, blood pressure, respiratory rate, SpO2. Intraoperative data that shows the type of surgery, surgical incision, postoperative pain control method, postoperative complications. Post-operative data: collected information including blood test results (urea, creatinine, liver enzymes), pain score (Visual analogue scale - VAS - scale from 0 to 10, the higher the score, the higher the pain level. more), analgesic drug consumption status, respiratory and circulatory changes, adverse events, and analgesic satisfaction.
Pain scale includes the average VAS score (Visual Analogue Scale) at rest and on movement of both groups. The Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) measures pain intensity. The VAS consists of a 10cm line, with two end points representing 0 ('no pain') and 10 ('pain as bad as it could possibly be'). Ask the patient to rate their current level of pain by placing a mark on the line. Time was recorded from initiation of catheterization or PCA insertion (H0) to after 72 hours (H72). Data will be analyzed using the software Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS), version 24.0. The average of the data will be described. The categorical distribution of the data will be analyzed using Fisher's exact test. The parametric data will be analyzed with the independent sample t-test for two groups, and the Wilcoxon test for two groups. The data will be measured and compared in pairs. A p value of 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

<|assistant|> Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of extra-uterine tissue at ectopic sites. Its diagnosis is essentially clinical and requires the association and concordance of signs and symptoms. Abdominal magnetic resonance imaging with MRI with dynamic sequences during pelvic pushing is a very sensitive examination for the detection of pelvic endometriosis, but few data are available on its mobility in the pelvis and on its correlation with symptoms. The main objective of this study is to define a dynamic MRI sequence of the pelvis during pushing (DMP) to assess any mobility changes of the pelvic organs of women with suspected endometriosis who will be subjected to a magnetic resonance examination in routine care. The secondary objective is to see if there is a relationship between organ displacement and women's symptoms. All women who have an initial pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination for the clinical suspicion of pelvic endometriosis will be included in this study. At the end of the examination, a dynamic sequence during pushing will be performed. A subsequent pelvic MRI with a DMP sequence will be performed three months later in case of histologically confirmed diagnosis of endometriosis (after surgery in case of suspicion of pelvic endometriosis on MRI). The investigator will check the patients' records for the occurrence of subsequent pelvic surgery one year later. All patients without endometriosis found at the initial pelvic MRI examination will also be included in this study. They will undergo the same procedures as women with endometriosis during the follow-up period. A post-therapeutic pelvic MRI sequel in the presence of the DMP sequence will be completed in case of pelvic surgery. Patients will be invited to participate in the examination after informing them. The data will be anonymized by masking. Patients will sign a consent form. All MRI examinations will be performed at CHV in Clermont-Ferrand (France). To monitor and evaluate up to date trends and influenza-related health care resource use in vaccinated and unvaccinated child in England since 2012.

Inclusion criteria: All individuals aged ≥2 and <18 years for the purpose of describing the influenza vaccine uptake and health care resource use in England between 2012 and 2020.

Exclusion criteria: The study population will be restricted to individuals between 2 and <18 years with no record of influenza vaccination in the current influenza season.

Primary outcome measure: The proportion of LAIV vaccine is available in England between 2012 and 2020 for LAIV, QIV, and influenza vaccination where the product is not specified.

Secondary outcome measures: The proportion of LAIV vaccine is available in England between 2012 and 2020. The outcome measures include the following:

- GP consultations for ILI (influenza-like illness)
- Laboratory confirmed influenza for ILI
- Admitted Patient Care (APC) episodes associated with ILI
- A&E attendances associated with ILI
- Outpatient attendances associated with ILI
- Length of stay in APC for influenza and ILI
- Number of antibiotic prescriptions
- Number of antiviral prescriptions

Tang poems are not only for language learning, but also induce people's positive emotions. Traditionally, some Chinese parents teach the very young kids to recite Tang poems even before the kids know how to read and write. Reciting Tang poems resembles singing a song without understanding the verses, and some kids can do so better than adults. Tang poems sound musical and should be easier to remember and recite than other texts. Learning and reciting poems at home could be happy and fun family activities in Chinese families. Whether using fun activities on small groups of kids in a community setting to promote Tang poem reciting and happiness could have the same effects of Tang poem reciting in Chinese kids is unknown for non-Chinese. This is a pilot pre-intervention trial with no controls, with 10-20 South Asian children in primary schools (Grades 1-2, age 6-9) being recruited. In most primary schools, grades 1-2 students have not started learning Tang poems. Students and their parents will be actively approached by Hong Kong Christian Service (HKCS). An information sheet will be provided to the parents of eligible children, and their contact information will be asked. Parents give written consent if they agree for their children to participate. Parents will be invited to join the intervention sessions to show support for students' participation but they will only sit at the back of the room without active interaction and learning requirements. The intervention comprises three 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem reciting and one session for participant performances. Experienced instructors from Bestreben Drama Association Limited will lead each session, and adherence to the protocol will be assessed by independent reviewers. Participants will recite two poems per session, with adjustments based on performance. Body language, sound, images, and videos will be used, along with engaging games, to enhance motivation and memory. Participants will receive stamp/sticker collection books and be rewarded for their achievements. Parents are invited to attend the sessions to show support, their role will be passive, sitting at the back of the room without active interaction or learning requirements. A final session will include a 15-minute assessment of poem recitation skills, followed by a performance session where participants can recite any Tang poem. Family members are encouraged to participate, and awards will be granted to motivate and appreciate participants and their families. Assessment will include pre-session assessments (T0, T2, T4, and T6) and post-intervention assessments after each session (T1, T3, T5, and T7). A follow-up assessment (T8) will be conducted 12 weeks after the baseline to evaluate the sustainability of outcomes approximately one month after program completion. Parents will complete questionnaires for themselves (Part II) and assisting their children (Part I). Parental presence and support will be acknowledged through supermarket coupon incentives. The feasibility outcomes will be reported descriptively and narratively, including the recruitment rate, duration, and retention rate. Descriptive statistics, mean (standard deviation) for continuous outcomes, will be reported for the secondary outcomes. The investigators will use content analysis method to analyze the qualitative data from the in-depth interviews. It is expected that those fun activities for reciting Tang poem may help promoting happiness and enjoyment in primary school ethnic minority students in Hong Kong.

Youth suicide remains an important public health problem. Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth and the 10th leading cause of death among all Americans. Adolescents aged 15-19 years old account for 9% of all US suicide deaths, and the numbers are higher among youth aged 10-14 years old. Suicide prevention efforts have been hampered by limitations in current preventive strategies. Despite effective treatments, a significant proportion of adolescents with current depressive and/or anxiety disorders do not receive needed treatment. Moreover, most suicide attempts preceding a completed suicide occur within two years of making an initial contact with a mental health professional. These two limitations have led to a heightened focus on proactive interventions, or programs that support adolescents outside of the mental health system. Yet few programs have been shown to substantially reduce suicide. The purpose of this study is to design and implement a novel proactive intervention that supports adolescents at high risk for suicide before and after making an initial contact with a mental health professional. To do this, the investigators will develop a comprehensive digital platform that allows practitioners to integrate mobile sensing data and HIPAA-compliant client communication tools into their management of youth at risk for suicide. The investigators will conduct a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT and feasibility trial) based at the intensive outpatient services (Intensive Adolescent and Family DBT program (Columbia Doctors)) to test the impact of using the Vira platform for patients versus treatment as usual control (TAU; i.e., not using Vira).

Sadovsky et al. 2020 recently showed that light exposure with blue/green light at night in the evening suppressed melatonin production significantly compared to light exposure of other wavelengths or no light exposure. The degree of suppression was related to non-visual light input that affects pupillary size. Intrinsically photosensitive Retinal Ganglion Cells (ipRGCs) are known to be the primary sensors of non-visual light in the human retina. In this study, we propose to test whether age and sex modify the effect of light on circadian timing and pupillary responses.
Pupillometer studies and laboratory measurements of melatonin concentrations will be performed in women and men between 18-85 years of age to determine the effect of aging and sex on response to non-visual stimuli, specifically using red and blue/green light input to affect the retina. We will study 30 women and 30 men between the ages of 18-85 years of age. The study will be conducted with visits to the laboratory to perform pupillometry and measurements of melatonin and a brief online survey. The study will include 2 nights in which participants will wear a saliva collection device. Participants will receive a light box, and perform a self-selected light exposure during the evening before each night of study. Light exposure will be self-selected, and participants may choose to be in the dark for the evening period. There will be an additional visit on at least 2 days for pupillometry testing. A brief online survey will take about 10 minutes and the visit will last about 3 hours for pupillometry testing.

The outcome measures will be: 1) Change in pupil size in response to different light stimuli during pupillometry testing and whether age and sex make a difference. 2) Comparison of melatonin levels measured in saliva on a night with red light exposure and the following night with blue/green light exposure.

The knowledge of how non-visual light input affects circadian timing on an individual level is important for the prevention or treatment of conditions associated with abnormal circadian rhythms and hormonal imbalances associated with circadian rhythms such as chronic insomnia, depression, anxiety, as well as some types of diabetes mellitus and obesity.

Parents who have ADHD often struggle to raise children with similar disorder. Most existing parenting protocols have not been adapted to meet the specific needs of parent with ADHD, and they often fail to help parents reduce stress, manage disruptive behaviors, and create a predictable and organized environment for themselves and their children. This pilot study tests the feasibility and potential efficacy of the IPSA program for parents with ADHD. The IPSA program combines group-based education and a systematic approach to implementing new parenting skills in the home. It is based in neuropsychology, behavioral parent training, and occupational therapy. The investigators expect that participants in the IPSA group will report greater improvement compared to an active waitlist control group. Findings obtained in this study could lead to a broader adaptation of the IPSA program for use in outpatient clinics and community-based health settings.

This study will test a technology-based intervention (Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention, or SUHRI) for youth aged 14 to 18 years with Justice involvement (i.e., probation). The primary purpose is health promotion with an integrated health-risk approach that addresses the interrelated topics of substance use (SU) and risky sex practices, within the context of personal relationships. This intervention represents a shift towards addressing health-risk behaviors of young people in non-medical settings with a focus on health promotion/risk reduction (rather than diagnosis and treatment of specific problems). The primary aims describe a two-condition evaluation where condition A is a single-arm, non-randomized arm designed to examine preliminary efficacy of the adapted intervention on the proximal outcomes. Youth aged 14 to 18 who are disposed to community supervision (deferred adjudication or probation) and meet eligibility requirements (1+ indicator of substance use, under community supervisions, English-speaking, and no indication of suicide risk or thought disorder) are sampled from a large urban Texas juvenile probation department. Protocol administration is proctored by a TCU research assistant at a private space within a juvenile justice office or mutually agreed upon location of participant's choosing. Youth are asked to complete all assessments and participate in the 4 individualized technology-based intervention sessions where youth receive information and engage in decision making scenario-based games about substance use, sex risk practices, and related health-risk.

Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) patients lack effective therapies for their disease. Treatment mainly targets patients with active inflammation (relapses and/or gadolinium-enhancing MRI lesions) but do little to prevent disability accumulation in the absence of inflammation. Recent trials have suggested that RIC (Remote Ischemic Conditioning) has the potential to protect against neurological injury and may be suitable as a therapy for people with progressive forms of MS. RIC entails cyclical inflation of an upper arm or a thigh cuff for a short 4-minute periods of time 3 times a day. It induces signals or molecules that protect the brain. It is tolerable by people with MS and can be done for up to a year. RIC may have a role in the treatment of Primary Progressive MS. This study aims to find the answer to the question "Is Remote Ischemic Conditioning effective at preventing disability worsening in people with Progressive Multiple Sclerosis when compared to historical (past) outcomes?". This study will be the first to use the RIC device in a study of MS. We will perform the first study for the RIC for people with PPMS. RIC is inexpensive, non-invasive, and can potentially be self-administered by the patient at home - it can be easily integrated into daily life. A positive result in this study would lead to additional larger trials and eventually a widespread use of RIC in PPMS. This will significantly improve the quality of life of patients with MS and their caregivers. In this exploratory, single arm, futility trial, the investigators aim to demonstrate non-futility of RIC for the reduction of disability in people with PPMS.
. The investigators will aim to reduce the Timed 25-Foot walk at 12 months in people with PPMS by 10% or more who have undergone remote ischemic conditioning. If this is achieved, the study will deem the intervention to not be futile. This is necessary prior to designing large scale outcome trials.

Prothrombin time and platelet count are key hemostatic factors that may play a role in mediating the response to steroid therapy. Autoimmune diabetes, celiac disease and cardiovascular diseases have a prevalence of 0.2-0.3%, 1-1.8% and 2-3% in the world population. Since their diagnosis is delayed, at-risk population is usually identified by their first appearance of complications, and an early staging of these diseases, based on low cost blood tests with capillary and/or venous sampling, would thus result in the possibility of reducing the incidence of complications, as shown in several diseases, and their burden in terms of quality of life and economic costs. Indeed, recent studies have demonstrated that even a low-level of autoantibodies is associated with an increased risk of developing celiac disease and type 1 diabetes. For this reason, research of new screening procedures is of particular interest to early detect the disease. Moreover, if a blood screening program could be accepted by the public, it would result in a significant reduction of the overall costs. The aim of this project is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of performing an universal screening program for the most prevalent chronic metabolic, cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases in a population-based setting. In particular, the main purpose of this study is to assess whether capillary screening for these diseases is feasible in a population-based setting and is acceptable and sustainable by public authorities and citizens. This study focuses on two localities in Milan, Italy, where the local population will be tested by a low-risk capillary screening program for blood glucose and lipid levels, and the prevalence of specific autoantibodies for type I diabetes and celiac disease. The main goal is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of performing an universal screening program for the most prevalent chronic metabolic, cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases in a population-based setting. We aim to recruit 4000 subjects from two Localities of Milan (Cerro Maggiore and Magenta) within the next two years. The primary hypothesis is that no more than 55% of the population will participate to the screening program, as it was observed in previous studies where subjects were summoned individually to perform the screening tests. Moreover, we hypothesize that all subjects enrolling into the trial will accept finger-prick tests for capillary sampling of blood levels, and venous sampling will be accepted by 20-30% of them. In addition, the feasibility of the research will evaluate the time required for each screening test and the results will be provided to the subjects within a few days. The ultimate goals of the study will allow a rapid screening of the population, and the reduction of the incidence of complications, improving quality of life and reducing economic costs.

Nursing mothers in Turkey are the primary risk group for smartphone addiction. According to the World Health Organization (2017), one in three mothers spend more than four hours on their smartphones daily during the first five months of postnatal period (WHO 2017). Additionally, mothers can experience infant colic and feeding problems (American Academy of Pediatrics (2012), Levent and Demircanl (2018)) which can be affected by maternal smartphone use. The aim of the present randomized controlled trial is to develop a smartphone cue-reactivity task, an attentional bias modification protocol, and an intervention plan to help nursing mothers who are at risk for smartphone addiction manage their smartphone use during breastfeeding. This study will investigate the main effects, and the possible interactions between nursing mothers' smartphone addiction, breastfeeding-related stress, and maternal-infant bonding.

The clinical trial titled "Bioequivalence Study of Entacapone,Levodopa and Carbidopa Tablets in the Postprandial State in Healthy Chinese Subjects" is a Phase 1 interventional study. It aims to evaluate the pharmacokinetic parameters of Entacapone, Levodopa and Carbidopa under fasting and postprandial conditions. The study is an open, randomized, single-dose, completely repeatable crossover bioequivalence study. It will be conducted on 36 healthy male or female subjects (ages 18 to 45 years) under fasting conditions in a randomized sequence. The subjects will be selected from the subjects without any abnormality of vital signs examination, clinical laboratory tests, and clinically significant abnormalities observed during physical and neurological examinations.
The primary outcome measures include the Peak plasma concentration (Cmax), Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-t), and Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC0-∞). The study period will be Day 1 to Day 9.
The purpose of this study is to assess the bioequivalence between the test tablet (T-L) and the reference tablet (R-L) of Entacapone,Levodopa and Carbidopa in Chinese healthy subjects. The study aims to provide pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic parameter data for the evaluation of the bioequivalence of the test and reference formulation. The study will also describe the safety and tolerability of the test and reference preparations in this subject population and support the registration of Entacapone,Levodopa and Carbidopa tablets in China.

This is a single arm study, which aims to develop new neuroimaging methods which will help to understand brain activity during both physical and psychological symptoms, and will contribute to the understanding of neurological and psychiatric disorders where these symptoms occur. This study will allow us to understand the brain regions involved in health and disease, and how brain regions are connected. We will achieve these goals using simultaneous electroencephalography-functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging at 7 tesla. The aim of this study is to perform neuroimaging in healthy individuals (N=15) and in patients with tremor (N=10), psychosis (N=10) and epilepsy (N=10) to determine how brain regions are connected in 7T functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging and how brain activity differs in the different disorders. Simultaneous electroencephalography and functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging will allow us to examine the activity of electrical signals in the brain (EEG) and the activity of blood vessels in functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) in both the same and different conditions in healthy individuals and patients with neurological or psychiatric features. This project is the first of its kind to use simultaneous electroencephalography-functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging to explore the brain at a microscopic level in neuropsychiatric conditions, and will provide a new and powerful tool for neuroimaging. The results of this study will allow us to achieve a better comprehension of the brain and will have an impact on the management of neurological and psychiatric diseases, with implications for their diagnosis and treatment, and for the development of predictive models for the progression of neurological and psychiatric pathologies. Participation in the study will last approximately 5 hours in total.

The objective of this study is to determine the effect of weight loss on hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in individuals living with obesity and iron deficiency anemia.
This study will consist of two phases: Phase 1, which will be cross-sectional, and Phase 2, which will involve a randomized controlled clinical trial. 
Phase 1: Cross-sectional Study: A cross-sectional study will be conducted to compare hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in people living with and without obesity. Upon obtaining signed consent, participants will undergo a medical history assessment, anthropometric measurements (weight, height, waist circumference), body composition analysis (% body fat, % skeletal muscle mass, % fat-free mass), and blood samples will be collected to determine serum hepcidin levels, iron status, inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, lipopolysaccharides), and oxidative stress markers (MDA). Additional blood samples will be taken for biochemical tests (glucose, lipid profile, creatinine, urea, liver function tests), insulin, leptin, adiponectin, and, optionally, DNA isolation for polymorphisms determination and those associated with iron metabolism and obesity. Participants will also complete a food frequency questionnaire (SNUT).
Phase 2: Open randomized controlled clinical trial: This phase will be conducted to assess the impact of weight loss on hepcidin levels, iron status, and inflammatory markers in individuals living with obesity. Participants recruited for this phase will be selected from those identified in the first phase who exhibit iron deficiency (serum iron < 50 mcg/dL). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two dietary intervention groups. The intervention groups will be as follows: 
Calorie-restricted diet with macronutrient distribution: 1.5 g/kg of ideal body weight in protein (including red meat), 50% carbohydrates, and 25-30% fats.
Calorie-restricted diet with macronutrient distribution: 1.5 g/kg of ideal body weight in protein (excluding red meat), 50% carbohydrates, and 25-30% fats.
Participants in both groups will follow the same dietary plan and will receive ferrous sulfate 200mg every 48 hours for three months to correct iron-deficiency anemia. 
During the initial and final visits, participants will undergo a 24-hour dietary recall, complete a physical activity questionnaire, and fill out a quality-of-life questionnaire. Additionally, anthropometric measurements and body composition analysis will be conducted. Blood samples will be collected to determine various biochemical parameters in the blood, including lipid profile (total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, triglycerides), liver function tests, glucose, insulin, creatinine, urea, oxidative stress markers, inflammatory markers (C-reactive protein and lipopolysaccharides), and iron status markers.
