Pregnant women in need for maternal and/or fetal monitoring are hospitalized at the obstetric high care (OHC) of Máxima Medical Centre (MMC). They are monitored for up to three times a day with conventional cardiotocography (CTG). In the meantime they reside at the OHC, but the status of the fetus and uterine activity (UA) is not monitored. Nemo Healthcare developed a wireless abdominal electrode patch for measuring fetal heart rate (FHR) and UA: The Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS). Previous research on non-invasive electrophysiological CTG (eCTG) has yielded promising results in monitoring FHR and UA both during pregnancy and labor. With the use of eCTG technology, safe continuous 24/7 monitoring is possible, which is not possible with conventional cardiotocography. The investigators hypothesize that by introducing continuous antepartum eCTG monitoring perinatal and maternal outcomes will improve. The investigators aim to include 1911 pregnant women ≥18 years old with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation requiring hospitalization on the OHC for maternal or fetal surveillance (including 1400 historical controls). Additional objectives: The collected NFMS and demographic data will be used to develop and verify a mathematical model for the prediction of time until (preterm) birth, which may be used in clinical practice to reduce unnecessary OHC admissions and facilitate a better timing of interventions. Furthermore, data collected in this study (NFMS, accelerometric, annotated ultrasound) will be used for the development and verification of a mathematical model for the automated detection of fetal movements in NFMS data. This latter model might provide new opportunities in non-invasive monitoring of fetal health.

A number of rare, severe and life-threatening infectious diseases have been reported for which a genetic origin may play a role: these are mainly viral infections but also bacterial and fungal infections. These infections are often disseminated and can become fatal. The aim of this study is to identify the factors that could explain this predisposition, in order to enable the early recognition of patients at risk. To do this, multiplex families will be sought in consultation with the Regional Reference Centers for Infectious Diseases. A retrospective search will be conducted in the computerized medical files and in the biological samples of these patients, their parents, their siblings, the relatives of the deceased patients and the relatives of the non-related patients, living or deceased, who presented the same disease as the index case. The multiplex families will be sought in consultation with the Regional Centers for Infectious Diseases and virology. The collection of samples will be carried out in the same centers. The samples will be collected if a non-consanguineous multiplex family is found among the patients suffering from an infection included in the study (except for viral infections which do not have sequels). The genetic analysis will be carried out on the DNA and RNA extracted from blood and from the skin cell sample (dermo-biopsy only in some cases), and will allow us to identify mutations in genes involved in susceptibility to infections, but also in genes that modify the immune system.
Infectious diseases: Disseminated bacterial, protozoal or viral infections.
1. Bacterial infections (meningitis, osteitis, endocarditis, osteoarticular infection (HLA 1), septicemia, Lyme disease)
2. Infections provoked by a viruse
3. Infections provoked by a fungus (mucormicrocosis, Candidiasis, histoplasmosis, coccidioïdomycosis)
4. Severe infections from an exotic origin (dengue, chikungunya, zika, yellow fever)
5. Infections in which the sequel is recurrence or chronicity (encephalitis, dermatosis, neurological, hematological, digestive, cardiac sequelae)
6. Infections with severe sequelae (encephalitis, dermatosis, neurological, hematological, digestive, cardiac, etc).)
7. Infections with a disseminated germ

The researchers conducted this cross-sectional study among married women living in Aksaray province, Turkey to examine the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life (QoL). The study design is a descriptive cross-sectional study, and the population consisted of 206 married women living in Aksaray province, Turkey.
Those who agreed to participate were included in the research. Those who did not want to participate were not examined.
Demographic characteristics of the respondents, health status and related problems, socio-economic aspects of the participants, life history, lifestyle, habits, medical history, physical activity level, and UI and its related factors were surveyed. The UI symptom, type, duration, and risk factors of UI were assessed using the Female Urinary Incontinence-Short form (FUI-S) questionnaire, the Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-7 (IIQ-7) questionnaire, and the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) questionnaire.
The prevalence of UI was found to be 35.1% in married women aged 18 years and over. The most common type of UI is stress UI, followed by stress-mixed incontinence, urge UI, and urge-mixed incontinence, respectively. The prevalence of UI increases with age, and it is also found that it is more common in those who are obese, have chronic diseases, have a sedentary lifestyle, and experience pelvic floor muscle weakness. The mean urinary Incontinence Quality of Life score was found to be 47.2± 39.5, with the lowest mean score in terms of sleep, sexual life, and body image. In multivariate logistic regression analysis, it was found that the use of diaphragm was a preventive factor for UI. It has been determined that UI causes social problems, dissatisfaction with body image and sexual life, and that it has an impact on self, interpersonal, and social aspects of the lives of women. It was emphasized that in order to reduce UI rates, social awareness needs to be raised, and people with UI, especially married women, need to be treated effectively and holistically, and multidisciplinary management needs to be provided.

Inclusion criteria: 1. Over 18 years
2. Married women
3. Those who agree to participate in the research

Knee osteoarthritis (OA) is the most frequent condition, responsible for pain, disability and the loss of quality of life, and the leading cause of disability in developed countries. A possible strategy to prevent or delay the progression of OA is to repair articular cartilage focal defects. Bone Marrow Aspirate Concentrate (BMAC) and Minimally Manipulated Adipose Tissue (MM-AT) have been reported to improve outcomes in patients with degenerative and traumatic diseases. While a vast majority of available studies support a positive effect on symptoms and signs, there are no rigorous studies that allow BMAC and MM-AT to be considered as standard regenerative treatment of knee OA. In the current study, the investigators propose to conduct an RCT to compare the safety and efficacy of BMAC with that of MM-AT as cell-based infiltrative therapy for knee OA. The investigators hypothesize that both BMAC and MM-AT could be effective in preventing OA progression and improving patient-reported outcomes. This study will provide fundamental data to confirm or amend the current indications of BMAC and MM-AT in the treatment of localized knee OA.

No current pharmacological therapy for insomnia that are non-benzodiazepine and non-z-drugs has been demonstrated to be effective. Cannabidiol, a constituent of hemp, has shown promise as a potential therapy for insomnia. The objectives of this study are to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CBD TPM Capsules compared to placebo in inducing sleep and improving the quality of night time sleep in adults with insomnia. A multi-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study will be conducted in adults with insomnia disorder. Two doses of CBD TPM Capsules, 75mg and 150mg, will be compared to placebo in two different cohorts. Each participant will receive treatment for 8 weeks. The primary outcome measurements include mean change from baseline of insomnia severity index score at 8 weeks and mean change from baseline in subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks.

Cirrhosis is defined as fibrosis of the liver in which a dense fibrous network or scars replace the normal liver cells resulting in the distortion of the normal liver architecture. The prevalence of cirrhosis on the earth is still high (>20%) with most commonly etiology including the infections such as Hepatitis B, hepatitis C, schistosomiasis, clonorchiasis. Intestinal parasitic infections have been considered to cause many complications in cirrhotic patients. However, there is not enough data in cirrhotic patients of Sohag University Hospital. The present study design aimed to detect the pattern and prevalence of the intestinal parasitic infection in the cirrhotic patients as well as to compare them with the pattern and prevalence in the non-cirrhotic persons to define the risk factor that may affect it.
Here, we want to design a study to determine the difference between the parasitic pattern and prevalence of cirrhotic patients and compare it with the non-cirrhotic patients in Sohag University Hospital, Sohag, Egypt.
Objectives:
The objective of this study is to determine the pattern and prevalence of the intestinal parasitic infection among cirrhotic patients with and without GIT symptoms in Sohag University Hospital.
Methods:
Patients and Methods:
Cases group: Case will be assigned to the hundred cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal symptoms or without will be included during the period of study time (July 2019 to March 2020). The patients' data will be collected (name, age, sex, parity, residence, profession) and the patients will be subjected to history taking, physical examination, parasitological examination of the stool, and the patient will be subjected to the full clinical liver assessment according to the guidelines of the American association for the study of the liver.
Control group: The control group will be one hundred patients with GIT complaints but not have any cormorbidity and will be divided into another arm.
The parasitological examinations of the stool will be done as follows:
The patient will be invited to submit two sets of stools to be examined separately for Ova& parasitic eggs. The first examination set should be taken from the patient while presenting their problem, and in the case of absence of the sample, the sample will be given home. The second examination set should be taken after one month from the first sample.
Finally, the final diagnosis will be achieved according to the Egyptian guideline for the liver.
The Ethical committee of the Sohag University will be presented with our study protocol, and it is expected that ethical approval will be achieved.
The study duration will take 5 months to collect the data and samples, and the results will be announced after a time interval of 12 months from the submission of this study.
Data Analysis:
The collected data will be processed and analyzed statistically using Microsoft excel version 10 and the software program Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS) version 20. Descriptive analysis such as absolute and relative percentages will be used to describe the results.

This study will allow us to detect the pattern of intestinal parasitic infection in the cirrhotic patients in Sohag University Hospital, Sohag, Egypt, and the risk factors that may cause it.
As a result, the study will find that there is an increase of the intestinal parasitic infections in the cirrhotic patients with a frequency of 30% to 35%, and the differences detected in the intestinal parasitic infection pattern between cirrhotic and non-cirrhotic patients will be due to the differences of the risk factors found in the study.
The results will be published in a peer-reviewed medical journal, and the patients will be informed about their liver health and preventive measures to reduce the risk of transmission of intestinal parasitic infection.

Purpose:
The purpose of the current trial is to compare the effect of adding intraocular gas tamponade (IFT) versus sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas tamponade versus perfluoropropane (C3F8) gas tamponade versus scleral buckle (SB) during combined vitrectomy /SB for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD).
The need for retinal reattachment surgery is one of the most common surgical eye emergencies. The most frequent cause of retinal detachment is a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD), a separation of the retina from the adjacent choroid and sclera. RRD is due to a defect in the retina allowing subretinal fluid to accumulate, leading to retinal detachment.
In the past, standard treatment of RRD was a combination of PPV and SB. However, with advances in the surgical technique and better treatment of vitreoretinopathy by PPV, the role of SB is becoming more debatable.
Intravitreal gas tamponade (ITG) as an adjunct to vitrectomy provides a tamponade effect to the vitreous cavity and facilitates adequate time for retinal adhesion. The tamponade effect also aids in maintaining anatomic integrity of the retina and provides time for the fibroglial substrate of the retina to undergo healing in cases where a retinal detachment occurs. In vitreoretinal surgery, the application of ITG allows for adequate time for the retina to reattach. The duration of exposure of intraocular gas to the globe is short because the gas disappears once absorbed by the peritoneal fluid. The inert nature of gas allows for a reduction in intraocular pressure over time in conjunction with the healing process.
Despite the advantages of using gas tamponade in the treatment of RRD, there are potential postoperative complications associated with gas including gas migration; gas bubble-related problems such as gas bubble opacification, gas bubble-related pain, and gas bubble-related discomfort to the eye and/or visual acuity impairment. Hence, the current trial investigates ways to help avoid issues with standard SF6 while taking advantage of the good properties attributed to C3F8. Based on the potential advantages of each treatment option and their inherent risks, it was decided to compare the 4 combined treatment options used in this trial in patients with RRD who are eligible for combined PPARV plus SB. It remains therefore to be decided whether these potential complications are outweighed by the increased benefit that the retina adherence obtained with the use of gas tamponade provides. The ultimate goal of this evaluation is to determine the best practice with regards to the use of combined PPARV plus SRT in standard retinal surgery and ultimately in improving the overall visual outcomes of these patients.

Research studies show that pregnant women with restless legs syndrome (RLS) experience the same complaints as non-pregnant people with restless legs syndrome. They report an increase in restless legs syndrome complaints during pregnancy, and it increases with gestational age. RLS complaints cause insufficient sleep, severe sleep disturbance and, as a result, a decrease in their quality of life. Women with restless legs syndrome who have severe sleep problems have high frequencies of depression, chronic fatigue and anxiety compared to women who do not complain about restless legs syndrome.
Pregnancy also causes an increase in the number of complaints about edema in pregnant women. The most common place of edema is the swelling of the feet of pregnant women. The most effective way to prevent swelling of the legs and feet is to use pressure socks during pregnancy.
It has been found that RLS complaints in pregnant women decrease with the effect of pressure socks. Pressure stockings increase blood flow in the legs and feet, prevent swelling. It is seen that compression stockings provide relief in the lower extremity edema which is the most common complaint in pregnancy and is effective in reducing the edema complaints in non-pregnant patients.
Pressure stockings have also been used in other areas. For example it is used in patients with edema complaints in the legs and feet, in patients undergoing cancer chemotherapy to prevent or reduce edema complaints in the feet, in patients with peripheral neuropathy in diabetes or other chronic complaints and in patients during long air flights, to prevent thrombosis complaints in the legs and feet. In patients with chronic neuropathy complaints in various areas and in other patients with complaints in the feet and legs due to chronic complaints; Pressure stockings are used to relieve these symptoms. In patients with diabetes, it is shown that the severity of diabetic neuropathy increases after the use of compression stockings in diabetic feet and legs.
In the scientific literature, it was not found in the database whether the sleep quality of pregnant women with RLS was effected by using pressure stockings.
In this study, which was planned to understand whether pressure stockings were used in pregnant women with restless legs syndrome, it was aimed to investigate whether these complaints would improve or change the quality of sleep of pregnant women and whether the quality of sleep would be increased.
The investigators aimed to compare the scores of the RLS Severity Rating Scale (RLSSRS) questionnaire, which is a validated scale for the evaluation of restless legs syndrome symptoms and the global scores of Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), which is a validated scale to evaluate sleep quality. The investigators compared the effects of using pressure stockings on the RLS severity and the quality of sleep in pregnant women.
After the necessary permission was obtained, a total of 60 pregnant women with RLS complaints with normal sleep patterns, including pregnant cases in the antenatal clinic of the Kahraman Maras State Hospital Department of Obstetric and Gynecology, and with a gestational age of 27 weeks or above, were included in the study. The cases who volunteered to participate in the study were included in the study after the patient information form, the PSSQRS scale in pregnancy, anemia, hemoglobin level, medical and obstetric history were evaluated. After the information form was completed and the scale and anemia were completed, pregnant women with RLS symptoms and quality of sleep complaints were included in the study. The patients were randomly assigned to two groups, the compression stocking group and the control group with knee socks, after the necessary randomizations were made. The 10 patients in each group were followed-up for 21 days. The PSQI and the RLS severity scale scale were evaluated in the first and 21st week. The scales were applied to the patients face to face. The scale data obtained from the patients in the study were recorded on the data collection form prepared for this purpose.

Postoperative pain following lumbosacral surgeries not only contributes to significant morbidities but also hampers early mobilization. Perioperative opioids, though relieve pain but hampers consciousness, increase PONV and delays mobilization. Caudal epidural block can be effectively given preemptively to alleviate pain and facilitate early mobilization. Caudal epidural block places the needle through the sacral hiatus into the epidural space to deliver medications. It can be performed as ultrasound guided procedure with very high successful rates. Single shot caudal block with local anesthetic (e.g. Bupivacaine, Ropivacaine or Levobupivacaine) provides analgesia for 2-4 hours but this can be further prolonged by adding adjuvants like opioids, steroids, ketamine, alpha 2 agonists, adrenaline etc. Ropivacaine is a long-acting amide local anesthetic agent which is less lipophilic, less cardiac and central nervous system toxicity with similar duration of analgesia, has lesser motor blockade and facilitates earlier mobilization than bupivacaine. Dexamethasone is a highly potent, long acting glucocorticoid. Caudal dexamethasone prolongs the analgesic duration of the ropivacaine. The aim of this study is to evaluate the role of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral surgeries and to compare the effect of adding dexamethasone to ropivacaine with respect to quality of analgesia, duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects and associated side effects. Patients will be allocated in one of the two groups, I and II, consisting of 30 each, using a lottery based random number. A box containing 60 chits, with 30 labelled as group I and other 30 as group II, will be given to each patient and will be asked to take out 1 chit. The group allocated will be written in separate paper by an anesthesiologist, who will also prepare drugs. Decoding will be done later after completion of all data collection.The patient in Group I will be given caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml containing dexamethasone 8 mg (0.5% Ropivacaine 10 ml + 8 mg/2 ml Dexamethasone + 8 ml NS) and group II will be give 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml. All the data collection will be done by another anesthesiologist, not involved in group allocation, drug preparation and administration.

Injuries are the fourth leading cause of death in children and one of the biggest contributors to the global burden of disease. Over 90% of these injury deaths and global burden of disease are in low and middle income countries, including Tanzania. In the Kilimanjaro Region of Tanzania, over 1000 children die every year from severe injuries. Over 50% of these deaths can be prevented by timely access to high quality life-saving care. Children die because they do not receive the high-quality, necessary care they need. The Pediatric Injury Knowledge, Innovation, Design (P-Kids) study is a mixed-methods implementation research study aiming to address health systems factors that hinder timely access to life-saving care for our youngest injured patients. The interdisciplinary and intercontinental team is working across two facilities in the Kilimanjaro region of Tanzania to improve timely access to care through a comprehensive health systems intervention.
The investigators will gather formative research findings to guide development and refinement of a contextually appropriate, evidence-driven health systems intervention integrating the Basic Emergency Care and Pediatric Resuscitation and Trauma Outcome (PROMIS) model. The investigators will then pilot the innovation in healthcare providers and facilities in Tanzania.

The hypothesis of this study is that a very short-course of antibiotics for acute cholangitis is non-inferior to a course of 4 to 7 days after adequate biliary drainage. This study is designed as a multicenter non-inferiority randomized controlled trial. Patients will be randomly assigned to the intervention group (one day of antibiotic therapy after ERCP) or the comparator group (4 to 7 days of antibiotic therapy after ERCP). The primary outcome measure will be the clinical cure rate of acute cholangitis without relapse at 14 days. This will be compared to a non-inferiority margin (difference in cure rates between groups of 5%) and with the international Tokyo Guidelines. If this is not achieved, then the one day group is not adequate to treat cholangitis resulting in unnecessary overtreatment with antibiotics.

Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria
-----------------
The inclusion criteria consist of a broad range of acute cholangitis etiologies as currently accepted definitions. Exclusion criteria include several comorbidities that impact the immune response and healing after antibiotic therapy. Contraindications for an antibiotic treatment are also included as exclusion criteria. In total, 133 patients will be needed to include 91 patients in each study-arm. Inclusion criteria:
Patients with acute cholangitis due to common bile duct stones, benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction or distal biliary stent dysfunction (only stents in situ for a minimum of 30 days) ERCP with adequate biliary drainage (all common bile duct stones are removed and/or there is adequate flow of clear bile with or without a biliary stent(s)) Absence of fever (temperature <38.5°C) or a decrease of body temperature of at least 1°C has occurred within 24 hours after ERCP Age ≥ 18 years Written informed consent (IC) Exclusion criteria:
Other aetiologies of acute cholangitis (e.g. primary sclerosing cholangitis, (sub)hilar and/or intrahepatic strictures or hilar stents) A recurrent cholangitis (within 3 months) Patients with surgically altered anatomy (leading to biliary-enteric anastomosis) Concomitant pancreatitis, according to International Association of Pancreatology/American Pancreatic Association guidelines. Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed in case fulfilment of 2 out of 3 of the following criteria: Upper abdominal pain Serum amylase or lipase >3x ULN Signs of acute pancreatitis on imaging Concomitant cholecystitis, according to TG18 criteria. Acute cholecystitis is suspected in case one item in A is met and one item in B and C. A. Local signs of inflammation A1: Murphy's sign A2: Right upper quadrant mass/pain/tenderness B. Systemic signs of inflammation B1: Fever B2: Elevated C-reactive protein B3: Elevated WBC count C. Imaging findings characteristic of acute cholecystitis Additional infectious diagnosis including but not limited to aspiration pneumonia, abdominal abscess, Clostridioides difficile infection and bacteremia Another additional infectious diagnosis Neutropenia

Studies conducted on the cardiorespiratory complications in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery reported different results of intraoperative Oxygen saturation and haemodynamic status. The routine use of lung expansion maneuvers has been advocated for the prevention of atelectasis and atelectrauma in obese patients. The standard lung expansion maneuver is the application of a PEEP followed by several inflations with a manual bag-valve device, which requires manual ventilation. Ultrasound is a novel tool to assess regional changes in lung morphology. Several studies have been performed for intraoperative lung ultrasound monitoring to detect the occured lung atelectasis and the potential application of lung ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuvers. The study will be conducted on morbidly obese adult patients scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. Lung ultrasound score will be performed every intraoperative hour by one of the investigators, an anesthesiologist who have been well trained and certified by the ultrasound department of the university hospital. Patients enrolled will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: two intervention groups in which the lung recruitment maneuver will be given with the help of lung ultrasound when atelectasis detected by lung ultrasound, or when the lung recruitment maneuver will be applied routinely at different times of surgery. The third group will receive only mechanical ventilation. The investigator who will assess the primary outcome (lung ultrasound score) will be blinded from the intraoperative treatment assigned to the patients.

Inclusion criteria: adult morbidly obese patients of BMI more than 40, scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. Exclusion criteria: patient refusal, patients with history of severe obstructive or restrictive pulmonary disease, patients with severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), presence of emphysematous lung bullae, decompensated cardiac disease (NYHA class 3 or 4), patients with uncontrolled hepatic or renal disorders.

Optimization of Fractionation Schedules of Heel Spur Radiotherapy

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study evaluates dose and fractionation schedule in radiotherapy of painful heel spur. One of the advantages of low dose external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) is its anti-inflammatory effect. Current treatment practice consists of administering low dose EBRT in a fractionated scheme. There are data showing dose effectiveness correlation. The fractionation schema of Heel Spur Radiotherapy treatment currently in use is not clearly defined.. Our study aim is to compare the efficacy and safety of different fractionation schemes and single doses. It is planned to treat 106 patients with chronic pain heel spur in six fraction dosing schemes and in one dose-fraction. Radiotherapy will be administered as outpatient procedure. Patients of 40 years of age and older, eligible for radiotherapy, diagnosed with heel spur for at least six months and having painful heel will be enrolled. The primary endpoint is pain relief measured by Calcaneodynia sum score. We will also analyze the questionnaires.

Gastroparesis is a clinical syndrome in which the stomach has impaired coordination of muscle contractions. The prevalence of gastroparesis is estimated to be 3% of the population in the United States. G-POEM is a novel therapeutic approach for patients with refractory (persistent symptoms for >6 months refractory to medical therapy) and severe gastroparesis based on GCSI > 2. In previous retrospective studies and a single randomized controlled trial, clinical symptoms significantly improved after G-POEM. However, only one study compared single versus double pyloromyotomy. It showed a higher clinical response rate after 3 to 6 months of two-portal pyloromyotomy (double pyloromyotomy) compared with one-portal pyloromyotomy (single pyloromyotomy). However, the follow-up reported in a small number of patients and the long-term outcomes and the durability of the different techniques between single versus double pyloromyotomy have not been investigated. Therefore, our hypothesis is that the double pyloromyotomy technique results in a significantly higher clinical success rate compared with the single pyloromyotomy in patients with refractory and severe gastroparesis undergoing endoscopic per-oral myotomy. In this randomized controlled prospective multicenter study, we aim to compare clinical outcomes and the efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy in G-POEM for refractory and severe gastroparesis.

This pilot study will investigate whether, in participants with chronic spinal cord injury, exposure to acute intermittent hypoxia followed by transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) applied in conjunction with resistance training and grip strength training, results in larger respiratory and upper limb strength gains compared to a placebo (sham) tSCS treatment. In this pilot study, 12-14 participants with complete (C7-C8) or incomplete (C6-T9) spinal cord injury will be recruited. All participants will undergo baseline measurements of respiratory and hand-grip strength, as well as measures of neural circuitry responsible for respiratory drive [i.e., transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and cervical magnetic stimulation (CMS)]. After the baseline assessment, participants will undergo three experimental sessions where AIHH immediately precedes or follows tSCS delivered via surface electrodes. Within each tSCS/AIHH condition, participants will breathe normally for the first 60-75 seconds, followed by 4 minutes of normoxia and 4 minutes of AIHH. After the ventilation protocol, participants will undergo 20 minutes tSCS interspersed with grip strength training (3 x 10-second repetitions/min) performed bilaterally. The experimental intervention will be randomized using a crossover design, where participants will complete a total of 9 sessions (A, B and A, B and C). Session A will consist of AIHH followed by tSCS. Session B will be sham AIHH followed by sham tSCS, whereas Session C will be normal air followed by placebo tSCS. Participants will be kept blind regarding the sequence of intervention. The AIHH/tSCS sessions will be separated by ≥ 1 week for washout.
To investigate changes in neural circuitry related to respiratory, arm and hand movement, participants will be assessed again immediately after the intervention, and will be reassessed 2 weeks post intervention. After each experimental sessions, all participants will be asked to provide feedback via a survey about their comfort levels and experiences.

The human brain consumes nearly 20% of the body's oxygen and glucose during wakefulness. Its supply and demand are tightly coupled and this coupling is called the cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2). The human brain maintains CMRO2 stability under normal conditions and consumes more oxygen when performing cognitive tasks. When the brain is exposed to a lack of oxygen, or an excessive amount of carbon dioxide, or when its blood-flow is reduced, CMRO2 will decrease and the relative oxygen extraction by the brain (OEF) will increase, resulting in ischemic events such as strokes. The relative oxygen extraction by the brain is used clinically as a tool to detect brain ischemia.

In anesthesia and intensive care setting, hemodynamic, metabolic and neural conditions may change rapidly, and thus it is crucial to accurately detect and respond to CMRO2 changes in real-time. The purpose of this research is to evaluate the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on the changes in cerebral hemodynamics and metabolic rates during surgery.
In recent decades, research on monitoring brain activity and metabolic status has moved beyond studying the brain's activity or disease, to studying the relationship between brain function, brain metabolism and the environment of the brain, such as blood perfusion. New non-invasive brain monitoring technologies which are relatively cheap have attracted the attention of many investigators. However, the majority of these studies only use signals from the scalp surface, which provides information about the metabolic status of scalp but not brain tissue itself.

A new developed device that combines two signal-measuring technologies in a single unit, the time-resolved (tr)NIRS device, is able to provide continuous monitoring of cerebral blood flow (CBF) and hemoglobin-oxygen saturation at the same time. In addition to CBF, complementary diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS) is applied, which monitors the microvascular blood flow (i.e. tissue perfusion). By combining these two signals, CMRO2 can be calculated. Compared to NIRS alone, trNIRS/DCS can accurately measure tissue perfusion to provide quantitative data about oxygen supply and demand in the brain. The validity of the trNIRS/DCS system has been tested extensively in healthy volunteers and critically ill patients, and we have shown that it can accurately monitor cerebral metabolism in these settings.

This research aims to collect data from 80 adult patients undergoing surgery to evaluate the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on the changes in cerebral hemodynamics and metabolic rates during surgery. Four groups composed of a mix of patients undergoing different types of surgery are designed:
- G1: Propofol group, phenylephrine group
- G2: Sevoflurane group, phenylephrine group
- G3: Propofol group, ephedrine group
- G4: Sevoflurane group, ephedrine group

The data collected using NIRS/DCS will provide direct evidence of the changes in CBF and CMRO2 before, during and after anesthesia induction, and throughout surgery between the two anesthetic maintenance groups (sevoflurane vs propofol) and the two vasopressor (phenylephrine vs ephedrine) groups. We anticipate that there is a lack of CMRO2 studies under the influence of anesthetic maintenance agent and vasopressor due to the lack of accessibility of bedside cerebral hemodynamic monitors.
We propose this 4-way, prospective, randomized, blinded and controlled study to address this research gap. This research will examine anesthetic-induced changes in cerebral blood flow and metabolic rate by comparing the four proposed groups, and to investigate the effect of vasopressors on cerebral blood flow and metabolic rate in adult patients undergoing general anesthesia. We believe this research is vital to advance our knowledge regarding cerebral blood flow, metabolic rate and vasopressor in clinical setting.

The RaDiCo Cohort aims at studying adult and children with imprinting disorders (ID) at the clinical, biological, genetic and morphometric levels. An investigation of the prevalence of metabolic aberrations (MA) and their influence on cardiovascular risks, metabolic syndromes, obesity as well as diabetes in these patients is planned. To better understand the metabolic phenotype, a biological analysis will be performed as well as a gene sequencing analysis to decipher the molecular bases of the metabolic phenotype. In a second phase, a genetic study will be carried out to better understand the pathophysiological mechanisms of these disorders and to detect the molecular origins of these pathologies in children and their families. Quality of life will be analyzed at regular intervals for a total duration of 10 years. This study will be a nationwide prospective study conducted within 12 specialized centers in France. The main idea of the study is to better understand each step of the metabolic pathways potentially altered in patients suffering from IDs to prevent MA and associated comorbidities in the RaDiCo-IDmet Cohort

The aim of the present study is to compare the clinical efficacy of unipolar versus bipolar interlocking in the treatment of unstable, closed, extra-articular fractures of the humeral shaft in adults. Fractures are classified according to the American Orthopyedic Association (AAO). The study is randomized and of a prospective type, a controlled monocentric study. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the quality of bone consolidation at 12 months. The quality of bone consolidation will be assessed on CT scan at the last follow-up, at 12 months. The secondary objectives are: the quality of life before the fracture, at 6 weeks and 12 months assessed by EQ-5D-5L. Cost analysis to describe and compare the direct and indirect costs generated by the two surgical procedures at 12 months during the follow-up of each patient. Early intervention programs for psychosis provide much-needed resources for people with new-onset psychosis, but there has been little progress in enhancing treatment of these individuals beyond standard of care. Cognitive dysfunction and diminished motivation are critical pathophysiological components of psychosis, and both of these domains have shown promising signs of recoverable brain plasticity. Yet currently available cognitive and motivational therapies often lag behind brain-informed remediation that specifically targets these areas. This study will combine proven cognitive therapy with a new mobile device to specifically address cognitive and motivational impairments in early psychosis. By specifically targeting a key therapeutic need of the new-onset population, this project will deepen our understanding of mechanisms of treatment response in early psychosis. These data will inform the design of future treatment strategies and may change clinical trajectories of those served by the national network of early psychosis intervention programs.

This study involves three study sites: UMass Memorial Medical Center, the University of Maryland School of Medicine, and the University of California, Los Angeles - the UCLA Early Psychosis Program. Participants at all sites will be recruited from coordinated specialty care (CSC) programs that have been shown to improve patient and family outcomes. Participants will be aged 18-40 years and will provide informed consent to participate in the study. Individuals enrolled in a CSC program will be screened for eligibility by the PI or designated study clinician. Participants will complete assessments (detailed below), and half will randomly be assigned to the treatment arm, while the other half will receive Treatment-As-Usual (TAU).
Participants in the Treatment arm will complete 45 minutes of cognitive training on the laptop twice per week for six weeks (a total of 10 hours), and then twice per week for an additional two weeks (for a total of 12 hours of training). Participants will engage in social cognitive training exercises for an additional 10 hours (10 sessions) of training while completing their cognitive training exercises. Social cognitive training exercises aim to develop a deep understanding of the key components that guide successful social interactions. This arm will also use the PRIME mobile app for three months to boost motivation and engagement, in addition to completing the training exercises. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a Treatment-As-Usual (TAU) or active intervention (cognitive and social cognitive training) group. In the TAU arm, participants will complete clinical interviews at baseline, following 6-weeks, 12-weeks, and 18-months. Participants in the TAU arm will also use a basic smart phone version of the PRIME app for three months. All participants will complete the same clinical assessments at these time points, with those in the active intervention arm completing these assessments three times more frequently (i.e., at baseline, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 18 months, as well as 3- and 9-months follow up clinical interviews).
Participants in both arms will be asked to complete 9 questionnaire measures at baseline, mid-training, 3-month follow-up, 6-months, 12-months, and 18-month study completion. In addition, participants will complete cognitive testing at baseline, mid-training, 12-weeks, 18-weeks, 3-month follow-up, 6-months, and 12-months clinical testing sessions. Participants in the Cognitive Training arm will also complete a set of questionnaire measures at baseline, 6-weeks, 12-weeks, 3-month follow-up, 6-months, and 12-months. To optimize data acquisition, these tests will be conducted in person and at 2-week intervals, if possible.
In summary, this study builds upon existing evidence in the fields of cognitive training, motivational enhancement, and mobile health to generate new knowledge that can be disseminated in the field of early psychosis. The results of this study will provide data-driven knowledge to deepen our understanding of factors that contribute to 2-year treatment response trajectories in early psychosis. It will promote better clinical outcomes by identifying new and innovative approaches to enhance individual motivation and social functioning. This project is also designed to test new ways of delivering innovative cognitive training approaches, particularly in a mobile, low resource format. The goal will be to deepen our knowledge about optimal ways to deliver these therapies to people in early psychosis. By leveraging expertise from multiple specialties and disciplines, we hope that this interdisciplinary project will serve as a model for optimizing

The purpose of this randomised controlled trial (RCT) is to evaluate the effectiveness of prehabilitation to optimise patient function for those undergoing open surgery for upper gastrointestinal (OG), hepatobiliary (HPB) or Lung Cancer (LC). To compare the effectiveness of two different methods of prescribing exercise to a prehabilitation population; i) Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) and ii) heart rate (HR) zones to achieve a predefined target heart rate. Secondary outcomes will also be collected to determine adherence to prescribed exercises, volume of activity undertaken during the week, patient satisfaction of using a fitness tracker and the impact the intervention has on the overall patient experience. The fitness trackers used will also be evaluated for their suitability for use in a prehabilitation setting for the duration of the study. The findings of this study will provide valuable insights into whether the use of HR zones improves adherence to prescribed exercise and thus could result in improved outcomes for OG/HPB lung cancer patients undergoing routine prehabilitation.

The treatment of pilonidal sinus disease (PSD) remains controversial. The recommended standard treatment for PSD is pit-picking surgery with de-epithelialization of the sinus tracts. However, recurrence rates are reported to be considerable. SiLaC (a minimally invasive therapy with a radial diode laser) has been shown to decrease recurrence rates and to improve healing of the sinus tracts. It is unclear which treatment for PSD is better in the long-term. The aim of this study is to compare pit-picking surgery with de-epithelialization of the sinus tracts alone to pit-picking surgery with SiLaC.
It is a multicenter, randomised clinical trial. To assess the effectiveness of pit-picking surgery with de-epithelialization or pit-picking with SiLaC therapy 150 patients are needed to find a difference in recurrence rates of 14% (α = 0.05; ß = 0.20). It is expected that 15 to 20% of patients will drop out during the trial, therefore inclusion of 187 patients is expected (97 in each group). To assess the difference in recurrence rates, an intention to treat analysis, adjusted for the Dutch staging system, is used.
The patients are patients aged 12 years and older presenting with primary PSD, type 1b and 3 according to the Dutch staging system. The primary outcome measure is the success rate of treatment, defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year, which include closure of all pits, absence of symptoms, absence of persisting sinuses and absence of recurrence of pilonidal sinus disease. The secondary outcome measures are pain score, patient reported outcome measures, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation and return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery for pilonidal disease, patient satisfaction and quality of life.
SiLaC is a minimally invasive laser-assisted technique, which is more expensive than standard pit-picking surgery. However, it offers the theoretical advantage of decreasing recurrence rates and improving healing of the sinus tracts. Therefore, it is reasonable to investigate whether it leads to better treatment of PSD. If a substantial less recurrences is found with the use of this device, this will have cost-beneficial consequences to the patient and for health care in general.

Finally, results of the study will be discussed in the context of evidence-based treatment, and suggestions will be made for local, regional, and national programs.

Seven to 10 out of 10 patients (70-100%) receive a dose of Durvalumab intravenously for 7 times.
This treatment is combined with tremelimumab administered intravenously and yttrium-90 radioembolisation performed 2 times. 
The first cycle of Durvalumab, tremelimumab, and yttrium-90 radioembolisation is given approximately 2 weeks apart.
Patients receive the first dose of yttrium-90 radioembolisation within the first cycle, and the next dose of yttrium-90 radioembolisation will be administered approximately a week (6-7 days) after the first cycle of Durvalumab and tremelimumab, usually in the second cycle.
Blood tests will be performed after the end of each treatment cycle to check the effect of the treatment on the liver. If there are any side effects, they will be recorded with descriptions and time-frames of occurrence and will be monitored as long as the effect of the treatment persists.
Each patient will have check-ups with imaging tests (e.g., CT or MRI scan) after 2 cycles, prior to each subsequent cycle of Durvalumab and tremelimumab, following the 2nd and 5th dose of yttrium-90 radioembolisation, and 2-3 months after the last treatment and stopping of treatment.
If a patient has responded well to the treatment, they will have another check-up after 3 years.
After the end of the 3-year follow-up, patients will be followed up every 6 months for another 2 years.

This is a phase 2, multicenter study of the effect of 4 cycles (1 cycle = 21 days) of durvalumab+tremelimumab±gemcitabine/cisplatin on resectability rate for patients with resectable intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. The trial includes a screening period of up to 30 days, during which participants will undergo medical history evaluation, physical exams, performance evaluations, blood tests, electrocardiograms (ECG), imagining tests including computed tomography (CT), and other laboratory tests to screen for any diseases that could impact the results of the trial or impact the safety of taking part. If the participant agrees to sign the informed consent, the patient will receive the trial medication. During the initial treatment period, the participant will be treated with chemotherapy as well as the immunotherapy medications for approximately 4 months. The chemotherapy treatment includes gemcitabine and cisplatin. During the first 12 weeks, the participant will receive treatment once every 3 weeks. The participant will receive tremelimumab 300 mg by IV infusion once, on Cycle 1. During cycles 1-4 (weeks 1-8), the participant will receive durvalumab 1500 mg IV on Cycle 1, Cycle 2, Cycle 3, and Cycle 4. After Cycle 4, the surgeon will assess the disease to determine if the participant is eligible to have surgery. If the surgeon decides that surgery is not an option, the participant will continue to receive the same treatment, without gemcitabine and cisplatin, during the maintenance phase until the end of the treatment period. Following surgery, the participants will follow-up medical appointments on a regular basis to evaluate how well the tumor has been removed. If the surgery was successful, the surgeon will assess the participant during follow-up appointments on Day 14 after surgery, at 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 9 weeks, and every 3 months thereafter to monitor for any signs of biliary cancer recurrence. If the surgery was not successful or the tumor returned, the participant will receive durvalumab until 1 year from randomization. After 1 year from randomization, the participant will receive no further treatment with durvalumab or tremelimumab and will be monitored by their participating physician for any complications of durvalumab or tremelimumab. Patients with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma will receive the durvalumab and tremelimumab combination therapy with chemotherapy. Surgery may also be considered if the tumor is evaluated to be resectable after neoadjuvant durvalumab+tremelimumab+gemcitabine+cisplatin after cycle 4 or after cycle 8. Surgery will be considered to be curative if complete resection is performed and pathological staging is cT0cN0cM0.
The primary study endpoint is the Rate of Conversion from unresectable to resectable. The secondary study endpoints are the Incidence of related Treatment Emergent Adverse Events, Objective Response Rate (ORR), Pathological complete response (pCR), Overall survival (OS), Progression-free survival (PFS), Rate of R0 resection, Relapse free survival (RFS), Patient Reported outcomes (PRO) decline, Event Free Survival (EFS), and Survival probability of 2 years and 5 years.

The purpose of the study is to test the safety and efficacy of STERIFY GEL in promoting healing of periodontal pockets following SRP, compared with treatment with SRP alone. With specific visco-elastic and mucoadhesive properties, STERIFY GEL easily penetrates into the deepest and hard-to-reach areas of periodontal and peri-implant pockets, adhering to the gingival tissue and alveolar bone, providing complete coverage of the pockets. The effect of STERIFY GEL is promoted by a physical mechanism of action. After SRP, the gel is applied into the gingival pocket, where it acts primarily as a filler to restore volume, physically preventing bacteria from entering and reinfecting the pocket. STERIFY GEL can thus mechanically protect treated pockets and bone defects, promoting tissue healing. The occluding action at the level of periodontal and peri-implant gingival pockets, in synergy with the accessory action of hydroxytyrosol, nisin, and magnesium ascorbyl phosphate, prevents bacterial recolonization and promotes subsequent tissue regeneration.

Background: Cardiac sarcoidosis is a clinically challenging disease, often diagnosed after symptoms have manifested and irreversible myocardial damage has occurred. Biomarkers that can allow non-invasive early diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis are of utmost importance in order to identify affected individuals prior to significant myocardial fibrosis caused by scarring and dysfunction. The inflammatory disease of sarcoidosis has previously been shown to express somatostatin receptors, especially the SSTR subtype 2 that is also expressed in cardiac sarcoidosis. The current study aims to investigate 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging of SSTR-expressing granulomas for the identification of cardiac sarcoidosis. Objectives: The aim of this study is to compare tracer retention in patients with cardiac sarcoidosis, inflammatory myocarditis, and neuroendocrine tumours for the identification of cardiac sarcoidosis. Methods: Sixty patients with suspected cardiac sarcoidosis will be included in this prospective, comparative study. Group A (n=16) is expected to have cardiac sarcoidosis based on specific clinical, echocardiographic, radiological, and/or serological features. These patients will undergo 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging with a protocol of the routine diagnostic work-up in addition to the standard imaging. In addition, the same procedures will be conducted in Group B (n=16) with verified cardiac sarcoidosis. Similar procedures will be performed in each of the groups, but in Group C (n=20) the same cardiac evaluation will be conducted in patients with acute lymphocytic myocarditis. The number of patients in Group C might be increased in order to obtain sufficient cases. Group D (n=10) will include patients with a neuroendocrine tumor (controls) which have previously undergone 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT as part of their diagnostic work-up or follow-up. Group E will include a large number of additional patients with verified inflammatory heart diseases in order to increase the number of cases for analysis. The study will involve 24 patients with verified acute lymphocytic myocarditis. The cardiac assessment will include: 1. Echocardiography, electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests, and lung function tests (LFTs) prior to 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging and 1-year follow-up. The patients will be followed for 2 years, and additional clinical, echocardiographic, and ECG assessments are to be performed, as well as 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT at 1-, 2- and 3-year follow-up. Data collection: Cardiac assessment will include ECG (ECG-12), lung function tests (LFTs), 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging, and echocardiography (Echo1). This assessment will be repeated at 2- and 3-year follow-up. ECGs and LFTs: ECG will be assessed after resting in the supine position for 10 minutes. Blood samples will be tested the same day. Lung function tests (Spirometry) will be performed using a handheld spirometer (Spirobank; Medical International Research, Rome, Italy). All tests will be done just prior to the 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging. After ECG-12, LFTs, and spirometry, 10 ml/kg of water with 90 mg elementartal for 1 hour and 6 mg heparin for 3 hours will be administered. Post-transplant diarrhea is a common complication affecting up to 60% of renal transplant recipients and the commonest cause of admission in these patients. The cause of infections include immune-suppression and use of antimicrobials like calcineurin inhibitors (CNI) and corticosteroids, antimetabolites and antithymocyte globulin. Post infectious diarrhea is the commonest cause of post-transplant diarrhea and will not be included in this research. The main aims of this study are to determine the rate of and to study the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive agents-associated diarrhea (ID) among renal transplant recipients. The second aim is to evaluate inflammatory markers in serum and feces of renal transplant recipients who have developed ID and to determine the type of bacteria living in the gut (gut microbiome) of those patients who have diarrhea.

Shoulder injury is a common chronic disease in the working-aged adult population. Rotator cuff tears are the most common cause of shoulder dysfunction and are common in the working-aged population. With advancing age they become more frequent. Over the past few years, superior capsular reconstruction (SCR) has been introduced as a new soft-tissue reconstruction procedure for massive rotator cuff tears. The study is conducted in Tartu University Hospital Sports Traumatology Centre and rotator cuff repair procedures will be done by three orthopaedic surgeons with long experience in arthroscopic shoulder surgery. Patients with massive rotator cuff tendon tears aged between 50 to 80 years will be included in the study following the eligibility criteria. Massive tear is defined as grade III tear according to Davidson and Burkhart classification (2010), supraspinatus (SSP) tendon retraction described by Patte (1990) classification. The study is conducted in Tartu University Hospital Sports Traumatology Centre and rotator cuff repair procedures will be done by three orthopaedic surgeons with long experience in arthroscopic shoulder surgery. It is determined intra-operatively whether the tear is reparable or not. If possible, the tendon(s) will be anatomically repaired. For irreparable tears intra-operative urn randomization takes place - either partial repair or partial repair with SCR using the LHBBT. Surgical techniques will be standardized. Patients who refuse operative treatment, will be followed as conservative treatment group. The primary objective of the study is the functional status of the included subjects in different treatment groups. The secondary objective of the study is to confirm whether the tendons are intact on follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) 6 months, 12 months and 24 months after operation using Sugaya classification (2007). The post-operative therapy regimen will be the same for each study group. Subjects will come for scheduled visits at 6-month, 12-month, and 24-month timepoints. Assessment tools consist of range of motion (ROM), strength measurements, preoperative radiography measuring acromio-humeral index (AHI), critical shoulder angle (CSA), acromion type and shoulder arthrosis (Hamada), functional scores: The Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH), The Constant-Murley score (CMS), The American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) and visual analogue scale (VAS), also including Tampa kinesiophobia score and emotional well-being (EEK) score. Goutallier classification (1994) will be used pre- and post-operatively to measure muscle fatty infiltration.

Participants will be allowed to withdraw from the study if they wish.

As stated in the introduction section, peri-implantitis is a significant health problem affecting a substantial percentage of the population. The condition can be prevented or can result in implant loss depending on the time and the ability to provide adequate treatment. Furthermore, even if the cause of peri-implantitis is not entirely clear, it is evident that it is a multifactorial condition, which can be influenced by genetic predisposition, a variety of bacteria, and some systemic conditions, such as diabetes, obesity or smoking.
In recent years, an increase in the number of new cases along with implant failure leads to the increased research of peri-implantitis, both in terms of diagnosis and treatment. As a result, researchers worldwide developed sophisticated diagnostic methods and a broad range of treatment modalities.
In this study, we aim to investigate the relationship among certain polymorphisms of the Cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX-2) gene (rs20417), aswell as the levels of Active MMP-8 in peri-implant fluid (PIF) and the characterization of microbiota associated with peri-implantitis in patients with a history of successful dental implant placement over the past 12 or 24 months.
Based on previous research on gene polymorphism, it has been shown that some genetic polymorphisms could predispose patients to be more susceptible to gum disease. In this context, Cyclo-oxygenase-2 (COX-2) gene polymorphism rs20417 (COX-2 SNP), located on chromosome 1q25.2, is involved in inflammatory and pro-thrombotic reactions (59). The SNP rs20417 of COX-2 is a G/T SNP, where G allele predisposes patients to increase the expression of COX-2.
Additionally, the involvement of prostaglandins as mediators of inflammatory mechanisms in gingival crevicular fluid (GCF), has been widely reported, being the main target of several anti-inflammatory agents. In particular, Eprosutan, a COX-2 inhibitor, has been proven to control the levels of pro-inflammatory markers as IL-1, IL-6, TNF-a, and prostaglandins (PG) E2 in GCF (60). Considering that peri-implantitis is a complex disease that involves many pathways and pro-inflammatory mediators, further research is mandatory for the identification of gene polymorphisms related to peri-implantitis diagnosis as well as to the characterization of host related factors.
The second aim of the study is the characterization of microbiota associated with peri-implantitis. In this context, peri-implantitis, as well as periodontitis, is an infection in which the microbiota is a crucial factor.
The third aim of the study is the assessment of Active MMP-8 levels in site-specific peri-implant fluid with the use of a novel biomarker testing system (ImplantSafe©). Active MMP-8 is considered to be a crucial factor in the breakdown of host tissue during infectious diseases (61). High aMMP-8 levels in peri-implant fluid indicate enhanced proteolytic activity in the tissue and could be considered as a predictive biomarker in peri-implantitis.
The fourth and last aim of the study is the development and validation of a novel, POC lateral flow point of care (PoC) biomarker test, which is based on active matrix metalloproteins aMMP-8.
This study will enroll 100 consecutive patients (50 with peri-implantitis and 50 patients with normal peri-implant status) referred to the Department of Periodontology, Dental School, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki for the diagnosis and treatment of peri-implantitis. At baseline, the demographic data of each patient will be collected, and the status of each implant involved in the study will be recorded. All the patients will be required to provide a buccal swab for gene polymorphism research. From each peri-implant, two paper points will be used for the characterization of microbiota, and one of these paper points will be stored overnight for the detection of aMMP-8 levels in each case. Also, an aMMP-8 lateral flow test (ImplantSafe©) will be performed according to the test's specific

The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of virtual reality video watched during trigger point injection on patients' anxiety, comfort and pain. 40 patients scheduled for trigger point injection will be randomized into two groups using a blind method. In one group, the patient will be given 10 minutes of virtual reality videos during the trigger point injection, in the other group, the patient will continue routine practice without using virtual reality glasses. State anxiety scale, general comfort scale, visual analogue scale (VAS) will be applied before trigger point injection, at the end of the injection and at the 24th hour after the procedure. It is planned to investigate the impact of virtual reality videos on patients with trigger point injections on anxiety, comfort and pain levels. The groups will be compared. The results of the study will be statistically analyzed with descriptive statistics methods, univariate analysis of variance (ANOVA) and independent groups t-test applied to parametric data or chi-square, McNemar and Mann-Whitney U tests.

POEM has been reported to have significantly less cardiovascular instability and fewer complications compared to the conventional Heller myotomy procedure. Although POEM seems to be a safe procedure, hemodynamic changes during the surgery have not been investigated. Objective: This study is designed to investigate the hemodynamic changes due to PEM comparing patients with autonomic dysfunction based on the heart rate variability test results with those having normal autonomic function. Methods: We will conduct a prospective observational study. Patients scheduled for per-oral endoscopic myotomy in Gangnam Severance Hospital for achalasia will be enrolled. Patients aged ≥ 19 years with good understanding of English will be included. Exclusion criteria include patients who are hemodynamically unstable prior to surgery, patients in whom the preoperative heart rate variability (HRV) test cannot be conducted, pregnant women or breastfeeding women, and patients unable to read the informed consent form. A total of 147 patients will be enrolled in this study. We will assess the correlation between SAP variation, cardiac index, cardiac output, stroke volume, preload, and heart rate during POM in relation to the autonomic dysfunction detected preoperatively using HRV tests. We hypothesize that autonomic dysfunction detected by HRV may be a predictor of more hemodynamic instability during surgery. This study aims to elucidate the factors that contribute to hemodynamic instability during PEM. This information will be useful for optimizing intraoperative management of the patients. The researchers aim to evaluate the analgesic effect of virtual reality glasses (Roller Coaster, Wild Dolphin) during inhaler treatment in children aged 2-5 years who present with recurrent bronchiolitis. It was determined that no study was conducted on this subject in children in our country. The use of VR glasses was aimed to reduce the discomfort of the child during inhaler treatment and to facilitate the procedure. Children will be included in the study group by random allocation. The effectiveness of the method will be compared with the standard treatment technique and no VR group. Parents will be asked about the child's anxiety scores before and after inhaler treatment before discharge at the end of hospitalization. The anxiety scoring made by the physician before and after the treatment will be recorded with a FLACC Pain Assessment Scale. It will be determined that a 1-minute crying period is more than 2 minutes in order to assess the analgesic effect of VR glasses used during inhaler treatment in pre-school children. At the same time, changes in SpO2, RR, and HR values during the inhaler treatment will be recorded, and it will be determined that if this value is over 96% for SpO2, over 17/min for RR, and over 160/min for HR, it signifies that the procedure was not successful. Anxiety scores before and after inhaler treatment will be compared using the Mann Whitney U Test and chi-square test. For the comparison of SpO2 and RR, the Kolmogorov Smirnov Test was used. The chi-square test was used for the comparison of HR. If the P value was less than 0.05, it signified a statistically significant difference. The researchers hypothesized that the use of virtual reality glasses during inhaler treatment will increase the number of successful inhaler treatments, shorten the duration of the treatment, reduce crying times, and reduce the anxiety of the child according to the parents.
The inclusion of children with a score of 5 and above according to the bronchiolitis severity score, children with chronic diseases who may have underlying chronic diseases, and children with fever above 37.5 degrees C, respiratory failure symptoms, obesity or malnutrition, with a previous operation or a sedative history, or using a previous prescription of inhaler therapy were not included in the study. Children who did not consent to the study or to whom their parents did not consent were also not included. Children with a saturation value below 92% at the time of admission, those with a severe asthma attack, those with respiratory failure symptoms, and those who did not speak Turkish fluently were included in the exclusion criteria.

Rapid sequence induction (RSI) is usually associated with an increased risk of hypoxia . Preoxygenation is generally used before induction to establish a reserve of oxygen and to reduce apnea time. Preoxygenation is usually performed with either a face-mask or high-flow nasal oxygen cannula (HFNOC), but the optimal choice is not known . The aim of this clinical trial is to compare two different preoxygenation techniques in terms of oxygen saturation and heart rate in pediatric patients. In this randomized controlled trial three groups will be studied. The first will be the control group where the face-mask preoxygenation will be performed. The second group will receive HFNOC preoxygenation and the third group will receive both HFNOC and face-mask preoxygenation. The primary outcomes will be oxygen saturation and heart rate. Secondary outcomes will be safety of the RSI protocol such as intubation attempt success rate, number of intubation attempts, intubation conditions. This research has not received any funding. It is a pilot study that will be presented to the Ethics Committee of the State Hospital Association in the 1st quarter of 2021, and approval will be requested. All patients requiring an acute surgery and rapid sequence induction/intubation will be checked for eligibility criteria and then an informed consent will be obtained. Afterwards, randomization will take place, which will divide a patient into one of three groups: 1) RSI + face-mask preoxygenation, 2) RSI + high-flow nasal oxygen cannula (HFNOC) preoxygenation and 3) RSI + face-mask and HFNOC preoxygenation. The demographic data, type of surgery and vital signs will be observed. Primary outcomes will be the impact of HFNOC preoxygenation on oxygen saturation. Secondary outcomes will be safety of the RSI protocol such as intubation attempt success rate, number of intubation attempts, intubation conditions. The RSI will be done according to our protocol. Initially, equipment will be checked and an i.v. line will be checked/started and then a bolus of ketamine will be given. Afterward, the preoxygenation will start according to the randomization result - group 1) face-mask preoxygenation, group 2) HFNOC preoxygenation and group 3) HFNOC (flow 2 L/kg/minute) + face-mask preoxygenation (flow 2 L/kg/minute) - with 100 % oxygen for three minutes. Then a bolus of anaesthetic and myorelaxant agent will be given. The neuromuscular blockade will be monitored, first intubation attempt will be started as soon as single twitch will be bellow 10 % or train-of-four (TOF) bellow 1 or after 60 seconds, whichever comes first. After that, the first intubation attempt will take place, a video laryngoscopy will be used and Cormack-Lehane score will be documented photographically. The attempt will end either by successful intubation with monitored capnography wave or by failure.

The effect of Swaddling the Pain and Comfort During the Placement of Peripheral Intravenous Catheter
The study was conducted to determine the effect of Swaddling and Inhaling Mother's Breast Milk Odour on the pain and comfort during the placement of Peripheral Intravenous Catheter in Term Infants. In this randomised controlled experimental study, a total of 120 (60 boys, 60 girls) healthy term infants (born at 37-41 weeks of gestation) hospitalized in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit and not having a previous insertion of peripheral intravenous catheter, were accepted to the research. The infants were randomly assigned to three experimental groups and a control group (each of which consisted of 30 infants). During the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter, the infants in the 1st experimental group were swaddled (N = 30), the infants in the 2ndexperimental group were made to inhale their mothers' breast milk odour (N = 30),the infants in the 3rd experimental group were both swaddled and made to inhale their mothers' breast milk odour (N = 30) and no procedure was applied to the infants in the control group. The pain and comfort levels of infants in the experimental and control groups were assessed before, during and after the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter with the Neonatal Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and the Newborn Comfort Behaviour Scale respectively.
All three experimental groups who were subjected to swaddling and inhaling milk odor or both, did not have any significant differences with each other in terms of average pain and comfort values.
The mean pain and comfort values of the infants in the 1st experimental group (swaddling), the infants in the 2ndexperimental group (inhaling milk odor) and the infants in the 3rd experimental group (both swaddled and milk odor) were statistically significantly lower than the control group.(P<0.05). In other words, the findings of the study indicate that the application of swaddling and inhaling milk odor was found to be effective in reducing pain and discomfort of the infants during the placement of peripheral intravenous catheter.
In short, the study showed that Swaddling and Inhaling Mother's Breast Milk Odour have an effect in providing comfort and pain relief to newborns during the process of catheter insertion and contribute to the psychological support of nurses in this process.

The purpose of the study is to determine if a new imaging agent called 111In-panitumumab can detect the sentinel node in patients with HNSCC. We also want to find out if this imaging agent adds any new information about tumor spread in the neck when combined with other imaging scans (MRI or FDG PET scan). In this study, patients will have an imaging agent, such as 111In-panitumumab, injected into a vein. The doctor will use a radiation camera to capture pictures of the injection as it moves around the body. The patient will have a scan 1-5 days after first injection. The scan will find a small number of lymph nodes that carry tumor cells and are at risk for removal during surgery. These scans will help identify which lymph nodes should be removed and which lymph nodes can be left behind. The scans will be compared for accuracy. The amount of information obtained from this imaging strategy, compared to results from standard imaging scans, will also be studied.

The investigators encourage the collection of all lymph nodes in a single surgical specimen. This makes the research results easier to interpret and compare with the results from standard imaging tests. The investigators will also encourage the use of standard imaging scans, but some patients will not receive them. This may lead to a slightly larger number of sentinel nodes being missed in the neck in patients who undergo a sentinel lymph node procedure and do not receive standard imaging scans. The researchers do not expect this higher rate to affect the long-range prognosis of the patients.

Recent preclinical and clinical studies have shown that electroacupuncture or acupuncture can alleviate anxiety symptoms by activating the non-invasive Vagus nerve stimulation (NVNS) pathway or the efferent branch of the Vagus nerve. Transcutaneous vagus nerve simulation (tVNS) is a non-invasive method to stimulate the vagus nerve and has been proven to have anxiolytic effects. Therefore, tVNS has been proposed as a useful tool for patients with anxiety disorders. In this study, we will use Nexo tVNS for transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation to explore its efficacy for treating refractory patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). The investigators will select 30 patients aged 18-65 with primary diagnosed generalized anxiety disorder as cases, and another 30 healthy people as healthy controls. At the same time, 10 cases will be withdrawn at once, and their vital signs monitoring data, Nexo tVNS stimulation and patient recovery will be monitored, and the collected safety data will be analyzed retrospectively.

Epiphora or recurrent infections with mucopurulent discharge are two major symptoms associated with lacrimal drainage obstruction. NLDO can occur at any level along the lacrimal drainage system: punctum, canaliculus, nasolacrimal duct (NLD), or nasal ostium. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a standard surgical procedure used to treat NLD obstruction. However, differences in the surgical technique, stringency of definitions of success, and duration of follow-up, may be confounding factors of success rates. Dacryoendoscopy was originally described in 1979 and has recently matured for use in lacrimal drainage system imaging. It has been proved to be useful instrument not only for understanding differences in the etiology of obstructions but also for treating LD obstructions. Hence, dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) offers direct therapy to the obstructed site, leading to minimal collateral damage external to the target zone. In addition to that, it has advantages such as short surgery time and less risk of bleeding during surgery, resulting in its increasingly widespread use in China. The aim of our study was to report DLDI results in the management of NLDO, and to identify factors associated with DLDI failure.

Chronic stroke patients have gait deficits that impair their ability to walk. The gait deficits are predominantly due to decrease ankle dorsiflexion with prolonged swing phase duration of paretic leg. Several studies have revealed that the ankle dorsiflexion in patients with stroke may decrease due to the hypertonicity in the stretch reflex of gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.
The aim of the study is to estimate the immediate effects of PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping. PNF technique is very powerful healing exercise for the improvement of muscle thickness, dynamic stability and gait. However, effects of application PNF with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait and functional mobility in chronic patients after stroke have not yet been investigated. The null hypothesis is that no significant difference exists between the three groups regarding the ankle dorsiflexion, gait and functional mobility after one treatment session. While the alternative hypothesis is that no significant difference exists between the three groups regarding the ankle dorsiflexion, gait and functional mobility after one treatment session.
