Diving catheters are used to administer medications or to carry out various routine medical procedures. For more than 20 years, the placement of diving catheters has led to considerable anxiety among patients due to the sometimes painful and cumbersome practice that has generated a multitude of painful, potentially traumatic complications, the costs of which do not always allow a cost-benefit balance to be found (Freund et al., 2018; VAN KIRK (2004); Guitton et al., 2015). In Belgium, for example, it is estimated that 2% of the total budget of the hospital sector is used for the placement and management of peripheral venous catheters, whereas in the American literature, the placement alone is estimated at more than 10 billion dollars per year in the USA (Freund et al., 2018).

A vascular access difficulty score (VAD score) (Laurent et al., 2016) was developed to quantify the risk of complications posed by a peripheral venous catheter at the time of insertion, by determining the morphology-anatomical characteristics (skin, vasculature, vein and hand characteristics related to the location of the vein for insertion), which define the VAD of the patient. The VAD score consists of a 6 items questionnaire, each item being scored from 0 to 10, for a total score of 11 to 110, which is then analyzed according to the risk group: 1) no risk, 2) low risk, 3) moderate risk and 4) high risk (Laurent et al., 2016) (Figure 1). Patients assigned to a high-risk VAD group have a mean pain of >3/10 on the scale, compared to 0 or 1 for the low-risk groups. The risk of failed insertions, phlebopathies and complications significantly increases in the high-risk groups (p=0.0001). Based on these results, it is possible to suggest ways to improve peripheral venous catheter handling, while reducing the complications related to catheter insertion, namely to prioritize operators trained in the use of the score to increase the success rate of catheter insertion and decrease complications. Although the use of the score alone has never been assessed, the current state of the literature shows that the VAD score alone and in addition to the algorithm is the subject of intense discussion. The work carried out in these centers for the last 24 months has allowed, through prospective studies, to identify an approach to improve the care given to patients, namely the implementation of the Algorithm, a tool for improving the care during and after catheter insertion. This Algorithm uses the VAD score by stratifying the patient groups with respect to VAD, then offering practitioners the choice between a classic insertion technique (Venefit catheter) and an alternative insertion technique (intra-epidermal insertion (ie, SEL) using a SEL-catheter in the case of anatomical difficulties to optimize the success rate of insertion, by decreasing the trauma to the vein and a faster recovery of the hand (De Beer et al., 2008), thus reducing the risk of complications. On the one hand, this tool has been shown to be acceptable and feasible by the population and all the people involved. On the other hand, it has been shown to reduce the number of punctures (from 3 to 1.7) and reduce pain from the beginning (5/10 compared to 3/10) for patients in high-risk groups, whereas there was no significant impact on the other patient groups. Despite the quality of the work carried out and the support of the literature, there is no proof as to the effectiveness of this tool in real-life situations, thus limiting its use in all patients and its implementation in all departments of the hospitals participating in the study. In addition to the impact on patients, this tool could save more than 120 € per patient and per catheter for health institutions, with significant savings for hospital institutions. The goal here is to evaluate the impact of this tool in the day-to-day life of the hospital departments participating in the study. In short, the goal of the study is: 1) To evaluate the impact of the use of the Algorithm for the management of peripheral venous cathers on the patients' risk of complication, the patients' perception of pain or success of insertion and the number of venipunctures required per patient;

Adolescent mental health problems are prevalent and pose a great burden on individuals, society and healthcare systems. Existing treatments focus on a subset of mental disorders and do not address subthreshold or multi-disorder problems. Furthermore, available treatments do not typically target disease mechanisms in a transdiagnostic way and do not work for all individuals. In addition, accessible care is limited by structural barriers such as geographical distance and social stigma, resulting in underdiagnosis and under-treatment. The aim of this randomized clinical trial is to determine the clinical efficacy of the 6-week emotion regulation treatment POET, a novel intervention that can be integrated with primary care. Treatment will be delivered in a blended treatment format combining asynchronous therapist-guided online modules and one synchronous session delivered in a virtual manner. Approximately 300 adolescents aged 12-17 years, seeking care for their mental problems, will be randomized to the POET condition or to an active control. Treatments in both conditions will include therapist support and will be delivered in a blended treatment format combining asynchronous therapist-guided online modules with one synchronous session delivered over video-link.

Non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) incidence as well as morbidity rates are high in older patients. Surgery is the standard of care. About 5 to 10% of NMSC present high-risk clinico-pathologic features that can increase risk of local recurrence (LR). Adjuvant radiation therapy (ART) is often discussed regarding the risk of local recurrence. Despite the lack of high level evidence, ART is indicated in patients according to unfavorable prognostic factors. ART benefit is generally questioned in regard to the potential degradation of the patient's quality of life (QoL). Currently there is no prospective trial or recommendations that take into account geriatric patients' evaluation and profiles during the management of NMSC. In addition, there is no data that could help to define the subgroup of elderly patients who will benefit from ART in tumors with unfavorable prognostic factors. In terms of ART, multiple fractionation schedules are available, ranging from standard fractionation (45-60Gy in 5-6 weeks) to the extreme hypofractionation delivering 16-18Gy in one fraction. In routine practice, HF is mainly preferred in elderly patients for more convenience by reducing the number of transports and increase health related quality of life (HRQoL). However, there is no data on the fragility profiles of these patients, nor validating any HF schedule in terms of efficacy, acute toxicity, cosmetic results, and impact on HRQoL. Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death in the United States, and surveillance colonoscopy is the only test recommended for reducing colorectal cancer incidence and mortality. Colonoscopy is especially risky for older adults, with an estimated 6,800 emergency visits or hospitalizations within 30 days of colonoscopy each year, and 1-3% of all deaths attributed to colonoscopy. To date, no study has adequately addressed the competing risks of colorectal cancer vs colonoscopy-associated harms among older adults. This study has three goals: 1) to determine whether surveillance colonoscopy in older adults reduces colorectal cancer incidence and mortality; 2) to compare risk of colorectal cancer after colonoscopy between those with and without prior serrated lesions; and 3) to obtain key stakeholder perspectives on existing data on CRC risk and surveillance outcomes in older adults to inform future value-based strategies for surveillance among older adults. To achieve these goals, more than 60,000 Veterans ages 75 and alive in 2019 will be followed over a 20-year period. Those with a prior, recent history of polypectomy (n=200,000) or with a recent, normal colonoscopy (n=400,000) will be followed to understand if surveillance colonoscopy, or colonoscopy without polypectomy, reduces colorectal cancer incidence and mortality. A separate subset of patients and providers will also participate in qualitative interviews and expert panels. Ultimately, the study will help define best surveillance practices in older adults, using data-driven methods to understand benefits and harms of surveillance, and stakeholder perspectives to inform future use and VA policy around surveillance among older adults.

The short-term benefits of exercise training are well documented in different disease states including cardiovascular, cancer, metabolic and musculoskeletal. Exercise training improves different biological and psychological functions in acute, subacute and chronic stages postoperatively.
Recently, several studies have shown that physical training in the form of bedside cycling is feasible in patients with different chronic diseases like Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Chronic heart failure. Studies conducted in these two population reported high tolerance and adherence to bedside cycling program and the improvement of selected physical, psychological and functional parameters.
Moreover, bedside cycling exercises showed superiority in comparison to the usual care, but the results are conflicting between them.
On the other hand, evidence of bedside cycling use as a form of physiotherapy in cardiac patients remains scarce.
This study will include all consecutive patients who will undergo valve surgical intervention. Patients will be randomly allocated into two equal groups, the bedside cycling patients and controls.
The bedside cycling patients will receive bedside cycling in addition to the medical treatment and routine physiotherapy protocol.
Afterward, the study will assess the selected outcomes in patients before discharge.
Primary outcome is the six-minute walk test.
Secondary outcome measures are quality of life measurement (SF-12), depression, anxiety and stress measurements (DAS-42), functional level and activities daily living (Barthel index) as well as the adverse events rate.
The results of this study will contribute to the scientific literature in different ways.
First, this study will be the first one to assess the effect of bedside cycling in patients after valve surgical intervention.
Second, this study will provide evidence for the role of bedside cycling as an effective method of early rehabilitation in patients who are too sick to participate in traditional rehabilitation program.
Finally, this study will contribute to improve the quality of life, psychological wellbeing, muscle strength and functional level of the treated patients after valve surgical intervention.
Therefore, this study is important regarding the novelty, need to assess the role of bedside cycling, potential early benefits, and improvement in the quality of care for cardiac patients undergoing valve surgical intervention.

Background
-----------------
Tirzepatide is a glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) analogue that is FDA approved for the treatment of obesity and diabetes. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effect of tirzepatide in people with Type 1 Diabetes with obesity. This is a pilot interventional study to investigate the effects of tirzepatide on weight loss, diabetes control, insulin requirements and overall cardio-metabolic health in individuals with Type 1 Diabetes that have not achieved satisfactory glycemic control despite insulin therapy.
Inclusion criteria for participants should include:
Individuals aged between 18 and 70 years
Type-1 diabetes for <1 year
Diabetes poorly controlled (Glycated Haemoglobin (HbA1c) of ≤10%)
Individuals with obesity (body mass index (BMI) ≥30)

Design
-----------------
The study will be an 8-week open-label pilot interventional study on the safety, tolerance and preliminary efficacy of tirzepatide in participants with Type 1 Diabetes and obesity. Participants will remain on their typical insulin therapy regimen, but will be prescribed tirzepatide, an FDA approved injectable medication, once per week for 8 weeks. Body weight, diabetes control, glycaemic parameters, insulin requirements, lipid parameters, and renal function will be assessed at each study visit.
Participants will undertake dietary assessment via an electronic diary, exercise evaluation by a standard online exercise assessment, and complete a screening questionnaire covering various aspects of their physical and emotional wellbeing.
Additionally, participants will use the following monitoring devices: NovoPen 6, Dexcom G6 and FreeStyle Libre 1. Two blood samples will be collected (pre-treatment and post-treatment) for laboratory analysis.

Official Title
-----------------
Tirzepatide for the Concurrent Treatment of Obesity and Type 1 Diabetes

Conditions

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, Obesity

Intervention / Treatment

* Drug: Tirzepatide

Eligibility Criteria

Age < 18 and > 70 years

Concurrent use of GLP-1RA or other glucose lowering medications
Participant unwillingness to use hybrid closed loop system for >3 months
Age < 18
Participant not willing to share devices data uploads
Current use of any steroidal medication or anticipated long-term steroidal treatment
Planning for bariatric surgery during the study

History of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, maculopathy, or severe NPDR requiring acute treatment
History of congestive heart failure class III or IV
History of acute or chronic liver disease
History of allergy to any form of insulin or GLP-1RA or its excipients
Participation to any intervention trial during the study period
Current use of any other oral anti-diabetic medication
History of malignancy requiring chemotherapy, surgery, or radiation (within 5 years of trial period)
Have a pacemaker, or metal implants

Background: Paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy (p-NSP) is a dose-limiting adverse event that limits the ability to administer neurotoxic chemotherapy such as paclitaxel in treatment of breast cancer patients. Our aims are to evaluate an objective and safe approach to the prevention and management of p-NSP when treated with standard of care chemotherapy agents.
Objective: The study has a two-arm randomized design. Study arm 1 involves the drug 100 mg, losartan, to be administered orally once daily for three weeks out of a four-week cycle of paclitaxel alone or in combination with docetaxel. The study arm 2 will receive standard-of-care management.
Detailed Description: The investigators will compare development of p-NSP and quality of life measures, including patient reported outcome on Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy/Gynecologic Oncology Group - Neurotoxicity scale, between patients in losartan arm and patients in control arm receiving standard of care management. Furthermore, levels of nerve growth factor (NGF), which play a major role in development of neuropathy are hypothesized to be higher in patients with p-NSP. We hypothesize that the administration of losartan in premenopausal patients undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer would decrease the incidence of p-NSP.

Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) represents a diverse group of neoplasms that can arise in any portion of the head and neck, including the salivary glands, mouth, throat, voice box, sinuses, and nose. Currently, the best initial treatment of newly diagnosed HNSCC is surgery or radiation therapy. However, in many cases, surgery and/ or radiotherapy cannot be safely administered because the disease has already spread to other parts of the body (metastases) when diagnosed. The current diagnostic imaging used to assess the presence of metastasis to other parts of the body is typically a CT scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the chest, abdomen, or pelvis (referred to as a chest CT or chest MRI). If a metastasis is detected during one of these scans, patients may undergo either a biopsy or additional imaging tests, such as a positron emission tomography (PET) scan to assess the presence of cancer in the bone, lymph nodes, liver, or other organs with greater sensitivity. PET is a type of imaging test that involves the use of a low dose of a type of radioactive substance, such as fludeoxyglucose F-18 (18F-FDG), that is absorbed by cancer cells and can then be detected using a special camera. Another type of radioactive substance that may be used in other types of cancer, zirconium Zr 89, can also be used in PET imaging. In this study, the researchers are interested in evaluating how well zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab PET is able to detect cancer compared to 18F-FDG PET in patients who have recurrent or newly discovered head and neck or cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. This study will determine if, in comparison to standard imaging tests (CT scans and fludeoxyglucose F-18 (18F-FDG) PET/CT imaging), zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab PET imaging can differentiate between cancer and non-cancer lesions in patients. In this study, two groups of participants will participate. One group will undergo panitumumab alone intravenously (IV) (1 mg/kg) and standard of care (SoC) imaging tests (e.g., 18F-FDG PET or CT scan or MRI) at the time of enrollment to be used to detect indeterminate metastases. The second group will undergo panitumumab intravenously and zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab IV, followed by PET/CT imaging. During the PET/CT procedure, radiation is obtained that measures the activity of the substance (zirconium Zr) in the body and images obtained from the PET/CT scanner may show an increase in the number of cancer-like cells that are seen only when tumor cells are present. The primary purpose of this study is to test to see if 89Zr-panitumumab can provide more accurate results compared to the use of existing standard-of-care imaging techniques and to assess any safety issues that are associated with zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab PET imaging. Patients who have a positive 89Zr-panitumumab PET results will be instructed to undergo additional imaging, such as 18F-FDG PET if necessary, and may also undergo other imaging techniques or procedures as determined by their healthcare providers. Patients may also be asked to complete questionnaires that assess the quality of their life. In addition, physicians may review the subject's medical records to evaluate the management of patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma and will document any follow-up procedures in which these patients undergo. The long-term goal of this research is to improve the accuracy of diagnosing metastatic head and neck cancer, which will ultimately lead to improved patient care.

Background: Prophylactic central neck dissection has been widely used in the treatment of thyroid cancer. But this operation did not effectively prevent lymph node metastases in central neck area. The effect of prophylactic central neck dissection on the survival and lymph node recurrence of papillary thyroid cancer at low risk is still controversial. The aim of this study was to investigate the survival and lymph node recurrence in patients with cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer to clarify the role of prophylactic central neck dissection in this population.
Methods: Prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled phase III trial. 3000 patients with T1bN0 low-risk PTCF (tumor sizes range from 11mm to 40mm, with pre-operation FNA positive) were selected for inclusion. The eligible patients were randomly divided into test group and control group. Prophylactic central neck dissection for test group, while no lymph nodes dissection was performed for control group. The main outcome were excellent response and recurrence.
Expected results: Prophylactic central neck dissection could effectively improve the excellent response of cN0 low-risk papillary thyroid cancer, and could significantly delay the recurrence time of lymph node recurrence. However, there was no statistically significant survival advantage of prophylactic central neck dissection.

The study will be conducted in the department of Tiebissou (Gbeke Region in Lac district) Southern Bouake city, central Côte d'Ivoire. The Lac district is characterized by intense indoor malaria transmission with a prevalence of malaria reaching 51.3% in 2021 in children of under 5 years of age and extremely high pyrethroid resistance intensity in the main malaria vectors Anopheles gambiae s.s. and An. coluzzii. A cohort of 50 children will be recruited per cluster in 33 clusters for 12 months follow up to compare incidence of malaria cases between each intervention study arm and the control arm, a cohort of 50 children (45 + 5 to account for loss to follow up) will be recruited per cluster in 33 clusters for 12 months follow up. Malaria infection prevalence surveys will be conducted at baseline, 6 and 12 months after LLIN distribution. Two next-generation LIN containing alpha-cypermethrin pyrethroids will be tested alone or in combination with chlorfenapyr synergist. Vector surveillance will be conducted with the same methods and schedule as for the cohort. Assuming a mean mosquito density of 28 in the control arm and a 60% reduction in mosquitoes in the two intervention arms with a coefficient of variation of 0.55 between clusters, this will give 80% power to detect differences at each timepoint.

In this study the investigators want to reduce the number of treatments down to only 3, given on consecutive days, further enhancing the patient experience and providing evidence that this number of treatments could become the new standard of care. In this study the investigators will be using the very latest state of the art radiotherapy machines and the unique RayPilot system, adopted for routine use by a small number of global radiotherapy centres when delivering prostate SBRT(Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy). The ability to track the position of the prostate cancer throughout the radiotherapy treatment using RayPilot allows the treatment to be given more precisely with less dose being given to the surrounding bladder and rectum. It also ensures that all the intended dose is given to the cancer as the treatment can be interrupted should the cancer move due to rectal gas, changes in bladder filling or simply the patient moving position on the treatment bed, maximizing the chances of cure and minimizing the risk of life changing side effects. This is a single arm 2 stage Phase II study that will test the safety of the 3 fraction radiotherapy schedule. It has built in safety measures to ensure that the immediate post treatment side effects on the bowel and bladder are within the expected limits of acceptance at 12 weeks post completion of treatment. After 43 patients are recruited the initial data will be analyzed and if acceptable the study will continue until all 100 patients have been recruited. The study will be opened in the UK with Edinburgh as the lead Centre, and also in a number of other global centres each of which will ask for their own local ethical approval and sponsorship. The anonymized data from each Centre will be recorded on a trial specific RedCap database held by the University of Edinburgh for analysis of the trial results.

Upper incisor intrusion treatment with mini-implants is considered an invasive treatment for adult patients with deep overbite in order to obtain a more aesthetic appearance, however; it may cause root resorption of these teeth which may lead to root fracture or loss.
This study compares the effectiveness of using a low-level laser (LLLT) in the orthodontic treatment of deep overbite by intrusion movement with mini-implants. In this study, we will measure the root resorption of the upper incisors by using Cone-Beam computed tomography (CBCT) after correction of deep overbite by intrusion movement with mini-implants. We will compare root resorption in the upper incisors of the test group that will receive the laser treatment with a control group that will receive traditional orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances. A total of 20 patients will be recruited for this study. Each patient will be randomly assigned using a randomization sequence (150) to one of the two groups (Low-level laser treatment group or the traditional orthodontic treatment group). Data will be analyzed using SPSS 23.0. Descriptive statistics will be used. The level of significance will be set at P < 0.05.

Colon cancer is the most common neoplasm in our society and the third in the oncological order of frequency. It is still the first in the ranking of oncological diseases mortality in our country. Surgery is the treatment of choice, both for curative reasons, and in cases of advanced and metastatic disease in non-surgical settings. In the curative setting of colon cancer surgery offers a high chance of resection with negative margins, and consequent increase in five-year survival. Radicality of the surgical technique is crucial for this. The quality of surgical specimen, for example the number of harvested lymph nodes is a fundamental factor for the selection of post-operative chemotherapy and for the definition of prognosis in terms of survival. The radicality of the surgical technique influences both: the extent of the en bloc resection of the colonic wall, and lymphadenectomy performed. The more proximal the radical colonic resection, the longer the terminal ileum and the number of vessels removed and consequently the number of lymph nodes collected increase. The quality of lymphadenectomy is an issue that has been the subject of debate for years and recent guidelines (ASCO-NCCN and ESMO) report the number of harvested lymph nodes (12 at maximum) as the main prognostic indicator of survival.
The right hemicolectomy is the most common operation in colon cancer. It consists in the removal of more than 90 cm of colonic wall, on average divided into 443 (45%), 228 (27%), 148 (16%) and 78 (8%) of resected bowel for male, female, right colon and left colon respectively. A D3 lymphadenectomy has not been demonstrated superior to a D2 in a randomized study, whereas a D3 lymphadenectomy has been shown to be superior to a D2 in a meta-analysis. However, these data have not been univocally confirmed by other randomized trials. Many retrospective studies have shown a trend towards better prognostic results in terms of lymph node dissection and reduced risk of tumor recurrence and patient death with a D3 lymphadenectomy compared to a D2. Many of the studies on lymphadenectomy have been based on post-surgical pathological studies. Only a few data indicate the incidence and percentage in the whole series, of cases with prognostic significance (R0, pN, ypN, pT, ypT, pStage) in the analysis of lymphadenectomy.
Thus, there are still controversial aspects regarding the best technique and consequently the best surgical specimen for quality post-operative treatment. No data in the literature exist about the quality of the lymphadenectomy in right hemicolectomy and in particular the impact of the type of lymphadenectomy (D2 versus D3) as related to surgical radicalness (R0, pN, ypN, pT, ypT, pStage).
For this reason, a study was carried out with the collaboration of the Italian Colorectal Surgery Society (SICRE) concerning the right hemicolectomy. In order to evaluate and standardize the quality of lymphadenectomy in the course of right hemicolectomy (RH) in Italian centers that perform high-volume surgery for colonic cancer. The study involves 125 centers throughout the country with at least 25 RHs performed in 2014. After a period of inclusion of 6 months the investigators will evaluate more than 1000 cases using a common data sheet. The study will end after 12 months from the date of the final enrollment of the patient (31/1/15).
For what concerns the study technique, it will be observational with a 12 months follow-up. Once the enrollment of new patients will be verified, patients will be referred to individual databases in each center. The personal data, tumour stage and the type of surgical procedure (open versus laparoscopic and/or robotic) will be collected in all cases. In addition the investigators want to evaluate the following: type of lymphadenectomy (D2 versus D3), mesocolic sail integrity (Benz criteria) and the quality of lymphadenectomy as related to the resection margins. At the end of the 12 months period the data collection center will transfer the data to the coordinating center by fax

The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of vestibular rehabilitation through exercises on balance and quality of life in children with a significant level of hearing deficit. The design of the study was randomized, controlled, with parallel assignment, in which all families signed informed consent. The participants were divided into two groups: Group I, performed balance exercises using the Cawthorne Cooksey method for 4 weeks, 3 sessions per week, half an hour. This group is called "Control" because there is no intervention for the second group. The participants in the control group will continue to receive treatment for their hearing loss as before. Group II, performed exercises with a Swiss ball for 4 weeks, 3 times per week, half an hour.

Efficacy is being evaluated using the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale (PedBBS), which has 43 items that assess the balance of patients according to age. Higher scores indicate improvements in balance, while lower scores indicate decreased balance.

The Four-Step Square Test was also taken to assess the balance of the participants with a 10-meter walk test. This test is used to assess the balance of the patient with a single task. This test takes 5 to 10 minutes..

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) is highly curative, but can have psychological consequences for women due to the nature of the diagnosis. Little is known about the psychological impact of diagnosis and treatment experienced by women following the completion of treatment. As the specialist centre for GTN in the North of the UK, it is important to understand the experiences and care needs of our patients, particularly given our high incidence rates of this cancer. The aim of the study is to explore women's experiences following treatment, how they managed any negative impacts and investigate if there is gap in the follow up support provided to patients after treatment. The study aims to have 20 participants who received chemotherapy. Semi-structured telephone interviews will be conducted; each interview will be digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim. Thematic analysis will be used to generate in depth descriptions of the patients' experiences. The findings will enable health care professionals working closely with this unique group of patients to gain some understanding of the patient perspective; recommendations will be made to improve the support and provision of care these patients receive after their treatment has completed.

Malunion of a distal radius fracture is a common complicaton after fracture of the wrist. If the malunion is not fixed by surgery, the patient suffers from persistent wrist pain and functional restrictions. Standard surgical treatment to correct the angulation in the distal radius (deformity) is open wedge corrective osteotomy (OWCO) and plate fixation. However, sometimes, the gap created in the cortical bone after the osteotomy does not heal properly and bone defects remains. One common way to improve bone healing is to fill the gap with bone grafts either from a harvesting site or as a combination of local bone, biodegradable scaffold, and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP). One possible source of bone grafts are the bone-forming cells in the iliac crest. We hypothesize that bone grafting will be more beneficial in improving osteotomy healing, reducing bone resorption, and reducing the incidence of complications.
All patients who fulfil the inclusion criteria for open wedge corrective osteotomy of the distal radius will be invited to participate in the study. After informed consent, a surgeon will examine the patients in the operating room under general anesthesia. The patients will be placed in a beach chair position, and the upper extremity in neutral position, at least three times longer than the size of the planned deformation. An additional skin incision is made on the lower part of the iliac crest to expose bone for harvesting or not, depending on randomization. Randomization is performed using sealed envelopes. All included patients will undergo an open wedge osteotomy and plate fixation according to the standard surgical techniques in both groups. In one group, the bone defect will be filled with bone graft of the iliac crest after open wedge osteotomy according the standard procedure. The other group includes patients who will not receive any bone grafts. The participating hospitals have extensive experience with both treatments. The surgeons are unaware of the contents of the prepared envelops. When the patient reaches the end of the postoperative care and is ready to be discharged, the surgeon records the primary outcome measures. The primary endpoints include number of reoperations, number of infection, total time to completion of bone healing, and complications such as bone resorption and hardware loosening. We expect the presence of complications to be more common among patients who have not received any BG.

Behavioral teaching difficulties (BTD) often occur in the classroom, are detrimental for classroom management and negatively affect the course of children's psychosocial and academic development. Despite the fact that BTD are relatively prevalent in schools, no previous studies have examined the effects of brief teacher training interventions for BTD in the school context. Therefore, the objective of the present study is to evaluate the effectiveness of a brief, individualized, three-session teacher training program that exists of two (bi)weekly individually tailored training sessions and a third session of one hour. The training program combines individually-tailored stimulus control and contingency management techniques to treat children's behavioral difficulties in two (bi)weekly training sessions of two hours and a third session of one hour in which the training will be evaluated and maintenance training will be provided. A randomized controlled trial with two arms will be used. Teachers will be randomly assigned (equal randomization) to (a) brief teacher training with practice as usual (PAU) or (b) PAU only. To ensure blinding of the outcome assessor, the severity of teachers-rated daily measured target behaviors in specific classroom situations will be measured with brief daily phone calls to teachers on four consecutive school days. This approach of using observer ratings to assess the effectiveness of a treatment intervention is novel, efficient and cost-effective. The results of this study will enhance our understanding of the effectiveness of such approaches to improve classroom management and support optimal behavioral development of children..

Chronic non-specific neck pain is a public health problem due to its high prevalence, the frequency of consultations, and the costs related to the disease. While physiotherapy is considered the gold standard of treatment for neck pain, tele-rehabilitation is increasingly being used. However, few studies have evaluated the feasibility and usability of tele-rehabilitation based on virtual reality exercises for pain, physical function, and health-related quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain. This study aims to assess the feasibility of a remote rehabilitation combining immersive virtual reality neck exercises and therapeutic education for individuals with chronic non-specific neck pain. The aims of this study are: (1) to evaluate the feasibility (mainly the retention rate, adhesion to treatment, safety, and implementation at home) of a remote rehabilitation based on virtual reality exercises and tele-consultations; (2) to assess the acceptability and usability of this tele-rehabilitation; and (3) to explore its effects on perceived pain, range of motion, neck disability, quality of life, and illness perception.

This study is an exploratory, randomized, controlled, monocentric, pilot study. 16 patients randomized in two groups are planned. The first group will receive virtual reality-based multimodal rehabilitation for six weeks (virtual reality exercises and tele-consultations with a physiotherapist), whereas the second group will receive therapeutic education (six information booklets on pain, physical activity, and relaxation, and weekly follow-up by the physiotherapist).

The study consists of three sessions. Session 1: screening assessment and informed consent. Session 2: baseline assessment (pre-intervention) and randomization into the two experimental groups. Session 3: post-intervention assessment (at week 6).

Quantitative data such as the retention rate, adhesion to treatment, safety, global perceived effect, pain intensity, quality of life, range of motion, and illness perception will be collected. Acceptability and usability will be assessed through self-reported questionnaires and semi-structured interviews at the end of the intervention.

In total, five booklets, four tele-consultations, and six virtual reality sessions will be planned over a six-week period.

Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) is a common cause of preterm birth and is associated with a high rate of neonatal complications, including neonatal respiratory complications, intraventricular hemorrhage, sepsis, pneumonia, and death. Cervical examinations, including digital examinations and speculum examinations, are recommended for patients with PPROM in order to estimate cervical dilation and fetal station. These are useful for planning for delivery, assessing the size and location of the fetal head in the vagina, and to assess the presence of chorioamnionitis. Traditionally, speculum examinations have been considered painful and uncomfortable for patients, but digital examinations have been associated with lower levels of patient discomfort. Due to a potential higher rate of maternal infection after PPROM, we previously studied the rate of bacteremia after PPROM comparing delivery after a speculum exam to delivery after a digital exam. After completing this study, we found no difference in the rate of maternal or neonatal bacteremia between the two groups. Conversely, digital exams were associated with lower total discomfort scores (10.24 vs. 18.97, P<0.001) and lower level of anxiety scores (4.0 vs. 8.1, P<0.001). Therefore, digital exams are likely a safer cervical exam without major drawbacks.
In the present study, we propose a randomized control trial comparing the rate of maternal and neonatal chorioamnionitis, maternal intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, maternal wound infections, maternal death, composite neonatal complications (sepsis, IVH, NEC, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, and neonatal death) and length of neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) admission in patients with PPROM undergoing speculum versus digital cervical examinations. 
Patients with PPROM will be randomized to either a speculum or digital cervical examination as necessary for clinical management. We hypothesize that the rate of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes, as well as length of stay in the NICU, will be similar between the two groups.

To address the lack of a reliable dexterity scale, the investigators propose to develop a novel finger dexterity tool based on current knowledge of hand function in myelopathy. Postoperative pain is an essential problem for both patient comfort and fast mobilization in the postoperative period. SPSIPB is used successfully in many areas of pain management. This is a prospective cohort study.
Recently, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) lesions can infiltrate along the ducts from the level of the nipple. Previously, the detection of a breast abnormality detected by breast imaging examination is always based on breast symptoms such as non-palpable mass or palpable mass, or an imaging finding with a high degree of specificity. Unfortunately, early DCIS lesions are mostly detected only by nipple discharge and are usually negative for breast palpation or imaging (especially mammography and ultrasound), and ductal discharge is not uncommon in Chinese women. When these early DCIS lesions are diagnosed after biopsy, they have infiltrated into the ducts and expanded to the surrounding breast tissue. In these cases, the breast imaging examination cannot detect the early breast lesion, and this diagnosis is often only based on the symptoms of nipple discharge and may be missed if the symptoms of nipple discharge are mild and do not follow the specific time cycle at all.
The mammographic findings of breast lesions caused by nipple discharge are mostly ductal calcifications, asymmetric or multiple intraductal masses, or abnormalities of ductal structures that may or may not be accompanied by calcifications. Compared with other lesions found by breast imaging, it is often not clear whether it is cancer. Therefore, ductal discharge in women is often treated as a high-risk group for breast cancer, and early detection measures should be used to identify early breast cancers and accurately assess the risk of breast cancer.
As an exploratory study, the study plans to conduct another imaging using contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after the routine iopromide 370 mgI/ml-enhanced ductography, so as to explore the optimization of the ductography technique and attempt to make a systematic description of the mammary duct structure in the Chinese population of patients with pathological nipple discharge, and thus to assess the clinical value of this delayed imaging protocol, including the effectiveness of the diagnostic dimension of the disease and the safety of the radiation dose and the degree of patient tolerance.

The purpose of this study is to compare the effectiveness of standard pelvic floor physical therapy with the addition of a pelvic floor muscle training device against using the pelvic floor muscle training device in isolation for the treatment of Stress Urinary Incontinence. The investigators expect to demonstrate that the use of the Pelvic Floor Trainer will enhance the efficacy of pelvic floor physical therapy. 
The Pelvic Floor Muscle Trainer (Pelex Upp) (device under study) is a self-diagnostic device that teaches the subject how to locate and control the pelvic floor muscle group, as well as assisting a clinician in measuring pelvic floor muscle function and strength using biofeedback sensors. The device delivers auditory and visual guidance to the subject, and reports the data to the subject's computer screen or mobile device. The device is not an aid intended to replace regular treatment plans or treatments with a treating physician, but instead a tool designed to assist treating physicians in providing treatment to patients with pelvic floor muscle issues related to stress, urge, or mixed urinary incontinence.
Subjects will be recruited via an online recruitment tool to participate in the study. Participating subjects will undergo a screening process and will take a pretreatment survey to assess urinary incontinence symptoms. After completing the survey, the participant will be assigned to one of the following three treatment groups: Group 1: Treatment with the Pelex Upp alone (device under study). Group 2: Treatment with the Pelex Upp in combination with 4 visits with a treating clinician (device under study). Group 3: Treatment with 4 visits with a treating clinician (comparative treatment). Subjects will be followed up approximately 4 weeks after treatment begins in order to evaluate the treatment's effectiveness.

The current study will identify efficient strategies to encourage attendance in Community Wise (CW), a manualized, multi-level intervention for the reduction of daily drinking among individuals with histories of alcohol/substances use disorder (ASUD). As a highly efficient experimental design, a full factorial experiment will be used. A full factorial experiment with three interventions (recruiting individuals under supervision, incentivizing intervention attendance, and delivering the intervention in an open group format) will be used to maximize study power and examine the individual and interactive contributions of each intervention delivery strategy on intervention attendance (with a minimum of 50% of participants attending at least 50% of the intervention; number of sessions attended) and to test their efficacy. The goal is to improve access to treatment through a greater understanding of these important factors related to intervention delivery strategies.

Inadequate pain management can have very serious consequences such as prolonged hospitalization and increased mortality and morbidity. Although many regional anesthesia techniques have been used to manage acute postoperative pain, the most common of which are intercostal block and paravertebral block, these techniques may not cover all dermatomes, which can cause incomplete pain control and the need for additional pain treatment. The interpectoral-serratus anterior plane block is a regional anesthetic technique applied to cover the thoracic dermatomes. This technique has been used for pain management in lung and mediastinum surgeries for years. There is no information about using this technique in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The aim of the intervention study is to evaluate the effect of interpectoral plane block combined with serratus anterior plane block on the pain and recovery process in the case of minimally invasive cardiac surgery using the erector spinae block. With the help of this study, the investigators wanted to determine whether the pain management of the patients is better with erector spinae block and interpectoral-serratus blocks in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. Since these treatments are the most common regional anesthesia methods used in regional anesthesia and have been used since many years ago, we believe that this study, which aims to provide clear data in terms of pain management in this surgery, will provide new data to regional anesthesia applications to be applied in minimally invasive cardiac surgery. The sample size of the study is estimated as 50 participants each for the intervention group and the control group, as a result of the literature review and the number of patients who came to our service in the last 12 months. In addition to the data obtained from the sample groups, data to be used in our statistical analyses from the literature will be reviewed and recorded. Inclusion criteria: In order for the participant to be eligible for this research, the following criteria should be met: The patient must give written consent to participate in the study. To be between 18-75 y. Higher surgical risk score calculated by the American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status Scale (ASA I-II) Patients with an average bleeding profile Patients who gave written consent to participate in the study Patients without local anesthetic allergy and a history Patients who have the intellectual level to use the patient-controlled analgesia device Patients who will undergo cardiac surgery for the primary time Exclusion criteria; There are no local anesthetic allergy and patients who had this history Patients who underwent previous open heart surgery before the surgery of heart valve The procedure should be re-operated due to any surgical complication within the 24th hour after the operation. Patients who do not have the intellectual level to use the patient-controlled analgesia device Patients not suitable for PCA Patients with abnormal bleeding profile Patients who were re-operated due to any surgical complication within the 24th hour after the operation. Patients who do not qualify for the study

Background: Colorectal cancer is one of the few tumors that can achieve long-term survival of patients, and maintaining the best possible quality of life in patients is of great importance. However, the recurrence and metastasis rates of colorectal cancer are still quite high, and about 30% of patients have tumor recurrence during the first three years after radical treatment. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to study the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for advanced CRC patients who have achieved NED after adjuvant chemotherapy.
Objective: To explore the clinical efficacy and safety of fruquintinib as maintenance therapy for advanced CRC patients who achieve NED after adjuvant chemotherapy.
Methods: This is a prospective, single-arm, phase II study. Patients will receive Fruquintinib maintenance treatment for six months or until tumor recurrence, metastasis or intolerable drug toxicities occur within six months. After achieving NED, a chest, abdomen and pelvis CT scan with contrast or a chest CT scan with abdominal and pelvic MRI scan will be performed every 6 months within 2 years. Colonoscopy will be performed annually. CEA, CA19-9 and abdominal and pelvic ultrasound will be performed every 3 months. If abnormalities are found, further imaging studies and colonoscopy will be conducted, and if necessary, a PET/CT scan will be performed. The primary end point of this study was the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate. The secondary end point includes the 2-year disease-free survival rate, 2-year overall survival rate and toxicity. The time frame of 2 years is used to ensure the completion of adjuvant treatment and the maintenance treatment at the designated time points. The incidence of drug-related adverse events is another important indicator for drug safety evaluation. The severity and frequency of adverse events in this study will be recorded and graded according to the NCI CTCAE version 5.0, and dose adjustments will be made according to the corresponding rules.

The investigators propose to conduct an aggregated N-of-1 randomized placebo-controlled trial of Methylphenidate for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and subjective cognitive complaints in Veterans with PTSD, with or without a history of mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). In this multi-site trial, 70 Veterans, ages 18-65, with a diagnosis of PTSD and subjective cognitive complaints, as measured by both the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function Short Form (NeuroQoL) and a single item about cognitive functioning in clinical interview, will be randomized to receive either methylphenidate (MPH) or placebo (PBO) for two 28-day treatment blocks, with the order of the treatment blocks randomly assigned. Weekly cognitive functioning assessments and bi-weekly PTSD, depression, and cognitive functioning evaluations will be completed during both treatment blocks. This study design consists of two cycles, providing 8 weeks each of MPH and PBO, and allows not only to detect a main effect of treatment on PTSD and cognitive functioning, but also a significant treatment response in those with a history of mTBI. Through careful and systematic evaluations of neurocognitive functioning, the investigators will explore whether the effects observed extend beyond symptomology to include improvements in neurocognitive functions, as measured by objective tests of attention and executive function. This design will provide the specificity of treatment effect necessary to evaluate the impact of MPH on PTSD, depression, and cognitive symptomology across a range of severity levels. Should the investigators find that MPH is efficacious for PTSD, depression, and/or cognitive functioning in this population, it would provide an important step in the search for effective treatment for the many suffering from these life-interrupting illnesses.

Invasive study of microvascular function has become highly relevant for the diagnosis of alterations in coronary physiology for diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic purposes. Currently, the microvascular resistance index (IMR) is considered the gold standard for invasive diagnosis of coronary microvascular function, with a recommendation of 2A in the current clinical practice guidelines of the European Society of Cardiology. In recent years, technical innovation has allowed for the measurement of absolute coronary flow (AF) and minimal microvascular resistance (MMR) using continuous thermodilution, enabling the determination of quantitative flow and resistance units. However, the main limitation is the absence of reference values. Objectives: The main objective is to prospectively validate the capacity of CFRflow as a predictor of the presence of angina measured by SAQ7 in patients with INOCA at 3 months. Secondary objectives include identifying hemodynamic factors related to the persistence of angina at 3 and 12 months, identifying clinical factors related to the persistence of angina, establishing the prevalence of patients with coronary microvascular dysfunction within the cohort of INOCA patients, identifying predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months, validating the pathological value of MMR and establishing the pathological value of AF measured in ml/min. The study also aims to evaluate the concordance between measures of the coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous thermodilution and bolus thermodilution, as well as their concordance with clinical characteristics.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a syndrome characterized by chronic, recurrent abdominal pain or discomfort. The etiology and pathophysiology of IBS are not well known; however, changes in the intestinal microbiome and ecosystem, food intolerance, persistent intestinal hypersensitivity, and inflammation are suggested. A temple stay is one lifestyle program consisting of a vegetarian diet and daily meditation, and our research team hypothesizes that it may be effective at stabilizing chronic intestinal inflammation and at inducing changes in the composition of the gut microbiome, leading to subjective symptom improvement. In this study, 30 patients with IBS who agree to participate in a temple stay for 8 days (4-day monastic training period and a 4-day observation period) will have baseline IBS symptoms recorded using the IBS-Symptom Severity Scale (IBS-SSS). Fecal samples will also be collected before and after the temple stay experience. The IBS symptoms score, intestinal microbiome, and quality of life will be compared before and after the temple stay experience by the Wilcoxon Signed-Rank test. The results will be calculated based on data from 15 subjects. The study will support the effectiveness of the temple stay in controlling the chronic glycemic symptoms of IBS by objectively validating the relationship between the change in the intestinal ecosystem and the change in symptom score, and its clinical impact will be observed.

Asthma is an airway disease and one of the most common non-communicable diseases affecting over 339 million individuals worldwide. One important advance in the treatment of this disease is inhalers (both dry powder inhalers and pressurised metered dose inhalers). However, there are significant environmental impacts to the production and disposal of inhalers. Metered dose inhalers (MDI) contain potent greenhouse gases (GHG) and a recent study from the UK revealed that although patient awareness of the discrepancy in climate impact of inhalers is low, their willingness to change inhalers after being educated on the subject is high. An example of inhaler change is to use the Bricanyl Turbuhaler (terbutaline) instead of Ventolin (salbutamol) as a rescue medication. They are both short-acting bronchodilators (SABA) and have similar pharmacodynamics. However, use of Bricanyl for one year produces 7,183 kgCO2e or the equivalent of 59.9 km by car, whereas use of Ventolin for one year produces 411,720 kgCO2e, the equivalent of 3,431 km by car. The objective of this study is to assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons as well as prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at patient's request. The study will also be assessing patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and the importance that they attribute to this issue as well as other important issues (such as cost and ease of use). The investigator will also be asking prescribers about their willingness to prescribe environmentally friendly inhalers.

Everyone may be temporarily or permanently disabled at some point in their life, and it has been stated that they will experience increasing difficulties in functioning in old age. He estimates that the prevalence of disability among women is 60% higher than that of men. Disabled women coexist in a dual state of vulnerability where being a woman and being a disabled person have two social disadvantages. Among people with disabilities, women with physical disabilities have higher unmet healthcare needs than women without disabilities. Cancer is an important public health problem and cause of death all over the world. According to the Turkish Cancer Statistics, it is estimated that approximately 69,633 women are diagnosed with cancer in our country. Among the most common cancers in women; breast, uterine corpus, ovarian and cervix cancers are seen to be prominent, respectively. It is known that with regular examinations and screenings, early diagnosis of breast and cervical cancer increases the chance of treatment. International studies show that women face barriers and difficulties in accessing reproductive health and cancer screening services. In the study of Horner-Johson et al., it was stated that especially rural women with disabilities had lower mammography and Pap-smear tests compared to non-disabled women. It is emphasized that as a result of lower screening participation of persons with disabilities, there is a higher risk of cancer mortality with delayed diagnosis. In another study investigating the reasons why women with physical disabilities do not engage in preventive health services; time constraints and priorities, interactions between health professionals and women with disabilities, lack of knowledge, belief, sensitivity, belief that people with disabilities have more information than service providers, economic problems, transportation problems, appointment problems, availability of accessible facilities, physical pain, mammography, pap smear It has been stated that the factors affecting the use of mammography and gynecological examination services and the women's belief and attitude systems were discussed with the participants. One of the most effective methods in health education for cancer is the Health Belief Model (SIM). The most basic components of the model are the perception of susceptibility, the perception of seriousness, the perception of benefit, the perception of obstacles, the health motivation and the perception of trust. The SIM recommends that if a person has a desire to prevent illness or a belief in recovery, he or she should take a specific health action to prevent illness as a positive behavior. This study was conducted to determine the barriers for women with physical disabilities between the ages of 18-65 to adopt behaviors to diagnose common cancers in women at an early stage, and to increase participation in early diagnosis behaviors in cancers that are common in women (Breast Self Examination (BSE), Clinical Breast Examination (CBE), Self-Examination. Vulva Self Examination (KKVM), Mammography and PapSmear Test) by determining the awareness of women with physical disabilities. The effectiveness of awareness training based on SIM was planned to be determined.

Trastuzumab is a biological targeted agent that improves survival in HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. It may also be effective in the neoadjuvant setting. We aim to identify high-quality clinical trials that report the effectiveness of the neoadjuvant treatment with Trastuzumab, combined with conventional chemotherapy, to treat HER2-positive breast cancer.
The primary endpoint for this systematic review is an estimated (with 95% confidence intervals) of the pathological complete response rate for the HER2-positive breast cancer. Secondary endpoints are estimates of overall survival and disease-free survival in the different trials.
There is a need for a systematic review to give a clear overview of the evidence on the efficacy and safety of the most promising and effective treatments in the management of HER2-positive breast cancer.
Inclusion criteria: - All patients with operable and locally advanced breast cancer who have received neoadjuvant therapy including trastuzumab and chemotherapy are eligible. - Clinical trials will be included in the review if at least 20 patients per treatment arm have been evaluated. - All cytotoxic chemotherapy regimens will be considered eligible for this systematic review given that the same drugs were given at the same dose in every trial.

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in the Western World. Current CAD management mainly involves the assessment of the severity of lumen stenosis (visual estimation of diameter stenosis) in the clinical workup. However, severe CAD patients with stable or unstable angina often undergo invasive coronary angiography (ICA) with a functional diagnostic evaluation using pressure wire-based FFR (FFR). Although FFR is currently best practice for assessment of functionally significant coronary stenoses, it is expensive and complex. IVUS and ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) represent new, non-invasive cardiovascular imaging modalities that could be utilized on a larger scale.
The present study examines the diagnostic performance of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) when compared to FFR in the assessment of functional hemodynamic relevance of coronary artery stenosis. A total of 80 patients with moderate, intermediated coronary lesions (DS: 30-75%) are recruited from the intervention group of the randomized, multicenter FACET trial to undergo a single IVUS pullback and the pressure wire-based FFR. The UFR will be measured prospectively using the ﬁfty-ﬁve Echo intravascular Echocardiography catheter (Fifty-Five, Vivid Diagnostics) immediately following PCI. The aim of the study is to investigate the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in comparison with FFR in regard to predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis per patient. The ﬁtness for clinical use is determined using the De Bakey classification.

Purpose: The purpose of this study is to compare the effect of Balint group activities on reducing nursing leaders' burnout and enhancing self-efficacy by means of randomised controlled study design.
Inclusion criteria: The inclusion criteria are registered nurse staff of clinical departments who have not participated in Balint groups previously.
Methods: The study adopted the design approach of randomized controlled trial (RCT) and the mixed-method parallel assignment study design. The sample of the study comprised 100 nurse leaders who voluntarily participated in the study. Participants in the Balint group completed Balint training for a period of three months.

Pre-established measures: Before the Balint training, both groups completed a series of questionnaires, including the general self-efficacy scale (GSES), the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS), and the self-reported questionnaire of quality of life. After the Balint training, the follow-up survey was conducted for all participants, in the format of the same measures as pre-tests. Two to four months later, some participants selected from both groups were invited to participate in in-depth interviews using a semi-structured interview.

Limitations: The potential biases include self-selection biases, inability to ensure the follow-up rate is completed by all participants until the end of the research, the possible influence of other work-related variables on the study outcomes, and the lack of control in a single unit for participants.

Expectations: It is expected that completing Balint training activities will reduce the burnout and increase the self-efficacy of nurse leaders.

Theory: Balint's original idea of Balint group is a safe working environment to help the improvement and progress of participants, including doctors, nurses, and other medical professionals. The Balint group is a collaborative, safe and open learning space. Balint believes that the working space of medical staff should be a place of mutual trust and protection. The Balint group is a place where participants feel safe and comfortable in the process of mutual supervision and exchange, can express themselves fully and accurately, in addition, can learn and improve through listening and self-exploration.
In China, Balint group has been proved to be effective in relieving burnout and improving self-efficacy. However, whether the effect of Balint group can be applied to the specific context of nurse leaders in China has not been systematically verified.
In this study, the investigators conducted a longitudinal study to evaluate the effectiveness of Balint groups intervention on reducing burnout and enhancing self-efficacy of Nurse leaders in China.

Background:
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is one of the most common causes of dementia. Among the neuropsychiatric and behavioral symptoms seen in AD patients, apathy is the most common symptom. In addition, depression, aggression, anxiety and sleep disorders often accompany and contribute to increased mortality and reduced quality of life for patients and their caregivers. Because of the inability to treat the disease completely and adverse drug side effects of the drugs used to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms and behaviors, it is recommended that non-pharmacological treatments be applied first. The concept of cognitive stimulation in AD is one of the most popular approaches. Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) is the best evidence-based practice with robust clinical trials, applied according to a specific guideline for individuals with mild and moderate dementia. The inability to treat the disease completely worsens this situation. Because of the inability to treat the disease completely and adverse drug side effects of the drugs used to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms and behaviors, it is recommended that non-pharmacological treatments be applied first.

Objective:
The aim of this research is to determine the effect of CST application on the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety and daily living activities in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.

Method:
Ethical permission has been obtained from the Ethical Board of Gaziantep University Faculty of Medicine.
After obtaining permission, data collection will include people with Alzheimer's Disease and their caregivers. In the first stage, individuals with Alzheimer's Disease and their caregivers who have agreed to participate in the study are informed about the research and the consent form is obtained from the caregivers of individuals with Alzheimer's Disease. Those who volunteer and prefer to participate in the research are assessed with the inclusion criteria.

Design Details: A randomized controlled experimental research design is planned with pretest, intermediate test and post-test control group as the design basis.

Study type: Interventional
Participants: Randomized controlled clinical trial
Intervention model: Parallel Assignment
Masking: Double

Procedure:
The participants who have been evaluated in terms of all inclusion criteria will be divided into two groups by the 4-block random sampling method, with one group receiving an intervention and the other group receiving no intervention. In the control group, in addition to standard care, individual and group activities will not be applied to the patients, and the control group will continue their daily routines with their family members. The group where the intervention will be applied will be called Intervention Group. This group will participate in Cognitive Stimulation Therapy application for 14 sessions. The training will be held two days a week at the same time and same location. After the 14th session, they will be given an individual session for the final application. CST sessions consist of 14 individual sessions, in which the patient completes at least 8 sessions, in addition to 2 to 3 sessions for each other. Before the application, an interview will be done and they will be evaluated using standardized scales. After the 14th application, these tests will be applied for the second time. In this way, the cognitive and social state, apathy, anxiety, loneliness and daily living skills of the patients will be assessed.

Instruments:
Data will be collected through forms and tests designed for the purpose of research. There is no standard Turkish version of the questionnaire or scale suitable for assessing the level of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, daily living skills and cognitive state in individuals with Alzheimer's. Therefore, validated scale Turkish versions (UCLA Loneliness Scale; Beck Depression Inventory; Geriatric Anxiety Scale - 14 items; Apathy Evaluation Scale in Alzheimer's; Functional Disability in Dementia Scale; Cognitive Stimulation Therapy Individual Session Evaluation Form; Cognitive Stimulation Therapy Group Session Evaluation Form; Treatment Feasibility Questionnaire for Psychological Interventions) will be used in the same form in the study.

Apathy Evaluation Scale in Alzheimer's: In this scale, which consists of 18 items, there are positive or negative statements. The aim of the study was to determine the effect of counselling and follow-up after breast cancer education on early diagnosis behavior and healthy lifestyle behavior.
The study was a prospective, parallel, two-arm (1:1), randomised controlled experimental study. Participants were randomly divided into the study group and the control group. The total sample of the study was 160. The study group that received counselling had its frequency of early breast cancer diagnosis behavior, counseling and healthy lifestyle behavior examined before and after training, whereas the control group was not given any additional education or application. Data was collected using the Descriptive Characteristics Form, Breast Cancer Early Diagnosis Behaviors Form, Counselling Form, and Healthy Lifestyle Behaviors Scale II.
The study found that counselling after breast cancer education had a positive effect on early diagnosis behaviors, specifically self-examination. However, there was no effect on healthy lifestyle behaviors. The investigators suggest that counselling after breast cancer awareness training for women with risk factors may increase self-examination and early diagnosis behaviors, and more research is needed to improve lifestyle.

The prevalence of chronic pain remains high at around 20 percent of the population, with a disabling impact on functional performance, personal well-being and daily life, as well as an economic burden at the national and international level. Chronic pain is nowadays one of the most challenging medical conditions that health professionals have to deal with, as it has proven extremely difficult to be treated, with a therapeutic success rate of only 10%. In order to provide a personalized and efficacious answer to the complexity of the physiological and psychosocial pain experience, new interventions and therapies are required to change the landscape of chronic pain management. The major problem with assessing pain is the heterogeneous nature of the construct of pain, which encompasses both physical and psychological aspects. While the gold standard in pain assessment is self-reported pain scores, today 95% of patients suffering from chronic pain have poor pain relief, presenting high satisfaction rates for treatment. Therefore, the efficacy of currently available treatments is suboptimal, and new approaches for characterizing pain have to be devised to improve patient's quality of life. pAIn-sense aims to design and develop a digital-based telemonitoring platform, integrating innovative digital technologies and Artificial Intelligence models, that enables real-time and objective pain monitoring in daily life scenarios. The investigators plan to study patient pain, as a continuous process in daily settings, using wearable non-invasive physiological sensors (such as galvanic skin response, blood pressure, heart rate, electroencephalogram, functional images and temperature sensors) and questionnaires (anxiety, depression, fatigue, pain catastrophizing, sleep, etc.), which will provide information on the patient's pain experience using an artificial intelligence model. The data collected will be used to produce daily personalized reports about the pain experienced by the subject. Physicians will have access to a holistic health-dashboard collecting both psychophysiological and psychosocial details, allowing them to adjust the medication, and to evaluate progress of pain. Therefore, pAIn-sense aims to provide a digital-based telemonitoring platform for pain assessment and personalized treatment, with the ultimate goal to provide a new tool for pain management that will improve patient's quality of life, by understanding the true nature and multidimensional aspects of their pain, thereby changing the current landscape of chronic pain therapy.

Introduction: Lymphatic Malformations (LMs) are abnormal collections of lymphatic vessels. There are two types of LMs: macrocystic and microcystic LMs. Macrocystic LMs are rare, and treatment options are limited. This study will be conducted to assess whether TARA-002, an investigational treatment, is effective and safe in reducing volume of cysts and increasing or restoring function in these rare LMs. Procedure, Risks, and Benefits: Subjects will be treated with 4 to 20 intracystic injections of TARA-002 spaced approximately 6 weeks apart into the target cyst or cysts for a total of up to 8 months. TARA-002 has been previously shown to reduce the volume of cysts and improve function. Risks are generally similar to those with other procedures to treat LMs, including surgery, sclerotherapy, microwave or laser ablation and chemoembolization. Benefits are injections can be given as an outpatient procedure under conscious sedation with local anesthetic. If the child completes the study it is likely that they will have decreased volume of their LM and increased function, and that the cyst or cysts will not have further increased in size. It is also possible that the participant will have a reduction in the need for treatment with local anesthetics, analgesics or medications to reduce swelling. This research may help to avoid surgical removal, as well as the potential complications that can be related to surgery such as increased pain, blood loss, infection, hospitalization or general anesthesia. Treatment is usually associated with discomfort or pain in the area where the injections or treatments are given. Other risks include the possibility of an allergic reaction to the treatment, which is rare, or injection of the treatment into the wrong cyst. Study participants will be monitored for side effects in the hospital after injections and outpatient. The study has risks that are similar to those of any type of treatment, such as the risk of infection or scar tissue formation, but it also has other unique risks such as changes in blood pressure, changes in heart rate, changes from normal blood tests, allergic reactions or problems that could affect your vision. There is the risk of the treatment being ineffective. Participants will need to have their parent or legally authorized representative (LAR) sign a written document of consent for the study. For younger participants, they will need to sign the assent form if they are old enough. Your doctor can answer any specific questions you may have. There will be an opportunity for participants and their families to learn more about the study during the screening visit. There will be additional opportunities to discuss the study during the visits in the hospital after treatments. If you agree to take part, you will be able to ask any questions or discuss the study further. If you and your parent/LAR decide to join the study, you will be asked to sign the informed consent/assent form and may have up to 2 screening visits prior to receiving any study treatment. You may receive treatment if you meet the selection criteria for the study. This study will assess the effectiveness in treatment of macrocystic LM in the Head and Neck region (H & N) (i.e., face, neck, eye orbits) after treatment of TARA-002. The study is an expansion of the Phase I safety study. The dosage and method of application of TARA-002 is currently unclear for larger cystic volume disease in children, especially those that are difficult to treat by conventional means of sclerotherapy or surgical resection. The study will be conducted as a single-group, open-label trial in participants between 6 months to less than 18 years of age. This study will assess the efficacy, safety, tolerability and long term performance of TARA-002 for the treatment of LM in participants. Repeat injection treatment within the same cyst can begin approximately 28 days (4 weeks) after the last injection in the previous cycle. The study may take up to 32 weeks after the last treatment injection. Participants who do well in their first treatment cycle may have an option to continue treatment in future cycles after discussing this with their doctor and obtaining approval from the sponsor. An opportunity for participants and their families to provide written feedback on the study and their experience is available after completion of the study at 32 weeks. This is a voluntary, anonymous process and is not part of any other study or clinical research. If the participant chooses to provide feedback, they may choose to share their information with their treating physician, but they do not have to.

The purpose of this study is to determine the potential long-term benefits of early aggressive treatment of patients diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia. During a period of five years, patients with hyperlipidaemia and/or Type 2 Diabetes will be encouraged to take dietary supplements and/or dietary advice and to undertake regular physical exercise. The hypothesis is that early aggressive treatment for two years of patients diagnosed with hyperlipidaemia will result in a lower number of patients developing heart disease (coronary heart disease, heart attack or stroke) and/or Type 2 Diabetes. Patients with dyslipidaemia/hypertension/ Type 2 Diabetes will also be treated.
