People with severe communication difficulties are known to face multiple access barriers to assistive technology. One major challenge for this population is access to augmentative and alternative communications (AAC), which can improve social interaction and employment outcomes. While AAC devices currently in use are effective, they may be inaccessible either due to high cost or the physical size of the device. More compact AAC devices are needed. These smaller devices can then offer greater flexibility in the AAC delivery environment and enable people to maintain a more natural interaction style with other people. Small handheld devices such as smartphones and tablets may be used as AAC devices due to their small size, multi-user access, and portability, however these devices are not optimised for AAC use. The Earswitch™ is a new type of AAC device which fits in the ear canal and operates using a soft biocompatible material in the form of an earpiece and a miniscule camera hidden inside the earbud. The camera sits in the ear canal in close proximity to the ear drum, which enables it to detect and analyse low frequency sounds (around 140Hz) that can be created using the tensor tympani (TT) muscle in the outer ear. The Earswitch™ provides a simple input mechanism using TT movements and no external switches or other input devices are needed.
Unfortunately, very little is known about how well people with severe communication difficulties can contract the TT muscle in response to visual or audio stimuli. This research study therefore aims to investigate the robustness of the Earswitch™ by asking participants to make TT contractions in response to a series of stimuli. Additionally, interviews will be conducted with participants about the fit of the camera and its overall suitability for future AAC implementation. Therefore, this study will aim to generate valuable information about the potential of the camera to act as an input device and about how well people with severe communication difficulties can use the Earswitch™ effectively.

Autologous Adipose Tissue (AAT), is well documented to contain stem cell populations, but also extracellular matrix elements and a diverse cell population. We aim in a randomized controlled trial to see whether AAT as cartilage regeneration technique would be superior to microfracture in cartilage repair in patients with femoral condyles lesion (type II-III according to Outerbridge classification). All participants in this study will undergo a single stage knee arthroscopy and will be divided into 3 different protocols in a randomized manner. This paper serves as an introduction into our study and describes the design, including outcome measures and baseline demographic data of all participants in the study.
The 50 consecutive patients with symptomatic single femoral condyles isolated ulceration with no previous intra-articular treatment were referred to KOREMA clinic. Inclusion criteria were a symptomatic femoral condyles focal cartilage lesion (type II-III according to Outerbridge classification) without previous treatment that could affect the evaluation of the procedures under study (previous knee surgery, systemic treatment for osteoarthritis). The presence of concomitant knee deformity was accepted if it was between 50-100 according to Whiteside classification. Patients with a valgus deformity above 100 or a varus deformity of 50-1000, a history of intra-articular injections of corticosteroid within the last 6 months, a varus deformity less than 10, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Gout, Systemic Arthritis, Crystal arthropathy, Psoriatic Arthritis, Post-infectious arthritis, Avascular necrosis, Osteochondral defect or Post-traumatic arthritis were excluded.

Exercise is a crucial component of many individuals' training programs and can play an essential role in improving health status and reducing several health hazards. It has been known that the benefits of high-volume exercise training are not limited to the physiological adaptations but can also improve physical performance and health status via modulation of the immune response. However, some have expressed the idea that there may be a "point of diminishing returns" at a certain exercise volume, and exercise above this point cannot improve performance. The immune response has been mentioned as this point and may depend on overreaching conditions that are believed to impair performance.
There is a vast amount of heterogeneity in both well-trained and untrained individuals' training volume. This heterogeneity is partly due to the lack of a structured approach on exercise volume, intensity, and frequency as well as the absence of a gold-standard recovery strategy after every bout of exercise. Therefore, we aimed to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery to improve physical performance and health status. The primary aim will be to determine the effect of different recovery strategies during 8 weeks of well-controlled, high-volume, large-scale, exercise training on the immune system, cardio-metabolic markers, and endocrine response. Secondary aims will include: (1) To determine the effect of different recovery strategies during 8 weeks of well-controlled, high-volume, large-scale, exercise training on body strength, aerobic capacity, and body composition.
We will recruit highly active and healthy participants from the Ministry of Defense to participate in an 8-week well-controlled, high-volume exercise training trial to investigate the influence of recovery strategy. Participants will be randomized into one of three groups: control (35 h/week), less exercise volume (25-45 h/week), and a longer rest group (35 h/week with longer rest between exercise sessions) for 8 weeks. Changes in health indices will be assessed by cardiometabolic, endocrine, and immune blood markers and body composition assessment at baseline (T0), after, 4 (T4), and 8 (T8) weeks of the intervention. Aerobic capacity, anaerobic threshold, and strength measurements will be used to determine changes in performance at T0, T4, and T8. We believe that we will be able to determine the relationship between exercise training and recovery and develop a sustainable training strategy that can further decrease the cardiovascular diseases, cancer incidence, and chronic low-grade inflammation's prevalence rate. Additionally, this study's results will aid individuals with medical problems, who often need to modify exercise volume or be more selective when implementing exercise in their daily practice, in designing more successful recovery protocols and improving the quality of life.

Osteoarthritis (OA) affects the knee joint on a large scale, where 80% of the joint surface wear is a result of the loss of the joint space. The joint space width (JSW) of the knee indicates the health of the cartilage and joint, and can be measured non-invasively on MRI scans. Weight-bearing MRI scans can give insight into joint space loss in the medial compartment of the knee in OA patients, as the medial compartment carries more weight than the lateral compartment. However, there is lack of evidence in regard to differences in medial and lateral JSW between different scan positions, including weight-bearing scans. Therefore, this trial will assess the differences in medial and lateral JSW in weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing scan positions in both the flexed and extended knee (in two randomized scan positions), in terms of the correlation with clinical variables.

Dysphagia is prevalent in almost all neurodegenerative conditions and results in the inability to effectively protect the lower airways from foreign (i.e., food/liquid) and endogenous (i.e., saliva) material [1-3]. An unfortunate consequence of dysphagia is aspiration pneumonia, which is a leading cause of death in Parkinson's disease (PD) [4-6]. Swallowing therapy has proven to be effective for the management of dysphagic symptoms in PD. Treatment is most often delivered in clinics once/week over short time periods with the expectation that exercises be completed at-home. However, these paradigms lack biofeedback to assess the accuracy and strength of the prescribed exercise and accountability to ensure completion of the exercise program. Without biofeedback or options for long-term therapeutic intervention at-home, patients often regress to baseline levels [7-9]. The proposed research project seeks to test the effectiveness of a novel at-home surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback therapy tool called Biofeedback in Strength and Skill Training (BiSSKit) on swallowing safety and efficiency in patients with PD. The significance of this project lies in the fact that dysphagia is expensive in terms of patient quality of life, health outcomes, and healthcare costs [10, 11] often increasing hospital costs by approximately 40% [12]. Thus, a targeted swallowing therapy system with biofeedback that can be utilized at-home may reduce hospitalizations secondary to dysphagia, help maintain therapeutic gains, and reduce the burden that dysphagia places on our healthcare system. sEMG is a therapy tool that has been used in rehabilitation practice for decades. Use of sEMG during swallowing therapy involves placement of electrodes under the chin (overlying the anterior belly of the digastric, mylohyoid and geniohyoid muscles) [13]. While the patient completes a swallowing task, electrodes detect collective muscle contractions associated with hyolaryngeal excursion - a biomechanical event critically important to airway safety and swallowing efficiency [14]. The patient can then see the waveform of the swallow displayed on a computer monitor. Measures of swallowing strength are derived from the amplitude of the waveform. sEMG provides external biofeedback regarding swallowing parameters by activating neural networks controlling both motor execution and imagery of the act of swallowing including the pre- and postcentral gyrus, inferior frontal gyrus, basal ganglia, insula, and cerebellum [15]. Research has shown that exercise programs incorporating biofeedback promote significant physiologic change that is maintained over time in patients with dysphagia [14, 16-18]. Patients with PD benefit greatly from biofeedback exercises for respiratory muscle strength and lingual strengthening programs and have even been found to maintain the gains made in therapy with at-home programs [7, 16, 19]. A limitation of the currently available sEMG programs is that research studies have solely focus on the strength aspects of the swallowing (amplitude of the waveform) while failing to address the dynamic, skill-based parameters such as timing and volitional initiation that is captured in waveform morphology. Skill based swallowing training focuses on the precision of movements; and this is especially important for patients with PD [14]. Additionally, traditional sEMG systems in the US lack the ability for clinicians to modulate swallowing targets during tasks, which, according to principles of neuroplasticity, is essential for maximizing therapeutic results. The BiSSKit program is a well-researched office-based biofeedback system that adheres to principles of neuroplasticity and incorporates skill training in addition to strength training [14]. Developed in New Zealand and recently approved by the US FDA, this program has been converted into an affordable and accessible home-based application for tablet computers. This hybrid BiSSKiT system incorporates clinical visits and home-based skill/strength training and shows promise to change current therapy delivery models. Although exciting, there is a paucity of data regarding the use of the BiSSKiT with daily home therapy focused on strength and skill based swallowing training on changes to swallowing safety and efficiency in people with PD. This study seeks to evaluate the impact of this device on swallowing outcomes compared to traditional swallowing therapy models in PD.

The main focus of the study will be to estimate prevalence of HPV and incidence of persistent HPV in women, with a special focus on women in low socio-economic areas of South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa. A total of 30,000 women in 8 different countries will be enrolled in this study and will complete a survey and provide a sample. Countries have been selected in order to represent regions with high, medium, or low cervical cancer incidence, countries with or without HPV screening and treatment programs, and countries that are in various stages of prophylactic HPV vaccine rollout. Urine sample and self-collected vaginal swabs (SCVS) will be collected for HPV testing, along with data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, cervical screening, HPV vaccination, and potential risk factors for HPV infection and cervical cancer. In selected countries, the comparison between urine and SCVS will be done using 16/18 DNA positivity rates. For the purpose of the study, a positive urine test is determined to be when the participant is HPV DNA positive irrespective of the type specificity (i.e., irrespective of the specific HPV types being detectable) and if there is at least 3500-genome equivalents of 16/18 type in the sample; the definition of a positive vaginal swab test is based on the presence of HPV 16/18 type in the sample. After informed consent and a completed survey, a urine sample and/or an SCVS will be collected. Urine samples will be collected first, and if urine sample collection is unsuccessful, an alternative test will be done with the SCVS. The main focus of the study will be to estimate the prevalence of HPV among a representative sample of women ages 9-50 in 8 countries in low SES areas of the south Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, and to evaluate the burden of HPV in a representative population sample of lower SES status, as well as in particular vulnerable sub-populations of girls and women depending on the country. For this purpose, up to 4 surveys with the same questions will be conducted, and urine sample and or SCVS will be collected from the same participant at least once in their lifetime. 108 of the 8 different countries will participate in one CSS and up to 5 CSS. Overall, approximately 15,000 women will be enrolled in the CSS. Additionally, women in five countries will also participate in Longitudinal studies (LS) in order to estimate the incidence of persistent HR HPV infection. 138 of the 8 different countries will participate in one LS and up to 5 LS. Approximately 15,120 women will be enrolled in the LS. LS participants will be followed up for 24 months and will be tested every 6 months for persistent high-risk HPV, with an SCVS being collected. In selected countries, urine samples will be collected at the first and all subsequent visits.

The use of cognitive functions such as memory is essential for the execution of daily activities and represents a crucial element for autonomy maintenance during aging. It is known that the physiological cognitive decline associated with aging also involves memory and can significantly impact the older person's independence. For these reasons, great interest has been generated by two tools that have proved to be decisive in supporting memory functions: non-invasive neurostimulation and memory training. Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is a form of noninvasive brain stimulation that modulates brain activity by employing a direct current delivered through electrodes applied to the scalp. Recently, the use of tDCS has been combined with training interventions focused on working memory in healthy older adults, providing evidence of a significant improvement in memory function when memory training is associated with the use of tDCS compared to when it is performed without it. In particular, adaptive memory trainings coupled with stimulation of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex provide benefits that last also at follow-up visits after 1 or 3 months, especially in participants who exhibit a lower baseline performance. While it was observed that adaptive working memory training alone is unable to modulate brain plasticity mechanisms, it was hypothesized that tDCS can modulate brain plasticity by acting through long-term potentiation (LTP) mechanisms and that it can modulate brain neurotrophic factor (BDNF), a protein that plays a relevant role in LTP. Several adaptive memory trainings focused on working memory, which is essential for decision-making processes and daily activities. Even if promising results have been shown so far, it appears that no study addressed the implementation of strategic memory training coupled with the use of tDCS. Adaptive trainings allow improving the performance in each task by gradually increasing its difficulty, without however resorting to teaching a strategy. Strategic memory trainings permit not only to improve participants' performance in the practiced task but also to generalize the use of memory strategies to new tasks. Intending to prevent cognitive impairment, using these intervention methods in healthy aging and the prodromal phases can be useful. To this end, subjective cognitive decline (SCD) indeed represents an intermediate state between normal cognition and mild cognitive impairment (nMCD) and may predict the development of objective cognitive decline. In this frame, the primary goal of this double-blind randomized controlled trial is to assess whether the application of transcranial direct current stimulation during strategic memory training (on-line neurostimulation) enhances the effect of strategic memory training. The follow-up visits allow for investigating whether eventual improvements are preserved over time and if this combined intervention affects the evolution of cognitive decline. The treatment protocol consists of 5 sessions (2/3 session/week, 1 hour/day) of strategic memory training combined with on-line tDCS (anodic tDCS, 2mA for 20 minutes, versus sham tDCS, applied to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex - DLPFC). Healthy old participants will be recruited from the general population. Participants with subjective cognitive decline (SCD) are recruited from Neuropsychology/Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Unit and Neurorehabilitation Unit of IRCCS Mondino Foundation. The diagnosis of SCD is formulated based on a comprehensive neuropsychological evaluation (baseline cognitive assessment - T0) according to the guidelines presented in the literature. At T0, the following standardized tests are used: Global cognitive function is assessed using Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE); Cognitive reserve is assessed using Cognitive Reserve Index Questionnaire (CRIq); Mood is assessed using Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS). At T0, practiced and not practiced memory tasks (Bottiroli et al., 2013) will be administered to the participants as pre-tests: Associative learning; List learning; Name-face learning; Place learning; Text learning; Grocery learning; Participants who met the inclusion and exclusion criteria are enrolled and randomly assigned to the experimental group (strategic memory training + ACTIVE tDCS) or control group (strategic memory training + SHAM tDCS).

Objectives:
- Study the impact of the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption of sexual intercourse on sexual function using the FSFI® score.

Main objective of the study:
To evaluate the effect of time after hysterectomy on sexual function using the FSFI® score.

Secondary objective of the study:
- To describe and compare postoperative complications according to the recommended time between hysterectomy and resumption sexual intercourse. The complications studied include dyspareunia, spontaneous pain outside of sexual intercourse, metrorrhagia, infection, and vaginal fundal suture release.
- To describe the follow-up to the recommendation in terms of time to resume sexual intercourse and describe the reasons for not following the recommendation.

Study design:

- Patients operated for benign gynecological disease will be informed of the study in the days preceding the hysterectomy by information provided in the consultation room and by the investigational delegates. They will be informed of the conditions in which they are eligible for the study.
- A patient who is eligible for the study and does not refuse to participate will be registered by signing the informed consent.
- The patient will then be considered included in the study as soon as the informed consent is signed.
- The patient who is not eligible for inclusion into the study or who refuses to participate will receive the care described in the "standard care."

- The patient is then randomized into 2 groups: the group indicated to resume sexual activity after Hysterectomy from 4 weeks and the other from 8 weeks.

Study arms:
- The participant group will be divided into 2 arms: 
  o Resumption of sexual intercourse recommended 4 weeks after hysterectomy
  o Resumption of sexual intercourse recommended 8 weeks after hysterectomy

Follow-up:
- The patient will complete the FSFI® questionnaire and answer a questionnaire during their consultation 3 months after their hysterectomy.
- The results of these questionnaires are stored in the EDC (Electronic Data Capture) under a unique identifier for each subject, independent of their first name (subject identifier) or hospital number.
  o Patient characteristics (age, Body mass index, parity, indication for hysterectomy and sexual activity)
  o Surgery type
  o The FSFI® score before and after surgery (evaluation at 3 months after the hysterectomy)
  o Complications (dyspareunia, spontaneous pain outside of sexual intercourse, Metrorrhagia, infection, and vaginal fundal suture release) evaluated at 3 months after the hysterectomy

Currently, there are no preventative strategies available to protect against the debilitating effects of the age-related decline in muscle mass and function, sarcopenia. This is a major challenge facing our aging populations. One of the main causes of sarcopenia is a decrease in testosterone (Test) with age that is also linked to a number of chronic health problems, as well as the onset of sarcopenia. However, Test replacement has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, suggesting we need to identify other ways of protecting our muscles. Epigenetic modification of the genome has been proposed as a mechanism whereby the body can store, or remember, information that is essential for the correct functioning of cells and tissues. In particular, epigenetics has been proposed as a mechanism of storing information about hormones, such as Testosterone. Testosterone is a powerful hormone that is involved in muscle mass and function and has been shown to induce epigenetic modifications in mouse skeletal muscle. These epigenetic modifications include an increase in Histone H3 acetylation and a decrease in Histone H3 lysine-4 trimethylation, in conjunction with changes in gene expression.
Skeletal muscle is the largest organ in the body that can store this type of information. Research within our group has shown that resistance exercise (REX) training induces epigenetic modifications, including acetylation of histone H3 at genes that encode for myosin heavy chains, a process that has been linked to an increase in muscle mass and strength. The mechanisms linking exercise to epigenetic modifications are not fully understood, and we have not determined if REX training can ‘sustain’ the epigenetic modifications induced by exercise training. This project is a randomised, placebo-controlled, crossover trial that specifically targets the testosterone hypothesis. The study is a pilot trial focusing on 15 middle-aged men who will undergo the intervention either in isolation or whilst undertaking REX training. The primary aim of the study is to investigate whether the combined effects of Testosterone and REX training induces epigenetic modifications that are able to withstand periods of detraining. The combined effects of Testosterone and REX training will then be compared to the effects of REX training alone in the absence of the hormone. It is hypothesised that the combined effects of Testosterone and REX training will be able to induce epigenetic modification that persist beyond exercise training and that these changes will be enhanced by the combination treatment. If this occurs, muscle will have a 'memory' of the Testosterone-REX treatment and this may lead to development of long-term prevention strategies against sarcopenia.

Background: Dengue is a mosquito-borne tropical disease that is prevalent in many countries of Latin America. With the increase in travel and the development of urban spaces for human settlements, a dengue epidemic occurred in Argentina in the fall of 2018. The objective of this study is to determine the prevalence of immunity to flaviviridae in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires prior to the outbreak.
Methods: This is a cross-sectional seroprevalence survey among a representative and random sample of 1,487 persons who reside in 104 sectors belonging to 19 municipalities of the Buenos Aires Metropolitan region. The study results will be an approximation of the seroprevalance of flaviviridae, divided by age and municipality, in the area of study before the outbreak. The sample will be randomly selected from 2010 census data. Primary sampling units are the census sections of the 2010 National Census of Population, Households and Dwellings (ECPOH 2010), which have been divided into strata based on income quintile. Enumerators will use a random selection of at least two residences within each primary sampling unit, and the members of the selected households will be surveyed for inclusion within the study population. Participants will be asked for demographic data and they will donate a blood sample taken by venipuncture to be analyzed in a laboratory certified by the National Administration of Drugs, Food and Tobacco (ANMAT). Sample calculation for the study assumes the presence of individuals with previous flavivirus infection in 30% of the population, varying according to the area of reference. The sample size was calculated based on the estimated probability of pre-infection for each of the municipalities and localities participating in the survey.
Immunoglobulin G anti-flavivirus IgG antibodies will be detected by direct ELISA using recombinant dengue virus proteins, and dengue-specific IgG antibodies will be identified by plaque neutralization with a pool of four dengue virus types. Dengue-specific immunoglobulin G antibodies measured by ELISA will be confirmed by dengue type-specific plaque neutralization assay and by a plaque assay on dengue virus of each serotype. Serotyping of neutralizing antibodies will be done with a plaque neutralization test. Plaques in the sample and control dishes will be counted and the sample: control ratio will be expressed in arbitrary units. Sensitivity and specificity of antibody detection to dengue will be previously analyzed in the laboratory. Serum neutralizing antibodies to other flavivirus were also assayed by plaque neutralization assay. Antibody titers will be expressed in International Units (IU), calculated as the reciprocal of the largest dilution that neutralized the virus in the plaque assay. This study will be conducted according to the principles of the Declaration of Helsinki, the ethical guidelines set forth by ANMAT and the guidelines of the American Society of Research through Human Subjects.
Discussion: This study will be the basis for defining public health policies for this disease, since after the sero-epidemiological data is published, the national and local authorities will have indicators to predict the risk of outbreaks in the country. It will also serve as an assessment tool to evaluate the effectiveness of national and city-based dengue control strategies, such as mass vector control interventions.

Ischaemic heart disease (IHD), the incidence of which continues to rise, represents one of the key factors determining future health expenditures and is expected to become the leading cause of death, despite a reduction in cardiovascular disease mortality in the past few decades mainly due to decreasing mortality from myocardial infarction (MI). In addition, due to their multifactorial nature, patients with IHD often are prescribed several medications that might interact and increase risk of bleeding.
The risk of adverse outcomes is greatly influenced by residual inflammation and platelet reactivity, an essential component of platelet function. Atherosclerosis (the hardening of arteries caused by plaque build-up) is considered to develop from thrombotic inflammatory atherosclerosis. The activation of platelets in the presence of activated endothelium, the key driver of atherosclerosis, triggers a positive feedback mechanism. As such, platelet activation and recruitment of inflammatory cells play an essential role in the progression of atherosclerosis and its complications.
Platelet reactivity is defined by the platelet’s ability to respond to specific stimuli leading to platelet aggregation and adhesion. While aspirin inhibits platelet reactivity by up to 80%, the introduction of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) (aspirin + clopidogrel, ticagrelor or prasugrel) was developed to decrease platelet reactivity in patients with recent symptoms of Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) and/or Coronary Stent (CS)/Prosthetic Heart Valve (PHV) implantation in subjects with increased bleeding risk. This approach has proven to be very effective for reduction of mortality and myocardial infarction (MI) rates in these conditions. However, long term DAPT is associated with an increased risk of major bleeding. Thus, the benefit of DAPT has to be weighed against the harm of increased bleeding risk. Although the benefit of the currently used P2Y12 inhibitor prasugrel and ticagrelor is significantly greater than that of clopidogrel, their use continues to be associated with an increased risk of bleeding. In clinical practice, the fear of bleeding and poor drug compliance might lead to undertreatment and reduced efficacy of DAPT.
In order to reduce major adverse clinical events (MACE) and bleeding events in high bleeding risk (HBR) patients, the de-escalation of P2Y12 inhibitors was proposed to decrease the bleeding risk, maintaining good efficacy and reducing mortality and MACE rates. A meta-analysis of different randomised controlled trials (RCTs) found that clopidogrel substitution to prasugrel or ticagrelor has no impact on major adverse cardiovascular/cerebrovascular events compared to standard dose therapy. Several international guidelines recommend to use full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors for at least 9 months after recent ACS, coronary stenting or coronary artery bypass grafting.
The DESC-HBR trial will explore (for the first time) patients at HBR, treated with full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors after recent ACS. Patients with HBR may be at excessively higher bleeding risk as suggested by the PRECISE-DAPT score validated on 62,314 patients, which may lead to high rates of discontinuation of DAPT. The DESC-HBR trial aims to assess in patients with HBR after a recent ACS the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor to clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg or ticagrelor 60mg bid, on the proportion of patients with optimal platelet reactivity (OPR). The secondary objective is to explore the effect of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy on clinical events and patients' quality of life. The primary outcome is defined as a platelet reactive unit (PRU) between 85 and 208 reactivity units based on international consensus. Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) and other adverse infant outcomes are the result of maternal alcohol drinking and other substance use during pregnancy. In low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) that lack or are under-resourced for maternal and child health, there is much at stake when it comes to children's welfare. While many countries in Africa have policies that ban drinking during pregnancy, this is not translated into practice. To address this, we will adap and test a behavioural intervention to improve maternal drinking and use of other substances (especially tobacco and marijuana) during pregnancy and breastfeeding, while improving care-seeking for substance use treatment interventions. By focusing on low-income South African women, and targeting alcohol use, tobacco use, and marijuana usages separately or in different combinations of use we will be able to understand the most effective strategy to reducing their use and preventing negative outcomes in their children.
Situated in the area with the highest number of births in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, key informant interviews conducted with expectant mothers and a review of the literature will inform the design of the intervention. A sample of women will be selected from existing clinical registries and antenatal services at the research area will be approached through a community-based sampling frame. The study will use a randomized design with two arms: an intervention arm, providing contingent incentives and text-based support, and usual care arm.

The study will be recruiting people who have had a limb amputation (traumatic or atraumatic) and are experiencing chronic phantom limb pain (PLP). Participants will be asked to be seated during the study session. Non-painful peripheral stimulation will be applied to elicit a brain response. Electrodes will be placed on the scalp to record these electrical brain responses during the study session. Visual feedback based on the response will be provided in pseudo realtime. The study will involve three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Assessments of pain intensity and quality, and neurophysiological sensorimotor response, will be performed before the first session, after the last session, and at follow-up sessions. Additional electroencephalography (EEG) based assessments will also be performed as exploratory measures, to assess inter- and intra- hemispheric functional connectivity and sensorimotor responses associated with amputation and operant conditioning training.

Trauma is the major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Invasive hemodynamic monitoring is commonly used to guide fluid resuscitation and resuscitate hemodynamic disturbances. Subclavian vein catheterization is generally considered as the ideal central vein catheterization route in trauma patients because high venous pressure may be associated with complications of peripheral vein catheterization. However, complications of subclavian vein catheterization like subclavian artery puncture, pneumothorax and hemothorax may not be easily detected with bedside X-ray, which makes the choice and placement of these catheters difficult.
Axillary vein catheterization is an alternative way for resuscitation in trauma patients because the diameter and volume of axillary vein are larger. Also the arteries and veins pass through a shorter distance. If the puncture is performed by ultrasound guidance, it is possible to reduce the incidence of complications.
There are no studies on the complications of axillary vein cannulation and hemodynamic monitoring in the intensive care unit in trauma patients recently. Whether ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization could reduce the complications during the resuscitation therapy in trauma patients still needs further study.
The investigators hypothesize that ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization for CVP or hemodynamic monitoring would reduce the incidence of complications in trauma patients during the resuscitation therapy.
In this study, the investigators sought to investigate the clinical effect of this method and its value in guiding the CVC catheter placement in trauma patients.
The investigators will retrospectively collect information on all axillary vein catheterizations from the intensive care unit of Beijing Youan Hospital, from October 2021 to April 2023. The parameters investigated include placement of the catheter tip, occurrence of complications during catheterization, thromboembolism events, death rate during TICU stay, ventilator support, length of TICU stay, ICU mortality and hospital mortality. Based on the collected data, the distribution of complications in axillary vein catheterization, the predictors of complications, the reasons for catheter tip errors, and the outcomes of patients with complications will be analyzed.

Background: Patients with multiple myeloma (MM) have a disease process that does not typically involve the blood and bone marrow. Treatment is initially geared toward killing cancer cells that grow and cause an increase in specific abnormal proteins in the blood. Over time, these cancer cells may continue to grow despite treatment. A type of therapy called BCMA (B cell Maturation Antigen)-directed Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T cells has been approved as a treatment for patients with MM whose disease is no longer responsive to traditional therapies. These CAR T cells seek out cells with a specific protein marker, BCMA, and eliminate them. This type of treatment has been shown to temporarily eliminate disease in about one third of patients with relapsed or refractory MM. Cevostamab is a monoclonal antibody that is designed to block interactions between a protein on immune cells, called CD32B, and the same cancer protein, BCMA, on MM cells. By preventing these interactions, it may help kill cancer cells and stop them from returning or progressing. Objective: To see how well cevostamab helps to eliminate MM cells in people who have received a specific type of CAR T cell therapy. Eligibility: Overall, people ≥18 years of age with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (MM) who have previously received a BCMA-directed CAR T cell product are eligible for this study. Design: People who meet the inclusion criteria will be given cevostamab, which will be given once every 3 weeks, with the first day of each treatment cycle being Day 1. People will receive 8 total doses of cevostamab during this study, unless they have achieved a complete response without detectable minimal residual disease (CR+MRD-) at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy. Some people will also have a bone marrow biopsy before treatment with cevostamab to assess their disease status. People who achieved a complete response without detectable minimal residual disease (CR+MRD-) at 12 months post-CAR T cell therapy will undergo repeat bone marrow testing or imaging studies (MRI or CT scans) every 6-12 months to monitor their response to treatment and assess time to progression. People who did not achieve a complete response without detectable minimal residual disease but remain in remission for ≥1 year post-CAR T cell infusion, will be followed annually by imaging studies to monitor their response to treatment. Follow-Up: The first follow-up visit after completing the treatment regimen will be approximately 2 weeks after the last drug infusion. After that, visits will take place up to 2 years after enrollment to assess the effectiveness of the drug. During follow-up, visits will be conducted to evaluate the patient's health and check for signs of recurrence or progression. The longest patient visit will be 3 days. A bone marrow biopsy will be requested at the week 12 visit after completing ≥6 cycles of cevostamab. If a patient is in stable CR+MRD- or CR+MRD-, the following follow-up tests will be conducted every 6-12 months until progression: Blood-based tests to assess MRD status. Bone marrow biopsy for complete remission response evaluation. CT or MRI imaging studies to assess response to treatment. Additional tests may be conducted for patients who are in remission without achieving a MRD-negative status. Blood samples will also be collected at the end of each treatment cycle to monitor the immune response and the safety of cevostamab treatment before discontinuation of cevostamab.

The obesity epidemic remains a major public health problem worldwide The prevalence of overweight and obesity is increasing alarmingly, especially in industrialized countries, according to WHO reports; overnutrition, overfeeding and a lack of physical activity is causing a rapid increase of obesity and an increase risk of noncommunicable diseases.
This study aimed to investigate the effect of the combination of cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis and repetition ultrasound-guided imaging (RUSI) on core muscles function. Thirty six subjects divided into three groups; 12 subjects in the cavitation group , 12 subjects in the repetition ultrasound guided imaging (RUSI) . Both Cavitation group and RUSI group had 10 consecutive sessions twice a week for 5 weeks. And combination of cavitation and RUSI group .
In order to understand the relationship between visceral fat accumulation and core muscle functions , 16 patients divided randomly into 2 groups , cavitation group , RUSI group. All patients had abdominal ultrasound in the supine position, and had RUSI to visualize diaphragm muscle on the screen, and the patient was instructed to have 5 seconds to contract the diaphragm muscle by deep breathing and hold the contraction, and to visualize transverse abdominis muscle after a slow cough test and to have 10 seconds contraction. All these procedures were performed under the guidance of an experienced ultrasonography medical professional. After 10 repetitions, image measurement was performed to determine the increase in muscle thickness during contraction compared to the baseline. Then cavitation and RUSI were given respectively
By ultrasound imaging , it was determined that the effect of the combined application of cavitation and RUSI on core muscles was more significant than the single application , and the mean diaphragm excursion was 120% in the cavitation group and 130% in the RUSI group and 145% in the combination group.
According to this result , it is thought that the combined application of cavitation and RUSI can be evaluated as a new method for increasing core muscle functions.

Objectives: Hypothesis 1: In patients with cryptogenic ischemic stroke, there is a linear relationship between the atrial fibrosis surface area determined by Cardiac MRI with contrast and the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) during the 3-year follow-up period. Hypothesis 2: A threshold value of the atrial fibrosis surface area determined by Cardiac MRI with contrast could help to predict the occurrence of AF within 3 years in patients with cryptogenic ischemic stroke. The AF burden (duration and number of episodes) will be determined by the implantable loop recorder. To reach this objective, the protocol of the study includes a group of patients with clinical suspicion of atrial fibrillation not previously diagnosed (suspect group), another group of patients without clinical suspicion of atrial fibrillation previously diagnosed (control group), and a third group of patients with clinical suspect of atrial fibrillation, previously diagnosed (control group), and a third group of patients with clinical suspect of atrial fibrillation previously diagnosed (control group). Each group will have 40 patients. Patients with clinical suspicion of atrial fibrillation of cryptogenic ischemic stroke, previously diagnosed by a permanent electronic loop recorder will be proposed to participate to the cryptogenic group. Patients with previously diagnosed atrial fibrillation will be randomly assigned to the control group. Procedure: Patients with cryptogenic ischemic stroke will undergo Cardiac MRI with contrast to determine the atrial fibrosis surface area. During this examination, blood samples will be taken in order to characterize parameters of renal function and other biomarkers predicting atrial fibrosis (MicroRNAs, C-reactive protein). The blood sample and the Cardiac MRI dataset will be stored for future biological analyzes. An implantable electronic loop recorder will be implanted within one week of the stroke and patients will be given anti-coagulation treatment according to international guidelines for long-term anticoagulation. Patients presenting AF episodes during the 3-year follow-up will be followed and if clinically relevant, will require a heart rhythm correction procedure and appropriate anticoagulation treatment. Patients without AF or with unobserved AF episodes during the 3-year follow-up will also be followed but no heart rhythm correction procedure will be proposed. Study population: The target population is patients with cryptogenic ischemic stroke, cryptogenic stroke is defined as neurologic symptoms with radiographic evidence of stroke that do not conform to one of the standard classifications (atherosclerotic or cardioembolic). Patients are referred to implantation of an implantable electronic loop recorder for diagnostic purposes. Patients with clinical suspicion of AF and cryptogenic ischemic stroke will be proposed to enroll to this study. The hypothesis to evaluate is whether a given atrial fibrosis surface area threshold defined by Cardiac MRI with contrast will lead to occurrence of AF, after 3 years of follow-up, independent of the patient characteristics. Sample size : for each group of patients, a sample of 40 patients will be enrolled. Patients who will provide informed consent will benefit from Cardiac MRI with contrast and will enroll into the suspect group (30 patients) or control group (10 patients). An Implantable electronic loop recorder will be implanted within one week of the stroke and patients will be given anti-coagulation treatment according to international guidelines for long-term anticoagulation. Stroke patients with atrial fibrillation of cryptogenic origin will be invited to enlarge the cryptogenic group to 40 patients. Patients with previously diagnosed atrial fibrillation will be randomly assigned to the control group.

The subjects have to be premenopausal or perimenopausal and are not allowed to receive any systemic chemotherapy for their locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer. The RecuR Score is a novel risk score developed at the University of Maryland Medical System (UMMS), that estimates the probability of 30-day unplanned hospital readmission for inpatients and patients in the Emergency Department (ED) at various UMMS hospitals. It is derived using claims data, laboratory data, Electronic Health Record (EHR) data, and sociodemographic information, but excludes race or insurance type from the calculation. The score is calculated in Epic, and the target population includes any inpatients, currently in-house ED patients who may become inpatients, and previous inpatients within the previous 30 days of discharge. Higher RecuR Scores indicate a higher probability of unplanned hospital readmission based on RecuR Score of the patient. A comparison of the performance of the RecuR Score, using a dataset that contains a mixture of Epic and Claims data, compared to two existing risk scores, LACE and HOSPITAL, showed that the RecuR Score was the most accurate at 48 hours post-arrival. It is known to work best during and immediately after the index admission for which the RecuR Score is calculated. The study objective is to identify patients at a higher risk of unplanned hospital readmission and then apply enhanced peri- and post-discharge care interventions to assess the impact on readmissions at UM CRMC. The interventions being tested include, use of a handheld digital device (iPad) or a physical patient education manual in lieu of a printed handout to educate patients about their medical conditions and medications, and a focus on the patient's RecuR Score during multidisciplinary team rounds. The study will also evaluate potential interventions offered through the Hospital's Readmission Prevention Program, such as home health visitation from Home Health Services (HHS), Mobile Integrated Healthcare (MIH), or Resources, Education and Access to Community Health (REACH).
Hospital readmission is a quality measure that measures the proportion of patients discharged from the hospital that is readmitted either to any hospital or the index hospital. Healthcare providers are financially penalized for repeat hospital admissions for the same episode of care, also known as episodes of hospitalization, within 30 days. Healthcare providers are notified of their year-over-year readmission rates for different diagnoses and conditions via an online dashboard called the Readmission Reduction Program (RRP) Dashboard. The Hospital at UM CRMC has one of the longest running transitional care programs in Maryland, called the Transitional Nurse Navigator (TNN) program, that provides assistance with medication reconciliation, home health education, scheduling of follow-up appointments, and community resource training on an individual patient basis. The TNN program has been relatively successful in lowering the hospital's 30-day unplanned hospital readmission rate. Despite the reduction in readmissions, the Hospital's overall readmission rate at UM CRMC and its associated financial penalties continue to decrease incrementally, from 1.5% in 2010 to 1.0% in 2016. Therefore, the Hospital has developed the Readmission Prevention Program (RPP) using a quality improvement (QI) framework that focuses on prevention of unplanned hospital readmissions. The goal is to implement the most effective interventions to provide patient-centered care that supports patients and their families in understanding their diagnosis, medications, and medical treatment, to make sure that patients receive appropriate care at the correct location, and to help reduce the burden of unplanned hospital readmissions.
If the Hospital is implementing an intervention, such as using nurse navigators, to support a patient population at higher risk of readmissions, it is important to compare the outcomes of patients who already receive this intervention (current approach) to those who receive additional resources. This study will look for an additional 30% reduction of 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions in the treatment group. There will be two study arms. The first arm will be the Standard of Care arm which will represent the status quo at the Hospital. The second arm will be the Enhanced Care arm where nurse navigators will receive additional training and education, and patients will receive expanded education and follow-up visits, and care coordinated through additional community resources such as, home health visitation from Home Health Services (HHS), Mobile Integrating Healthcare (MIH), or Resources, Education and Access to Community Health (REACH) to potentially lower the rate of readmissions in this high-risk patient population. All enrolled participants will receive the standard of care, regardless of study arm.

Worldwide more than approximately 500 million people suffer from AR (30% of the Dutch population) and its prevalence is expanding. Nasal congestion (i.e. reversible mucosal congestion/nasal mucosal obstruction) is one of the most general and bothersome symptoms in rhinitis and is associated with other medical conditions such as rhinosinusitis and otitis media.
This study is relevant as in addition to the high global occurrence of AR, this disorder has substantial effects on the quality of life (QOL) (e.g. during sleep and work). AR is related to high direct medical costs (mainly prescription of medications and outpatient visits) and indirect economic costs (including productivity decrease). Current medications are undesirable due to their side-effects (such as sedation in the case of intranasal antihistamines (INAH)). Acupuncture for AR in general can be considered as safe and can be seen as a potential remedial blueprint for nasal congestion. Evidence supported that acupuncture is clinically used for signs and symptoms of nose disorders, such as nasal congestion, with effectiveness, but whether acupuncture has immediate, post-treatment and long-term effects on specifically nasal congestion in AR is not verified by strictly designed clinical study. The ANCAR trial aims to evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in AR compare to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). A standard treatment protocol with a fixed set of acupuncture points has been established - to be as scientific as possible from Western medical viewpoint - and this selection of acupuncture points can be seen as a solid and profound approach from which every AR patient may benefit. This standard set opens the nose and affects the underlying energetic imbalance and immunity at the same time to maintain its nose opening effect (i.e. to prevent recurrence of the complaint). The acupuncture protocol concerns 8 treatments during 6 weeks (i.e. 2 treatments per week during the first 2 weeks and 1 treatment per week in the consecutive 4 weeks). The positive effects of this treatment protocol (such as improvement QOL) may result in more confidence in the direct, post-treatment and long-term effects of acupuncture and lead to more acceptance of acupuncture as a solid treatment option for nasal congestion in AR instead of using an INAH spray. Hypothesis: Acupuncture will improve nasal congestion in AR compare to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). Objective: To evaluate the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in AR.

Interest in the effects of cold exposure on the brain has developed dramatically in recent years. One of the most promising results reported since the mid-1990s is that mild cold exposure can improve mood. Although mood improvements have proven difficult to replicate, they have nonetheless been observed in a number of laboratory trials, as well as in two large scale field studies. In the present proposal, we would use neuroimaging (functional MRI) to investigate the neural underpinnings of these improvements, and to assess how these improvements compare to the improvements that typically follow exercise-based treatments for depression. Our central hypothesis is that cold exposure will lead to measurable improvements in mood, with these improvements being linked with activation in the basolateral amygdala, an area strongly implicated in processing emotional stimuli such as those associated with negative affect. We further hypothesize that the extent of the cold effect on mood will depend on the extent of activation in the basolateral amygdala. This proposal will represent the first direct investigation of the relationship between changes in body temperature and the neural underpinnings of mood, with potentially important implications for basic understanding of mechanisms linking the body with the brain, as well as potential clinical applications in the context of novel therapies for depression, anorexia nervosa, and other eating disorders.
Participants to be studied include 30 men and women with subthreshold symptoms of depression and anxiety, randomly drawn from undergraduates enrolled in introductory psychology courses at University at Buffalo, State University of New York at Buffalo.
The following study procedures will be utilized: Subjects will participate in six sessions to be conducted during a two-week interval. In session #1, subjects will complete online questionnaires assessing depression symptoms, general anxiety, physical health and physical complaints of depression symptoms, as well as complete medical and drug history questionnaires. In session #2, we will administer the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV, Axis I Disorders to confirm our subjects have no present diagnosis of major depression, and perform a cardiovascular fitness exercise tolerance test, a urine drug screen, and saliva collection for genetic studies. In session #3, we will collect fMRI measures while subjects passively view a series of images eliciting distress and pain. In session #4, we will assess the impact of moderate cold exposure on mood and functional magnetic resonance imaging neural activity. In session #5, we will assess the impact of an acute increase in body temperature on mood and neural activity. In session #6, we will have a follow-up interview to clarify mood ratings assessed at home following sessions #4 and #5.

This is a retrospective study of a total of 990 cycles of insemination and IVF in women 18 to 42 years of age without any indication of polycystic ovaries or chronic abnormal ovarian function.
The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of the starting dose for Follitropin Delta in a mixed protocol, including both hCG and HP-hMG, in the evaluation of the IVF cycle from the perspective of the number of oocytes, fertilization rate, embryonic development, blastocyst formation, and implantation.
This retrospective study consisted of three sub studies.
Study 1: Follitropin Delta plus HP-hMG: 809 cycles of insemination and 181 cycles of IVF.
Study 2: Follitropin Delta plus hCG: 62 cycles of insemination and 56 cycles of IVF.
Study 3: Follitropin Delta and hCG: 182 cycles of insemination.
For all cycles where only one protocol is used, a maximum of 3 cycles with the same protocol is authorized to be selected, according to the number of cycles from which there is more than 8 weeks of data available, based on the criteria established by the CIOMS (WHO / ICMJE) scale. In the case of cycles of a different procedure, the data from a maximum of 2 cycles of the same protocol will be analyzed, but each patient may only be present in the database with a maximum of 8 weeks of follow-up (for the number of oocytes and good quality blastocysts).
In Study 1 an hCG-based dose was used for Follitropin Delta (starting dose), with the dosages being increased to cover for the individual inter-individual difference in sensitivity. Serum LH will be monitored and, at the discretion of the doctor, hCG will be added. In Study 2 a combination of Follitropin Delta and hCG at different doses to cover the individual inter-individual difference in sensitivity. Serum LH will be monitored and, at the discretion of the doctor, HP-hMG will be added. In Study 3 HP-hMG will be used for ovarian stimulation and serum LH will be monitored to evaluate the effectiveness of Follitropin Delta at different fixed doses according to AMH values and body weight, ranging from 150 IU to 300 IU, with 50 IU increments.
The effectiveness of the starting dose is measured by the number of good quality blastocysts.
The main hypothesis is that there is no difference between these protocols in terms of the number of good quality blastocysts, since the effectiveness of the dose used for ovarian stimulation did not differ from the hCG-HP-hMG dose used as a control.

Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) are chronic disorders characterized by alternating periods of remission and exacerbation, with periods of clinical relapse occurring frequently. IBD patients often need to attend several visits to their local hospital. Additionally, the symptoms of the disease cause substantial disturbances in the quality of life. The symptoms of IBD are characterized by pain, diarrhea, bloating, and fatigue. These symptoms cause substantial emotional distress and negatively impact patients' ability to work, socialize and carry out daily activities.
The aim of the study is to evaluate the effect of a telemonitoring intervention in patients with IBD on the quality of life, remission rates, number of adverse drug reactions, health-related expenditures, and the frequency of outpatient visits, hospitalizations and surgical interventions.
The outcome will be compared between patients with IBD who were monitored through a newly developed telemedical platform and patients with IBD who were monitored using standard face-to-face interventions. Based on the results of the research, the authors intend to create a universal software product with an online interface for a web platform, which can be integrated into the information systems of medical institutions and will allow monitoring the dynamics of IBD and support decision-making on the further treatment of patients with IBD.

A total of 432 participants will be randomised into this multicenter international randomised trial. After progression of their disease on first-line SSA treatment, patients with locally advanced or metastatic neuroendocrine tumours (NET) will continue (on or off SSA treatment, according to local policy) or alternatively discontinue their SSA treatment for a duration of 18 months. For pragmatic reasons, treatment decisions will be based solely on the local clinician's decision. The participants will then be crossed to a central imaging review committee, blinded for allocated regimen, to estimate objective responses according to RECIST criteria. The secondary objective is to demonstrate non-inferiority in objective tumour response in the subgroup of patients continuing SSA treatment.
An important secondary objective is the evaluation of costs (for health care providers) and quality of life.
This trial will provide evidence for future policy on the appropriate management of patients with progressive G1/Gr2 non-functional neuroendocrine tumors upon discontinuation of SSA treatment. The design of this trial is pragmatic to reflect future clinical practice and enhance generalisability of the results, and is also of importance in case a treatment beyond the standard option is being considered for patients. We will be able to explore the economic impact of extending or stopping SSA treatment after progression.

The investigators propose that improving socialization experiences in the preschool classroom for children with language delay through a peer mediated intervention will disrupt the social exclusion of targeted children, leading to improved growth patterns for the core language delays of 3-5 year olds at risk for further language and literacy delays in elementary school. Specifically, this randomized controlled trial (RCT) focuses on 25 preschool classrooms, with 12 classrooms randomized to the experimental group and 13 classrooms randomized to a control group. Children identified as most excluded from the classroom social network through social network matrices are selected as focal children, and the peer-mediated intervention is implemented by a classroom facilitator-a teacher or teaching assistant who works in the classroom daily. Focal children in the experimental group receive peer-mediated pivotal response training from the teacher who is randomized to this assignment, and focal children in the control group continue as usual. The goal is to recruit 65 children from 25 childcare centers, inclusive preschools, or pre-kindergarten classrooms within one geographical area. Research staff observe each focal child in the classroom setting for a 9-month period, including 4 play interactions observations and 4 peer interaction observations per focal child. Researchers will also record auditory and linguistic communication with an audio detector or device. This audio data will be transcribed, and the amount of incoming talk will be calculated for each focal child. The primary outcome variables will be: (a) changes in auditory comprehension and expressive language skills, as measured by the Preschool Language Screener 5; (b) changes in pragmatic language skills, as measured by the Developmental Pragmatic Profile; (c) changes in teacher perceptions of social/behavioral competencies, as measured by the Teacher Checklist Rating Scales; and (d) changes in focal children's social/behavioral competencies, as measured by the Peer Assessment Scale. Results from this study have the potential to accelerate social and linguistic growth in children with language delay, as well as inform school-based prevention programs, including strategies for implementing peer-mediated interventions and training protocols.

There is strong evidence that physical therapy can improve mobility-related function in people with MS, and emerging evidence that motor-relearning approaches to rehabilitation may be associated with changes in brain structure and function that correlate with improvements in functional performance. The leading pharmacological intervention for walking-related deficits in people with MS is dalfampridine. Dalfampridine improves motor function by increasing nerve conduction through demyelinated axons, however, dalfampridine alone is not likely to generate neuroplastic changes needed for lasting benefits, because neural plasticity requires salient and task-specific practice with high repetition at adequate intensity, as well as complex environments that stimulate opportunities for movement to facilitate synthesis of neurotrophic factors. Indeed, the treatment effects of dalfampridine are reversed as soon as the treatment was discontinued. However, it is possible that improved nerve conduction velocity provided by dalfampridine may accelerate neuroplasticity generated from rehabilitation. Yet, combining dalfampridine with concurrent rehabilitation has never been studied. The objective of this study is to test our central hypothesis that providing a motor-relearning physical therapy intervention in combination with dalfampridine will produce superior gains to either intervention alone in mobility through augmented neuroplasticity.

Investigators wanted to study how CLEFT-Q works with patients who have had secondary surgery to improve speech and also with patients who has surgery on the lip, jaw, nose or to change the opening between mouth and nose.

Cerebrovascular autoregulation is an important protective mechanism that maintains a constant and adequate blood supply to the brain, and an equally important cerebral reserve capacity, able to rapidly increase brain blood flow in the event of a sudden fall in blood pressure. Several conditions common during general anesthesia (general hypoventilation or hypotension) increase the risk of impaired cerebrovascular autoregulation and thus may cause organ dysfunction and complications during surgery. The main objective of this study is to better characterize this protective mechanism by identifying patients at risk of a reduced perfusion reserve and predict the risk of complications by assessing the sensitivity of the monitoring used during general anesthesia for surgery. In addition, new non-invasive monitoring methods that are easy to use and offer great potential by providing complementary information to the clinician about the patient's physiological state will be implemented. The use of these monitoring tools during surgery will also make it possible to predict the risk of complications in cardiovascular patients, the elderly and pregnant women.

Introduction: Small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor with a median survival of < 1 year due to metastatic potential and the rapid development of chemoresistance. At present, the chemotherapy regimen of platinum plus etoposide ± thoracic radiotherapy has been considered as the standard treatment, however, the response rate and prognosis of this treatment regimen are not ideal. With the advent of immunotherapy, immunotherapy combined with chemotherapy has become a new treatment regimen for SCLC. Currently, immunotherapy is also used as the first-line treatment strategy for extensive small cell lung cancer .
Serplulimab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against PD-L1. Studies have shown that serplulimab combined with chemotherapy has a higher objective response rate and a longer time to progression (TTP) compared with chemotherapy alone . However, due to the heterogeneity (subtype) of SCLC, it is important to assess the clinical response and the impact of immunotherapy on tumor progression and the immune microenvironment in SCLC patients undergoing first-line immunotherapy. Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) is defined as a small number of intact individual tumor cells/nests, which cannot be detected by conventional imaging criteria during remission, but can be detected by laboratory methods. MRD can predict the response of tumors to treatment and can be used as early indicators of disease control and treatment efficacy . 
This prospective single arm cohort study will include adult subjects aged ≥ 18 years with newly diagnosed and previously untreated subjects diagnosed with extensive small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). All subjects in the study will receive serplulimab combined with etoposide plus cisplatin or carboplatin as first-line treatment. To comprehensively evaluate the clinical benefits of PD-L1 immunotherapy against SCLC, circulating MRD testing will be performed before treatment, after 2 cycles of treatment, after 6 cycles of treatment, 6 months after the end of chemotherapy, and 1 year after the end of chemotherapy. The long-term efficacy and safety of PD-L1 inhibitor combined with traditional chemotherapy can be comprehensively revealed, and the MRD test can reflect the depth of remission, evaluate the control efficacy and treatment efficiency.

The lack of regular heart-healthy physical activity is an important risk factor associated with impaired cardiac rehabilitation outcomes, including recurrence of cardiac events. While cardiac rehabilitation programs are effective at promoting activity, this behavior change is largely lost to follow and after discharge from cardiac rehabilitation. The present project ACTIVE-CaRe intends to design, implement, and evaluation of a digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy physical activity of cardiac rehabilitation patients following completion of the intervention. The design and development of a digital application called aktivplan are based on the ACTIVE principles, integrating principles from behavioral sciences (e.g., self-efficacy, self-regulation, motivation, and user experience).

This study will test whether nasal oxytocin improves social behavior and reduces repetitive behavior in youth with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). 22 male or female youths with ASD will receive either 24 international units of oxytocin (Ox) or a placebo (placebo) twice daily for four weeks in a double-blind, randomized, cross-over design. The dose and dosing regimen are based on our previous trial which showed a beneficial effect of the same dose on behavioral inflexibility, social behavior, repetitive behavior and repetitive cognition in male adults with ASD and an effect of a similar dose range on behavior in ASD compared to controls. We will evaluate both primary (social behavior and repetitive behavior) and secondary (behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, vagally-mediated cardiac autonomic function) outcomes using questionnaires, behavioral tasks and ECG.

Background:
Neonatal complications are of paramount importance, especially for those born before 37 weeks (preterm neonates), whose number is increasing in recent years in our country. As a consequence of their prematurity these neonates are at risk of many pathologies, mainly digestive problems (gastric reflux or malabsorption), that will lead them to abdominal complications. The intensive care unit of Clermont-Ferrand University hospital proposes the evaluation of newborns in order to optimize clinical decision-making.
Objectives:
To create a clinical evaluation scale of the premature baby's abdominal condition (ECAP) by a multidisciplinary neonatal committee (physician, physiotherapist and nurse). To validate the ECAP scale and to evaluate its use in clinical practice, in order to propose, if necessary massages whose interest has been demonstrated.
Methods:
It's an observational study with longitudinal follow-up regarding validation of the ECAP scale.
Inclusion: 70 Premature babies (≤37 weeks of amenorrhea) hospitalized in neonatal intensive care units and born in Clermont - Ferrand University hospital will be included and evaluated during 21 days.
The ECAP assessment consists in: 
1st evaluation: the evaluation will be performed between the 3rd day of life and the 21st day by the nurse of the neonatal ward. The aim is to record, in a standardized way, abdominal findings (abdomen, periumbilical and anal areas) encountered for this premature infant
2nd evaluation: on the 20nd day, it is necessary to perform an evaluation of the abdominal massage. The investigators aim to make this evaluation in a standardized manner and to check that the abdominal massage allows an improvement and/or resolution of abdominal pathology encountered in the first evaluation
3rd evaluation: the abdominal massage is also evaluated. The investigators aim to make this evaluation in a standardized manner and to check that the abdominal massage allows an improvement and / or resolution of abdominal pathology encountered in the first evaluation.
Evaluation of the first evaluation: the aim is to validate the ECAP scale developed by the panel of experts proposed in the ECAP standardization protocol (for prematurity) in France and Belgium. This evaluation corresponds to an evaluation on all parameters described in the ECAP standardization protocol (for prematurity) in infants born under 37 weeks of amenorrhea.
Evaluation of the second and third evaluations: it corresponds to a comparison between the preterm infant's abdominal condition at the first evaluation by the ECAP scale (ECAP score ) and at the last evaluation (ECAP+/- massage score ) by the ECAP scale in preterms with the abdominal massage and without the abdominal massage for the comparison group (the abdominal massage is indicated based on the score of Clinical Abdominal assessment scale for Premature infants, at the first evaluation by the ECAP scale).
The investigators aim to do an evaluation in which the ECAP score and its evolution during the time will be the same whatever the abdominal massage or its absence. The aim is to improve the care of preterms by proposing only the medical indication of an abdominal massage if necessary.
Assessor:
1. First assessor: the physician, nurse or physiotherapy assistant who performs the evaluation of the ECAP scale. 
2. Second assessor: the other member of the nursing team who will do the same evaluation. 
3. Third assessor: the other member of the nursing team who will do the same evaluation. 

Official Title: Creation and Validation of a Clinical Evaluation Scale for Abdominal Condition of the Premature

<|assistant|> Study Overview ================= The prevalence of persistent pain (PP) continues to rise in the United States, making it the most frequent reason for physician visits and the leading cause of disability, which is the biggest barrier to participation in clinical trials and care for other illnesses. PP is highly prevalent among minority patients, women, people with obesity, and those with a low socio-economic status. These disparities in PP are due to a variety of factors including lack of access to care and inequalities in pain treatment. The lack of access and treatment for PP creates an unmet need in the United States that needs to be addressed through innovative and cost-effective pain treatment approaches. Pain self-management is essential in managing the burden of PP, but access to it is disproportionately low among marginalized communities. Furthermore, research supports that providing education and skills training in self-management can increase participants' ability to improve their pain and function. Addressing these disparities in pain care requires nurses to lead the way in advocacy, education and access for marginalized communities. Nurses are at the forefront of health care delivery and are in a unique position to deliver pain management programs to patients within primary care practices and community settings. However, few programs have been tested whether nurses can deliver pain management programs. These barriers and disparities need to be addressed to reduce the burden of pain in patients at risk for unmet pain needs. The goal of the study is to test a cost-effective and scalable approach to providing education and skills training that can reduce pain and improve function in patients with persistent pain. This pilot study will conduct a randomized controlled trial to compare a scalable nurse-led pain education and skill training program with usual care for participants presenting with PP in primary care and community nursing settings. It will be tested in an underserved adult population in which there are disparities in access to pain care. The long-term goal of our research is to improve pain communication. Our study focuses on patients with chronic pain, the health care nurses assessing their pain, and patient-reported health indicators. We will address two objectives in this study: objective 1) compare pain intensity rating scales in terms of their perceived mental effort, and objective 2) compare patient- and nurse-reported perceptions of the mental effort required to understand or describe a variety of ratings based on pain in a muscle.

Objective 1: This objective addresses our first aim, which is to compare the mental effort of choosing and understanding different pain intensity rating scales. The scale type can be categorized as worst pain you have ever felt versus worst pain you can think of; using a scale over a shorter time frame versus a longer time period, and assessing pain across multiple body areas versus concentrating on one area. Aim 1a: Compare the mental effort perceived by choosing pain intensity ratings using the worst pain you have ever felt versus the worst pain you can think of scales, using a 1-month versus 7-day recall period, and assessing pain in one body area versus across multiple body areas. Aim 1b: Compare the mental effort perceived by understanding pain intensity ratings using the worst pain you have ever felt versus the worst pain you can think of scales, using a 1-month versus 7-day recall period, and assessing pain in one body area versus across multiple body areas. The study aims to compare pain intensity scales on the amount of mental energy required for each type of scale on these characteristics.

Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is a treatment method for patients with hematological malignancy. The most important outcome indicators of the treatment are the hematopoietic recovery speed after transplantation and the incidence of severe adverse reactions.
There are many factors that can affect hematological recovery and adverse events after transplantation. Previous studies have shown that the speed of hematopoietic recovery after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is affected by a variety of factors. At present, the main clinical treatment method for accelerating blood recovery after transplantation is immunosuppressive chemotherapy therapy (PFG). In recent years, research on the role of exogenous stem cells in improving hematopoietic recovery after transplantation has made significant progress. 
The investigators believe that mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have immunosuppressive properties and can promote early hematopoietic recovery in patients undergoing bone marrow transplantation, and can inhibit or alleviate the occurrence of complications of a variety of organ damage. In this study, the investigators try to clarify the mechanism of MSCs immunomodulation in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and explore the role of MSCs in the treatment of poor graft function after transplantation. This will provide a theoretical basis for the role and function of MSCs in regulating allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.
