The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness of the Quit Genius-Alcohol application for Alcohol Use Disorder. Participants will be randomized into two groups. Participants assigned to the experimental group will receive monthly appointments with a medical provider who, upon evaluation of each participant for appropriateness for pharmacotherapy, will order the prescription of oral naltrexone with the option to refill up to 90 days after the initial prescription. The mobile application will provide participants with CBT-based support. Participants assigned to the active comparator (control) group will receive the same medical management but no adjunctive digital support. The study will utilize a longitudinal design with follow-up assessments at 15 days, 3 months, and 12 months.

The disease burden and patient pain associated with pancreatic cancer has risen to a level that is now the sixth leading cause of cancer death in the United States with a dismal 5-year survival of 5%. For most patients, metastatic pancreatic cancer is diagnosed too late in the disease course to resect; therefore, chemotherapy is the mainstay of therapy. The current standard of care is a combination of three chemotherapy agents (gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel + 5-Fluorouracil). Even with a response rate of more than 55 %, the median overall survival remains just 4.9 months, with 50 % of patients alive at 1 year compared with 15 % at 2 years. As patients progress through and beyond first-line therapy, there is no known way to stop relapse of the cancer or to halt it from progressing.
Investigators propose to test the combination of botensilimab (CTLA-4, an Fc-engineered anti-CTLA-4 monoclonal antibody), balstilimab (PD-1, a human monoclonal IgG4 antibody that inhibits PD-1 binding by PD-L1 and PD-L2), celecoxib (COX-2, a cancer suppressor), and chloroquine (CQ, an anti-malarial agent). This treatment combination is predicted to cause an increase in the levels of anti-tumor cells to be able to combat cancer cells with three key mechanisms that are thought to be associated with pancreatic cancer: 1) increased ER stress, 2) inhibition of anti-apoptotic gene BCL-2 (B-cell lymphoma 2) that prevents cell death, and 3) autophagy, or a process within a cell by which the cell destroys itself to survive the damage done by cytotoxic drugs.

In this study, we compare clinical pregnancy and live birth rates of Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) in substituted and natural cycles.

Frozen embryo transfer (FET) is a well-established assisted reproductive technology (ART) technique for patients undergoing IVF treatments. The endometrial cycle can be substituted to synchronize with the frozen embryo development. However, natural cycle FET (NC FET) is more advantageous due to its simple preparation without administering exogenous hormonal agents and its less costly and less complicated procedure.

The aim of this study is to compare clinical pregnancy and live birth rates between substituted FET (sfFET) and natural cycle FET (ncFET).
In a substituted cycle, estrogen and progesterone are given and a transfer is planned when the endometrium is ready (usually 3-4 days before ovulation). In ncFET, no hormones are given, and the transfer is planned when there is a dominant follicle apparent at the ultrasound (usually up to 14 days after last menstrual period).

Cryopreserved embryos may be used to attempt to establish pregnancy in an additional method of infertility treatment, i.e.., Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET), which has a considerably lower cumulative ongoing pregnancy rate than a first cycle in a fresh cycle, despite of the higher cumulative ongoing pregnancy rates of the 2nd or 3rd cycle (approximately 30%).

The present study compares pregnancy and live birth rates of NC FET and sfFET in selected cases according to embryo implantation potential by comparing day 5/6 blastocyst rates, in order to assess the usefulness of NC FET regarding the increased risk of failed stimulated cycles with high grade embryos (5/6 grade) transferred.

Natural cycle FET (NC FET) will be compared with substituted cycle FET (sfFET). This could lead to an increase of clinical ongoing pregnancy rate.

Inclusion criteria: age < 40 years old, Women having undergone either a frozen embryo transfer in natural cycle or substituted cycle IVF and FET cycles performed at Clinique OVO, excluding patients with egg or embryo recipient, history of recurrent miscarriages, defined as ≥ 3 consecutive losses, patient that needed Viagra, Plasma-Rich Platelet (PRP) or other modalities to improve their endometrial thickness, uterine abnormalities, abnormal hormonal profiles, FET stimulated cycles, history of recurrent implantation failure.

The design is a retrospective cohort study.

The endpoints will be clinical pregnancy and live birth rates. The primary endpoint will be clinical pregnancy, defined as the presence of fetal heartbeat at the viability ultrasound, while the secondary endpoint will be live birth rates.

FET cryopreserved embryo thawing, preparation and transfer will be monitored by a specially trained nurse. After the FET, embryo implantations and pregnancy rates will be followed. The ongoing clinical pregnancy will follow embryo implantation, the miscarriages will follow the outcome and the live birth will follow the neonatal outcome. Statistical Analysis: The demographic and outcome data will be collected and tabulated and Chi squred analysis will be performed to compare the 2 groups of embryo implantation potential.

Furthermore, it is important to know the clinical pregnancy and live birth rates.

Aim 1: Determine the effects of intravenous vs. inhalational anesthesia on incidence of postoperative delirium and postoperative cognitive dysfunction in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery.
1. Hypothesis 1 - Intravenous anesthesia is associated with a lower incidence of POD and POCD compared to inhalational anesthesia.
2. Primary outcomes: Incidence of postoperative delirium and postoperative cognitive dysfunction
3. Secondary outcomes: delirium severity, delirium duration

Aim 2: Determine the effects of intravenous vs. inhalational anesthesia on incidence of postoperative functional decline and patient-reported outcomes in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery.
1. Hypothesis 2 - Intravenous anesthesia is associated with a lower incidence of postoperative functional decline and improved patient-reported outcomes (PROs) compared to inhalational anesthesia.
2. Primary outcomes: Incidence of postoperative functional decline; patient-reported outcome scores

Aim 3: Determine the effects of intravenous vs. inhalational anesthesia on blood phosphorylated tau 181 (p-tau181) and other blood biomarkers in older adults undergoing non-cardiac surgery.
1. Hypothesis 3a - Elevated preop blood p-tau181 is associated with increased POD and POCD
2. Hypothesis 3b - Postoperative increase in blood p-tau181 is greater with GAS relative to IV
3. Hypothesis 3c - Postop increases in blood biomarkers of neuroinflammation and AD pathology are greater with GAS relative to IV
4. Primary outcomes: preoperative levels of blood p-tau181 and change in levels from preoperative baseline to postoperative.
5. Secondary outcomes: Other candidate biomarkers include those previously implicated in POD or POCD: p-tau217, Aβ,54 NF-L,60 S100β,76 interleukin (IL-6),58 IL-1β,22 IL-10,46 tumor necrosis factor (TNF-α),22 CCL2,62 and glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).77. The study will assess blood biomarkers, cognitive function, and delirium after anesthesia with IV or GAS for a median of1 year.

Background: Children with congenital heart disease (CHD) are always suffering from nutritional deficiency that may affect their growth and weight. It is important to identify the prevalence of undernutrition and the causes in these children. A standardized pediatric care system is not available in Egypt. To the best of our knowledge, there has no published work from Egypt about the effect of nutritional management on growth and nutritional status in the infants affected by CHD. 
The objective of this study: To determine the prevalence of undernutrition and the cause from the Egyptian Egyptian sample. 
Objective is to assess the nutritional status and the nutritional cause of undernutrition in children affected by CHD and to determine the effect of nutritional management on growth and the nutritional status of these children. 
Hypothesis: There is a significant effect of nutritional management on the nutritional status and growth in Congenital heart disease in Egypt. 
Method: This is a descriptive study on children with CHD; The study will include 222 children (111 males and 111 females) aged more than one month and till age of 18 years that present to Assiut University Hospital Units with Cyanotic and ACyanotic Congenital heart disease. The diagnosis will be confirmed by preoperative and postoperative echocardiogram. Children with comorbidities other than congenital heart disease will excluded from our study. Full history taking includes date of birth,gender,residence,and socioeconomic status. According To Socioeconomic status we will ask about where the family live,family income (high or middle or low income) Perinatal history as maternal age,gestational diseases,medications use during pregnancy,irradiation exposure ,presence of antenatal care. Natal hisrory ;mode of delivery(vainal,cesarean) ,site of delivery (home,hospital) Post natal history; required resuscitation or not,cyanosis,jaundice and incubator care needed or not,birth weight will be categorized into appropriate ,small or large for gestational age. Feeding history; breast or formula feeding,age of weaning ,type of food for weaning, supplementation of vitamin D.iron. All patients will subject to general and systemic examination. Children included in our study will fall under Complete general and systemic examination especially heart disease. Nutritional assessment and anthropometric measures will be followed up to these patients; AThe weight ; will be taken on a scale that has been properly calibrated and the value will be plotted on a standardized WHO growth chart . B)The height ; this measurement for children more than 2years will be taken without shoes using astadiometer and the value will be plotted on the WHO growth chart. C)The length; this measurement in children 2 years and younger is more accurate ,the child will position in supine on ameasuring board. D)Head circumference; will be measured using a flexible tabe ,we will measure the maximum diameter through the supraorbital ridge to the occiput and the value will be plotted on the growth chart. E)Mid arm circumference; this measured using a flexible nonstretch tape laid at the midpoint between the acromion and olecranonprocesses on the shoulder blade and the ulna respectively. F) BMI: Measured by the person's weight divided by the square of height in meters for children aged more than 2years and will be plotted at the WHO growth chart.

<|assistant|> This study will evaluate safety of resection of infiltrating glioblastoma (GB) based on pre-operative imaging. We have found using high resolution MRI, specifically amine chemical exchange saturation transfer (microscopic CEST), an abnormal pH in Glioblastoma. Using this technology, we have shown that 1) high pH is associated with decreased PFS, and 2) resection of these pH abnormalities results in maximal safe resection and increased survival in our initial case series with no significant surgical complications (NCT01777570). We hypothesize that maximal safe resection of infiltrating glioblastoma based on microscopic pH will minimize the post-operative tumor cell burden and allow for increased survival. Furthermore, we hypothesize that this resection will be safe, with similar frequency of complication as the standard of care resection strategy. In order to test our hypothesis, we will conduct a prospective, randomized controlled trial of surgical resection of glioblastoma with microscopic pH (ME). This will consist of two study arms. All patients will have standard of care resection. One group will receive an experimental CEST+ME resection (surgery), and one group will receive standard of care resection without CEST+ME resection. Both groups will have standard of care adjuvant therapy (temozolomide + radiation therapy). We will compare the primary endpoint of progression free survival and secondary endpoints of overall survival, surgical complication rates and quality of life metrics with 1) no intervention and 2) standard of care only (No intervention arm) to assess if maximal safe resection based on microscopic pH improves outcomes compared to standard of care only. All analysis will be conducted on an intention-to-treat basis. Urinary Bladder Cancer (UBC) is a leading cause of cancer mortality worldwide. UBC is much more common in African Americans and other minority groups than in Asians, Caucasians, and Hispanics. The incidence of UBC is highest in low-income, rural areas of the world, and in developing countries. The highest incidence rate in any country worldwide is in Egypt. However, the incidence rate of UBC in Egypt and other parts of Africa is lower than that of industrialized countries, such as the United States, Germany and Japan. The Sudan is in the middle of the countries that are considered to have a high incidence of UBC. It is not a leading cause of death in the Sudan. Nevertheless, it can be a leading reason for consultations and hospitalization because of the lack of early detection and poor performance of the treatment offered. There is a paucity of data on the incidence, presentation and histology of UBC in Darfur.
This research study investigates the patterns of urinary bladder cancer (BC) in Darfur, Sudan, with a focus on understanding the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of the disease. We plan to interview and perform clinical exam, imaging (ultrasound, CT, and X-ray) as well as histology and genetic analysis of urinary bladder mass in adult (age of age > 18) Sudanese pts who lives in Darfur and presented with urinary bladder mass. We will gather patients from Nyala Specialized Teaching Hospital (NaSTH) and Sennar Hospital. We will retrospectively analyze the clinical outcomes of patient with urinary bladder tumor in these two hospitals from January 2010 through December 2019.
This is an observational study, and the results will be published in the medical literature. Information from this study will be kept confidential and used to advance knowledge and treatment of the disease.

This study will focus on evaluating the relationship between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. A total of 1000 patients scheduled for colonoscopy will be enrolled for further analysis. The quality of bowel preparation will be assessed by the Boston bowel preparation scale(BPS), which is widely used by colonoscopists to evaluate the overall quality of bowel preparation during colonoscopy. Physical and mental stress levels will be assessed using standardized scales before colonoscopy. The aim of this research is to understand the relationship between physical and mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation during colonoscopy. The study may also provide insights into the psychological factors impacting bowel preparation compliance in patients undergoing colonoscopy.

The investigators propose to examine the effects of a short playful interaction on the cognitive, social, and mood of older people. The investigators will examine changes in indices of mood, mental health, social functioning, cognition compared to an active control intervention. The investigators will examine whether the effects of short-term playful interaction tasks will be preserved in the online format. In addition, in the past two decades there has been a shift toward the development of tailor-made interventions that fit individual needs and abilities. This trend is especially important in aging, given increased variability in personality and cognitive and sensory characteristics. The investigators will examine how personality traits, cognitive functions, and socio-emotional factors will influence the effects of a playful interaction on the dependent variables. The investigators hypnotized that playful interactions will induce greater effects on emotional and social indices, as well as on executive functioning, compared to more familiar social interactions. The investigators hypothesize that these effects will be found in older populations. Overall, the research on playful interactions in aging aims to investigate novel ways for stimulating and supporting cognitive, emotional, and social functions of aging and provide insight on how to support these functions in at-risk populations. The research on playful interactions has received great international attention, and the current research will provide an opportunity to bridge this fascinating field with the aging field. It is hoped that the current research will contribute to the field of aging by showing the importance of cultivating playfulness and novelty seeking as a way to support cognitive, emotional, and social functions of aging. The novel aspect of this research is the use of improvisation as a metaphor for stimulating novelty seeking, playfulness, creativity, and social connection. Moreover, to date, research that has looked at playful interactions has used young participants or participants with specific cognitive or psychological impairments. The investigators propose to use an experimental design to examine the effects of playful interactions on cognitive, mood, and social functioning of generally aging populations.

Recent studies suggest that parents of youth with developmental disabilities report less frequent communication about sexual health and puberty compared to parents of youth without disabilities (Hershenson et al., 2008). A 2016 Kaiser Family Foundation national poll found that more than half of parents lack confidence in having conversations about sexual health topics with their teen, with a clear discrepancy among parents with children with disabilities (48%) compared to parents of teenagers without disabilities (36%) (Kaiser Family Foundation, 2017). Evidence-based practice supports parent training as an excellent way to improve a wide range of parenting behaviors, including sexual health communication (Raposa, Nelson, & Witkiewitz, 2010). Further, these skills can be taught through a brief microskills intervention for parents resulting in significant and lasting improvements (Davies, Witkiewitz, Hilton, Nelson, & Brown, 2010). Although no studies have examined skill-based interventions with parents of youth with developmental disabilities, one study demonstrated significant improvements in parent skill usage when communication curriculum was taught with parents of youth with neurodevelopmental disabilities (SkillTalk, Davies et al., 2016) compared to usual care where the majority of parents made no improvement. Research supporting the effectiveness of an adaptable microskills parent training with families of youth who have disabilities (Davies et al., 2016) combined with the growing evidence for the effectiveness of online modules in improving communication skills (e.g. Davis et al., 2018; Kulik, Vogel, & Weinstock, 2017), warrants testing the potential impact of online trainings with parents of youth with autism spectrum disorder. This study aims to examine the impact of an online training for parents of youth with ASD on parents' demonstrated skills, confidence, communication frequency, teen knowledge, attitude, and behavior around sexual health and relationships between January 2022 and December 2022. Based on existing evidence of efficacy found in studies with parents of youth without disabilities, parents of youth with developmental disabilities will demonstrate a modest to moderate improvement in communication knowledge, skills, and frequency.

Official Title
-----------------
Communication Training Around Sexual Health Topics for Parents of Youth With Autism Spectrum Disorder

The incidence of sepsis is high, but the mortality rate is high in sepsis, among which septic shock is life-threatening for critical patients, and more than half of the patients die. Septic shock is an inflammatory response with extensive multiple organ dysfunction and pathological vascular permeability. Studies have reported that the increase of vascular endothelial injury reflects the severity of the disease and predicts poor prognosis. Recent studies have found that the sepsis patients induced gasdermin D (GSDMD) pore formation on vascular endothelial cells, thereby disrupting the plasma membrane, promoting the occurrence of multiple organ failure, and promoting cell death. The exact regulatory mechanism of GSDMD pore formation under septic conditions has not been elucidated, and the relationship between sepsis patients induced GSDMD pore formation and pyroptosis remains unclear. DDX17 is a member of the DExD/H domain helicase family, and DDX17 plays an important role in regulating cell apoptosis and pyroptosis. Moreover, high expression levels of DDX17 in tumor tissue are associated with a poor prognosis of patients. However, the relationship between DDX17 and sepsis has not been fully addressed. Therefore, this study aimed to explore the relationship between DDX17 and GSDMD pore formation in sepsis patients, and to establish the relationship between DDX17, GSDMD and vascular endothelial injury, and to evaluate its clinical impact on the prognosis of sepsis patients. The research hypothesis: DDX17 is associated with GSDMD pore formation in sepsis patients. The higher the expression level of DDX17 in the plasma of sepsis patients, the more severe the clinical manifestations, the more serious the organ failure, and the less satisfactory the prognosis. The study aims to confirm the hypothesis by combining clinical and basic information to confirm the relationship between DDX17 and sepsis. At the same time, a follow-up research proposal is put forward to explore the regulatory mechanism of DDX17 on GSDMD pore formation in sepsis patients.

Glioblastoma (GBM) is a life-threatening disease with only a 5-year overall survival (OS) of about 5% in real-world studies. Elemene is an anti-tumor drug found to be effective in treating glioblastomas (GBMs) in preliminary retrospective studies. This study aims to conduct the phase II clinical trial "Efficacy and Safety of Elemene Plus Stupp Protocol Versus Stupp Protocol Alone for Newly-diagnosed Glioblastoma: A Multi-center Phase II Randomized Controlled Trial" and to test the safety and efficacy of adding Elemene to the conventional Stupp protocol consisting of irradiation, radiochemotherapy, and adjuvant TMZ in treating GBM patients.
Patients with newly-diagnosed GBMs will be randomly divided into two arms: 1) the experimental arm will take Elemene for 6 cycles during the adjuvant TMZ administration, and 2) the control arm will receive placebo during the adjuvant TMZ administration. Before the start of the clinical trial, the investigators aim to recruit 80 patients at 15 hospitals in China, using block-randomization and random number tables to allocate patients into two arms.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a syndrome characterized by widespread inflammation and diffuse alveolar injury, resulting in hypoxemia, and frequently requiring invasive mechanical ventilation to guarantee the alveolar oxygenation, which in turn increases the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI). VILI increases the stress that the lungs exert to the surrounding thoracic cage, with an effect dependent on the position of the patient, i.e. the direction of the gravity-vector with respect to the lung: in the supine position, when the lungs are placed vertically under gravity, some areas of the lungs (i.e. the dependent lung regions) are more vulnerable to overdistension, while other areas (i.e. the non-dependent regions) are more prone to atelectasis. For this reason, patients on mechanical ventilation commonly present greater respiratory system compliance (Crs) when the patient is in the supine position. On the other hand, when the patient is in the prone position, both non-dependent lung regions and dependent lung regions are equally vulnerable to overdistension, with a consequent decrease in Crs and an increase in driving pressures, resulting in increased risk of VILI. Therefore, to reduce the stress exerted by mechanical ventilation on damaged lungs in ARDS, the prone position, as compared to the supine position, has been demonstrated to improve oxygenation impairment by reducing lung non-uniformity, increasing FRC, decreasing heterogeneous distribution of lung ventilation and homogenizing alveolar recruitment. In infants and children ARDS is characterized by a different pathophysiology as compared with adults, with greater heterogeneity of lung ventilation, even when the patient lies in the supine position, because of the limited airway closing pressure and the lower pulmonary compliance. For this reason, it has been hypothesized that these subtleties in the pathophysiology should result in a higher efficacy of prone positioning in preventing lung collapse and non-uniformity of ventilation in children ARDS. However, prone position efficacy in children with ARDS is uncertain, since studies performed in this population so far lack evidence. The current knowledge gap on the effects of prone positioning in non-intubated infants/children with ARDS is mainly due to the lack of standardized measurements to identify the respiratory and hemodynamics effects of body position. Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the physiological effects of prone positioning during non-invasive, CPAP-supported ventilation in infants/children with ARDS.

The present study focuses on comparing the effects of progressive relaxation training (PRT) on pain features, attack frequency, activity perception, self-efficacy, and social participation in women with migraine or TTH. In this experimental study, 44 women underwent PRT or no intervention for 6 weeks. Before the intervention and at the 1st week after the intervention, occupational self-sufficiency, disability, catastrophizing, headache impact, perception of activity and social participation were assessed. It was hypothesized that the women who participated in PRT would have a lower perception of work performance and participation in social life limitations, less disability, lower frequency of attacks and less pain impact due to the treatment compared to the control group. The findings revealed that women who participated in PRT had lower attack frequencies, reduced pain severity more than women in the control group, while they felt less physical disability, but did not see improvement in cognitive/ emotional aspects such as participation in daily activities and social life. No statistical difference was determined between the groups in terms of pain features or attack frequency in women with TTH. Furthermore, no effect of PRT was found in women with migraine. In this group at the end of the study, the women who underwent PRT had less headache impact and physical disability and felt less pain in the week following the training; they felt less physical disability 1 month after the training, and this was important for their self-sufficiency perception and participation in social life. These findings demonstrate that PRT has a more positive impact on women with migraine than women with TTH. In this group, the training increased perception of work performance and improved participation in social life, which are vital in terms of self-sufficiency. The findings indicate that PRT is a non-invasive treatment option for women who experience pain.

Infant withdrawal syndrome after prenatal exposure to opioids is a serious illness that requires prolonged hospitalization and long-term medication use. Opioid addiction is growing in prevalence, particularly among pregnant women. Infants exposed to opioids in utero often experience withdrawal syndrome, which is commonly called Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS) or Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS). NOWS or NAS describes a group of symptoms experienced by infants after birth when maternal opioids are stopped or reduced. These symptoms may include tremors, fever, sweating, seizures, vomiting, poor feeding, diarrhea, and poor weight gain. In some cases, withdrawal symptoms can be severe and require prolonged hospitalization, long-term medication use, and may even be life-threatening. 
The use of pharmacological agents to treat NOWS/NAS is the standard of care for the past several decades. This treatment is often not without side effects including suppression of growth and feeding difficulties, as well as a risk of adverse behavioral effects in later life. Unfortunately, the clinical course of withdrawal may also be unpredictable, with some infants experiencing mild symptoms and a short treatment course while others may have severe symptoms and prolonged courses lasting over a month. Currently, there are no reliable predictors of withdrawal severity and clinical course. 
In addition to pharmacological treatment, the treatment of infants with NOWS/NAS in the current clinical context is largely trial and error. It is well known in clinical pediatrics that no two infants with withdrawal react exactly the same, but the severity of symptoms and response to treatment can take anywhere between a few hours and a day to manifest. Unfortunately, current withdrawal guidelines and scoring systems used to determine the severity of individual symptoms are subjective, and may be based on the assessment of different clinicians. The standard withdrawal severity score is the Finnegan Neonatal Abstinence Scoring Tool (NAS-FIN). The Finnegan neonatal abstinence score is used on a 24-hour schedule, but there is currently no scoring tool that accurately predicts the severity of infants with NOWS/NAS in a shorter clinical time span. 
A potential alternative to traditional pharmacological interventions for NOWS/NAS could be the use of non-opiate medications that target different aspects of withdrawal. Such medications could provide a more consistent and reliable response and could be used in place of or supplementation to traditional medication. For example, the anti-pruritic medication chlorpheniramine seems to be effective in reducing withdrawal symptoms in animal models, and we have initial anecdotal data suggesting that chlorpheniramine combined with morphine results in reduced withdrawal symptoms as judged by the Finnegan score in some infants with NOWS/NAS. 
Recent investigations have focused on a group of small molecules found in the body and body fluids called microRNAs. These molecules have been found to be present in human fluids such as blood or saliva, and may be responsible for signaling between cells. Recent studies from our lab have shown that microRNAs are differentially expressed in infants with NOWS/NAS compared to infants experiencing withdrawal but are not exposed to opioids in utero. Specifically, we reported that the microRNAs let-7a, miR-126 and miR-299, as well as the long non-coding RNA lnc-MEG3, are changed in infants with prenatal opioid exposure. These microRNAs were highly expressed in those infants experiencing withdrawal. Furthermore, using a cell culture model, we found that exposure to opioids reduces the expression of these microRNAs, suggesting that these molecules may be a target for future pharmacological agents to modulate withdrawal. 
Despite our preliminary work, no other investigation has looked at the relationship between microRNAs and NOWS/NAS in human infants. In this study, we aim to examine the microRNA response to withdrawal and their use as potential biomarkers for NOWS/NAS. We plan to enroll infants between 1-5 days of age meeting diagnostic criteria for withdrawal. After obtaining informed consent from the infant's mother, we will perform a blood draw from the infant and a buccal (saliva) swab. We will also enroll infants in the clinical research protocol to receive morphine treatment of withdrawal for five days. We will then examine the differences in microRNA expression between NOWS and non-exposed infants using a combination of qPCR and

Women receiving opioid treatment during pregnancy are at high risk of experiencing precipitated withdrawal with opioids used for delivery. They are also at high risk of illicit drug use during pregnancy. Opioid treatment programs commonly prescribe buprenorphine for the management of withdrawal and treatment of opioid use disorder in part to facilitate delivery. Induction of buprenorphine requires an initial period of withdrawal before the opioid effects of buprenorphine are realized and in most cases occurs in a hospital inpatient setting. This 18 to 30-month prospective, randomized controlled trial compares the effect of a transdermal patch containing buprenorphine in pregnancy versus no medication during buprenorphine induction. Participants will be recruited prior to entering labor and managed in an outpatient setting for the purpose of buprenorphine induction. This study aims to determine whether outpatient administration of the buprenorphine transdermal patch is effective for maternal and neonatal outcomes.

Background and rationale: Chronic pancreatitis is an inherently complex disease requiring coordinated, multidisciplinary care. Patients suffer from constant, distressing, adverse symptoms including abdominal pain, steatorrhoea, bloating, wind, cramping, and fatigue, making it difficult to eat a normal or sufficient diet. They develop vitamin deficiencies, osteoporosis, and a difficult-to-manage diabetes subgroup (type 3c diabetes). There is no effective medical/surgical treatment, and the disease is progressive and incurable. The mainstay of treatment is diet, supplementation, and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, which helps patients to digest and absorb their food, alleviating symptoms somewhat.
Chronic pancreatitis is a challenging disease with a significant burden on patients and society. It is characterised by relapsing/remitting episodes of pain (lasting up to 15 days) and steatorrhoea, exacerbating diarrhoea, bloating and abdominal discomfort, and affecting a patient's ability to eat a normal diet. Patients suffer from a range of vitamin deficiencies secondary to malabsorption. Patients usually present to tertiary hospitals with advanced disease and often have associated diabetes (3c diabetes). There is no effective medical or surgical treatment for the disease, but the mainstay of therapy consists of good nutritional advice, ensuring adequate nutrition through dietary supplements, ensuring adequate medication (pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy) and managing associated morbidities.
Chronic pancreatitis is a challenging diagnosis as many patients still smoke, remain obese and/or alcohol-dependent, which adds to the complexity of their management and often makes them 'treatment-refractory’. The investigators have identified a need to improve the management of this condition because:
1) it is challenging to coordinate care and this leads to poorer outcomes, high hospital admission and unplanned attendances to the hospital;
2) there are no new medical treatments available to treat the condition;
3) there is no evidence-based guidance to support a more coordinated approach to care; and
4) patient access to specialist pancreatic services is not always available, or patients travel long distances, leading to inadequate ongoing patient/clinic communication;
5) existing resources for patient/family support are limited; and
6) existing patient information available is limited.
What is the intervention?
A steering group designed and developed the SmartCP mobile phone app during 2022 with the support of a government innovation grant. SmartCP consists of a symptom tracker, diet/physical activity log, alert system for escalating symptoms, quality of life assessment, red-flag alerts for diabetes/pancreatic cancer, educational content, push notifications and messaging function.
The smartphone app will be used for the next 6-18 months. At the end of this period, a patient survey will determine how patients have used the application during this time, the number of interactions and what they felt the application was useful for.
The app is available for download on Apple and Android smartphones.
The investigators will ask a group of patients with chronic pancreatitis and a group of nurses to evaluate and feedback on the app. Patients will be asked to provide feedback on their experience of using the app before and after the intervention. Nurses using this app will be asked to evaluate and feedback on their experience of using the app.

Official Title

Feasibility Study of a Mobile Health App for Symptom Monitoring in People With Chronic Pancreatitis: The SmartCP Study

This study was planned as a randomized prospective controlled study. Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who needs root coverage surgery in the Department of Periodontology were included in the study. The subepithelial connective tissue graft was obtained in each patient using the single incision technique from the region between the mesial of canine and the mesial of first molar in the palate. Connective tissue dimensions were approximately 10 × 5 × 2 mm. Finally, the incision line was sutured with 5/0 synthetic, nonabsorbable, sterile monofilament suture in the control group while L-PRF membrane was placed to the donor site in the test group before the suturing. Patients were evaluated using an ultrasonography device (MyLab™ Seven, Esaote, Genoa, Italy) at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology. USG measurements were performed on days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30 and 90 for palatal tissue thickness and tissue vascularization by an oral and maxillofacial radiologist with at least six years of experience. A 6-18 MHz intraoral probe was used in intraoral USG examinations. Sterile gel was applied to the intraoral probe and covered with a stretch film. Then, it was placed directly on the mucosal surface of the donor site in the palatal area. Mucosal thickness was evaluated using the B-mode of the device, and vascularization was evaluated using the color doppler and pulsed wave doppler modes of the device. The mean pulsatility index (PI) values of each patient were calculated and considered for statistical analysis. The power analyse of the study was performed for sample size calculation. Sample size was calculated using a statistical program (G*Power; Universitat, Dusseldorf, Germany) for α = 0.05 and effect size = 0.26. The analyses revealed that 10 subjects per group achieved a power of 80 % with 95% confidence. The data were analysed with the SPSS 21 program (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL). Continuous variables were presented as mean ± standard deviation and categorical variables as numbers and percentages. Shapiro-Wilk test was used to detect data's normality. For the comparison of the parameters of the study groups, independent samples T-test test was used for normally distributed data while Mann Whitney U test test was performed as non-parametric test. Within-group comparisons between the different time periods were tested with repeated measures of ANOVA. Bonferroni correction was performed for multiple variations. The statistical significance value was accepted as p < 0.05.

This study will seek to collect high quality data on outcomes and costs for patients receiving ARRC treatment in an Australian public hospital. This will involve piloting the use of a database to record these outcomes and costs from patient admission to 7-10 post-operative days.
This approach is intended to serve two purposes. Firstly, it will allow for collection of data to establish the effectiveness, safety and acceptability of ARRC treatment in an Australian setting. Understanding the experiences and outcomes of patients, and the cost implications of this model of care, is essential before scaling up to larger evaluations. Secondly, a database allowing collection of post discharge data will allow the researchers to maintain contact with patients, facilitate the evaluation of longer term outcomes, and build on the results of a previous study at RAH.
This study will be in a pragmatic, real-world context and will focus on surgical inpatient care at Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH), particularly care in the Post Anaesthesia Recovery Care unit (PARC).
The study will recruit all patients who are admitted to RAH for surgery, who meet specific inclusion criteria of low inpatient mortality risk and expected to stay at least one night. Data will be collected from admission to discharge (estimated to be one week in most cases), and will include details of patient demographics, medical history, surgery details, post-operative care, complications, discharge destination and death.
The results of this study will help inform and improve models of care for surgical patients in both Australia and internationally. By establishing the best possible foundations for future studies and by building strong relationships between researchers, clinicians and consumers, the researchers aim to ultimately improve the value of surgical care provided to patients around the world.

This study aims to investigate the emotional status of individuals with TMD compared to healthy individuals (control group). 
  It will be a prospective, comparative study with two phases.

Eighteen patients with TMD according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM)-IV criteria will be included in the study. It was aimed to include an equal number of women and men in total 18 in all. The same process will be applied for healthy individuals (n: 18) whose symptoms of TMD will not be observed according to DSM-IV criteria. Data will be collected by using the 25th Edition of the International Classification of Function, Disability and Health Questionnaire. For the patients included in the study, demographic characteristics and a clinical evaluation will be done. 
  Additionally, participants will complete the RDC questionnaire, a questionnaire used in the assessment of pain, fatigue and sleep problems, a questionnaire used in assessing the overall stress level, a dental trauma questionnaire, and a clinical examination questionnaire. For the control group to be created, the same processes will be applied to individuals whose symptoms of TMD will not be observed.

The results will be analyzed with statistical package for the social sciences (SPSS) 20.0 software. 
  It was aimed to investigate the emotional state in individuals with TMD. It was thought that this study would contribute to the literature by shedding light on this issue.

This is a randomized controlled trial with a double-blind design.
Preterms often present neurological and metabolic complications that can lead to long-term health disorders (i.e., cerebral palsy and neurological or cognitive disorders, hypertension and cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, immunological disorders, etc.). Despite a large body of research on the impact of neonatal intensive care interventions on the neurodevelopmental and metabolic outcomes of preterm infants, the effects of specific interventions on the development of the central nervous system remain controversial.
Touch can have positive effects on the growth of infants (including preterms) and the modulation of emotional, cognitive and behavioral responses. Recently it has been suggested that touch has beneficial effects on the organization and the regulation of specific brain areas involved in the modulation of emotions, including the prefrontal cortex, the amygdala, the hypothalamus and cortical regions associated with affective processing such as the insula and the anterior cingulate cortex.
Hypothesis:  We hypothesize that touch (TOT) intervention has beneficial metabolic and neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm infants.
Through this study, the researchers aim to verify the possibility that a 6-month treatment program can lead to beneficial neurodevelopmental and metabolic outcomes in preterms. The program could help preterms in developing adequate connectivity in the central nervous system and in regulating metabolic markers.

HIV-infected men in Hong Kong are at high-risk of Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI). Mycoplasma Genitalium(MG) has an increasing prevalence among MG-naive male recruited from two clinics of Prince of Wales Hospital in the past two years. The aim of this study is to investigate the prevalence of MG infection, MG drug resistance mutations, and the overall STI burden in HIV positive male patients in Prince of Wales Hospital. This study will recruit 750 HIV-infected male patients attending the Prince of Wales Hospital HIV outpatient clinic in Hong Kong. Participants will receive self-sampling kits to collect urine, rectal and pharyngeal swabs for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis(CT)and Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) testing for both men who have sex with men (MSM) and heterosexual men. The data of clinical diagnosis of STI will be extracted from medical records. The study will determine the prevalence of MG infection. To investigate the prevalence of MG resistance mutations, genetic studies will be performed on bacterial DNA isolated from MG positive samples from rectal and pharyngeal sites with quantitation of the number of MGgenotypic resistance mutations. The prevalence of CT and NG infections would be examined. The investigators will estimate the overall STI burden in HIV cohort, which is important to inform clinical practices for better management of STI among HIV positive patients. This study can enhance the surveillance of the prevalence and genotypic resistance mutations of MG infection and the overall STIs burden in HIV positive male patients. Ultimately, understanding the prevalence and resistance mechanisms of MG infection can inform local practices and policy to prevent and manage MG infection.

This research study is conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Dalpiciclib (Dalpara) combined with endocrine therapy in patients with HR+ HER2- recurrent/metastatic breast cancer after CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment failure. The study will include 80 subjects from 10 medical centers. The study is an internationally, multicenter, open-label, randomized (1:1), phase II trial.

What is the study measuring?
-----------------
The primary purpose of this study is treatment, allocation is randomized, intervention model is parallel assignment, and masking is none (open label). The study includes an experimental arm of Dalpiciclib combined with physician-selected endocrine therapy and an active comparator arm of chemotherapy selected by the physician. It is believed that the combination of Dalpiciclib with endocrine therapy will be effective.

How is the study designed?
-----------------
All participants will go through a single-group baseline and observation phase. Then, participants will be randomized to either the experimental arm or the active comparator, with a balance ratio of 1:1. The experimental arm consists of the combination of Dalpiciclib once daily on days 1-21 of each 4-week cycle. Participants are required to undergo a CT or MRI assessment 4-8 weeks after randomization. Assessments at week 12 must be consistent with the first interim assessment. The active comparator consists of the clinically applicable chemotherapy regimen as determined by the clinical physician who is responsible for the selection of the chemotherapy. Patients are required to conduct the examination four weeks after randomization to determine disease progression. Participants are required to undergo a CT or MRI assessment 4-8 weeks after the first examination after the start of treatment. Assessments at week 12 must be consistent with the first interim assessment.

Inactivity is the fourth leading risk factor for global mortality, leading to chronic diseases and obesity. Much of the world's population is inactive and older adults are at highest risk. Inactivity in older adults is linked to age-related diseases and cognitive decline, along with imposing social costs in the form of increased medical expenses. Incentive-based interventions have gained popularity among behavioral scientists and policymakers for improving health-related behaviors such as physical activity, but there are drawbacks due to concerns of scalability, habit formation, and crowd-out effects. While financial incentive programs are popular, they may be costly, and the effects are not long-lasting. Therefore, the investigators propose to design and evaluate alternative incentives that address these issues by focusing on prosocial incentives and personal incentives. The investigators will aim to encourage physical activity through alternative incentives by making meal donations on behalf of participants (prosocial incentives) and offering participants monetary incentives (personal incentives) for their walking behavior. Both types of incentives have underpinnings in behavior economics. For example, prosocial preferences are the tendency to derive pleasure from helping others, and may be more powerful than monetary incentives for reducing inactivity. The participants will be randomized to receive prosocial, personal, or no incentives for 8 weeks. Step count, mental health, and overall physical health of these participants will be tracked. The investigators will recruit 200 older adults from stores, cafes, and community centers around San Diego and track their step counts for 8 weeks.

This is a retrospective study on the prevalence of Head and Neck Cancer (HNC) at the Department of ENT- Head and Neck Surgery of Shree Birendra Hospital, the largest tertiary-level health-care centre in Nepal. The study aimed to analyse the clinicopathological profile of 80 patients of newly diagnosed HNC at the hospital. The study included the number of cases of various subtypes including oral cavity, oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx, and salivary gland malignancies. The overall prevalence of HNC was 12% of the total outpatient consultation in the ENT department during the study period, and 97% were males. Oral cavity cancers are the most common cancer in Nepal which need early detection and treatment. The major outcome of this study is to provide the data of basic demographics including the clinical characteristics of this disease in Nepalese population which is important to plan and implement strategies for early detection and prevention of such malignancies.

The study will then be further divided based on age group, where one half of all subjects will receive the same rehab protocol, but with the addition of blood flow restriction using a tourniquet during certain exercises. The hypothesis is that a short course of rehabilitation incorporating blood flow restriction therapy will promote faster gains in muscle strength, reduce time to return to work and other daily duties, and reduce pain at time points following surgery. The study will be powered to detect a difference of 5lbs in grip strength between the two groups, while reducing inter-group variability based on age and gender. We believe these goals will be achieved by recruiting subjects from our own institution, and by ensuring the same surgeon is involved in all surgeries, and the same physical therapist in all rehabilitation. These methods will help minimize inter-group variability related to surgeon and rehab therapist experience with each individual patient.

Background: Recent guidelines recommend coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) as the first line test for the evaluation of patients with suspected coronary artery disease (CAD). However, the management of patients with non-obstructive CAD is less clear, with a significantly increased risk of developing major cardiovascular events. An AI-based analysis combining multiple CAD determinants, including an innovative quantitative angiosegographical parameter (coronary adipose tissue attenuation), has been shown to stratify patient-risk and predict the severity of adverse cardiovascular events. Objective: The aim of this study is to develop an AI-based model that can accurately predict patient-risk and improve personalized management in patients with suspected CAD. It has two main goals:
1. To prospectively validate the clinical-imaging AI-based model in a retrospective cohort (month 0-30) in patients who underwent a cCTA exam for CAD evaluation. Specifically, 3000 patients will be enrolled in the retrospective single center cohort (2500 in the AI training cohort and 500 in the AI testing cohort), and the AI-based model will be validated retrospectively on a prospectively enrolled cohort of 500 patients who also underwent a retrospective follow-up.
2. To validate the AI-based model on a prospective cohort (month 0-60) of 500 patients who underwent a cCTA examination for CAD evaluation. The AI-based model will be prospectively developed and validated on this study population, and a prospective follow-up of 3 years will be performed. As a final step, a software solution will be developed to be integrated in the clinical workflow following the standardized regulatory procedure "regulatory sandbox" (1446/2019/EC). This will increase usability and reduce costs for the integration of AI-based applications in clinical care.

The Mediterranean diet has been associated with a reduced risk of diabetes, obesity and cardiovascular diseases. The regular consumption of pasta in moderate amounts is part of the diet, even though it is wrongly considered too caloric and associated with weight gain, especially if consumed at dinner. The scientific literature, however, does not evaluate, in a comprehensive way, the best time to consume pasta for improving or maintaining health status, especially with respect to metabolic, sleep and gastrointestinal parameters.
Thus, this study aims at investigating the effects of consuming pasta at two different phases, namely at lunch or at dinner, on sleep quality, anthropometric indices, cardiovascular risk factors, composition and functionality of the gut microbiota. Furthermore, the individual chronotypes, which have recently been considered for their influence on dietary habits, metabolic indices and human health, will be evaluated to understand if they have an impact on the study outcomes.
The investigators will recruit 30 normal weight participants to the study, each fulfilling the inclusion criteria. The participants will be randomly allocated to two groups, one that will eat pasta at dinner for 3 months at the beginning, and one that will eat pasta at lunch for 3 months at the beginning. After 3 months of intervention, the groups will change the phase of pasta consumption according to the following sequence: the dinner group that was initially at dinner will move to lunch, whilst the lunch group that was initially at lunch will move to dinner. Participants will be provided with 100gr of whole wheat pasta with tomato sauce, consumed at their habitual mid-meal meal (lunch or dinner, depending on the group they are in).
The investigators will perform several measures of sleep quality at the beginning and at the end of each dietary intervention period. Sleep will be evaluated by standardised questionnaires, sleep logs and actigraphy monitoring. The primary outcome of the study will be related to sleep and gastrointestinal health, while secondary outcomes will assess body weight, body composition, blood parameters, gut microbiota composition and short chain fatty acid production.
The results of this study are expected to provide novel insights on the impact of pasta consumption at two different pharmacological phases on the health of normal weight subjects. This information may be used to optimize pasta consumption for overall health and to develop dietary recommendations related to meal timing.

Change in the sleep quality of patients before and one month after implementation of the sleep protocol is measured by the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality questionnaire.

It will also increase our understanding of the health enhancing potential of bacteria such as L. reuteri PB-W1™ that are rare in contemporary Westerners.

In China, about 9.5 million new cases and 5.1 million deaths occurred each year. Among those deaths, about 21% of the elderly died of chronic diseases. With the aging of the population, China will have an unprecedented burden of stroke. According to statistics, by 2025, China's urban elderly population will reach 267 million, accounting for 35.9% of the elderly population, and in 2050, China's urban elderly population will reach 387 million, accounting for 38.3% of the elderly population. It is predicted that the number of stroke patients in China will reach 4 million by 2030 and 6.7 million by 2050. The prevention and control of stroke has therefore become one of the important tasks that cannot be ignored in the future.
In February 2013, the National Development and Reform Commission announced the "Medical and Health Special Plan for Stroke Prevention and Control (2013-2020)", which pointed out that the basic scientific research of new drugs for high-risk patients with stroke prevention and control is an important task.
AD16 is a new drug designed by Professor Liu Jian from the University of Texas at Austin (UTSA), which is expected to be used for the prevention of cognitive decline, dementia and Alzheimer's disease in patients with a high risk of disease or mild cognitive impairment according to the 1996 NINCDS-ADRDA criteria. AD16 is a low-molecular-weight heparin with a molecular weight of approximately 5 kDa, which is derived from heparan sulfate. Its mechanism of action may involve activation of protein phosphatases 1, 2A, 2B and 5B, inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase-3β, and inhibition of tau protein aggregation and phosphorylation under certain conditions.
Ad16 is a stable drug with low immunogenicity and toxicity under certain conditions. It is currently undergoing preclinical and clinical development in the United States by Rexahn Pharmaceuticals Inc.
The purpose of this trial is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 in adult healthy subjects after a single oral dose. 72 participants from 2 cohorts (60 healthy men and 12 healthy women) were selected, and the experimental groups and the matching placebo groups received a single oral dose of AD16 0, 10, 20, 30 or 40 to 80 mg. The dosing order according to dosing cohorts is 5 to 8 mg, 10 to 13 mg, 20 to 23 mg, 30 to 33 mg, and 40 to 43 mg.
AD16 showed excellent efficacy in neurocognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease animal models. In a clinical trial in healthy volunteers, the incidence of abnormal laboratory test results was lower in the AD16 group than in the placebo group, and the serum concentrations of AD16 in the drug group were higher than those in the placebo group, suggesting that AD16 has good safety and tolerability and good pharmacokinetics. Based on a large number of previous studies and preclinical and clinical data, the investigator believes that AD16 is safe and well-tolerated and has good pharmacokinetics. This study can provide data for the optimization of the dose form and dosing frequency and the design of subsequent clinical trials.
In summary, this study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, escalating-dose study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of single oral doses of AD16 in adult healthy subjects. The study's dosing schedule is 6 dosing cohorts, which are selected according to the dose escalation scheme.

Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is the most common form of cardiovascular dysfunction in adults and has a prevalence similar to that of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Despite intensive research, prognosis and management of HFpEF with clinical implications is still unsatisfactory. No specific diagnostic algorithm as well as no targeted drug therapy has been approved, unlike heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. As a consequence, the number of hospitalizations for acute decompensation of HFpEF is increasing. The identification of patients with HFpEF, the use of the most effective methods of preventive and therapeutic care, the improvement of patient compliance, and the introduction of comprehensive treatment management should improve the level of HFpEF management. The investigators have previously shown that the phenotype of acute decompensation of HFpEF with preserved ejection fraction is influenced by comorbidities, gender and obesity. Obese patients hospitalized with heart failure are characterized by metabolic disorders with obesity-related cardiomyopathy, which is associated with a poor prognosis; they have elevated levels of markers of systemic inflammation and are characterized by a significant percentage of impaired renal function. The investigators conducted a randomized controlled trial in non-hospitalized patients with obesity and HFpEF, which confirmed the positive effect of exercise on the quality of patient compliance and on the prognosis of the disease. At the same time, the investigators still lack a comprehensive algorithm that combines the use of various clinical, laboratory and instrumental methods and that assesses the severity and course of HFpEF decompensation and predicts long-term outcomes. 
An international database is planned to be created to compare new tools for assessing the course, severity and long-term outcomes of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. A prospective randomized study (PRE-HF-pEF) of 120 patients with HFpEF and acute decompensation is planned, as well as 150 apparently healthy obese people as a control group.
Inclusion criteria are HFpEF and acute decompensation, confirmed by instrumental and / or laboratory criteria. The main inclusion criteria that allow for a full-scale registration include the following. Female patients ≥ 40 years old and male patients ≥ 40 years old who will visit the Cardiology or Intensive care unit at the city clinical hospital named after. V.V. Veresaeva for HFpEF decompensation with an estimated age ≥ 40 years. Patients with a confirmed diagnosis in accordance with instrumental and / or laboratory diagnostic criteria. Exclusion criteria: Refusal to sign informed consent to participate in a clinical trial and to process personal data.
A multidisciplinary team will be involved, with the following specialists participating: a cardiologist, a nephrologist, a dietician, a psychotherapist.
The investigators plan to conduct the assessment of gender characteristics, clinical and anamnestic factors, body composition, topical characteristics of congestion, instrumental data and biochemical markers associated with cellular inflammation and stress in obese patients with acute decompensation of HFpEF. After assessing the baseline characteristics of the registered patients, the investigators will compare the clinical and instrumental characteristics of the patients and the control group to determine the phenotype of acute decompensation of HFpEF to identify patients at risk for adverse long-term outcome, based on which the investigators will develop recommendations for therapeutic management. This will allow for a comprehensive assessment of the course, severity, and long-term outcomes of hospitalized patients with HFpEF. In addition, these patients will have the opportunity to receive evidence-based treatment aimed at a positive long-term outcome.

Apraxia is a motor-based disorder that interferes with the programming and execution of voluntary movements. This motor disorder is characterized by difficulty producing speech sounds correctly, with both the accuracy of consonants and vowels being abnormal; thus, accurate speech production is not consistent or systematic. A growing body of preliminary research suggests that speech therapy combined with frequent practice sessions at home can improve speech production in children with apraxia, but parents and caregivers may face challenges in implementing treatment gains at home without direct supervision by their child's speech-language pathologist (SLP).
In this study, we aim to provide further evidence of the efficacy of this intervention and examine the role of a parent/caregiver training component in treating children aged 2:6 to 7:11 with congenital Childhood Apraxia of Speech (CAS). In addition, our research team will determine whether direct caregiver training provides a significant advantage over indirect caregiver involvement.
The present study is a multisite randomized control trial (RCT) that aims to investigate the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. This proposed work is multisite parallel-group randomized control trial (RCT) that aims to investigate the impact of parent/caregiver involvement on DTTC treatment outcomes in children with CAS. Participants will be seen in two groups: 1) Direct Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Direct Caregiver Training); 2) Indirect Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Indirect Caregiver Training).
The DTTC plus Home Practice plus Direct Caregiver Training Group will receive DTTC treatment for 16 sessions (8 weeks) over 20 treatment words. Additionally, direct coaching from the SLP will be provided during half of each 30-minute treatment session. Treatment will be implemented with the involvement of parents/caregivers as the primary practitioner during home practice sessions during the 4-week follow-up period.
The DTTC plus Home Practice plus Indirect Caregiver Training Group will receive DTTC treatment for 16 sessions (8 weeks) over 20 treatable words. Indirect training will be used during half of each 30-minute treatment session, in which treatment will be implemented with the support of parents/caregivers, who will receive online guidance from the SLP. Treatment will be implemented with the involvement of parents/caregivers, who will receive online guidance from the SLP, during home practice sessions during the 4-week follow-up period.
Hundred children with CAS and their primary caregivers will be randomized between the two study arms. Each child will complete 4 probe sessions (overall time commitment of approximately 3.5 hours) at 5 different time points (Pre-treatment, Post-treatment, and 1-week and 4-week follow-up). In this study, the effect of parent/caregiver training and treatment delivery on the progress of participants with CAS will be quantified and reported.

There is currently no organized social support for patients undergoing laryngectomy. Some organizations such as Chant pour Vivre offer psychological care through the organization of meetings. Laryngical cancer is one of the top ten cancers in France and one of the deadliest cancers due to its early dissemination and late diagnoses. The consequences of total laryngectomy are multiple: loss of phonation (voice) and need to learn to speak again through speech therapy; Disappearance of oral-nasal breathing (and therefore loss of smell, or even taste); Disappearance of the capacity of the effort with closed glottis (used in the acts of daily life: defecation, sexual act in men, etc.); Impairment of body image and sometimes self-esteem. These consequences impact patients' quality of life. A survey carried out by the University Hospital of Dijon and Lyon showed that the disappearance of voice had significant consequences on self-esteem. These patients then need adapted care. The ENT department of the Bichat hospital performs an average of fourteen surgeries of total laryngectomy per year over the last three years. The direct consequences of total laryngectomy are multiple: loss of phonation (voice) and need to learn to speak again through speech therapy; Disappearance of oral-nasal breathing (and therefore loss of smell, or even taste); Disappearance of the capacity of the effort with closed glottis (used in the acts of daily life: defecation, sexual act in men, etc.); Impairment of body image and sometimes self-esteem. For these reasons, it is essential to accompany patients post-operative to help them understand their body image and mitigate the direct and indirect consequences of this intervention. To support laryngectomized patients, the study will test and validate the creation of self-help and support groups. The study will include laryngectomized patients who wish and can participate in these groups. The sessions will take place as follows: 1st: presentation of each, answers to questions; 2nd: intervention of the association of the mutilated of the voice; 3rd: questions / answers with a resource patient (laryngectomized for 13 years at Bichat hospital), groups are planned after the third session: these groups will gather each of the four groups to evaluate the satisfaction of patients regarding the program. In order to assess the benefit of these meetings, two specific questionnaires will be given to patients before the first session and retrieved beforehand. The WHOQOL-BREF is a global quality of life questionnaire. It contains 26 subjects that can be grouped, with a score from zero to 100 in each group, and a total score where the scores in the four groups were joined and divided by four to obtain an overall score ranging from 26 to 130 . The EORTC QLQH&n43 is an ENT-specific quality of life questionnaire. It assesses the effect of hearing loss or deafness on various levels of life. It also assesses the impact of laryngectomy on quality of life. These questionnaires are accompanied by a free text part, so that the person fills in the keys that the workshops have brought him. Patients who cannot participate in the exchange groups for geographical or personal reasons will constitute a control group. They will also complete the two questionnaires four months apart. The number of patients registered and the participation rate at each session will be evaluated.

A new innovative fountain faucet will be designed that will allow individuals with spinal cord injuries (SCI), particularly those living with quadriplegia, to access water more independently for basic activities of daily living such as drinking, rinsing, and grooming. The faucet will incorporate electromechanical controls and software programs to adjust spray outlets, spray angles, and water temperatures. A proximity sensor and voice recognition function will allow users to control the faucet through a smart speaker. The faucet design will include a camera and other sensors to enable hands-free operation of the faucet. The investigators expect that the new fountain faucet will enhance the independence and quality of life of individuals with SCI through the following aims: (1) test control of water streams via motion, voice, and eye gaze control sensors; and (2) develop standardized outcome measures for the control of water streams via fountain faucets for activities of daily living such as drinking, rinsing, and grooming. Testing will be done at the Kennedy Krieger Institute (KWI) in Baltimore, MD. Forty-five able-bodied control subjects will perform task-based activities such as drinking and rinsing using a fountain faucet. Testing will focus on individuals who live with quadriplegia or tetraplegia to assess the feasibility of using the fountain faucet for daily activities and to develop a system usability scale (SUS) to evaluate the usability of the fountain faucet. Outcome measures for the control of water streams will be developed to measure the subject's independence level for hydration and grooming in daily life.

Post-secondary student mental health is crucial; however, there exist significant barriers in achieving equitable access to mental healthcare. These barriers include but are not limited to geographical distance from mental health services, long wait times for mental health appointments, social stigma associated with mental health services, and financial constraints. In response to these barriers, the proposed research project aims to create an online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT program that is accessible, cost-effective, and efficient. The goal of this project is to create an online mental healthcare resource that is not only scalable but also can be easily integrated into existing care models.

The project aims to create a comprehensive care model guided by a robust delivery of a seven-pronged mental healthcare hub (pre-adoption, delivery, post-adoption phases of the hub). The study will assess the current mental healthcare landscape and needs of post-secondary students through surveys and focus groups. The information gained from surveys and focus groups will be used in the development of 6-week online psychoeducation and 12-week diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs (guided by Aim 2 and Aim 3).

The psychoeducation program will be followed by 6 months of online journaling exercises. If the AI algorithm detects a psychiatric disorder (Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), Social Anxiety Disorder (SAD), or Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)) during the journaling exercises, the algorithm will make a referral to the relevant diagnosis-specific e-CBT program. Each e-CBT program will involve 12 weekly modules and homework, followed by 6 months of follow-up assessments.

This study will have three aims: Aim 1 will assess post-secondary student mental health needs through surveys and focus groups. Aims 2 and 3 will use the information from surveys and focus groups to develop 6-week online psychoeducation and 12-week diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs. Aims 4 and 5 will determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online psychoeducation and diagnosis-specific e-CBT programs by comparing them to treatment as usual. Aims 6 and 7 will use the collected data to monitor the success and fidelity of the programs. If this study finds the programs to be efficacious, the findings will significantly improve post-secondary student mental healthcare services in Ontario, and potentially Canada. We anticipate that our mental healthcare hub will support a range of mental health services; for example, the hub can function as a stand-alone service for individuals who do not have access to mental health specialists in the local community or can easily complement existing community services to improve access to care.

The proposed project aligns with the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada Competition-based Medical Education (CBME) program that requires medical students to participate in the development of a new care program before its implementation. Additionally, this project aligns with the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) Fundamental Research (FR) program, which aims to find basic, early-stage knowledge that will inform our understanding of the origins and nature of psychological distress and its impact on individuals, groups, and populations in Canadian communities.

In conclusion, this proposed research project will significantly contribute to accessible and efficient mental healthcare services in Ontario, Canada. With the implementation of the mental healthcare hub, our proposed research project will improve psychiatric care for post-secondary students in Ontario, and potentially other Canadian municipalities.

Background: Warts are caused by viral infection with human papillomavirus (HPV). They are benign growths of skin and mucous (wet warts) that are contagious and can spread to other areas of the body by touch transmission. Warts can be treated with antiviral or cytotoxic agents, but these treatments are associated with significant side effects and are costly.
Objective: The aim of the study is to assess the efficacy of antiviral ointment (AV2) in combination with Salicylic acid (SA) for treatment of the most common wart type (cutaneous warts). This is a phase II randomized open-label study with an investigator-masked end-point, comparing the standard of care (100% SA) versus AV2-SA treatment.
Methods: Eighty patients with 113 cutaneous warts will be enrolled; of these, 44 patients will receive the AV2-SA treatment, and 36 patients will receive standard SA treatment. All patients are given WhatsApp to upload photos of the warts once weekly for follow-up. Treatment efficacy of both treatments will be assessed by cure rates.
Discussion: No prior studies have investigated the efficacy of AV2-SA combined therapy for cutaneous warts. This study will provide important insights for the treatment of cutaneous warts and help determine whether this new combination therapy is superior to standard SA treatment in patients with multiple or persistent cutaneous warts. The study will potentially impact patient quality of life by offering an alternative that is readily available and cost-effective.

Human chorionic gonadotropin is produced in the trophoblast at the time of implantation and rapidly rises during the first 2 weeks of pregnancy. However, if the pregnancy implanted outside of the uterus, hCG will increase even when the pregnancy is abnormal. Therefore, the best method of detecting and confirming ectopic pregnancy is measuring the beta subunit of hCG, called beta hCG (ßhCG). Treating ectopic pregnancy is a routine obstetrical practice, and most patients, except those with ruptured ectopic pregnancy, are treated with methotrexate. Many studies have shown that methotrexate can be applied in 85-97% cases with good response. However, the complications of treatment, such as infection, adverse reactions to methotrexate, and drug refractoriness, have increased the search for alternative medications. Letrozole is a drug that has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of advanced breast cancer and breast cancer. Letrozole inhibits the production of estrogen and is used in obese, postmenopausal patients. It was reported in some studies that letrozole will lead to decreased pregnancy in the ovary. By blocking the synthesis of estrogen and progesterone, letrozole can reduce the levels of hCG in the blood. Based on the information mentioned above, we believe that in this study to assess the efficacy of letrozole in management of ectopic pregnancy, the first group will receive a single dose (50 mg/m2) of methotrexate. The beta-hcg level is measured on the first day, and the hcg serum level is routinely measured on the fourth, seventh and fourteenth day. The second group will receive letrozole is given in the form of 2.5 mg tablets twice a day for 10 days. And on the fourth, seventh and fourteenth day, the HCG level is measured. And the third group will receive letrozole is given in the form of 2.5 mg tablets 3 times a day for 5 days, and hCG levels are measured on days 4, 7, and 14. Based on the results of this study, it is desired to examine the efficacy of letrozole for treatment of ectopic pregnancy compared to methotrexate.
