Background: Serum amyloid A (SAA) is an acute phase reactant predominantly produced in the liver in response to systemic inflammation, tissue damage and infection, mainly by bacterial endotoxins. In idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), serum concentrations of SAA are associated with disease severity, progressive fibrosis and worse prognosis. In sarcoidosis, serum concentrations of SAA are increased in extra-thoracic disease, and are correlated with disease severity, but it is unknown whether SAA is a specific marker of thoracic sarcoidosis. Our aim is to investigate the role of SAA in the diagnosis and follow-up of intrathoracic sarcoidosis.
Objective: Main objectives of the current research are: 
- Determining the mean serum concentration of SAA at the time of diagnosis and during follow-up in sarcoidosis patients and compare these concentrations to controls.
- Investigating if serum concentrations of SAA in intrathoracic sarcoidosis corelate with disease activity and extent, and correlate with changes in disease extent and lung function tests during follow-up.
- Evaluate if serum concentrations of SAA at the time of diagnosis correlate with the need for therapy and the progression towards extra-thoracic disease.
Methods: This is a single center case series study in sarcoidosis patients, with a control group consisting of healthy volunteers.
The study is conducted at the Pulmonary Department at the Ghent University Hospital.

Exclusion criteria: individuals with granulomatous disease that could not be unequivocally diagnosed as sarcoidosis were excluded, as well as patients with possible confounding other known systemic inflammatory illnesses, acute infection, patients on immunosuppressive drugs or immunotherapy and patients with active cancer.

During initial diagnostic work-up, baseline blood sample will be drawn from the patient to determine the initial serum concentration of SAA. Patients will be followed up after one year and three years to analyze the impact of SAA on disease progression and response to therapy.

Pregnancy rates after embryo transfer by frozen technology remain modest in the absence of a previous biopsy of the embryo (8-20%), with no increase in multiple pregnancies. The objective of this clinical trial is to test whether introducing a first culture medium into the uterine cavity prior to embryo transfer, in a population of patients not primed with progesterone, results in a significant increase in pregnancy rates. A single-blind, randomized, controlled trial conducted in 15 IVF centers in France will compare the pregnancy rates of a standard embryo transfer with those of an immediate embryo transfer after introduction of blank culture medium into the uterine cavity.

As a result, the economic burden on the health system increases with these patients. Acupressure is an ancient and safe treatment method that has been used traditionally in the treatment of pain and other symptoms. This application has been accepted in developed countries, and randomized controlled studies also report that this application is used in the treatment of various diseases. It is known that acupressure has some positive effects on pain management. This study was planned to examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The aim was to see whether there was a difference in the reduction of back pain in the cesarean section group who received acupressure treatment in the late postpartum period. It is aimed to determine if the study meets the primary outcome, whether there is a difference in the reduction of late postpartum lumbar pain in puerperal women who received acupressure treatment after cesarean delivery, and secondary outcomes between groups. It is planned to apply to 70 participants from different family health centers in the first day of the late postpartum period (between 7-15 days) before and after the application. It is thought that acupressure is a potential and cost-effective method in the treatment of back pain in the late postpartum period.

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of serotonin on cardiovascular function in the context of septic shock. The investigators hypothesize that, by reducing serotonin, vasopressor drugs use can be reduced without worsening organ function or mortality. A double-blind placebo-controlled randomized trial will be realized to assess the effect of serotonin removal on the vasopressor requirement. Vasopressor use will be recorded 24 hours apart, between enrollment and ICU discharge or death. Paroxetine will be started at a dose of 40mg/day, once a day for 5 consecutive days or until removal of all vasopressors at a stable dose for 48 hours or until shock resolution. Admission and outcome measures will be evaluated to assess mortality, need for mechanical ventilation, number of days and ICU stay after the end of vasopressor use.
Inclusion criteria:
Inclusion Criteria: Patient over 18 years of age; Patient diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and using a minimum dose of noradrenaline (0.01 mcg/kg/min); Patients and/or legal guardians who consented to participate in the study through the free and informed consent term before randomization.
Exclusion Criteria:
Pregnant women; Patients with inability to use the gastrointestinal tract; Patients with known intolerance to paroxetine and/or fluoxetine; Patients on concomitant use of medications that may potentiate the occurrence of serotonin syndrome (tramadol, citalopram, escitalopram, sertraline, desvenlafaxine, venlafaxine, duloxetine, sibutramine, bupropion, amitriptyline, nortriptyline, lithium); Patients in end-of-life care or with an expected survival of less than 24 hours at the time of eligibility.

The purpose of this single-center randomized controlled trial is to measure the impact of a psycho-education program on the care pathway of patients diagnosed with a moderate depressive episode according to ICD10 criteria. The program will consist of five individual remote sessions.
Inclusion Criteria: Inclusion Criteria: Presenting a depressive episode of moderate intensity according to the DSM-V With a prescription for an antidepressant started less than 2 months before inclusion in the trial. Whose state of health is compatible with follow-up by their GP (possibility of occasional advice from a psychiatrist). Have Internet access at home (computer) and are able to use the digital platform.
Exclusion Criteria: Patients who are unable to complete self-questionnaires (language barrier, etc.) Who have already undergone a psycho-education or therapeutic patient education programme regarding depression. Whose state of health requires follow-up by a psychiatrist.
All subjects, after having signed the consent, will complete the inclusion questionnaires on the digital platform. They are: socio-demographic data; the Hamilton score; the Edinburgh score; the Beck depression scale; the Montgomery-Åsberg score; the General Self-Efficacy scale (GSE); the Barriers to Access to Care (V3 BACE), the SF36 questionnaire; the Client Satisfaction Questionnaire and the WHO Well-Being Index.
The outcome will be assessed at three time points: inclusion, 1 month post inclusion, 6 months post inclusion.
Six months will also be the time frame for all outcomes mentioned in the outcome measures, except the GSE score which will be completed at inclusion and at 3 months.
The main outcome measure will be the maintenance rate on continuous antidepressant treatment at 6 months after inclusion in the study, measured by healthcare reimbursement data. We will use the General Self-Efficacy scale and the barriers questionnaire for additional outcome measures. The two other questionnaires used for the outcome will be completed at inclusion and at 3 months.

This is a pilot, observational, non-interventional study of the Dreem Headband.
Purpose: The objective of the study is to assess the ability of the Dreem Headband to diagnose narcolepsy and demonstrate a response to treatment.
Participants will wear their own Dreem Headband at home for a period of 2 weeks. Each night they will complete a single hour of sleep by wearing the headband and performing a sleep log via the Dreem application. They will return the headband to the investigator for analysis of the sleep data.
A diagnosis of narcolepsy will be made by an investigator using the clinical International Classification of Sleep Disorders 3: Diagnosis and Treatment of Sleep Disorders (ICSD-3). Only the sleep data from the Dreem Headband will be examined to determine whether this method can accurately diagnose narcolepsy.
Participant compliance will be measured by:
The number of hours of sleep as recorded by the Dreem Headband in comparison to the participant supplied sleep log.

The objective of this study is to demonstrate safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of SAR444836, developed by Adverum Biotechnologies, which is a purified, recombinant Human Phenylalanine Hydroxylase (PAH) expressed in AAV-mediated gene transfer. SAR444836 is being administered in a dose escalating manner and will allow for dose estimation to support further development in Phenylketonuria (PKU) patients. Additionally, an expanded cohort will be evaluated on a single, standardized, predefined efficacy dose of SAR444836 to inform selection of optimal therapeutic dose going forward. This will enable the development of therapeutic indications for SAR444836 as an effective treatment option for PKU.

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD) are usually diagnosed by brain MRI, FDG-PET and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for biomarkers (amyloid-beta and tau). The investigators here will analyze if pCASL (pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling) sequences can perform the same role as FDG-PET in MCI and SCD. The investigators will recruit 120 patients with MCI and 10 with SCD and correlate brain perfusion indices and standardized uptake value ratio (SUVr) by pCASL with standardized indices of metabolisms by FDG-PET (SUVr), and CSF profile (Aβ, t-tau and p-tau). The time frame will be 3 years.

<|assistant|> Cardiomyopathy, or heart muscle disease, is a serious condition occurring in patients with Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy where insoluble amyloid protein causes damage to the heart muscle, leading to left ventricular dysfunction or heart failure. Tafamidis, a medicine which stabilizes the damaged protein and prevents it from forming in the body, has been shown to safely reduce the risk of death and hospitalizations related to cardiac events, such as heart failure, in patients at risk in a global population. To further understand the safety of Tafamidis in patients in India and to ensure its continued use for patients with Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy, a post-marketing surveillance study called ATTR-CM VyndaMx® Registry Study (Registry Study) will be conducted. Patients who are already treated with Tafamidis, or about to start treatment with Tafamidis in the course of treatment would be eligible for this registry study. The study aims to enroll up to 600 patients in order to study the number of adverse events or undesirable effects related to the ongoing use of Tafamidis in the population. The investigators would collect data on the number of adverse events while the patients are on tafamidis treatment. The study type is observational and all the patients would be treated with tafamidis as part of routine clinical practice. No additional interventions or treatments would be done as this is not a controlled trial. Therefore the patients would not face any major restrictions or changes in their treatment plans or activities. The study is intended to gain further insights into the safety of tafamidis in the existing population suffering from Transthyretin Amyloid Cardiomyopathy. Patients to whom VyndaMx® Capsules is prescribed for the treatment of wild or hereditary ATTR-CM. Exclusion Criteria: Patient with hypersensitivity to VyndaMx® Capsule or to any of the excipients in the product. Patients with rare hereditary problems of fructose intolerance. Patient who has a contraindication to VyndaMx® Capsules according to the approved local product label. Background: 
Median sternotomy is required as part of many cardiac surgical interventions, such as valve replacement, coronary artery bypass grafting, and heart transplantation. It is associated with serious complications, such as sternal instability and nonunion, especially in patients with risk factors for those conditions. These can result in postoperative pain and limited physical function, prolonged hospital stay, and even re-intervention. Several devices have been developed to secure the sternal closure and prevent complications however they are not widely used mainly due to their cumbersome configuration.
Therefore, the main objective of the study is to compare the safety and efficacy of the STERN FIX sternal closure device, in terms of sternal stabilization, with the standard of care sternal closure method, and to assess both their impact on postoperative pain and patient’s quality of life. 
Methods: 
This multi-center randomized controlled clinical trial will be conducted in 3 Brazilian hospitals. A total of 150 patients will be allocated to one of the two treatment groups:
Group A (intervention) will receive a combination of STERN FIX devices and wires to close the median sternotomy.
Group B (control) will receive the standard of care sternal closure method, only wires.
The primary outcome will be sternal stability, assessed by a dedicated clinical scale during regular patient follow-up. Secondary outcomes will include safety, sternal nonunion or malunion, sternotomy closure time, chest pain, hospital length of stay, blood loss, upper limbs functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union assessment, sternal halves alignment assessment, sternum integrity assessment, sterotomy closure system integrity assessment, among others.
Statistical Analysis: 
A sample of 150 patients, divided into 2 groups (A, B), with 75 patients in each, will be required to obtain a statistical power of 80%, with a significance level of 5%, and an estimated prevalence of main outcomes of approximately 10-15%. A Cox-Mantel chi-square (or Fisher’s exact test) will be used to compare categorical outcomes and the effect-size will be reported as the odds ratio with its 95% confidence interval. Chi-square test will be used for associations between proportions considering a 5% significance level. Continuous data will be compared using Student’s t- or Mann-Whitney U- tests.
Study Impact: 
The results of this study will provide important data regarding the safety and efficacy of a new sternal closure system. If proven efficacious, it may significantly reduce healthcare costs due to fewer revision surgeries, decrease pain and improve quality of life for patients.

Patient with sternal anomalies that, according to the surgeon's opinion, prevent the use of the product, such as bone tumours in the implantation area. Musculoskeletal discomfort, including low back pain (LBP), is one of the most common musculoskeletal disorders and today it is known that the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the prevalence and intensity of LBP. This may be explained by the prolonged sitting time. Most people sit for a long hours in a slumped sitting posture. Prolonged sitting causes changes in the passive structures of the spine and induces a low back compressive load significantly higher than that observed in standing.
Physiotherapists recommend many different sitting positions to prevent and treat negative effects of prolonged sitting. However, there is debate regarding what is an optimal sitting posture. Periodic rest breaks have been identified as a way to reduce self-report discomfort at the low back.
The main goal of this study is to evaluate the effect of active break on reduce LBP and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with LBP. Research outcomes will be developed to match the needs of young people with LBP and the possibilities of the environment and subsequently reduce LBP and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and maintain health and quality of life.

The aim of this study is to evaluate the correlation between hematocrit to haemoglobin ratio (HCT/Hb) and Red blood cell distribution Width (RDW) as markers of disease severity and the expression of erythropoietin in Polycythemia Vera (PV) disease. 150 patients will be selected in the Polycythemia Vera department in Sohag University hospital from December 2022 to September 2023. It will be a prospective analytic study in case and control arm. Patients with secondary erythrocytosis will be included as controls and will be recruited from Sohag university hospital and the control group will consist of 50 subjects. Clinical data will be collected from all patients including the level of hematocrit (HCT) and HAEMATOCRIT TO HAEMOGLOBIN RATIO and Red blood cell distribution Width (RDW). Data analysis will be done by 2 sample independent t test or 1 sample t test. Chi square test will be done to compare the distribution of qualitative variables in both group and compare the mean in each group. In this study a significant increase in Hematocrit to Haemoglobin ratio and increased values of Red blood cell distribution Width (RDW) were observed to be significantly higher in polypoid hyperplasia compared to the nonpolypoid and normal groups that was statistically highly significant. The same increase was observed in the polypoid hyperplasia PV group compared to secondary erythrocytosis non polypoid hyperplasia which was statistically significant. It was concluded that Hematocrit to Haemoglobin Ratio and Red blood cell distribution Width increased in both disease and that the same increase was found in disease polypoid hyperplasia compared to the secondary erythrocytosis non polypoid hyperplasia while there was a highly statistically significant increase in Hematocrit to haemoglobine ratio and significant increase in Red blood cell distribution Width as compared to polypoid hyperplasia.

The relationship between the perfusion index and the emergency triage classification in patients with dyspnea will be examined through the use of the Perfusion Index, which is a non-invasive peripheral perfusion measurement and has a high negative predictive value in the rule-out of acute coronary syndrome.
In the past 5 years many studies have been published in the literature investigating the role of the perfusion rate in the prediction of myocardial injury in the differential diagnostic triad of dyspnea: DIL, pneumonia, acute coronary syndrome. In these studies, Pulse CO-Oximeter is the most widely used non-invasive method to measure the level of end organ perfusion of peripheral tissues. One study published in 2015 showed that at the time of admission to the emergency room, even if the diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome is made, the perfusion levels measured with the pulse CO-Oximeter do not change or decrease. There is no data on the relationship of the perfusion index with the triage classification of patients admitted to the emergency room with signs and symptoms of dyspnea.
Thus, the aim of this study is to determine the effect of perfusion index measurement on the triage status of patients with dyspnea.

End-stage illness is associated with physical, psychological as well as social consequences that often lead to considerable limitations in quality of life (QoL). Palliative care aims to identify and alleviate such limitations with targeted treatment approaches in order to improve QoL and reduce health care costs. Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD), a psychedelic drug, has been proven to improve psychological distress (anxiety, depression), psychological burden and reduce opioid use in healthy subjects or healthy cancer survivors in controlled laboratory studies as well as in terminally ill cancer patients in pilot studies. The present study is designed as a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo-controlled phase II study and aims to estimate the benefit-risk-profile of two low doses of LSD (100 or 200 μg oral solution) applied in two sessions over a distance of two weeks compared with an active placebo in subjects with physical deterioration in their last phase of life. The design includes a main efficacy endpoint - changes in state anxiety assessed by questionnaire (state anxiety inventory, STAI-S) compared with active placebo - as well as a number of secondary efficacy endpoints, such as changes in pain level, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, QoL as well as changes in psychological distress assessed using questionnaires, qualitative interview, and psychometric rating scales. Moreover, the study includes patient's behaviour and attitudes rated by community observers, caregiver burden, adverse events, and measures recording acute effects of LSD as well as psychological changes after both acute and after long-lasting treatment effects.
Furthermore, a comprehensive collection of safety measures, such as vital signs, physical and general discomfort, as well as a detailed assessment of the participants' social situations are monitored. The investigators expect that in subjects with physical deterioration in the last phase of life, low doses of LSD - if administered in a safe and controlled fashion in a medical environment under supervision of specialized medical staff - may be an efficient and safe treatment option that can improve the psychological health of these individuals, leading to a better QoL, a reduction in the caregivers’ burden and an increase in end-of-life satisfaction. The present study will provide important valuable information for clinical practice.

Pregnancy is a period during which one's daily habits, including diet, physical activity, tobacco use, and other behaviours that can impact prenatal care attendance can change to affect maternal and infant outcomes. The text-based app SmartMom, used in the first study, aims to improve prenatal care attendance and promote healthy behaviours during pregnancy. SmartMom provides evidence-based information about the importance of specific health behaviours for pregnancy, and it has successfully improved prenatal care attendance and birth outcomes in a previous study. However, its content may not fully address all healthy behaviours and topics of interest for all pregnant persons. Therefore, it is unclear whether additional text streams tailored to specific needs would further improve maternal and infant outcomes.
The investigators aim to test an expanded version of SmartMom that includes five (5) additional streams of content to address specific concerns: mental health (in particular postpartum depression), excessive weight gain, older age at the time of birth, excessive alcohol use, and use of prescription opioids and non-prescription pain medication in the third trimester. The investigators will compare the expanded SmartMom intervention to a placebo-like control program and to the standard SmartMom program.
The investigators aim to conduct a follow-up study to a previously reported trial. Participants in the current study will receive one of three text-based programs: standard SmartMom messaging, expanded SmartMom messaging, or control messaging. The investigators will conduct a mixed-methods, randomized, controlled trial of 3200 patients with a singleton pregnancy at 15 weeks or earlier. SmartMom and control text messages will be sent to participants three times per week from the beginning of pregnancy until 38 weeks of gestation; expanded SmartMom text messages will be sent beginning at 20 weeks of gestation in participants with a higher-than-minimal BMI, postpartum depression symptomatology, prescription opioid or anti-inflammatory use, older maternal age, and excessive alcohol use in the previous 3 months. The investigators will evaluate the differences in primary and secondary outcomes between the groups.
